FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Trans-Canada Highway</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, near </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> on Highway 59, or near Steinbach on Highways 12 and 52. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Things weren't much better in the city. Manitoba Public Insurance was expecting about 600 collision claims by the end of yesterday, spokesman Brian Smiley said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That's a far cry from the previous Tuesday, when 383 claims were filed in the city. More accident claims caused by yesterday's stormy weather will likely be filed in the next few days, Smiley said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The storm forced snow plows to make a rare May appearance on city streets. Crews were expected to work late into the night salting bridges and major streets, said Bob McDonald, the city's public works spokesman. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's very unusual," McDonald said of the storm. "It's not unheard of but fortunately it's quite rare." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The estimated cost of yesterday's cleanup was $150,000, pushing the city's snow-clearing budget further into the red for the year. The city dipped into the snow-clearing reserve account to cover the cost of yesterday's cleanup, said McDonald. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The weather system is expected to stick around until the weekend, with temperatures hovering around 0 C, said </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Anderson</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. He joked that Manitobans should take the crummy weather as an opportunity to dust off their winter sports equipment. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I haven't seen any skis out there yet but it's pretty sloppy for that. I'm sure there will be a few snowmen around," said </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Anderson</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-TRANSFORM: uppercase; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-TRANSFORM: uppercase; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 6-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Fined for driving into lake: Booze-Fuelled cruise costs motorist $800
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> man was fined $800 yesterday for a booze-fuelled beachfront cruise that sent his car to the bottom of </SPAN><st1:place><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Falcon</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lake</SPAN></st1:PlaceType></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. Ian James Darbell, 21, was driving his 1989 BMW near the lake's campground and boat launch on </SPAN><st1:date Month="8" Day="22" Year="2002"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Aug. 22, 2002</SPAN></st1:date><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. After failing to negotiate a simple left turn at the end of the roadway, he drove the vehicle -- and its two passengers -- directly into the water. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"They came to rest about 60 metres from the shoreline, and the car began sinking immediately," Manitoba Public Insurance spokesman Brian Smiley said yesterday. "When the police arrived, they found a wine bottle and beer cans floating around the vehicle." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Despite the bottles and cans, the smell of alcohol, and a subsequent admission from Darbell, cops didn't think they had enough evidence to prove he was driving, so a breathalyser test was never administered. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">MPI continued to investigate the matter and eventually found a number of witnesses who placed Darbell in the driver's seat. He was charged with impaired driving eight months later, on </SPAN><st1:date Month="4" Day="29" Year="2003"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">April 29, 2003</SPAN></st1:date><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The case went to trial in Steinbach last month, and Darbell was found guilty yesterday, Smiley said. He was handed an $800 fine and his driver's licence was suspended for a year. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ironically, Darbell sued MPI following the incident for failing to pay him the $8,500 insurance claim on his vehicle. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Smiley said MPI was withholding payment pending the outcome of their investigation, noting Darbell's conviction makes the lawsuit a moot point. Neither of Darbell's passengers were injured in the incident.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 7-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Local briefs: St.Laurent eyes photo radar
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Another </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Manitoba</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> community is considering photo radar. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The Rural Municipality of St. Laurent has told the province it's interested in using the traffic enforcement technology to nab speedsters along a winding portion of Highway 6. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The speed limit on the stretch of Interlake road drops to 60 km/h from 100 km/h. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The RCMP monitor as much as they can, but I think it's common for people to go through there way too fast," said St. Laurent Coun. Hugh Sigurdson, who sits on the RM's transportation committee. "It is a safety concern." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Transportation Minister Ron Lemieux said the RM may be out of luck if it wants photo radar on the highway. Under provincial law, the technology is permitted only in school zones, construction zones and at controlled intersections. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Currently, we're not looking at expanding that," Lemieux said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Several other communities are interested in photo radar, including the </SPAN><st1:place><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">RM</SPAN></st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> of </SPAN><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">West St. Paul</SPAN></st1:PlaceName></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> and </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Brandon</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lemieux said the Doer government is working on an application process for communities interested in the technology. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, six mobile enforcement vans equipped with photo radar nab speeders in construction zones, as well as by schools and playgrounds. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">There are another 24 red-light cameras. By 2007, there will be 30 cameras in </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, rotated through 60 intersections. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><BR style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always; mso-special-character: line-break" clear=all></SPAN>

Title: 8-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: May in manitoba! Roads And Schools Closed, Jets Grounded, Power Out
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, Mb    Free Press    May.12/04    Page A1/A4
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: By Kevin Rollason and Aldo Santin
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">IT'S an unofficial record -- </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'s largest single snowfall in May fell yesterday, and more is coming today. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Environment </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Canada</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> said between 20 and 25 centimetres of snow fell across </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> yesterday, likely beating the record of 21.1 cm that fell </SPAN><st1:date Month="5" Day="1" Year="1967"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">May 1, 1967</SPAN></st1:date><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We don't have data yet for the airport but unofficially this could be the greatest May snowstorm we've ever had," meteorologist Rob Paola said late last night. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Paola said we can expect another miserable day today, with up to another 10 cm of snow and winds gusting up to 60 km/h. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Across southern Manitoba yesterday, cars slid into ditches, highways including the Trans-Canada were closed, airlines cancelled flights, power outages dotted the province, schools were closed and broken branches littered roadways. Amazingly, however, there were no reports of serious injuries. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Environment </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Canada</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> left its heavy snowfall warning in effect overnight, calling for another two to five centimetres of freezing rain or ice pellets.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"You have a combination of heavy snow, zero visibility and then you're hearing thunder -- it's a forecaster's nightmare," said Jay Anderson, Environment Canada's warning preparedness meteorologist. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The scene was repeated right across the southern Prairies and into northwestern </SPAN><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ontario</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, which had been hit hard by a weather condition known as a Colorado Low that hung in over the area longer than expected. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Cathie Crossin said the drive from her home in Shilo to her </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Brandon</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> office yesterday morning "was the most treacherous driving of the winter. It took me twice as long to get there. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We've got so much snow (falling) outside my window it looks like a snow globe." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">If there was a silver lining to that thick cloud cover, it's that farm fields can use the moisture. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It looks bad because of the white covering but it's more of a benefit than a hindrance," John Hollinger, a provincial agronomist with Manitoba Agriculture, said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Hollinger said farmers will be happy for the moisture, no matter what form it comes in. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We wish it was a lot warmer but we're happy with the moisture," Hollinger said, adding cereal crops won't be damaged by the snow. Some seeding may be delayed, he said, but it's still early. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-TRANSFORM: uppercase; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'Back in fields'</SPAN></B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-TRANSFORM: uppercase; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"With lighter soils, they'll be back in the fields on the weekend." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Trans-Canada Highway</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> from Virden to Ignace, Ont. was closed for the better part of yesterday afternoon, as was Hwy. 10 from Minnedosa to the </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">U.S.</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> border. Segments of both highways were opened up by late in the afternoon. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's probably the latest we've closed the Trans-Canada," said Manitoba Highways spokesman Neil Gobelle. "I don't recall closing the highway this late because of blizzard conditions." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">RCMP Cpl. Larry Dalman said there were several collisions in the first few hours of the storm, including a semi-trailer jackknifing but there had been no injuries. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Road conditions on the </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Perimeter Highway</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> were worse last night than they had been during the day and police were advising motorists not to use it. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Dalman said people should plan on leaving for work early today to get through the predicted weather conditions. Winnipeg Police Service Const. Shelly Glover said officers dealt with 20 motor-vehicle collisions during the day but there were probably an untold number of minor collisions that hadn't yet been reported. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Glover said a collision on the northbound lanes of the Disraeli Freeway near </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Main Street</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> at about </SPAN><st1:time Hour="14" Minute="30"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">2:30 p.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> required police to close those lanes for part of the afternoon while damaged vehicles were cleared . Glover said there were no serious injuries there or anywhere else in the city yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Glover said there were numerous reports of snow-laden branches falling on vehicles and blocking roadways and at least four intersections were without traffic lights for part of the day. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Manitoba Hydro spokesman Jim Peters said the snow caused problems on power lines throughout the city and province. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The weather is wreaking havoc," Peters said. "It is collecting on tree branches and causing the branches to fall on or go against the power lines." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Branches falling on power lines caused problems across southern </SPAN><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Manitoba</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. The largest power outage occurred in </SPAN><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">East Kildonan</SPAN></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> when about 4,000 customers were without power late in the morning. Outages were reported in Hartney, Deloraine, </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">St. Pierre</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, </SPAN><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Souris</SPAN></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, Minto, Cartwright and Birtle. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Businesses along the Trans-Canada near </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Brandon</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> were without power for about three hours. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Numerous flights in and out of </SPAN><st1:place><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">International</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Airport</SPAN></st1:PlaceType></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> were cancelled yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Christine Alongi, spokeswoman for the Winnipeg Airports Authority, said </SPAN><st1:date Month="4" Day="5" Year="1997"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">April 5, 1997</SPAN></st1:date><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, had been the latest date when flights were cancelled due to snow. Alongi said snow-plow crews at the airport concentrated their efforts keeping one runway open. She said at least one Air </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Canada</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> flight had been redirected to </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Thunder Bay</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> while a flight from </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Chicago</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> was diverted to </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Grand Forks</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">WestJet cancelled all of its flights in and out of </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Brandon</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, 1,700 students had to find their own way home after the school division pulled their buses off the road in the afternoon. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The Southwest Horizon school division and the Western school division cancelled buses and closed their schools yesterday. The </SPAN><st1:place><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Turtle</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Mountain</SPAN></st1:PlaceType></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> and Beautiful Plains school divisions also cancelled afternoon bus service.</SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 9-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teenagers and teetotalling
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Toronto, On  National Post  May.12/04    Page A17
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Alberta MLA Barry McFarland has concluded that too many 18 year olds are drinking and driving. But he can't take away all their driver's licences, so he's come up with the next best solution: getting </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Alberta</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> in synch with seven other provinces by boosting its drinking age to 19.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">If only life were that simple. The reality is that Canadian teenagers will find ways to get alcohol no matter what age limit we put on its purchase. So the real question isn't whether there's a way to stop them from drinking, but whether there's a way to make them drink responsibly.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The answer, in part, is to make it less of a dangerous taboo. And to do that, you need to stop pretending that it's abnormal or outrageous to drink before you're 19.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">My parents were young children when they immigrated from </SPAN><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Europe</SPAN></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, but they somehow took the </SPAN><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Old World</SPAN></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'s sophisticated approach to alcohol with them. So when I was a teenager, if I wanted a small amount of beer or wine, it wasn't considered a big deal. And in turn, I didn't consider alcohol a convenient way of acting out.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">When I was 14 or 15, and my friends would sneak to a local park to down a couple of beers they'd managed to pilfer from their parents' fridge, it all seemed a little silly to me. When you're able to have the occasional glass of wine at home, there's nothing particularly thrilling about skulking around a playground drinking Labatt Blue.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Later on, when we were drinking more heavily, I was able to do so more responsibly because I didn't have to keep it a big secret. I suppose it wouldn't have gone over real well if I'd stumbled in the door falling-down drunk. But if I'd had a few drinks, I could do the safe, smart thing -- take transit home, or crash with a friend -- without having to go through some elaborate charade to keep it hidden.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Because I was treated like an adult, I acted like an adult. But the kids who were more overprotected were often the ones who acted out the most. And to make matters worse, their parents were powerless to do much about it because they were completely oblivious.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The higher the drinking age, the easier it is for them to stay oblivious. South of the border, I'm sure there are parents who think their college-age kids are waiting until their magical 21st birthdays to crack one open.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">At least our laws aren't that delusional. But they're still more conservative than they need to be. I'm not suggesting we let 15 year olds into bars (I'm certainly not dying to trip over them every time I go out). But 19 is just too old.</SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 10-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: DRIVER WILL FACE CHARGE - POLICE: Fatal Portage Crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The man accused of being the driver involved in a fatal crash last week on Portage Avenue will be charged -- but not until his condition improves, police said yesterday. "Due to his condition, they (Division 11 officers) haven't had a chance to arrest him and formally charge him," said Winnipeg police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">PASSENGER KILLED <o:p></o:p></SPAN></B></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">No condition report was available yesterday for the 27-year-old man, who was identified by sources as Pedro Maldonado. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Passenger Shauntelle Elizabeth Roulette, 20, of 368 Anderson Ave., was killed when the eastbound Pontiac Grand Prix jumped a median and demolished a stone planter, a fire hydrant and a tree, before hitting George Richards Big &amp; Tall Menswear, a men's clothing store at 1295 Portage Ave., about 1:45 a.m. last Friday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Roulette was sitting in the front passenger seat. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver, who was ejected during the horrific crash that occurred between Clifton Street and Valour Road, was taken to Health Sciences Centre in critical condition. He was later upgraded to stable. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A second passenger, a 25-year-old man, was treated at HSC for minor injuries and later released. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Witnesses were amazed that anyone walked away from the crumpled wreck. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">An investigator told The Sun yesterday that "speed appeared to be a factor" in the early-morning collision. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It was unknown whether alcohol also played a role. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Roulette's next of kin couldn't be reached for comment yesterday.</SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 11-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: A may day record: Most Snow During 24-Hour Period
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>If you thought it was a lot of snow, you're right. Between Tuesday and yesterday, Winnipeg broke a 37-year-old record for snowfall in a 24-hour period in May. Unofficially, the storm dumped 21.8 centimetres at the measuring station at Winnipeg International Airport -- besting the previous record of 21.1 centimetres set on May 1, 1967.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>In total, the storm dumped 31 centimetres of snow in roughly 30 hours at the airport. Between 25 and 30 centimetres of snow was recorded in St. Boniface by yesterday morning. About 28 centimetres had fallen in Charleswood and Headingley, said Environment Canada meteorologist Jay Anderson.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The snow wreaked havoc with motorists, particularly those who needed to travel outside Winnipeg. The Trans-Canada Highway westbound from Winnipeg to Virden near the Saskatchewan boundary was to remain closed until at least this morning.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN lang=EN-CA><STRONG>LINE OF SEMI-TRAILERS   <P></P></STRONG></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The highway closure created a line of parked semi-trailer drivers nearly five-km long on the outskirts of Winnipeg. Many of the drivers had been stranded since Tuesday.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"They're backed up as far as the eye can see," said John Ganas, who was kept busy filling coffee cups for weary drivers at Nick's Inn on the edge of the city.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>In Virden, the junior high school was turned into an emergency shelter for stranded travellers.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Trucks and motorists were also stranded in Brandon when Highway 10 to the United States border was closed.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>During the worst of the storm Tuesday, 16 hardy Winnipeggers made pit-stops for hot fudge sundaes and ice cream cones at the Bridge Drive-In.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"There were some diehards," said manager Roger Brisebois, who keeps a daily tally of customers and temperature. "They say they had to come because there's no lineup."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>On the same day last year, staff served 700 customers as the mercury rose to 22 C.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The snow tapered off in Winnipeg yesterday -- turning to ice pellets and freezing rain -- but the low was still hovering about -4 C. Another two to five centimetres of precipitation was expected to hit the city as the system pulled away, Anderson said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>A mix of sun and cloud today will help melt the snow but normal May temperatures aren't expected until the weekend, Anderson said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN lang=EN-CA><STRONG>CAA KEPT BUSY   <P></P></STRONG></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Yesterday, CAA crews were kept busy pulling vehicles out of deep snow and towing stalled cars, said spokeswoman Jeanie Dalman. At one point, 90% of calls stemmed from windshield wipers that broke when motorists tried to clear the wet, heavy snow.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Winnipeg International Airport returned to normal yesterday afternoon, after many flights had been delayed, cancelled or diverted a day earlier, said Christine Alongi of the Winnipeg Airports Authority.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The weather also brought down power lines. Some homeowners in Brandon, Elie and Carman were without power yesterday while crews cleared ice and repaired downed lines.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>There were scattered outages throughout the city on Tuesday, including one in East Kildonan that affected 4,000 customers.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"Certainly some people are without power today but things have improved substantially," a Manitoba Hydro spokesman said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Snow clearing for the storm cost about $150,000, said the city's public works spokesman Bob McDonald.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Heavy rain fell in Kenora yesterday as precipitation was expected to reach 100 millimetres. The Ontario Provincial Police were kept hopping with collisions and vehicles stuck in the snow but no serious injuries were reported.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Nearly 40 millimetres of rain and snow was recorded in Emerson by yesterday morning.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 12-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Storm crippled trucking industry across canada: Stuck In Bottleneck
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>Manitoba took the brunt of the spring storm this week, but the impact has been felt from one end of the country to the other. The snowstorm that has closed down the Trans-Canada Highway between Headingley and the Saskatchewan boundary for much of the past two days also crippled the country's trucking industry, said Bob Dolyniuk of the Manitoba Trucking Association.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN lang=EN-CA><STRONG>HUNDREDS SHUT DOWN   <P></P></STRONG></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"It's not just this province that's affected, you've got trucks going from one side of this country to the other that are waiting (for the stretch of highway to re-open)," he said. "You're talking about hundreds of trucks being shut down in Winnipeg, Brandon and Portage la Prairie -- that   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN>comes with a very significant cost for companies and drivers."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The Trans-Canada, closed by Mounties because of poor visibility and road conditions, was expected to re-open this morning.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The highway, specifically between Headingley and Portage la Prairie, has been closed many times during the past few winters because of weather conditions.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Trees have been planted along the highway in the hopes of insulating it from storms like the one this week.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Dolyniuk said that more needs to be done in the short term to help the trucking industry cope with closures and the costs they create.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 13-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car thieves slam cab while fleeing police: Chase Was Called Off
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>A Unicity cabbie and his wife were sent to hospital with minor injuries early yesterday morning after a stolen Dodge Intrepid slammed head-on into their taxi. Police, who had aborted a high-speed chase with the car moments earlier, rounded up four suspected teenage thieves as they tried to flee the wreckage near the McPhillips Street underpass.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Unicity general manager Adrian Peters said the taxi driver, who was driving his wife to work at Health Sciences Centre just prior to starting his shift, had no time to get out of the way of the oncoming stolen car.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"There's not much any driver can do," Peters said, adding the taxi was totalled.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The early-morning drama began about 5:50 a.m., when officers in a patrolling cruiser spotted the Intrepid in the area of Home Street and Notre Dame Avenue in the West End.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN lang=EN-CA><STRONG>ABORTED   <P></P></STRONG></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"Almost immediately, the stolen auto rammed the police car in an attempt to disable it, then took off west on Notre Dame at a high rate of speed," said Winnipeg police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The cruiser began to pursue the car, which turned north on McPhillips.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>But after the officers broadcast the traffic and road conditions to the police communications centre, the duty inspector aborted the chase for safety reasons, Johnson said, adding police had been in pursuit for only 32 seconds before it was called off.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"It was just enough time for them to broadcast road conditions and weather conditions and that was the end of it," he said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Although the officers were forced to stop, the Intrepid sped northbound on McPhillips.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"Officers could see that it had entered the southbound lanes just north of Logan Avenue and just at the crest of the underpass it came into a head-on collision with a taxi," Johnson said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Two men, a boy and a girl ran. The girl appeared to have a broken ankle and didn't make it very far before police arrested her, a witness said. The three males were also soon corralled. The boy and the girl required treatment at hospital for broken bones.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Meanwhile, the cabbie and his wife were taken to HSC in stable condition.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>A witness said the taxi driver appeared to be in a state of shock and was favouring his neck. Paramedics later fitted him with a neck brace.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Jared Schaffer, 19, has been charged with driving while suspended, possession of goods obtained by crime, flight from police and dangerous operation of a motor vehicle causing bodily harm.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Three others -- 18-year-old Eric Wirfell, a 17-year-old boy, and a 16-year-old girl -- were charged with joyriding. Wirfell and the male youth also face charges relating to breaches of probation.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 14-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cops cautious about pursuits
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>Abandoning a high-speed vehicle chase -- like the one yesterday morning on McPhillips Street -- is common, police said yesterday. "We abort a fairly large number in the interest of public safety," Winnipeg police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson told The Sun yesterday.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The decision to call off a police pursuit is made by the duty inspector and it depends on factors such as road and weather conditions, and the time of day.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We discontinue the pursuit at that point. We're not following the vehicle at higher speeds. Generally, the officers will shut off their emergency equipment," Johnson said. "The idea is to get the whole situation to decelerate, particularly the vehicle that's being chased, to send a clear message that we're no longer chasing them."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>But that doesn't always mean the suspects will slow down.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"Many times the people that are being chased are not even looking back, don't even know that we've aborted the chase," Johnson said ... Their goal is to get away either way and don't often slow down."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 15-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Punks lay waste to garbage fleet: Civic Recycling Trucks Vandalized
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>Vandals smashed windows and busted the radiators of most of the city's fleet of recycling trucks this week, causing thousands of dollars in damage -- and major headaches for garbage officials. "I call it wanton destruction with no purpose," said City of Winnipeg manager of solid waste services Dan McInnis.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"It's very unfortunate."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN lang=EN-CA><STRONG>RENDERED INOPERABLE   <P></P></STRONG></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>A civic employee arrived at work about 6:30 a.m. yesterday and discovered the destruction on the fleet of 23 recycling collection trucks, which were parked inside a building, McInnis said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>He did not want to divulge their exact location for security reasons.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>McInnis said the culprits busted into the compound, punctured the vehicles' radiators with some sort of implement and broke many windows.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>In total, at least 16 of the trucks -- just purchased new by the city last September -- were rendered inoperable.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>McInnis said he's never heard of such damage being inflicted on city equipment before.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"I've been here five years and this is the first time I've actually really experienced it," he said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>City officials frantically tried to track down replacement parts for the trucks and organize repairs yesterday.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>McInnis said at least four garbage trucks were re-assigned to recycling duty and crews were going to be putting in some "big time" overtime to pick up as much material as possible.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>He wasn't sure if crews were going to be able to get to all the households that work on a Day 3 schedule, and he asked Winnipeggers to keep their blue boxes out and be patient until the trash can be collected.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"I think they'll be quite late into the night," McInnis said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We're trying to keep the service up as much as we can."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Manitoba Public Insurance spokesman Brian Smiley said MPI has spent more than $18 million on vandalism repairs since 2002. Nearly 16,000 claims were submitted to the agency in 2003, and MPI racked up 3,000 claims in March and April of this year alone.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 16-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: City hall briefs: Truck-route decision delayed
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>Residents of Transcona's Plessis Road may not get rid of large, loud transport trucks as easily as they had hoped.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>City hall's executive policy committee voted yesterday to delay a decision on shifting a truck route off Plessis and through the St. Boniface Industrial Park, choosing to have bureaucrats study the matter further.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>A public works committee had endorsed the truck route shift to appease dozens of homeowners who fear for their children's safety.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30- </SPAN></P>

Title: 17-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cops nab big stash: Truck Packed With Grass
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>Cops sniffed out nearly half a million dollars worth of marijuana hidden in a truck Tuesday morning, after they pulled the driver over for speeding. The weed -- about 31 1/2 kilograms -- was stashed away in "secret compartments," according to police.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We're not about to instruct people on how to hide them (bags of pot), so we're not going to talk about where they all were, but they were quite professionally done," said Winnipeg police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson. "Police have had some experience with similar vehicles in the past. So it's getting to the point where we know where to look for the stuff."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The truck, an eastbound 1995 Ford pickup with Ontario licence plates, was clocked travelling "well over the speed limit" on Portage Avenue near the Perimeter about 8 a.m., when it was stopped, Johnson said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Officers soon became suspicious of an odour coming from the truck and got the occupants' permission to search the vehicle, Johnson said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN lang=EN-CA><STRONG>NO GANG LINKS   <P></P></STRONG></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Besides the marijuana, police also seized $600 cash.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Police weren't certain where the weed originated, or where it was destined.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The driver Choi Van Nguyen, 40, of Kitchener, Ont., and his passenger To Van Nguyen, 39, of Vancouver, were charged with possession of a controlled substance for the purpose of trafficking and trafficking in a controlled substance.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Despite their Asian names, there was no indication that the suspects had ties to any Asian-based criminal organizations, police said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 18-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: When will spring return? It Had Better Be Soon For Trapped Truckers
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, Mb     Free Press         May.13/04     Page A1/A4
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: By Aldo Santin, Jason Bell And David Kuxhaus
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>THE freak storm that buried the southern Prairies from Calgary to Kenora under heavy, wet snow for two days finally petered out last night.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>As Winnipeggers started to dig out from a record May snowfall, hundreds of motorists stranded along the Trans-Canada Highway expected the end of the storm will let them get moving this morning.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Environment Canada meteorologist Jay Anderson said the last wisps of snow and freezing rain should have fallen overnight. There's no snow or rain in the forecast for the next few days, he said, but the sky will still be gloomy.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"There's a lot of snow on the ground and that's going to keep the thermometer in the single digits for the next few days," Anderson said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"It'll be foggy, cloudy and damp for the next few days."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>He said Winnipeg officially received 31 centimetres of snow Tuesday, breaking the previous record of 21.6 cm on May 1, 1967 as the greatest amount of snow for one day in May. But he said Kenora received more snow and rain, a total of 80 mm, compared to 30 mm of precipitation in Winnipeg. Large amounts of rainfall were also recorded in Morden (51.2 mm) and Emerson (41 mm).   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Temperatures in Winnipeg today should hit 4 C and are expected to get as warm as 10 tomorrow and Saturday. Earlier forecasts called for warmer weather tomorrow, but Anderson said the long-range forecast originates out of Montreal and staff there are not aware of the lingering snow that will cool temperatures.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The end of the storm is good news for Winnipeg resident Joanne Miller and her father, Leslie, who spend last night sleeping in the gym of the Virden Junior High School, along with 60 other Greyhound bus passengers.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"They said the highway could reopen (this morning) or later this afternoon but we're hoping for the morning," Miller said last night during a telephone interview.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>In Virden, 300 semi-trailer trucks were lined up four-lanes wide in a four-kilometre stretch. It was a scene repeated at the other end of the Trans-Canada, at Headingley, where west-bound trucks sat bumper to bumper for three kilometres between John Blumberg Golf Course and the Headingley weigh station.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>West-bound truckers and other vehicles were also reported stranded near Portage la Prairie, Austin, Brandon and near the Saskatchewan border.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Don Scribner, leaning back in the driver's seat, his feet up on the huge dashboard, said he'd never seen such a long lineup in more than 30 years of truck driving. "This is the worst I've seen in 34 years," said Scribner, en route from Steinbach to Brandon for Big Freight Systems Inc. "The snow plows were just riding up on top of the slush and couldn't clear anything out."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Improving road conditions permitted the opening yesterday of the eastbound lane from Portage to Winnipeg. However, RCMP weren't allowing traffic to go the other way because they feared traffic would get bottled up in Portage.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Several long-haul truckers were critical of the provincial Highways Department, who they said were waiting for Mother Nature rather than using snow plows.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"You go through the Rockies out in Alberta and B.C. where they have plenty of blizzards and you don't see this," Mel Prince, of Kelowna, said while waiting at Nick's Inn in Headingley. "Maintaining the roads, they just don't do it here. Manitoba and Saskatchewan are the worst."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Clayton Gording, vice-president of operations for Reimer Express Lines Ltd., said the province seemed to be slow in getting plows out.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"There seems to be a reluctance to clean the roads," said Gording. "They seem to be waiting for it to melt."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Meanwhile, it was nearly business as usual at the Winnipeg International Airport, where flights in and out of Winnipeg were back on schedule.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>A number of flights had been cancelled Tuesday.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN lang=EN-CA>Phones were ringing off the hook at many Winnipeg tree removal companies as the heavy, wet snow felled trees and snapped off branches. "On every street, there are tree limbs down somewhere," said Greg Lajoie, owner of Allpro Tree Service. "I've never seen anything like this before."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The blast of snow and freezing rain is unlikely to cause flooding in southern Manitoba, according to the province's water stewardship department.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The department anticipates the moisture will easily soak into the soil. Only minor rises were expected on the Red and Assiniboine rivers.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Snowfall warnings were lifted for the Brandon area last night but remained in place for Dauphin and Swan River.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The storm caught just about everyone by surprise. Staff at the Westgate Inn Motel in Portage had to turn people away when the storm first hit.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We were full up," said manager Rollande Roberge. "Some of the people staying work in Portage but live in Winnipeg and couldn't get home."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Cpl. Larry Dalman of Headingley Traffic Services said the safety of motorists far outweighed the inconvenience to drivers.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"If we allowed traffic through and if collisions occur, we're not doing our job," Dalman said. "Our job is to protect the motoring public. But you expect the odd grumbling at the barricade."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Bob Dolyniuk, general manager of the Manitoba Trucking Association, said his office was flooded with calls yesterday from frustrated members. He said part of the problem is it's not clear under what conditions snow plows are allowed to go out and clean the highway.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P align=right><I><SPAN><A HREF="/News/ClippingsAdmin/mailtAldo.santin@freepress.mb,ca">Aldo.santin@freepress.mb,ca</A>   <P></P></SPAN></I>  <P></P>  <P align=right><I><SPAN><A HREF="/News/ClippingsAdmin/mailtJason.bell@freepress.mb.ca">Jason.bell@freepress.mb.ca</A>   <P></P></SPAN></I>  <P></P>  <P align=right><I><SPAN><A HREF="/News/ClippingsAdmin/mailtDavid.kuxhaus@freepress.mb.ca">David.kuxhaus@freepress.mb.ca</A>   <P></P></SPAN></I>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 19-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Veterans’ licence plates under study: NDP Not Ruling Out Tory Idea
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb     Free Press         May.13/04     Page A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>TORY MLA Ralph Eichler is asking the Manitoba legislature to recognize Manitoba's veterans with a special licence plate.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>He introduced Bill 211 in the legislature yesterday to allow for Manitoba to make and distribute licence plates with a poppy on them, similar to those already in existence in Ontario and New Brunswick.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Eichler said veterans need to be recognized.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"Golly, they made life what it is today," he said. "We have our freedom because of them."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Transportation Minister Ron Lemieux said he hadn't seen the bill yet but said he knows veterans have been talking about something like this for some time.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"I want to take a look at the legislation and see what they're putting forward," Lemieux said. "I'm going to look into it. I'm not dismissing it." In Ontario, the veterans' licence plate is available at no cost to those who served in wartime in the Canadian Armed Forces, allied forces, Merchant Navy or Ferry Command, who served a minimum of three years in the Canadian Armed Forces, or who performed NATO service in a peacekeeping mission as a member of the Canadian Armed Forces, a UN peacekeeping force or the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Harold Bastable, a D-Day veteran of the Royal Canadian Air Force during the Second World War, isn't quite convinced this is a good idea.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Bastable said he would like to see the use of veteran licence plates restricted to what he calls "true" veterans -- those who actually served in a war or a peacekeeping mission for Canada.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P align=right><I><SPAN><A HREF="/News/ClippingsAdmin/mailtmia.rabson@freepress.mb.ca">mia.rabson@freepress.mb.ca</A>   <P></P></SPAN></I>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30- </SPAN></P>

Title: 20-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Recycling Firm Trashed: Trucks Vanalized, Pickup Delayed After Break - In At Planet
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb     Free Press         May.13/04         Page B1/B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>RECYCLING in Winnipeg suffered a blow yesterday when vandals trashed trucks used by the private company that collects the city's recyclables.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Vandals broke into International Paper Industries Ltd.'s garage on Henry Avenue and smashed the windshields on 16 of the company's 23 trucks.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>IPI's general manager Jim Moore could only shake his head in disgust as he looked at the damaged trucks.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We didn't need quite this aggravation, especially with the weather," Moore said yesterday.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"It's disheartening. These are $200,000 brand-new units that we have a lot of pride in. We have a contract to help the citizens of Winnipeg.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We don't know if it's a random bit of violence or what." Moore said the break-in and damage were done sometime between 11 p.m. Tuesday and yesterday at 6 a.m.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Moore said the company was supposed to pick up recyclables from 30,000 residences yesterday, but the vandalism put them behind. He doesn't know when all the trucks will be back in service.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The city even pressed four garbage trucks into service to help collect the recyclables, but it's expected recyclable collection will be delayed for the next several days.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"If people see their recyclables being picked up by a garbage truck, don't worry," said Dan McInnes, the city's solid waste services division manager.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We're asking people to leave their blue boxes out until they're picked up."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Winnipeg police Const. Shelly Glover said police are investigating the vandalism. "We do have some significant pieces of evidence that we will be testing," Glover said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Meanwhile, McInnes said the city is being kept abreast on the status of several lawsuits filed against the recycling company.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We're not worried," McInnes said, noting they're mostly disputes over payments for construction work. "Our contract is not in jeopardy. They're doing an absolutely fantastic job."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Last year, the North Vancouver-based IPI was awarded a 14-year, $41.6-million contract to collect, separate, and sell the city's recyclables.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The company's recycling plant is located at a former garbage-incineration plant on Henry Avenue, which the city sold to IPI for $1 last year.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Since the beginning of the year, various contracting companies have launched lawsuits against the recycling company for allegedly not paying for services. The companies are: B and L Welding Ltd., for $45,342; 4788029 Manitoba Ltd. and 42952111 Manitoba Ltd. for $180,000; and Pritchard Engineering Co. Ltd., for $108,991.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Pritchard Engineering has also filed a lien on the property for $106,642.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>In another statement of claim, Ray Rybachuk is suing the company for $41,000 for wrongful dismissal.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Two other lawsuits have been discontinued in recent weeks: one launched by McCaine Electric Ltd., for $115,794, and another by R. Litz and Sons Co. Ltd., for $73,440. Moore would not comment about the lawsuits.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>A spokesperson at IPI's head office in North Vancouver could not be reached for comment.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN><A HREF="/News/ClippingsAdmin/mailtkevin.rollason@freepress.mb.ca">kevin.rollason@freepress.mb.ca</A>   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 21-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen car crashes head-on into taxi: Two In Cab, Two In Speeding Vehicle Injured
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb         Free Press         May.13/04         Page B8
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>A stolen car, speeding north on McPhillips Street in the wrong lane, smashed head-on into a Unicity taxi early yesterday, sending a cab driver and passenger to hospital in stable condition, police said yesterday.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Const. Bob Johnson said the collision happened at about 6 a.m. just seconds after police aborted a pursuit of the stolen Dodge Intrepid.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Johnson said the stolen car sped north from Logan Avenue and hit the taxi at the crest of the CPR underpass. Four males -- two adults and two youths -- were in the stolen car.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>He said the chase started moments earlier after the stolen car rammed a patrol car near on Notre Dame Avenue near Home Street in an attempt to disable the police car.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The stolen car then sped west on Notre Dame, running a red light at Arlington Street, and turned north on McPhillips, but in the south-bound lane. The car continued speeding north past the intersection on William Avenue.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Johnson said when an officer in the patrol car radioed in that driving conditions on McPhillips were wet, a senior officer called off the pursuit. It had only lasted 32 seconds with speeds reaching about 80 km/h. He said police chases are routinely aborted because the risk to the public is too great.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The cabbie and a passenger were taken to the Health Sciences Centre in stable condition.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Two males in the stolen car were also taken to hospital in stable condition. Two others were arrested after a short foot chase.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Police said that the two youths -- a 17-year-old female and a 16-year-old male -- face joyriding charges. The female was released on an appearance notice but the male was held in custody at the Manitoba Youth Centre as he was also charged for breach of probation.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The two adult males were charged and held in custody at the Remand Centre. Jared Schaffer, 19, is charged with suspended driving, possession of stolen property, flight from police, possessing break-in instruments and dangerous operation of a motor vehicle causing bodily harm. Erid Wirffel, 18, is charged with joyriding and two counts of failing to comply with conditions of a recognizance.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30- </SPAN></P>

Title: 22-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: high-speed deja-vu: Police Chase No.2 On Wed. Ends In Crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police busted two suspected auto thieves and were looking for two others after a stolen van slammed into a </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">West End</SPAN></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> pool hall on </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Notre Dame Avenue</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> Wednesday night. The vehicle -- a 1995 Dodge Caravan -- led cops on a high-speed chase that started in the area of Wall Street and </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Richard Avenue</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, near </SPAN><st1:place><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Technical</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Vocational School</SPAN></st1:PlaceType></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, and lasted for several blocks. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It was the second time on Wednesday fleeing car thieves wound up in a collision. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Joe Valente, owner of The Blue Room Billiards and Amusement Parlour, shook his head yesterday afternoon as he surveyed the damage to his three-storey brick building. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I don't know what they're going to do with these people," Valente told The Sun. "Can you imagine if someone was walking down the sidewalk?
