You'd be pinned against the wall here." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Officers tried unsuccessfully to pull the van over about </SPAN><st1:time Hour="22" Minute="20"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">10:20 p.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver accelerated north on Wall and east on Notre Dame before eventually losing control and crashing sideways into the pool hall at Home Street. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police reported reaching about 90 km/h during the pursuit. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A witness said the driver of the van tried to turn south on to </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Home Street</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> but ended up sliding at the slippery intersection. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We just heard a loud bang," Valente recalled. "I thought maybe somebody fell upstairs (in one of the apartment suites)." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">At least four cruisers immediately converged on the crash site, Valente said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Cops corralled two out of the four suspects after a lengthy foot chase, said </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">An 18-year-old man and 15-year-old boy were facing charges yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoHeading8 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-WEIGHT: normal; FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">HEAD-ON CRASH <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Less than 17 hours earlier, a Unicity Taxi cabbie and his wife were sent to hospital with minor injuries after a stolen Chrysler Intrepid slammed head-on into their taxi near the </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">McPhillips Street</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> underpass between Logan and Jarvis avenues. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police, who had aborted a high-speed chase with the car moments earlier, rounded up four suspected teenage thieves as they tried to flee the wreckage. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That chase had originated at </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Notre Dame Avenue</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> and </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Home Street</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> -- right where the second chase would end later that day. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Officers were involved in a third chase early yesterday morning in which the suspect or suspects got away. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That chase began about </SPAN><st1:time Hour="2" Minute="30"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">2:30 a.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, when cops spotted a stolen vehicle speeding westbound over the </SPAN><st1:place><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Redwood</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Bridge</SPAN></st1:PlaceType></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The pursuit ended near the corner of </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Manitoba Avenue</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> and </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Sheppard Street</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, several blocks west of McPhillips, where the occupant dumped the vehicle and made his escape. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">No arrests had been reported by press time last night. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police fear some teenage car thieves enjoy the adrenaline rush of being chased by cops. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Just by the actions that they undertake when they steal a vehicle, they purposely go out of their way to make sure police know they're driving the vehicle," Johnson said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">About 2,400 vehicles were stolen or had been subjected to attempted thefts between January and March this year -- which marks a 2.1% increase over the same time period in 2003, according to statistics from Manitoba Public Insurance. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Most of the vehicles being pursued by cops are stolen. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">--- <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoHeading8 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-WEIGHT: normal; FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">NOT THE THRILL OF THE CHASE <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">- </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> police were involved in 132 vehicle pursuits in 2003, a 30% increase from 2002, which police attribute to a proportional increase in the number of stolen vehicles. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">- About 90% of those pursuits were initiated for criminal-related offences. The remaining 10% were initiated for a variety of other reasons, including suspicious driving. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">- The average pursuit in 2003 lasted 2.64 minutes, covered 3.48 kilometres and reached 88.67 km/h. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">- Police are 76% more likely to engage in a pursuit between </SPAN><st1:time Hour="22" Minute="0"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">10 p.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> and </SPAN><st1:time Hour="8" Minute="0"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">8 a.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">- There's a 37% chance the pursuit will be aborted. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">- If it's not aborted, 30% of the time there's property or vehicle damage, and 11% of the time a minor injury occurs. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-- Source: </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> Police Service<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 23-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Snow takes a toll on truckers, golfers: Economic Losses From Storm Estimated In The Millions
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, MB Free Press    May.14/04    Page A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">THE bizarre blast of May snow that closed a key portion of the </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Trans-Canada Highway</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> could cost the transport industry millions, says the general manager of the Manitoba Trucking Association. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Economically, you could attach a price of $2 million to the delay of 500 to 600 trucks for the better part of 48 hours," Bob Dolyniuk said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Without question, the business has been affected. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The highway is critical to the delivery of products coast to coast, so there's a huge impact across the country." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The storm closed the </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Trans-Canada Highway</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> from </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> to the Manitoba-Saskatchewan border. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">As expected, trucks stacked up since Tuesday on the highway just outside of </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> were finally allowed to move west yesterday morning, after RCMP lifted barricades at the Headingley weigh station. A number of other highways in southern </SPAN><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Manitoba</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> were also reopened. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Dolyniuk said it's difficult to predict the residual effect of having two days of work scrapped by Mother Nature. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Obviously, there's product sitting in trailers intended for store shelves already," he said. "Some products may not have been protected because of the delay... Some truckers were running short on fuel to heat their trailers." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"And those 48 hours also represent about $500 of lost income per driver. It's money that's gone." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Dolyniuk said it could take until today before the trucking backlog is cleared. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"That's one heck of a convoy, both east and west," he said. Clayton Gording, vice-president of operations for Reimer Express, said it could actually take up to a week before things are running smoothly and deliveries and pickups are back on schedule. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's like a domino effect," said Gording, "Once you get out of that rhythm, it takes a while to get it back." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">According to Environment Canada, the record-setting storm buried the southern Prairies, all the way from </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Calgary</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> to Kenora. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But more seasonable conditions are on the way, said Environment Canada meteorologist Jay Anderson. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The temperature is expected to reach 7 C today, in the low teens tomorrow and mid-teens by Sunday, with a mix of sun and cloud anticipated throughout the weekend, he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That's good news for </SPAN><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Manitoba</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> golf-course operators, who lose money every day their courses stay closed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'s five municipal courses -- </SPAN><st1:place><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Kildonan</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Park</SPAN></st1:PlaceType></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, </SPAN><st1:place><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Windsor</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Park</SPAN></st1:PlaceType></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, John Blumberg, Harbour View and Crescent Drive -- could be out as much as $85,000 in combined revenues with four days sliced off the season. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">And that's assuming the snow's melted by tomorrow. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The best-case scenario is we'll have the weekend," said Mike Sterdan, chief operating officer of Winnipeg Golf Services. "Obviously, we're not pleased with this. "May and June are premium months for us. That's when people are most interested... They're anxious to get out after the winter and they're trying out their new clubs." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Sterdan said the three 18-hole courses, Kildonan, Windsor and Blumberg, attract about 250 golfers during a regular weekday, while about 200 players tee up at the two nine-hole courses, Harbour View and Crescent Drive. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Hopefully, over the course of the season this all balances out," he said. "Maybe we're getting rid of all the bad weather now." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Sterdan said there is a silver lining to all the white stuff. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The moisture is not a bad thing. If we get some heat soon, the courses will be in exceptional shape in a few weeks."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 24-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: More Auto Thefts, more risky police chases
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, MB, Free Press    May.14/04    Page B1/B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">THE jump in car thefts last year is behind a steadily increasing number of high-speed police pursuits in </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, police say. Statistics released yesterday show there were 132 police chases in 2003, up from 103 the year before. In the same period, the city's car-theft rate jumped 6.7 per cent; 6,611 vehicles were stolen last year compared to 6,190 in 2002. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson said police expect the number of police pursuits to rise as young thieves continue to steal cars and minivans, usually vehicles that don't have ignition or steering-wheel locks. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">For example, police officials are now reviewing three high-speed chases that took place overnight Wednesday and Thursday -- one of which ended with a stolen car crashing into a Unicity cab and injuring two people and another where a stolen car smashed into a building. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In the third chase, the thieves abandoned the car before they hit anything. All chases are reviewed by a police committee. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Johnson also said police believe that, in many chases, thieves bait police by speeding by a patrol car or even ramming it. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's why they call it joyriding," he said. Last year's statistics come from the Winnipeg Police Service's 2003 Pursuit Report. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The report said the average chase lasts only 2.64 minutes and covers an average distance of 3.48 kilometres before either being called off or ending with the vehicle being stopped. The average speed of a chase is 88.67 km/h. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Johnson said of all the chases in 2003, 37 per cent were aborted by police because it was too dangerous to continue. Of the chases not aborted, 30 per cent ended with vehicle or other property damage. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He said 11 per cent ended with someone getting hurt; either people in the car being chased, innocent people in other cars or police officers. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In 2003, 22 people were injured because of police chases. In 2002, 13 people were hurt. No one was killed in either year. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In 90 per cent of chases, a criminal offence has been committed and the suspect is trying to get away. In the remaining 10 per cent, the offender has committed a Highway Traffic Offence, like running a red light. Manitoba Public Insurance spokesman Brian Smiley said car owners must bear the final responsibility of reducing potentially dangerous police chases. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Get an ignition immobilizer or steering-wheel lock," he said. "That way kids can't steal cars and they can't drive down the road like maniacs and police won't have to chase them." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Johnson said 75 per cent of stolen cars are being driven by males under 20 years old. Of those, 60 per cent are under 16. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police also say that over the past decade they have been more inclined to call off chases for safety reasons. The service has a pursuit policy -- a checklist of variables such as weather and road conditions ---that is taken into account when deciding if a pursuit should be aborted. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The chase policy balances the need to catch criminals with the issue of safety for both police and the public.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: right" align=right><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-style: italic"><A href="mailto:Bruce.owen@freepress,mb,ca">Bruce.<SPAN style="mso-bookmark: _Hlt72290475">owen@freepress.m</SPAN>b.ca</A><A name=_Hlt72290475></A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 25-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Insurance for dummies: To Achieve Cheaper Auto Insurance, Don’t Dumb Down The System. Instead, Make It Smarter By Allowing Market-Oriented Innovations
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Toronto, On    Financial Post  May.14/04    Page FP15
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lowering auto insurance rates doesn't involve "rocket science," Alberta Premier Ralph Klein scoffed last week. To prove his point, he vowed to sit his MLAs down together in the same room one day soon to lower rates for 80% of </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Alberta</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> drivers. His ideal is one-size-fits-all insurance. "What we want to achieve is comparable levels of premium payments for the middle of the pack so to speak ... you, me."<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Klein doesn't want insurance policies complicated by actuarial mumbo-jumbo. Nor is he alone in insisting that auto insurance be dumbed down to a simpleton's comprehension level. Politicians across </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Canada</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> are wondering why the aged should pay higher premiums simply because their eyesight is failing and their reaction times are slowing. Or why young single males should be hit with higher premiums to insure their souped-up vehicles. Or whether insurers should have the right to balk at insuring drivers with perfectly valid drivers' licences, merely because they have had five or six accidents. The only provinces not considering dumbing down their auto insurance are those under public ownership: They've already hit bottom.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The dumbing down produces predictable results: More dangerous drivers on the road, higher claims costs, and, all else being equal, higher insurance premiums. Dumbed-down provinces can escape higher premiums, however, by limiting compensation: </SPAN><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Alberta</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, for example, is considering capping payouts at $4,000 to lower the cost of auto insurance. That's too much for provinces such as </SPAN><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Prince Edward Island</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> to fathom. It capped its payout at $2,500.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">While </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Canada</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> is busy dumbing down its auto insurance industry, the </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">United States</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> has been expecting more from its insurers, and getting it. Auto insurance rates south of the border will be falling this year, but not because governments have frozen rates (Ontario) or rolled them back (Nova Scotia) or rebated insurance premiums (New Brunswick) or given Canadians small savings in premiums coupled with big reductions in benefits (most of the rest). </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">U.S.</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> rates are falling because competition has forced auto insurers to provide consumers with more value: more choices, better service, more accurate pricing and lower costs. </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">U.S.</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> consumers like the result. In contrast to Canadians, who dislike their insurance industry whether it's publicly or privately run, U.S. consumers give their auto insurers a satisfaction rating approaching 90%, and believe that more deregulation -- not more regulation -- would lead to even lower rates.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Canada</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'s politicians set up roadblocks to prevent insurance companies from offering meaningful choices. </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">U.S.</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> politicians allow insurers more of an open road, letting aggressive companies such as Progressive and Safeco hit the accelerator. Where these insurers once relied on a few simple factors such as age, sex and driving history to determine insurance rates, they now employ thousands of variables. Many of those variables make no sense to customers -- "what does my credit history at Wal-Mart have to do with my driving record," a customer might ask. Progressive's answer: "We consider you a higher risk. Others may not." Progressive, now </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">America</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'s third-largest auto insurer, provides its rates alongside the rates of other companies -- a practice it pioneered 10 years ago -- to help consumers compare and decide which insurance product best suits their needs.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Safeco, another new-breed insurer, has likewise transformed its once-dumb business practices, such as putting everyone between the ages of 21 and 70 in the same age category. Now Safeco proudly discriminates: by age, by marital status, by neighbourhood, singly or in combination. Mostly, it discriminates in favour of safe drivers, who cost it least in claims, and who deserve, as a result, the best rates.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In part, insurance is becoming more accurate due to changes in technology. In parts of the </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">United States</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> and the </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">United Kingdom</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, drivers are beginning to pay for their insurance by the mile --the more they drive, the more insurance they pay. But when and where they drive, and under what conditions, also matters. It costs less to drive on rural roads that have a good safety history than on dangerous roadways, such as congested inner-city expressways. The </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">United Kingdom</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'s Norwich Union tracks the weather to vary rates by driving conditions -- driving on roads that are slippery when wet now comes at a higher per mile insurance premium.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The pay-per-mile schemes set rates by using satellite technology to track the movement of vehicles. To limit their liability, auto rental companies now also make widespread use of tracking technologies -- an estimated 25% of rentals are monitored in this way -- to make sure their cars aren't taken across borders or driven dangerously. Some rental companies even fine drivers for speeding to discourage reckless behaviour and lower insurance costs.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The best insurance-lowering innovation of all, however, may soon come from another </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">United Kingdom</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> market-oriented experiment: the pricing of roads. Just over one year ago, </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">London</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> began to charge road users to enter its downtown area. </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">London</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> hoped to lower traffic congestion, and in that it succeeded. To the city's surprise, eliminating congestion also led to an immense reduction in accidents: 28% fewer cars were involved in accidents and 6% fewer pedestrians. If the safety improvements that </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">London</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> experienced carry through to all </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">U.K.</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> roads when they become tolled in the next five to seven years, </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">U.K.</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> consumers are in for premium reductions. The reductions could also come in Continental Europe, which is likewise developing smart technologies to allow it to toll its roads.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Meanwhile, </SPAN><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Canada</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> grows dumber and dumber. Each new interference in the insurance industry convinces either companies to leave, lowering competition, or investors to demand a higher return on their capital. Either way, consumers pay. The savings that politicians promise consumers, meanwhile, are either artificial and temporary, such as when government artificially freezes rates, or nonexistent. </SPAN><st1:State><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Alberta</SPAN></st1:place></st1:State><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> officials now acknowledge there may be no forced savings to be had, and that Ralph Klein may not be able to deliver on his promise.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But Klein does have a way to lower rates, and it doesn't involve rocket science. He need only move aside and let the insurance market work.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 26-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Automotive Showcase: toking and driving – who’s the real dope? Pot Smokers Are A Risk On Highways
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    May.14/04    Page E13
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">I received a letter earlier this year from an old friend, an Englishman who was skipper of a motor torpedo boat after the Second World War. At that time, he and his contemporaries smoked marijuana quite regularly, which if nothing else proves how little is new. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He writes: "A group of us with local girls used to meet on Friday nights to smoke some pot and listen to what we thought of as magnificent music. One Friday I was called out on an emergency and did not get there until late. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"When I walked into the room I was confronted by a group of gals and guys sitting around with stupid looks on their grinning faces listening to atrocious music on a worn out, wind up, scratchy record player. I left and did not return nor did I touch weed for about 30 years and then only once, with similar results." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">This is not meant to be a diatribe against marijuana. I've tried it, and unlike former President Bill Clinton I inhaled, but had no desire to do so again. It has not been a part of my life for the simple reason that, in my teens, I was living in a pup tent near Snetterton race track in </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">England</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, fighting my way into the racing business. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">I don't know of a single professional racing driver of note who smokes pot. Even here in Whistler, where according to some we are all permanently stoned, the stuff is no more prevalent than it would be in </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, perhaps less so. Most good athletes know better than to blunt their faculties. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">If nothing else, based on how many stand-up comics joke about smoking pot, there is a lot of it around. I know lawyers, realtors, doctors and many others who use the stuff, at least on occasion. It doesn't seem to hurt them, though someone high on marijuana is not very interesting company for those who are sober. That, plus the resultant munchies can clean out a fridge in short order. How people live is their own business, as long as it has no negative effect on others. Pot, like booze or any other intoxicant, should not be used while operating a motor vehicle. A few years ago, I was driving with a friend on a logging road. He pulled out a joint and had a couple of puffs. Noting my expression he said, "It makes me drive better." A few minutes later, after our progress had become distinctly erratic, he turned to me and sheepishly said, "It only makes me think I drive better." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">There are a bunch of ways to be impaired behind the wheel, from fatigue to medication. I don't have a major problem with the legalization of marijuana, barring legitimate medical evidence of its danger. This could curb a lot of illegal activity as well as providing another taxable product, which seems to be the drug governments crave the most. It has been done well, and safely, in parts of </SPAN><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Europe</SPAN></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">What we need, though, and quickly, is a roadside test for drug use. Just as drinking and driving used to be a subject for jokes, people who smoke pot and drive don't seem to realize what a risk they are taking. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">On the plus side, unlike many drunks or users of other drugs, they probably won't be belligerent with the hospital staff. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><EM><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Alan Sidorov is an experienced automotive racer, product tester and freelance journalist. You can e-mail Alan at the address below.</SPAN></EM><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> <I><o:p></o:p></I></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: right" align=right><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:highambitions@telus.net">highambitions@telus.net</A> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 27-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Reset internal clock when driving in country: Relaxed Pace Of Rural Life Means City Slickers Need To Chill Out When They Head For Hills
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    May.14/04    Page E16
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">IT'S that time of year when many city dwellers head for the hills- and lakes, and shores. What awaits might surprise the driver used to the hustle and bustle of the city where traffic is controlled by a myriad of signs, signals and markings. Out there in the rural world there is a lot more real estate, much of it bereft of traffic controls. Heck there isn't even much traffic -- unless it's summer and the folks from the city are prowling around! <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It's ironic, but the same area we choose to train beginning drivers because of the paucity of traffic can pose a challenge for experienced drivers. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">There are two main differences about rural driving -- pace and conditions. Drivers who live and work in rural areas generally operate at a different pace than those in the city. They aren't governed as much by the clock, traffic and commuter systems as they are by the need to get things done -- they often rise earlier and may call it a day later. But as much of the work may be physical, they generally pace themselves and that might include driving more slowly on secondary roads. They don't work in crowded areas, congregate for lunch or share commuter rides so when they run across friends and neighbours they take the opportunity to stop and catch up. It is just this more relaxed outlook and way of life many city dwellers envy -- yet forget when they are visiting. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Once you leave primary, limited access roads reset your internal clock to a slower pace. You are likely to run into folks travelling at a reduced speed -- they are probably staying within the limits. This silly notion of obeying posted speed limits is quite foreign to your average city dweller -- but still much in vogue in rural areas. In addition, frequent stops are common, often where there are no stop signs! Once again, an unfamiliar trait for some. And of course let's not forget those other tourists or visitors, some of whom came to enjoy the scenery, many of whom are either driving in unfamiliar territory or in rented or recreational vehicles. They are also likely to be paying less attention to their driving and more to the scenery. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Another factor to keep in mind when travelling through rural areas are the roads themselves. They are almost exclusively two lanes, but also likely to contain sharper corners and steeper hills. Rural roads are darker at night and often flanked by drainage ditches on both sides with little shoulder room. Railway crossings may not be as well signed. Trees, bushes and crops may block your view on narrow, winding roads. The variety alone is worthy of consideration not only in terms of composition (concrete, pavement, gravel, sand, etc), but also with reference to condition. Rural roads commonly run between different jurisdictions with different budgets and maintenance schedules. You can be driving on a well-maintained smooth surface only to see it change in a matter of metres to a pot-holed, uneven mess as it passes into another community -- where the tax money is being spent elsewhere, or the local politician is not worried about re-election. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">And let's not forget the preponderance of heavy vehicles ranging from tractors and farm implements to heavily laden trucks and other vehicles shuttling between sites. Not only are these vehicles travelling more slowly, they are also slow to get up to speed after pulling unto the road. There are fewer passing spots and they probably have dragged some dirt or mud unto the paved road -- making the surface not only slippery but also likely to be dusty in dry conditions or be thrown unto your windshield when wet. All of these factors require special consideration. Animals -- wild and domestic -- are a common scene and they often don't know it's tourist season and the approaching vehicle is unaware of their habits. It is also not uncommon to find foreign objects on the road including branches, leaves, fallen rocks etc. The local road maintenance crew has more area to cover and probably a variety of jobs -- this being only one of them. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Driving in unfamiliar areas requires more attention and less speed. Enjoy the view!<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 28-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: SPIKE BELT ENDS RURAL CAR CHASE
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>Apparently police chases don&#8217;t just take place inside the Perimeter.</P>  <P align=justify>About 3:40 a.m. Saturday, an officer with the St. Pierre Jolys RCMP detachment stopped to check on a suspicious car on a street in St. Adolphe. The officer discovered the driver asleep behind the wheel and woke him up, police said.</P>  <P align=justify>The driver got out of the car while the officer attempted to question him, but he refused to identify himself or provide any answers. After a minute or two, the driver got back in his car and sped off with the cop in pursuit, police said.</P>  <P align=justify>The speeding car drove to Winnipeg, turned around and went back to St. Adolphe, back to Winnipeg again. Police chased it along St. Mary&#8217;s Road, Highway 75, Highway 59 and Bishop Grandin Boulevard and finally out onto the Trans-Canada Highway eastbound.</P>  <P align=justify>About 30 km east of the Perimeter Highway near the junction of Highway 12, Mounties laid a spike belt across the road and safely stopped the car. The chase had covered about 95 km and hit speed of 150 km/h, but no one was injured.</P>  <P align=justify>The 30-year-old man is facing charges of dangerous driving, flight from a police officer and driving while suspended.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 29-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CURBING CAR THEFT DEMANDS MORE THAN FAITH
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB    Free Press    May 17/04    Page B1
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A faith-based car racing program aimed at getting kids to stop stealing cars is spinning its wheels as it continues to hunt for government funding. </P>  <P align=justify>Stan Schroeder, head of Righteous Racing, said yesterday he's been forced to lay off staff and turn away kids as he doesn't have the money to run the program. </P>  <P align=justify>He said he now has to rely on volunteers to teach kids how to build race cars out of wrecks and take then out to Victory Lane Speedway, where they learn how to race. </P>  <P align=justify>"We are still trying to find funding," he said. "The sad part is that we're turning kids away because we just don't have enough dollars." </P>  <P align=justify>Schroeder made his comments soon after Winnipeg police released statistics that show high-speed police chases are increasing at the same pace as the city's auto-theft rate, which jumped 6.7 per cent last year from 2002. </P>  <P align=justify>There were 132 police pursuits in 2003 compared to 103 the year before. Most thieves are teenage males and most steal cars to joyride. There were five pursuits last week, the latest two happening overnight Friday. One involved an impaired driver downtown and the other a stolen vehicle in the north end. Both police cars were slightly damaged in the two chases. Only the impaired driver was arrested. </P>  <P align=justify>Schroeder said he needs stable funding for Righteous Racing -- it's at 75 Stadacona St. in East Kildonan -- so that more young men learn automotive skills and get work experience so they stop stealing cars and give up crime. </P>  <P align=justify>The idea was to have about 140 young offenders, from ages 15 to 25, go through the program a year. To date, however, only about 40 teens have been involved in the program since Righteous Racing opened two years ago. </P>  <P align=justify>Schroeder has said Righteous Racing is now about $50,000 in debt, with no provincial or federal funding in sight. </P>  <P align=justify>He said any amount of funding would be welcome, as it would provide some stability. Right now, Righteous Racing relies on private donations and volunteers. </P>  <P align=justify>Meanwhile, Winnipeg's Youth Justice Committees are planning to expand the Shifting Gears intervention program. Shifting Gears was created in 2002 as part of Ottawa's new Youth Criminal Justice Act to teach offenders about the ramifications of auto theft. Wendy Singleton, project manager of Achieving Justice in Our Community, said 16 youths have completed the program this past year. </P>  <P align=justify>She said Shifting Gears is an educational program designed for youth ages 12 to 18 who have been involved in an auto theft offence. The goals of the program are to teach young people about the consequences of auto theft, like the damage that is inflicted and the penalties against them, like withholding of a driver's licence and financial restitution. </P>  <P align=justify>Currently, the program is being evaluated to see if any of the students have become re-involved in crime. </P>  <P align=justify><A HREF="/News/ClippingsAdmin/mailtbruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca"><U><FONT color=#0000ff size=2><A href="mailto:bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca-30">bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</U></FONT></A><FONT size=2></P>  <P align=center>-30</A>-</P></FONT>

Title: 30-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Gas anger explosive: Fuel prices could become burning election issue
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB    Sun    May 16/04    Page A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>&nbsp;</FONT>OTTAWA -- An irate senior in Ontario drives away from the gas pump after paying only $20 -- "the fair price" -- for a $25 fill-up. He leaves his name and phone number, defying police to charge him. The Canadian Automobile Association in Quebec gets more than 33,000 signatures on an online protest letter.   <P align=justify>Nova Scotia introduces legislation that would force oil companies to give two days notice before hiking gasoline prices. </P>  <P align=justify>On B.C.'s Salt Spring Island, prices hit $1.01 a litre. </P>  <P align=justify>There's an anger in the land, and with a June 28 federal election call looming in an issue-deficient season, gasoline could be the accelerant for a hot campaign. </P>  <P align=justify>The issue appeared to flare from nowhere in the final week of the Commons session as Conservative MPs repeatedly hammered the Liberals over gas tax policy. </P>  <P align=justify>The Tories want Ottawa to stop charging GST on top of the federal gas excise tax, arguing that every one-cent increase in gasoline retail prices inflates federal tax revenue by $32 million annually. </P>  <P align=justify>"The least they can do is leave some of that money with Canadians, especially leading up to this busy (vacation) season," Conservative MP Rahim Jaffer said Friday in the Commons. </P><B>  <P align=justify>'HARDLY A BENEFIT' </P></B>  <P align=justify>Finance Minister Ralph Goodale, rose to rebuff the charge. </P>  <P align=justify>"To make the simplistic change the honourable gentleman is proposing makes a difference of about one cent per litre, and that's hardly going to make an appreciable benefit to consumers," said Goodale. </P>  <P align=justify>"The search for a solution has to be a little more sophisticated than a glib opposition one-liner." </P>  <P align=justify>But with experts already predicting that the latest federal Competition Bureau investigation into soaring gas prices will come to naught, Goodale must know that glib one-liners serve as well as impotent inquiries. </P>  <P align=justify>The Canadian Taxpayers' Federation estimates that, on average, 42% of the price of a litre of fuel is taxes, providing Ottawa with more than $5 billion a year. </P>  <P align=justify>Liberals counter that those revenues pay for essential services. </P>  <P align=justify>Environmentalists and public policy analysts, meanwhile, argue that artificially reducing gas prices would encourage wasteful driving and is simply bad public policy. </P>  <P align=justify>It's a no-win debate. </P>  <P align=justify>And woe to the Liberals if this gasoline protest really catches fire, said Don Desserud, a political scientist at the University of New Brunswick in Saint John. </P>  <P align=justify>Bottom-dollar consumer issues have a way of galvanizing voters, said Desserud, and incumbent governments forget it at their peril. </P>  <P align=justify>"They have to realize that policy issues like this can take over. You think you're running a campaign on the questions of leadership, honesty, integrity -- the usual banalities -- and the public says, 'No, here's the issue that's bugging us.' "</P>  <P align=justify>&nbsp;</P><B><U>  <P align=justify>[feedback]</P></B></U>  <P align=justify>The price of gasoline is a key election issue.</P>  <P align=justify>Agree 632-2661 Disagree 632-2662</P>  <P align=justify>Use a touch-tone or rotary phone.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 31-Jul-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Pump game irks skeptical drivers: Where’s The Competition, Buyers Ask
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, Mb    Sun    May.16/04    Page A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>Bev Abbott keeps her 1987 Dakota pickup in good repair. "It runs well and I get good mileage," she said after topping off the tank with $60 worth of gas. </P>  <P align=justify>"You're damn right it hurts," said Abbott, who eased the pain of paying with a discount coupon at Canada Safeway. </P>  <P align=justify>Like other drivers interviewed by The Sun, Abbott wondered why gas companies don't simply lower the price, instead of issuing coupons. </P>  <P align=justify>"They hike up the price of gas and then try to make you think you're getting a bargain," said Abbott. "It's not a bargain." </P>  <P align=justify>Most advertised prices in Winnipeg yesterday were 91.9 cents a litre, with many outlets offering discounts from 3.5-to-9.5 cents a litre. </P>  <P align=justify>Sonia Fontes has a $20 fill-up limit, so each price increase means she doesn't drive as far. </P>  <P align=justify>"I don't like it but I don't have a choice," said Fontes after a stop at a McPhillips Street Domo. "I like the coupon thing. I have to take advantage." </P>  <P align=justify>Fontes wondered why there is no real competition, since all gas outlets raise their prices at the same time. </P>  <P align=justify>"It's like monkey see, monkey do," quipped Fontes. </P>  <P align=justify>Ken Drohomereski also wondered about the lack of competition. </P>  <P align=justify>NOT ALLOWED TO ADVERTISE </P>  <P align=justify>"Why is that? I think there is price fixing, but there's a lot of things the consumer doesn't know," he said. "It's got to the point where a government has to get involved." </P>  <P align=justify>One gas bar employee, who did not want to be identified, said most drivers spend $20. </P>  <P align=justify>"They said they're waiting for the price to go down, but that could be a long way away," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>The employee said independent outlets are not allowed to advertise lower prices than the major retailers. "That's why we have coupons. So we don't get cut off," the employee said. </P>  <P align=justify>Abbott was surprised to hear that most Winnipeg gas outlets were supplied by a single Henderson Highway depot. </P>  <P align=justify>"I was always told the gas came from the same place," she said. </P>  <P align=justify>Drohomereski is using regular grade, instead of prime, in his Silverado in an attempt to stretch his gas dollar. </P>  <P align=justify>"People are upset," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>"Every increase affects the economy. Fewer people are buying new cars. I read more people are buying used cars," said Drohomereski.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 1-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [photo]    down and out
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB    Sun    May 16/04    Page A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Emergency personnel work to extricate the passenger of this Jeep Cherokee that was involved in a two-car collision at the corner of McDermot Avenue and Princess Street about 1 a.m. yesterday morning.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 2-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police briefs: Drunk driver mows down two teenagers
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, Mb    Sun    May.16/04    Page A16
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>&nbsp;</FONT>  <P align=justify>Two Winnipeg teenagers are in hospital after being mowed down by a drunk driver early yesterday.</P>  <P align=justify>The pair had been walking across Andrews Street between Manitoba and Magnus avenues about 2:20 a.m. yesterday when when they were hit by the car, duty Insp. Doug Lofto said yesterday.</P>  <P align=justify>Moments later, the car drove over the curb at Andrews and Burrows Avenue and came up to a stop. The female driver and passenger jumped out and fled, Lofto said.</P>  <P align=justify>Officers in a passing cruiser spotted the car, called for backup and the two suspects were arrested. The two injured teens were rushed to Health Sciences Centre.</P>  <P align=justify>A 16-year-old boy was in stabe condition yesterday with a fractured leg. His 17-year-old female companion was more seriously hurt and was in unstable condition at first but upgraded to stable last night.</P>  <P>The 21-year-old female driver of the car will be charged with two counts of impaired driving causing bodily harm and driving while suspended, police said.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 3-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teens hit the road: MPI Hosts Driver-Ed Challenge
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, Mb    Sun    May.16/04    Page A17
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>&nbsp;</FONT>  <P>Teenager Chelsea Thomas put the pedal to the metal behind the wheel of a police cruiser yesterday and pointed the car in the direction of two police officers standing nearby. Luckily for them, another officer was cautiously guiding Thomas from the passenger seat -- and the teenager was more afraid than the cops. </P>  <P>"It's pretty scary. I didn't know what I was doing," said the 16-year-old Rivers resident, after knocking down a pylon during her first run through a tight practice track. "But it's OK now." </P>  <P>Thomas was one of 60 Manitoba high school students to compete in yesterday's Manitoba Public Insurance Driver Education challenge. </P>  <P>The youths spent the day at Red River Exhibition Park learning about collision avoidance techniques, tips on reversing and drinking and driving statistics. They also wrote tests and got in the driver's seat for different hands-on lessons. </P>  <P>MPI and police decided to team up for the contest to help novice drivers around the province improve some of their basic skills before falling into some poor habits. </P>  <P>"From the time they come in to the time they leave, we see a marked improvement in their driving skills," said Const. Jim Thiessen of the police training division. </P>  <P>Fort Richmond Collegiate student Garrett Wisniewski said he had a new appreciation for the excitement -- and dangers -- of speeding after he got his group's 2004 Honda Civic SI up to about 80 km-h. </P>  <P>"I've ... learned how much fun it can be to drive a car faster than you're allowed to. I had a lead foot," Wisniewski said with a smile. "You actually felt the G forces pulling you to one side. It was the highlight of the day so far." </P>  <P>Grand prize winner Leo Narynsky, 16, took home a $1,000 university scholarship, while Mike Rogalsky, 17, and Meaghan Pacholek, 16, each earned $500 toward their post-secondary studies. All three are from Winnipeg.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 4-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In brief: Teens hit by drunk?
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    May.16/04    Page A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>TWO teenagers are in hospital after they were hit by a suspected drunk driver early yesterday morning. </P>  <P align=justify>Police say the victims were crossing Andrews Street, between Magnus and Manitoba avenues, just before 2:20 a.m. when they were hit by a car. </P>  <P align=justify>Moments later police saw a vehicle jump the curb and come to a stop after the driver attempted to turn at Burrows Avenue and Andrews Street. </P>  <P align=justify>The driver and a passenger tried to flee on foot but were arrested by police. A 21-year-old woman is facing two charges of impaired driving causing bodily harm and driving while suspended. </P>  <P>Police said a 17-year-old girl received serious injuries but is in stable condition while a 16-year-old boy suffered a broken leg.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 5-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Flying truck part injures driver on Toronto highway
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    May.16/04    Page A6
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>TORONTO -- Police were asking for witnesses to come forward after a motorist was struck in the head and seriously injured by a truck part that flew through the windshield of his car early yesterday afternoon. </P>  <P align=justify>The 59-year-old man was driving along Highway 401 on the north end of Toronto when a part broke loose from a truck that was likely travelling in the opposite direction. The part crashed into the man's car and hit him in the head. The piece then bounced out of his vehicle, shattering the sunroof. </P>  <P align=justify>Police said the man was on life support in hospital yesterday and was not expected to live. They erroneously said earlier that the man had died. </P>  <P align=justify>The motorist was not immediately identified. </P>  <P align=justify>The transport truck didn't stop after the accident and police were asking for public assistance in tracking the driver down. </P>  <P>"It's unlikely the truck driver would even have known the part came off," said Ontario Provincial Police Sgt. Cam Woolley. Woolley said the rig may have been travelling eastbound when it threw off an orange "shoe" from the so-called "landing gear," a part used to stabilize the vehicle when it's parked. </P>  <P align=center>-30-<B></P></B>

Title: 6-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: nuts behind wheel: Survey Finds Winnipeg Drivers Have Short Fuse
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>Move it, ya jerk! Winnipeg motorists caught in traffic are three times more likely than the average Canadian to shout at other drivers, according to a survey sponsored by the Uniroyal tire company. </P>  <P align=justify>"If they're by themselves in the car, it might be harmless ... I really can't tell if you're wishing I hadn't pulled in front of you or if you're singing along (to the radio)," said Roger Stapley, the Uniroyal Tire Doctor, with a chuckle. </P>  <P align=justify>The questionnaire looked at the driving habits of Canadians. Uniroyal would not disclose how many people responded to the survey. </P>  <P align=justify>In Winnipeg, 6% of drivers shout at other motorists. The national average is 2%, the survey found. </P>  <P align=justify>"The biggest trigger for aggressive driving is usually traffic congestion combined with a schedule (the driver) can't meet," said Jeanie Dalman, CAA Manitoba spokeswoman. </P>  <P align=justify>Dalman said 82% of Manitoban drivers admitted to aggressive driving, according to a 2003 study done by the Steel Alliance and the Canada Safety Council. The Canadian average was 84%. </P>  <P align=justify>For those about to rock ... you must be from Winnipeg. </P>  <P align=justify>AC/DC and Metallica is playing on the radios of more Winnipeggers than any other type of music at 53%, the Uniroyal survey found. </P>  <P align=justify>Nationally, rock music is also the most popular style of music to listen to while taking a road trip, at 34%. </P>  <P align=justify>Country music is the least popular among Winnipeggers surveyed, with only 6% of drivers tuning in to a twangy-voiced crooner. In Canada, 14% of road-trippers listened to country. </P>  <P align=justify>The most popular road trip in Canada -- and among Winnipeggers -- is to the Canadian Rockies, with more than 50% who answered the questionnaire calling the mountain range their ideal destination. </P>  <P align=justify>The survey found a flat tire is the "most dreaded road trip occurrence," with 31% of respondents choosing that option. </P>  <P align=justify>In Winnipeg, 28% of drivers said having their car stall is their least favourite event that could happen during a family road trip. </P>  <P align=justify>Dalman said locking your keys in the car, with kids or pets trapped inside, is CAAs most dreaded hot or cold-weather occurrence. </P>  <P>"We attend that situation immediately," she said, adding pets and kids are in serious danger when trapped in a sweltering or frigid car.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 7-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Would-be road warriors keep cops busy: Week Of Chases Nets Wrecks, 10 Arrests
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Car thieves have been busy this week playing a dangerous game of cat and mouse. Winnipeg police busted four more suspects early yesterday morning following two pursuits that ended with damage to the stolen vehicles and cop cruisers. </P>  <P align=justify>Between Wednesday and yesterday, a total of 10 auto thieves had been arrested following five high-speed police chases -- including two that ended in serious crashes. </P><B>  <P align=justify>ILL-FATED CHASES </P></B>  <P align=justify>Despite what seems to be a springtime explosion of ill-fated cop chases, police say they just happened to publicly release information about more pursuits this week. </P>  <P align=justify>"You're hearing more about them," said Winnipeg police spokeswoman Const. Shelly Glover. "Quite often, we don't release information about pursuits -- particularly when youths are involved." </P>  <P align=justify>Last year, police engaged in 132 chases. </P>  <P align=justify>"When you have 132 chases in a year, you're getting several a week," said police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson. </P>  <P align=justify>Officers chased a drunk driver shortly before 2:45 a.m. in the area of Central Park on Edmonton Street, where they arrested two occupants. The vehicle and the cruiser had minor damage, said police. </P>  <P align=justify>About an hour later, cops chased a stolen vehicle through the North End before cuffing two teenage suspects on McGregor Street. </P>  <P align=justify>The driver, a 15-year-old boy, and his passenger, a 13-year-old boy, face charges. </P>  <P align=justify>Once again, the vehicle and a cruiser sustained damage. </P>  <P align=justify>Early Thursday morning, cops chased a stolen vehicle west over the Redwood Bridge to Manitoba Avenue at Sheppard Street, where the occupant dumped the vehicle and made his escape. </P>  <P align=justify>On Wednesday night, a 1995 Dodge Caravan full of teens led cops on a high-speed chase that started in the area of Wall Street and Richard Avenue and ended when the van crashed into a Notre Dame Avenue pool hall. An 18-year-old man and 15-year-old boy were arrested. </P>  <P>Early Wednesday morning, a cabbie and his wife were sent to hospital with minor injuries after a stolen Chrysler slammed head-on into their taxi near the McPhillips Street underpass between Logan and Jarvis avenues. </P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 8-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Licence plates to honour vets: Program Begins In Winter
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>The Manitoba government will begin issuing special licence plates to honour veterans as early as this winter, says the province's transportation minister. Ron Lemieux told The Sun yesterday the province wants to begin distributing the plates as a way of acknowledging the work vets have done for the country. </P>  <P align=justify>"We're going to be the first province in Western Canada to do this," Lemieux said. </P>  <P align=justify>Lemieux said details of the plan must still be worked out.
