It's unclear what the plates will look like, how they will be distributed or who will be eligible, he said. </P>  <P align=justify>He said one option is to provide the plates free of charge to those who fought in the two world wars, the Korean war or have been enlisted in the armed forces for more than two years. </P>  <P align=justify>Lemieux said he wants to make sure peacekeepers are also eligible. </P>  <P align=justify>He said the plate will somehow identify the driver as a veteran and may include a graphic of some kind. </P>  <P align=justify>"We want to make sure we have all those loose ends tied up," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>Lemieux's announcement came just days after Tory MLA Ralph Eichler introduced a private member's bill that would see the province recognize veterans with a special licence plate. </P>  <P align=justify>"I'm just like a kid with a new toy," he said yesterday after hearing the NDP government will move ahead with a plan similar to the one he was proposing. </P><B>  <P align=justify>'WAY OVERDUE' </P></B>  <P align=justify>Cliff Tessier, president of the Manitoba and Northwest Ontario command of the Royal Canadian Legion, said licence plates honouring vets are "way overdue." </P>  <P align=justify>"It's certainly a great way to show our veterans we appreciate them," Tessier said. </P>  <P>Lemieux said Ontario, as well as the Atlantic provinces, have plates that recognize the registered owner as a veteran. </P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 9-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Virden patrollers help truckers trapped by weather
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, Mb    Free Press    May.15/04    Page A8
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>SNOW, sleet and generally wacky weather didn't stop the Virden Citizens on Patrol from doing good deeds for truckers trapped in what seemed like the middle of nowhere during this week's storm. After a call for help from the overwhelmed RCMP, co-ordinator Todd Sparwood and his team hit the icy roads in four-wheel drive trucks to check on about 275 truckers stranded on the Trans-Canada and other closed highways. </P>  <P align=justify>"There were some that were getting low on gas and there were some guys that were hungry and a few that needed water," Sparwood said. "They all appreciated that we were out there." </P>  <P align=justify>The volunteers distributed phone numbers for the local RCMP and let the truckers know they could call 911 if they had an emergency. </P>  <P align=justify>"Some of them had no idea even how far from town they were," Sparwood said. </P>  <P align=justify>Manitoba Attorney General Gord Mackintosh made a special presentation to the group last night at the opening of the third annual Citizens on Patrol Program conference. </P>  <P align=justify>The province has 1,600 COP volunteers in 58 groups. Sparwood said his group's 50 to 60 members walk through the town at night "looking for trouble." </P>  <P align=justify>He said they report to the RCMP by cellphone any licence plates of out-of-town vehicles that are in suspicious locations. </P>  <P>The provincial network is co-ordinated by Manitoba Public Insurance, which relies on the volunteers as one way of reducing auto thefts.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 10-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Minister supports vets’ plates
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    May.15/04    Page A6
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>TRANSPORTATION Minister Ron Lemieux says Manitoba veterans should be able to get licence plates that commemorate their service to Canada before next winter. Lemieux made the announcement yesterday, two days after Tory MLA Ralph Eichler introduced a private member's bill to create veteran commemorative licence plates in Manitoba. The plates would be similar to those available in Ontario, New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, and will likely have a poppy and the word veteran on them. </P>  <P>"This is just a small way of recognizing people who put their life on the line for us," Lemieux said. "It's a small symbol to show our appreciation." </P>  <P>Lemieux says he was thinking of doing this before Eichler introduced his private member's bill, although he never mentioned that when interviewed about the Tory MLA's legislation. </P>  <P>Eichler laughed when told Lemieux was taking credit for it, but said he isn't that worried about who thought of it first. He said he's just glad it's going to happen. </P>  <P>"It's going to make the legionnaires ecstatic," Eichler said. </P>  <P>Lemieux said he didn't know how much the plates will cost. He said a department staff member is consulting with officials in the other three provinces to find out how the program worked there.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 11-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: POLICE CRACK DOWN ON ROAD VIOLATIONS: Officers Out In Force On Long Weekend
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May 18/04  Page B3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>POLICE across Manitoba will be out in full force this weekend cracking down on impaired drivers, speeders and people who still refuse to buckle up. <BR>The traffic enforcement program is part of Canada Road Safety Week and will see police across the country out on the roads and highways for the first long weekend of the summer. <BR>RCMP Const. Eric Edmonds said yesterday police will also target drivers who ignore stop or yield signs and red lights at major intersections. <BR>Edmonds also said there has been fewer traffic deaths in rural Manitoba so far this year compared to this time in 2003; 13 people have been killed this year in collisions, compared to 17 people at this time last year. <BR>Edmonds said what's not known is whether tougher penalties against people caught not wearing seatbelts is behind that reduction. <BR>But he said anecdotal evidence from Mounties on the front-line indicates that's the case. Edmonds said RCMP will conduct a more detailed survey shortly to see if more motorists and their passengers are belted in. <BR>The province recently raised the fine for not wearing a seatbelt to $230, up from $100. Since Nov. 1, Manitoba drivers who are caught not wearing seatbelts have also been assessed two driver's licence demerit points. The increased fine and demerits were brought in to get more Manitobans to use seatbelts. The province has one of the worst records for compliance in Canada. <BR>In Winnipeg, there have been 46 road deaths since 2002. <BR>Canada Road Safety Week is sponsored by Transport Canada as part of Road Safety Vision 2010, which has a goal of making Canada's roads the safest in the world by 2010. The goal is to reduce traffic fatalities or serious injuries by 30 per cent by the year 2010. <BR>In a recent study, Transport Canada said there were 2,778 deaths due to motor vehicle traffic collisions in the year 2001 -- a rate of 8.9 deaths per 100,000 population. <BR>In 2000-2001 there were 24,403 hospital admissions for traffic-related injuries for a rate of 79 hospitalizations per 100,000 population. Transport Canada also says drivers account for more than half of all road users killed. Risk increases with driver inexperience and health limitations common among elderly drivers. <BR>Many Canadians also die in single-vehicle crashes or rollovers on undivided rural roads. Drinking and driving also remains a problem along with non-use of seat belts. Approximately 40 per cent of all fatally injured occupants are unrestrained and of these almost half are ejected from their vehicles. <BR>Transport Canada also says driver distraction -- including talking on a cellphone -- is another factor in deadly car crashes. <BR><A href="mailto:bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca">bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P>

Title: 12-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [PHOTO] THREE INJURED
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Three people were taken to Concordia Hospital yesterday morning in stable condition after their vehicle rolled over at Winona Street and Kildare Avenue in Transcona.</P>  <P>-30-</P>

Title: 13-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MAN IN CRITICAL AFTER ROLLOVER  BY STAFF
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A 40-year-old man remained in critical condition yesterday in Health Sciences Centre after a single-vehicle rollover just outside the city.</P>  <P>The accident occurred about 11 p.m. Monday in the RM of Springfield when the man's southbound vehicle slid into the ditch on Dundee Garson Road and rolled repeatedly, said Oakbank Mounties. The man - an RM of Springfield resident - was thrown from the vehicle, said RCMP.</P>  <P>-30-</P>

Title: 14-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: TRUCKS REPAIRED, RECYCLING RETURNS TO NORMALCY
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May.19/04  Page B4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>THE city's recycling service is back to normal less than a week after vandals trashed many of the collection trucks. </P>  <P>Dan McInnes, the city's solid waste services division manager, said the 16 trucks were fixed by yesterday morning. </P>  <P>"It's a miracle," McInnes said yesterday. </P>  <P>"I was really surprised because it was so fast. It's great news." </P>  <P>McInnes said he was expecting the backlog of recycling would be picked up by last night. Sixteen of the 23 trucks owned by International Paper Industries Ltd., which won the city's contract for recycling last year, had their windshields smashed and radiators punctured while parked in the company's 1029 Henry Ave. garage last week. </P>  <P>Winnipeg police are continuing to investigate the vandalism. </P>  <P>McInnes thanked Winnipeggers for their understanding.</P>  <P><BR>-30-</P>

Title: 15-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: EWATSKI RIPS RAMMERS: ‘They’re Trying To Injure Our Police Officers’
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>The city's top cop says courts must come down hard on car thieves who deliberately ram police cruisers. Winnipeg police Chief Jack Ewatski was reacting to last week's rash of five high-speed pursuits in three days. The suspects in at least three of the chases allegedly tried to disable the pursuing police cars by crashing into them. </P>  <P>"I don't understand the mentality. They're trying to injure our police officers. That's something that can't be tolerated," Ewatski told The Sun yesterday. </P>  <P>"The courts have to look at those circumstances and deal with them in a severe manner. </P>  <P>When somebody goes and intentionally tries to injure a police officer, that has to be dealt with in a manner that sends a very strong message -- that an attack against a police officer is an attack against society." </P>  <P>'THEY THINK IT'S A GAME' </P>  <P>Ewatski, who joined the Winnipeg police in 1973 -- a time when young people stopped when police ordered them to pull over -- said some teens appear to want to be chased. </P>  <P>"Some of them have this bravado mentality where they think it's a game," he said. "But it's a game that could result in some tragic consequences, not only for themselves but for other people, too." </P>  <P>The police chief said countless innocent lives have been lost across North America in stolen vehicle-related crashes. </P>  <P>"I don't see what the joy is in joyriding. It's a very dangerous thing to do," he added. "I would urge these people who are thinking of going out and stealing vehicles to really think of the consequences." </P>  <P>Violence against cops reached a shocking level last Saturday in Ontario with the apparent premeditated fatal throat-slashing of a 39-year-old Cobourg police officer. </P>  <P>"I was terribly saddened. I was shocked by the circumstances of it," Ewatski said. </P>  <P>"If anybody has a plan and wants to try and carry that plan out, that type of individual has to be dealt with in the most severe fashion."</P>  <P>-30-</P>

Title: 16-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RECYCLING FLEET ROLLS AGAIN
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Recycling in Winnipeg is back on track. Last Tuesday, two-thirds of International Paper Industries' fleet of 23 recycling trucks were rendered unusable after vandals broke into a North End compound, punched out windows and smashed radiators. </P>  <P>Solid waste services manager Dan McInnis said the "wanton destruction" cost thousands of dollars and forced employees to work overtime. </P>  <P>Yesterday, officials said the vehicles have been repaired and the schedule has returned to normal.</P>  <P>-30-</P>

Title: 17-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: HIGH-LIFE HYDRO SCAMMER AWAITS SENTENCE
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May.20/04  Page B1/B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A Winnipeg Hydro employee seen as a role model by co-workers was leading a bizarre double life, quietly pocketing $290,000 in company funds that he spent on vacations, fancy hotels and a stream of prostitutes and escorts. </P>  <P>Larry Lapointe, 42, kept the scam secret for more than five years until it -- and his life -- unravelled in January 2003 when he was hospitalized with life-threatening flesh-eating disease. </P>  <P>"It was just too easy," Lapointe told police last fall when asked why he committed a crime that devastated Hydro employees and sank morale so low that a grief counsellor was called in. </P>  <P>Lapointe's sentencing hearing began yesterday after he pleaded guilty to theft over $5,000. </P>  <P>Crown attorney Don Melnyk is seeking three years in prison for Lapointe, who has no prior criminal record but committed a major breach of trust that the prosecutor says cries out for serious punishment. </P>  <P>"This was someone who was seen by staff as a role model, mentor and a trusted friend," said Melnyk. Lapointe has asked for a conditional sentence, which would allow him to remain free in the community under certain restrictions. A pre-sentence report portrays him as an extremely low risk to reoffend. </P>  <P>Provincial court Judge Howard Collerman plans to give a decision today. Lapointe has since made a recovery from the flesh-eating virus, but still receives treatments to his leg, defence lawyer Rocky Pollack said yesterday. </P>  <P>He is on anti-depressants and has told friends he wishes he had died rather than face the people he betrayed, he said. </P>  <P>Lapointe has spent all the money and has since declared bankruptcy. He made numerous trips to Las Vegas, Mexico, Banff and other Canadian cities and was an avid gambler, court was told yesterday. He often bought women in his office flowers and lunches, and credit card records show he was a frequent customer of escort agencies and phone dating services. He often booked rooms for several days at a time at downtown hotels. </P>  <P>Lapointe also admitted retaining the services of prostitutes. Other expenses included a golf membership, Manitoba Theatre Centre tickets and fancy dinners. </P>  <P>"This was not an individual who was stealing in order to survive," Collerman noted yesterday. </P>  <P>Lapointe committed the deception while working as head cashier at Winnipeg Hydro's former Mandarin Building facilities at 223 James Ave. He was also the unit vice-president for CUPE Local 500, representing Hydro employees in the civic union. The utility was purchased two years ago by Manitoba Hydro. </P>  <P>Lapointe avoided detection by using the passwords of 14 co-workers to get into the computer system and move money from account to account. He stole funds on 331 separate occasions beginning in 1996 and always kept on top of which he accounts he had to "top up," court was told yesterday. </P>  <P>He targeted corporations with large monthly hydro bills such as Manitoba Public Insurance and MTS, where he believed there was less chance of detection. Lapointe also falsified bank deposits, which proved to be his undoing. </P>  <P>He left work feeling ill on the same day he accidentally sent the Royal Bank a deposit slip for a $47,000 cheque he had used to pay off other accounts from which he'd stolen. Hydro began investigating, and realized the magnitude of the crime weeks later when Lapointe was laid up in hospital recovering from surgery for the flesh-eating disease that ravaged his leg. </P>  <P>Provincial authorities called to inquire why a $32,000 cheque had cleared their accounts, but hadn't registered on that month's hydro bill. Due to his illness, Lapointe couldn't move the funds around to cover his tracks. </P>  <P>Hydro conducted an audit, and initial suspicion fell on all 14 co-workers whose identities Lapointe had used in the computer system.</P>  <P><BR>-30-</P>

Title: 18-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: THIEVES TARGET RARE TRANS AM: BRAZEN DAYLIGHT HEIST WITH TOW TRUCK
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>Car thieves with a tow truck snatched a luxury sports car from a busy parking lot in a brazen daylight heist Monday. "I'm stunned. It really just floored me that you can have every alarm and it doesn't matter because somebody can pull up and just tow your car away," said Shael Lander, whose 2002 Pontiac Trans Am was towed from Heavenly Bodies Fitness Centre, at 2146 Main St.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>His wife, Rice Lander, who works at a hair salon inside the gym, parked the bright red Trans Am outside work that morning.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>It had an alarm system and an immobilizer.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <H6 align=left><SPAN lang=EN-GB>'I COULDN'T BELIEVE IT'   <P></P></SPAN></H6>  <P><SPAN>When she left for lunch after 2 p.m., she discovered the car missing.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"I stood there with a dumbfounded look on my face thinking, 'where's my car?' I couldn't believe it. I just kept walking outside thinking it would still be there."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>A woman exercising at the gym told police she saw an unmarked pink tow truck picking up the car. The woman had not known she had been witnessing a theft in progress, Rice said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The couple paid $38,000 for the car. It had been specially ordered in January 2002, Rice said. It had a tan leather interior and a distinctive ram air hood.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>They weren't behind on their payments, Shael said. The couple has made a claim with Manitoba Public Insurance, but is devastated by the loss.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>At their wedding last September, they had their pictures taken with the Trans Am and had a cake made in the shape of it.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"It was our baby. They don't make them anymore. You can't replace it. We babied it," she said. "It's just not fair. We work hard to get something special and it's just not fair for someone to take it away."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said thieves who use tow trucks aren't common in Winnipeg.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"But we know they exist," he said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Cars stolen by such methods are either sold for parts or shipped to other provinces or countries for sale, he said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The stolen auto unit knows of the scam, though it is rare, said Winnipeg police spokeswoman Const. Shelly Glover.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"We don't see it very often either, though certainly it would take some sophistication," he said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The Landers ask anyone with information on their missing Trans Am to call 777-7923.</SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN>-30-<SPAN><BR clear=all></P></SPAN></SPAN>

Title: 19-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MANIAC DRIVER INJURES TEACHER: RUN OVER ON SCHOOL GROUNDS
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><SPAN>A young teacher was struck down in the parking lot of an </SPAN><SPAN>East Kildonan</SPAN><SPAN> high school yesterday in front of dozens of students heading home for the day. Class had just let out about 3:10 p.m. when some teachers and students noticed a blue Honda Accord driving fitfully in a grassy field connected to the school's parking lot.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"He was driving in the field and trying to have fun in the field," said Kildonan East Collegiate Grade 12 student Brandon Kudlak.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>He said carpentry teacher Grant Smart, who's worked at the school for about three years, walked over to the field, stood in the only exit wide enough for the vehicle to fit through and motioned for the driver of the Honda to stop.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Instead, Kudlak said the driver -- who witnesses believe didn't attend the school -- pointed the car right at the teacher.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"He didn't even attempt to slow so (Smart) could get out of the way," he said.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>The teacher became lodged under the vehicle and was dragged for a short distance before dropping off in the parking lot, said Kudlak.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"He was crying, moaning and screaming, rolling around," said the teen, adding he believed Smart's leg and hip were broken. "He was pretty mangled."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Electrical teacher Gord O'Brien said he was called out from the school to help because of his experience with first-aid.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"He was lying on the ground, his arms were all gushing blood," said O'Brien. "He couldn't feel his hip."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Paramedics took Smart to Concordia Hospital in stable condition and police taped off the area where Smart had been lying, with a shoe and a sock and a small pool of blood.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Meanwhile, witnesses said the Honda ripped out of the parking lot and turned onto London Street.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Teenager Luis Sorto, a Grade 11 student at nearby Miles MacDonnell Collegiate, was behind the wheel of his parents' car on Concordia Avenue when he noticed the Honda coming toward him.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <H6 align=left><SPAN lang=EN-GB>SUSPECT ARRESTED   <P></P></SPAN></H6>  <P><SPAN>"He was going pretty fast to get out of here," said Sorto. "I saw him coming down and he just hit me."   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>Sorto said a police cruiser was already following the blue car when the accident occurred. Officers arrested a suspect a short time later.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>O'Brien said he's been at K.E. since 1985 and he knows schoolyards can be the scene of some unusual things -- but yesterday's situation was a new one on him.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN>"I've never heard of anything as strange as this," O'Brien said. "Our parking lot is usually pretty calm.   <P></P></SPAN>  <P></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN>-30-   <P></P></SPAN>

Title: 21-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [photo]: seatbelts for dummies
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ramsay Huska demonstrates a rollover simulator to students at the MPI compound yesterday. The dummies used were not belted into the Ford F-150 cab. Spinning at 110 revolutions per minute, a 75 km/h rollover is simulated and after a few spins the dummies are thrown from the cab.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 22-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'death strip, kills again: At Least Two Feared Dead In Fiery Disaster
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, MB  Free Press  May.21/04    Page A1/A4
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: By Paul egan and Bruce owen
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">KENORA -- At least two people are believed dead following a pileup of four and possibly five tractor-trailers early yesterday on a stretch of the Trans-Canada highway known as the "death strip." <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The accident shut one of the busiest highways in Canada all day as police and emergency personnel tried to deal with the twisted, smouldering wreckage. The highway is expected to reopen today. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police believe four trucks, and possibly a fifth, were involved in the collision on Hwy. 17 in northwestern Ontario, about 20 kilometres east of Kenora. At least two of the tractor-trailers burst into flames and burned beyond recognition. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">There was some concern a third truck also burned up, but the damage was so severe that police won't know for sure until the blackened hulks are removed from the highway, likely sometime today. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The drivers of the burned trucks have been listed as missing until police can verify human remains. Firefighters were on the scene until late afternoon dousing the wreckage with water. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Two of the trucking firms involved have offices in Winnipeg; Gardewine North and Day &amp; Ross Inc. Officials from both firms were unavailable.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The collision happened at about 1 a.m. at a sharp, rising corner of Hwy. 17 one-and-a-half kilometres east of the junction of Hwy. 71, which is 18 kilometres east of Kenora. Hwy. 17 is part of the Trans-Canada Highway network and is one of the busiest truck routes in Canada. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The route between Kenora and Vermilion Bay has been dubbed the "death strip" because of a high number of fatal collisions in the past decade. The twisting, two-lane highway snakes through the rocky Canadian Shield. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ontario Provincial Police spokeswoman Const. Sue Cain said investigators were not able to publicly identify the missing truckers or the province in which the trucks were registered. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Two other people, a truck driver and a passenger, were seriously injured in the mishap and are now at Health Sciences Centre in Winnipeg. Their truck did not catch fire. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Another truck crashed into a rock face near the highway; the driver and passenger were not injured. They apparently swerved to miss the accident. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Cain said police were not able to comment on what caused the mishap, but people at the scene believe one of the trucks was trying to pass another at the blind curve. It may have been raining at the time. There were thunderstorms in the area. Bob Dolyniuk, general manager of the Manitoba Trucking Association, said the accident highlights two things: Government must put more money into making highways safer, and that police must do more to crack down on speeding. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"There are professional drivers and there are other drivers," Dolyniuk said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The Manitoba Trucking Association has also long lobbied for the route between Dryden and Kenora to be twinned. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Arnold Brothers driver Dan Yeryk of Winnipeg said putting in another two lanes would make the road safer. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"This should all be four-lane, that's my opinion," he said. "It's dangerous. You've got to use a lot of common sense." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Yeryk was sent to Kenora from Winnipeg to relieve another driver who was bringing a load of mail from Eastern Canada. That driver had been behind the wheel for 13 hours -- about four of those hours were spent detouring around the wreck site. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">All traffic was re-routed south on Hwy. 71 to Hwy. 11 and east to Hwy. 502 and back north to Hwy. 17 at Dryden. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The stretch of Hwy. 17 where the accident occurred is a two-lane, undivided highway with a speed limit of 90 km/h. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A spokesman for the Ontario Ministry of Transportation said in the past four years, the Ontario government has repaved the road surface, installed paved shoulders, put up larger road signage, improved marking on the pavement, added passing lanes and built "rumble strips" along the highway's edge. (Rumble strips noisily alert the driver if a vehicle strays onto the highway shoulder.) Several rock faces were also removed to widen the roadway. Harold Rabb, manager of Emergency Medical Services in northwestern Ontario, said the highway has improved 100 per cent since being upgraded. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We're going to see fewer accidents," he said. "It's night and day. The problem is keeping people awake. Most of the accidents happen after midnight and that's when people fall asleep." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He said another problem behind many accidents are drivers pulling out to pass and slamming into oncoming traffic. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The majority of collisions are due to driver error," Cain added, saying that includes impairment, speeding or talking on a cellphone. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The highway improvements came after a 1997 <EM><SPAN style="FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Reader's Digest</SPAN></EM> article that described Hwy. 17 -- the 71 kilometres between Kenora and Vermilion Bay -- as the "death strip." At the time, it had half the traffic volume but three times the accident rate of the highway east of Vermilion Bay. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Don and Harriet Schulpius of St. Germaine, Wis., said yesterday they spend every summer at a campground near the crash scene. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">They said it's remarkable Canada's national highway is not four-lane coast-to-coast. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"From what I can guess, they've been talking about four-laning it forever and you're probably going to get this until they do," Don Schulpius said. "Two-lane highways today are really outdated."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:Bruce.owen@freepress.ca">Bruce.owen@freepress<SPAN style="mso-bookmark: _Hlt72895205">.</SPAN>mb.ca</A><A name=_Hlt72895205></A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:Paul.Egan@freepress.mb.ca">Paul.Egan@freepress.mb.ca</A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 23-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Automotive Showcase: please, use some common sense
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, MB    Sun    May.21/04    Page A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Let&#8217;s get serious for a second here.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Last month on Oprah, a woman was describing the &#8220;worst day of her life&#8221; and, after listening to her story, it wasn&#8217;t even close.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She&#8217;ll never have a worse day than this one.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The day started off like any other &#8212; she picked up her children (four boys, ranging in age from 7 years old to a newborn) from school.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Because three of the four kids were still rather young, she strapped them in their car seats in the van &#8212; a smart move for any parent, right?<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Right.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Before they headed out to dinner, she had to return home and drop off their pet bird, as one of the children had brought it to school. She pulled up in front of her apartment building and ran upstairs to drop the bird off, a task that would only take two minutes.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She left the children in the van.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">For three years now, General Motors has been working in association with the National Safe Kids Campaign getting the word out about the dangers of leaving young children in vehicles.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">From 1996, GM researchers count 228 children deaths in the </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">United States</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> as a result of this careless behaviour &#8212; a number that only included those instances covered by the media. According to GM research, there were almost 70% more of such fatalities reported in2003 than in 2002.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Since the &#8220;Never Leave Your Child Alone&#8221; campaign started, it was only aimed at the parents, trying to change their behaviour before an accident happens. Leaving kids in the car on a hot day, keeping the children in an unattended vehicle, or leaving the car unlocked in the driveway are the three biggest abuses committed by caregivers.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">This year the program is directed at every-one, as the message still isn&#8217;t getting across to some people with young children.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;Many of these deaths happen when a child is left behind or forgotten by an adult, while others occur when a child gains access to an unlocked car and can not get out,&#8221; says Dr. Angela Mickalide, program director of the National Safe Kids Campaign.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;We want parents to know that leaving a child alone in a vehicle, even for a few minutes, is never OK.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;We also want people to know that if they see a small child alone in a vehicle, they need to get help.&#8221;<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Studies by GM of Canada and Dr. Oded Bar-Or of McMaster University have shown just how easy it is for children to suffer a fatal dose of heatstroke.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A 2001 study discovered that a child left in a hot, closed vehicle in dry heat could face serious risk of injury or death in just a few minutes. A more recent study, released last year, showed that humid heat could increase the onset of a serious injury or death in half the time.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">These studies should convince people that keeping the children in a car &#8212; even if the window is cracked open &#8212; is not a good thing. But perhaps the story told by the woman on Oprah will drive that point home better.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">When the woman hurried back to the vehicle, the worst day of her life started.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The van was on fire.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">One of the children &#8212; the oldest one not in a child seat &#8212; had started a piece of paper on fire with a lighter. The boy couldn&#8217;t put the fire out, and it quickly spread throughout the inside of the van. He couldn&#8217;t get any of his brothers out of their seats, nor could he get his own seatbelt off.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Fortunately, the four boys survived, but all were severely burned &#8212; some to the point of being deformed. Everything changed for the boys and the mother, and all it took was two measly minutes.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Scary isn&#8217;t it?<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 24-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Automakers lead the way in side-impact airbags
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, MB    Sun    May.21/04    Page A24
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">When it comes to saving lives, it&#8217;s the most important auto safety regulation in years<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But the impact of the National Highway Traffic SafetyAdministration&#8217;s new rule on side crashes, estimated to save close to 1,000 lives a year, is lessened by efforts already underway by automakers.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">NHTSA is proposing a standard that vehicles must meet to protect occupants in a side-impact accident<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But carmakers already are rushing to install head-protecting side air bags to do well on an insurance industry side crash test and to meet voluntary auto industry guidelines. The most notable effects of the new </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:country-region><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">U.S.</SPAN></st1:place></st1:country-region><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> rule are that automakers likely will have to install a certain type of head-protecting side air bag, known as a side-curtain air bag. And they likely will be forced to include side-curtain bags in even their largest sport-utility vehicles and pickups.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Rather than side curtains, some automakers have been installing air bags that deploy in one piece to protect the head and torso. Those probably won&#8217;t be sufficient to meet the standard.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Also the biggest SUVs and pickups are not tested by the insurance industry group, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, nor would the big trucks have needed the side curtains to meet the voluntary guidelines.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">NHTSA is not expected to specifically require side curtains &#8212; its rules typically set performance, not technology, requirements. But stricter limits on head injuries and the new test procedure will make it all but impossible to meet the rule without them, industry officials familiar with the proposal say.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">NHTSA is expected to propose a crash test that uses a pole that hits the car from the front at a side angle. If the top part of the head-and torso-protecting side air bag now found on many vehicles were not wide enough, the pole could hit the test dummy&#8217;s head. Curtains<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">extend the length or a window&#8212; and often into the rear seat of the car &#8212; to protect of heads of all occupants seated near doors<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">IIHS estimates that head-protecting air bags reduce the risk of death in a side crash by 45%.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Among automakers who already are moving toward side curtains: </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Toyota</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. which has them as standard or optional equipment on 18 of 25 </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Toyota</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> and Lexus models; General Motors, which meets the industry guidelines on 25% of its vehicles; Ford Motor, which has side curtains in many Ford, Lincoln and Mercury models, including the new Ford Freestar and Mercury Monterey minivans.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Chris Tinto, </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Toyota</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8217;s safety director, says the new federal rule will likely require changes beyond the installation of side curtains. &#8220;It will drive some different structural designs and improved sensors for side curtains,&#8221; he says.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">IIHS, which has been performing side crash tests since last summer, has found the levels of protection offered by different types of side and head air bags can vary widely.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Without any head protection, none of the small sport-utility vehicles or midsize inexpensive cars tested have performed well in the tests.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But when tested with optional side air bags that included head protection &#8212; either as a curtain or as part of the bag &#8212; vehicles including the Ford Escape SUV and Toyota Canny scored &#8220;good.&#8221;<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But GM&#8217;s Saturn L series, which has a side curtain, scored &#8220;poor&#8221; because the curtain did not reach down far enough to protect the small-sized &#8220;female&#8221; dummy IIHS used.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Adrian Lund, IIHS chief operating officer, expects most vehicles will have side curtains by 2007, when automakers have voluntarily agreed to have half of their fleets meet the industry side-impact standards. </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lund</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> says all automakers have been making changes to improve their scores on IIHS&#8217; highly publicized tests.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 25-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: FIERY TRUCK PILEUP  At Least Two Dead After Four  Semis Crash And Burn
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It was such a horrific crash that Ontario Provincial Police had yet to provide a final tally on the number of victims by press time last night. And the scene, a stretch of the Trans-Canada Highway east of Kenora, was expected to be closed to traffic for about 24 hours. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Every year there seems to be a couple of bad accidents on that stretch. I think this one can only be termed as 'horrific,' " said Bob Dolyniuk, general manager of the Manitoba Trucking Association. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">At least two people were killed in the fiery pileup early yesterday morning involving five tractor-trailers on Highway 17 about 1.5 kilometres east of Highway 71 in Ontario. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Four of the semis collided about 1 a.m. in a massive wreck in the middle of the highway which soon became a fireball that lit up the dark sky. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"At least one of the tractor-trailer units burst into flames following the collision, which resulted in a fire that involved several of the other tractor-trailer units," said OPP spokeswoman Const. Sue Cain. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H1 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB">PRESUMED DEAD <o:p></o:p></SPAN></H1>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Three of the units were destroyed in the blaze, which took Longbow Lake firefighters several hours to douse. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">An unknown number of occupants were unaccounted for and presumed dead. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver and passenger of the fourth transport truck were rescued and taken to Lake of the Woods District Hospital, then transferred to Health Sciences Centre in Winnipeg. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A fifth semi struck a rock cut in an attempt to avoid the collision, said OPP spokeswoman Sue Cain. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver and passenger of that vehicle were uninjured and walked away from the crash. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The semi was from a Winnipeg outlet of eastern Canada trucking company Day &amp; Ross Inc. A New Brunswick-based spokesman for the company couldn't be reached for comment yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">One of the other semi-trailers was from trucking company Gardewine North in Winnipeg. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver was among the victims who were unaccounted for, said a company employee. Gardewine officials declined comment yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Among the semi's haul were 9,300 issues of yesterday's Wawatay News -- an aboriginal newspaper published every two weeks and distributed in Sioux Lookout, Ont. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Our understanding is the papers burned in the crash," said managing editor Bryan Phelan. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The newspapers had been picked up in Kenora, where they had been printed at the Kenora Daily Miner and News. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Many motorists have died on Highway 17 near Kenora over the past several years. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It is a bad stretch there," said an employee of nearby Redden's Camp and Trailer Park, who didn't want her name used. "That stretch of road is not a good road. I don't know what it is." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Between 1,500 and 2,000 trucks travel through the area daily -- not including other traffic, said Dolyniuk. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's a very busy highway," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Dolyniuk said he wonders if enough tax revenue is being poured into highway maintenance and whether police are doing enough to enforce the speed limit. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"You have to wonder what kind of enforcement is out there and is it tough enough," he said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN>

Title: 26-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: OFF BEAT: SENTENCED TO WATCH SURGERY OF VICTIM
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">BUENOS AIRES -- An Argentine bus driver must watch surgery being performed on a traffic accident victim as part of his punishment for striking and killing an 11-year-old boy, a judge said on Friday. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"This is an important legal warning to people who violate transit laws," said Judge Cesar Raul Jimenez of the northern province of Misiones, calling the unusual sentence an "educational measure." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ramon Rodriguez Dos Santos, 44, was convicted of manslaughter after his bus collided with the child on a scooter. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The judge also barred him from driving for five years and gave him a two-year suspended prison sentence.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-TRANSFORM: uppercase; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-TRANSFORM: uppercase; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 27-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: ATVers WARNED AFTER FATAL WEEKEND ROLLOVER
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police are reminding ATV enthusiasts to wear a helmet and drive with caution after a fatal rollover on the weekend that claimed the life of a 38-year-old man. David Bate, a resident of the Rural Municipality of Springfield, lost control of the four-wheel, all-terrain vehicle he was driving within several miles of his home Sunday night. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's very unfortunate. We don't like to see these things happen. We like to see people drive responsibly, wear a helmet, take safety precautions," said Cpl. Mark Bingham of the Oakbank RCMP detachment. "Remember that you have family and loved ones to go home to." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Bate, who was not wearing a helmet, was pronounced dead at the scene. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">His family declined comment yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A passing motorist spotted Bate's ATV in the ditch about 8:30 p.m. and alerted emergency personnel. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police believe the machine rolled while Bate travelled alone westbound on Hazelridge Road, about eight kilometres north of Anola, east of Highway 12. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The Mounties are awaiting results of a traffic analyst report to find out if speed played a role. They don't believe alcohol was a factor. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We see too many of these things happen," Bingham said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Bate's death is the second fatal accident involving off-road vehicles in as many days. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">On Saturday, experienced motocross enthusiast Robin Onosson, 29, of Winnipeg, was killed while executing a jump at a gravel pit near Lac du Bonnet. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police said Onosson took the proper safety precautions and called his death a freak accident. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Last June, Portage la Prairie resident Bradley Ryan Cress died when he lost control of his four-wheel ATV as he rounded a corner and hit a tree at Delta Beach, a small community on Lake Manitoba. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H1 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 3pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB">WASN'T WEARING HELMET <o:p></o:p></SPAN></H1>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The 25-year-old wasn't wearing a helmet. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Three months earlier, Winnipegger Ryan Shymkiw, 30, died after losing control of his ATV along Wyper Road near McGillivray Boulevard when he struck a muddy rut and flew off the machine. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">At the time, family told The Sun Shymkiw wasn't wearing a helmet. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">In May 2002, 24-year-old Michael Roulston of Kenora was killed when the ATV he was driving skidded on a gravel road and went into a ditch while he tried to turn a corner.</SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 28-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: TRUCKERS HAVE TOUGH HAUL
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Re: Drivers, not road, the problem (Martin Speight letter, May 22). <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">My husband is a long-distance truck driver and I've had the opportunity to go on several trips with him through both Canada and the U.S. I won't deny there are truckers out there who drive in a manner which could be dangerous, however most people have no clue as to what they have to put up with from other vehicles on the road. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">On many occasions I have been completely appalled at the way four-wheelers drive when around a semi. From darting in front to riding the back end, I've even seen cars force trucks onto the shoulder. There are constantly people honking or shouting at you when the light turns to green and you don't get through in less than five seconds; how fast could your car go if you had 100,000 pounds of weight and 15 gears to go through just to get moving? <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The fact is that the majority of semi trucks are governed at a speed of 110 km/h so while a small number might be able to ride your back end at 120, for most it's not even an option. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Nevada Gergatz, </SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg Beach <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Thanks for sharing the view from the cab.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 29-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: LOCAL BRIEFS: THREE HELD AFTER COP CAR RAMMED
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police arrested three males after a Winnipeg police cruiser was rammed by a stolen car in the North End about 4:30 a.m. yesterday. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The car chase ended when the police car was hit at Aberdeen Avenue and Parr Street. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The police vehicle was not damaged and there were no injuries, police say. No names were released.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoHeading7 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 3pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">II<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H5 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB">Impaired drivers arrested<o:p></o:p></SPAN></H5>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police arrested four impaired drivers and laid 13 charges under the Highway Traffic Act during checkstops on Saturday night. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Headingley RCMP, Selkirk Traffic Services, East St. Paul Police Service and Winnipeg Police Service joined forces and stopped 600 vehicles. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoBodyText style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The checkstops coincided with Canada Road Safety Week.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 30-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the editor: MAKE HIGHWAY FOUR LANES
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May.25/04  Page A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Re: the May 21 article 'Death strip' kills again. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Again our pathetic, under-funded national Trans-Canada Highway has taken more lives. When is the federal government going to take responsibility and fix our national highway? <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">With over a billion-plus dollars wasted on a national gun registry program that has not been proven to have saved a single life, and the dollars squandered on the sponsorship scandal in Quebec, I hope our federal government is proud of what it has accomplished. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">If this money had been spent on our national highway, lives would be saved every day. It should be four lanes from coast to coast, with no level crossings and no lights, just like the U.S. interstate highways. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Oh, there will always be those why say "If this highway should be four lane, then so should all the highways in Canada, it's only driver error that causes accidents." This isn't so. We all know that when the volume of traffic goes up, so does the potential for accidents. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">On a four-lane highway with a decent separation between opposing lanes, the potential for head-on collisions is virtually eliminated, as well as driver frustration, and the need to use the oncoming lanes for passing. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">ROY MILLARD, </SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 31-Aug-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MOTOCROSS ACCIDENT DEADLY: Man, 29, Catapulted Over Handle Bars Following Jump
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May.25/04  Page B/B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">ROBIN Onosson lived for riding his motocross bike, but in the end his passion turned deadly. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Onosson, 29, died Saturday afternoon after being catapulted over the handle bars of his motorcycle when his front wheel suddenly lodged in a depression after jumping over the lip of a hill at a sand pit popular with motocross riders south of Lac du Bonnet. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Onosson's 28-year-old girlfriend Mandy, who asked that her last name not be used, watched in horror as her boyfriend landed on his head and rolled to a stop just metres away from where she was sitting snapping photographs of his jump. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"When I saw it happen I ran to him and undid his helmet," Mandy said. "I was kind of freaking out. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I didn't try CPR. Someone was yelling at me not to move him. I don't know if it would have made any difference. I couldn't tell if he was breathing, but one guy said he was breathing, but I think he was lying. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"His eyes were open, but he never woke up at all. I don't think he was in pain. He died instantly." On Sunday, Onosson's girlfriend, relatives and friends gathered at his house to mourn a motocross biker who had years of experience and was planning to ride soon in his first competitive race. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Everyone said Onosson always made sure he wore the proper equipment. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Onosson would have celebrated his 30th birthday yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Anybody you talk to can give fond memories of him," Mandy said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"He was loved by everyone." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Onosson, who has three brothers, including <EM><SPAN style="FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">New Meanies'</SPAN></EM> bassist Sky Onosson, grew up in Charleswood. He attended Beaumont School, Westdale School and Oak Park High/Ecole Secondaire Oak Park, all in Charleswood, before taking courses at South Winnipeg Technical Centre and becoming a machinist. He worked at Custom Castings Ltd., and before that Pritchard Engineering.
