"There was nothing he could do." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lansall, 35, who lived in Winnipeg, was likely killed instantly when the other truck hit him head-on. The three occupants in the east-bound truck were also killed. Both trucks then caught fire. A third truck rear-ended Lansall's truck and a fourth crashed into a rock face to avoid the burning wrecks. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"He was the safest driver," Prefontaine said. "When he left I'd always tell him to drive careful and he'd say, 'I always do. It's the other idiots on the road that I worry about.' <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"He never took chances," she added of Lansall, who worked for Gardewine North for about four years. "If he was tired he'd pull over and sleep." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ontario Provincial Police spokesperson Sue Cain said police aren't able to release names of the dead or confirm Lansall was killed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">All were burned beyond recognition and police are hoping DNA testing will confirm their identities. That process should take a few weeks. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police are also still investigating what caused the crash. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In the meantime, Prefontaine said the waiting is prolonging the grief. A memorial service or burial can't be held until Lansall's remains are released. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He had left Winnipeg a short time earlier, hauling grocery products to Red Lake and Dryden before heading back to Winnipeg. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She said she learned of the collision when she saw in it Friday's newspaper. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I went out there on Saturday to see it for myself," she said. "You could tell by the damage everything happened in the east-bound lane. Nobody was passing anybody." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Prefontaine is also survived by his former wife and two teenage sons who live in Saskatchewan.&nbsp;</SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 15-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: POLICE, CAR BUFFS TO HOST SPECIAL DAY FOR CRUISERS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May 27/04  Page B12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">CITY police and local car buffs will hold a joint show-and-shine this weekend in a bid to cut down the number of complaints that come with Sunday night cruising and illegal street racing. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Organizers hope Saturday's event at Polo Park Shopping Centre will go a long way in telling cruisers what's allowed and what's not. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We're hoping that the information sharing will deal with the idiot factor," said Bob Chubala, chairman of the Manitoba Association of Auto Clubs. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The MAAC, The Winnipeg Police Service, Manitoba Vehicle Inspections and the Manitoba Safety Council will host the event. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It will take place between 10 a.m. and 3 p.m. and features trained officers conducting safety inspections and advising drivers of potential vehicle problems, like altered suspensions and too-dark window tinting. Any customized car, truck and motorcycle can be inspected. The public is also welcome. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police also say they will hand out information on potential fines and consequences of related Highway Traffic Act infractions. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Sgt. Larry Solilak said everyone is welcome and no one should fear being ticketed if the car, after inspection, doesn't meet road standards. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"But if someone squeals out from under our noses, obviously we have to do something," Solilak said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Participants are also eligible to win prizes sponsored by local auto clubs and businesses. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Murdoch MacKay Collegiate automotive instructor Bill McEwen said the event is also geared to getting young people out to meet and mix with custom car owners.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The intent is to get them to get more involved in car club activities and fundraising events. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">By getting more involved, young people develop the skills for a life-long hobby and maybe even learning a trade, he added. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">For example, McEwen got his students to build the Corsitour, two front-wheel-drive cars (a Chevy Corsica and Ford Contour) cut in and put back together into one car, but only the front ends. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The students show off the car, which can only be driven when one end of it is put in reverse and the other in drive. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Sunday night cruising has become a yearly summertime problem in Winnipeg with cars jamming up Main Street and Portage Avenue. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Loud stereos, noisy spectators, revving engines, squealing tires and the odd drag race at green lights have sparked a litany of complaints from nearby residents. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Efforts have been made each year by police and car clubs to contain the complaints, but so far only winter weather has had an impact.&nbsp;</SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 16-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'JOLLY BRIGHT' STUDENT DIES IN ROAD-RAGE HIT
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: NATIONAL, MB  Post  May 27/04  Page A2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoBodyText style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A Canadian graduate student died yesterday after a late-night attack on the streets of Cambridge, England, resulted in &#8220;non-survivable&#8221; injuries that put him in a coma.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Kenneth Sutherland, a 31-year-old from Palconbridge, Ont., who was in the second year of his PhD at Jesus College, Cambridge University, had enjoyed a night out drinking with friends in the city late Saturday, before an altercation with a passing motorist left him hospitalized.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The Jesus College chaplain, Reverend Jonathan Collis, described Mr. Sutherland&#8217;s death as a tragedy, and said he appeared to have been the victim of a bizarre, unprovoked road-rage attack.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">British sources said a passing motorist stopped because Mr. Sutherland was in the road. The Canadian was hit after insulting the driver during a confrontation.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Andrew Roberts, a 22-year-old Englishman, appeared in a Cambridge court on Tuesday and sobbed upon hearing that Mr. Sutherland was on life support.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He is charged with grievous bodily harm, which could become manslaughter or murder when he appears in court again at a later date, according to local police sources.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The family of Mr. Sutherland, who was pronounced dead yesterday afternoon, had flown to the United Kingdom to be with him and have given authorities permission for his organs to be removed for donation.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Known to his friends as &#8220;Ken,&#8221; Mr. Sutherland went to Cambridge University in January last year to pursue a PhD in geotechnical engineering, after working as a consultant for Golder Associates, an international mining firm, and completing a master of applied science at the University of Toronto.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He had been awarded several academic scholarships in both Canada and the U.K., and was one of 40 students on Cambridge University&#8217;s prestigious Geotechnical Engineering Research Group.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;He was very popular and very much a college man: sociable, outgoing and generally friendly,&#8221; said Rev. Collis, who gave Mr. Sutherland his last rites.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;This terrible event happened with a group of friends after an afternoon playing sport &#8212; typical of the type of person he was.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;He was a jolly bright lad who came from the back end of Ontario. You have to be pretty hot stuff to come here from that sort of background, full of determination and grit.&#8221;<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Mr. Sutherland&#8217;s colleagues were said to be devastated with news of his condition, which before his death had been described by the hospital as &#8220;critical&#8221; but the death was not expected to be announced in the college until today.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">All Cambridge students were warned to be on their guard this month after a spate of stabbings in the centre of the city, but police could not yet say whether the incidents had any connection with Mr. Sutherland&#8217;s assault.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;We do suffer from drink-related assaults here,&#8221; said a Duty Sergeant with the Cambridgeshire Constabulary.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;It&#8217;s not uncommon to have violent assaults in Cambridge, especially on a Saturday night, although it is uncommon for someone to die as a result&#8221;<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The Duty Sergeant speculated Mr. Sutherland received a single blow and may have been further injured when he struck something while falling.</SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 17-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: DRIVER DINGED FOR FACTORY TINT: Says cop 'overzealous'
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">A Winnipeg motorist is seeing red after a city cop told him his windows are too black. Bob Payne, 37, said he plans to fight the $105 ticket he received earlier this week for allegedly having illegally tinted windows on his 2002 Lexus RX300. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The luxury vehicle is a lease and the windows are factory tinted to Canadian standards, Payne told The Sun yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"It's just so extremely irritating that I have to take time out of my day to go to court and fight it," said Payne, the president and CEO of PrintCrafters, a general commercial printing company. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"It's not about the $105. The money doesn't matter to me." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Payne has complained to Winnipeg police, believing he is the victim of an overzealous cop. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">District 3 Insp. Keith McCaskill confirmed he spoke to Payne and is looking into the matter. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Payne was on his way to pick up his children from day care about 5 p.m. Tuesday when an officer pulled him over near Inkster Boulevard and McPhillips Street and started writing him a ticket. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H2 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: left" align=left><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'BURST OUT LAUGHING' <o:p></o:p></SPAN></H2>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"I burst out laughing and said, 'You're kidding me,'" he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Despite trying to reason with the officer and even contacting his dealership -- Woodhaven Lexus Toyota -- on his cellphone, Payne was ticketed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Tom Strange, Lexus sales manager at Woodhaven, said more than 250 identical RX300s -- worth about $53,000 in 2002 -- have been sold in the Winnipeg area between March 1998 and the spring of 2003. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"And the window tint has never changed since then," Strange said. "He was definitely unjustly given that ticket. It's our No. 1-selling vehicle and this has never come up before." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">An industry expert said cops have stepped up enforcement on tinted windows for two reasons -- officer safety and driver safety. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Under Manitoba law, the windshield of an SUV must allow 70% of light to be transmitted while the front-side windows can legally block out 55% of light, said Wes Anderson, president of Future Tint &amp; Stripe. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"If this gentleman or dealership didn't add any film, he shouldn't have any problem at all," Anderson said, adding there are no restrictions on the back windows of SUVs. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 18-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: SETTING RECORD STRAIGHT ON SCOOTER LICENCES
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Sun  May 28/04  Page A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I have no problem admitting when I&#8217;m wrong.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">A few weeks ago, the subject of scooters came up an one of the first questions I had about these little machines was about the licensing.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Could someone with a Class 5.0 licence drive one, and if not, then what permit is needed?<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I spoke with scooter dealers who assured me a Class 5.0 &#8211; a normal driver&#8217;s licence &#8211; is the only certification you need to get on one of these economical rides and zip off to work each day.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I had discussions with two friends of mine, both longtime scooter drivers. They are both law-abiding, professional men who use their scooters for merely financial purposes; not to look cool or cling to a previous era in their lives of being hip.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">They both are smart guys, and only have Class 5.0 licences, so I figured I was in the know on this aspect of this burgeoning scooter frenzy.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Nope.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I thought I had all my information correct regarding the licence requirements for operating a scooter but, after receiving a number of emails questioning the validity of my statements, I was forced to revisit the licence confusion.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Traci sent me a well-written tale of the headaches and frustration her husband faced when purchasing scooters. She writes:<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">&#8220;We only bought bikes this small because we were under the impression that we did not need a (motorcycle) licence. I&#8217;ve had my bike licence for 20 years or so, but my husband now has to get his and it is a graduated licence! To drive a 49cc scooter! Ha!&#8221;<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Obviously, she&#8217;s a little put off.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">She continues on regarding the costs and time involved for her husband toget the motorcycle permit. All told, it seems the fact that a 50-year-old man has to obtain a Class 6.0 permit to operate a scooter has left quite a bitter taste in her mouth.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Lonestar Motors also expressed some concerns regarding the previous information I provided, so I decided to go straight to the Government of Manitoba Highway Traffic Act, to see what&#8217;s what.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">This is straight from the text, Section 1 (1) Definitions:<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">&#8220;Motorcycle&#8221; means a motor vehicle, other than a tractor which<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt 21pt; TEXT-INDENT: -21pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 21.0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: Verdana"><SPAN style="mso-list: Ignore">(a)<SPAN style="FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Is designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, and<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt 21pt; TEXT-INDENT: -21pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 21.0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: Verdana"><SPAN style="mso-list: Ignore">(b)<SPAN style="FONT: 7pt 'Times New Roman'">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </SPAN></SPAN></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Has a seat or saddle for the use of the rider sitting astride thereof and is capable of attaining a speed of 50 kilometres per hour or more, and includes a bicycle with a motor attached by which it is driven, and a motor scooter.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">So it looks like both Traci and Lonestar are right.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Apparently, scooters used to be defined by the size of their engines, similar to mopeds (anything under 50 cubic centimetres fell under the Class 5.0 permit allowance), but that is no longer the case.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Speeds (and potential speeds) are now the measuring stick, which is why Traci&#8217;s husband was forced to go through the process of obtaining his motorcycle licence. Scooters can now reach speeds up to 70 km/h.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Bottom line: If you buy a scooter, check to see if you&#8217;ll need a Class 6.0 permit. Thank you Traci and Lonestar.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I regret the error, and I hope this clears up any confusion.</SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"></SPAN>&nbsp;</P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 19-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: NISSAN EYEING MORE HYBRIDS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Sun  May 28/04  Page A12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Nissan officials say more hybrid cars, in addition to the 2006 Altima hybrid, will be announced next month at a product forum in California, reports thecarconnection.com.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Likely recipients would be the Nissan Murano and Infiniti FX35 SUVs. Thecarconnection.com also reports that the company may show-case diesel vehicles that use diesel technology by owner Renault. The Nissan Titan pickup is a possible recipient of the diesel power.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Nissan hasn&#8217;t been as aggressive in pushing its hybrid future, focussing more on hydrogen and diesel power than gas-electric vehicles.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">- Autonet.ca</SPAN></I></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"></SPAN></I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 20-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: PORSCHE, VW RECALL SUVS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Sun  May 28/04  Page A12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">BERLIN &#8212; Porsche is recalling more than 40,000 Cayenne sport utility vehicles worldwide and rival Volkswagen recalled some 60,000 of its Touareg SUVs to check for potential faults in rear seat belts.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The Gennan automakers jointly devel-oped the Cayenne and Touareg models, and the vehicles share some parts. The recall is to check for bolts anchoring the seat belts to the frame that were improperly welded and could come loose.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Porsche says it became aware of the problem through quality tests, but no incidents had been reported.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">About 1,000 of the faulty parts were installed in the Cayenne and Touareg vehicles, says Volkswagen spokesman Alexander Skibbe.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Porsche said the seat belts in the driver and front passenger seats are not affected by the fault.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Both companies said the fault lies with the supplier, which they refused to identify.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Porsche said its recall affects Cayenne, Cayenne S and Cayenne Turbo models manufactured between Oct. 1, 2002 and Dec 17, 2003&#8212; a total of 40,848 vehicles; Brisk sales of the Cayenne have boosted Porsche&#8217;s results over recent quarters. </SPAN><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">-AP</SPAN></I></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"></SPAN></I>&nbsp;</P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"></SPAN></I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 21-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MOM BROKE NO LAW, CAR SEIZED: Bizarre case begins after mechanic drove her car suspended
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May 28/04  Page A1
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">BRANDY Simmons took her 1993 Pontiac Sunbird into the shop for a tune-up -- but the Manitoba government took possession of the car after her mechanic, who was suspended from driving, got busted for moving it from the parking lot into the garage. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The bizarre case has left the struggling single mother out more than $5,000 and without a vehicle. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The mechanic's arrest triggered a mandatory section of provincial legislation that authorizes police to impound and eventually seize the vehicle he was driving -- regardless of the owner -- because it was his third offence within five years. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"This has turned my life upside down. And I've been innocent in this whole thing," Simmons, 26, told the Free Press yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The province agrees Simmons was the victim of a "highly unusual situation," but has refused to reimburse her for the financial loss. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Simmons' nightmare began when the mechanic got pulled over by police last November while driving her car into the inner-city garage. Somehow, officers caught the man during the minute-long spin. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Simmons bailed her car out of the impound lot one week later, but had it seized for good in March after her mechanic pleaded guilty to the Highway Traffic Act offence. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The conviction triggered the next mandatory piece of legislation -- complete forfeiture of the vehicle in question. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Simmons was sent a forfeiture notice in February, which permitted her to appeal within a 30-day period. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">But she ignored the document because she naively assumed her role in the messy ordeal was over. Simmons said she was confused and believed the notice must have been sent in error. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Tom Percy, a lawyer with Thompson Dorfman Sweatman, who is assisting Simmons with her plight, said he doesn't blame her for ignoring the notice. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"She had no clue what was happening here, and this notice was so vague -- we passed it around the office here and three or four lawyers couldn't make heads or tails out of it," Percy said yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">To add insult to injury, about three months after Simmons retrieved her car from the impound, it was stolen from beside her apartment building. Days after it was stolen, government officials came to seize it, but it was still missing. Police eventually found the smashed-up car, and Manitoba Public Insurance deemed it a write-off. MPI was ready to pay Simmons $5,300 for her loss, but the province swooped in and grabbed the cash instead. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"Yes, she probably should have gone down when she got that notice, but she didn't understand what was going on. This all just seems so incredibly unfair," said Percy. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Don Lofendale, Crown counsel with the provincial civil legal services branch, said yesterday he sympathizes with Simmons' situation. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">But his department has refused to return the cash from her wrecked car based solely on Simmons' failure to respond to the forfeiture notice in a timely fashion. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Lofendale said provincial legislation doesn't allow for the review of cases like Simmons' once forfeiture has occurred. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"When she failed to take that step (to respond to the notice) and this fellow was convicted, the forfeiture was triggered," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Percy said he was told the decision is final, but Lofendale told the Free Press his department is continuing to "give it a hard look." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"This is a very unusual case," he said, adding a decision is expected soon. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The impound and forfeiture provisions don't kick in when a person's car is stolen and a suspended driver is caught behind the wheel. Lofendale agreed there are similarities between Simmons' ordeal and that of a victim of car theft. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Percy said he may file a formal legal challenge of the provincial legislation if Simmons isn't compensated for her loss. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"I understand the intention of this legislation is to make drivers more accountable, and that's fine. But there is no way a case like this could be the intention of the legislation," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Simmons is angry with both the province and her former mechanic. She said the financial fallout has forced her to drop out of Red River College, where she was in her final year of studying child and youth care. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"I'm really struggling, and I'm wondering where the justice is here," she said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"I've always been a positive person, and I'm trying to hold my head up high, but it's difficult. I've really been thrown off by this case."</SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 22-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the Editor: TRUCKERS DESERVE OUR THANKS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May 28/04  Page A19
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">This is in response to the horrible truck accident on Hwy. 17. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I am the wife of a truck driver and truly understand the worry that the wives and girlfriends of the men who chose this life go through. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I feel the pain that the families of the victims of that crash must be going through. And my heart is sad. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Every week I pray that my husband will arrive home safely. The time that we spend together is so precious as I know he will be leaving again in a couple of days. Back on the road, which is where he earns a living for us. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">What I want people to understand is this: <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Without truckers bringing or taking their loads to various locations, we, the public would be without all the necessities in life. You probably don't give two thoughts to how the things you are buying in the stores even got there. Chances are they were brought by truck. Their lives on the road are by no means easy. They drive tremendous hours, sleep when they can (have you ever had to sleep in the back of a truck?, Not easy.) They have to go by very strict guidelines set out by our government, which allows them the time they need to sleep, but not like you or I, who have a nice comfy bed to crawl in each and every night. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I have had the chance to go with my husband on the road. It is a real eye-opener! When I saw everything that he has had to endure each and every day that he is on the road, I just couldn't believe my eyes. There are way too many things to even tell you. But I can tell you one very important thing. I have a huge respect for what he does. And I have the utmost respect for all the other truck drivers out there. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">So, when you are out there on the road, and come across these big rigs, please, please respect them, and move over for them on the highway instead of trying to sneak by them. They can't always see you, but you most certainly can see them. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">What happened on Hwy. 17 is very unfortunate. And that highway is a "death" highway. Hopefully the Ontario government will do something about that horrible stretch of highway. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I will leave you with one last thought. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Next time you see a trucker, perhaps say "Thank You." Thank you to all the truckers out there! <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">JANICE BECKER, </SPAN></I><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:City><st1:place><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Winnipeg</SPAN></I></st1:place></st1:City></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><st1:City><st1:place><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"></SPAN></I></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 23-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: BUY A SUBARU, DRIVING LESSONS INCLUDED: New techniques improve skills
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May 28/04  Page E4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">FRONTIER Subaru, Winnipeg's Subaru dealer, has a new special deal for first-time customers. Anyone buying a new Subaru now has the option of enrolling for free in the new Subaru Advantage advanced driving training program being offered by long time driver trainer Bill Ward in conjunction with Frontier Subaru through his Vehicle Research Centre (VRC) St, Andrews at the St. Andrews Airport. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Ward reports that he had a full class for the first session on May 16. "We had a full range of Subaru buyers from Imprezas to STIs to Foresters," he says. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">And all agreed that the new techniques they learned improved their driving skills. "I guess you can teach an old dog new tricks," said Phil Guliov who purchased a Legacy GT. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Chris Rieken, who is driving a WRX, said that the course was very well structured and the execution excellent. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Bill Ward has been teaching advanced driving skills for 35 years. His clients have included race car drivers, government employees and corporate fleet drivers. The Subaru Advantage program and a second new course for young drivers are his first programs for the general public. Both programs consist of an hour of classroom work and three hours of hands-on practice on the course he has built at the airport area on Highway 8 north of Winnipeg. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"Gary Fridfinnson, one of our sales reps, had read an article about Bill and his course," said Denise Thompson, Frontier Subaru's general manager. "Gary and I went out to meet with Bill and see first hand what he is doing. We feel that what he is doing is a great way to enhance the value of Subaru which is already one of the safest models on the road. And the Subaru Advantage gives our customers an opportunity to enhance their driving skills." The program is open to other drivers -- in addition to new Subaru owners -- for a fee of $149.95. The course is open to a maximum nine students per session to ensure personalized attention -- there is one instructor for every three students. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"We teach new Subaru owners skid control, threshold breaking and enhanced ABS function," Ward says. "We can teach you how to make a lane change in one-fifth the time and distance and how to react to avoid collisions. We teach you how and where to look, how to sit in a car and hold the wheel and how to shift to neutral to reduce stopping distance. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"We have to practice Subaru skid control on grass because Subarus never skid on asphalt." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Ward reports that VRC is also offering a couple of other Subaru programs. Denise Thompson said Subaru Canada is considering starting a rally school at VRC as well. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 24-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: WHERE'D ALL THE FENDER SIGNALS GO? Same place as idea of signalling, perhaps
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May 28/04  Page E6
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">JUST look at the headlights on that new car, glimmering like jewels on a classy store-bought Rodeo-Drive pendant. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Look carefully at your headlights and you'll see the sculpted chrome neatly tucked in behind a translucent cover that screams "look at me." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Behind that are the dozens of tiny little mirrors that appear to have been painstakingly glued on, one postage-stamp-sized piece at a time. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Headlamps on new cars are things of beauty. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Today's auto stylists should be patting each other on the back for a form-meets-function job well done... except that somewhere along the way, perhaps swept up by the glee and freedom of being able to design headlights just about any way they want, (remember when they were simply round or rectangular?), they forgot those handy little side-mounted fender signal lights. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Really, I looked all over the place and I just can't find them. Depending on the vehicle and/or the manufacturer, it's hit or miss. They certainly weren't on the car that was stopped in the middle of a busy two-lane street yesterday morning as I was on my way to work. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">As anyone who drives in rush-hour will tell you, sitting at a stop sign to turn left onto a jam-packed two-way street can be a pretty trying task. Turning right is no problem since you really only have to sneak your way into one lane of traffic: the one you're turning into. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Turn left, however, and you have to time the traffic for both lanes, which happen to be travelling in opposite directions at varying rates of speed and frequency. Since each intersection doesn't come with its own handbook, it's necessary to rely on the reflexes you honed playing the Frogger video game back in the early 1980s. Or you have to really, really, really pay attention to what the other traffic is doing, via their signal lights, if, in fact, the other drivers feel like using them. The problem is, no matter how good you are, your eyes can't be everywhere at the same time. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">So, discovering what appeared to be the perfect break in traffic, I headed out across the first lane, waiting for just one car to pass in the far lane, the lane travelling in my direction. However, the car came to dead stop right in front of me. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Puzzled, for sure, I gave a light toot of the horn and provided the hands-in-the-air, "Umm, hey, what's up?" signal. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Looking out the driver's-side window and staring straight down my hood, the driver made the international, "Hey, Cat, I'm-stopped-because-I'm-tuning-left-in-front-of-you," signal. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Certainly appreciative of the friendly exchange of information, but with the traffic grinding to a halt all round us, and me blocking one lane and he blocking the other, it would have been much better if the driver had used his signal light to let everyone around him know that he was stopped dead in the middle of the road because he was turning left. In fact, regular readers of this column know exactly how I feel about people not using their signal lights. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">However, it wasn't until he made the turn in front of me that I realized he actually DID have his signal light on. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">What did I miss? Nothing, apparently, and everything all at the same time since there was no signal light on the side of the car to let me know his intentions. Based on that, I probably put both our lives in unnecessary danger by proceeding into traffic. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">An isolated incident, perhaps. But I receive sporadic letters from readers who say that some of the signal lights in today's all-in-one combination headlamps just don't stand out enough in traffic, especially against a backdrop of low-beam and daytime running lights that emanate from the same pod. Some cars are better than others. The Mazda3 parked in the driveway next door is a prime example of the way it should be. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">You have to have dynamite peripheral vision to catch everything that's going on at the best of times, so why make things more difficult by leaving off what many consider to be the basics: turn signals located on the side of the car? <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Lane changing -- when vehicles are right beside each other -- would be safer and, well. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Are they left off some vehicles because they're ugly? Perhaps, but if designers can make headlights that appear as fine jewelry instead of the unsightly round or square blobs they once were, surely they can figure out how to get those functional little fender lights back on all cars with added style in another example of form meeting function. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Or, they could just look at a BMW 3 Series to know how to do it right. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 25-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: READING THE ROAD CAN KEEP YOU SAFE: Temperatures, debris affect driving surface
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May 28/04  Page F1
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I was paddling on the Lillooet River a few days ago. The Lillooet emerges from the Pemberton Ice Cap in the British Columbia Coast Range, and while fairly mellow, takes perpetual vigilance to descend safely. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Mario Chartrand, who runs a canoe and kayak company on the river, had let me take the helm of the big watercraft, and afterwards complimented me on how I read the water. Credit Dad for that; we have done a lot of wilderness trips, and as the bowman (bow urchin) I made my share of choices as to where to point our canoe through stretches of whitewater. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The same principle applies to reading the road. There is so much to be gained from paying attention to such things as textures, temperature, drainage and light. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">In racing or testing, I always try to get up close and personal with a track by taking a walk or run around the course. The information gained is often vital. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">In the recent Grand Prix of Monaco, one driver got it completely wrong. He tried to overtake another racer on the outside of the turn that goes through a tunnel, got in the marbles, which refers to bits of debris, mainly from tires, that gather there. To make things worse, he ended up on a part of the track that is off-camber. The resultant crash was spectacular, and it is a testament to the safety of Formula One racing cars that the driver emerged unscathed, though his car looked rather second-hand. A speed of 250 km/h is not a good one at which to begin bouncing off guardrails. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">On the highway, there are many things to watch for. Truck grooves, which gather rain and are polished to boot, offer reduced traction. Gravel, debris, and all kinds of other stuff litter the far outside edge of on- and off-ramps. Oil from leaking vehicles tends to accumulate at stop lights and can create a skid pad of sorts in the event of rain. Leaves, in autumn, can do the same in shady corners. Cooler temperatures will cause icing, sometimes only from dew, when the temperature drops. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">I'm sure any one of you could add to this list. The point is that there is a lot more to driving, in any conditions, than a well-maintained vehicle and good judgment regarding speed. A friend crashed her new Mazda this past winter when caught out, supposedly, by black ice. I talked her through it and she had all the information at hand to make a good decision: summer tires, dusk, cooling temperatures. Her only excuse was "I always go through those turns at that speed." Wow. Please, no comments about women drivers; I know a lot of guys who have done something just as dumb or dumber. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">That Formula One driver in Monaco seemed, at least at first, to be looking for someone or something to blame for the crash. Sorry, tiger, your choice, fault, and foul. This is not something any of us wish to blunder into on a vacation trip or in everyday driving. Therefore, add reading the road to any list of driving skills you may wish to possess. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The only acceptable excuse we really need on a vacation weekend is why the beach towels stayed at home. Feel free to be creative there. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 26-Sep-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: GET ON THE HYBRID BUS: It’s a pillar of GM's alternative-fuel strategy
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  May 28/04  Page F15
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">AS I was walking into the Canadian International Auto Show earlier this year, Stew Low, head of communications for General Motors of Canada, grabbed my arm and said "You have to drive my bus." <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"Sure, Stew, call me after the show," I said helpfully, if not impatiently. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"No, right now," he said, gripping my shoulder and steering me toward the exit. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">He was quite insistent. So, I drove the bus. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Turns out it was GM's new hybrid bus, built by Winnipeg's New Flyer Industries in collaboration with GM and Allison. It's a pillar of GM's alternative-fuel strategy, said Mike Grimaldi, who is president of GM of Canada and is certain to see his star rise even higher at the world's largest automaker. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"GM's strategy is to target the highest fuel consuming vehicles first. We have hybrid transit buses and full-size pickup trucks available today and will be offering hybrid versions of our full-size sport-utilities, compact sport-utilities and passenger cars over the next few years," he said. What that short test drive made me realize is that the bus is a key to a story that many folks are missing precisely because that other media darling, hydrogen fuel cells, usually uses up all the ink. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Fuel cells are certainly glamorous in a sci-fi, stuff-of-the-future way, but right now hybrids are here and they are saving fuel today while hydrogen powered cars are still very much a dream with no due date. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">That's the story. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Of course I realize it's everyone's wish to power our vehicles with a renewable, non-polluting energy source -- but cutting emissions and increasing mileage is a positive interim step. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Low's insistent "Right now!" command woke me up to the fact the momentum towards environment friendly transport is here now and as consumers we should be (as they say) on the bus. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The Hybrid GM is offering is a diesel/electric system that saves fuel. Nowhere near as expensive or as complicated as hydrogen fuel cell technology, it also has another advantage -- it's right here, right now. This bus hybrid system has two 100-kilowatt motors and a 588-volt, nickel metal hydride battery. Each time the bus decelerates it charges the battery. Each time it accelerates the electric motors help it to get going. This allows the bus to use a smaller 8.9L engine rather than an 11L engine, saving fuel. The system also extends brake, engine oil and transmission oil life. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">As to what impact hybrid buses might have, GM did a study looking at 13,000 transit buses currently in service in the nine largest U.S. cities. They estimated that if they could replace those buses with ones featuring the GM hybrid system, the savings would be more than 100 million litres of diesel fuel every year. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">But the buses are just the beginning. This type of hybrid system also works on pickup trucks and GM already has parallel hybrid full-size pickup truck in production that will provide a 10- to 12-per cent fuel savings over the same conventional truck. Currently they're available to fleet customers in Canada, but these trucks will be available to the public later this year. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The pickup trucks work a bit differently than the bus, but having driven a prototype in the summer of 2001 I can say that it's performance is seamless and if anything -- unamazing. What is amazing is the fuel savings. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Instead of a conventional starter motor and alternator, the parallel hybrid truck features an electric motor that is integrated into the drivetrain. This motor is then the starter and is also a generator; that saves weight and parts. Each time the truck coasts it is making as much as 4.8 kilowatts of electricity that is stored in a 42V battery pack, which (among other uses) can power tools off a pair of 110V, 20-amp outlets in the cab and bed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Where the truck really saves fuel though is at stoplights. Here the gasoline engine actually stops running, but most of the accessories continue working using the stored electrical power. To keep the systems alive at lights the hybrid truck's power steering is run by an electrically driven hydraulic pump rather than the traditional belt-drive system. Similarly, the heating system has an electric pump that keeps hot water circulating even when the engine is off. When the light turns green and the driver steps on the accelerator, the gasoline engine kicks in again. (Think about how a gasoline golf cart works; same principle.) <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The truck gets more out of each litre of gas because of the engine start/stop function and regenerative braking (which is what turns the motor into a generator each time the truck decelerates). <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The hybrid truck has obvious environmental advantages, but the one that occurred to me is how handy it would be to have a portable generator sitting in my driveway -- particularly after last summer's massive hydro outage. Next time I'll plug my house into my truck. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">This parallel hybrid system was applied to trucks first because of the size and weight of the batteries. But, GM suggests that as more 42-volt systems and by-wire controls become available, this new architecture will accommodate them as these 42-volt subsystems tend to be smaller and lighter than their 12-volt counterparts. General Motors has already announced its intentions to continue to expand the use of parallel hybrid systems to include SUVs and even cars.
