Drivers saved an average of 25% from what they would have paid with a fixed charge, the company said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">An option such as per-distance insurance would provide more consumer choice and would impose the costs of driving more directly on those who decide to do it. If per-distance insurance were a choice, lower-mileage drivers would not have to subsidize those with higher mileages to the same extent. Fixed-rate options would become relatively more expensive, but this would be compensated to the extent that lower levels of overall driving and congestion would lead to reduced accident risks and lower insurance costs for most policyholders.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">With a smarter, forward-looking system, my friend who does not drive so much anymore, would get fairer pricing -- as would all Canadian drivers.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><EM>Tom Roberts, a recent graduate of the University of Western Ontario, is a C.D. Howe Fellow.</EM> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 30-Nov-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: AUTO INSURANCE - A YEAR LATER
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  National Post  June.10/04  Page A17
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">NEW BRUNSWICK - During last year's New Brunswick provincial election, skyrocketing insurance premiums became a lightning rod for voter discontent for two reasons. First, it was the sort of pocketbook issue that has a very tangible impact on voters. But more importantly, it was symbolic of the disconnect between the government's perception and New Brunswickers' reality.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Despite all the uproar, though, New Brunswickers continue to be gouged by unacceptably high insurance premiums a year later.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It has been three years since this issue first emerged at the provincial level. Letters and calls began trickling in to offices of the members of the Legislative Assembly in the spring of 2001. In the beginning, the rate hikes were primarily hitting older drivers, those in the northern -- predominantly Francophone -- regions of the province, and especially those under 25. By the fall of 2001, concerns about insurance had spread as more New Brunswickers were being hit with staggering premium increases. Average drivers with no demonstrable increased risk were now finding it impossible to access insurance in the regular market, and were forced into the expensive Facilities Association for high-risk drivers.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The Liberal opposition introduced the first of several motions in the legislature to explore remedies for the skyrocketing rates. And finally, in January. 2002, the government was compelled by public pressure to strike an all-party committee on insurance.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The committee's report was not tabled until November, 2002 -- a year that was particularly difficult for consumers in the province, as New Brunswickers were hit, on average, with a 70% increase in insurance premiums that was by far the highest in the country.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In March, 2003, the government finally brought forward its plan to stabilize insurance rates and "perhaps" see reductions by the fall. But two companies actually announced rate increases of 15% shortly after the plan was announced. And regardless, merely stabilizing rates at their unprecedented levels was not satisfactory to New Brunswickers.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It was clear that the public wanted and needed real rate relief. So in April, 2003, the opposition unveiled our plan to lower them. The cornerstone was a premium reduction task force that would review the rate increases of all companies. Those who could not justify their hikes would face legislated roll-backs. We committed to lowering insurance rates by an average of 25% within 90 days of taking office, and committed that if the insurance companies did not co-operate, a Liberal government would introduce a publicly run system.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">While we stood by our plan, the Conservatives vacillated and backtracked throughout the 2003 campaign -- moving from calling the insurance issue a media invention to making their insurance plan a central part of their election advertising campaign. By the time the campaign was at its halfway point, the Tories had finally decided they wanted a mandate to fix insurance. They announced a "no frills" plan that would see reduced coverage offered at a lower cost. They also committed to legislating changes that would see insurance rates drop by July 1, 2003, when their plan was to take effect.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Fast forward 11 months, and high insurance rates continue to take their toll on New Brunswickers. The re-elected Conservatives have failed to bring forward no-frills insurance or take the necessary steps to lower insurance rates, and dragged their feet on implementing the recommendations of a legislative committee on automobile insurance. After the government brought forward legislation to supposedly reduce insurance rates, fewer than half of insurance companies complied by the Aug. 15 deadline.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Three years of rising insurance rates have hurt individuals, families and businesses. In a province that is predominantly rural, where public transport options are limited and where many industries rely heavily on trucking, rising premiums have a significant economic impact -- especially at a time of skyrocketing fuel prices.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">To add insult to injury, the Canadian insurance industry made a record profit of $2.63-billion in 2003. That's an increase of nearly 700% over the previous year. The industry sunk huge amounts of money into advertising campaigns and aggressive polling in an effort to endear itself to the public. But news of billions of dollars in record profits severely undermined these public relations efforts.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The evidence is mounting that we need a seismic shift in the way that automobile insurance is delivered here in our province. That these changes need to come sooner rather than later is abundantly clear.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The report by the Select Committee on Public Automobile Insurance was released two months ago, and government has made no movement on it. The proposed system would be a no-fault model similar to Manitoba's. The start-up cost would be $82-million over a five-year period, but there would be payback and money would stay in the province. And the proposal incorporates a role for New Brunswick brokers and agents to mitigate job losses arising from switching from a private to a public system.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Undoubtedly the greatest benefit of the proposed public system would be the predictability it offered to New Brunswick consumers, who would no longer be at the mercy of large insurance corporations.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It is expected that, before the end of June we will learn the government's intentions regarding public insurance within the next two weeks. In anticipation, some insurance companies have filed for minor rate decreases, but many are saying it's simply a last-ditch effort to ward off the move to a public system -- a case of too little, too late.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The time for "maybe" has passed. Now is the time to commit to a public system of automobile insurance, to a made in New Brunswick solution, and to giving drivers the relief they so desperately need.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Shawn Graham is leader of the official opposition in New Brunswick.</SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 1-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CLAUSE TO JAM PHOTO RADAR? Ex-cop fighting daughter's ticket
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">A flap over photo radar could have far-reaching legal implications if a traffic court judge sides with a former cop who's fighting his daughter's ticket. Former city police officer Len Eastoe appeared in traffic court yesterday, arguing that his daughter's red light camera ticket is rendered invalid by the wording of the Highway Traffic Act (HTA). <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H2 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: left" align=left><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Singles out word 'and' <o:p></o:p></SPAN></H2>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Eastoe's 22-year-old daughter, Michelle, received the ticket in October 2003 for allegedly travelling 78 km/h through the intersection of Henderson Highway and Kimberly Avenue, where the speed limit is 60 km/h. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Michelle took the stand yesterday and admitted it's possible she was speeding, but Eastoe closed his case by quoting the HTA clause on photo enforcement, stating "they may only use them to detect speed limit violations that occur: (a) in construction zones, playground zones and school zones; and (b) at intersections that are controlled by the traffic control lights." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Eastoe singled out the word "and," claiming its usage suggests that photo enforcement can only be used at controlled intersections located in one of the three zones. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"My contention is the Act doesn't allow them to (ticket) in intersections that aren't in school zones, playground zones or construction zones," said Eastoe, who works for Traffic Ticket Experts. "It shouldn't have been written this way -- it should say 'or.'" <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Crown attorney Nicholas Wansbutter countered by arguing that if Eastoe's logic was applied to the first portion of the clause, photo enforcement could only be used at intersections in areas where all three zones existed at once. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"If those three do not need to exist, it would follow that (b) does not need to go with (a)," Wansbutter said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Magistrate Norman Sundstrom reserved judgment on the matter, noting a similar argument is before the courts and he'd like to rule on both cases together. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The case could have "very serious repercussions," said Sundstrom, who predicted he'd be hearing quotes from textbooks on interpreting statutes -- many of which devote whole chapters to the "and/or problem." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 2-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: HONDA RECALLS 150,000 VEHICLES
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Sun  June 11/04  Page A11
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">DETROIT &#8211; Honda Motor Co. Ltd. is recalling more than 150,000 vehicles due to problems with air bags and interior lights, federal safety regulators said this week.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said potentially incorrect inflation rates in the driver&#8217;s side front air bag prompted Honda to recall 130,617 compact CR-V sport utility vehicles from the 2002-2004 model years.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Separately, it said Honda was recalling 19,572 Accord sedans because the dimmer control for their instrument panel lights can fail due to heat buildup.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Drivers of the Accords, from the 2000-2001 model years, may be unable to see instrument panel gauges at night.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">--Reuters<o:p></o:p></SPAN></I></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 3-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RED-LIGHT CAMERAS FACING LEGAL CHALLENGE
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June 11/04  Page B1
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">THE legality of Winnipeg's intersection safety cameras -- there are 24 now and 12 more coming by August -- was challenged yesterday in a city courtroom. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The challenge means the cameras, up and running for more than a year, may be operating under bad law, said Len Eastoe of Traffic Tickets Experts. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Specifically, Eastoe said one word, the use of "and" in a section of the Highway Traffic Act, makes any speeding tickets issued by the fixed cameras invalid. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Eastoe made his case yesterday in front of Magistrate Norm Sundstrom, arguing a speeding ticket issued against his daughter Michelle last Oct. 10 by the camera at Henderson Highway and Kimberly Avenue should be tossed out. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">He said because the HTA poorly defines how the intersection cameras are supposed to be used, his daughter should be found not guilty of going 78 km/h in a 60 km/h zone. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Sundstrom interrupted the hearing, saying because the case is so unique, he needed to adjourn it to give more time for the province to prepare its defence. "This is a serious matter not only for your client, but for the province," Sundstrom said. "There are serious repercussions." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Police and a spokesman for the province said because the case was before the courts, they could not comment. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Sundstrom also said a second person has made a similar argument about the legitimacy of the cameras. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">He said he wanted it combined with Eastoe's so all parties can argue their cases at once. A hearing is expected within the next few weeks. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"I want to give this serious consideration," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">If Sundstrom rules in Eastoe's favour, it's not known what the impact would be on the thousands of speeding tickets already issued by the intersection cameras and the number of fines already paid. The crux of Eastoe's case against the intersection cameras has to do with section 257.1 (2) of the HTA. It outlines how the "imaging-capturing speed enforcement devices" can be used by municipalities. It was enacted by the province in the days leading up to the unveiling of photo enforcement in Winnipeg by former mayor Glen Murray Nov. 6, 2002. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">It says these devices can only be used: (a) in construction zones, playground zones and school zones and; (b) intersections that are controlled by control lights. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">"When 'and' is used, it means both 'A' and 'B' have to be present," Eastoe said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Eastoe claimed the intersection camera that caught his daughter is not in a playground zone -- the closest is the Bronx Park Community Club further south on Henderson -- and nowhere close to a school zone or construction zone. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Many of the other 24 cameras in operation around the city are also nowhere close to construction, school or playground zones. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Eastoe said in other sections of the HTA, the wording is more specific -- the use of the word "or" eliminates any confusion. For example, the HTA section regarding the mobile photo radar units -- there are five of them that rotate around the city -- is more clear; they can only be used near playground, school or construction zones. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The Doer government crafted the wording of the HTA sections, restricting the use of the mobile speed cameras to distinct areas, to mitigate any perception they were being deployed as part of a cash grab. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Police recently announced 12 new intersection-camera locations in the city. They also began using a special construction zone speed trailer to get people to slow down near roadway projects. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Starting in August, cameras will rotate through the 36 intersections so that drivers won't know which intersection has a camera. The intent is to slow drivers even though their picture will not be taken. In 2005, another 12 intersections will get the camera hardware installed, but no new cameras will be purchased. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">The camera system has been issuing full offence notices since Jan. 7 last year. More than 218,000 tickets have been sent out and more than $17.3 million in fines has been collected. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 4-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: VEHICLE'S HANDLING COULD SAVE YOUR LIFE: Suspension, weight are important factors
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June 11/04  Page E1
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">WE in the automotive press write often about how well, or how poorly, a car handles: how quickly it can slice through a slalom or fly through the emergency lane-change manoeuvre. We'll talk about G-force, body roll, tracking and steering precision. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">A lot of drivers, if they read reviews at all, probably gloss over that section, thinking it can't possibly apply to them since they aren't about to find a slalom in the middle of the road. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">That's an incorrect and dangerous assumption. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Handling is one of the key attributes of driving safety. A number of years ago, BMW, in a thinly veiled dart tossed Volvo's way, ran a commercial where a couple were wheeling their way through a twisty, sea-side highway. As they proceeded merrily along, the voice-over talked about how some manufacturers go to great lengths to build cars that will survive crashes. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Then, as the couple rounded a bend at speed, only to come across a crash scene dead ahead, the voice-over changes tone slightly: "At BMW," pause, as the car swerves left then right, narrowly missing the carnage, and comes safely to a stop to assist the crash victims, "we build cars to avoid them." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Self-serving advertising, admittedly. But behind it is an undeniable truth: the easiest crash to walk away from is the one that never happened. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">There are two keys to that: driver training (and in Canada we are woefully inadequate in preparing people to hurl 1,200-kilogram weapons down the road) and excellent handling. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Great handling encompasses a number of attributes, but at its core, it's about keeping the wheels always pointed where the driver intends, independent of body roll, squat, dive or bumps in the road. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">(Squat happens on acceleration, when inertia forces the rear end of the car to lower, or squat. Dive is the opposite and occurs on braking when the nose lowers. Both are undesirable since they mean the tires at the opposite end have less grip.) <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">For maximum traction, tires should be nearly vertical to the road, so that the most tread contacts the road at any given contact patch. Poorly designed suspensions will often show radical changes in how vertical the tire remains (called camber) from the bottom of its travel to the top. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Those camber changes not only have the potential to change the position of the wheel relative to the driver's desired direction, they also mean that in hard cornering, only a fraction of the tire's contact patch is in full contact with the road, which makes those tires more likely to lose grip and start sliding. It's also why some cars require course corrections when driving over bumps, even when driving over those bumps in a straight line. (If you're looking at a new car and it does this during the test drive, keep looking.) <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">There are several things that must come together for good handling to happen: well-designed and well-tuned suspension is obviously key. Another is low weight. Vehicles that weigh less handle better, since there's less mass to move and less inertia to overcome. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">A strong, flex-free chassis is another. It's not just to keep a car rattle- and squeak-free. When the chassis flexes, the distances between all the various suspension components change. Yet most of those pieces aren't flexible, so if the required distance between the steering rack and tie-rod end changes, the tie-rod isn't going to expand or contract to compensate, it's simply going to pull or push the wheel out of position. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Chassis flex also means that sway bars can't fully do their jobs. Essentially, even the best suspension systems require their mounting points to be as stable as possible to work effectively. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">It may be true that few cars, if any, are so poorly designed as to create major problems when driving in normal circumstances. Problem is, emergencies never happen so conveniently. To avoid a crash, emergencies often mean hard braking and quick steering that quickly takes a car to its limits. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">A car that handles well enough has higher limits than one that doesn't and is more likely to get you out of harm's way. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">So if you think how well a car handles isn't of concern to you, think again. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 5-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Recalls: 2003 LAND ROVER FREELANDER
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June 11/04  Page E14
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Keep your childs rear seat entertainment firmly focused on harassing their siblings, and not opening their doors. The child rear door lock that actuates the left hand rear door only may become disengaged without warning. Your Land Rover dealer will replace the faulty latch. Quote Land Rover recall number B163.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 6-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: WE'RE SUCH GOOD DRIVERS -- WHEN WATCHED
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June 11/04  Page F12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">SPENDING time in the right-hand seat of a vehicle provides a great opportunity to observe the behaviour of other motorists. Those of us in the driver-training field get to see it from a few additional perspectives -- watching drivers following proper procedures, the reaction of others "inconvenienced" by new drivers actually obeying the rules, and observing how drivers change when they are being monitored. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">It comes as no surprise that new drivers -- those learning the necessary skills -- obey speed limits, actually come to a stop at stop signs, observe crosswalks, slow for a stale orange light, etc. During fleet or corporate programs, it is fun watching experienced drivers practise these same basic rules and skills -- while being observed and critiqued. When training instructors, we usually make it a point to have the new teachers spend a few hours at intersections and other critical points observing the real-world behaviour of motorists and the dangers they will face when training new drivers. During these sessions, it is amazing to watch motorists, as they notice people observing them, drastically alter their behaviour. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">One of the most common sources of death and injury from traffic crashes is that of making a left turn across a lane of moving traffic. Novice drivers, especially while in the learning phase and with an instructor present, will usually allow more time than necessary before completing the turn. While this is safer than moving too quickly, it will almost always cause a following motorist to blow the horn or otherwise indicate his or her displeasure at being held up. But as that new driver gains more time at the wheel, they progress from too much time through to too little. If they survive the latter, they find a happy compromise -- happy to them at least. Later, that same driver will leave a little more time -- when under observation. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">Then there is the issue of rudeness. Folks who would never even consider butting into a line ahead of others in a bank or grocery store think nothing of flying by a line of traffic on the right or left and pushing in as the lane disappears or their exit comes up. But watch these same folks, under observation, revert back to the proper, thoughtful, safe behaviour they know to be correct. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">One of the biggest concerns for traffic safety experts is that of schools and children. A lot of time, effort and thought goes into making sure students are safe while going to and from school -- special zones, crosswalks, guards, buses, reflective tape, lights, etc. But the same parents who insist on and support these efforts often ignore them when they get behind the wheel. One of the most dangerous areas for students is that right in front of the school where parents pick up or drop off their children. These folks are oblivious to no-stopping zones and crossing guards, driving to within feet of the school, making illegal turns, blocking driveways and crosswalks, stopping wherever they wish and leaving on their own good time. And it is not just drivers who suffer from brain fade or ignorance in the vicinity of a school. How many times have you watched a parent taking their son or daughter by the hand cross a busy road between crosswalks, in essence teaching the youngster to ignore the rules at an early age? <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">And that's during good weather. It gets really bizarre during nasty weather when that doting parent attempts to get even closer to the school door! We have all watched as a driver goes speeding by on either side -- way over the limit -- only to jump on the brakes when they see a police car. It's amazing how driving behaviour becomes more considerate, legal and constrained in the presence of the law! <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">There are obviously two driving modes: the times we know we are being watched -- and the rest of the time. Unfortunately, the latter constitutes the majority of our time at the wheel. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-US">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 7-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: DEER KILLED ON MAIN ST. ‘Upsetting’ Scene After Vehicle Strikes Animal
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It's not every day you see a deer running down Main Street near the heart of the city, says a North End resident. Winnipegger David Reimann said it was an unusual scene with a bad ending. The disoriented animal was struck and killed by a northbound vehicle about 2 p.m. yesterday, witnesses said. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It was a pleasure to see such beauty in the area," said Reimann, adding his neighbourhood is better known for its frequent crime scenes instead of animal wildlife. "But seeing it lying there dead wasn't a treat. For little kids to see it lying there, bleeding. It was upsetting." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Reimann first spotted the animal on Charles Street and Mountain Avenue and followed on foot between apartment buildings, parking lots and down a back alley before the deer emerged into heavy traffic on Main Street. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg police duty Insp. Gary Walker said the incident is not unique. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We've had deer in the city quite a bit this year," Walker said. "We get them every year." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H5 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'FREAKED HIM OUT' <o:p></o:p></SPAN></H5>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He cited several similar deer sightings downtown in recent weeks. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Deer have been known to travel near the rivers, get spooked and lose their sense of direction. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Reimann, who has called the North End home for some 40 years, recalled seeing a deer more than a decade ago running down Burrows Avenue and jumping over two vehicles. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">This time around, the station wagon driver was left startled. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I guess it kind of freaked him out, driving a car in the city and hitting a deer of all things," Reimann said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 8-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: NET FIRM SELLS FAKE DRIVER'S LICENCES: RCMP Powerless To Stop Brit Company
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.14/04  Page A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">RCMP say there is nothing they can do to stop a British company from selling fake driver's licences from provinces, including Manitoba, on the Internet. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">RCMP Staff Sgt. Lou Morissette, of the Ottawa-based major fraud and identity-theft division, said the only action they can take is against those who are using the cards to misrepresent themselves. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Morissette said there are several websites that sell fake IDs and although the RCMP is "very familiar" with them, it can't take action against them because they're mostly international and because they don't claim to produce legitimate documents. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">However, he suggested the companies may be fronts for illegitimate businesses that take advantage of the personal information customers give them. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"They probably want your name and your address and your birthday and a lot of good vital stats to create that piece of plastic," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">One company, Digital Products, sells convincing fake licences for seven Canadian provinces --Manitoba, B.C., Alberta, Ontario, Quebec, Nova Scotia, P.E.I. -- 34 U.S. states, and six Australian states and territories. Some of the bogus licences come with holograms and magnetic strips, and the company boasts that it provides customers with "the highest quality products, at the best prices." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The company warns the fake cards, which cost $90, are for novelty use only and "misuse may be illegal," but also tells customers the products have been thoroughly tested. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We've tested most of the products and equipment on the market, and have narrowed down our selection to the products that have performed the best during repeated day-to-day use," the website says. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">B.C. Solicitor General Rich Coleman looked at the website this week and said he immediately notified police services about it. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's just so blatant and it really, frankly, ticks me off, because IDs can be used for so many things," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A well-made fake licence can be used to buy airline tickets or board a plane and open a bank account. In some cases, it can be used to get into the United States at a land border crossing. A fake licence could also be used to create a false identity or steal someone else's identity.</SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"></SPAN>&nbsp;</P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 9-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In Brief: DRIVER BEATEN, CAR STOLEN
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.14/04  Page B7
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">WINNIPEG police are looking for a man who beat up a driver and stole his car early yesterday morning. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">According to police a 24-year-old man was driving near Roblin Boulevard and Barker Boulevard at about 3:30 am when he was flagged down by a man on the street. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver stopped and the man jumped into his car and began punching and beating him. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The attacker told the victim he had a knife. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver was pushed out of his car and the attacker drove away in the man's 2002 red Pontiac Grand Am GT licence number DKK 451. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver suffered minor injuries in the attack. Police are looking for man in his 20s, 6', about 200 pounds with short brown hair. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 10-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RCMP HELPLESS TO STOP INTERNET SALES OF PHONY CANADIAN LICENCES
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  National Post  June.14/04  Page A6
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">VANCOUVER - The RCMP say there is nothing they can do to stop a British company from selling fake Canadian driver's licences on the Internet.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">RCMP Staff Sergeant Lou Morissette, of the Ottawa-based major fraud and identity-theft division, said the only action they can take is against those who are using the cards to misrepresent themselves.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Staff Sgt. Morissette said there are several Web sites that sell fake IDs, and although the RCMP is "very familiar" with them, it cannot take action against them because they are mostly international and because they do not claim to produce legitimate documents.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">However, he suggested the companies may be fronts for illegitimate businesses that take advantage of the personal information customers give them.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"They probably want your name and your address and your birthday and a lot of good vital stats to create that piece of plastic," he said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">One company, Digital Products, sells convincing fake licences for seven Canadian provinces --B.C., Alberta, Ontario, Quebec, Manitoba, Nova Scotia, P.E.I. -- 34 U.S. states and six Australian states and territories.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Some of the bogus licences come with holograms and magnetic strips, and the company boasts it provides customers with "the highest-quality products at the best prices."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The company warns the fake cards, which cost $90, are for novelty use only and "misuse may be illegal," but also tells customers the products have been thoroughly tested.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We've tested most of the products and equipment on the market and have narrowed down our selection to the products that have performed the best during repeated day-to-day use," the Web site says.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Despite the company's blatant boast about the high quality of its fake IDs, a legal statement on its Web site says no laws are being broken in their production.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=FR style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: FR">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 11-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'LUDICROUS' SENTENCE : No Jail For Drunk Driver Who Killed
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Family members of Michael Antosh are disgusted with the "ludicrous" sentence given yesterday to the young woman who killed him while driving drunk last summer. "There is virtually no justice for the victim of this crime," said Antosh's wife, Eppie Austria, in a written statement. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Our family has been devastated by the event. An honest, hardworking father, husband, brother and friend no longer exists." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A 40-year-old husband and father of two, Antosh was killed on Aug. 15, 2003, while delivering newspapers for the Winnipeg Free Press on Portage Avenue between Rita Street and Mount Royal Road. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He was killed after stepping out of his Ford Bronco and being struck by a vehicle driven by Lindsay McCaughan, then 19, who swerved into his lane. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H6 style="MARGIN-TOP: 6pt; TEXT-ALIGN: left" align=left><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">CONFESSED TO POLICE <o:p></o:p></SPAN></H6>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">McCaughan, who left the scene but returned a short time later and confessed to police, received an 18-month conditional sentence from provincial Chief Judge Raymond Wyant yesterday. She pleaded guilty to impaired driving causing death. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Her sentence was a joint recommendation approved by her defence lawyer, two directors of prosecution, two senior Crown attorneys, and an independent lawyer brought in to avoid any conflicts of interest. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">McCaughan, a first-time offender, was drinking beer at the Tijuana Yacht Club in the hours prior to the accident, and only drove home because she didn't want her parents to worry about her absence. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She told police she'd been "dozing off and falling asleep" while on the road, attributing her fatigue to a lack of rest the previous night. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She claimed she'd been "sipping her drinks," but still blew a blood alcohol reading of .12. The legal limit is .08. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">McCaughan addressed both the court and Antosh's family yesterday, promising she's learned a "very hard lesson" from the tragic incident. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I wake up every morning with a surge of guilt for my mistake," she said, her voice breaking. "I will never forgive myself for this and I'll live with it for the rest of my life -- every day." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But for Antosh's family members, the apology wasn't enough. Outside court, they railed against the sentence, and against a justice system that allows for such leniency. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H6 style="MARGIN-TOP: 6pt; TEXT-ALIGN: left" align=left><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'HOW MANY MUST DIE?' <o:p></o:p></SPAN></H6>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"How many more Canadians must die before our elected officials stiffen the penalties for impaired drivers who kill?" asked Alan Storie, Antosh's brother-in-law. "What is the deterrent that will stop impaired drivers from driving? It sure is not a conditional sentence." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Antosh died just one day before the fourth birthday of his son Bradley, a date that will forever be marred by tragedy, Storie said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A spokesman for Mothers Against Drunk Driving echoed the family's disappointment. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Conditional sentences don't give the public the denunciation that is necessary," said Rod Sudbury, president of MADD Winnipeg. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">McCaughan's sentence includes a three-year driving suspension -- raised from the usual one-year ban -- and orders to abstain from alcohol and perform 200 hours of community service. She must abide by a curfew between 10 p.m. and 7 a.m. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The judge strongly recommended McCaughan speak to others about the dangers of drunk driving.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 12-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: JUSTICE OR SLOGANS?
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">We&#8217;ve all seen the ads. In Manitoba, when you drink and drive, you&#8217;ll be dealt with very harshly. Government puts it on billboards, in newspaper ads and on TV.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;Toughest drinking and driving laws in Canada,&#8221; the government claims.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Right.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A 19-year-old woman gets drunk, gets behind the wheel of her car and kills a 40-year-old man who steps out of his Ford Bronco while delivering newspapers.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">And what does she get for this serious crime? An 18-month conditional sentence.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That means no jail time and no real consequences.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lindsay McCaughan &#8211; then 19 &#8211; was driving home after a night of drinking in August 2003.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Her vehicle swerved into Micheal Antosh&#8217;s parked Bronco as he was getting out of his vehicle.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He was killed.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">McCaughan fled the scene but returned later and confessed to police.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She pleaded guilty to impaired driving causing death.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">And despite all the rhetoric about how tough Manitoba is with people who drink and drive, the province&#8217;s prosecution branch seeks such a light sentence.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">If the province was truly serious about impaired driving it would send a policy directive to the prosecution branch to seek much harsher penalties for drunk drivers who kill.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It would set minimum standards and ensure the harshest penalties available in the Criminal Code are sought.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But obviously they&#8217;re not that serious about it. It&#8217;s more rhetoric than substance.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Jutice Minster Gord Mackintosh has said repeatedly that conditional sentences are not an appropriate penalty for impaired driving causing death convictions.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Yet his own prosecution branch, including the director of prosecution who was directly involved in this case, recommended one.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It doesn&#8217;t add up. And it makes a mockery of Mackintosh&#8217;s so-called tough stance on drinking and driving.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">And as usual, it&#8217;s the family of the victim, Michael Antosh, that has to endure<SPAN style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </SPAN>the injustice.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 13-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police Briefs: HIT-AND-RUN VICTIM UNSTABLE
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A 41-year-old victim of a hit-and-run was listed in unstable condition following surgery yesterday morning at Winnipeg's Health Sciences Centre. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police found the man lying on Ellice Avenue about 3:30 a.m. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police were looking for the driver of a blue Dodge Caravan as a possible witness, said spokeswoman, Const. Shelly Glover. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Last night, police said they had arrested and released a man on a promise to appear in court. Charges of criminal negligence causing bodily harm, dangerous driving causing bodily harm and failure to remain at an accident scene were to be laid. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 14-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police Briefs: CYCLIST'S INJURIES SEVERE
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A 48-year-old cyclist was in stable condition at Health Sciences Centre yesterday with severe injuries to his head and chest. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The man was riding his bike on Jarvis Avenue between Sinclair and McPhillips streets Thursday around 5 p.m. when he swerved into a taxi, witnesses said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 15-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'SLAP' ANGERS VICTIM'S FAMILY: Drunk Driver Receives Conditional Sentence
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.12/04  Page B1
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">THE angry family of a Winnipeg man killed by a drunk driver called on all Canadians to make lax sentences a federal election issue after an emotional court hearing yesterday. Lindsay McCaughan, 20, was given an 18-month conditional sentence for impaired driving causing death under a joint agreement between Crown and defence lawyers. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><EM><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Free Press</SPAN></EM><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> carrier Mike Antosh -- a married father of two young children -- died last August after McCaughan's car struck him on Portage Avenue in St. James. Her blood alcohol was .12 after a night of partying and drinking with friends. The legal limit is .08. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"How many more Canadians must die before our elected officials stiffen the penalties for impaired drivers who kill? What is the deterrent here?" Alan Storie, Antosh's brother-in-law, said outside court yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Because of federal laws, the impaired driver can kill your family member and suffer nothing more than a slap on the wrist. Wake up and get on board, Canada. We need to have this law changed immediately before this tragedy happens to your family." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Antosh's wife, Eppie, stood beside Storie on the steps of the courthouse, holding her young son, who was to celebrate his birthday the day after Antosh died. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Storie said alcohol has proven once again to be a criminal's best friend. "I implore all Canadians to carry with them while driving a bottle of alcohol. If you're ever involved in an accident and injure a person, drink that bottle. It's your best defence," he said sarcastically. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Conservative Leader Stephen Harper recently announced his party's justice platform, which includes eliminating conditional sentences for serious cases such as drunk driving causing death and manslaughter. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Antosh's family is also upset with Manitoba Justice Minister Gord Mackintosh, who has blasted conditional sentences in the past and promised to lobby Ottawa for changes. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Yet Mackintosh's own prosecutions department agreed to the conditional penalty for McCaughan before farming the case out earlier this spring for an independent opinion, the family noted. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The same situation occurred last summer, when Mackintosh was angered after a conditional sentence was handed to a man convicted of killing a 58-year-old woman while driving drunk. However, the Crown had actually agreed to the conditional sentence. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In this case, McCaughan's lawyer, Hymie Weinstein, accused Mackintosh's office of "political interference" by trying to override the plea bargain once the government caught wind of it just hours before the case was set for court. He called the decision to get a special prosecutor involved a "black day for justice" and said the NDP was trying to dodge criticism in a case sure to attract controversy. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In the end, prosecutor Marty Minuk agreed with the conditional sentence plea-bargain, which had been approved by two senior Crowns prior to having the case stripped away from them. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Provincial justice officials claim politics played no role in the last-minute decision to seek an outside opinion, but rather McCaughan's brief stint as a cook in the kitchen at the remand centre, which could be seen as a conflict of interest. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Minuk told court yesterday the family isn't happy with his recommendation, but said the courts hands are tied because of legislation and previous sentencing precedence. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"If changes are to come about, it has to be at the level of Parliament," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The family understands the limits I have as a prosecutor. I can't go outside the boundaries." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">McCaughan has no prior criminal record and expressed deep remorse for her actions, including a tearful statement in court yesterday. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I'd like to give my most sincere apology to the Antosh family. I will never forgive myself," she said quietly, dabbing her red eyes with tissue. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Weinstein filed 34 letters of support for McCaughan, which spoke of her prospects for a bright future.
