He said jails were not built for people like her, despite an often vengeful public that believes the courts are too soft on crime. "The public just doesn't get it. Courts are not here for revenge or for retribution," said Weinstein. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"She will carry the sentence of having killed Mr. Antosh for the rest of her life." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">McCaughan told police she drank only four beers in the hours leading up to the fatal crash and believes she may have drifted off to sleep while driving home at 5:30 a.m. She briefly left the scene, but returned after calling her father saying she'd been in an accident. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I was driving and all of a sudden there was glass everywhere. But I didn't know I hit anyone," she told officers at the scene. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Chief provincial court Judge Ray Wyant agreed with the joint recommendation for a conditional sentence, which includes a daily curfew of 10 p.m. to 7 a.m., an order to abstain from alcohol and another to perform 200 hours of community service work. He also suspended McCaughan from driving for three years. The Crown and defence had recommended a one-year prohibition. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Wyant told the Antosh family he understood their anger. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Who among us wouldn't want that retribution, that punishment -- an eye for an eye. But the courts are not based on those principles," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He said the tragedy should serve as yet another in a long line of wake-up calls for people to stop drinking and driving.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:Mike.mcintyre@freepress.mb.ca">Mike.mcintyre@freepress.mb.ca</A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 16-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In Brief: MAN HURT IN HIT-AND-RUN, WITNESS SOUGHT
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.12/04  Page B3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">POLICE are seeking a witness in an early-morning hit-and-run yesterday that left a 41-year-old man in hospital fighting for his life. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police say the man was walking across Ellice Avenue near Young and Langside Streets at about 3:30 a.m. when he was struck by a vehicle. Police spokesman Const. Shelly Glover said yesterday police believe a person driving a blue Dodge Caravan may have witnessed the incident and are asking that person to contact investigators at 986-6222.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN>

Title: 17-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: SAFE GRAD PLAN STOPS TROUBLE BEFORE IT STARTS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.12/04  Page B7
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">SAFE grad organizers are beefing up security in an effort to prevent fights like the ones that disrupted two graduation ceremonies last year. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We remember what happened last June," said Keith Thomas, risk manager for the Manitoba Association of School Trustees. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Organizers are bringing in more police, telling parent chaperones to get involved at the first sign of trouble and defuse it before security guards arrive, and principals are carefully combing guest lists for previous troublemakers. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We've told the security committees, get involved. Get parents to intervene before the security guards intervene," said Thomas, who led the drive to create parent-supervised safe grads after a Winkler grad died in a car accident several years ago on the way home from a night of celebrating in Winnipeg. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Some large schools are hiring more off-duty police for this year's grads, Thomas said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He singled out Glenlawn Collegiate for limiting how much alcohol a grad can have. Throughout the year, Thomas has shown Grade 12 students an Ontario poster which shows a young man in a tuxedo throwing up, and asks if that's how they want to remember their grad. "I've had several principals phone me about people bringing dates who've been big troublemakers in the community," Thomas said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Thomas advised principals to tell partygoers who have a bad reputation: "Any problems with you, you're out of here, you're going home." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">One mother, who asked not to be identified, said her daughter's principal had refused to allow her to bring as a date a former student who had brandished a weapon during a gang brawl a year ago. That same principal rejected as grads' dates two young men who were now out of school, one of whom had several marijuana offences on school property. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">As for the other, said the mother, "Boys get in trouble in school, he was in trouble in school." She charged that the principal was being unfair and going on a power trip. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That principal sounds as though he's using good judgment, Thomas said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"If something goes wrong, your school's identified," Thomas said. He has not heard of any young women being barred as dates for grads: "It's all been guys who had trouble, run-ins with the police."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:Nick.martin@freepress.mb.ca"><SPAN style="LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: both">Nick.martin@freepress.mb.ca</SPAN></A></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"></SPAN>&nbsp;</P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 18-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: HYPNOTIZED BY SOBER SECOND THOUGHTS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Globe and Mail  June.12/04  Page A1/A15
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">CHILLIWACK, B.C. -- Twenty minutes ago, Chad Benson was the life of the party. His classmates at Sardis Senior Secondary School laughed hysterically when he was led into a hypnotic trance, kicked up his heels and pretended to be Michael Flatley, Lord of the Dance.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Then the lights dimmed and the sound of two cars crashing slammed through loudspeakers.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Down on the school gymnasium floor, in the glare of blue strobe lights, Mr. Benson now drags his former Feet of Flames through the wreckage of an imaginary drunk-driving accident. Up in the stands, 1,400 students stare in stunned silence as the 18-year-old cradles another hypnotized male student in his arms, slumps over the limp body and cries out in anguish.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I can't feel my legs," a student from the second car screams. The other hypnotized participants wail and moan, as imaginary tears slide down their cheeks.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The grief these 14 students just experienced lasted less than five minutes. "Not everyone is so lucky," says Marc Savard, the hypnotist who presented this startling alcohol-awareness demonstration on Monday, less than a week away from the school's graduation celebration, when the message is perhaps most pertinent.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Mr. Savard assures the students -- and other hypnotists later agreed -- that this session will not leave them traumatized for life. Still, according to the participants, the lesson isn't one they'll easily forget.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"You can't forget something like that," says Mr. Benson, still looking stunned 30 minutes later. Will he ever drink and drive? He spits out his reply without a moment's hesitation.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Absolutely not! And if any of my friends tried, I would wrestle them for the keys."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Aaron Bartsch, the "drunk driver" behind the wheel, says the experience was so vivid, he thought he was going to throw up. "I was so angry at myself, I can't even describe it. I just kept thinking to myself, 'What have I done?' " <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Mr. Savard, a former Kelowna resident now based in Las Vegas, has just wrapped a Canadian tour of 50 high schools. In B.C., he is endorsed by ICBC, the provincial insurance corporation. And for the past two years, his $1,500 show -- Your Mind, Your Power, Your Choice -- has been paid for by the Road Safety program, funded by the province's individual auto-plan brokers in partnership with ICBC.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I'm not making huge money from this," says Mr. Savard, who normally charges $4,000 (U.S.) for his "cluck-like-a-chicken" corporate entertainment shows. "I do it because it helps me sleep at night."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In 1996, Mr. Savard -- already a hypnotist -- was hit by a drunk driver in a head-on collision.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He was returning home from a performance.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He broke his back and was rescued just moments before his Ford Explorer burst into flames. The drunk driver in the other car died.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I remember the feel of brain fluid leaking out my nose," Mr. Savard, now 29, tells the students during a slide presentation of photos from the accident that accompanies his two-hour show.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Like many young adults, Mr. Savard thought he was invincible. "I never thought it could happen to me," he explains. "I didn't even drink."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">After the crash, he began speaking to schools in Western Canada and the United States about the dangers of drunk driving. According to statistics from Mothers Against Drunk Driving, 40 per cent of teenage drivers who are killed in road crashes have been drinking.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He soon realized that his lecture wasn't enough and he began incorporating hypnotism into his presentation.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">His method of shock therapy seems to work on teens. But first he has to get their attention.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Are we going to have some fun or what?" Mr. Savard asks at the beginning of the show, as strobe lights flash through the dark and rock music blares through the speakers. The students roar their approval.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">About 100 students dash forward at the request for volunteers.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Close your eyes and let your whole body relax," Mr. Savard instructs. He takes them all through a number of easy hypnotic suggestions -- pretending they are part of an orchestra, then a heavy-metal band -- weeding out those who are obviously nervous or faking the trance.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">As the group is whittled down to 14, the pranks continue for about 45 minutes. The hypnotized teens prance around like ballerinas. They win a make-believe lottery. They lick invisible lollipops "as big as a beach ball." Told their neighbour "is the ugliest person you've ever seen in the world," they look around with horrified expressions, a few gagging.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The crowd is in stitches. Mr. Savard has them eating out of his hand.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The power of the mind is a wondrous thing, says Mr. Savard, who credits hypnosis for his own fast recovery from the accident. His crash occurred on Aug. 1. By Oct. 9, he was playing hockey again. "We all have this ability, we just have to learn how to use it."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Not everyone is as comfortable with the concept of hypnosis. Some schools have declined his presentation, fearing parents might object. Bob Patterson, principal of Sardis Senior Secondary, was one.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I was concerned about the hypnosis part," he explains. "My mind was changed in a hurry" after watching the presentation at a nearby school.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"What I enjoyed most is that it provided an opportunity for kids to talk about their experiences with other kids. We can show all the videos in the world we want, but kids are going to listen to people they know."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Before each high-school appearance, Mr. Savard makes sure that notices are sent home to warn parents about what will happen. Students are not obliged to attend.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We have a lot of Road Sense speakers who are very good," says Debbie Wilson, an ICBC insurance broker in the Fraser Valley. "But Marc has a bit more impact because he involves the students. It's a very effective way of getting the message across to the kids because they see their friends going through the emotions.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"And as Marc says during the presentation, they can walk away at the end of the show. In real life, that doesn't happen. That's a very important message we want to get across."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Back in the gymnasium, the lights go dim. "What you're about to see is not going to be funny," Mr. Savard warns. "If you're uncomfortable with it, feel free to leave."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The volunteers are divided into two groups. "All of you are coming home drunk from a high-school graduation party," he says to the people in the first car. "None of you should be driving."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Aaron Bartsch is moved to the front row. "You are the driver. All the guilt, fear and panic will be on your shoulders," Mr. Savard calmly explains.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The other students are passengers. One girl will smash into the windshield. Her face will need reconstructive surgery, but it will never be the same again. Another will be paralyzed from the waist down.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"You're not going to feel the [physical] pain," Mr. Savard assures them, "but you will feel all the emotion that goes with it."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In the second car, a family is returning from a birthday party. One of the children will be killed.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Morgan, you will not move at all because for the purpose of this demonstration, you are dead," Mr. Savard says. "Mom, it's going to take a few minutes for you to realize you've just lost a child."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The final instructions are whispered into each volunteer's ears. Dad is told he cannot make any physical contact with the driver -- Mr. Savard has had to break up fistfights in the past.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">To the young woman who needs surgery, Mr. Savard suggests she hold her face "to keep it all in" and make the scenario more visual for the audience, who will not feel her horror.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The music stops. The sound of screeching car tires echoes through the gym. There is a crash. And then all is quiet. In a few moments, the wailing begins.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"This situation was a figment of your imagination," Mr. Savard says as he leads the students out of the trance. "You will never experience these emotions again, but you will remember them and be able to think about them objectively."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He turns to the audience. "The people here will never drink and drive again. But it's already too late. Someone is paralyzed. Somebody is dead."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He turns to Morgan Cox. "How does it feel to be dead?"<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Uh, pretty dead," says Mr. Cox, who is still trembling.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Is there hockey in the afterlife?"<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Mr. Cox stares at the hypnotist incredulously.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Just kidding," says Mr. Savard, gently slapping the student on the back.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"That's the idea behind this demonstration," he says, returning to the audience. "I want you to talk to your friends about it. Laugh about it, joke about it, cry about it. But the next time you're out drinking, please think twice about driving.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 19-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Canada In Brief: KILLED MAN DRIVING DRUNK, WINNIPEGGER AVOIDS JAIL
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Globe and Mail  June.12/04  Page A14
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> -- A local woman is not going to jail for killing a newspaper carrier while driving drunk.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lindsay McCaughan will serve 18 months in the community with a nightly curfew and must abstain from drinking. The 20-year-old is also prohibited from driving for three years.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">During sentencing, Judge Raymond Wyant of Manitoba Provincial Court spoke of the evil and tragic results of Ms. McCaughan's decision to drink and drive Aug. 15, 2003, when she killed Mike Antosh.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He also encouraged Ms. McCaughan to preach to others in an attempt to remember her victim and stop someone else from drinking and driving. <I>CP</I><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 20-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: WINE FOR THE TABLE
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Globe and Mail  June.12/04  Page A22
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">MADD Canada, the anti-drunk-driving watchdog, has criticized Ontario's move to introduce corkage in restaurants. It says the legislation, given first reading on Thursday, will make restaurants less likely to cut off the supply of alcohol to customers who are drinking too much and will encourage customers to drink more. It also accuses Consumer Minister Jim Watson of breaking a promise to MADD about the timing of the new move.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">We don't know about the timing -- imagine, a minister of Ontario's McGuinty government breaking a promise -- but the arrival of corkage is welcome. It expands consumer choice without compromising the safety that MADD so rightly values.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Corkage, a practice already permitted in Quebec, British Columbia and Alberta and in jurisdictions in the United States and Australia, is the freedom of customers to bring their own bottle of wine to a restaurant rather than buy one from the restaurant's stock. The restaurant takes, stores, opens and serves the wine as it would its own bottles, and charges a corkage fee to make the routine worth its while. In general, that fee is less than the markup a restaurant adds to what it pays for its own bottles.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ontario's plan, which is restricted to commercial wine (no homemade plonk), is voluntary. Many restaurants won't want to lose markups of 200 or 300 per cent on their wine or complicate their business further. Terry Mundell, president of the Ontario Restaurant Hotel and Motel Association, says only 238 of Alberta's 8,011 restaurants have signed up since that province introduced corkage last fall.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But for those Ontario restaurants that extend their liquor licences to include corkage, it should be business more or less as usual. They will still control the serving of wine, and they will still determine whether a patron is drinking too much. It is hard to accept MADD's argument that, simply because the customers supply the wine, waiters and owners will be less inclined to offend them by refusing to open another bottle. Diplomacy and judgment are staples of the business regardless of whose wine is being withheld. As for MADD's observation that people are likely to drink more if the price is lower, the corkage fee will help curb that instinct. In any case, the government notes that restaurants will be free to limit the number of bottles brought and require a minimum food order.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">There is one point on which Mr. Watson and MADD agree. It doesn't make sense to force diners to finish a good bottle of wine or lose it; that's a recipe for encouraging drivers to drink more than they should. Ontario will let restaurants seal half-finished bottles, whether sold by the restaurants or brought by their customers, so that customers can take them away. Choice and sense -- they're a recommendable combination.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 21-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: NO EASY RIDES FOR MOTORCYCLE INSURANCE
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Financial Post  June.12/04  Page IN1
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Feeling rebellious? Get a tattoo. Take up an extreme sport. But unless you're financially flush, don't go anywhere near a motorcycle. Whatever you believe about the dangers of tooling around on a two-wheeled machine without a crumple zone, the cost of insurance is a killer in anyone's books<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Just ask Allan Johnson. The retired government researcher who lives in bucolic Georgetown, Ont., recently saw his rates shoot up more than 80%.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I was insuring four motorcycles, full coverage, for $650 [a year]," he says. "Right now, for three of those bikes, I'm paying $881 for minimum coverage."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It isn't as though he's been hitting the speedway, or has a record of unsafe riding. Mr. Johnson's three vintage motorcycles, including a British-manufactured Levis dating back to 1927, get revved up only a few times a year, at parades and gatherings of the Canadian Vintage Motorcycle Group to which he belongs.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I've been riding bikes since I was a teenager at Northern Secondary School -- 45 years. And I've never had a claim, and I've never had a ticket."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">So what gives?<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Motorcycle riders across Canada have seen their insurance premiums soar more than 50% over the past three years, according to Bob Ramsay, president of the Motorcycle and Moped Industry Council, a national, non-profit association for manufacturers, distributors and retailers of two-wheeled vehicles.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">First-time riders have been hit the worst, and last fall insurers started slapping a surcharge on young motorcycle enthusiasts that can more than double the already high cost of premiums.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">At Primmum Insurance Company, for example, a newly licensed 18-year-old man with no previous motorcycle coverage would be subject to a 100% to 120% surcharge, bringing the cost of premiums for a Kawasaki Ninja sport bike to a jaw-dropping $7,000 to $8,000 annually.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That's more than it would cost to acquire the bike. A brand-new Kawasaki Ninja ZZ-R250 retails for $6,299.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Some young and first-time riders are being shut out completely, unable to find motorcycle insurance anywhere, at any price.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Because of the tightening of the market, insurance companies only want the best risks," Mr. Ramsay observes.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Other riders insured by Primmum endured rate hikes of 14% to 40% last year.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Looking at those costs from a broader perspective, Mr. Ramsay says the average rider now pays $1,500 a year for insurance -- even though most ride only on weekends, and only for seven months out of the year.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That's about the same as it costs to insure a car or minivan that's driven every day, according to the Canadian Automobile Association's 2004 Driving Costs report.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">What many riders find frustrating is the number of motorcycle insurance claims haven't been increasing in tandem with these recent price hikes. Indeed, riders have proportionately fewer claims than automobile drivers, Mr. Johnson says, noting that in 2002, there were 107,000 motorcycles insured in the province of Ontario, but only 51 claims for third-party damages.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ah, but sheer numbers and third-party claims aren't the issue, insurers would say.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"With bikes, people don't have little accidents," observes Gregory Ellis, co-founder of the insurance-shopping Web site Kanetix. Couple extensive personal injuries with similarly skyrocketing healthcare costs, and, he says, "You've got these accident benefit claims costing more and more."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Also to blame is the same post-9/11 angst that's inflated car and residential premiums over the past three years.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Subsequent to the events of September 11, 2001, the industry became more cautious about how it approached all insurance activities," Mr. Ramsay says, and riders have taken the brunt of that new caution.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Motorcyclists have had no offers of government protection against rising rates. Yet, three provinces, including Ontario, Prince Edward Island and, most recently, Newfoundland and Labrador, have legislated caps on the cost of automobile insurance. And, according to Statistics Canada, automobile premiums fell back an average of 1.3% in April.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Meanwhile, riders who try to shop around for the best deal are severely limited in their choices.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"There's very little competition in the market. It becomes very difficult to shop around for your insurance premium," Mr. Ramsay says.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Fewer than 1.5% of insurers offer motorcycle coverage, he adds, and only three companies -- Primmum, Kingsway General Insurance Inc. and Jevco Insurance Company -- will insure bikes on a stand-alone basis, meaning they don't require that you insure your car and home with them, as well.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Lots of people who go to two or three or four brokers... and can't find anybody -- it's because most of these brokers are only using one [motorcycle insurance] firm," Mr. Johnson complains.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Does this mean middle-age crazies should abandon Easy Rider fantasies? Not necessarily. If you're hell-bent on taking up with the two-wheeled set, there are a few things you can do to tame the cost of insurance.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">For starters, make peace with the fact that you'll have to pay your dues at the outset. Once you've proven you're a safe driver and a good risk, your premiums should ease slightly. For example, a 39-year-old man with no previous motorcycle experience, who is looking to insure a 2004 BMW bike with an 1100-cc, 90 horsepower engine, will pay about a third more than a man with the same personal attributes who has six or more years' experience.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Next, shun showy or sport bikes. The larger and more powerful the engine, and the pricier your bike, the more you'll pay to insure it, Mr. Ellis says.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Instead, consider a touring model -- and if it's a few years old instead of brand new, so much the better.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Another tip: "Don't buy insurance you don't need," Mr. Ellis continues. Really think about what it would pain you to pay for out-of-pocket. If you wouldn't mind covering the cost of a replacement windshield, for instance, you can probably skip comprehensive coverage.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"If you have an older bike, you probably do not need theft [coverage]," Mr. Ramsay says.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Similarly, he suggests bumping up your deductible to the highest level you can afford. If your current policy requires you to pay $500 out-of-pocket for claims, ask your insurer to raise that to $1,000, or even $2,000.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">People like Mr. Johnson, who have a long history of safe riding, may wish to ask for a reduction in their liability coverage. Although most insurers automatically put $500,000 or more on a motorcycle policy, you can ask them to take it down to $200,000 -- a move that will shrink your premium considerably.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Finally, if you feel as though you're getting nowhere with an insurer's customer service rep, Mr. Johnson advises asking to speak to the team leader.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">If you have a unique situation, a green or unknowledgeable customer service rep may tell you you're uninsurable, he warns. Don't believe it.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"If supermarkets sold food the way the insurance industry sells insurance," he says, "there'd be people in the streets starving to death who couldn't figure out how to buy a loaf of bread."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 22-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: COPS FIND HIT-AND-RUN SUSPECT
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A 21-year-old Winnipeg man is facing several charges in connection with a hit-and-run in the West End last week that left a 41-year-old pedestrian with severe injuries. The driver who allegedly struck the man about 3:30 a.m. Friday near Ellice Avenue and Langside Street was believed to have been driving a 1993 blue Asuna Sunfire. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Later that day, police found him at his parents' home in the 100-block of Saratoga Crescent in the Maples. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The driver -- who was released on a promise to appear in court at a later date -- faces charges for criminal negligence causing bodily harm, dangerous driving causing bodily harm and failure to remain at the scene of an accident.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 23-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: STOLEN CAR LEADS COPS ON CHASE
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Two men were arrested following a high-speed chase yesterday through Winnipeg and west of the city. At one point the vehicle was being driven while missing a rear wheel, said Winnipeg police Const. Bob Johnson. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">An off-duty police officer first spotted the vehicle in a strip mall at Cavalier Drive and Portage Avenue with two suspicious-looking occupants about 10:50 a.m., Johnson said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Cops soon discovered the vehicle was stolen. The driver sped away when police intervened. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Before city police aborted the chase due to heavy traffic, officers pursued the vehicle west on Portage Avenue. Police requested assistance from Headingley Mounties when the suspect continued west of the Perimeter on the Trans-Canada Highway.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 24-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CAR LOSES TIRES IN POLICE CHASE
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.15/04  Page A6
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A high-speed chase yesterday left the suspects' car running only on its wheel rims as it continued to flee police. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The pursuit started in St. James a little after 10 a.m. and ended an hour later when two men were arrested after apparently ditching a battered, tireless Pontiac Grand Am in a River Heights garage. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police and witnesses say the chase started after an off-duty city police officer noticed a suspicious vehicle driving around a credit union. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A records check of the plates showed the car was allegedly stolen and may have been used in a recent break-and-enter in which guns were taken. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">When patrol units tried to pull the car over, it sped off west on Ness Avenue, touching off a chase that led police down Sturgeon Road and onto Portage Avenue where it headed out of the city. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police, worried that the chase was becoming too dangerous, called it off as the Grand Am sped towards Headingley. RCMP were notified and soon officers in a patrol car spotted the Grand Am heading west on the Trans Canada Highway. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">RCMP spokesman Sgt. Steve Colwell said Mounties followed the car, reaching speeds as high as 170 km/h as far as Elie, where it suddenly did a sharp U-turn and sped back towards Winnipeg. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Minutes later the car blasted past the Charleswood library on Roblin with its tires flat and shredding after apparently going over a police spike belt. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"There were no tires," said Kara Pihychyn. "Rubber was just flying off." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><I><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca">bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></I></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 25-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: IN BRIEF: ‘Leaving Scene’ Charge
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.15/04  Page B8
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A 21-year-old man has been charged with leaving the scene of a collision that seriously injured a 41-year-old male pedestrian early last Friday. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police found the suspect vehicle later in the day on Mandalay Drive. They say the car had damage consistent with such a collision. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The victim was hurt as he crossed Ellice Avenue between Young and Langside streets about 3:30 a.m. He was rushed to hospital in critical condition, but has since been upgraded to stable. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">At 2 p.m. Friday, police arrested the 21-year-old suspect at his home on Saratoga Crescent. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He is charged with criminal negligence causing bodily harm, dangerous driving causing bodily harm and failing to remain at the scene of an accident and exchange particulars. He was released on a promise to appear in court.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 26-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Business Watch: 450,000 VEHICLES RECALLED
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.15/04  Page C16
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">TOKYO -- The truck company spun off from Japanese automaker Mitsubishi Motors Corp. said yesterday it was recalling 450,000 trucks and buses for defects it had failed to report four years ago when a defect cover-up scandal surfaced. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Earlier yesterday, police raided the home of Katsuhiko Kawasoe, the former president of Mitsubishi Motors, who was arrested last week on suspicion of hiding auto defects after promising to come clean in the earlier scandal. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But the latest list of 47 recalls, announced by Mitsubishi Fuso chief executive Wilfried Porth, dates back to models produced as far back as 1983, and is linked to 13 accidents resulting in injury, 26 accidents resulting in property damage and 74 fires in vehicles. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 27-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CHOP-SHOP BUST: Stonewall Man Faces Charges In Sting Op
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The 51-year-old owner of an automotive business in Stonewall is accused of allegedly running a chop shop, police said yesterday. John Wallace, who runs Wallace Enterprises Inc., faces five counts of possession of goods obtained by crime. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A Winnipeg police and RCMP joint investigation is continuing and further charges may be laid. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Last Friday, members of the Winnipeg police stolen auto unit, the RCMP major crimes unit and Stonewall Mounties conducted a shop inspection at Wallace Enterprises, said Winnipeg police spokeswoman Const. Shelly Glover. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"During the inspection, numerous stolen auto parts and three stolen vehicles were located," Glover said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Cops also seized about $73,000 in stolen auto parts at the automotive shop at 13 Patterson Dr. -- including fenders, transmissions, cabs, seats, hoods and shells. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Investigators allege newer-model vehicles were stolen from streets and parking lots across Winnipeg, then shipped to Stonewall where they were stripped down. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The parts were then allegedly either re-installed in other vehicles or sold. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Chop shops can be a very profitable enterprise," said MPI spokesman Brian Smiley. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's certainly a form of auto theft -- not overly common in this province, but certainly they do exist." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Among the seized items were 25 car doors, which police believe were removed from stolen vehicles. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"MPI will co-operate fully with all the police agencies involved in assisting them to identify the parts," Smiley said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Wallace, who was at work yesterday, didn't return calls from The Sun. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">One of the biggest chop shop busts in Manitoba in recent history came in March 1997, when RCMP found $310,000 worth of stolen vehicles on a residence in Grunthal. Allan LeMay, 53, and his son Daniel, 29, were sentenced to three years and one year in jail, respectively.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 28-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: TORNADO TERRORIZES BRANDON: Blows Out Car Windows, Topples Trees In Trailer Park
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.16/04  Page A3
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: By Eliza Barlow And Marcy Nicholson
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">BRANDON -- A tornado touched down on the outskirts of Brandon yesterday afternoon, leaving startled residents of a trailer park unharmed but awash in debris. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"In five seconds, this all happened," an incredulous Ed Harder said, standing among uprooted trees, debris-littered yards and damaged cars outside his home in the Brentwood West mobile home park. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A funnel cloud reportedly formed in the Virden area and hit the ground as a tornado at the southern edge of Brandon at about 2:45 p.m. before rising into a funnel cloud again. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Environment Canada received multiple reports of the funnel cloud, which followed a roughly eastbound route along the Trans-Canada Highway. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Hail was reported as a line of thunderstorms moved across southern Manitoba, with nickel-sized hailstones in the southwest corner of Winnipeg near the Perimeter Highway and pea-sized stones at Polo Park. Environment Canada received reports of hail damage to crops in the Neepawa area. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Most witnesses in Brandon described a deafening roar as the funnel cloud raged through, punctuated by banging noises as car windows were blown out. Harder said he was sitting on his sofa when it suddenly got eerily calm and quiet outside. Seconds later, he was looking out the window at a mess of debris swirling in the air. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Janissa Stocki, who lives across the street from Harder, was looking after the children at her day care when she looked out the window and spotted the funnel cloud heading straight for her house. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It touched down where that shed uplifted," she said, pointing across the street. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Then it came diagonally, right through here, and took out the trees." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Stocki frantically told the children to get to her bedroom and get under the bed, as she has no basement in her trailer home. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It was in the trees and it was crashing the cars," said Jordan McDonald, 4, adding he was worried about his two-year-old brother, Nicholas.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I was just shaking. I'm scared of tornadoes." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In the aftermath of the tornado, residents of the trailer park came out of their houses and stared agog at the damage, later trying to retrieve property that had flown from their yards onto others. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Marcel Kenler, who arrived home just after the funnel cloud left, stood shaking his head over a huge Scotch pine tree that had fallen right where he usually parks his pickup truck. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Behind him, a neighbour's blue tent was hanging from Kenler's eavestrough and flapping in the breeze. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"My neighbour said, 'If you'd wanted my tent, you could have just come over and asked for it,'" Kenler chuckled. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lorna Hodgins came out of her mobile home to find her tin shed torn right off its foundation and lodged in a nearby tree. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Potatoes that she'd tilled under in her garden had mysteriously been sucked out of the earth and were lying on top of the soil. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The destruction wasn't limited to the Brentwood trailer court. Near the junction of Maryland Avenue and 26th Street, resident Barb Vinthers and her husband watched the funnel rage through their yard on its way to the Brentwood area. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It sounded like a train going over," she said. "When we saw it coming, we ran for the basement." Vinthers said she was amazed by the seemingly random damage wrought by the tornado, pointing to a rusted metal post lodged in her back lawn. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I have no idea where that came from," she said. Plastic covers on her tomato plants just metres from the post were completely untouched. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Environment Canada considered the tornado relatively weak, with winds spinning at perhaps 100 kilometres an hour. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Environment Canada gave Brandon residents about two hours notice of the potential for severe weather, with a tornado warning a half hour before it struck. This is the second tornado to hit western Manitoba this year. On June 7, a tornado estimated at 400 metres wide broke 25 power poles six kilometres southwest of Melita. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><EM><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-- with files from Helen Fallding</SPAN></EM><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:mnichols@brandonsun.com">mnichols@brandonsun.com</A> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:ebarlow@brandonsun.com">ebarlow@brandonsun.com</A> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 29-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: AUTO GROUP SAYS ROAD LITTER 'DEADLY'
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.16/04  Page A11
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">WASHINGTON -- A hunk of tread off a tire. A bag of garbage. A chunk of scrap metal. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">More than an eyesore, the debris littering roadways causes over 25,000 crashes and up to 90 deaths a year in the United States and Canada, says the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In 2001, there were more than 6.3 million motor vehicle crashes in the United States and 154,000 in Canada, the organization said. The national vehicle-related road debris, or VRRD, crashes were estimated at 25,217 in the United States and 612 in Canada. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The report stressed that the estimates do not take secondary crashes that may have been caused by VRRD. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Although vehicle-related road debris crashes are generally less severe than other crashes, individual incidents can be catastrophic," foundation president Peter Kissinger said in the report, which is being released today. It's the first time a comprehensive tally of such accidents has been done, according to AAA. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 30-Dec-12
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: GARAGE'S OWNER CHARGES
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.16/04  Page B5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A 51-year-old man faces five charges of possessing goods obtained by crime after a police inspection at a small garage and towing firm in Stonewall. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police said yesterday officers from the Winnipeg Police Service's stolen auto unit, the RCMP's major crimes unit and Stonewall RCMP conducted a shop inspection under the Highway Traffic Act at Wallace Enterprises June 11. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Stolen parts, vehicles <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg police spokeswoman Const. Shelly Glover said officers found numerous stolen auto parts and three stolen vehicles. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She said police seized about $73,000 in stolen auto parts including fenders, transmissions, cabs, seats, hoods and shells. The investigation is continuing in an attempt to identify an additional 25 car doors believed to belong to stolen vehicles. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Wallace Enterprises is located on Patterson Drive in Stonewall's industrial area. But a man who answered the phone at the Stonewall company said police have it all wrong. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I have no knowledge of it," said the man, who declined to identify himself. "All I can tell you is that no complete stolen car was found here." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police said the owner of the business has been released on a promise to appear in court.
