TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The teens were arrested following a high-speed police chase. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">One of the teen's co-accused was sentenced to two years of adult time earlier this year after racking up 51 criminal charges -- 31 of them for stealing cars. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That offender had already spent six months at the Manitoba Youth Centre and was sentenced to a further two years less a day in an adult facility. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"This clearly demonstrates that auto theft is many times a gateway to other offences," Manitoba Public Insurance spokes--man Brian Smiley said yesterday. "Vehicles are not just being stolen and taken on joyrides, they're being used in the commission of other more serious offences." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The teen sentenced yesterday has already spent 260 days in custody and will serve the remaining 18 months of his sentence at the Manitoba Youth Centre. His sentence will be followed by one year of supervised probation.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 16-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: TRICKED-OUT RIDES ON XZIBIT
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Turn on a television set at any given time and something is being made over: A room (TLC's Trading Spaces), a house (ABC's Extreme Makeover: Home Edition) or even a human being (Fox's The Swan). But leave it to MTV -- which ushered in the reality TV era more than a decade ago with The Real World -- to put its own spin on the makeover show with Pimp My Ride, a weekly series that transforms broken-down autos into tricked-out masterpieces. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The half-hour show, which CTV Ch 5 is airing on Sundays at 8.30 p.m., has been a solid addition to MTV's lineup of original programming in the U.S. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Hosted by rapper and car enthusiast Xzibit and featuring Los Angeles-area aftermarket shop West Coast Customs, Pimp My Ride selects young, automotively challenged Southern Californians and transforms their jalopies into triumphs. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Everybody has had a bucket in their life," said Xzibit, using L.A. slang for a clunker. He has had two of his own rides -- a Hummer H2 and a Mercedes-Benz S500 -- "pimped" at West Coast Customs. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Xzibit said the show owes much of its success to the element of charity. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It never gets old seeing somebody do something positive for somebody else," Xzibit said in a telephone interview. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The show is in such sharp contrast to every other reality show. It kind of fits the formula but it serves another purpose. There's something positive being done at the end of every show." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A typical episode begins with Xzibit paying a surprise visit to the viewer and humorously highlighting the car's numerous problem areas. Then it's off to West Coast Customs, where a team of professionals disassembles the vehicle and completely refurbishes it with custom rims and paint, plush interiors and the latest in lighting, car audio and video accessories. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Believe it or not, there's more. Some of the special features that vehicles have received include a ping-pong table in the bed of a 1985 Ford Ranger pickup truck, a motorized shoe rack in the trunk of a 1978 Cadillac Sedan DeVille and a remote-controlled digital camera in the passenger side visor so the owner of a 1989 Ford Mustang convertible could take pictures of her friends while driving. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Not only has the show been a winner for the network but also for West Coast Customs, which has seen an upturn in business since the show's debut in March. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It has opened the door to do other things," said founder and owner Ryan Friedlinghaus, whose rep for outfitting rides for stars like Los Angeles Lakers star Shaquille O'Neal and rappers Ludacris and 50 Cent helped it land the show. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Each show ends with the car owner triumphantly returning home to the oohs and aahs of friends and family. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's not just about the cars anymore," Xzibit said, but also "the boost that these kids get in their self-esteem. You can see it in their faces."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 17-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: IN BRIEF RCMP IDENTIFY MAN CHARGE IN ROAD DEATH
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.22/04  Page A6
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">RCMP identified a man charged in a fatal accident Saturday night that killed a 28-year-old Norway House man. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Oliver Gordon Scribe, also 28, is charged with impaired driving causing death, drive over the .08 legal blood-alcohol limit and dangerous operation of a motor vehicle causing death. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Brian Luke Anderson was struck and killed while walking on Provincial Road 373 on the Norway House Cree Nation.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 18-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: MAKE HELMETS MANDATORY
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.22/04  Page A15
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Cycling season has begun in Winnipeg; meaning that the province of Manitoba is into another year of forcing cyclists to ride on the roads and fining those who are caught riding on the sidewalks. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Many people who drive vehicles find cyclists on the road a nuisance as our city is not properly constructed for accommodating cyclists as in other cities like Ottawa, and as such do not appropriately yield to cyclists. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Laws are supposed to help protect people, for instance, wearing seat belts in a motor vehicle is mandatory. If the government is making it mandatory for bikers to ride on the roads then, along side of that they should also make it mandatory for helmets to be worn as a preventative health measure. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">In 2002, Alberta Children's Services stated that over 60,000 Canadians are injured every year in bike-related incidents. They further noted that riders not wearing helmets are three times more likely to suffer head injury in the event of an accident and that bike riders with head injuries are 20 times more likely to die. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Manitoba Public Insurance stated that 85 per cent of head injuries from cycling could be avoided simply by the use of a helmet. Five provinces in Canada already have implemented this legislation and have displayed a significant increase in helmet use. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Simple things that can be done to prevent more burden to the health-care system should be taken into account when government wishes to maintain a successful health system that is already overstressed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Also it should be recognized that good health care is not just a reaction to illness but one that helps to embrace good health. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Bicycle accidents lead to an increase in health services. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Perhaps simple legislation surrounding mandatory helmet use for all cyclists could lead to future health-care savings and better protected cyclists. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">KARALYN BAGSHAW, </SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Winnipeg<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 19-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: JUDGE REFUSES TO DISMISS CHARGES
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.22/04  Page B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">THE physical scars have healed, but a Winnipeg woman crushed by a car three years ago says a never-ending court case is keeping the emotional wounds fresh. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Heather Schach, 30, breathed a sight of relief yesterday when a Queen's Bench judge refused to dismiss criminal charges against the man accused of causing the near-fatal April 2001 crash. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Defence lawyer Stan Nozick argued 38 months was too long for a case to linger before the courts, and the lengthy delay was a violation of his client's charter rights. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Justice Deborah McCawley disagreed following a full morning of arguments and said written reasons would soon follow. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Her decision means the case against Ryan Relleve will finally begin this morning. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I had hoped, and thought, things would have proceeded a lot quicker than this," Schach told the <EM><SPAN style="FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Free Press</SPAN></EM> outside court yesterday. She suffered a severe broken leg and required lengthy hospitalization and skin grafts to repair the damage. Schach underwent six months of physical rehabilitation. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I couldn't walk for the first four months," she said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Schach was injured while trying to retrieve something from the trunk of her car, which was parked on Ellice Avenue. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A vehicle -- allegedly driven by Relleve -- ran into another parked car directly behind Schach's, forcing it into her legs. She was pinned between both vehicles and her legs were crushed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The suspect vehicle fled the scene, but Schach's friend was able to get a licence plate number give it to police. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Relleve was arrested within 20 minutes at his home. Police didn't lay charges until the fall of 2001 after seeking a Crown opinion, said Nozick. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">There have been three major delays in the case. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The first occurred when a Crown attorney with conduct of it retired. The second involved a Crown witness being unavailable to testify. The third was caused by Nozick's busy schedule. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Nozick said yesterday the only issue for McCawley to decide at trial is whether Relleve was behind the wheel of the car when it caused the chain reaction that injured Schach. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Police officers will testify this morning about a statement Relleve gave upon his arrest. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:mike.mcintyre@freepress.mb.ca">mike.mcintyre@freepress.mb.ca</A> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 20-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: A CENTRE OF EXCELLENCE: Creating New Collision Facility Both A Challenge And A Privilege For General Manger
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">You wouldn&#8217;t think someone who works all day restoring cars to good health would spend his free time doing the same.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But Vein Hiebert, General Manager of the new Jim Gauthier Collision Centre at 160 Watson Street, has an abiding passion for all things automotive. Hiebert has been involved with repairing cars and trucks for more than three decades and in his spare time loves to tinker with engines and build street rods.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">His pride and joy &#8212; a 1948 Chevrolet Sedan Delivery -- is a gleaming blue and white restoration which he has taken across Canada as well as to New York and San Francisco.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">As general manager of the Collision Centre, Hiebert presides over a staff of 10 highly skilled technicians with combined work experience of almost 190 years.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;We repair not only General Motors products, but pretty well everything, including foreign vehicles,&#8221; he says. &#8220;Mr. Gauthier actually asked me to design this Centre and that was both a challenge and a privilege.&#8221;<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Hiebert specifically suggested it be called a &#8220;Collision Centre&#8221; rather than a &#8220;body shop&#8221; because the latter has negative connotations for some people.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The GM says particular attention has been paid to landscaping the Centre to ensure it blends seamlessly into a largely residential neighbourhood. Damaged vehicles are carefully stored away from public view.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Hiebert says the new Centre is more than 14,000 square feet, compared to the previous premises which were a little over 4,000. It&#8217;s a modern, state-of-the-art facility with two down draft spray booths with bake cycles.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The Centre also has the latest frame straightening equipment and many other modern features, including a vacuum sanding system which ensures the highest workplace and environmental standards.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">All solvents and oils at the new Collision Centre are recycled and special care has been taken to ensure emissions are absolutely minimal. The Centre works on everything from small cars up to one ton trucks.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;The Centre is custom designed and allows us to make repairs faster and with much more efficiency,&#8221; Hiebert explains. &#8220;We do pretty well everything from framework to glass work painting. The main challenge is scheduling work so that we have a steady flow.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That also means ensuring spare parts are ordered and obtained on time. Since several suppliers are often needed on a single collision repair job, that can take some juggling.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Hiebert says the Centre does repair jobs ranging in price from $100 all the way up t recent one on a fancy SUV which cost $28, The aim is always the same &#8212; do quality repairs as quickly as possible and get the vehicle, back to a satisfied customer.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">This efficient approach is paying off.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Hiebert estimates business has doubled in past couple of years, thanks to a sterling t of technicians who really know their work<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;Finding good people is a challenge but you get them you look after them well and they stay with you,&#8221; he says.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">&#8220;Our team has a great deal of experience and most are usually working on two or three jobs at any one time. It&#8217;s certainly possible make a good living working here and we v well together.&#8221;<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 21-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: AUTO INSURANCE RATES TO DIP FOR MOST ALBERTA MOTORISTS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Financial Post  June.22/04  Page FP2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">EDMONTON - Most Alberta drivers will pay slightly lower rates on part of their auto insurance coverage under reforms announced by the province yesterday. But along with the lower rates the government will slap a $4,000 cap on the amount of compensation that can be paid out for minor car crash injuries. Finance Minister Pat Nelson said the new insurance regulations that will come into effect on Oct. 1 will save Alberta motorists about $200-million a year. Under the changes, most drivers should see a minimum 5% rollback on compulsory insurance. The rollback will not apply to optional insurance options such as collision and glass coverage. Most drivers with good records will only save about $60 on annual premiums.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 22-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: dna tests identify three dead truckers
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>The identities of three of four truckers killed in a fiery semitrailer pileup near Kenora last month have been confirmed through DNA testing.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Troy Lansall, 35, of Winnipeg 30-year-old Balinder Chandi of Brampton, Ont., and Dilbag Singh, 48, of Montreal died in the horrific May 20 crash, Ontario Provincial Police said yesterday.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Lansall&#8217;s girlfriend, Rena Prefontaine, told The Sun last month he was a safety-conscious driver who worked for Winnipeg-based trucking firm Gardewine North.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>The remains of a fourth person killed in the collision have yet to be identified.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Two transport trucks collided head-on shortly after 1 a.m. in the eastbound lane and exploded into flames, OPP said.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>A second eastbound truck became involved in the crash, while a second westbound truck struck a rock cut while attempting to avoid the initial collision OPP said.</FONT></P>  <P align=center><FONT face=Verdana size=2>-30-</FONT></P>

Title: 23-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Truckers’ remains identified in crash  Examinations Identify 3 Of 4 In Kenora Wreck
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb Free Press June.23/04 Page A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P><FONT face=Verdana size=2>ONTARIO Provincial Police have identified three of four truckers who were killed May 20 in a fiery multi-vehicle collision on Hwy. 17 east of Kenora. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Police said forensic examination confirmed the deceased are Troy Lansall, 35, of Winnipeg, Balinder Chandi, 30, of Brampton, Ont. and Dilbag Singh, 48, of Montreal, Que. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Const. Sue Cain said the fourth victim has not yet been identified. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Friends of Lansall earlier said they suspected he was killed because one of the trucks involved was his, a Gardewine North tractor-trailer unit on a night run to deliver groceries to outlets in northwestern Ontario. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>"He was driving east and when he was coming toward a corner, a westbound truck was in his lane," said girlfriend Rena Prefontaine. "There was nothing he could do." </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>It's believed Lansall was killed instantly when the other truck hit him head-on. The three occupants in the east-bound truck were also killed. Both trucks then caught fire. A third truck rear-ended Lansall's truck and a fourth crashed into a rock face to avoid the two burning wrecks. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>"He was the safest driver," Prefontaine told the <I>Free Press</I>. "When he left I'd always tell him to drive careful and he'd say, 'I always do. It's the other idiots on the road that I worry about.'" </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>The victims were burned beyond recognition and police used DNA testing to confirm their identities. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>The driver and passenger of the second truck, which rear-ended Lansall, are both still recovering in a Winnipeg hospital. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>The driver and passenger of the second westbound truck, which hit the rock face, were not injured. </FONT></P>  <P><FONT face=Verdana size=2>bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></P>  <P align=center><FONT face=Verdana size=2>-30-</FONT></P>

Title: 24-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car’s owner denies he was driving at time of crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb Free Press June.23/04 Page B5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>THE owner of a badly damaged car denies he was behind the wheel when it caused a chain-reaction accident that left a Winnipeg woman badly injured. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Ryan Relleve told court yesterday city police officers are lying to suggest he made self-incriminating statements about his involvement in the near-fatal crash. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Two officers have testified that Relleve said "it just happened so fast" and "I just pulled out of the parking lot -- I don't know what happened" following his April 2001 arrest. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>"I never said that. I asked them, 'What accident?' " Relleve testified yesterday. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Relleve claims he had returned home hours before the accident, leaving his car parked in the driveway. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Heather Schach, 30, suffered extensive leg injuries while trying to retrieve something from the trunk of her car, which was parked on Ellice Avenue. A vehicle, allegedly driven by Relleve, ran into another parked car directly behind Schach's, forcing it into her legs. She was pinned between both vehicles and her legs were crushed. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>The suspect vehicle fled the scene, but Schach's friend was able to get a licence plate number give it to police. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Police quickly traced it to Relleve and were at his Burrows Avenue home within 20 minutes. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>They found Relleve inside a bedroom, where he claimed to have been sleeping. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>One officer testified yesterday he searched Relleve's pants and found the keys to the car, which had sustained front-end damage. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Defence lawyer Stan Nozick is challenging the admissibility of Relleve's statements to police, claiming they were made after his client was refused access to a lawyer. "They were cursing me, screaming vulgarities, telling me I'm a liar," Relleve said yesterday of the arresting officers. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>"They were telling me to confess, to admit I was the driver. I was scared. I didn't know what to say." </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Police said yesterday they allowed Relleve to phone counsel within 30 minutes of his arrest, once they arrived at the Public Safety Building. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>They said he made the incriminating comments of his own free will, without threats or inducements. </FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Relleve's trial has taken 38 months to get to court because of a series of delays, including a retiring Crown attorney and a missing witness. </FONT></P>  <P><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Justice Deborah McCawley is expected to rule this morning on Nozick's attempts to have his client's statement dismissed. </FONT></P>  <P><FONT face=Verdana size=2><A href="mailto:mike.mcintyre@freepress.mb.ca">mike.mcintyre@freepress.mb.ca</A></FONT></P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>  <P align=justify>&nbsp;</P>

Title: 25-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In brief  Crash kills brandon man
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb Free Press June.23/04 Page B8
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT face=Verdana size=2>A&nbsp;27-year-old Brandon man was killed Sunday night after a car he was travelling in crashed near Polonia, Man. </FONT>  <P><FONT face=Verdana size=2>RCMP say Jody David Single was one of four males in a car going westbound on PTH 265 when the driver lost control on the gravel road. The car then flipped into the ditch. </FONT></P>  <P><FONT face=Verdana size=2>One of the men was treated at the scene and two were taken to Brandon hospital and are listed in serious condition with non-life-threatening injuries. RCMP say alcohol and speed are believed to have been factors in the mishap. </FONT></P>  <P><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Polonia is about 20 kilometres north of Neepawa. </FONT></P>  <P align=center><FONT face=Verdana size=2>-30-</FONT></P>

Title: 26-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: dna tests identify three dead truckers
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>The identities of three of four truckers killed in a fiery semitrailer pileup near Kenora last month have been confirmed through DNA testing.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Troy Lansall, 35, of Winnipeg 30-year-old Balinder Chandi of Brampton, Ont., and Dilbag Singh, 48, of Montreal died in the horrific May 20 crash, Ontario Provincial Police said yesterday.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Lansall&#8217;s girlfriend, Rena Prefontaine, told The Sun last month he was a safety-conscious driver who worked for Winnipeg-based trucking firm Gardewine North.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>The remains of a fourth person killed in the collision have yet to be identified.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>Two transport trucks collided head-on shortly after 1 a.m. in the eastbound lane and exploded into flames, OPP said.</FONT></P>  <P align=justify><FONT face=Verdana size=2>A second eastbound truck became involved in the crash, while a second westbound truck struck a rock cut while attempting to avoid the initial collision OPP said.</FONT></P>  <P align=center><FONT face=Verdana size=2>-30-</FONT></P>  <P align=justify>&nbsp;</P>

Title: 30-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: TWO WHEELS, TOO COSTLY?: MPI To Ratchet Up Motorcyclists' Rates Again
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">This shouldn't come as a surprise -- motorcyclists could see another Autopac increase next year. Manitoba Public Insurance applied yesterday to the Public Utilities Board to boost rates for motorcycle owners by 15% to its premium revenue. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Every year we've seen more motorcycle claims and every year the average claim gets more expensive," said Marilyn McLaren, MPI's vice-president of insurance operations, in explaining the proposed rate increase. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Linda Thomas, acting president of the Coalition of Manitoba Motorcycle Groups, said her organization isn't happy about another rate hike. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Some motorcyclists have had to quit riding because, for them, it's no longer affordable to ride," she said, adding the increase will cost some riders an additional $270. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <H5 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">EXCLUDE NOT-AT-FAULT CLAIMS <o:p></o:p></SPAN></H5>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Motorcyclists will pay about $2,200 to insure their bikes for the May 3 to Sept. 30 riding period this year, said Thomas. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Her group wants MPI to exclude accident claims where a motorcyclist isn't at fault when determining its new rates. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We don't mind paying our fair share of insurance but we don't feel that we should be paying if we haven't been at fault," Thomas said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Although motorcyclists could pay more next year, MPI hasn't requested an overall increase in premium revenue for the sixth time in seven years. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">More than half of all motorists in Manitoba -- about 444,000 -- will pay the same rates or less next year. Of the approximate 391,000 vehicle owners that will receive premium increases, most will be less than $50. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Owners of family passenger vehicles will pay the same rates as last year -- about $776 -- while trailer and off-road vehicle owners will see reductions of 22% and 41%, respectively. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The amount each owner pays for insurance depends on the make and model of the vehicle, how and where it's driven, and the motorist's driving record, McLaren said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">MPI didn't need to increase its overall premiums this year because of stronger investment income, operational efficiency and revenue increases from a larger and more modern provincial vehicle fleet, she said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">MPI reported profits of $36.5 million for 2003. The public insurer saw approximately 243,000 claims for 2003/2004 at a cost of about $662 million. That's an increase of 8.8% compared to 2002/2003. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">If accepted, the new rates will take effect March 1.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 31-Jan-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: IN BRIEF: BUS COLLIDES WITH TRUCK
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.24/04  Page A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">TWO children and an adult were injured slightly when a school bus collided with a truck at about 11:30 a.m. yesterday on Lagimodiere Boulevard at Bishop Grandin Boulevard. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The three victims were taken to Victoria General Hospital in stable condition. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The bus was reported to be from nearby Springs Christian Academy. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 1-Feb-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: AUTOPAC PROPOSES TO FREEZE RATES FOR CARS IN 2005: But Motorcycle Coverage Would Go Up By 15%
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.24/04  Page B11
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">MANITOBA Public Insurance is proposing a series of rate changes that will see a freeze on the average family passenger vehicle for 2005 but a premium jump of 15 per cent for all motorcycle owners. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Jack Zacharias, MPI president and CEO, unveiled the proposed rate applications during a formal news conference yesterday afternoon at a downtown hotel. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The proposed premium changes will be submitted to the Public Utilities Board for review. A week-long public hearing will be held in September, with a decision expected by December. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Zacharias said this is the sixth year in the last seven where MPI is not requesting an overall increase in revenue. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Zacharias said that if the PUB approves the proposed premiums, the owner of the average family passenger vehicle will pay the same amount for insurance next year as this year, about $776. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We pride ourselves in the value we provide Manitobans and this application demonstrates yet again that Manitobans will continue to have among the very lowest insurance rates in Canada," Zacharias said. MPI used the example of a 1998 Chevrolet Cavalier LS, with a $300 deductible and 25 per cent merit discount. The owner now pays a premium of $1,025 and if the new application is approved the premium would drop $10 to $1,015. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">MPI said premiums for motorcycles are increasing to offset the cost of claims from motorcycle accidents. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">MPI estimates that if the PUB approves the application: <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">* Premiums will go down for 51.5 per cent of vehicle owners (430,438 vehicles). The bulk of these (86%) will see their premiums decrease by up to $50. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">* Premiums will increase for 47 per cent of vehicle owners (391,189 vehicles), with 89 per cent of these seeing increases of less than $50. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">* Premiums will be unchanged for 1.7 per cent of vehicle owners (13,934 vehicles). <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:aldo.santin@freepress.mb.ca">aldo.santin@freepress.mb.ca</A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 2-Feb-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RUNNING ROAD TO RECOVERY: Organizing Race For Mental Health Is Accident Victim's Therapy
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.24/04  Page
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">IT was during one of her regular twilight runs with her husband Eugene, on a sultry September night in 2002, that Colette Keefe's life began to spin out of control. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">And today -- 20 months after her body was struck by a car and broken in five places -- the 45-year-old mom is still trying to pick up the pieces of a life that's become as arduous and gruelling as the marathons she used to compete in. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Physically I've recovered, but it threw me right out of life, it completely threw me off," Keefe said from the </SPAN><?xml:namespace prefix = st1 ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" /><st1:place><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Grace</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">General</SPAN></st1:PlaceName><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> </SPAN><st1:PlaceType><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Hospital</SPAN></st1:PlaceType></st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">'s Extended Treatment Unit, part of its psychiatric ward. Her scheduled release last Friday from her third lengthy stay at the facility since the accident has been delayed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I couldn't bend over, I couldn't do a lot of things," said Keefe, who is allowed home for supper and a run with </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Eugene</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, every night. "I couldn't even comb my hair, my daughters had to comb it all the time because I couldn't lift up my arm. It just threw me. I don't know, I just... spun into another world after that." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">That world included hiding a deep post-accident depression from her husband until her psychiatrist had her committed to the Grace because she was suicidal. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">But running has been her real therapy, Keefe says. In fact, it's mostly from inside her hospital ward that, for the past year, she has "made thousands of calls" to organize a 5-km run/3-km walk this Sunday to raise funds for the Mental Health Education Resource Centre of Manitoba. "I want it to be a huge success," Keefe said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Being in this hospital, seeing people with schizophrenia and seeing them being locked up and everything, I sympathize with them and that will be my next career if... when I do, you know... this will be my next career... It's something I would like to do and help out with." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Christine Lafond, resource co-ordinator for the Manitoba Health-funded centre that provides information on mental illness to patients, their families, professionals and anyone else across the province, says 20 per cent of Canadians -- one in every five -- have some sort of mental illness ranging from anxiety to schizophrenia. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She says Keefe, who first contacted her about the run/walk last summer, is a remarkable person. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We thought that was a great opportunity to encourage, to stand behind her, and to give her as much support as we could," Lafond said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Keefe started running in 1993 and loved it, competing in Manitoba Marathons and running in the Timex Road Race series, often winning or finishing second in her age class. Then the accident happened. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Crossing the street while she was out for a run with </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Eugene</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">, she was struck down by a car whose driver failed to see her at the corner of St. Mary's Road and Nova Vista. She suffered five broken bones, a punctured lung and head injuries. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She was hospitalized for nine days and spent four months recovering at home under the care of one of her daughters. A deep depression, including suicidal tendencies, set in as her badly bruised body was starting to mend in hospital. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Once home, she hid the depression from </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Eugene</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">. But that all ended when she couldn't assure her psychiatrist she wouldn't harm herself. The doctor, over her initial objections and "3 1/2 hours of begging," had her committed to hospital last August. She was also hospitalized in January and she's been in this time since March. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It was hard," she said of keeping her depression from her husband. "I didn't talk as much, I know that. I was hardly talking when we'd go out for walks at night. Sometimes we didn't say one word. We ran every day and we walked every night. Running was a form of stress relief -- I don't feel depressed when I'm running -- and that was good." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">She'll be released from hospital to participate in Sunday's run but </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Eugene</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> says she might not be discharged from the Grace until July. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"It's been a bit of a hard ride for me," </SPAN><st1:City><st1:place><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Eugene</SPAN></st1:place></st1:City><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> said yesterday, adding about 50 runners had registered and he's hoping for about 150 runners and perhaps 50 walkers on Sunday. "This run, though, is helping her to carry on." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Sunday's run/walk is slated to start at </SPAN><st1:time Hour="8" Minute="0"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">8 a.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> at Assiniboine Park Duck Pond. Registration is $20, and race kits can be picked up at the Running Room's location at </SPAN><st1:Street><st1:address><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">1875 Grant Avenue</SPAN></st1:address></st1:Street><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> on Friday between </SPAN><st1:time Hour="16" Minute="0"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">4-8 p.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> or Saturday between </SPAN><st1:time Hour="10" Minute="0"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">10 a.m.-2 p.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Race day registration (</SPAN><st1:time Hour="6" Minute="45"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">6:45-7:20 a.m.</SPAN></st1:time><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">) is $25. For more information or to register, call the Keefes at 255-2488 or the Mental Health Education Resource Centre at 772-4917. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:chris.cariou@freepress.mb.ca">chris.cariou@freepress.mb.ca</A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 3-Feb-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: LOCAL BRIEFS: Motorists fill court to argue tickets
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">There's a long line forming in the court house to challenge the legality of red light and photo radar cameras in Winnipeg. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">While five men were contesting their photo radar tickets before Magistrate Norman Sundstrom in traffic court yesterday, Jon Siddall filed a notice of motion in Queen's Bench seeking to overturn his $93 ticket. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Siddall will appear July 15 but his lawyer Daniel Orlikow said the case will be adjourned to a later date. Siddall wants permission to file a class action suit to force the city to return millions of dollars in alleged unfairly collected fines levied from city drivers. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Orlikow said the case will proceed regardless of Sundstrom's ruling, to be handed down Nov. 15. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"We believe the city can not place the photo radar devices anywhere it wants," said Orlikow. "What (Sundstrom) rules has no bearing on what happens in this case. If he says the tickets are still valid, that's his opinion. We will strongly consider his opinion, but you can have two opinions." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Five people -- including Harold Danielson, Michelle Louise Eastoe, Donald Dacquisto and Ken St. Germaine -- argued their tickets, received at intersections, should be tossed aside since the cameras were not in a school zone, playground or construction area.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 4-Feb-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: PHOTO ENFORCEMENT UNDER ATTACK: Lawyer Wants To Sue City For Wrongly Placed Cameras
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  June.25/04  Page A12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">WINNIPEG'S venture into photo traffic enforcement fell under attack on a second front yesterday with a city lawyer asking for the right to sue city hall to force it to pay back anyone caught by a wrongly placed intersection camera. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lawyer Dan Orlikow said yesterday he wants to ask a Court of Queen's judge for permission to launch a class action suit on behalf of Winnipeggers who've been fined after being photographed by intersection cameras that aren't near a playground, school zone or road construction area. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">More than 218,000 tickets have been sent out and more than $17.3 million in fines has been collected since January last year. Orlikow has a court date set for July 16, but that will likely be put over to early winter as another judge wrestles over wording in the province's Highway Traffic Act, the section that regulates photo enforcement. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Lawyer Donald Dacquisto and Len Eastoe of Traffic Tickets Experts argued in Traffic Court yesterday that the wording is such that the law for the cameras is so ambiguous that it can't be enforced. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The crux of the case has to do with section 257.1 (2) of the Highway Traffic Act. It outlines how the "imaging-capturing speed enforcement devices" can be used by municipalities. It was enacted by the province in the days leading up to the unveiling of photo enforcement in Winnipeg on Nov. 6, 2002. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">It says the devices can only be used: (a) in construction zones, playground zones and school zones and; (b) intersections that are controlled by control lights. Dacquisto and Eastoe said that the word "and" is conjunctive, meaning elements in both "a" and "b" must be present in deciding where the city's 24 cameras are placed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Twelve new cameras are to be put up by August. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"This is legislation drafted by the government," Dacquisto said. "They can say anything they want. When they use 'and' they're stuck with it." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Magistrate Norman Sundstrom is to issue a written decision on the case Nov. 15. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Crown attorney Lisa Cupples said the language in the Highway Traffic Act is clear and to interpret it as far as Dacquisto and Eastoe would be absurd. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Orlikow said the case law that supports both challenges is solid. "It's a legal issue, not a factual issue," Orlikow said. He also said other case law prevents the province from retroactively re-writing the section, replacing "and" with "or". He added whatever Sundstrom decides, or what happens with his own push for a class action suit, the case will likely go to the Supreme Court of Canada before any decision is made on whether Winnipeg drivers deserve to get any fine money back.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><A href="mailto:Bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca">Bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; LAYOUT-GRID-MODE: line; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 5-Feb-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: FACING THE ROAD NOT TAKEN: Many Canadians Are So Afraid Of Driving That Their Lives Revolve Around Staying Off The Highway, But There Are Treatments That Can Help, Writes Erin Pooley
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Globe and Mail  June.25/04  Page A13
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Mary Anne Catalano used to be terrified of highways. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The 26-year-old athletic therapist spent more than three years completely avoiding the high-speed arteries for fear of getting in an accident or losing control.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"The highway seemed like the scariest thing ever -- it was just way too high-speed," said Ms. Catalano, who estimates she added an extra half-hour to her commute every day by opting for a slower route to school from her home in Etobicoke, Ont.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ms. Catalano is one of thousands of Canadian drivers who experience some degree of anxiety when it comes to getting behind the wheel, said Dr. Martin Antony, director of the Anxiety Treatment and Research Centre at St. Joseph's Healthcare in Hamilton.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">And although the majority of those individuals never seek treatment for their fear, 1 to 5 per cent of Canadians develop a clinically significant anxiety disorder related to their fear of driving, estimates Dr. Antony.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">For Ms. Catalano -- who got her licence at 21 -- a fear of high speeds, merging into traffic and getting into an accident started to "become a major pain in the butt."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoBodyText3 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: left" align=left><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I wanted to be able to go places. Knowing that I was graduating, I didn't want to restrict my job search just to places I could get to without taking a major highway," she said, adding she has gradually been able to get over her fear by "taking on the highway" one step at a time.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">For other motorists, a fear of driving can be related to making left turns, crossing bridges, parallel parking or getting caught in a traffic jam. Many motorists are also afraid of causing or getting into accidents as a result of their fear. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A study conducted by Dr. Antony in 1997 showed the average age of onset for driving-related phobias is 26, and that females experience the problem to a greater degree than males. He said heredity also plays a role in phobias.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Ironically, said Dr. Antony, "most people with a fear of driving are excellent drivers. They're really focused on driving, they have both hands on the wheel, they don't speed, they don't tailgate, they don't weave in and out and they don't drink while they're driving. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"I've never treated anyone who actually got into an accident because of a panic attack or anxiety. I've driven with lots of anxious people and they drive as well as anyone," he said. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">The good news is that there are a variety of treatments available for individuals with a driving phobia -- the majority of which involve some sort of repeated exposure to the driving environment. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Dr. Jaye Wald, a post-doctoral fellow in the department of psychiatry at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver runs a virtual-reality driving simulator that is used to treat patients in a "safe environment" while exposing them to common driving situations including nighttime, highway and urban driving "with snow and ice."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">A recent study published by Dr. Wald and Dr. Steven Taylor in the journal CyberPsychology &amp; Behaviour showed that some patients who underwent treatment saw improvement that lasted up to seven months.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Without treatment, the impact of a driving phobia on a person's life can range from being a mild inconvenience, such as in Ms. Catalano's case, to being severely debilitating, he said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">He recalls one patient who turned down a good job "so he could keep working at McDonald's" because it was within walking distance from home. Another patient sunk into a severe depression because of his fear, and yet another had to rely on her husband to chauffeur her around. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Despite a plethora of studies on more well-known phobias including arachnophobia (a fear of spiders) and acrophobia (a fear of heights) there has been relatively little research conducted on driving phobias.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Part of the problem, said Dr. Wald, is that people are ashamed to even acknowledge their fear. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Driving is a fairly large part of people's everyday daily life," she says. "To admit you're afraid of driving is quite embarrassing. I've seen many clients who are ashamed . . . if they're unable to."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">Steve, a 46-year-old sales representative from Hamilton, said his fear of being caught in a traffic jam has forced him to "completely rearrange" his driving schedule so he won't end up having another panic attack.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana">"Some people are fine if they're driving themselves, but if they're a passenger in the car, it's much worse," said Dr. Antony.
