In Europe, you see them from one end of the road to the other -- they are driven by teenagers and businessmen in three-piece suits."<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Indeed, Mr. DesRosiers notes that the micro segment in Europe currently captures a lofty 25% share of the entire vehicle market.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>And given the Smart Car's low base price, Mr. DesRosiers says it will also appeal to Canadians, who tend to be more frugal than Americans when it comes to purchasing automobiles. To wit: more than 40% of new vehicles sold in Canada each year are entry-level models.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"I think [Smart Car] is going to be overwhelmingly successful here," says Mr. DesRosiers. "They won't be able to ship enough of them to satisfy demand."<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Still, he cautions that the Smart Car isn't for everyone. Only the two-seater model -- known as the "Smart fortwo cdi" -- will initially be sold in here.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>A spokesman for Mercedes-Benz Canada says the company will eventually bring a four-seat model here and even introduce a Smart SUV, but in the meantime, the Smart Car is more suited as a family's second (or even third) vehicle.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>As well, Mr. DesRosiers says the car is best suited for city, as opposed to highway, driving. "It isn't meant for you to drive it from Toronto to Montreal every second weekend," he says.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>So, how does the Smart Car hold up in day-to-day driving? Recently FP Money was given a Smart Car for a week-long test. Here's what we discovered.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Size: First things first: the Smart Car makes a Toyota Corolla look like a Cadillac Escalade. Just 2.5 metres long, this is one extremely tiny automobile. Put another way, it actually fits into a standard-size parking space sideways.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Trunk space is limited to a few gym bags at best, although when driving solo, the passenger-side seat can be folded down to gain additional storage room.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>However, once seated within the Smart Car, the vehicle does not feel small at all. Indeed, the driver and passenger are actually positioned higher in a Smart Car than in a conventional automobile. Also, there is an abundance of headroom and legroom.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>And don't let the apparent lack of crumple zone worry you. Mercedes notes that in European crash tests, the Smart Car actually scored higher than much larger cars in the sub-compact category.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Technical details: The Smart Car is powered by a three-cylinder, 0.8-litre diesel engine generating 40 horsepower. The car has rear wheel drive, with the engine situated at the rear of the car, much like the old Volkswagen Beetle.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Two transmissions are offered: a fully automatic transmission or a six-speed "clutchless" tranny (and if you forget to shift, no worries: the Smart Car will shift for you -- it's just that darn Smart).<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The gas tank, meanwhile, holds just 27 litres of fuel (including five litres in reserve, beyond the point when the needle on your fuel gauge hits "E"). Theoretically, the Smart Car is capable of travelling more than 600 km on a single fill-up.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Performance: With a 40-horsepower engine (generating 74 lbs. of torque), the Smart Car doesn't exactly embody Corvette-like acceleration. Heck, it doesn't even deliver Chevette-like acceleration.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But that's not to say it's out of its league in real-life driving. On the contrary, it is a peppy performer given its low curb weight (730 kg). Meanwhile, on the highway, it is capable of a maximum speed of 135 km/h. Better yet, even when the pedal is pressed to the metal, the engine never seems to be labouring.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Still, the real test of the Smart Car is not on a drag strip or a racetrack oval. Rather, the car excels in real-life urban driving. Being so small, it makes for a very nimble automobile, able to squeeze past chubbier cars mired in traffic.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>That can translate into significant time savings. At one point during our test, traffic was bumper-to-bumper along the left lane of Toronto's Eglinton Avenue. The right lane was a write-off due to the proliferation of parked cars. Even so, there was still enough overlap asphalt for our Smart Car to zip past in the curb lane.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Reaction: This vehicle is nothing short of a head-turning machine. Drivers and pedestrians alike -- especially women --adore the Smart Car. (A 40-horsepower babe magnet -- who'd have thunk it?)<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The attention can be a tad disconcerting at times. When immobile at a stoplight across from a public transit bus, be prepared to receive the stares from a smorgasbord of faces. During such occasions, the Smart Car resembles an aquarium on wheels (and the driver feels like some sort of exotic fish).<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>In this regard, the Smart Car can slow you down. During our test, people were constantly gravitating towards our vehicle, peppering us with questions. (The three most common queries being, "What the [expletive] is that?", "Does it run on electricity?" and "Are you allowed to take it on the highway?") Therefore, be prepared to act as an ambassador for Smart Car Nation if you don't want to come across as some sort of an automotive snob. (Either that or carry around some brochures to hand out to inquisitive onlookers.)<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The money angle: In addition to its low sticker price, the Smart Car -- depending on the amount of driving one does -- could conceivably pay for itself within three or four years, given its miserly fuel consumption.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Mercedes claims the car consumes 3.1 litres of diesel fuel to travel 100 km on the highway and 3.9 litres per 100 km in city driving (for a combined rating of 3.5 litres per 100 km).<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>That's equivalent to about 80 (yes, 80) miles to the Imperial gallon, which is better fuel economy than a hybrid car such as the Toyota Prius. (Note, however, that during our test period, the Smart Car we tested consumed 4.4 litres per 100 km of combined city and highway driving.)<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Another benefit is that diesel fuel is priced cheaper than garden-variety gasoline. The day we filled up, a litre of diesel was selling for 69.9 cents while a litre of premium unleaded was going for 79.9 cents.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But frugal commuters be warned: Mercedes is selling every Smart Car that is being churned out by its Hambach, France plant. There will only be 800 new-model-year Smart Cars available for sale in Canada come this fall; after that, Mercedes plans on shipping about 1,000 models per year to Canada. There are no plans as of yet to sell the Smart Car in the U.S.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Bottom line: For all its funky cuteness and minuscule size, one can't help but feel that the Smart Car is a sneak peak at the sort of cars so many of us will be driving in the years to come, whether we like it or not.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Thanks to relatively inexpensive oil, we are currently living in a golden age of automobiles, wherein vast size and thunderous horsepower rule supreme.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But given that planet Earth contains a finite quantity of oil, micro vehicles such as the Smart Car are likely the shape of things to come.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Some gear-heads may scoff at the car's Mini-Me dimensions and its limited power, but consider this: driving a Smart Car still beats walking.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 15-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: AUTOMOTIVE SHOWCASE: TWO CAMPS EMERGE ON TOKING AND DRIVING: Sharp Points Of View On Marijuana Issue
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.03/04  Page H1/H10
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>MY recent column on marijuana use and driving drew a lot of response. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The theme of the article was that while I have no problem with the legalization of marijuana, we need to develop an accurate field test that would discourage people from smoking dope and driving. This is just one of the ways that a person can be impaired, and others would include medications, fatigue, and perhaps even an overdose of chocolate. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The letters fell into several categories, with two extremes. On the one hand were those who still believe that pot leads to harder stuff and should be totally banned. This seems rather unrealistic, since dope doesn't make you nasty but at worst, just temporarily stupid. Take it out of the realm of crime, make it taxable, and I doubt it will lead most users into the depths of depravity. If a person has a truly addictive personality, then everything from cough syrup to Coca-Cola can pose a danger. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The other kind of mail came from those who generally welcomed my position but did not see any danger in smoking pot while behind the wheel. Both extreme letter types came with links to a whole bunch of studies supposedly supporting their case. Apparently, for example, there is research that proves that people may even drive better while under the influence of marijuana. There are other, equally convincing papers for the other side, that demonstrate that pot rots the brain, destroys willpower and causes acne. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Sorry folks, we all know that there are enough studies around that you can always find one to support an idea, no matter how wild. Convinced that aliens are behind low-carb diets? I'm sure there is a research paper somewhere that appears to prove this. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>When it comes to driving, in the absence of real performance-measuring research, we have to go with empirical evidence. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>I have never seen anybody drive better, or even well, after having smoked dope, and we don't really need a new definition for universal joint. I'm willing to be proven wrong, but it is far too early for that. Push the credibility envelope too far and it could backfire. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Think of this. You are about to board a plane for a flight to Europe. On the gangway are the three pilots, passing a fattie back and forth, and acting rather giddy. Do you feel really good about trusting them with your life and the lives of your loved ones? How about a report from a traffic helicopter that starts with "dude, this is so cool." A fighter pilot who takes one last hit on a joint then prepares for a carrier launch? Drivers at the Indy 500 lighting up in the garage before the start? <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The Fraser Institute recently came out in support of legalizing marijuana. This was not a social study, but a hard dollars-and-cents evaluation of potential benefits. That is good, but in the absence of better information, keep it off the roads. Right here and now, we can't ignore the potential dangers of something that impairs motor skills and concentration. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><FONT face=Verdana><I><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB">Alan Sidorov is an experienced automotive racer, product tester and freelance journalist. You can e-mail Alan at the address below:</SPAN></I><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><A href="mailto:highambitions@telus.net"><FONT face=Verdana>highambitions@telus.net</FONT></A><FONT face=Verdana> <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 16-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: PASSIVE PROTECTION PUTS VOLVO SEDAN IN SAFEST COMPANY
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.03/04  Page H11
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>THERE are two types of safety built into modern vehicles: active and passive. Active safety is something that affects the way a driver controls a vehicle, such as vehicle handling and roll characteristics, ABS brakes, stability control and active steering systems. Many performance-oriented drivers believe that if all vehicles were built with superior handling, the passive safety systems would never be needed because drivers could easily steer their way out of danger. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Driver's skill becomes an important factor, however, and then there is always the unpredictable, such as a deer jumping out in front of you. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Passive safety systems include seatbelts, air-bag systems and body-structure design. All of these may be used during a collision to protect us from life-threatening impact forces. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Safety, both active and passive, has improved immensely in the last couple of decades and Volvo is one of the leaders in safety design. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The 2005 Volvo S40 sedan is their newest vehicle to enter the marketplace and is a fine example of current passive safety technology. The S40 is a smaller sedan but contains all the safety capabilities of their much larger vehicles. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Some of this safety technology is offered on other vehicles, but Volvo continues to lead with some new and innovative systems. Body structure plays a huge role in protecting vehicle occupants. Race fans have witnessed racecars self-destructing against track walls at over 300 kilometres per hour, and the drivers have lived to tell the story. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>These cars protected the driver by gradually absorbing the impact forces and directing them away from the driver's compartment. Passenger car body structure does the same thing. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Volvo's S40 front structure uses four kinds of steel to control the rate and direction of impact forces. A small car like the S40 sedan is more difficult to design because all the deformation forces must be controlled in a shorter distance, but Volvo safety engineers have accomplished this by building the body structure in a "crash box" design. Each crash box has its own crumple rate to progressively absorb the impact forces as they get closer to the passenger compartment. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Another advantage of using this crash box design is that the crash boxes can be replaced separately if they are damaged in a collision, lowering vehicle repair costs. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Side impact forces are also absorbed by crumple zones, but this time the crumple zone is located as part of the S40's centre floor pan tunnel. As impact forces push the side of the car in, the force is transferred into the seat, where special bars carry to forces to the centre of the floor pan tunnel. The tunnel crumples, allowing the seat to move inward and cushioning the impact forces on the passenger. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Front air bags, side-impact air bags and side-curtain air bags are all common on many new vehicles. While you may be familiar with air bags, many are not aware that some seatbelts also contain devices to pull the belts tight in a collision so occupants are held securely in position. Pyrotechnic charges are the most common method of deploying this type of seat belt. Some vehicles have the charge located at the base of the seatbelt buckle but more and more vehicles are placing the charge by the retractor mechanism, so that the shoulder belt is pulled tight first. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The air bag's system computer activates the seatbelt charge and the belt is pulled tight. During an impact, the belt system is designed to "stretch" gradually, allowing the occupant to move forward slightly and reduce the force placed on our body. Volvo has taken this concept one step further and introduced an industry first -- the retracting steering column. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Steering columns are designed to retract during an impact by shearing some plastic pins and allowing the outer column tube to slide down the inner tube. This often happens when the driver impacts the steering wheel. To further reduce the possibility of injury, Volvo's S40 uses a pyrotechnic charge to pull the steering column away from the driver. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>With 140 millimetres of travel, the steering wheel can be moved away before the driver hits it, reducing upper body injuries. Sensors in the driver's seat monitor seat position in relationship to the steering wheel and sophisticated software activates the charge to retract the steering column only when necessary. Every collision and every driver is unique. The system is designed to react differently for each situation. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Most of the safety built into a vehicle is never visible. It is usually only truly appreciated after a serious collision. Volvo has long been known for innovative safety design and when one manufacturer leads the way, the others are usually quick to follow. Everyone is driving safer vehicles today because of the leadership shown by a few.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 17-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: PRUDENT PASSING BECOMING A LOST ART
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.03/04  Page I1
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>WITH the increasing prominence of multi-lane roads, the art of safe passing is rapidly, and sadly, becoming a memory. Sadly, because failing to conduct this important manoeuvre safely results in almost certain injury -- and all too frequently, death. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Improper passing has led to a new phenomenon -- the widespread cry to twin roads, to spend millions to ensure vehicles and drivers don't meet while going in opposite directions. Until the various jurisdictions locate the funds to acquire the land, design and build the multi-lane roads, perhaps a tiny percentage of that money could be spent on education and enforcement. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The trick, like the law, is really quite simple. Pass only in designated areas and when there is sufficient space and visibility. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The problems begin when drivers fail to follow one of these two basic rules. The failure to do so can often be broken into two areas -- passing when you can't see far enough ahead, or failing to look far enough ahead. Impatient drivers who pull out and pass without being able to see far enough ahead to complete the manoeuvre safely are the biggest problem. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Anyone passing on a solid line or other area or situation where vision is limited is endangering not only himself or herself, but the vehicle(s) they are passing and oncoming traffic. The most common mistake is passing on turns or hills, but other problem areas include bridges, tunnels or when an intersection or railway lies ahead. It seems as though each week we read or hear of serious injury or death resulting from this stupidity. Like driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, and a number of other tragic and illegal activities, this can only be reduced by enforcement and punishment. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The other issue is not realizing how much room or time is needed. Beginning drivers are usually taught this activity with an instructor in the right-hand seat using some sort of timing technique. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>There are several advantages here: The instructor has experience, a will to live and knowledge the driver is inexperienced. The lesson, though, is something all too few people carry on through life -- look carefully at the traffic, particularly at any approaching vehicle. Pass only if the road is level, straight and there is a sufficient time to complete the manoeuvre safely. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>How much time? Therein lies the rub. Traffic is generally moving faster than at any time in history. And all too often, the oncoming vehicle is travelling well in excess of posted limits, making timing even more critical. A vehicle travelling at 100 km/h covers 27 metres, or about 100 feet, every second. That means the gap between vehicles travelling in opposite directions closes at the rate of 54 metres, or 200 feet, per second. Obviously if speed is higher, the distance needed to pass is greater. Without getting into complicated math, generally speaking you need about 20 seconds to safely pass another vehicle travelling 10 to 15 km/h slower than you. There are a number of factors, including the difference in speed between your vehicle and the one you wish to pass, the speed of the oncoming vehicle, the ability of your vehicle to accelerate quickly and the need to stay within the speed limit, to list just a few. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>The first and most important rule is to leave plenty of room. If you are passing while another vehicle is approaching, make sure that driver knows you are passing -- use your signals and lights. We are lucky in this country to have daytime running lights, allowing us to identify vehicles coming in the opposite direction more readily. But don't bet your life on it -- older vehicles, American tourists and non-passenger vehicles do not have daytime running lights. A lot of people make the mistake of pulling right up behind the vehicle they wish to pass, reducing their ability to see what's coming until they actually pull out into the opposing lane. Hang back a safe distance to increase your ability to see what's coming. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Other considerations before attempting to pass include: 1) Is someone passing you? Check your mirrors before starting your pass. 2) Are there any side roads or driveways were another vehicle might pull into your path? 3) Does the driver of the vehicle you are passing know of your intentions? <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Once you are committed, signal, accelerate past the other vehicle and check for roadside hazards, areas of reduced space and visibility. Think of an escape path or way out should something happen. Do not pull back into your lane until you can see the vehicle you passed in your rear-view mirror, not your side mirror. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>A properly timed and executed pass is a thing of beauty. Done properly, a pass should not inconvenience other drivers. The vehicle you are passing or any coming in the opposite direction should not have to change their speed or direction. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><FONT face=Verdana>Like everything else we do at the wheel, it's all a matter of visibility, time and distance -- with more than a bit of patience thrown in.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-GB style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 18-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CYCLIST CRASHES INTO SPORT UTILITY
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">A cyclist was in serious condition in hospital last night, hours after he and a sport utility vehicle collided at a North End intersection. Witnesses say the male cyclist, 47, was southbound on McGregor Street when he slammed into an eastbound Chevrolet Tracker passing through the intersection on Burrows Avenue. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"The guy in the Tracker had the green light and the guy on the bike came barrelling into it," said Roy Mykytyshyn, who was outside the Ukrainian National Home Association on Burrows when the accident happened at 3:04 p.m. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"(The cyclist) fell down, the vehicle stopped in the middle of the intersection, and the driver ran out to see how the guy was," Mykytyshyn said, adding the cyclist wasn't wearing a helmet. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"He was just lying there. He looked dead," he said. "Who knows why the guy on the bike was in the middle of the intersection on a red light?" <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">A man who lives at the corner said the driver stayed at the scene for a few minutes after the accident. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">John, who didn't want to give his last name, thought he saw the man get into the back of a police cruiser. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">He said paramedics put a brace around the cyclist's neck and lifted him on to a stretcher before he was loaded into an ambulance and taken to hospital. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Winnipeg police taped off the intersection and marked evidence on the road, including a pair of sunglasses near the curb. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">No charges had been laid as of press time last night.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 19-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: HIT CYCLIST SUFFERS MASSIVE INJURIES
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.07/04  Page B3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">A cyclist was rushed to hospital yesterday with massive head and chest injuries after he was hit by a vehicle at the intersection of Burrows Avenue and McGregor Street. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The accident occurred around 3:30 p.m. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The 21-year-old driver of the Chevrolet Tracker which hit the cyclist said the accident wasn't his fault. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"I've never been in a situation like this before," said the shaken young man, moments before he was led into a police cruiser. "I feel really bad. I don't know what to say, but I'd like for anybody who was close to him to know it wasn't my fault and I hope he's okay." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The driver said that the cyclist ran a red light. Police quickly closed off the entire intersection with yellow tape after the collision. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">About a dozen officers were called into analyse the scene, some taking pictures. The cyclists' sunglasses were still lying in the intersection hours after he had been hit with blue chalk marking where his body landed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">One witness who was interviewed by police said the cyclist was at least 35-years-old and wasn't wearing a helmet. The man declined to comment further. The cyclist was riding an older model blue Raleigh 10-speed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Damage to the bike was minimal. The front tire was slightly bent, the seat twisted and the chain off. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The Tracker, which appeared to be travelling eastbound on Burrows Avenue was parked just a few metres away from the bike which was propped up against a traffic box. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The vehicle had a couple of dents on the right front side of its hood. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Ken Miller who lives just one house away from the intersection said he saw the victim lying in the street. "I could just see the top of his head," said Miller adding that he didn't see any blood. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Miller said there are plenty of close calls and accidents at the intersection. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Last Sunday he said a car plowed into a tree on the boulevard just east of the crossing. "A lot of people run red lights," said Miller. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">He said the police should install a red-light camera at the intersection. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:david.kuxhaus@freepress.mb.ca">david.kuxhaus@freepress.mb.ca</A> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 20-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MOTHER CRIPPLED BY VAN CAN'T SUE: Autopac Act Bars Going After Chrysler
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.07/04  Page A1/A2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">PARALYSED from the chest down last October after a rollaway Chrysler minivan crushed her in front of her own home, Darlene Hellerman can no longer tuck her two young sons into bed. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">There's a lot the 35-year-old Headingley resident can't do anymore. Can't reach the boys' bedrooms in the lower level of their beautiful custom-built home. Can't play outside with Eric, 6, or Gregory, 8. Can't exist without a daily handful of pills and a world of pain. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">And now she knows she can't sue Chrysler, the company she blames for her tragically altered life. She and her husband claim the auto giant built family vehicles for eight years without a brake-shift interlock, an inexpensive feature that prevents vehicles with an automatic transmission from accidentally being knocked into gear. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Because the full-time mom, a native of Ontario, lives in Manitoba and this province has no-fault insurance, she cannot go after the car manufacturer she believes is responsible for her accident. It seems impossible, but the Manitoba Public Insurance Corporation Act flatly denies Manitoba drivers the right to sue not just other drivers, but even the makers of possibly defective cars. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">On page 50 of the massive 104-page act, there are two lines of legalese that forbid the sort of action the Hellermans want to take. The message, although it might seem unbelievable to those of us who don't know the nuances of the act, is clear. Compensation "stands in lieu of all rights and remedies arising out of bodily injuries to which this part applies and no action in that respect may be admitted before any court." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">In other words, not only can you not sue the person who runs a red light and smashes up your car, you can't sue a company you believe manufactured an automobile with a defect that caused your accident. MPIC general counsel Kevin McCulloch says the act is clear and has been tested in the Manitoba Court of Appeal. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"It's an absolute denial of any right to court action," he says. A complainant who felt a defective seatbelt had contributed to his injuries attempted to challenge the act in court, McCulloch says. He failed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The 1998 Caravan that struck Hellerman was owned by a girlfriend. It had the key in the ignition but was not running. After the other kids had been unloaded, the friend's five-year-old bumped the gear shift into reverse. It started to roll. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The brake-shift interlock, which prevents a vehicle from rolling unless the brake pedal is also depressed, became mandatory on Chrysler minivans in 2000. Transport Canada did not make the brake-shift interlock mandatory until 2003. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Calling Hellerman's accident "a sad situation," DaimlerChrysler senior manager of communications Stuart Schorr says in an e-mail the brake-shift interlock "is a convenience feature." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"The 1998 Dodge Caravan was equipped with a key interlock system designed to prevent unintended vehicle movement. We understand, in this situation, the keys were left in the vehicle with an unattended child," his e-mail reads in part. "This situation is a sad reminder that children should never be left alone in vehicles. Regardless of the features in the vehicle, the company stresses drivers follow basic safety principles, including never leaving keys in an unattended vehicle, not leaving children unattended in a vehicle and putting children under 12 in the back seat." It's hard to know who Glen and Darlene Hellerman blame more -- Chrysler for not issuing a recall of the minivans, or MPI for preventing them from suing. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Glen consulted three lawyers about a lawsuit. Each time, he says, he was told he'd never be allowed to proceed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"MPI is deemed to provide benefits to everyone in the province," Glen says, his words bitter. "We didn't want to settle, but the lawyers just told us to give up. The citizens of Manitoba need to be made aware of the shortcomings of public insurance. "The problem is, we wanted to make sure Chrysler would be forced into a recall. How many other families have these vehicles?" <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Darlene, often struggling with tears, says this is not about money. Cash, she says, won't give her back her legs. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"I just want to fix it so no other mothers or children have to suffer." <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">She used to do everything with her boys. She was the one who volunteered at their school, threw ball with them and made sure their lives ran smoothly. She was the one who kept the house running. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The family is resigned to accepting an Autopac settlement of about $90,000. They've also had some home-care support, had the seat of their own van renovated for wheelchair access and been provided with a manual wheelchair and a hospital bed. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">While they qualify to have their house made wheelchair-accessible, they're returning to their home town of Chatham, Ont., at the end of the month and renovating a house there. Autopac will pay for those changes. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Life here is just too hard, they say, and they need family support. There have been other injuries and deaths linked to rolling Chrysler minivans in the U.S. Court cases were launched in at least two incidents where mothers were struck and killed by their own vehicles. Schorr did not answer questions about those lawsuits or whether they have been settled. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The Hellermans still have two questions of their own. First, how can a public insurance act claiming to benefit all Manitobans prevent them from taking action against a huge corporation they believe has harmed them? And how else are they going to get the message out to the hundreds or thousands of other parents who might be courting danger in the family minivan? <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">They've just taken steps to answer that second question, although that's surely small comfort to a mother who just wants to tuck her boys in at night. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:lindor.reynolds@freepress.mb.ca">lindor.reynolds@freepress.mb.ca</A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">-30-<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>

Title: 21-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: IN BRIEF: CHASE NETS STOLEN GOODS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.07/04  Page A2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">POLICE have recovered property reported stolen in break-ins between Portage la Prairie and Sandy Bay after arresting two men from Sandy Bay First Nation. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The Dakota Ojibway Police Service arrested the men Sunday after chasing a vehicle reported stolen from Portage la Prairie, acting Chief Jim Cockburn said in a news release. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">During the chase, the driver of the stolen vehicle tried to ram a police vehicle, Cockburn said. Eventually, the stolen vehicle stalled and police captured the two men after a foot chase. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Police recovered thousands of dollars worth of stolen property, including two guns, a lawn mower, a chain saw, a garden tiller and a battery charger. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Joseph Ryan McIvor, 21, is charged with possessing stolen property worth more than $5,000, fleeing police, dangerous driving, and breaching the terms of his release from custody. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Bradley Robert Richard, 19, is charged with possessing stolen property worth more than $5,000, fleeing police, and breaching the terms of his release. <o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 22-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: A HAZARDOUS CYCLE
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Globe and Mail  July.07/04  Page A12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">It may have been small-claims court, but the claim being made on behalf of Toronto cyclists was large: that cities have an obligation to design roadways so that they are safe for bike riders.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The case involved a cycling activistwho received a "door prize" on Queen Street West, a busy east-west artery inToronto's downtown core. A door prize is the sardonic name for a car door that opens in a cyclist's path. Hannah Evans suffered a mild concussion and bruises in the 2002 accident and sued the city for damages.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">At its simplest, the case was about basic negligence. The city had once designated the street a bicycle route and put up signs inviting cyclists to use the street; but as safety standards for lane width evolved and it became clear that Queen Street West did not meet them, the city apparently removed the designation without remembering to remove the signs. To compound the problem, the downtown area's most popular designated bicycle lane, which follows Beverley and St. George Streets, leads to Queen Street West, where cyclists are in effect stranded.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">But Ms. Evans made a broader claim. Citing common-law principles about the sharing of roadways, dating from the early 19th century when horses stood to win a door prize from careless drivers, she argued through her lawyers that cities have an obligation to adapt the roads to changing uses so that they are safe for all. On Queen Street West, between 14 and 17 per cent of vehicles are bicycles, according to evidence presented in court. And the city has a stated policy of encouraging people to use bicycles instead of cars for work and school trips, of making all streets safe for cyclists and of expanding bike routes. Roughly 8 per cent of local residents ride bicycles to school or work.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">This is a rather literal case of rights colliding. Cars and bicycles have a right to be on the road, but should the city be required, say, to remove Queen Street West's parking lane, as cyclists argue, to make the road safer for cyclists? That would be unfair to merchants.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">In the end, Deputy Judge Morris Winer found that the city shouldered 25 per cent of the blame in this case; the car driver bore 50 per cent and Ms. Evans bore 25. (She was not wearing a helmet, which points to the lack of respect some cyclists have for the law.) He ordered the city to pay Ms. Evans $1,125 and a portion of her legal costs, and said the city should make changes to Queen Street West in keeping with the changing use of the street.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Wisely, he did not prescribe these changes, leaving it to the city to balance all the interests involved. Motorists defeated the horse long ago, but cyclists are notgoing to go away. They deserve respect.</SPAN><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 23-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: OIL FIRMS FORBID DRIVING WHILE YAKKING ON CELLPHONE
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Globe and Mail  July.07/04  Page B4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">If you think that jerk meandering across your lane with a cellphone in his ear is a road hazard, Big Oil agrees.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><B><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Imperial Oil Ltd.</SPAN></B><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"> and <B>Exxon Mobil Canada Ltd.</B> have joined their Texas-based parent, Exxon Mobil Corp., in forbidding employees to use phones while driving on company business. <B>Shell Canada Ltd.</B> and the rest of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group adopted the same rule last winter.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"'Engine on, cellphone off' is the short form of our policy," Shell Canada public affairs manager Jan Rowley said in Calgary.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Eric Bristow, safety and environmental planning manager at Toronto-based Imperial Oil, said the company's rule is: "When you're driving, you can't answer the cellphone and you can't make the call out. If you get a cellphone call, have your recording take the message, pull over, park safely and then you can call back."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Although the risks of using a phone behind the wheel have been debated in the Alberta Legislature, a Quebec coroners' inquest and elsewhere, it remains legal in Canada to yak and drive. That doesn't make it safe, the oil companies say.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">The Exxon Mobil rule, which took effect June 1 but wasn't announced in Canada until yesterday, was based partly on a survey of scientific literature by yet another subsidiary, New Jersey-based Exxon Mobil Biomedical Sciences Inc., Mr. Bristow said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"We had them do a study of the various studies that have been done on the subject and they actually looked at nine different studies that they viewed as scientifically credible. Reviewing the studies, it became quite obvious that there was a clear and significant risk involved in someone using a cellphone while driving."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Among the findings, he said, were these:<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Cellphone users showed a reduced ability to maintain lane position.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Their lag times in braking could be three times those of drivers with legal amounts of alcohol in their systems.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">Hands-free phones were not significantly safer. "There's a bit of a false perception that if you're using a hands-free device, somehow that's a lot better than a handheld device, but the studies and the data show otherwise," he said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">He said some people see using a cellphone as comparable to listening to the radio or chatting with a passenger but researchers found no increased risk in the latter two pastimes. He has his own ideas about why that is so, he said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">"If you're engaged in listening to the radio, you can sort of tune it out if you need to, or if there's somebody beside you, they're going to see the traffic unfolding and you can temporarily tune them out. But if you're talking to somebody on the other end of a cellphone, they don't know what's going on and it's hard to sort of say, 'Hey, can I put you on hold for a second?' There's that constant pressure to keep the conversation going."<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">He said the rule was adopted out of concern for employees' safety, not out of fear that the company would be held liable for accidents they caused. "That wasn't a consideration in developing this policy. In fact it never came up in developing the policy," he said.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 24-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: TWO SERIOUS MOTORCYCLE CRASHES
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 3.75pt 0in 6pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none"><FONT face=Arial><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; COLOR: #333333; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">There's been yet another serious motor-vehicle accident involving a motorcycle. Just after 8 'clock Wednesday morning a motorcycle and a car collided at Selkirk and Arlington. The motorcyclist's injuries are considered serious. The intersection will likely be closed for most of the morning. </SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; COLOR: black; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 3.75pt 0in 6pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none"><FONT face=Arial><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; COLOR: #333333; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">Tuesday night, a 23-year old man on a motorcycle struck a tree, and a metal sign on Church near Sheppard. He died of his injuries. </SPAN><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; COLOR: black; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 3.75pt 0in 6pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; COLOR: #333333; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><FONT face=Arial>The 49-year old male cyclist who collided with a car Tuesday afternoon at Burrows and MacGregor also died of his injuries. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 3.75pt 0in 6pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; COLOR: #333333; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><FONT face=Arial>No names have been released. </FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 3.75pt 0in 6pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none" align=center><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; COLOR: #333333; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><FONT face=Arial>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 25-Mar-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Govt. rejection of public auto insurance 'is an insult to motorists' intelligence'
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Northern Light (Bathurst)   Wed 07 Jul 2004   Page: A1 / Front   Section: News   Byline: Gregory Delaney   Source: Northern Light
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 5pt 0in; mso-layout-grid-align: none"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><FONT face=Arial>The New Brunswick government's decision to retain private <B><SPAN style="COLOR: #000066">automobile</SPAN></B> <B><SPAN style="COLOR: #000066">insurance</SPAN></B> will make this the only province in Canada with a three-tier system, according to a long-time advocate of public <B><SPAN style="COLOR: #000066">auto</SPAN></B> <B><SPAN style="COLOR: #000066">insurance</SPAN></B>. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 5pt 0in; mso-layout-grid-align: none"><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><FONT face=Arial>"It's a terrible shame, demeaning and is an insult to the intelligence of the motorists of this province," says Ed Levert of Bathurst.
