They said the parent at the wheel backed up and struck the child, who was seriously injured and died later at Health Sciences Centre. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>As word of the accident spread in the farming country southeast of Winnipeg, neighbours expressed sympathy for parents Arnold and Kim Lange. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But details about the tragedy were scarce. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"I (only) heard the ambulance go screaming by," said one neighbour. Authorities report sending an ambulance to the farm at 5:20 p.m. Tuesday. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Just minutes before, Bryann Lange, 29 months old, had wandered down the short driveway that links her family's modest bungalow to the barn where her parents raise dairy cattle. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>She made her way inside to watch one of her parents clean up the barn with the aid of the Bobcat tractor. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But the parent didn't know the toddler had come to check out the noise in the barn, or that she had wandered into the path of the machine. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The parent apparently backed up and struck the child. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Yesterday at the farm, a number of women stood outside the family's bungalow, firmly turning down inquiries, while inside, other people took one sympathy call after another. A representative from the Chief Medical Examiner's Office said there was nothing to report to the public from the autopsy yesterday. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Neighbour Marc Hutlet said he met Arnold Lange as a customer of his seed business, but didn't know how he was coping with the tragedy. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"He's very quiet, reserved, a nice person," said Hutlet, "very hardworking and dedicated." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Hutlet described the family as "like a lot of people that live in the country, very friendly." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>About 10 preschoolers die every year in farm accidents in Canada, a rate 50 per cent higher than the national rate of preschool injuries resulting in death. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>A study conducted by the Canadian Agricultural Injury Surveillance Program found that of the deaths, 29 per cent happened with children who were run over by machinery when they were bystanders. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Director Dr. Rob Brison said deaths like Bryann's happen all too often. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"This is certainly a tragic injury, but this is the most common pattern of fatal injury for two-year-olds who live on farms," said Brison. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"It's so unfortunate when something like that happens, it really is," said Donna Riddell, head of the Farm Safety 4 Just Kids south central Manitoba chapter. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Riddell said the best way to prevent accidents like these is to keep preschool children away from work sites. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"I think that the safest place for kids is honestly off-site child care, whether it's with a neighbour down the road who is focusing on children, or a licensed childcare facility," she said. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Riddell said the main problem is that alternative child care is often not accessible or affordable for farm families. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:alexandra.paul@freepress.mb.ca"><FONT face=Verdana>alexandra.paul@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></A><FONT face=Verdana> <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:lindsey.wiebe@freepress.mb.ca"><FONT face=Verdana>lindsey.wiebe@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></A><FONT face=Verdana> <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 11-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: VEHICLE NOISE TOO LOUD
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.08/04  Page A11
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>I write to encourage citizens who are concerned by vehicle noise to contact the Winnipeg Police Service and ask that serious attention be paid to the decibel levels of motorcycles and cars this summer. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>It seems as though modern mufflers are being manufactured with high volume as the goal. I'd be surprised if these items are marketed as mufflers at all; what exactly are they muffling? <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Watching the public's disdain for the noise level becomes obvious as the offenders roar by a restaurant's patio, or down a street where the public is gathered. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Motorcycles and custom-fitted cars rev their engines with contempt, and judging by the stream of negative adjectives from bystanders that follows the intrusive and unhealthy noise, one can only wonder why the law is not being enforced. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><FONT face=Verdana><B><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">TIMOTHY SANDERSON</SPAN></B><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"> <o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Winnipeg<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 12-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: TWO DIE ON MOTORCYCLES: Separate Tragedies Eight Hours Apart: Bicyclist Succumbs To Injuries
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.8/04  Page B1/B2
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: By Jason Bell And Bruce Owen
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>TWO men are dead following back-to-back motorcycle crashes only eight hours apart in the city's North End yesterday morning. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>City police also confirmed bicyclist Paul Schellenberg, 49, struck by a vehicle Tuesday afternoon in the North End, died overnight in hospital. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Just after midnight yesterday, Gregory Kyle Shumila, 23, was killed when he lost control of his motorcycle on Church Avenue and struck a tree and a metal railway sign. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>He was rushed to Seven Oaks General Hospital but was dead upon arrival from severe internal injuries. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Police say he appears to have been speeding west on Church on a new Suzuki GSR, of which he had taken possession about two hours earlier.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"He was trying to find out how fast it could go and it ultimately cost him his life," police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson said. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Police believe Shumila's powerful motorcycle hit a curb at the intersection of Milner Street, striking with such impact the front fork snapped and catapulted the 2000 West Kildonan Collegiate grad into the tree and sign post. He was wearing a helmet. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"He was a typical young boy," his grieving mother Val said. "He just loved bikes." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>She said her son recently took a job working in construction after being employed in the auto body trade for the past four years. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"We don't know what happened," she said about the accident. "We have a lot of unanswered questions" <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Just hours after Shumila's death, police collision analysts were again called out to go to the intersection of Selkirk Avenue and Arlington Street for another motorcycle collision. Around 8 a.m., 25-year-old Martino Soares was fatally injured when he smashed his Honda sport bike into the side of a compact car. He died a short time later in hospital, despite also wearing a helmet. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The male driver of the silver Acadian wasn't injured. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>A Kenora resident was heading west on Selkirk approaching the intersection just as the motorcycle rammed into the car. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Jim, who wouldn't give his last name, said the motorcyclist ran the red light. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"He was in the wrong," the man said. "He hit the car and just came to a complete stop. It was terrible. I probably won't sleep for the next couple of nights." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Police say they believe Soares was riding south on Arlington when at the last second he realized he was going to hit a red light and tried to "lay the bike down" to stop. However, he was travelling too fast and suffered massive head injuries. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Another witness, Patricia Shannacappo, was left quite shaken by the collision. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"Four ladies from the day-care centre (Keep Childcare) were helping him. They covered him with a fire blanket," said Shannacappo. "He must have hit the pavement hard to bleed through his helmet like that." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Staff at Keep Childcare Inc., located near the intersection, did not want to be interviewed. Several of Soares' friends gathered at the intersection in the early afternoon just as a tow truck arrived to remove the damaged vehicles. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>One man said he had been to Health Sciences Centre to say goodbye to his friend, but felt compelled to return to the collision scene. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"I don't understand," he said. "He wasn't a speeder... he babied that (motorcycle)." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Friends and relatives also met at a home in Old Kildonan late yesterday to mourn Soares, who worked in sales at electronic products manufacturer J.R. Stephenson Ltd. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>His sister said he'd been a motorcycle enthusiast for several years. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Yellow police tape surrounded the crash scene for hours, and children playing at King Edward School stood and watched as investigators pieced together the circumstances of the second deadly collision of the morning. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>On Tuesday during rush hour, cyclist Paul Schellenberg was rushed to hospital with massive head and chest injuries after he was hit by a vehicle at the intersection of Burrows Avenue and McGregor Street. He later died at the Health Sciences Centre. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The driver of the Chevrolet Tracker said the cyclist ran a red light. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Police are still investigating all three collisions and say no determination of fault has been assessed at this time. The three deaths bring to 12 the number of people killed on city streets this year in traffic-related mishaps. Winnipeg averages about 22 road deaths a year.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:Jason.bell@freepress.mb.ca"><FONT face=Verdana>Jason.bell@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:Bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca"><FONT face=Verdana>Bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 13-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: BIKES ARE 'WAY TOO BIG' FOR INEXPERIENCED RIDERS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.08/04  Page B1/B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>IN just eight hours, Winnipeg reached a grim statistic -- recording as many motorcycle deaths as it normally does in an average year. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Two men died in separate collisions in the North End yesterday. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>In 2001 and 2002, there were two motorcycle fatalities in the city. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Last year there were three, while one cyclist died. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Robin Alford, spokesman for Winnipeg Fire Paramedic Service, called the deaths of Gregory Kyle Shumila and Martino Soares needless tragedies. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"Even a helmet can't protect you from everything," he said. "Our people have a hard time dealing with these things -- they know they're preventable." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Both motorcycles were newer, high-performance sport bikes, often referred to as "crotch rockets." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Mike Waite, executive director of the Manitoba Safety Council, said the machines are often disasters waiting to happen. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"Kids are buying these bikes that are way too big and way too powerful," he said. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"They just don't respect them. These are bikes that you need to be experienced on. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"You don't start off with a rocket." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Waite said all new riders must complete a 21-hour safety program with the council before they can be fully licensed to ride in Manitoba. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Linda Thomas, the acting president of the Coalition of Manitoba Motorcycle Groups Inc., was shocked when informed of the back-to-back fatal collisions. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"Two of them? That's terrible," said Thomas, an avid rider for years. "Anytime something like this happens, we feel for the families of the people involved." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>She said the coalition works closely with Manitoba Public Insurance to spread the word about safety. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"We try and get the message of safety out to everyone... because we're on two wheels, we're a little more vulnerable," she said. "Our brochure just came out. This year, the message is lessening your speed." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Members of the motorcycle coalition have been very outspoken in recent years about MPI rate hikes. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Just two weeks ago, MPI announced it is asking the Public Utilities Board to approve a premium jump of 15 per cent for all motorcycle owners. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>It costs an average of $827 to insure a motorcycle with MPI, although they can only be safely operated for about five months <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>per year. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The average annual cost to insure a passenger vehicle is $776. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>An MPI spokesman said premiums for motorcycles are increasing to offset the cost of claims from motorcycle accidents. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"Motorcycles are inherently risky," said Ted Wakefield. "They offer no protection to the rider, and they only have two wheels so they are harder to control and can go off the road." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Wakefield added the average cost of a motorcycle claim is $14,000, while the average cost for a passenger vehicle is $2,500. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"To cover our costs, we should actually be asking for a 37 per cent increase, but we capped it at 15 per cent," he said. "That means about 22 per cent is subsidized by other classes, primarily passenger cars."<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:Jason.bell@freepress.mb.ca"><FONT face=Verdana>Jason.bell@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 14-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: AUTOPAC SETTLEMENT BETTER THAN SUIT: OFFICIAL: Victim Will Get Lifetime Wage
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.08/04  Page B3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>DARLENE Hellerman is better off with her Autopac settlement than she'd be if she could sue Chrysler, a senior Manitoba Public Insurance official said yesterday. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"The average claim for an injury like hers will be at least three, $3.5 million worth of coverage. It lasts a lifetime and is not only a one-time indemnity," public affairs vice-president John Douglas said yesterday. "Instead of fighting for seven or eight years with a manufacturer, they can have their money immediately." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>And while MPI could sue Chrysler on her behalf, it doesn't plan to. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Hellerman was paralysed from the chest down last October after a roll-away Chrysler minivan crushed her in front of her own home. I told you about her yesterday, about her sorrow that she can't be the kind of mom she wants to be anymore, and about her anger at both Chrysler for manufacturing a vehicle she believes was unsafe, and MPI for preventing her from suing the manufacturer. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>She will receive approximately $90,000 in an MPI cash settlement. The remainder of Douglas' estimated $3.5 million will come from a wage that will be paid to her through her lifetime, based on her role as a homemaker; renovations to the family's future home; transportation; rehabilitation; home care and medical expenses. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"I don't want to pretend we can make this person whole or make them better," said Douglas. "For an insurance company, these kinds of things are tough to deal with. It's a life that none of us would ever want to deal with." Hellerman and her husband, Glen, claim the auto giant built family vehicles for eight years without a brake-shift interlock, an inexpensive feature that prevents vehicles with an automatic transmission from accidentally being knocked into gear. Because Manitoba has no-fault insurance, she can't go after Chrysler. There have been cases in the U.S. where families have sued the manufacturer after minivan owners were crushed to death. Those cases were reportedly settled out of court. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Douglas says MPI sometimes sues on behalf of injured Manitobans. It did exactly that when Ford vehicles developed ignition fires and recovered almost $2 million for local drivers. There's a catch, though. MPI only seeks to recover the money it has paid out. A victory for MPI doesn't mean a payday for an accident victim. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"Insurance in Manitoba is not a punishment tool," Douglas said. "This is a program that looks after people." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Part of the problem is that Transport Canada didn't make the brake-shift interlock devices mandatory until 2003. No other cases of the vehicles slipping into gear and rolling have been reported in Manitoba. MPI has to look at the likelihood of a victory and the cost of getting there. "If we're looking at $1 million in cost recovery and it's going to take five years and cost $2 million, we're not going to do it," Douglas said. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Darlene and Glen Hellerman aren't after money. They don't really want to see anyone punished. They're packing up their two little boys and moving home to Chatham, Ont., where they hope life will be a little easier. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>They just hope and pray that no other moms are left too injured to care for their children because Darlene's story didn't get an airing in a courtroom. </FONT><A href="mailto:lindor.reynolds@freepress.mb.ca"><FONT face=Verdana>lindor.reynolds@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 15-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: CYCLISTS AND HELMETS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: TORONTO, ON  Globe and Mail  July.08/04  Page A12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Your editorial about the cyclist who was injured on an unsafe Toronto street ( A Hazardous Cycle &#8211; July 7) was largely correct, except for one error: The cyclist&#8217;s failure to wear a helmet does not demonstrate lack of respect for the law on her part or on the part of cyclists generally. In fact, there is no such law in Ontario requiring adult cyclists to wear helmets.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>TIM GLEASON, Toronto<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 16-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: DRIVING A BETTER DEAL
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  National Post  July.08/04  Page A13
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The last few years have not been kind to New Brunswick drivers. Even as auto insurance costs spiraled upwards, availability decreased -- a counter-intuitive conundrum in a free enterprise economy -- and the consumer was left to figure out why.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Not surprisingly, this produced widespread outrage, and significant pressure on Bernard Lord's Conservative government to do something.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>In the spring of 2003, at the peak of the province's insurance crisis, Premier Lord introduced significant reforms, supported by the opposition Liberals, to New Brunswick's insurance policies. The objective was to reduce costs and allow private insurers to price car insurance in relation to the manner in which costs were incurred.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>In other words, insurers were permitted to price an individual's policy so that it bore some relation to the risk that person presented when driving. Insurance, after all, is a risk-based product. One pays a premium so that, in the event a loss is suffered, one will be indemnified. It only makes sense for the price to relate in some way to the associated risk factor. Otherwise, the market is totally irrational, and good drivers are forced to subsidize higher risk drivers.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>This endorsement of the risk-based insurance system provided the much-needed impetus to restore and increase competition in the insurance market and accounts, to a large degree, for the rapid improvement in availability and price of auto insurance in New Brunswick during the last year.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Given the vision of the 2003 risk-based reforms, and the impressive results in the marketplace, it was surprising to see the government introduce recently what can only be described as a regressive decision to reject risk-based pricing going forward.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Among the changes announced last week is a new mandatory rating structure. Actuarial statistics demonstrate, incontrovertibly, that certain characteristics -- like age -- are very reliable predictors of the risk one presents on the road. It is a truism that parents of 18-year old males may not like, but it is a time-proven one. However, insurers will no longer be permitted to rate according to age-related risk. At least, not in New Brunswick.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>As a practical matter, this means that there will be significant rate dislocation in the New Brunswick insurance market, primarily affecting good, older drivers and younger females, who will pay markedly higher premiums than they should, given their statistical driving experience.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Furthermore, experienced drivers will subsidize newly-minted ones. As announced last week, insurers will be mandated to offer discounts to new drivers who have undergone driver training, notwithstanding statistical data regarding the greater risk that all new drivers pose.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Driver education is laudable and the insurance industry promotes and supports such programs. But, rather than rely on statistical evidence on the impact of driver training on the incidence of accidents involving new drivers, the proposal is to arbitrarily discount premiums.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Among the significant changes to car insurance announced last week is the bold and intelligent introduction of "no frills" insurance. This is a base product providing minimal coverage as required by statute. Then, there are "bells and whistles" options, which provide enhancements to particular coverage plans, as different families may require.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Many consumers will need and want additional coverage. However, the government requires that the "Cadillac" policy be the starting point. You get it all until you advise otherwise. And, human nature being what it is, the likelihood is that most will accept what is delivered and not question the options.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>If the model were flipped, and consumers bought no-frills and built up, they would become better informed about their coverage, and independent brokers and companies would participate in developing a more knowledgeable customer base, which, ultimately, is in everyone's best interest.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Consumers hate what has come to be known as the "negative option" approach, which is what they now have.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>New Brunswick drivers should be relieved that government-run auto insurance was rejected as a solution to the very legitimate concerns of the population. The message that private enterprise, when left to manage its capital and investment prudently and responsibly, provides more economic kick and consumer benefits than any government program ever will is a message that resonates among the people of New Brunswick. It is this principled commitment that spurred increasing investment in New Brunswick which in turn catalyzed the province's dramatic economic turnaround during the last 15 years. However, New Brunswick consumers could do better, and so could the government.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>There is a strong and undeniable public interest in ensuring that all drivers are licensed and insured. Hence, the government's involvement. However, this involvement invariably leads to excessive political micro-management of the auto insurance that province requires to be purchased.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>New Brunswick has demonstrated leadership in responding to what was a dire insurance crisis a mere two years ago. The ultimate prescription to cure the insurance malady is minimal government intervention, combined with optimal industry competition, which will only be achieved with a truly risk-based system.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana><EM>George L. Cooke is the President and Chief Executive Officer of The Dominion of Canada General Insurance Company.<o:p></o:p></EM></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 17-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: LOCAL BRIEFS: MAN HIT BY VEHICLE, IN HOSPITAL
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>A 22-year-old man suffered serious injuries when he was hit by a vehicle at the intersection of Dafoe Road and University Crescent about 7 p.m., last night police said.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>He was taken to Victoria General Hospital in unstable condition but later upgraded to stable, police said.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 18-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MAN HIT BY CAR ON U OF M CAMPUS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.09/04  Page A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>A 22-year-old man was in hospital last night after being hit by a car in a University of Manitoba intersection. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Police said the man was on foot when a black car hit him just after 7 p.m. at Dafoe Road and University Crescent, an intersection with traffic lights. The man apparently hit the car's front windshield on the passenger side, leaving a large, concave hole in the shattered glass. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The man was rushed to Victoria Hospital, initially in unstable condition, but police said last night his condition was not life-threatening, although he may have brain injuries. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Shortly after the accident, police officers and campus security roped off the eastbound lane with yellow police tape and rerouted traffic, leaving the damaged black car parked about a metre in front of the crosswalk. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Officers were interviewing at least one witness to the crash.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 19-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: BALLARD WILL SELL FUEL CELL BUSINESS TO PARTNERS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.09/04  Page B12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>TORONTO -- In a major strategy reversal, Ballard Power Systems announced plans yesterday to sell its German vehicle fuel cell business to its partners, DaimlerChrysler AG and Ford Motor Co., and take an $18-million US writedown in the third quarter as a result. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The company said the huge demand it had expected for its automobile fuel cell systems -- which incorporate a hydrogen fuel cell right into a vehicle -- hasn't materialized. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"When we look at the long-term potential of systems business today, what we're finding out is that the (automakers) prefer to do systems in-house and that market isn't as large as we envisioned," Ballard CEO Dennis Campbell said in a conference call from Vancouver. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Ballard said the two big automakers will acquire Ballard AG, formerly Xcellsis, and they will be jointly responsible for research, development and manufacturing of the fuel cell systems that fit into their cars. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But Ballard will still be called on to supply the fuel cells stacks, the core of the fuel cell systems, during development and when they finally come to market -- likely by the end of the decade. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>And DaimlerChrysler and Ford, Ballard's two biggest investors, will provide up to $58 million US to Ballard to fund the next two generations of vehicular fuel cells and the next generation electric drive system. If Ballard shareholders approve the scheme, the Vancouver-area company will concentrate on two businesses -- fuel cell development and electric drives -- instead of three. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 20-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Portage Mounties Cope With Adversity
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>  <P align=justify>PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE &#8211; Portage la Prairie RCMP officers were rallying around one of their own yesterday after a Mountie was struck by a tractor-trailer while issuing a speeding ticket on Saturday.</P>  <P align=justify>Const. Terry Aselton, who was taken to Portage District General Hospital, was listed in stable condition yesterday. He suffered undermined injuries in the accident which occurred shortly after 2 p.m. on the Trans-Canada Highway about 15 kilometres west of Portage. </P>  <P align=justify>"He&#8217;s OK. I saw him Saturday afternoon and he&#8217;s definitely conscious," said Insp. Ken Turner, an officer with the Portage detachment.</P>  <P align=justify>Turner said most of Aselton&#8217;s fellow officers have taken the opportunity to visit him in the hospital since the accident.</P>  <P align=justify>The 14-year veteran and father of two was struck by a passing truck while standing on the shoulder of the highway. Police have charged Lipsett Cartage driver Murrey Reynders of North Battleford, Sask., with careless driving under the Highway Traffic Act.</P>  <P align=justify>The RCMP is not releasing any information on the extent of Aselton&#8217;s injuries but a paramedic at the accident scene said he believed they were not life threatening.</P><B>  <P align=justify>Third incident</P></B>  <P align=justify>This accident marks the third incident in recent years that a Portage officer has ended up in t he hospital in the line of duty. On Feb. 22, 2002, Const. Mike Templeton was shot in the face while trying to stop a stole Pontiac Firebird on the Trans-Canada just east of Portage. He returned to active duty last year. </P>  <P align=justify>Several months before that, in late 2001, Const. Peter Magdic was killed in a traffic accident. Turner commented that despite the adversity the detachment has faced in recent years morale is still high and that Aselton performed his duty by the book.</P>  <P align=justify>"He did everything correctly," Turner said. "You just can&#8217;t take actions on everyone&#8217;s driving ability."</P>  <P align=justify>Cpl. Marty Grainger, another officer with the Portage detachment, said the real strength of the close-knit detachment comes out at these times of adversity. He also said all the officers are doing their best to lend support to Aselton&#8217;s family.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P></FONT>

Title: 21-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Girl Saw Mother Die
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: Fell Under Wheels Of Tractor-Trailer  By Chris Kitching
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>  <P align=justify>ANOLA -- A 10-year-old Anola girl watched her mom die Friday night when she was run over by a semi-tractor hauling a flatbed trailer, a community resident says. Oakbank RCMP haven't released the accident victim's name, but neighbours identified her as Christine Duma. </P>  <P align=justify>Her daughter, Chantelle, watched as she was run over and killed about 8:20 p.m. Friday by the vehicle driven by her boyfriend, Cory McCaughan, said a woman who asked not to be named. </P>  <P align=justify>Oakbank RCMP Const. Andy Christie said the 38-year-old accident victim jumped on to the side of the moving tractor-trailer and then fell under its wheels. </P>  <P align=justify>"There's a whole bunch of rumours flying around out there," he said. </P><B>  <P align=justify>OCCURRED IN PARKING LOT </P></B>  <P align=justify>Police haven't talked to the driver of the vehicle since Friday night, said Christie, who didn't indicate whether charges will be laid. </P>  <P align=justify>The accident happened in the parking lot of a Petro-Canada at the corner of Highway 12 and Highway 15. </P>  <P align=justify>A woman who lives a few houses away said Duma cleaned houses for a living. </P>  <P align=justify>Many people in Anola declined to speak to The Sun about Duma's death and her relationship with McCaughan, who couldn't be reached for comment. </P>  <P align=justify>Some residents feared backlash from the couple's families and their neighbours in the tiny community 25 kilometres east of Winnipeg. </P>  <P align=justify>"Anyone who knows something about it doesn't want to talk about it," said a man at a flea market across from the service station, where the semi-tractor and trailer were still parked yesterday. </P>  <P align=justify>The vehicle, with the words "Cory Amber" scrawled on the side, has the logo of C.W. Trucking on its doors. Owners of the company, based in Lumsden, Sask., couldn't be reached for comment.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>  <P align=justify></P></FONT>

Title: 22-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Local briefs
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>  <P align=justify>An 68-year-old man was pushed to the ground by two thugs who stole his Cadillac outside his St. Norbert home.</P>  <P align=justify>The victim and his wife were pulling into their parking stall in the 900-block of Cloutier Driver on Saturday about 11 p.m., Winnipeg police said.</P>  <P align=justify>The suspects approached and one of them pulled a knife as the couple got out of the car, police said. Police describe the suspects as black men in their early 20s.</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P></FONT>

Title: 23-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorcycle Rider Injured
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>  <P align=justify>Firefighters and paramedics attend to the rider of a motorcycle whose southbound Yamaha slammed into the back of a sedan on Pembina Highway near Mulvey venue noon yesterday.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>  <P align=justify></P></FONT>

Title: 24-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the Editor
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>  <P align=justify>I'm writing this letter to express my severe displeasure at the comments MPI official Ted Wakefield has made in regard to motorcycles after the loss of two lives in such a short period (Risky machine to ride: MPI by Tammy Marlowe, July 8). </P>  <P align=justify>It is unfortunate that two young men have passed away. Mr. Wakefield's comments, however, were very poor and false. </P>  <P align=justify>As any motorcyclist or cyclist knows, a two-wheeled vehicle in motion is not inherently unstable; gyroscopic effect dictates that it will continue to roll in an upright manner until speed has decreased to a significant level. Nor do they have a tendency to lose control. Operator error is the largest single factor in single-vehicle motorcycle accidents. </P>  <P align=justify>While it is true a motorcycle offers less protection than a car for its rider, today's safety gear is incredibly effective at mitigating injuries; unfortunately far too many riders ignore wearing it. MPI doesn't help this fact by not covering safety gear in single-vehicle accidents. I won't get into the speed kills campaign, but MPI has done more over the years than they used to in safety campaigns. Education is key; the new mandatory course is a step in the right direction. Training is critical and more needs to be done. </P>  <P align=justify>It is time that we start taking a progressive view toward motorcycles; after all, they make a valid form of transportation, at least in the summer months, are easier to park, cheaper on fuel, less harmful to the roads. </P>  <P align=justify>I suggest that Mr. Wakefield get his facts correct before commenting to the media. </P>  <P align=justify>Craig Stieben </P>  <P align=justify>Winnipeg </P>  <P align=justify>Or to put it another way ... </P>  <P align=justify>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P></FONT>

Title: 25-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the Editor
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>  <P align=justify>So the MPI spokesperson is quoted as stating motorcycles are "inherently unstable and prone to losing control." It's interesting to note that in one breath he accuses Transport Canada of allowing unsafe vehicles into the country and also shows his ignorance of physics as it applies to single-track vehicles. </P>  <P align=justify>I have been riding motorcycles for over 30 years and have yet to experience this phenomenon, however I have had ample opportunity to experience the intolerance and narrow-mindedness that he displays by his comment. The gentleman obviously does not have any engineering background or knowledge of the subject and I respectively submit that he should limit his comments to areas he is familiar with. </P>  <P align=justify>Dan Decorby </P>  <P align=justify>Winnipeg </P>  <P align=justify>That harmonizes with a chorus of riders.</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P></FONT>

Title: 26-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In Brief
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb  Free Press  July.12/04  Page A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>  <P align=justify>TWO armed men took the keys of a Cadillac from an elderly couple Saturday night and drove away with the car, Winnipeg police said yesterday. </P>  <P align=justify>An 86-year-old man and his wife had just pulled into a parking space on Cloutier Drive when they were approached by two men, Insp. Darryl Preisentanz said. </P>  <P align=justify>One man said he had a gun. The other produced a knife. They demanded the car keys and drove away with the wine-coloured, four-door, 1995 Cadillac STS, he said. </P>  <P align=justify>Nobody was injured. </P>  <P align=justify>Police are still looking for the car, which had Manitoba licence plate AEV 404. One man is described as black, 22 to 26 years old, 5-10, with a thin build and short black hair. He wore a dark-coloured windbreaker, track pants, and a baseball cap. The other man is described as black, 23 to 25 years old, 5-6 to 5-7, with a stocky build and short black hair. He wore a waist-length windbreaker and track pants. </P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P></FONT>

Title: 27-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Truck Hits Mountie--  Writing Ticket, Slammed By Tractor-Trailer
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Sun    July.11/04    Page A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE -- A Mountie was injured after being hit by a tractor-trailer as he wrote a traffic ticket at the side of the Trans-Canada Highway yesterday. The collision took place about 2 p.m. near Bagot, about 10 km west of Portage la Prairie. Const. Terry Aselton, a 14-year RCMP veteran and a member of the Portage la Prairie Traffic Services, was standing on the shoulder of the highway next to a black Honda he had pulled over for speeding when a westbound semi hit him. </P>  <P align=justify>He was taken to Portage District General Hospital in stable condition, said RCMP. </P>  <P align=justify>The driver of the Honda called 911 on his cellphone moments after the accident occurred. </P>  <P align=justify>A driver-side rearview mirror that lay on the ground about an hour after the collision was the only visible damage to his car. </P><B>  <P align=justify>CHARGED WITH CARELESS DRIVING </P></B>  <P align=justify>The semi belonged to Lipsett Cartage, a Regina-based company. </P>  <P align=justify>The driver -- Murrey Reynders of North Battleford, Sask. -- has been charged with careless driving. </P>  <P align=justify>Traffic was reduced to one lane around the accident scene following the collision while officers investigated. </P>  <P align=justify>This isn't the first time a Portage la Prairie Mountie has faced peril. </P>  <P align=justify>RCMP Const. Mike Templeton was shot in the face on Feb. 22, 2002 when he tried to stop a stolen Pontiac Firebird on the Trans-Canada Highway just east of Portage la Prairie. </P>  <P align=justify>He returned to active duty last year. </P>  <P align=justify>Daniel Jonathon Courchene, 28, admitted his involvement in the shooting earlier this year and was sentenced to 10 years in prison. </P>  <P align=justify>Michael Gary Regamy, 22, of Edmonton, and a 17-year-old Alberta girl who can't be identified were also charged with attempted murder. Their cases are still before the courts. </P>  <P align=justify>Meanwhile, Portage Const. Peter Magdic, 28, died after his Chevy Tahoe police truck he was driving on Highway 240 left the road on a curve and rolled over on Nov. 18, 2001. </P>  <P align=justify>An RCMP investigation revealed excessive speed and driver inattention as contributing factors to the wreck. </P>  <P align=justify>Magdic, who was returning from a call at the Long Plain First Nation at the time, was not wearing a seatbelt when the crash occurred.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 28-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Anola woman dies tragically--  Killed After Fall Under Wheels
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Sun    July.11/04    Page A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>ANOLA -- A 38-year-old Anola woman fell under the wheels of her boyfriend's semi-tractor trailer and died Friday night. The woman -- who Anola residents said was named Christine -- either tried to jump out of or scramble onto the moving vehicle about 8:20 p.m. near where Highway 12 and Highway 15 meet, witnesses said. </P><B>  <P align=justify>'VERY SAD' </P></B>  <P align=justify>She was pronounced dead at the scene. </P>  <P align=justify>"The whole thing is very sad, very tragic," said Peter Waite, who manages a restaurant attached to the Petro-Canada near the scene. </P>  <P align=justify>Christine and her boyfriend were in the service station's parking lot when the incident occurred, Waite said. </P>  <P align=justify>Waite said the dead woman had a young daughter. </P>  <P align=justify>Yesterday, the tractor-trailer -- carrying a load of wooden items -- was parked behind Petro-Canada. Two men in a white truck approached the semi. </P>  <P align=justify>When asked about the woman's death, both refused to speak of the incident. Eyes filling with tears, one man called the accident a tragedy before both drove away. </P>  <P align=justify>A strand of yellow police tape on the ground was the only indication of the incident. </P>  <P align=justify>Oakbank RCMP released no further details yesterday. </P>  <P align=justify>Anola is about 25 km east of Winnipeg.</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 29-Apr-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Semi hits, seriously injuries Mountie--Portage Officer Stable After Highway Mishap
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.11/04    Page A1/A2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE -- A veteran RCMP officer is in hospital after he was hit by a semi-trailer truck during a routine traffic stop along the Trans-Canada Highway yesterday afternoon. Const. Terry Aselton was listed in stable condition last night at Portage District General Hospital. </P>  <P align=justify>The accident occurred just after 2 p.m., about 30 kilometres west of Portage la Prairie, in the highway's westbound lane. </P>  <P align=justify>RCMP say Aselton, a member of the traffic services unit of the Portage detachment, had pulled over a black four-door Mazda for speeding after clocking the car on radar. </P>  <P align=justify>His cruiser, with its lights flashing, was parked on the shoulder of the highway in front of the Mazda. </P>  <P align=justify>Aselton was standing beside the driver's door of the Mazda when he was hit. </P>  <P align=justify>The driver of the semi-trailer truck, Murrey Reynders, said he tried to swerve to avoid hitting the officer. "If I could trade places with him right now, I would," said the distraught driver from North Battleford, Sask., in an interview. </P>  <P align=justify>Reynders, 32, said that just before the accident he was reaching down with his right hand for his Thermos to pour himself a cup of coffee. He said his rig at this point was already over a metre onto the shoulder of the highway. </P>  <P align=justify>Reynders said he looked down for a moment and when he looked up he saw the flashing lights of the police cruiser. Reynders said he was only about 200 to 300 metres away. </P>  <P align=justify>"I just saw him (the officer) and cranked the wheel," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>But Reynders said he was unable get his rig, which has eight axles and was hauling two flat-bed trailers of galvanized steel, to turn left quickly enough. </P>  <P align=justify>It appears the officer was struck by the side of one of the trailers and then bounced off the car he had stopped. The car's sideview mirror was shorn off. Reynders said he wasn't sure he had struck Aselton until he looked back through his rearview mirror and saw the officer down. </P>  <P align=justify>"I'm deeply sorry this happened to him and his family," said an emotional Reynders. </P>  <P align=justify>RCMP have charged Reynders with careless driving under the Highway Traffic Act. However, they said it's possible that more charges could be laid once the investigation is complete. Traffic investigators were on the scene yesterday taking measurements. A black tire mark that appeared to be from the semi-truck could be seen running alongside Aselton's cruiser and the other car. </P>  <P align=justify>Reynders, who works as an owner/operator, said he has been driving for 12 years and routinely travels down this stretch of highway. </P>  <P align=justify>"I know it like the back of my hand," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>Reynders said he has only been in one accident before, and that happened six months after he got his licence. </P>  <P align=justify>Meanwhile, family of the officer gathered at the Portage hospital. </P>  <P align=justify>The father of two has been with the service for 14 years. </P>  <P align=justify>His teenage son declined to comment on the accident yesterday. Cpl. Marty Grainger of the Portage detachment said he visited Aselton in hospital shortly after the incident. He couldn't comment on his injuries but said Aselton was conscious. </P>  <P align=justify>"He was well aware of the surroundings and what's going on," said Grainger. </P>  <P align=justify>"He's very lucky." </P>  <P align=justify>The Portage detachment has had its share of tragedies over the past several years. </P>  <P align=justify>In February 2002, Const. Mike Templeton was shot in the face after he pulled over a stolen car east of Portage la Prairie on the Trans-Canada Highway. Three months earlier, Const. Peter Magdic was killed in a traffic accident while on duty. </P>  <P align=justify>"We have members who were here for those two major incidents, so when we first heard about this you immediately think the worst," said Grainger. </P>  <P align=justify>david.kuxhaus@freepress.mb.ca</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 30-Apr-13
