NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Auto experts says chrysler knew of dangerous flaw--  Could Fix Have Prevented Paralysis?
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.11/04    Page A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <FONT size=2>&nbsp;</FONT>A North American automotive expert claims Chrysler knew for years that the lack of an inexpensive part was causing their minivans to unexpectedly shift into gear and start moving, the same problem that apparently caused a 1998 Caravan to run over and cripple a Headingley woman last year.   <P align=justify>It's the latest twist in the saga of Darlene Hellerman, who is paralysed from the chest down after a friend's child bumped the gearshift of her vehicle. </P>  <P align=justify>Now a second local woman claims she was injured this week trying to stop her runaway Chrysler car. </P>  <P align=justify>Phil Edmonston, author of the Lemon-Aid series of car guides, says he was warning his readers about the problem as early as 1998. </P>  <P align=justify>"It's not just a Canadian problem; it's an American problem, too," says Edmonston, who is based in Florida. "People have been complaining about this for a long time." </P>  <P align=justify>The Caravan lacked a brake-shift interlock, a device that prevents a car from slipping into gear unless the brake is depressed at the same time the gearshift is moved. Chrysler began installing the devices on their 2001 models but never issued a recall of the older vehicles. "There's no program to address this specific concern," says Chrysler public relations representative Stuart Schorr. </P>  <P align=justify>Other manufacturers, including Ford, began installing the devices in the early 1990s. </P>  <P align=justify>If Edmonston is right -- and he's got a pretty good track record -- the company has been receiving complaints about the problem for more than six years. He's certainly been writing about it that long. </P>  <P align=justify>But Schorr says the problem has never been a malfunction of Chrysler vehicles. If anything, he says, it's a problem with drivers. </P>  <P align=justify>"There has been pedal misapplication. People would put the car into drive and nail the gas. They would confuse the gas and brake pedals." </P>  <P align=justify>Reminded that, in Darlene Hellerman's case, a minivan that was not running was bumped into gear by a child who was not stepping on either the gas or the brake, Schorr says the responsibility still rests with the driver. "They should not leave a child alone in the vehicle," he said. "It's clearly not a common occurrence. I just think people need to be careful and not leave a key in the car." </P>  <P align=justify>Besides, he says, cases such as Hellerman's are "rare." </P>  <P align=justify>Meanwhile, Transcona resident Lori Hoskins is nursing bruises she says she got this week when her 2000 Plymouth Breeze unexpectedly slipped into gear with her six-year-old son Brandon still inside. </P>  <P align=justify>The car was parked and the keys were in her purse. </P>  <P align=justify>"I heard him screaming. I dropped the groceries I was carrying and just ran. I threw myself into the car. I'm so grateful we weren't seriously hurt. </P>  <P align=justify>"I just wonder how often this happens," Hoskins said. "I guess we were just lucky." </P>  <P align=justify>The U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website says an American recall for the Breeze and several other models manufactured between 1993 and 1999 was issued in January. Hoskins called her dealership, which will be fixing her car next week. </P>  <P align=justify>According to the NHTSA website: "On certain passenger vehicles, the floor shifter ignition-park interlock may fail and allow the shifter to be moved out of the park position with the key removed. An inoperative interlock may also allow the key to be removed when the shifter has not been placed in the park position. Either circumstance may result in the vehicle rolling away without warning." </P>  <P align=justify>Schorr says the recall was done to make the shifter "more robust." The recall is small comfort to Hoskins, who is only grateful she was able to move quickly enough to avert tragedy. </P>  <P align=justify>"When I think about that poor woman (Hellerman) and think about my son being in the car, it just makes me realize what could have happened." </P>  <P align=justify>Hellerman and her husband are frustrated that Manitoba Public Insurance Corporation Act rules prevent them from suing Chrysler. They say cash can't give her back her legs. They just want to call public attention to the missing interlock. </P>  <P align=justify>They believe there should be a recall of older minivans -- vehicles sold as safe family transportation -- to install the devices. </P>  <P align=justify>MPI could sue on their behalf but has chosen not to. An MPI spokesman said earlier this week that Hellerman will receive up to $3.5 million in care in her lifetime, likely more than she'd get from a court settlement. </P>  <P align=justify>Transport Canada didn't make the brake-shift interlock devices mandatory until 2003. </P>  <P align=justify>According to a report found by Edmonston, Chrysler dealers were told that 135,000 owner's manuals distributed in 2000 Caravans indicated the vehicles had the devices when they did not. </P>  <P align=justify>Chrysler's advice? Dealers were told to mail a self-sticking label to vehicle owners and tell them to slap it over the misinformation. </P>  <P align=justify>Darlene Hellerman, and now Lori Hoskins, are left wondering just how loud someone has to complain before they're heard. Hellerman will live with the effects of the rollaway minivan for the rest of her life. Hoskins is grateful her injuries will fade. lindor.reynolds@freepress.mb.ca</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 1-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In brief--  Driver in stable condition
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.11/04    Page A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A man is in stable condition in hospital after the Jaws of Life were used to remove him from his car following a collision with a bus Friday night.</P>  <P align=justify>The collision occurred at the intersection of Maryland Street and Portage Avenue.</P>  <P align=justify>Officers in a police cruiser noticed the man seemed to be asleep at the wheel, but before they could intervene, the man&#8217;s foot hit the gas pedal and the car went through a red light.</P>  <P align=justify>No one on the bus was hurt.</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 2-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver sorry--  Killed Cyclist’s Family Forgives
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>The family of a 47-year-old cyclist killed after he collided with an SUV Tuesday afternoon says they've made peace with the man who struck their loved one. Cory, the 21-year-old driver of the Chevrolet Tracker involved in the fatal accident that claimed Paul Schellenberg's life last Tuesday in the North End, sent his condolences to the man's family and friends through The Sun on Wednesday. He asked not to have his last name used. </P><B>  <P align=justify>INVITATION FOR DINNER </P></B>  <P align=justify>Yesterday, Schellenberg's family called The Sun to say they forgave Cory, who showed up at Elmwood Mennonite Brethren Church on Henderson Highway for Paul's memorial service. </P>  <P align=justify>"Cory kept saying he was thankful, that he was so happy Paul's parents weren't angry at him," said Lynda Toews, Schellenberg's cousin. "He said he was crying since it happened on Tuesday. </P>  <P align=justify>"It took a lot of guts for him to show up at the funeral." </P>  <P align=justify>Toews said Cory and the Schellenberg family hugged and exchanged phone numbers. </P>  <P align=justify>He has an invitation for dinner with the family, Toews said. </P>  <P align=justify>Schellenberg was riding his bicycle southbound on McGregor Street on the way to a friend's home shortly after 3 p.m., when he collided with a Chevrolet Tracker that was eastbound on Burrows Avenue. </P>  <P align=justify>He was taken to Health Sciences Centre, with severe head injuries. He was later pronounced dead. </P>  <P align=justify>Charges are not expected in the crash that killed Schellenberg or in two other fatal crashes this week, police said yesterday. </P>  <P align=justify>Nine hours after Schellenberg was hit, 23-year-old Gregory Kyle Shumila was testing out his upgraded Suzuki motorcycle when he lost control and smashed into a tree and metal railway sign near the intersection of Church Avenue and Milner Street. </P>  <P align=justify>Less than nine hours later, 25-year-old Martino Soares was riding his Honda motorcycle southbound on Arlington Street when he reportedly ran a red light at the intersection of Selkirk Avenue and slammed into the driver's side of a car. </P>  <P align=justify>Police said speed was a factor in both motorcycle crashes.</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 3-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sun reader offers tip in fatal shooting--Police Collect Vehicle From Behind E.K. Hotel
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>RCMP got the lead they were looking for in their latest homicide investigation with the discovery yesterday of a "vehicle of interest." And they have a Winnipeg Sun reader to thank. </P>  <P align=justify>A 20-something man who didn't want his name published said he called Mounties yesterday morning after reading in The Sun that they were looking for a gold 1993 Nissan Pathfinder believed to be connected with last weekend's fatal shooting of a 22-year-old St. Vital resident. </P>  <P align=justify>The tipster told RCMP the SUV -- with licence plates DWV 633 -- was parked in the rear parking lot of the Nor-Villa Motor Hotel at 1763 Henderson Hwy. in North Kildonan. </P>  <P align=justify>He said he noticed the Pathfinder had been there since Tuesday, but had never seen anybody get in or out of it. </P>  <P align=justify>There had been no obvious damage to the abandoned SUV, but "it was kind of beat up," the tipster said. </P>  <P align=justify>Mounties responded to the call about 9 a.m. and had left the Nor-Villa -- with the Pathfinder in tow -- a couple hours later. </P><B>  <P align=justify>NOT REPORTED STOLEN </P></B>  <P align=justify>RCMP spokesman Sgt. Steve Colwell wouldn't discuss what the vehicle had to do with the homicide investigation or whether it was pointing to any possible suspects. </P>  <P align=justify>"At this time, we have no suspects," Colwell said. </P>  <P align=justify>But sources said the vehicle hadn't been reported stolen. </P>  <P align=justify>It was unknown by press time last night if investigators had tracked down the registered owner for questioning. </P>  <P align=justify>The body of Trevor Neil Tanner was discovered by passersby shortly after 2 a.m. Sunday on a dead-end gravel road between the Red River and the floodway, just northeast of the Lockport Bridge in the RM of St. Clements. </P>  <P align=justify>Tanner, a graduate of Glenlawn Collegiate who lived with his parents Jack and Marcheta and younger brother Luke in a middle-class St. Vital neighbourhood, was shot "execution-style" in the back of the head, sources said. </P>  <P align=justify>Described by family as easy-going with a beautiful smile and gentle nature, Tanner reportedly got into a fight with a group of men with possible gang connections at the Forks last Saturday night, only a few hours before his death. </P>  <P align=justify>He will be buried today. A memorial service is slated for 11 a.m. at Glen Lawn Funeral Home, 455 Lagimodiere Blvd. </P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=justify>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 4-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cops probe bus collision
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A man whom witnesses allege was asleep at the wheel escaped with minor injuries after being broadsided by a bus last night. "I couldn't believe it. He woke up and his car shot right out straight through the red light. (It got) hit pretty hard," said Bruce, who witnessed the crash. </P>  <P align=justify>The young man's car was stopped at a light at Portage Avenue and Maryland Street about 7:40 p.m. when a police car pulled up behind him, said Bruce, who asked not to have his last name used. </P>  <P align=justify>The officer stopped his car to investigate why the man was slumped over, said Winnipeg police Staff Sgt. Gordon Gold. </P>  <P align=justify>When the officer approached, the man abruptly awoke and slammed on the gas, Gold said. </P>  <P align=justify>The beige Chevrolet Impala shot through a red light into traffic and was hit by a No. 11 Winnipeg Transit bus, said Saskia Ferwerda, a witness who had been on the bus. </P>  <P align=justify>"People went flying off their seats," Ferwerda said. "I braced myself and hurt my wrist." </P>  <P align=justify>No serious injuries to bus-riders were reported. The motorist was taken to HSC in stable condition, police said. </P>  <P align=justify>Police will determine if the driver had a drinking or a medical problem, Gold said.</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 5-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Argument ends in tragedy
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.10/04    Page A2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A woman was killed in a tragic accident last night that was sparked by an argument with her boyfriend in the town of Anola. </P>  <P align=justify>RCMP couldn't be reached for information, but an Anola resident said the woman and her boyfriend were arguing when he jumped into his tractor-trailer and started to drive away. </P>  <P align=justify>She jumped onto the side of the tractor, with the man yelling at her to get off, said the resident. </P>  <P align=justify>He continued driving and the woman fell off and slid beneath the rig, said the resident, who didn't want to be named. </P>  <P align=justify>Anola is about 60 kilometres west of Winnipeg at the corner of highways 12 and 15.</P>  <P align=justify>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 6-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [PHOTO]
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.10/04    Page A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>Winnipeg Fire Paramedic Service personnel use Jaws of Life to free driver of a car involved in a collision with a city bus at intersection of Portage Avenue and Maryland Street yesterday at about 8 p.m. A police officer noticed the driver appeared to be asleep at the wheel while stopped in the southbound lane on Maryland, but the car accelerated through the intersection, colliding with the bus, before officers could intervene. A police spokesman didn&#8217;t know the extent of the man&#8217;s injuries or if anyone on the bus was injured. Police are investigating whether alcohol or medical problem were factors.</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 7-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Deal to speed MRI’s--  Clinic To Do Scans For Workers’ Compensation
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.10/04    Page A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>THE Workers' Compensation Board has struck a deal with the Pan Am Clinic for MRI scans that proponents claim will get injured workers back on the job weeks earlier and save more than $1 million a year in benefit payouts. </P>  <P align=justify>The deal between the WCB and Pan Am, a publicly owned but privately managed sports medicine and surgical clinic, comes after months of political turbulence that scuttled earlier attempts to get injured workers expedited medical services. </P>  <P align=justify>In exchange for fees of approximately $1.3 million over an eight-year period, WCB claimants will get expedited access to a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanner scheduled to be installed at the Pan Am Clinic by next spring. </P>  <P align=justify>WCB spokesman Warren Preece said that by shaving weeks off the time injured workers wait to have an MRI scan, the insurance program will save a minimum of $1 million in salary replacement each year of the lease arrangement. </P>  <P align=justify>On average, it costs $350 a week in benefits to replace salary for each injured worker, Preece said. Last year, the WCB paid out more than $76 million in salary replacement. </P>  <P align=justify>The WCB each year orders about 700 MRI scans, a key tool for diagnosing many work-related injuries. Each scan costs about $685. It can take up to 17 weeks to get an MRI for an elective patient. "Lower costs -- that is the reward to us as an insurance company," Preece said. "The reward for the injured worker is returning to work faster, which is good for the employer as well." </P>  <P align=justify>Because workers' compensation is an insurance program funded by employers, Manitoba Health does not cover the cost of medical services for injured workers. Employer premiums cover the $34 million in annual health-care services purchased for WCB claimants. </P>  <P align=justify>The province purchased the privately owned Pan Am clinic in 2001 for $17 million. Although it is government-owned, Pan Am pays for all its overhead from the same procedure and facility fees paid to any private surgical clinic. </P>  <P align=justify>However, the province has provided considerable money for capital expansion at the facility. Pan Am is just now finishing a $4-million government-funded expansion that has added two state-of-the-art operating rooms and new space for plastic surgeons and therapists. </P>  <P align=justify>The renovated facility will allow up to 10 orthopedic surgeons to maintain offices in the same facility in which they operate, making Pan Am unique in Canada. </P>  <P align=justify>The province is also paying for the installation of a new MRI scanner at Pan Am at a cost of $3.5 million, all covered by a special federal medical technology fund. Dr. Wayne Hildahl, general manger of the Pan Am Clinic, said the WCB will receive a minimum of 20 MRI slots each week. If there is a need for more scans, efforts will be made to accommodate as many WCB claimants as possible without delaying other elective patients. </P>  <P align=justify>The new MRI at Pan Am should give many non-emergency patients easier access to scans, Hildahl said. Currently, emergency cases take MRI priority at the Health Sciences Centre, leaving many elective patients, including WCB claimants, waiting weeks or months. </P>  <P align=justify>The income from the WCB lease should allow Pan Am to proceed with yet another expansion, this time to add a second floor to the $4-million addition that was opened this spring. </P>  <P align=justify>The WCB was initially criticized by business lobby groups and opposition MLAs for contemplating lease agreements with the Pan Am Clinic. Last year, the WCB raised employer premiums by nearly five per cent, in large part to make up ground lost on stock market investments. </P>  <P align=justify>dan.lett@freepress.mb.ca</P>  <P>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 8-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Slaying probe finds suv--  Pathfinder Being Examined For Possible Evidence
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.10/04    Page B1/B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>RCMP may have moved another step closer yesterday to identifying a suspect in last weekend's killing of Trevor Neil Tanner. </P>  <P align=justify>Mountie spokesman Sgt. Steve Colwell said investigators found a gold 1993 Nissan Pathfinder yesterday morning in the city. It was found unattended in a parking lot in North Kildonan after being reported to police by a newspaper reader. </P>  <P align=justify>Colwell said the SUV -- Mounties issued a public plea Thursday for its recovery -- will now be examined by forensic experts for any evidence. </P>  <P align=justify>Police believe the Pathfinder was somehow involved in the disappearance and subsequent murder of Tanner, 22. </P>  <P align=justify>He was found dead at the end of a gravel road just outside Lockport shortly after 2 a.m. Sunday. </P>  <P align=justify>The Glenlawn Collegiate graduate had been shot to death, apparently in the back of his head. Sources say the Pathfinder is registered to a St. Vital man and had not been reported stolen. It's not known how long it had been at the city parking lot. </P>  <P align=justify>The registered owner was unavailable yesterday, but a family member said the SUV had been stolen several days ago. </P>  <P align=justify>He also said police had recently been to his family's Island Lakes home to interview the SUV's owner. </P>  <P align=justify>"The police have been here, but I'm not telling you anything," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>Police have not released the Pathfinder owner's name and Colwell said he could not comment on whether investigators had identified any "persons of interest." </P>  <P align=justify>Colwell said investigators would now like to speak to anyone who has information about the movements of the Pathfinder. Contact RCMP Serious Crimes Services at 984-6447 or Manitoba Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477. </P>  <P align=justify>A man who lives on the River Access Road, where Tanner's body was found, said police questioned him Sunday morning about whether he heard gunshots Saturday night. </P>  <P align=justify>Yesterday, Keith Skiba maintained someone in the area was blowing off fireworks between 9 and 9:30 p.m., and then he distinctly heard two loud pops around 11 p.m. that he believes were gunshots. </P>  <P align=justify>Skiba, 36, also said he saw two vehicles between 10 and10:30 p.m. heading to the area at the end of his road -- also known as a lover's lane -- where the body was found. </P>  <P align=justify>Although it was dark, he believes one was a truck and the other an SUV. </P>  <P align=justify>Colwell has said he could not comment on how RCMP became aware of the Pathfinder. </P>  <P align=justify>Relatives of Tanner have said they believe he and a young friend were involved in a fight with several men at The Forks Saturday evening. </P>  <P align=justify>Police were called, but Tanner and the men had disappeared by the time they arrived and no arrests were made. Tanner's friend was treated for some minor injuries, the source said. </P>  <P align=justify>"We think he might have been taken away by (the people attacking him)," a source told the <I>Free Press</I>. Police have already questionned bar staff at The Forks in connection with the Tanner investigation. </P>  <P align=justify>It's believed Tanner became involved in a dispute with young men involved in the city's drug trade. </P>  <P align=justify>A memorial service for Tanner will be held today at 11 a.m. at Glen Lawn Funeral Home, 455 Lagimodiere Blvd. south of the Royal Canadian Mint. </P>  <P align=justify>The family has asked that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Manitoba Organization of Victim Advocates or to Cancer Care Manitoba. </P>  <P align=justify>bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 9-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Looking out for money launderers
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri 09 Jul 2004   Page: F1   Section: Auto
NEWS_ITM_TXT: THE term car wash has a new twist, an RCMP inspector told vehicle sales reps and dealers during a recent professional development program.   <P>"One of the ways that criminals launder money is by buying big ticket items such as new cars," Insp. Scott Kolody told sales representatives and dealers attending the most recent Manitoba Motor Dealers Association (MMDA) sales certification program convocation and professional development program this past Wednesday </P>  <P>He encouraged them to report anyone who comes in with more than $10,000 in cash. </P>  <P>Kolody, new head of the RCMP's integrated proceeds of crime section in Winnipeg, noted that sales reps should be very suspicious should a young fellow come in with a large sum of money in cash in a plastic bag and try to buy a car with it. </P>  <P>As it happens, that is something the MMDA also encourages. MMDA past president Larry Vickar (Vickar Chev Olds), in thanking Kolody, observed that dealerships have forms that are supposed to be filled out on any customer who has more than $10,000 in cash with them. For dealerships that don't have the forms, copies are available at the MMDA office. </P>  <P>10th anniversary </P>  <P>At this most recent convocation, 30 new graduates joined the ranks of MMDA certified sales professionals. Don Neufeld, current MMDA president (and president of Auto City Mazda in Steinbach), noted that this July marks the sales certification program's 10th anniversary. In that time, 857 sales reps and dealer principals provincewide have graduated from the program. </P>  <P>"Manitoba was the first province to certify sales reps and dealerships, Vickar added. "It has made a real difference in the industry." </P>  <P>Even though the sales certification program has been an unqualified success, the MMDA is not resting on its laurels. Neufeld announced that the MMDA has hired consultant Rosalie Olson (Dynamic Resource Management) to review the program and recommend improvements. She is scheduled to present her findings around the end of August. </P>  <P>In other industry-related news, Neufeld noted the provincial government's new cost-of-credit disclosure regulations. "That's a key area of our business," he said. </P>  <P>He also praised the government's decision to merge the motor vehicle licensing branch with <B>Manitoba Public Insurance </B>and the new provincial licensing standards that require anyone selling more than five vehicles to be licensed and to display that licence in a prominent place. </P>  <P>Another new government program requires dealerships to check customer and new employees' drivers licences to make sure they are valid and current. </P>  <P>"We are also working with the government on changes that would make odometer tampering more difficult," Neufeld said. </P>  <P>In other news, Denise Thompson of Frontier Subaru notes that there are a few spaces still open for the dealership's test drive event for the 2005 Outback and Legacy unveiling next Thursday evening at the Red River Ex Fairgrounds. Anyone who would like to attend please call Frontier Subaru at 944-6604. </P>

Title: 10-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: car-jacking terror    Knife-Wielding Coward Knocks Down Owner, 83
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A legendary Assiniboia Downs horse trainer just wants to get back on track and forget he and his wife were car-jacked at knifepoint outside their upscale Fort Garry-area apartment. Albert (Bert) Blake, who suffered cuts and bruises when he was shoved to the ground and left to watch helplessly as two thugs raced off in his Cadillac late Saturday night, was waiting to get his luxury car back yesterday from police. </P>  <P align=justify>"I'm fine. It's much ado about nothing," Blake, 83, told The Sun yesterday. </P>  <P align=justify>"I'd just as soon forget the whole thing. I'm glad it's over." </P>  <P align=justify>Blake and his wife, Eileen, were returning home from the racetrack about 11:10 p.m. Saturday, when they pulled into their parking stall at the Marina del Rey apartments at 916 Cloutier Dr., just off Pembina Highway. </P>  <P align=justify>The senior citizens got out of their maroon four-door 1995 Cadillac STS -- only to be confronted by two 20-something men who demanded Blake hand over his car keys. </P>  <P align=justify>Blake, a D-Day vet who landed on Juno Beach, refused. </P>  <P align=justify>"I wasn't going to say, 'Here it is,' and put a ribbon around it," the Brandon native recalled. "I wasn't frightened." </P>  <P align=justify>That's when one of the men knocked him over and then flashed a large filleting knife. </P>  <P align=justify>Realizing the severity of the situation, Blake decided to hand over his keys. </P>  <P align=justify>"They got what they wanted, and that was it. Game over," he said, adding he immediately called police in the hopes that they would be able to catch the thieves red-handed. </P><B>  <P align=justify>SPOTTED SUSPECT </P></B>  <P align=justify>The investigation led cops to the address of a known suspect, said Winnipeg police spokesman Const. Bob Johnson. </P>  <P align=justify>Police were en route to the suspect's residence about 3:15 a.m. yesterday, when they spotted him driving the stolen Cadillac southbound on Maryland Street near Ellice Avenue. </P>  <P align=justify>Refusing to stop for police, the driver turned east on to Ellice and then continued south on Colony Street, Memorial Boulevard and Osborne Street -- running six red lights while reaching speeds of 120 km/h, Johnson said. </P>  <P align=justify>After just 17 seconds, police aborted the pursuit at Osborne and Mostyn Street for public safety reasons, Johnson said. </P>  <P align=justify>A short time later, police found the stolen Caddy -- with a stolen licence plate -- abandoned at the rear of a Roslyn Crescent residence. </P>  <P align=justify>Police were in the process of getting an arrest warrant for the suspect yesterday afternoon. No arrests had been reported by press time last night. </P>  <P align=justify>Blake, who has owned pricey thoroughbred racing horses in the past, wasn't sure whether he was targeted because of his stature in the racing world. </P>  <P align=justify>"I guess they were casing the joint," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>"We were getting out of the car. There was no one around. They couldn't have come at a more opportune time." </P>  <P align=justify>Neighbours said the block, which is monitored by a security company, is usually quiet. </P>  <P>"Someone probably saw them driving a nice car," said one tenant, who didn't want to be identified. </P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 11-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Prison for teen shooter    Guns Down Man After Burglary
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A teenage boy received a 3 1/2-year adult sentence yesterday for capping off a rural burglary by shooting a stranger in the back. The 16-year-old, who can't be named under the Youth Criminal Justice Act, had pleaded guilty to aggravated assault and using a firearm to commit an indictable offence. </P>  <P align=justify>He did not oppose the Crown's plan to seek an adult sentence for his crimes. </P>  <P align=justify>At his sentencing yesterday, Crown attorney Joyce Dalmyn told court how the youth stole a van, drove it drunk past the outskirts of town northwest of Winnipeg, then broke into the Rosser residence of 82-year-old Mike Husak. </P>  <P align=justify>Husak wasn't home, but his friend, 57-year-old Barry Scaife, arrived to work in Husak's garden while the youth was inside. </P>  <P align=justify>Approaching the house with an armload of vegetables, Scaife noticed the youth and asked what he was doing. </P>  <P align=justify>The teen told Scaife he was lost, then disappeared into the residence when Scaife didn't believe him. </P>  <P align=justify>'BEGGED FOR LIFE' </P>  <P align=justify>He returned bearing a shotgun he'd found inside and pointed it at Scaife, who began backing away. </P>  <P align=justify>"Mr. Scaife begged for his life -- he brought to (the youth's) attention that he had a one-year-old grandson he hadn't had the opportunity to play with yet," Dalmyn said. "The youth was oblivious." </P>  <P align=justify>Scaife turned to run, and the youth shot him once in the back, Dalmyn said. A second shot narrowly missed Scaife's head. </P>  <P align=justify>The gunshot wound punctured Scaife's bowel, causing him injuries that prevented him from ever returning to work as a heavy equipment operator. Because he can't do heavy lifting anymore, he'll be unable to work as casual handyman, which he'd planned to do on retiring. </P>  <P align=justify>Even the youth admitted the shooting was horrific, and defence lawyer Lori Van Dongen told court yesterday he's "absolutely horrified by his actions." </P>  <P align=justify>The adult sentence, reached via a joint agreement between lawyers, will see the youth serve another three years in addition to the nine months he's already spent in custody. </P>  <P align=justify>The sentence will be served in a youth facility.</P>

Title: 12-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Bullet- and truck-proof    Vest Probably Saved Cop’s Life
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A&nbsp;Portage la Prairie Mountie, struck by a passing truck on Saturday while writing up a speeding ticket, could have his bulletproof vest to thank for saving his life. Const. Terry Aselton was discharged from Portage District General Hospital on Sunday after suffering only "cuts, bruises and scrapes" in the highway accident. </P>  <P align=justify>"He's very lucky he didn't sustain any serious injuries," said Portage RCMP Cpl. Marty Grainger. </P>  <P align=justify>Grainger said there are many documented cases of police officers who have been saved from serious injury in automobile accidents because they were wearing their body armour, particularly after being struck by the steering column during a collision. </P>  <P align=justify>"We think that may have happened here. This is all speculation, but in this case he was hit by the trailer and the vest could have taken the brunt of the force." </P>  <P align=justify>Aselton declined to speak to the media about the accident. </P>  <P align=justify>Grainger said an expert would have to examine Aselton's vest to determine what role it played in limiting his injuries. </P><B>  <P align=justify>MANDATORY </P></B>  <P align=justify>"An expert would have ... to see if the vest sustained any damage that Terry would have sustained had he not been wearing it," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>RCMP made wearing body armour mandatory for all operational officers following the murder of Manitoba Mountie Dennis Strongquill in December of 2001. </P>  <P align=justify>Strongquill was gunned down while trapped inside his cruiser outside the Russell RCMP detachment office. He wasn't wearing his body armour. </P>  <P align=justify>His killer, Robert Sand, was sentenced to life in prison following a trial in Brandon last summer. </P>  <P align=justify>Aselton, 44, was expected to see a doctor today and will remain off work for at least a few days, Grainger said. </P>  <P align=justify>"We're not going to rush him back at all. He's going to get better and come back when he's ready," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>Aselton was standing on the shoulder of the Trans-Canada Highway about 15 kilometres west of Portage when he was hit by a passing truck shortly after 2 p.m. Saturday. </P>  <P align=justify>Police have charged Murrey Reynders of North Battleford, Sask. with careless driving.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 13-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [photo]    quick turnover
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A rescue crew works to free a woman trapped in an overturned SUV on Doncaster Street and Tuxedo Avenue yesterday after she was involved in a two-vehicle accident.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 14-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Give him 3 years in jail: crown    Drunk Driver Blamed Accident On His Friend
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A man who drunkenly rolled a female friend's car -- and then tried pinning the blame on her -- should go to prison for the next three years, a lawyer argued yesterday. </P><B>  <P align=justify>LOOKING FOR A RIFLE </P></B>  <P align=justify>Wayne Orville Henrikson, 49, was convicted last winter of charges of impaired driving causing bodily harm and dangerous driving causing bodily harm, for an accident that took place on a gravel road near Manigotogan, in northeastern Manitoba, on Sept. 30, 2000. </P>  <P align=justify>At his trial, court heard how Henrikson had been driving "erratically" with passenger Lois Muir, and how he began speeding from property to property in search of a rifle to shoot a moose he'd just spotted. </P>  <P align=justify>The accident occurred when he lost control of Muir's vehicle, sending the car rolling into a ditch several times before it came to rest upside-down. </P>  <P align=justify>The accident left Muir in a back brace for nine months, but that didn't stop Henrikson from trying to blame her for causing the crash -- both at his trial and at the time of his arrest. </P>  <P align=justify>While en route to the hospital, Henrikson told an ambulance attendant, "I can't believe I rolled her car . ... I mean I can't believe she rolled the car," Crown attorney Joanna Kostiuk told court at trial. </P>  <P align=justify>Yesterday, at Henrikson's sentencing hearing, Kostiuk cited Henrikson's "cocky, arrogant" manner while being arrested as a mitigating factor. </P>  <P align=justify>"When asked about the accident, his response was something like, 'Car? What car? Are we in a car?'" Kostiuk told Queen's Bench Justice Holly Beard. "When asked again, he tries to put the blame on Ms. Muir." </P>  <P align=justify>Kostiuk is seeking a three-year sentence for Henrikson, who has one previous conviction for driving impaired causing bodily harm, and who was on probation at the time of the crash. </P>  <P align=justify>Defence lawyer Tony Cellitti, who tried arguing at trial that Henrikson wasn't in the driver's seat at the time the car rolled, is asking for a conditional sentence of two years less a day. </P>  <P align=justify>Beard has reserved her decision until later this month.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>  <P align=justify>&nbsp;</P>

Title: 15-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letter of the day    Stop! Thief!
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>My reward for enjoying the weekend with my family was returning to find that my bike had been stolen Friday or Saturday night. My son's scooter was stolen two weeks ago. I am reporting these thefts to the police, as I have the serial numbers. </P>  <P align=justify>Thieves (yes, that's what you are) -- if you develop a conscience, please return these items to their rightful yard. Parents -- theft is theft! </P>  <P align=justify>Don't be afraid to ask your children to explain how they have attained their new silver Raptor scooter or blue ladies' bike. </P>  <P align=justify>Check the Auto Theft website developed by the Citizens For Crime Awareness of Winnipeg/Neighbourhood Watch if you think these small thefts don't lead to bigger things. </P>  <P align=justify>By the way, we are a one-car family. The kids and I get to most of our activities by bike. I guess I'll be walking! </P>  <P align=justify>W. Prychitko </P>  <P align=justify>Winnipeg </P>  <P align=justify>Sad to say, but lock them up.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 16-May-13

Title: 17-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Woman killed under rig; RCMP seeking witnesses
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, Mb    Free Press    July.13/04    Page A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>RCMP are asking the public for help after a woman fell under the wheels of a tractor-trailer driven by her boyfriend and was killed Friday evening in Anola. </P>  <P align=justify>"We are asking if anybody witnessed this to let us know," said Staff Sgt. Dan Murchison of Oakbank RCMP. The accident claimed the life of 38-year-old Christine Bruinson Douma. </P>  <P align=justify>She and her boyfriend, Cory McCaughan, were arguing in a Petro-Canada station parking lot when he jumped into his tractor-trailer and started to drive away, an Anola resident said. Police said Douma jumped onto the side of the moving tractor, fell off and slid beneath the rig. Douma was dead at the scene. </P>  <P align=justify>No charges have been laid, Murchison said. </P>  <P align=justify>"There are no actual witnesses, independent of the families, who saw anything," he said. </P>  <P align=justify>Douma's 10-year-old daughter was in the area at the time of the accident, he said. The driver of the rig had not been drinking, Murchison said. An autopsy was being conducted on the woman's body yesterday, he said. </P>  <P align=justify>Anola is about 30 kilometres west of Winnipeg and located at the junction of highways 12 and 15.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 18-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Bullet-proof vest credited with saving Mountie
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.13/04    Page B3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>RCMP are crediting a Mountie's bullet-proof vest with sparing him serious injury or even death when he was side-swiped by a semi-trailer truck Saturday afternoon. </P>  <P align=justify>Const. Terry Aselton, who is now resting at home after spending one night in hospital, was wearing his protective vest when he stopped a car for speeding on the Trans-Canada Highway about 30 kilometres west of Portage la Prairie. </P>  <P align=justify>Cpl. Marty Grainger, of the Portage detachment, said officers believe the vest partially shielded Aselton as the truck's trailer grazed him as he stood beside the stopped black four-door Mazda. </P>  <P align=justify>"We do believe it protected him from a serious injury to his upper body." Grainger said. </P>  <P align=justify>The collision pinned Aselton against the car, the trailer rolling him almost the length of the vehicle, denting it and also tearing off its driver's side rear-view mirror.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 19-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Part of perimeter closes tomorrow for repairs
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, Mb    Free Press    July.13/04    Page B4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>A section of the Perimeter Highway will be closed to all traffic for a half-day tomorrow. The highway will be closed to all traffic from the north junction of PTH 59 to the junction of PTH 15 from 5 a.m. to noon tomorrow. </P>  <P align=justify>The route will be closed to allow crews to carry out the first phase of repairs to the CN rail crossing near PTH 15. </P>  <P align=justify>The second phase of the repairs will be scheduled in about two weeks. Those repairs will also require the road to be closed temporarily. </P>  <P align=justify>Traffic will need to choose alternate routes -- such as Lagimodiere Boulevard -- during the closure.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 20-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Trainer gets stolen caddy back after police chase
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.13/04    Page B4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>AN 83-year-old horse training legend who was car-jacked at knife-point got his Cadillac back yesterday when it was abandoned after a high-speed police chase. Albert Blake was pushed to the ground and robbed of his keys by a pair of knife-wielding thieves outside his St. Norbert condo Saturday night. </P>  <P align=justify>He was returning home from Assiniboia Downs at about 11 p.m. when he was jumped in the outside parking lot. The ordeal didn't stop Blake from returning to the Downs on Sunday to see his three-year-old colt Shanghied win the $40,000 Manitoba Derby Trial. </P>  <P align=justify>Yesterday, a police unit spotted the stolen wine-coloured 1995 Cadillac STS as it pulled onto Ellice Avenue from Maryland Street at about 3:15 a.m., said Const. Bob Johnson. </P>  <P align=justify>The driver of the car soon spotted the police car behind him and took off east towards downtown to lose it, reaching a top speed of about 120 km/h, Johnson said. </P>  <P align=justify>The Caddy then swung south onto Memorial Boulevard to Portage Avenue down Osborne Street. Police called off the chase at Mostyn Place just before the Osborne Bridge for safety reasons, Johnson said. </P>  <P align=justify>The chase last 17 seconds and covered less than a kilometre. Johnson said police soon found the car abandoned behind a residence on Roslyn Crescent. It had licence plates on it stolen from another vehicle. </P>  <P align=justify>Blake said police called him yesterday morning saying they'd found his car and he could pick it up later in the day. </P>  <P align=justify>"They told me it wasn't damaged," he said. "That's one good thing." </P>  <P align=justify>Johnson also said detectives are investigating several suspects, but had not made arrests late yesterday. </P>  <P align=justify>The first suspect is described as black, 22 to 26 years old, 5-10, with a thin build and short black hair. The other man is described as black, 23 to 25 years old, 5-6 to 5-7, with a stocky build and short black hair.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 21-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [photo]    suv flips in collision
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.13/04    Page B5

The SUV and another vehicle were involved in a collision at the corner of Tuxedo Avenue and Doncaster Street about 1 p.m. Both drivers were reported to be in stable condition.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 22-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: no increase in premiums, mpi predicts    Forecasts Freeze Will Last For The Next Five Years
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>Gas prices may be up but most Manitoba motorists could be in for a break on auto insurance. Manitoba Public Insurance is forecasting a 0% increase in overall premiums during the next five years. </P>  <P align=justify>The freeze is part of the public insurer's long-term financial outlook, which was recently filed with the Public Utilities Board (PUB). </P>  <P align=justify>"It is a forecast, and we wouldn't want to portray it as anything more than a forecast," MPI spokesman John Douglas told The Sun. "It's our best assessment of what we can have moving forward." </P>  <P align=justify>The freeze doesn't mean individual premiums wouldn't go up or down, Douglas said. Rates in some categories may rise while other may fall, he said. </P>  <P align=justify>Motorcyclists have been hit the hardest in recent years. MPI has applied to the PUB to boost motorcycle premiums by 15% next year. </P>  <P align=justify>"This doesn't mean anything overall," Doug Houghton, spokesman for the Coalition of Manitoba Motorcycle Groups, said of the projected rate freeze. </P>  <P align=justify>Houghton said motorcyclists can expect to continue to be hit with increases in their insurance. </P>  <P align=justify>Douglas said MPI's five-year rate projections have been "98% accurate" during the past three decades. However, he warned the outlook could change if a sudden storm causes significant damage to many vehicles or if bad winter weather contributes to an abnormal number of accidents. </P>  <P align=justify>A study last year found Manitoba had the lowest auto insurance rates in the country. </P>  <P>The Consumers' Association of Canada found the average auto insurance rate in Manitoba was $835, compared with $904 in Saskatchewan, $1,106 in British Columbia and $1,778 in Nova Scotia.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 23-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Local briefs    Arsonists target cars, cycles
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>The Arson Strike Force is looking to snuff out a rash of potentially explosive vehicle and motorcycle fires this week in Fort Rouge. </P>  <P align=justify>Since early Monday morning, there have been nearly half a dozen suspicious fires reported along Roslyn Road and Wardlaw and Dorchester avenues. </P>  <P align=justify>"It's needless damage. It's costing a lot of money and it's got to stop," said Arson Strike Force Sgt. Derrick Todoruk. "I don't think you get explosions but ... the chance for explosions is always there." </P>  <P align=justify>Shortly after midnight early yesterday morning, a motorist discovered someone </P>  <P align=justify>&nbsp;</P>  <P align=justify>had stuffed a rolled up newspaper in the gas filler of his Dodge Neon, which was parked in the area of 43 Roslyn Rd., and then tried to light it on fire. </P>  <P align=justify>"They were either scared away or they left it and it didn't ignite, just blew itself out," Todoruk said. </P>  <P align=justify>A resident in an apartment at 16 Roslyn Rd. wasn't as lucky. He looked out his window about 5:30 a.m. yesterday to see his motorcycle on fire. The cause hadn't been determined by press time last night. </P>  <P align=justify>Another motorcycle blaze, which spread to a Volvo, was reported on Dorchester about 4:15 a.m. Monday. </P>  <P align=justify>There was also a similar fire on Wardlaw.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 24-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Local briefs    Witness to fatal crash sought
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>Police were looking for a motorist yesterday who may have witnessed a fatal motorcycle crash last week. </P>  <P align=justify>Martino Soares, 25, was riding his Honda motorcycle southbound on Arlington Street about 8:25 a.m. last Wednesday, when he reportedly ran a red light at the intersection of Selkirk Avenue and slammed into the driver's side of an eastbound car. </P>  <P align=justify>Soares was taken in critical condition to Health Sciences Centre, where he was pronounced dead. </P>  <P align=justify>A police investigation has revealed an unidentified man was driving alongside Soares just prior to the collision. </P>  <P align=justify>He was described as a short male with a red beard. He was wearing denim shorts, and he was driving an older-model Japanese vehicle that was grey-primer coloured. </P>  <P align=justify>The possible witness stopped at a nearby Mac's Store after the collision but left before police could interview him. </P>  <P align=justify>He or anyone who knows him is asked to call the Winnipeg police collision analyst at 986-6271.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 25-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police seek accident witness
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.14/04    Page B4
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>CITY police are looking for a witness to a July 7 fatal motorcycle crash at Arlington Street and Selkirk Avenue which claimed the life of 25-year-old Martino Soares.Police said yesterday investigators believe an unknown male was driving alongside Soares' motorcycle just before the collision, which happened at about 8 a.m. </P>  <P align=justify>The witness was also driving south on Arlington when Soares crashed his Honda sport bike into the side of a car travelling on Selkirk. Witnesses said Soares ran a red light. </P>  <P align=justify>Police say the man was driving an older, Japanese model vehicle that was painted in a grey primer. He stopped at the Mac's Store at the corner after the collision, but drove away before police could interview him. </P>  <P align=justify>He is described as a short male with a red beard, wearing blue jean shorts. </P>  <P align=justify>Traffic investigators want him to call the Traffic Unit at 986-6271 to be interviewed. </P>  <P align=justify>Soares was rushed to the Health Sciences Centre in critical condition and pronounced deceased shortly after arrival. </P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 26-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [photo]    three injured in crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>Winnipeg Fir Paramedic Service members attend to three people hurt in a motor vehicle accident at Maryland Street and Ellice Avenue yesterday.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 27-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [photo]    crash injuries three
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg, mb    Free Press    July.14/04    Page B8
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P align=justify>Paramedics remove one of three people injured in a two-vehicle collision at Maryland Street and Ellice Avenue yesterday morning. The intersection was closed while rescuers worked.</P>  <P align=center>-30-</P>

Title: 28-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: GET SERIOUS, GORD: Fulfil Vow To Jail Killer Drunk Drivers
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Manitoba Justice Minister Gord Mackintosh is the June winner of this column's Eight-Ball Award. It's the first time a politician has won the award, handed out monthly to highlight the worst perversions of justice in our court system. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Judges are usually the recipient of the award, since the courts have the last say on sentencing. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But the perversion of justice doesn't always lie with the judge alone. And in the case of newspaper carrier Michael Antosh, who was mowed down and killed by a drunk driver on Aug. 15, 2003, the government was as culpable as the judge in what can only be described as a case of gross injustice. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><B><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>JUDGE ERRED <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></B></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The injustice was that the drunk driver, Lindsay McCaughan -- convicted of impaired driving causing death -- did not serve a day in jail for her offence. Instead, she got an 18-month conditional sentence last month, where she serves her "time" at home. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The judge obviously erred in the case by failing to ensure that the sentence met the basic sentencing principles of denunciation and deterrence. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The sentence also clearly failed to meet the overriding principle in Sec. 718.1 of the Criminal Code, namely that the sentence be proportionate to the gravity of the offence. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>I'd say killing someone is pretty grave. But what bothered me most about the McCaughan case was that the conditional sentence was recommended by the Crown. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Which means all of the political rhetoric we hear from Gord Mackintosh -- who for years has been publicly criticizing the use of conditional sentences for serious crimes such as impaired driving causing death -- is just that, rhetoric. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Mackintosh cannot get involved in individual cases. But what he can do is issue directives to the prosecution branch to oppose conditional sentences for all impaired driving causing death cases. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>He obviously hasn't done that. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Mackintosh likes to portray himself as a "tough-on-crime" guy. And he's been saying for years that conditional sentences are not appropriate for crimes such as impaired driving causing death. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"With impaired driving causing death cases, it's important that there be a strong and clear message that this is a very serious crime for which there are very serious consequences," said Mackintosh in January 2000. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"The conditional sentence law has created case after case in this country of injustice, especially in cases of death," he said Aug. 29, 2003. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Just last month we ran a story about how Mackintosh planned to continue to lobby Ottawa to make certain crimes, such as impaired driving causing death, ineligible for conditional sentences. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Yet his own prosecution branch is recommending the opposite. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>If Mackintosh were truly serious about his conditional sentence campaign, he would instruct his Crowns to oppose -- in every case -- conditional sentences for drunks who kill behind the wheel. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>As the attorney general of Manitoba, he has that authority -- just as the federal government has the authority over the Criminal Code. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>And he has failed to exercise that authority. As a result, he has contributed to the perversion of justice in our court system. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>And for that, he is the June winner of the Eight-Ball Award.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 29-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: IGNORANCE GIVES RISE TO OUTRAGE: LAWYER
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Public outrage over court sentences that appear to be too lax or lenient can usually be linked to a lack of understanding of the law, lawyers say. "People just don't get it, in so far as what conditional sentences are, what their objectives are ... and that the courts are not here for revenge," says defence lawyer Hymie Weinstein. "People think they're a slap on the wrist, but they're not." <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Last month, Weinstein's client, 20-year-old Lindsay McCaughan, received an 18-month period of house arrest -- for an August 2003 drunk driving accident that killed Michael Antosh, a husband and father of two. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Despite the fact the sentence was a joint recommendation between Weinstein and the Crown and the fact a neutral third party stepped in for the final stages of negotiations, the term still drew the ire of the public, particularly members of Antosh's family. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Weinstein went to great lengths to explain why McCaughan deserved a conditional sentence over a jail term -- citing her young age, her lack of any prior criminal record and the likelihood she'd never again be involved in a criminal matter. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoHeading7 style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><B><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>BOUND BY LAW <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></B></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Reporters and ordinary citizens often don't realize the courts are bound by law to exhaust every possible option before resorting to incarceration, Weinstein said <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>In a recent seminar on media and the law, the courts echoed Weinstein's sentiments. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"Parliament demands that judges seek alternatives to jail sentence, particularly for non-violent offences," reads a document prepared for reporters. "Too often, restorative initiatives and sentences of house arrest are met with a torrent of criticism and editorial outrage ... This attitude fuels public dissatisfaction with the justice system and ignores the reality that prisons have proven to be a poor setting for rehabilitating criminals." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Before conditional sentences were introduced, Canada was imprisoning more people than any other civilized nation, with few positive results, Weinstein said. People often don't realize conditional sentences can be even harsher than jail terms, especially since there's no chance of early parole.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 30-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: WASHOUT HITS NO.1 HIGHWAY: Rains Burst Beaver Dam
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Canada's national symbol is being blamed for closing Canada's national highway for nearly 12 hours yesterday. Following several days of heavy rain, a beaver dam burst about 2 a.m. yesterday, creating a flash flood that washed out an eight-metre section of the Trans-Canada Highway about 15 kilometres east of the Manitoba-Ontario boundary. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"It's amazing what the power of water can do when you see something like that," said Const. Sue Cain of the Ontario Provincial Police. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"A beaver dam down the way just let go, and the water and debris that went with it washed out the highway." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The two-lane highway was reopened to single-lane traffic about 1 p.m. yesterday. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Tractor-trailers and other travellers clogged the streets of nearby Kenora as they waited for the highway to reopen. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>At the Kenora Husky Travel Stop, owner Amanda Johnson was waiting for a gas truck stuck on the other side of the washout. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"I'm hoping I don't run out of gas before (the road reopens)," she said. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Dozens of trucks, campers and cars filled the parking lot and lined the highway outside the truck stop while restaurant staff were kept hopping feeding the stranded motorists yesterday morning. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"We were really busy first thing this morning so we'll see what happens at lunchtime," Johnson said. "People have to eat lunch, too. That's OK, it's good for me." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The highway was expected to be open for two-lane traffic late last night. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"The Americans have al-Qaida. We have a beaver that shuts down the whole country," one highway construction worker quipped. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Cain said motorists should expect delays for the next couple of days as work crews complete repairs to the highway.<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 31-May-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [PHOTO]: HOLDING ON
