Title: 1-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: FEEDBACK
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>There should be a mandatory jail sentence for impaired driving causing death (see page 3).<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>To agree<SPAN style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp; </SPAN>632-2661<SPAN style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </SPAN>To disagree<SPAN style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp; </SPAN>632-2662<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>You can use a touch-tone or rotary dial phone.</FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 2-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: [PHOTO] BEAVERS CLOSE TRANS-CANADA: Broken dam causes traffic jam
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.15/04  Page A1/B12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Motorists on the Trans-Canada Highway were delayed for up to 12hours yesterday after a &#8216;beaver-dam blowout&#8217; washed out a portion of the highway, about 40 kilometres west of Kenora. Please see story and pictures on page B12.<?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>CANADA'S national symbol caused chaos on its national highway for 12 hours yesterday. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>A "beaver-dam blowout" closed the Trans-Canada Highway from the Manitoba-Ontario boundary to 32 kilometres west of Kenora, backing up traffic for several kilometres while Ontario Ministry of Transportation crews worked to repair the damaged road. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"The water was three-feet deep over the road at one point," said the ministry's regional director, Larry Lambert. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The Trans-Canada near Granite Lake was reopened to one lane of traffic yesterday afternoon. The second lane was expected to open last night, but Ontario Provincial Police were warning motorists to anticipate delays over the next day or two while portions of the highway are repaved. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>A transport driver discovered the twisting two-lane highway was washed out at about 2:10 a.m. yesterday when his rig almost didn't make it through. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"He had a considerable amount of difficulty with the water flowing over the highway," said Lambert. Heavy thundershowers in the area washed away beaver dams in creeks and clogged a culvert under the highway with debris. It forced water up over the road and damaged the road bed. Crews used a backhoe to remove the debris from the culvert then began to tear up the pavement, repair the road bed, and re-pave the highway. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Granite Lake cottager Dawn McKeag recalled the highway was washed out about five years ago. The Winnipeg senior was waiting for her husband and daughter to come from Winnipeg in time for lunch, but expected they'd be lucky to make it for supper. "This area has washed out before," McKeag said. "Nobody gets terribly excited." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>When she went to pick up a copy of the <I>Free Press</I> at the store at Pinewood Lodge at 7:30 a.m., there were already 11 tractor trailers lined up waiting for the highway to reopen. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The beaver's handiwork kept Pinewood's owner busy. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"The highway stopped right at our restaurant," said Ken Willms, whose highway eatery was packed with waylaid truckers yesterday morning. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"I would imagine there are trucks as far as the eye can see," he said. Willms had nothing but praise for the toothy rodent responsible. "The beavers did it. That's great. We can't fix mother nature." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:carol.sanders@freepress.mb.ca"><FONT face=Verdana>carol.sanders@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></A><o:p></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 3-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI MAY FREEZE RATES FOR 5 YEARS: Crown Insurer Won't Guarantee Prediction
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.15/04  Page A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>MANITOBA Public Insurance is back in the black and predicting five years of rate freezes. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The Crown corporation's annual report shows MPI posted a gain of $37.3 million in 2003-04, compared to a loss of $22.6 million in 2002-03. The total revenue in 2003-04 was $679.2 million. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>And the corporation is forecasting no increase in premiums over five years, said MPI spokesman John Douglas. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But he warned the freeze isn't set in stone and could be affected by factors like weather and collision claims. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"If there was a change in trends -- if Manitobans started smacking into each other more and more -- we would have to change the forecast." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>This year, Manitobans paid on average 3.7 per cent more for auto insurance, the first hike in five years despite insurance costs skyrocketing in other provinces. If the Public Utilities Board approves MPI's rate forecast in December, Manitobans are in for another five years of freezes. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But not everyone would see their rates frozen. For example, for the year 2005-06, only 53 per cent of drivers will pay the same or less for their insurance. The rest will pay more, depending on factors like the type of vehicle and the driver's record. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>According to MPI's annual report, the corporation's revenue increase in 2003-04 was mostly due to it's investments growing to $134 million from $57 million. That trend won't continue. MPI staff are only projecting a net income from investments of $2.8 million. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>A 2.5 per cent growth in the number of vehicles on the road and success in MPI's "competitive lines" -- special-risk extension and Autopac extension -- also helped keep MPI in the black. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Manitoba is one of only four provinces that offers "no-fault," government-run automobile insurance, providing basic coverage on a non-profit basis, with drivers given the option of purchasing additional coverage. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>In this province, the total cost of paying out claims increased $52.7 million in 2003-04, bringing the total to $662.5 million. The number of claims reported are also on the increase -- 243,400 last year compared to 227,579 in 2002-03. Using more recycled and after-market parts and managing the costs of towing, labour and other contracted services helped MPI keep the average physical damage claim lower in Manitoba than the rest of Canada -- $1,882 compared to the Canadian industry average of $2,980. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><A href="mailto:patti.edgar@freepress.mb.ca"><FONT face=Verdana>patti.edgar@freepress.mb.ca</FONT></A><FONT face=Verdana> <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Verdana; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA">-30-</SPAN></P>

Title: 4-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: Theft Of Bike Means I'll Be Walking
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.15/04  Page A13
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>My reward for enjoying the weekend with my family was in returning to find that my bike had been stolen Friday or Saturday night. My son's scooter was stolen two weeks ago. I am reporting these thefts to the police as I have the serial numbers. Thieves (yes, that's what you are) -- if you develop a conscience, please return these items to their rightful yard. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Parents -- theft is theft! Don't be afraid to ask your children to explain how they attained their new silver Raptor scooter or blue lady's bike. Check the Auto Theft website developed by the Citizens For Crime Awareness of Winnipeg / Neighbourhood Watch if you think these small thefts don't lead to bigger things. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>By the way, we are a one-car family. The kids and I get to most of our activities by bike. I guess I'll be walking! <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><FONT face=Verdana><B><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA">WANDA PRYCHITKO, </SPAN></B></FONT><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>St. James<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><o:p><FONT face=Verdana>&nbsp;</FONT></o:p></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: center; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 5-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: TRUCKERS, RCMP AIM FOR CLEARER SIGNALS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: WINNIPEG, MB  Free Press  July.15/04  Page B12
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>BRANDON -- Snowstorms are never far from Dennis Engel's mind, even as the truckers he represents barrel down the bone-dry summer highways in their big rigs. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" /><o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Engel has spent part of his summer lobbying the RCMP and the provincial highways department for better communication during storms such as the big Manitoba snowfall last May that stopped truckers in their tracks. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>"We're not questioning the RCMP in their decision to close the roads," said Engel, director of terminals for the Manitoba Trucking Association. "But next time, (the communication) will be a little more streamlined, a little more automatic and regular." <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>The province's trucking industry was out an estimated $2 million by the time the roads opened after two days of being almost completely closed in mid-May when a huge blizzard hit the province. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Hundreds of truckers were stranded by the side of the road along the Trans-Canada highway and Virden and Brandon were inundated by stranded semi drivers, who were left to wonder along with everyone else when the roads were going to re-open. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>That storm, and the huge financial losses the industry sustained, spurred a recent meeting between the trucking association, RCMP Traffic Services and the province to talk about what could be done better next time. Engel said the truckers asked that RCMP let representatives from the trucking association know as soon as a decision is made to close the roads, adding the association would ideally like hourly updates as to the status of the roads throughout the closure. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>But hourly updates would be difficult to carry out during the hectic event of a road closure, said Cpl. Larry Dalman of Headingley Traffic Services. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Dalman said as part of an effort to keep truckers in the loop, RCMP will get rid of their Big Mouth program, which is supposed to send an automated voice mail message to dozens of groups when a road is closed but is so outdated it doesn't get messages to everyone anymore. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>RCMP will instead compile a list of fax numbers, including those of big trucking firms, to "fan out" road closure announcements and updates during a storm, Dalman said. That fax system should be running by this fall, Dalman said. <o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>Adding to the confusion of the May snowstorm was that Manitoba Highways closes its 24-hour road information service on April 15 each year.</FONT></SPAN></P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt"><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana></FONT></SPAN>&nbsp;</P>  <P class=MsoNormal style="MARGIN: 6pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 11.6pt" align=center><SPAN lang=EN-CA style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Verdana; mso-ansi-language: EN-CA"><FONT face=Verdana>-30-<o:p></o:p></FONT></SPAN></P>

Title: 6-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Witness sought in pedestrian death
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Mon Mar 29 2010 Page: 5 Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police are looking for a driver who may have swerved around an elderly pedestrian before she was struck and killed by a pickup truck Saturday night. </P> <P>The 91-year-old woman was hit by the northbound truck while trying to cross Main Street at Atlantic Avenue shortly after 7 p.m. </P> <P>BLACK TRUCK </P> <P>She was transported to hospital, where she died of her injuries. </P> <P>A spokesman for the Winnipeg Police Service said an investigation by the central traffic unit indicates a witness in a black truck may have swerved around the pedestrian before she was hit. </P> <P>"They're a witness to her crossing the street and we need to speak to them about that," said Const. Blair Good. </P> <P>The motorist, or anyone else who may have witnessed the incident, is asked to call the central traffic unit at 986-6271. </P> <P>NO CHARGES FOR DRIVER </P> <P>The male driver of the truck that struck the woman remained at the scene after the incident. He was the only occupant of the vehicle. </P> <P>Police said it doesn't appear alcohol, drugs or speed were factors in the collision, and that charges against the driver are not being contemplated. </P> <P>Officers remained at the scene late into the night Saturday.</P>

--30--

Title: 7-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MAN PULLED FROM BURNING CAR
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Sunflashes Column Mon Mar 29 2010 Page: 15 Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A man was pulled from his burning vehicle by a passing motorist after his car crashed and caught fire on the south Perimeter Highway early Sunday. </P> <P>RCMP were called about 3 a.m. to the scene approximately 2 km east of Oak Bluff. </P> <P>Police said a 2001 Chevrolet Malibu was headed east when the driver, a 23-year-old man, lost control of the car, which struck the median. The car then rolled over, coming to rest on its roof and catching fire. </P> <P>The driver was helped out of the car by a passing motorist before the Malibu was completely engulfed in flames, RCMP said. He was then transported by ambulance to Health Sciences Centre in Winnipeg. </P> <P>The driver, who is from the Rural Municipality of Rockwood north of Winnipeg, was reported to be in stable condition Sunday with undetermined injuries, police said. </P>

--30--

Title: 8-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police Briefs - Driver survives rollover, fire
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Mon Mar 29 2010 Page: B3
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 23-year-old man is lucky to be alive after his Chevy Malibu rolled over and caught fire early Sunday morning on the Perimeter Highway. </P> <P>At about 3 a.m., the man was driving eastbound on the Perimeter just east of Oakbluff when he lost control of his 2001 Malibu, hit the median and rolled over. His car came to rest on its roof and caught fire. </P> <P>Passing motorists helped the driver from the car before it was completely engulfed in flames. The driver, who is from the rural municipality of Rockwood, was taken to Health Sciences Center by ambulance. He was in stable condition with undetermined injuries, said RCMP. </P> <P>Firefighters were able to extinguish the burning vehicle and provincial highways staff made sure the road was cleared of debris and safe for travel. </P> <P>RCMP continue to investigate. </P> <P>Car crash witness sought </P> <P>POLICE are looking for the driver of a black pickup truck who may have witnessed a car crash that killed a 91-year-old woman. </P> <P>The woman, whose name has not been released, was crossing Main Street near Atlantic Avenue Saturday evening at about 7 p.m. when she was allegedly hit by a northbound pickup truck. The driver, who police say had a green light, stopped at the scene and is not facing any charges. It's possible the woman may have been crossing at an uncontrolled intersection. </P> <P>Anyone who may have witnessed the accident should call police at 986-6271. </P>

--30--

Title: 9-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Elderly woman dead after collision
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Sun Mar 28 2010 Page: 16 Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 92-year-old woman is dead after she was hit by a vehicle Saturday night. </P> <P>The collision happened shortly after 7 p.m. at the intersection of Main Street and Atlantic Avenue. </P> <P>Winnipeg police are investigating but a spokeswoman said it doesn't appear alcohol or drugs were factors in the incident. </P> <P>Officers remained at the scene late last night. </P>

--30--

Title: 10-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man dies after being thrown from car in rollover
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Sun Mar 28 2010 Page: 16 Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 20-year-old man was killed in a rollover in Headingley early Saturday. </P> <P>Police were called to the scene of the single-vehicle crash on the Trans-Canada Highway west of Winnipeg about 4 a.m. </P> <P>RCMP said a white 1997 Pontiac Sunfire was headed east when the driver lost control of the vehicle. Police said witnesses reported the Sunfire rolled and came to rest in the parking area of the Headingley weigh scales. </P> <P>The driver, a young man from the Lorette area, was ejected from the car. His name has not been released pending notification of family. </P> <P>The driver was the only person in the car, police said. </P> <P>RCMP believe speed was a factor in the fatal crash and are investigating. </P> <P>Meanwhile, in a collision on Winnipeg's southern edge on Friday, a Hyundai Santa Fe struck a parked Pontiac LeMans on St. Anne's Road near Four Mile Road shortly before 9 p.m. </P> <P>Both vehicles then went off the road and at least partially into the adjacent Red River Floodway, causing minor injuries to a man and woman in the Hyundai. The man and woman -- the Hyundai's only occupants -- were treated in hospital and released. </P> <P>No one was in the Pontiac. </P> <P>Winnipeg Police Service spokesman Const. Blair Good said it's uncertain whether any charges will be laid in connection with the incident.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg woman, 91, killed crossing Main Street Witness in black truck sought
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: CBC News Sunday, March 28, 2010 3:42 PM CT
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An elderly Winnipeg woman was killed while trying to cross a busy street on Saturday evening, police said.</P> <P>The 91-year-old was struck by a northbound truck on Main Street at Atlantic Avenue shortly after 7 p.m. CT. She died of her injuries in hospital.</P> <P>At the scene, the woman's shoes and her wheeled grocery cart lay strewn along the busy street as police investigated. Police did not identify her.</P> <P>Video footage from the scene appears to show that the woman was standing on a concrete median in the middle of Main Street — a busy Winnipeg route — just prior to being hit. There are no traffic lights at the intersection.</P> <P>Police said on Sunday they are seeking to speak to a potential witness driving a black truck who may have swerved around the woman prior to her being hit.</P> <P>Investigators are also asking anyone who witnessed the crash to call the traffic unit at 204-986-6271 directly.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/03/28/man-woman-killed-main-street.html#ixzz0jZWC1A2R" target=_blank>http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/03/28/man-woman-killed-main-street.html#ixzz0jZWC1A2R</A></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Passersby pull injured driver to safety
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: CBC.CA News Sun Mar 28 2010, 10:20am ET Section: Canada
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A witness at the scene of a serious crash on the outskirts of Winnipeg early Sunday says passersby pulled the wrecked vehicle's driver to safety as the car burned. </P> <P>The crash happened at about 3 a.m. CT on the south Perimeter Highway between Highway 2 and Highway 330. </P> <P>A semi-trailer driver who spoke to CBC News said the car rolled a number of times and burst into flames. Other motorists stopped and pulled the male driver to safety, the trucker said. He did not want to be identified. </P> <P>RCMP and fire crews from surrounding rural areas rushed to the scene. The injured driver was taken to hospital by ambulance; police did not immediately confirm his condition. </P> <P>There were no passengers in the car. </P> <P>Traffic was blocked on the highway for about an hour as police investigated what happened. </P> <P>RCMP are expected to release details on the crash later Sunday. </P>

--30--

Title: 13-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teens left unlocked detention centre
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: CBC.CA News Sat Mar 27 2010, 6:42pm ET Section: Canada
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two teenagers accused of robbery with violence in Manitoba simply walked out of the Regina youth detention centre where they were being held. </P> <P>The youths, whose names have not been released because of provisions of the Youth Criminal Justice Act, were arrested March 15 by RCMP in Brandon. </P> <P>The two, a 14-year-old and a 17-year-old, are face charges relating to the violent robbery of a convenience store and liquor vendor in the small town of Alexander, Man., about 20 kilometres west of Brandon. </P> <P>The Stahl's Food Mart was the target of robbers around noon on March 15. Police say four youths, including the two from Saskatchewan, ordered the clerk to the floor and proceeded to help themselves to as much liquor as they could carry, plus some money from the cash register. </P> <P>They took off in a stolen car, but police caught up with them later in the day at a nearby First Nation after receiving a tip. </P> <P>Everyone involved in the food mart robbery was charged, including the two escapees from Saskatchewan, as well as a 15-year-old from the Sioux Valley First Nation in Manitoba and a 19-year-old from Brandon who is a relative of two of the boys. </P> <P>CBC News contacted officials from the Corrections, Public Safety and Policing Ministry in Saskatchewan and learned that the two escapees had been in what was described as "open custody" at the Paul Dojack Youth Detention Centre. </P> <P>"The two youths left the open custody unit at Paul Dojack at approximately 4 a.m. on March 14," Judy Orthner, a spokeswoman for the ministry, said in an email to CBC News. "The doors on the open custody unit are not locked, allowing youth to slip away or bolt if the so wish." </P> <P>Orthner added that police in Regina were notified immediately. </P> <P>Stolen car found in Manitoba </P> <P>According to RCMP in Manitoba, it is likely the two Saskatchewan teens left Regina in a stolen car. RCMP said a vehicle with Saskatchewan licence plates was located near to where another car was stolen in Brandon. </P> <P>The distance from Regina to Alexander, Man., is about 340 kilometres. </P> <P>Orthner said members of the public were not notified about the escape, but the incident would be included in a regular report to the minister. </P> <P>RCMP in Manitoba said all four youths had been detained in custody in Brandon, pending their court matters. </P>

--30--

Title: 14-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letter to the editor
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Sentinel Courier, Pilot Mound, MB Tuesday  March 30, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Enough advice from the Manitoba Public Insurance Claim Unit advising clients to hide their keys to help reduce auto theft. Originally, many moons back, AutoPac threatened to void theft claims where keys were left in vehicles. This died on the vine when the first offender was one of those “I’m above the law type” and we all know some like that. Since this legislation was never enforced, the careless were never cured. Nothing changed.</P> <P>AutoPac admits to hundreds of thefts since and in spite of immobilizers being installed in 2006. Several “victims” have filed multiple claims, at whose expense—the taxpayers’. Isn’t it past time AutoPac made some effort to penalize those leaving cars accessible to thieves? One severe penalty would cure most offenders, providing justice was equally meted to all.</P> <P>Old soldiers used to say, “No names, no pack drill.” When you have names and no pack drill something needs fixing. Any theft requires opportunity. Is not AutoPac providing this chance by not penalizing those having multiple thefts through their carelessness?</P> <P>When you know the problem and have no solution, or still do diddly-squat, perhaps others should have a try. Don’t hold your breath. All Manitoba drivers are automatic AutoPac customers, unfortunately, with no alternative.</P> <P>Thank you,<BR>Robert C. Bissett<BR>Morden, MB<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teen dead in single-car crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Tue Mar 30 2010   Page: 17   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 13-year-old boy who was seriously injured in a single-vehicle crash near Minnedosa on the weekend has died of his injuries, RCMP say. </P> <P>Police said the boy died at a Winnipeg hospital Monday morning. His name hasn't been released. </P> <P>He was one of five people in a 2004 Ford Explorer, which went out of control and rolled into the ditch on Highway 10, about five km south of Minnedosa, Sunday about 1 a.m., RCMP said. </P> <P>All are from the Dauphin and Grandview area. Four are related and one is a friend, police said. </P> <P>Two teenage boys were ejected from the southbound vehicle. It appears they may not have been wearing seatbelts, RCMP said. </P> <P>Police said two teens were taken to Winnipeg's Health Sciences Centre -- one is in stable condition -- while a third boy was taken to hospital in Minnedosa, where he was treated and released. </P> <P>The driver and front passenger weren't injured, RCMP said. </P> <P>Alcohol and speed aren't considered factors, police said. </P> <P>No charges are being contemplated at this time but the investigation is ongoing, RCMP said. </P>

--30--

Title: 16-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teen hockey player killed
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Tue Mar 30 2010   Page: A6
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 13-year-old hockey player from Grandview died in a car crash Sunday on his way to watch a championship game. </P> <P>Brock Pulock was in a car with three relatives and a friend when it rolled about five kilometres south of Minnedosa. </P> <P>The Grade 7 student and team captain of the peewee Grand Plains Hawks was known for leading others, like when he shaved his head for cancer research. </P> <P>"It's devastating," said Darren Grasby, a friend who was helping the family Monday at their home in Grandview, north of Riding Mountain National Park. </P> <P>Police said that around 1 p.m. Sunday, a 2004 Ford Explorer was heading south on Highway 10 near Minnedosa when the driver lost control and it went into a ditch. Police said two teenage boys were thrown from the car, and that they may not have been wearing seatbelts. They were taken to Health Sciences Centre in Winnipeg, where Brock died early Monday. </P> <P>The other teenager was in stable condition with non-life-threatening injuries, said police. The driver and front passenger were not injured, and a third teenager was treated and released at hospital. </P> <P>Police said alcohol and speed were not factors. </P> <P>The boy's mother, Tannis Pulock, is principal of Grandview School, said residents. </P> <P>Grasby said Brock, a tall boy with a gentle touch, was admired for being kind to others. </P> <P>Residents said the family is well-known in the community for the three hockey-playing brothers. </P> <P>Derrick Pulock and Ryan Pulock play for the Grandview Comets, and Ryan was recently drafted by the Brandon Wheat Kings.</P>

--30--

Title: 17-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Bus driver remembers little of fatal crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: CBC.CA News   Mon Mar 29 2010, 7:06pm ET   Section: Canada
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The woman who was driving a school bus that crashed in 2007, killing a Calgary girl on board, says she remembers what she had for breakfast that day, but nothing of the collision itself. </P> <P>Kathelynn Occena, 9, was killed when the bus careened onto the shoulder of Crowchild Trail on Oct. 18, 2007, smashing into a gravel truck and then hitting a light pole. Eleven other children on the 30-passenger bus suffered mostly minor injuries and were taken to hospital. </P> <P>Testifying Monday at a provincial inquiry into the crash, bus driver Louise Rogers outlined the personal turmoil she was going through in the months before the fatal incident. </P> <P>In 2007, Rogers temporarily separated from her husband and was living with another man. She had converted to Islam and had begun wearing a hijab head-covering. </P> <P>She said her history of mental illness had sent her to hospital several times. She went on stress leave in the spring but in September 2007, she tried to kill herself by overdosing on pills. </P> <P>That same fall, Rogers, 42, said she was taking antidepressants and sleeping pills, prescribed by her family doctor. </P> <P>The bus driver said the Third Academy, her employer, was aware of her personal problems. She visited regularly with the school's psychologist ? at her manager, Arlene Waldner's suggestion ? to talk about her personal issues. </P> <P>Rogers testified she took the prescribed amount of medication the night before the crash, and she woke up the next morning in a good mood. But while Rogers remembered that she ate toast for breakfast that morning, the memories of the crash itself are a blank, she testified. </P> <P>The bus was taking children to two private schools in Calgary's southwest that day. Occena and her sister were the last two passengers onboard before the bus turned onto Crowchild Trail. </P> <P>Rogers admitted it was possible that she dozed off. She said she can't remember if she made any evasive manoeuvres or even hit the brakes after the bus hit the parked truck, which had pulled over because of mechanical problems. </P> <P>"I remember I didn't know what I hit," she said. "I kept going and hit a pole and I was like, oh my god, what did I do?" </P> <P>Was listening to iPod </P> <P>The driver conceded she was listening to an iPod at the time, but insisted only one of the digital media player's ear buds was tucked into her head scarf. </P> <P>She denied using a cellphone before the crash, but admitted she had answered the phone in the past while driving. </P> <P>Rogers pleaded guilty in September 2008 to a single charge of careless driving under the Traffic Safety Act. She was fined $2,300 ? the maximum penalty allowed ? and her driver's licence was suspended for 90 days. </P> <P>Rogers is currently unemployed. She worked as a lunchroom supervisor at another school before becoming a school bus driver in 2004. </P> <P>The provincial fatality inquiry is not intended to assess blame but is looking at training and bus safety in this case after the accident raised concerns about the standards and qualifications of school bus drivers. </P>

--30--

Title: 18-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Unbuckled crashes causing more deaths in '10
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Mounties are hoping a rise so far this year in the percentage of victims of fatal road accidents not wearing seatbelts does not represent an upward trend. </P> <P>So far in 2010, RCMP said eight of 13 or 62% of people involved in fatal collisions in areas under their jurisdiction were not wearing seatbelts or helmets, which is up from recent years. Last year, 47% of those who died in road accidents weren't buckled up or properly protected. The percentage has gone up over recent years, from 37% in 2006 to 38% the following year and up to 39% in 2008. </P> <P>"It's a spike that we don't appreciate seeing and there's no logical reason for it," said RCMP traffic services Sgt. Wayne Blackmore. "Maybe we're just unlucky and it's going to settle out and come back down around 40% for the rest of the year. I hope it's not going to be the trend for the summer." </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said a Transport Canada survey in 2007 that showed 90% of Manitobans were consistently buckling up, but in rural parts of the province the percentage declines to 87%. </P> <P>"If you're not wearing a seatbelt, you're 25 times more likely to be killed in a collision," Smiley said. "It takes one second to do a seatbelt up to prevent a lifetime of grief." </P> <P>Young people also make up a large percentage of those not wearing seatbelts, RCMP said. </P> <P>"I'd like to see 100% of people buckling up," Blackmore said. "People just don't think something is going to happen to them." </P> <P>Seatbelts have been mandatory since 1984. There is a fine of $278 and penalty of two demerits for not wearing a seatbelt. </P> <P><A href="mailto:jason.halstead@sunmedia.ca">jason.halstead@sunmedia.ca</A> </P> <P>"There's a bit of a misnomer out there that the airbag will protect everything," Smiley said. "In fact, the airbag is the secondary occupant safety device. The seatbelt is primary." </P>

--30--

Title: 19-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba Public Insurance; Manitoba's teen drivers highly endorse the Driver Education Program
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Wed Mar 31 2010   Page: 5   Section: News   Source: Souris Plaindealer
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Nine of 10 driver education students say the course helped them to be a more careful driver, according to a survey conducted by Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>The telephone survey polled driver education students and their parents about the program they had recently completed. The survey was conducted last November and reported the following: </P> <P>- More than nine in 10 teen drivers agree that the Driver Education Course is valuable training for new drivers and would recommend the course to their friends. </P> <P>- More than eight in 10 agree that young drivers who take the course are more skilled than young drivers who do not take the course. </P> <P>- More than half agree that if they had not taken the course, they would have had more accidents by now. </P> <P>"Driver experience and providing a solid base of safety are key components to properly preparing our teen drivers," said Lou Gervino, Manager of Driver Education and Training with Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>"This survey confirms that our program is accomplishing its goals and objectives both in the classroom and within the car. The Driver Education Program incorporates best practices from other jurisdictions and continuously reviews the pro -gram." </P> <P>The High School Driver Education (HSDE) program has existed since 1966 and has been administered by Manitoba Public Insurance since 1987 with the support of partner organizations and Manitoba high schools. The program is designed to raise awareness in young drivers of road safety issues and teach them the appropriate skills for driving on Manitoba roads. </P> <P>All full-time Manitoba high school students over the age of 15 are eligible to attend the program, explained Gervino. Students receive 34 hours of in-class instruction, eight hours of behind-the-wheel training and eight hours of in-car observation. </P> <P>Every year over 12,000 Manitoba high school students participate in the program which is offered in 150 high schools across the province. </P> <P>"Overall, youth have a high regard for the benefits and outcomes associated with the HSDE Program," said Gervino. "The survey also confirmed that adults have a high degree of awareness of the program and share a high regard for the benefits and outcomes associated with it." </P> <P>Some of the adult responses were: </P> <P>- Nine in 10 adults agree that the program is valuable training for new drivers and that they would recommend the driver education course to their friends and the program helps students be more careful drivers. </P> <P>- More than eight in 10 adults agree that young drivers who take the course are more skilled than young drivers who do not take the course. </P> <P>"A key component of the Driver Education Program is parental involvement and assisting the young driver to gain driver experience," said Gervino. "The Driver Education Program is continuously evolving to mirror the challenges which drivers face on a daily basis." </P>

--30--

Title: 21-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RCMP officer injured in MVA
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>East St. Paul R.C.M.P. are investigating a police - motor vehicle accident late Tuesday afternoon on Henderson Highway in the R-M of East St. Paul. </P> <P>An R.C.M.P. vehicle was traveling north on Henderson, responding to a call for service, when the police vehicle struck another vehicle traveling north bound from behind.    The incident happened around 5:30 pm.</P> <P>The police officer and the driver of the second vehicle were both taken to hospital, treated for their injuries and later released.</P> <P>The accident caused a major traffic back-up on northbound Henderson into the early evening.</P>

--30--

Title: 22-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Lack of driving instructor cause of concern
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: By PAUL RAYNER  Boissevain Recorder  March 27, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Hopes are that the lack of a driving instructor for Boissevain students will be a temporary problem and not a long term one.</P> <P>When long-time driving instructor Marlene Reimer moved to Winnipeg in January, this left a hole in the drivers’ education program in the community. Manitoba Public Insurance advertised for an instructor for Boissevain/Deloraine last October, but to no avail. This meant the young driving students this spring had to look elsewhere to learn the rules of the road.</P> <P>Judy Adams, whose son Bryce is in the program for the spring session, said it was a difficult and confusing situation initially. She said normally the drivers ed program would work through the school, where the classes would be held. Without an instructor, they had to find a program in the area.</P> <P>“It took a few phone calls to find out where to go,” Adams explained. “I guess some people knew Marlene was leaving and did some phoning and we phoned Autopac in Brandon to confirm things. Some of the kids went to Killarney and some to Deloraine.”</P> <P>At least six of the kids joined the Adams in the program in Deloraine. They were able to hold the classes there as an instructor from Virden was willing to come out to the Highway 3 community if they had 16 students, which they obviously were able to enroll. The classes started on March 17. Not having an instructor in Boissevain does cause some obvious problems. There are 34 hours of class time to learn rules of the road students have to go through, which translates into 12 classes to the end of April – two nights a week excepting spring break. This means a fair bit of travel for parents.</P> <P>As well, there are driving lessons themselves. Each student has to put in eight hours behind the wheel with the instructor, and eight hours of observation. This too will be done in Deloraine, which leads to more travel.</P> <P>Adams said they are lucky so far, as there are enough parents to share some of the driving load. However, once the actual driving part starts up, there is no guarantee the Boissevain kids will have the same schedule.</P> <P>“We don’t know who is paired up with who, for driving and observation. Hopefully, they will pair kids up from Boissevain together, to help us out.”</P> <P>There have been other changes to the drivers’ education and licensing programs over the recent past. Now, for example, a greater degree of identification is needed to receive a license than before. According to an MPI pamphlet, there is a need to establish different elements – a person’s birth date, three parts of identity (legal name, signature, photograph), Manitoba residency and permanent address, and entitlement to be in Canada. Brian Clark of Clark Agencies, and Autopac Agent in Boissevain, said the greater focus on identification comes from a famous incident almost a decade ago.</P> <P>“The ID, that’s 9/11,” Clark explained, saying these moves came into being more than a year ago.” There is a lot more ID required to meet worldwide demand for security. In this day and age, when we go airplanes, we want more security. It is just the way things go.”</P> <P>However, the bewildering array of needs can be staggering. Birth certificates, health cards, study permits etc. might not all be required, but can all play a role in establishing identity. As Clark stated, different people have different struggles. For example, women can have extra burdens because of marriage, as they have to establish the married name. For students, sometimes establishing residence can be difficult. Many documents used for this, like utility bills, income tax statements, or mortgage documents, are just not items young people have. Others, like guarantor declaration forms, where authority figures sign to where the student’s residence is, are more likely bets. The fact that two residency documents are required does not make it any easier.</P> <P>“It can be an awkward and very frustrating situation when someone comes into our office. We help collect it and it goes to the identity unit in Winnipeg. If it is not nice and tidy it comes back to us.”</P> <P>Adams added that they need a log of 24 hours additional driving with a parent over nine months after getting their learner’s permit to get their full license.</P> <P>One area of concern for Clark has been the recent moves to centralize testing. For example, as of March 1, the knowledge testing, or written test for learner’s permit, has been centralized in Brandon, although arrangements can be made to do it in a few other communities, the closest being Killarney. This is a difficult situation on many levels, he said.</P> <P>“There are some significant changes as far as testing is concerned,” he explained. “The closest you can go is Killarney now. They used to do that in Boissevain, but now anyone wanting to take a written test has to go to Killarney or Brandon. This is when we are supposed to be going green. To me, it’s just another erosion of services.”</P> <P>Although there are still driving tests in Boissevain, Class 1 is no longer offered in the community, it being also centralized in Brandon. Over the years, Clark said there has been a continuing move out of town, with the tests, both written and practical, once available weekly. Now they are down to once a month.</P> <P>Adams said some of the kids in the spring class will be able to write their learner’s test in the classroom on April 13, if they are 15 ½ at that time. If not, they will have to go where the test is.</P> <P>She added that the instructor said the kids would be taken to a driving trip in Brandon, a usual rite of the program, but only if they are ready, which she thought was a good policy. However, there is the background fear that eventually, if driver ed is centralized in the Wheat City, learning to drive there could be the norm.</P> <P>“If the program was not in Deloraine or Killarney,” Adams explained, “maybe people would have to go to Brandon, and the kids would be forced to learn to drive in Brandon, which I’m not sure is a good thing.”</P> <P>Both Clark and Adams praised Reimer for her dedication. She started teaching driving in Boissevain in 2001, and by her count, had over 700 students by the time she left, both here and in Deloraine. Reimer said she started because there was no instructor at that time her son was learning to drive, and kept at it as it turned out to be a good fit.</P> <P>She could set her own time schedule and she enjoyed teaching teenagers. Although she started with MPI vehicles, by 2008 she had bought her own, which enabled her to take kids for a few gravel road lessons and take older, private clients. She also would take kids privately for refreshers before their driving test. She said she was a little disappointed when someone did not take over locally.</P> <P>“I thought someone would pick it up,” Reimer said, “I enjoyed it so much, I didn’t realize no one would do it. I had people meet me on the street and say ‘you can’t go’. I hope someone takes it over.”</P> <P>According to MPI, they are still taking applications for a Boissevain/Deloraine driving instructor. Anyone interested can go to the MPI web site at <A href="http://www.mpi.mb.ca">www.mpi.mb.ca</A>, check out the career section and go from there. Both Adams and Clark hope an instructor can be found to bring drivers education back to Boissevain.</P> <P>“Definitely, we don’t want to see this go out of town,” Adams stated. “For the kids’ sake and the parents, it is important to bring this back.”</P> <P>“If we’re adequately going to teach them to be good drivers,” Clark added, “they need some training. I think it’s vitally important to have it here and not have them have to go to another community for this.”</P>

--30--

Title: 23-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Take your keys out!
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Keep keys out of vehicle: Manitoba Public Insurance  Southern Manitoba Review  April 1, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Nearly 300 immobilizer-equipped vehicles were stolen last year in Manitoba because the keys were left in either the ignition or elsewhere in the passenger compartment, according to Manitoba Public Insurance claims data. </P> <P>These immobilized vehicles were stolen after the owners had left their keys in the ignition, or left a running vehicle unattended, or stored keys within the glove box, console or under the floor mats. Approved immobilizers are automatically activated once the key is removed from the ignition. When the ignition or steering column is attacked by an auto thief the immobilizer automatically shuts down the vehicle’s ignition, electrical and fuel systems, rendering the vehicle unmovable.</P> <P>According to Manitoba Public Insurance data, auto theft in 2009 continued to decline with 919 fewer vehicles stolen in Winnipeg while 121 fewer vehicles were stolen in rural Manitoba.</P>

--30--

Title: 24-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Mounties rear-end vehicle
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>No one was seriously injured when an RCMP cruiser rear-ended a civilian vehicle just north of Winnipeg on Wednesday, police say. </P> <P>The crash occurred on Henderson Highway in the Rural Municipality of East St. Paul about 5:30 p.m. </P> <P>An East St. Paul RCMP cruiser was northbound responding to a call for service when it struck a northbound vehicle from behind, RCMP said. </P> <P>The police officer and driver of the second vehicle were taken to hospital and later released, RCMP said. </P> <P>RCMP continue to investigate. No charges have been laid. </P>

--30--

Title: 25-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: School didn't alter policy after bus crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: CBC.CA News   Wed Mar 31 2010, 7:50pm ET   Section: Canada
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Calgary charter school has made no major changes to its transportation policies or system of evaluating school bus drivers since one of its buses crashed in 2007, killing a girl on board. </P> <P>Kathelynn Occena, 9, was killed when her school bus veered onto the shoulder of Crowchild Trial and sideswiped a gravel truck that had pulled over because of a mechanical problem. The bus, with one side sheared off, then slammed into a light pole. </P> <P>Eleven other children on the bus were taken to hospital. </P> <P>Arlene Waldner, transportation manager of the Third Academy, on Wednesday told a provincial inquiry into the incident that the school is holding the same kind of safety meetings and annual evaluations that were in place before the crash. Assessments include a self-evaluation by the driver and peer evaluation by colleagues. </P> <P>Waldner acknowledged there have been no major changes to how bus drivers are evaluated since the crash. </P> <P>Waldner told the inquiry she was aware that Louise Rogers, 42, the bus driver, was going through personal problems and taking sleeping pills in the months before the crash, but didn't think it would affect her driving. </P> <P>"She was emotional, and her home life was deteriorating," said Waldner, who said she had a close relationship with Rogers. "She had mentioned to me one day that she was on sleeping pills and she needed to take them before 7 p.m. or she wasn't able to drive." </P> <P>On Monday, Rogers testified that she remembered little of the crash itself and admitted she may have dozed off beforehand. She also talked about a failing marriage and other problems in her life that required several hospital visits. </P> <P>Rogers took one week of stress leave in May 2007, on the school psychologist's recommendation, then returned to work. </P> <P>A month before the crash, Rogers said she tried to kill herself by overdosing on pills, which Waldner said she wasn't aware of. Waldner said she thought Rogers had gone to the hospital because she had been assaulted by a one-time boyfriend. </P> <P>Waldner testified the school has no new policy regarding drivers with mental health issues, but if someone goes on stress leave, a doctor's note is now required stating he or she is OK to return to work. </P> <P>The fatality inquiry is probing training and bus safety in this case to prevent similar future incidents, but it cannot assign blame. </P> <P>The inquiry has heard from at least three witnesses who said they complained to the school about seeing Rogers speeding, running a red light and talking on her cellphone while driving. </P> <P>School ticketed after safety audit </P> <P>Waldner said she knew Rogers sometimes listened to an iPod while driving the bus. </P> <P>"We have radios on our buses, and I would prefer they listen to that. But we don't have a policy on that," Waldner said. </P> <P>Waldner, who hired Rogers in 2004, acknowledged she received a complaint from one driver on the road who encountered Rogers, as well as from a teacher and students who rode the bus. </P> <P>She said she told Rogers to stop using her cellphone while driving. </P> <P>Alberta Transportation issued three tickets to the school as a result of a safety audit of the Third Academy's bus system after the crash. Violations included not having the driver's documents on file. </P>

--30--

Title: 26-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI immobilizer warranties criticized
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Monday, April 5, 2010 | 5:42 PM CT CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Bev Owens says she paid $560 to replace an MPI-approved immobilizer in her vehicle just about 2 years after it was installed. (CBC)</P> <P>A Winnipeg woman is accusing Manitoba Public Insurance of being deceptive for failing to warn motorists about the duration of warranties on mandatory immobilizing devices installed in vehicles.</P> <P>Under Manitoba law, many vehicles must have an MPI–approved immobilizer installed as part of the province's crackdown on auto theft.</P> <P>But Bev Owens said the Crown corporation failed her by not telling her the device only has a two-year warranty.</P> <P>A little over a week ago, Owens said her car had to be towed because the immobilizer broke and couldn't be started.</P> <P>Because her warranty for the device has expired, she was forced to pay $560 to have it replaced so her car would start up again. She said if the public insurer demands that some drivers have the devices, then they should have longer trouble-free warranties.</P> <P>"It shouldn't just be two years because this is a mandatory thing that we have to do," Owens said. "I think the price should be lowered a little bit. So make a three to five-year warranty," she said.</P> <P>She said no one she's talked to ever realized the immobilizers only have two-year, and not longer, warranties.</P> <P>"I was disappointed because I had other plans for that money … that buys a lot of gas, that buys groceries," Owens said.</P> <P>MPI's offices were closed for the Easter Monday holiday and were unavailable to comment.</P> <P>However, the corporation's website said that 99 per cent of customers have no problems, and the remaining one per cent can take their complaints to the Immobilizer Quality Care Group (IQCG) — an independent agency — to help resolve their issue.</P> <P>The website does not appear to mention the terms or length of warranties for immobilizers.</P> <P>The IQCG can be reached at 1-888-662-6033.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/05/man-mpi-immobilizer-warranty.html#ixzz0kKH7N80J">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/05/man-mpi-immobilizer-warranty.html#ixzz0kKH7N80J</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Slow And Easy The Key To Safe Spring Driving
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Sentinel Courier, Pilot Mound, MB   Tuesday, April 6, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Spring in Manitoba can mean wet, slippery roads. And wet, slippery roads can lead to dangerous driving conditions.</P> <P>“Thousands of collisions and many injuries happen every year because drivers don’t adjust their driving to the road conditions,” said Clif Eden, manager of road safety programming for Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>“Most of these collisions and injuries are completely preventable.”</P> <P>In wet conditions, the average stopping distance for most automobiles is twice what it is on a dry road. Throw in poor visibility caused by a dirty windshield or bad weather and stopping distance can be even greater.</P> <P>To stay safe and avoid a collision, special precautions are needed. Here are some spring driving tips that will help to keep you and your family safe:</P> <P>•Slow down and leave extra distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you. It takes longer to stop or adjust on wet, dirty roads. In particular, don’t follow large trucks or buses closely. The spray from their wheels will dirty your windshield and reduce your visibility.</P> <P>•Replace old or brittle windshield wipers. Worn wipers won’t clear water and grit from your windshield, causing streaking and smearing that could dangerously obstruct your view.</P> <P>•Make sure your running lights or headlights are on when driving on dark, overcast, foggy days.</P> <P>•Stay in the middle lanes as much as possible. Water tends to pool in the curb lanes.</P> <P>•Avoid puddles by driving around them or taking a different route. If you have to drive through standing water on a road and you don’t know how deep it is or what’s underneath, go slow. If it’s deeper than the bottom of your doors, turn around and find another route. Deep water can ruin your car’s electrical system, and an unseen pothole or obstruction can cause hundreds, even thousands of dollars in damage to your car.</P> <P>•After driving through water, your brakes can lose some of their stopping power. When traffic allows, pump your brakes lightly a few times to dry the brake linings.</P> <P>•Please don’t splash pedestrians. Being splashed with a wave of cold, dirty water isn’t much fun.</P> <P>Eden added, “As the old saying goes, ‘it’s not rocket science.’ To stay safe when road conditions aren’t the greatest, slow down and take some extra precautions. It could prevent a collision or something far worse.”</P> <P>For more information on safe driving, visit <A href="http://www.mpi.mb.ca">www.mpi.mb.ca</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RCMP remind motorists to always wear seatbelts
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: JASON HALSTEAD QMI Agency The Central Plains Herald-Leader  April 3, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Mounties are hoping a rise so far this year in the percentage of victims of fatal road accidents not wearing seatbelts does not represent an upward trend.</P> <P>So far in 2010, RCMP said eight of 13 or 62% of people involved in fatal collisions in areas under their jurisdiction were not wearing seatbelts or helmets, which is up on recent years. Last year, 47% of those who died in road accidents weren’t buckled up or properly protected. The percentage has gone up over recent years, from 37% in 2006 to 38% the following year and up to 39% in 2008.</P> <P>“It’s a spike that we don’t appreciate seeing and there’s no logical reason for it,” said RCMP Traffic Services Sgt. Wayne Blackmore. “Maybe we’re just unlucky and it’s going to settle out and come back down around 40% for the rest of the year. I hope it’s not going to be the trend for the summer.”</P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said a Transport Canada survey in 2007 that showed 90% of Manitobans were consistently buckling up, but in rural parts of the province the percentage declines to 87%.</P> <P>“If you’re not wearing a seatbelt, you’re 25 times more likely to be killed in a collision,” Smiley said. “It takes one second to do a seatbelt up to prevent a lifetime of grief.” </P> <P>Young people also make up a large percentage of those not wearing seatbelts, RCMP said.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Jun-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Two cents a mile
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: BY LORRAINE STEVENSON  Co-operator staff April 1, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The dilemma facing those who want to continue living rurally, while reducing their transportation footprint, has been much on Homewood-area resident Rob McClement's mind. His family, which includes a trio of teenagers, can make several trips per day to nearby Carman, a round trip of about 35 km.</P> <P>A do-it-yourselfer by nature, (McClement is owner of R-Tech Industries Ltd. at Homewood, a company custom building agricultural research equipment), he decided to fix their too-much-driving problem himself—by building his own zero-emissions battery-operated electric car.</P> <P>He was inspired to try several years ago.</P> <P>"Three and a half years ago, I first saw the Chris Paine documentary, 'Who Killed the Electric Car?'" said McClement. The film tells the story of the late-1990s limited commercialization and subsequent destruction of a General Motors battery-powered electric vehicle, the EVl. The film impressed him so much, McClement now jokingly calls viewing it the beginning of his "conversion experience.</P> <P>"That was the beginning of this project for me," he says. "Once realizing there was a credible alternative to gas, I began doing research on electric vehicles, particularly conversions."</P> <P>What that's resulted in is his 1996 Mazda Miata, sans tailpipe and gas cap, initially purchased second-hand and now run entirely on batteries.</P> <P>It represents about 500 hours of McClement's time, spent over about a year and a half, plus thousands of Internet-based parts searches and online chats with fellow do-it-yourselfers.</P> <P>So he wouldn't have to figure everything out himself, McClement signed on to <A href="http://www.diyelectriccar.com">www.diyelectriccar.com</A>, a popular online forum for others converting cars, trucks and motorcycles around the world.</P> <P>The Internet helped him find supplier networks for parts. The batteries were purchased from a distributor in Washington state but were shipped directly from China. The majority of the components came from California. The motor came from an American company in Illinois.</P> <P>The final price tag: around $17,000 for the parts, plus an outlay of $5,000 to buy the Miata.</P> <P>"It may seem like a lot," says McClement. "But I now have a very efficient, non-polluting and fun little sports car."</P> <P>Efficient, indeed. He's tallied the cost to operate it, based on cost of a kilowatt hour to charge the vehicle, at about two cents per mile for energy cost (one-sixth or less that of gas).</P> <P>That's like paying 20 cents for a litre of gas.</P> <P>“And the more this car is driven in place of our gas vehicles, the more it pays for itself."</P> <P>On one charge<BR>The McClement family can't use the sporty two-seater as its primary vehicle; the family has a gas car and a diesel truck for longer trips. But with a range of 130 km between charges, the Miata is what they'll now use for those multiple trips to Carman, and to points in Winnipeg, says McClement.</P> <P>"We should be able to make three to four round trips to town on a single charge, then charge up overnight."</P> <P>Those interested in trying this themselves take note: any car, truck or motorcycle can be converted. McClement chose the Miata because he appreciated the design and the relative efficiency of it in its previous life as a gas-powered car.</P> <P>"The best advice I've been given about choosing a vehicle to convert is to choose a vehicle that you will want to drive," he said."</P> <P>Costs and time for other conversions needn't go nearly as high as McClement's did either.</P> <P>Costs can vary hugely, anywhere from $3,000 to $30,000, he's learned from hi s fellow online do-it-yourselfers. It boils down to the more spent, the better performance and longer range you get.</P> <P>As for choosing a vehicle to convert, generally, light and aerodynamic cars are better candidates than large and heavy cars or trucks.</P> <P>"It all comes down to the energy required to move the vehicle. Large vehicles can be converted but require a larger electric motor and controller and much more expensive batteries for significant range."</P> <P>McClement hopes his "green" red car will spur more to think about the multiple advantages of driving EVs. Their motors are simpler and more durable than gas engines, and so require much less maintenance. They can be built to go fast. And they're as quiet as they are clean in the environment.</P> <P>“At lower speeds, an EV is not much louder than a bicycle," he said.</P> <P>Admittedly, range before requiring a recharge will be an issue depending on where you live. But he points out a typical range for a well -built electric car is between 80 and 160 km.</P> <P>“And most people drive less than 60 km each day."</P> <P>McClement can list plenty of reasons why an electric car is a good fit for his family's lifestyle. He can list off plenty more why he thinks adopting cleaner energy sources - the sooner the better -- is imperative.</P> <P>"Fossil fuels are a very finite resource that we have been burning through at an alarming rate," he said. "Oil will not last forever, likely only for a few more decades. And while we burn oil for personal transportation, we are damaging the environment."</P> <P>Meanwhile, EVs are functional and feasible right now, not for all situations, but for a significant portion of most people's daily driving.</P> <P>"If individuals like me can convert a gas vehicle to clean and efficient electricity, the big players in the auto industry certainly can and should," he said.</P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance officials estimate there are fewer than a dozen pure electric cars registered in Manitoba right now. There are about 2,500 hybrids currently licensed.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man dies in rollover
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 28-year-old man is dead after the car he was a passenger in rolled over on Route 90 after fleeing from a police traffic stop. </P> <P>Winnipeg police said the incident began just after 4 a.m. Sunday when a cruiser pulled over the northbound car -- a white, older model Chevrolet Malibu -- on Kenaston Boulevard near Academy Road. As a police officer approached the vehicle -- with the 24-year-old female driver and 28-year-old male passenger inside -- it sped away north, crossing the St. James Bridge. </P> <P>Police followed and the car was found a short time later near the intersection of Century Street and Silver Avenue, where it had rolled over. </P> <P>The male passenger was taken to hospital in critical condition, where he later died. The vehicle's driver was taken to hospital in unstable condition, but her injuries are not considered life-threatening, police said. </P> <P>"It does appear the vehicle lost control and actually rolled over several times, landing on its roof," said Winnipeg Police Service spokeswoman Const. Jacqueline Chaput. "I am of the understanding that one person was ejected from the vehicle but it's unclear to me right now whether it was the driver or the passenger." </P> <P>Police did not release the name of the man killed Sunday and said they did not know how the driver and passenger were acquainted with one another. Family members told media the man's name was Jerome Bender. </P> <P>Chaput said it was not known Sunday why the driver fled the traffic stop. </P> <P>"If you're stopped by police for any reason, comply with police officers," she said. "This could have easily been averted had the driver not fled." </P> <P>The vehicle remained on its roof on the west boulevard of Route 90 until late afternoon Sunday as the central traffic unit kept the area closed to traffic while the investigation continued. </P> <P>High rate of speed </P> <P>Officers took measurements and marked evidence on the ground around the badly damaged sedan. At least 40 evidence markers were placed at the scene. </P> <P>Police said Sunday that a high rate of speed was a factor in the rollover, but are still investigating whether drugs or alcohol played a part. </P> <P>No charges have been laid in relation to the incident. </P> <P>The vehicle had not been stolen, police said. </P> <P><A href="mailto:jason.halstead@sunmedia.ca">jason.halstead@sunmedia.ca</A> </P> <P>Passenger in vehicle that fled cop traffic stop <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 2-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car rolls over, passenger dead
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Mon Apr 5 2010 Page: A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 28-year-old man died early Sunday morning after the car in which he was a passenger rolled several times on Route 90 near St. Matthews Avenue. </P> <P>The driver of the car, a 24-year-old woman, is in hospital in stable condition. </P> <P>Winnipeg police said the rollover happened shortly after 4 a.m. </P> <P>The car was originally pulled over for a traffic stop on Kenaston Boulevard near Academy Road. </P> <P>Const. Jacqueline Chaput said that while the officer was walking towards the car, it sped up, going north on Kenaston. </P> <P>The woman lost control of the car, a white, late-model Malibu, and it rolled several times. </P> <P>The man was taken to hospital in critical condition and he died a short time later. </P> <P>Chaput said it's not known why the driver sped off. </P> <P>The intersection was closed for several hours while police traffic accident analysts investigated. </P> <P>"It's clear at this point that there was excessive speed and speed was a factor," Chaput said, noting the car was not stolen. </P> <P>It wasn't known Sunday if alcohol consumption was a contributing factor. </P> <P>Chaput said she could not confirm that the car was being chased by police before the driver lost control. </P> <P>The dead man's name was not released, but friends identified him as Jerome Bender. </P>

--30--

NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press Sun Apr 4 2010 Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ A 28-year-old man has died after the car in which he was a passenger rolled several times on Route 90 near St. Matthews Avenue. </P> <P>The driver of the car, a 24-year-old woman, is in hospital in stable condition. </P> <P>Winnipeg police said the rollover happened shortly after 4 a.m. </P> <P>The car was originally pulled over for a traffic stop but Const.
