Title: 4-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Charges pending in fatal rollover
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Tue Apr 6 2010 Page: A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>POLICE may lay criminal charges after a 24-year-old driver tried to flee police and flipped her friend's car. </P> <P>Jerome Bender, 28, the owner of a Chevrolet Malibu involved in the dramatic crash around 4 a.m. Sunday, was killed. </P> <P>Sources say Ashley Dineen Klingzahn was driving the vehicle when it flipped. The car had originally been pulled over for a traffic stop on Kenaston Boulevard near Academy Road. While an officer was walking towards the car, it sped north on Kenaston and, after travelling about two kilometres, it rolled several times near the intersection of Route 90 and St. Matthews Avenue. </P> <P>Klingzahn and Bender had dated, but it's unclear if they currently were. </P> <P>Friends describe Bender as a French-speaking man of small stature. </P> <P>Jerome Bender's father, Norbert Bender, said his son was a "very nice" person. He said Monday he was still making plans for the young man's funeral. </P> <P>Police did not release the names of the people in the Malibu. </P> <P>"Charges aren't always instant," said Winnipeg Police Service spokeswoman Const. Jackie Chaput. "(Officers) have to complete their thorough investigation before they can proceed with charges." </P> <P>Klingzahn remained at the Health Sciences Centre Monday. </P> <P>She is a Winnipeg woman who lists herself as a former student of St. Mary's Academy on an online profile. </P> <P>In an online photo, she is shown blowing a kiss at a camera. </P> <P>Serena Etches, a friend of Bender's, said he'll be sorely missed. </P> <P>"Jerome was a very special person, he was so polite and caring," she said. </P> <P>Bender did not have any children, said friends. </P> <P>The Central Traffic Unit continues to investigate the crash. Police said the car was speeding. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: $50,000 tab for MPI to fix high-tech goof
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed Apr 7 2010   Page: A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>MPI is facing a $50,000 tab to fix new, high-tech drivers' licences that confuse paramedics with delivery truck drivers. </P> <P>The trouble stems from a little chart on the back of the new, one-piece licence that Manitoba Public Insurance has begun to mail out to drivers. The chart lists each of the six licence classes and the type of vehicle a licence- holder can drive in each class. </P> <P>The trouble is that on about 20,000 of the new plastic cards, Manitoba Public Insurance transposed the icon representing ambulances with the one representing delivery trucks. It appears as though an ambulance driver now needs a more rigorous Class Four licence, the one required to drive two-axle trucks like dump trucks and delivery trucks. </P> <P>Paramedics only need a Class Three licence, the same one used for years by most emergency services personnel, including police. </P> <P>Paramedics started noticing the glitch recently and many had a moment of panic thinking the rules had suddenly changed and they were no longer fit to race out to emergencies or transport patients. </P> <P>But Chris Broughton said MPI was quick to explain the glitch and reassure medics who called the customer service line. After that, word got around fire and paramedic halls about the mistake. </P> <P>"Now people are finding it quite humorous," said Broughton, president of the paramedics' local of the Manitoba Government and General Employees' Union. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said the glitch was discovered about two weeks ago by internal quality control staff. </P> <P>"We're not happy about it." </P> <P>But he said the licences are still valid and MPI has alerted police to the error in case any driver gets stopped. </P> <P>Not all of the 20,000 cards have been issued yet, but Smiley said Class Three and Four drivers who did get one will receive a replacement in a matter of days. He noted MPI sends out about 90,000 new licences a month, so the glitch is not massive, considering there are 770,000 drivers in the province. </P> <P>It will cost about $50,000 to print new cards and replace the flawed ones. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Slow and Easy the Key to Safe Spring Driving
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Western Canadian, Manitou, Manitoba  Tuesday, April 6, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Spring in Manitoba can mean wet, slippery roads. And wet, slippery roads can lead to dangerous driving conditions.</P> <P>“Thousands of collisions and many injuries happen every year because drivers don’t adjust their driving to the road conditions,” said Clif Eden, manager of road safety programming for Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>“Most of these collisions and injuries are completely preventable.”</P> <P>In wet conditions, the average stopping distance for most automobiles is twice what it is on a dry road. Throw in poor visibility caused by a dirty windshield or bad weather and stopping distance can be even greater.</P> <P>To stay safe and avoid a collision, special precautions are needed. Here are some spring driving tips that will help to keep you and your family safe:</P> <P>• Slow down and leave extra distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you. It takes longer to stop or adjust on wet, dirty roads. In particular, don’t follow large trucks or busses closely. The spray from their wheels will dirty your windshield and reduce your visibility. </P> <P>• Replace old or brittle windshield wipers. Worn wipers won’t clear water and grit from your windshield, causing streaking and smearing that could dangerously obstruct your view.</P> <P>• Make sure your running lights or headlights are on when driving on dark, overcast, foggy days.</P> <P>• Stay in the middle lanes as much as possible. Water tends to pool in the curb lanes.</P> <P>• Avoid puddles by driving around them or taking a different route. If you have to drive through standing water on a road and you don’t know how deep it is or what’s underneath, go slow. If it’s deeper than the bottom of your doors, turn around and find another route. Deep water can ruin your car’s electrical system, and an unseen pothole or obstruction can cause hundreds, even thousands of dollars in damage to your car.</P> <P>• After driving through water, your brakes can lose some of their stopping power. When traffic allows, pump your brakes lightly a few times to dry the brake linings.</P> <P>• Please don’t splash pedestrians. Being splashed with a wave of cold, dirty water isn’t much fun.</P> <P>Eden added, “As the old saying goes, ‘it’s not rocket science.’ To stay safe when road conditions aren’t the greatest, slow down and take some extra precautions. It could prevent a collision or something far worse.”</P> <P>For more information on safe driving, visit <A href="http://www.mpi.mb.ca">www.mpi.mb.ca</A></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Most stolen vehicles in Canada
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Insurance Bureau of Canada has released its latest list of the most stolen vehicles in Canada, and Vice President of Investigations Rick Dubin says that thieves typically look for "a car that's easy to steal, with no approved anti-theft electronic immobilizer" or "newer, high-end vehicles ... (that) are harder to steal (but) can make a strong profit". This list certainly proves that:</P> <P>10 - 2005 Cadillac Escalade 4WD<BR>9 - 2006 Hummer H2 AWD<BR>8 - 2000 Audi S4 Quattro 4-door<BR>7 - 1997 Mitsubishi Eclipse Spyder<BR>6 - 2005 Cadillac Escalade ESV AWD<BR>5 - 2002 Cadillac Escalade EXT AWD<BR>4 - 2006 Chevrolet/GMC Trailblazer SS 4WD<BR>3 - 1999 Honda Civic SiR 2-door<BR>2 - 2003 Cadillac Escalade ESV AWD<BR>1 - 2000 Honda Civic SiR 2-door</P>

Title: 8-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Drunk driver crashed into cop car: police
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Thu Apr 8 2010   Page: 16   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Portage la Prairie man is facing charges after he allegedly crashed into a police car while drunk in Altona on the weekend. </P> <P>If not for the police cruiser being in the way, the incident may have had disastrous results, said Altona Police Service Chief Perry Batchelor. </P> <P>"Had the (police) vehicle not been struck, the (suspect's) vehicle would have gone into a crowd of people," Batchelor said. </P> <P>The incident happened in the Altona Motor Hotel parking lot Sunday at 2:45 a.m., shortly after the hotel bar's closing time. </P> <P>Officers responded to a complaint of loud noise and a crowd of about 30 to 40 people, Batchelor said. </P> <P>Upon arrival, the suspect's vehicle appeared to have jumped a curb stop and struck a building but it suddenly reversed and broadsided the police cruiser, occupied by one officer, on its driver's side, Batchelor said. </P> <P>No one was injured, he said. </P> <P>The suspect drove a short distance but was stopped and arrested. </P> <P>Police administered a breathalyzer test and the male allegedly registered a blood-alcohol level twice the legal limit of .08, Batchelor said. </P> <P>Batchelor said a 20-year-old Portage man faces charges of impaired driving, driving with a blood-alcohol level over .08, dangerous driving and a Highway Traffic Act offence. </P> <P>The police car sustained significant damage and is out of service, he said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RCMP concerned over seatbelt use decline in fatal MVAs
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: By Jason Halstead  The Valley Leader  Friday, April 09, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Mounties are hoping a rise so far this year in the percentage of victims of fatal road accidents not wearing seatbelts does not represent an upward trend.</P> <P>So far in 2010, RCMP said eight of 13 or 62% of people involved in fatal collisions in areas under their jurisdiction were not wearing seatbelts or helmets, which is up on recent years.</P> <P>Last year, 47% of those who died in road accidents weren’t buckled up or properly protected. The percentage has gone up over recent years, from 37% in 2006 to 38% the following year and up to 39% in 2008.</P> <P>“It’s a spike that we don’t appreciate seeing and there’s no logical reason for it,” said RCMP Traffic Services Sgt. Wayne Blackmore. “Maybe we’re just unlucky and it’s going to settle out and come back down around 40% for the rest of the year. I hope it’s not going to be the trend for the summer.”</P> <P>Slight rural drop<BR>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said a Transport Canada survey in 2007 that showed 90% of Manitobans were consistently buckling up, but in rural parts of the province the percentage declines to 87%.</P> <P>“If you’re not wearing a seatbelt, you’re 25 times more likely to be killed in a collision,” Smiley said. “It takes one second to do a seatbelt up to prevent a lifetime of grief.”</P> <P>Young people also make up a large percentage of those not wearing seatbelts, RCMP said.</P> <P>“I’d like to see 100% of people buckling up,” Blackmore said. “People just don’t think something is going to happen to them.” </P> <P>Mandatory use of seatbelts in automobiles was implemented in Manitoba in 1984. There is a fine of $278 and penalty of two demerits for failing to wear a seatbelt, Smiley said.</P> <P>“There’s a bit of a misnomer out there that the airbag will protect everything,” Smiley said. “In fact, the airbag is the secondary occupant safety device. The seatbelt is primary.”</P>

--30--

Title: 11-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Tories want to know where money for more officers went
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri Apr 9 2010   Page: A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Where'd the money go? </P> <P>That's what Progressive Conservative justice critic Kelvin Goertzen wants to know in what the province did with $14.4 million signed over from Ottawa two years ago to hire 30 more police officers on top of what it was already doing to put more cops on the beat. </P> <P>Goertzen said he's been told by law enforcement officials those extra officers haven't been hired. </P> <P>"We could use those officers," the Steinbach MLA said Thursday. "I think the government's reneged on their promises." </P> <P>The money was made available in 2008 under the Harper government's $400- million Police Officers Recruitment Fund, intended to put 2,500 more police officers on the street nationally over the five years. </P> <P>At the time the province accepted the money, then acting Attorney General Gord Mackintosh said it allowed the province to hire 30 new officers above the 100 police positions it wanted to hire. </P> <P>"We'll make sure we can set the best blueline for the buck," Mackintosh said at a news conference alongside senior Manitoba MP and then Treasury Board President Vic Toews and local police officials. </P> <P>Goertzen said the province has only managed to hire 64 officers since the spring of 2008. </P> <P>"They said 130 new officers over the next four years," Goertzen said. "Now it looks like that's not going to happen. Where did they spend the money? It's not where they promised to spend the money." </P> <P>Attorney General Andrew Swan said the province hasn't broken any promises -- it's just spending the $14.4 million wisely. </P> <P>"When the details (of the recruitment fund) came out it became apparent it was time-limited," Swan said, explaining the province only funds new officers on a permanent basis, not temporary. </P> <P>"So we when fund another officer for the city, there is no best-before date at which point the officer disappears," he said. </P> <P>He added since 2008 the province has committed $58,880,000 in additional funding for policing, including money to hire 64 new officers at a cost of about $6 million a year and $1 million for the Winnipeg Police Service's new helicopter unit in 2010. </P> <P>"It's kind of comparing apples and oranges," Swan said. "We're using the federal money. We're adding police officers, and we're going to make those permanent. We're not going to turn around to the city once this five-year period is up, and say, 'Well, we're taking back the police officers; we're cutting back funding.' </P> <P>"Five years is not the career of a police officer. We know it's a long-term commitment." </P> <P>Marc Pellerin, vice-president of the Winnipeg Police Association and spokesman for the Manitoba Police Association, said because of the different ways police officer positions are funded now, it's difficult to track how much money is being spent and by whom on new positions. </P> <P>He said 160 city police officer positions are funded externally, meaning the money comes from provincial coffers, Manitoba Public Insurance or the Winnipeg Airport Authority. </P> <P>"It's a tough puzzle to unclutter," he said, describing the police complements outside the City of Winnipeg as being "fairly static" over the past two years. </P> <P>Pellerin also said the police union believes the Winnipeg Police Service (WPS) needs to hire more officers despite recent comments from officials it's currently over-complement. </P> <P>He said the WPS is 54 officers above the approved complement of 1,348 officers (from chief to constable). </P> <P><A href="mailto:bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca">bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>64 new officers </P> <P>The province says since March 2008 its funded an increase of 64 new permanent police officers: </P> <P>Winnipeg Police Service: 33 </P> <P>RCMP: 24 </P> <P>Brandon Police Service: 4 </P> <P>First Nations policing: 3 </P> <P>Since the NDP came to power in 1999, it's funded 219 new police officers in Manitoba. </P>

--30--

Title: 12-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Youth organizations benefit from Operation Red Nose
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Jim Sexton  THE INTERLAKE SPECTATOR  Friday, April 9, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Completing their fifth annual campaign to keep impaired drivers off the road during the holiday season, members of the Gimli Car Club were pleased to distribute $7,000 to local youth organizations. Receiving support this year were Winnipeg Beach Youth Curling, Winnipeg Beach School Parents Advisory Council, Gimli Skateboard, BMX and Inline Skatepark Committee, Gimli Minor Hockey and Gimli High School Parents Advisory Council.</P> <P>More than 100 Volunteers worked long hours to deliver 166 rides and raise $2,851 in client donations. The number of people out of harm’s way as a direct result of those 166 rides is compounded when you consider most rides had anywhere from two to four passengers added. In addition to the client donations, the local campaign received funds from the provincial pool– funds remaining from provincial corporate donations after expenses. The fund is managed by the Provincial Host, Safety Services Manitoba and the principal donor is Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI), the founding sponsor for Operation Red Nose in Manitoba 15 years ago.</P> <P>The Gimli Car Club reports they were able to pass on the bulk of funds received from the provincial pool as a result of cash donations and donations in kind received from the local business community. There are more than 65 companies that contribute. The Lakeview Resort has been home to Operation Red Nose the past five years and a big thank you goes out to their staff for all their help as well as the RCMP Gimli detachment for their support.</P> <P>The volunteers and sponsors make the program happen and we thank them. We also thank the clients who call in for rides. They're doing the responsible thing and the Gimli Car Club encourages everyone to think Operation Red Nose in December- it can save lives!</P> <P>Starting from modest numbers in 2005, the program has grown each year both in rides provided and donations to local youth organizations. The Gimli Car Club is proud that to report donations from Operation Red Nose in our area now total $20,500.</P>

--30--

Title: 13-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Removing ankle bracelets backfires against car thieves
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri Apr 9 2010   Page: A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>TWO of Winnipeg's worst car thieves thought they'd pulled a fast one by cutting off their electronic ankle bracelets and tossing them from the window of a speeding, stolen car. </P> <P>Turns out the joke was on them -- one of the devices somehow flew into the backseat, without their knowledge, providing police a direct link to their location. </P> <P>"If you even so much as bend one of these bracelets the wrong way, an alert will send," Crown attorney Liz Laite told court Thursday of the December 2009 incident. "In this case, the police knew these two were together, and exactly where they were." </P> <P>Members of the stolen auto unit were able to communicate with the monitoring company, based out of Atlanta, and captured the pair after a dangerous, high- speed chase ended with plenty of damage but no injuries in Elmwood. </P> <P>The 18-year-old passenger of the stolen Ford Fusion pleaded guilty Thursday to several charges stemming from his role in the incident and was given a two- year prison sentence under a joint-recommendation from Crown and defence lawyers. </P> <P>The Free Press is not publishing his name in order to include details about his extensive criminal past as a youth, which would otherwise be protected by law. This incident is his first adult conviction. </P> <P>"He is a danger to society. The public has to be protected from him," said Laite. "You hope at some point the light will go on for him and he will realize this is ridiculous. Otherwise he's going to end up doing a life sentence on the installment plan." </P> <P>The young man has numerous car theft convictions as a teen and is a Level 4 offender, which is the most serious designation given by police. He is a friend of three infamous Winnipeg brothers, who have racked up hundreds of convictions over the years and are deemed among the "worst car thieves in Canada," said Laite. </P> <P>In fact, the 17-year-old brother was allegedly behind the wheel of the Fusion and remains before the courts. Laite said they will be seeking an adult sentence against him if convicted. His older brother is now an adult and serving time at Stony Mountain Institution, while his younger brother has become a regular visitor to the Manitoba Youth Centre. </P> <P>The man, and the alleged driver of the vehicle, began their most recent crime spree by stealing an SUV. They went to a residential neighbourhood and broke into three empty homes. During the final break-in, the pair drove away with the victim's Fusion. </P> <P>They took the car for a spin and slashed their ankle bracelets while in motion, said Laite. Police were alerted and tracked the vehicle to Kenaston Boulevard, where a brief chase ensued. Officers had to call it off when speeds reached 100 km/h, said Laite. </P> <P>Police tracked the vehicle again in the area of North Kildonan. The driver was eventually boxed in by several police cars on Chalmers Avenue. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Ditched ankle monitor, gets jail time
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Fri Apr 9 2010   Page: 20   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An electronic ankle monitor didn't deter Gerren Jeffrey McKay from stealing cars. Maybe prison will. </P> <P>The level 4 car thief was sentenced Thursday to 28 months in prison. </P> <P>McKay, 18, was arrested last December following a high-speed chase in a stolen SUV. </P> <P>Court heard McKay and another level 4 car thief were both sporting ankle monitors when they broke into three homes and stole a Chevrolet Suburban. </P> <P>Police linked the pair's whereabouts to two of the homes where security alarms had been tripped, said Crown attorney Liz Laite. </P> <P>By the time McKay and his partner had cut off their bracelets, police were in pursuit. </P> <P>Police chased the pair along Kenaston Boulevard at speeds reaching 100 km/h. The chase ended after police boxed them in near Chief Peguis Trail.</P>

--30--

Title: 15-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car thieves caught when tossed electronic ankle bracelet lands in backseat
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: National Post   Fri Apr 9 2010   Page: A6   Section: Canada   Source: Canwest News Service
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Two notorious Winnipeg car thieves thought they had pulled a fast one on justice and parole officials by cutting off their electronic ankle bracelets and tossing them from the window of a speeding, stolen car in December. But one of the GPS devices landed in the backseat. "The police knew these two were together, and exactly where they were," Crown attorney Liz Laite told court yesterday. Members of the stolen auto unit were able to communicate with the monitoring company, based out of Atlanta, and captured the pair after a dangerous, high-speed chase ended with plenty of damage but no injuries. The 18-year-old passenger of the stolen Ford Fusion pleaded guilty yesterday to several charges stemming from his role in the incident and was given a two-year prison sentence under a joint-recommendation from Crown and defence lawyers.<BR>

--30--

Title: 16-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Vehicle safety bill coming to Parliament  Toyota recall prompts MP to propose amendments to federal legislation
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Thursday, April 8, 2010 | 2:27 PM CT CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg MP wants to force automakers to act quicker when vehicle safety issues come to light.</P> <P>New Democrat Jim Maloway told reporters in Winnipeg on Thursday that he is pursuing an amendment to the federal Motor Vehicle Safety Act that would require automakers to immediately alert federal officials about any significant problems and then post consumer complaints to their websites within 48 hours.</P> <P>At the very least, consumers should learn about defects by mail within 14 days, he said.</P> <P>As well, information recorded by a vehicle's onboard computer in the seconds before an impact would also have to be made available to government accident investigators.</P> <P>Maloway, who was prompted into action by the recent problems with some Toyota vehicles, has drafted a private member's bill and intends to table it in the House of Commons within the next two weeks.</P> <P>Auto association applauds effort<BR>George Iny, president of the Automobile Protection Association, is encouraged by the proposed bill, which he said would address the weaknesses found during the investigation of sudden acceleration complaints on Toyota vehicles.</P> <P>However, certain provisions of the bill need to be worked out, he said.</P> <P>"Requiring that automakers to post defects reported by customers within 48 hours is too onerous. And requiring all owners to be notified when an investigation is opened, but a defect has not been confirmed, would create unnecessary confusion," Iny said.</P> <P>Any solution must also include more engineers and resources for the defect investigations branch at Transport Canada, he added.</P> <P>Toyota has recalled more than eight million vehicles worldwide, including 270,000 in Canada, because of accelerator pedal problems in multiple models and braking issues in the Prius hybrid.</P> <P>The United States government has linked 52 deaths to crashes allegedly caused by accelerator problems in Toyotas. No deaths have been reported in Canada.</P> <P>Toyota attributes the issue to sticking gas pedals and accelerators that can become jammed in floor mats and has cited no evidence of an electrical problem.</P> <P>Congressional hearings, criminal investigations<BR>In the U.S., the recalls have led to congressional hearings, a criminal investigation by U.S. federal prosecutors, dozens of lawsuits and an intense review by the U.S. Transportation Department.</P> <P>In Canada, the federal Transport Department is investigating Toyota Canada's handling of consumer concerns about the safety of its vehicles.</P> <P>Earlier this year, several Toyota executives appeared at a Commons committee hearing in Ottawa to answer questions about recent recalls.</P> <P>Toyota began hearing a handful of complaints about the accelerating system on Toyota cars in October 2009, Stephen Beatty, managing director of Toyota Canada Inc., told the committee.</P> <P>Soon after, Toyota began discussions about gas pedals with its suppliers, but the company didn't notify Transport Canada until Jan. 21, when it issued a recall notice.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/08/mb-bill-automakers-maloway-manitoba.html#ixzz0kbjDvSGJ">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/08/mb-bill-automakers-maloway-manitoba.html#ixzz0kbjDvSGJ</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car dealer alleged crime 'bank'
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Sat Apr 10 2010 Page: 12   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>If you wanted to buy a car, Nello Chiapetta was the man who ironed out your financing. </P> <P>Court documents made public yesterday allege the former Eastwood Truck and Toy Centre finance manager was also the go-to guy for city gangsters looking to launder their ill-gotten gains. </P> <P>Chiapetta, 39, was among more than two dozen people arrested in Project Divide, a December 2009 police sting targeting the Hells Angels "puppet club" known as the Zig-Zag Crew. Chiapetta, who is not a member of either gang, has been charged with two counts of laundering the proceeds of crime and one count of conspiracy to launder the proceeds of crime. </P> <P>The charges against him have not been proven in court and he remains innocent until proven guilty. </P> <P>According to court documents at least one city gangster, Hells Angels member Sean Wolfe, referred to Chiapetta as "the bank." As in previous similar stings, police enlisted the aid of a paid criminal agent, Zig-Zagger Michael Satsatin, to ensnare Chiapetta and other targets. </P> <P>Satsatin told police Wolfe -- then responsible for overseeing Zig-Zag operations -- and Chiapetta met on "numerous occasions" and that he believed Chiapetta "controls" Wolfe's money. </P> <P>"The agent is aware that suspicion is raised if a business receives an amount of $10,000 or more in a cash transaction," says a RCMP affidavit. "He further believes that Chiapetta would be able to 'take care of the paperwork' to make the transaction not appear suspicious." </P> <P>According to Manitoba Public Insurance records, Wolfe and Chiapetta's relationship, as of last year, included joint ownership of a 2007 Harley Davidson motorcycle. </P> <P>Police say criminals involved in drug trafficking often use "nominees" to conceal ownership of property and hide assets. </P> <P>"I believe that without sufficient evidence of any criminality on Chiapetta's part, it would be difficult for the authorities to seize Wolfe's motorcycle and have it forfeited as proceeds of crime," a police officer wrote in an affidavit. </P> <P>Court documents allege Chiapetta helped Satsatin launder $25,000 in American currency, money Satsatin said came through the sale of marijuana. The transaction included the sale of a 2003 Pontiac Grand Am for $9,700 cash. Chiapetta and Satsatin allegedly brokered another deal to launder an additional $22,000. </P> <P>Hundreds of pages of Project Divide documents have now been unsealed by the court. The documents reveal a wealth of insider revelations, including infighting among gangsters, the Zig-Zag Crew's plans for expansion to B.C., and plots to intimidate trial witnesses. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 18-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Running the numbers
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sat Apr 10 2010 Page: F2

Title: 19-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorcycle safety tips – what you need to know
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Spring is now upon us and that means that we’ll start seeing motorcycles come out of winter hibernation and return to the roadways.</P> <P>All motorists are encouraged to share the road. Drivers of passenger vehicle are reminded that motorcycles are entitled to be on the roadways. Driver courtesy can go a long way to prevent collisions.</P> <P>Motorcycles are a fun, efficient mode of transportation, but they simply don’t have a ton of steel around them to protect the rider. Motorcycle riders are encouraged to take a few precautions prior to every ride.</P> <P>Before you start out, take a few minutes to do a pre-ride safety check, including an inspection of your tires and brakes. And make sure your headlight, mirrors, windshield and visors are clean.</P> <P>Driver responsibly and stick to the speed limit. Motorcycles can accelerate quickly and reach speeds far in excess of speed limits. Leave plenty of space between you and other vehicles, so you have enough time to react if something unexpected happens, and vice versa. Always ride with your headlight on, and be aware of other driver’s blind spots.</P> <P>Wear appropriate protective gear – it can protect you from severe injury. Start with an approved motorcycle helmet and visor. Leather clothing and gloves are recommended, along with boots that cover the ankle. T-shirts and cutoffs are not advised.</P> <P>Consider taking a motorcycle riding and safety course to practice and expand your driving skills and learn how to anticipate dangerous scenarios. Safety Services Manitoba offers several courses, including a 21 hour course featuring practical and classroom training, and an eight hour course focused on practical training. Both courses include motorcycle dynamics, including balance, control and steering, defensive driving skills, braking techniques and proper riding attire. </P> <P>For more information, contact Manitoba Safety Services at 949-1085 or <A href="http://www.safetyservicesmanitoba.ca">http://www.safetyservicesmanitoba.ca</A><BR></P>

--30--

NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: What you need to know for a safe summer ride
NEWS_ITM_TXT:

Title: 21-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man 'stable' after two-car crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police are investigating whether speed was a factor in a two-vehicle crash on a Winnipeg street that resulted in a rollover and one person being sent to hospital Friday morning. </P> <P>The adult male driver of a car was in stable condition when he was taken to Health Sciences Centre, a few blocks from the crash scene, said Winnipeg Fire Department district chief Ted Kuryluk. </P> <P>Kuryluk said the man's car, a Chrysler Sebring, was eastbound on McDermot Avenue, a one-way street, when it struck a parked sport utility vehicle and flipped on to its roof about 9:30 a.m. </P> <P>Lone occupant </P> <P>The crash occurred just east of Lydia Street in the inner-city Centennial neighbourhood. </P> <P>The car went through a 50 km/h school zone outside Ecole Sacre-Coeur School just before the collision. </P> <P>Kuryluk the man was extricated by firefighters because the overturned car's doors couldn't be opened. The car's back end was elevated. </P> <P>"The doors were crimped shut, so to speak," Kuryluk said. </P> <P>The driver was the car's lone occupant and he was wearing a seatbelt when firefighters arrived, Kuryluk said. </P> <P>Witness Jason Hill said the man was speaking to firefighters and paramedics at the scene. </P> <P>Pulled out window </P> <P>"They dragged him out the (shattered) passenger side window," Hill said. "He was sitting up and then they laid him on the stretcher and put him in the ambulance." </P> <P>Hill and others who live and work in the area wondered if the car was speeding. </P> <P>"If you're speeding, look what can happen," Hill said. </P> <P>Parked in the north curb lane, the sport utility vehicle, a Toyota 4Runner, was unoccupied. It was struck on the rear passenger side and was partially pushed onto the curb, It appeared to sustain significant damage. </P> <P>Winnipeg police are investigating the incident. No charges have been laid. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hit-and-run motorist hurts 3 in parking lot
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Sun Apr 11 2010 Page: A11
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A throng of police cruisers converged in Elmwood on Saturday to arrest a 26-year-old man in connection with a weekend hit-and-run that sent three people to hospital. </P> <P>A 29-year-old man and two women were taken to hospital with non life- threatening injuries around 2:30 a.m. Saturday after they were struck by a vehicle in a parking lot near Panet Road and Regent Avenue West. The vehicle fled the scene and the victims were treated for minor upper- and lower-body injuries. </P> <P>They have since been released from hospital. </P> <P>Winnipeg police Const. Jason Michalyshen said information about the suspect vehicle led police to a residence on Union Avenue West in Elmwood. Multiple cruisers blocked access to Union Avenue West from Watt Street around 11 a.m. as a group of officers approached a home in the 400 block. </P> <P>One neighbour said police told her to take her grandchildren and leave the area. </P> <P>Michalyshen said the scene likely appeared more dramatic than it actually was, though he confirmed the man taken into custody was known to police. He said the man is the registered owner of the vehicle allegedly involved in the Transcona hit-and-run. </P> <P>Michalyshen said no charges have been laid and police are still investigating to determine who was driving the vehicle at the time of the accident. </P> <P>"We're still sorting that out," he said. </P>

--30--

Title: 23-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Elmwood house surrounded, suspect nabbed after hit & run
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A police investigation into a hit-and-run in which three people were injured led city officers to surround an Elmwood house Saturday before taking a man into custody. </P> <P>Several hours after the victims were hit by a car -- possibly intentionally -- about 2:30 a.m. Saturday in a parking lot at the Cavalier Inn at Regent Avenue West and Panet Road, members of the heavily armed Winnipeg Police Service tactical support team closed in on the house in the 400-block of Union Avenue West. </P> <P>"They told me, 'Get back in your house! Get back in your house!' And I was like, 'What the hell is going on?'" one woman on Union Avenue -- refusing to give her name -- told the Winnipeg Sun of the officers, who she said numbered a dozen or more, with firearms drawn. </P> <P>"There were four at the corner here and there were three on the rooftop there," she added, pointing to an industrial warehouse building across the street from her house. "There were three in the alley, and two over here. They were everywhere." </P> <P>Close watch </P> <P>Police removed a 26-year-old man from the house "without incident" in the early afternoon, said Winnipeg police spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen, after officers kept close watch on the residence based on the licence plate number and a description of the vehicle that had allegedly struck the victims before fleeing. </P> <P>The three adult victims -- two women and a man -- were hit by the car in a corner of the hotel's parking lot, outside the inn's Live Wire Cabaret. </P> <P>"At least three people were conveyed to hospital," Michalyshen said, adding that though the three victims were in stable condition, one of the women was initially transported to hospital in critical condition. She has since been released. </P> <P>The male victim is 29, said Michalyshen, who didn't know the women's ages. </P> <P>Investigators are examining whether the driver intended to hit the victims with the car. </P> <P>"We're going to look at all of the options -- whether or not this is accidental or whether these individuals were targeted," Michalyshen said, adding investigators haven't confirmed whether the driver or the victims had been at the hotel's bar before the incident. </P> <P>"There's no indication that there's a relationship between the people at this point. We're certainly looking at the possibility that there may have been a verbal altercation or dispute. We're still interviewing some of the victims and witnesses." </P> <P>While the man taken into custody is suspected to be the registered owner of the car that struck the victims, Michalyshen said it's unclear whether he was the driver. </P> <P>"There may have been more than one person in that vehicle," he said. "We certainly may be in a position where we have to interview additional people too." </P> <P>A black Chevrolet Epica was towed from Union Avenue West near the house where the man had been taken away by police. Michalyshen said the car matches a description of the suspect's vehicle. </P> <P>Police are asking anyone who witnessed the incident outside the hotel to call them at 986-6271 or Crime Stoppers at 786-TIPS (8477).</P>

--30--

Title: 24-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'Covered in blood' ; Four hurt after car ran red: witnesses
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Four people were sent to hospital after a serious two-vehicle collision in the West End on Sunday afternoon. </P> <P>Police were called to the intersection of Ellice Avenue and Wall Street about 3 p.m. after a black Chevrolet Cavalier and a newer model white Chevrolet Sierra collided. </P> <P>Two people were in each vehicle at the time of the crash. </P> <P>One person, whom witnesses said was the female passenger of the Cavalier, was rushed to hospital in critical condition. Police said Sunday night that she is now in unstable condition. Three others were in stable condition Sunday night. </P> <P>The badly damaged Cavalier ended up against the front of Central Baptist Church just east of Ellice and Wall, while the Sierra remained in the middle of the intersection, with heavy damage to the front of the vehicle. Debris from both vehicles was strewn around the intersection. </P> <P>Police kept the area closed to traffic late Sunday afternoon as they investigated the collision. </P> <P>Witnesses said first responders had to extricate the female passenger from the Cavalier. </P> <P>Michael Callahan, who works at the Red River Co-op gas bar near the intersection, rushed to the scene immediately after he heard screeching tires and a loud bang. </P> <P>"I ran over to the black car to see if anyone needed a hand," he said. "The female passenger was pinned in and covered in blood." </P> <P>He said an adult male had been driving the Cavalier and estimated the female passenger was in her mid-20s. </P> <P>"The driver was OK and was mobile, and seeing what he could do to help her," Callahan said. </P> <P>Witnesses said the Cavalier had been travelling eastbound on Ellice, appeared to run a red light and was T-boned on the passenger side by the pickup truck, which was northbound on Wall Street. </P> <P>Callahan said the two occupants of the truck were shaken up but appeared to escape serious injury. Another witness said one occupant of the truck had been placed in a neck brace. </P> <P>Callahan said it was the third crash he's witnessed at the location in the three months he's been working at the gas bar. </P> <P>"It's a pretty deadly intersection," he said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hit-and-run victims home from hospital as arrest made
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 26-year-old man is facing charges for leaving the scene of a hit-and-run incident early Saturday that led to the police tactical response team surrounding an Elmwood home. </P> <P>Police said the male, who is believed to be the driver of a vehicle that struck several people about 2:30 a.m. in the parking lot of the Cavalier Inn at Regent Avenue West and Panet Road, is facing charges under the Highway Traffic Act. </P> <P>Three women, all family members celebrating one victim's birthday at the Live Wire Cabaret, were sent to hospital. </P> <P>The male was taken into police custody without incident shortly after noon Saturday when the heavily armed police unit was called to a home in the 400-block of Union Avenue West. A black Chevrolet Epica was towed from near the house where the man had been taken away by police. </P> <P>"It's a serious incident," said Winnipeg Police Service spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen. "People were hit with a vehicle." </P> <P>Police said there appeared to be a confrontation between people in the suspect vehicle and the group of people who were struck. No one is currently facing criminal charges in relation to the incident. </P> <P>TURNED DOWN ADVANCES </P> <P>Joy Yackel, 25, whose birthday the group was celebrating, was transported to hospital in critical condition but was released from hospital later that day. She says she suffered rib, pelvis and neck injuries in the incident. </P> <P>Yackel said she and relatives were arguing verbally with males in a vehicle before being struck. She said the argument stemmed from the women turning down at least one man's advances at the bar. </P> <P>"I just saw lights and then the car hitting me and trying to grab onto a windshield," Yackel said of the incident. "That's all I remember." </P> <P>Joy Yackel said her sister Chancey Yackel, 21, ended up with a bruised chin after being carried on the vehicle's hood for a distance. She said her aunt, Cynthia Courchene, 38, required stitches in her scalp after being struck. </P> <P>An adult male, who was an acquaintance of one of the Yackels' relatives, also sustained minor injuries during the incident. </P>

--30--

Title: 26-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Elderly man struck on Main
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An elderly man was in hospital in serious condition after being hit by a car in the North End early Sunday. </P> <P>Winnipeg police said the 73-year-old was crossing Main Street at Machray Avenue from the east side when he was struck by a northbound vehicle. </P> <P>Police said the man, who lives in the general area of the incident, was struck by a Pontiac G6 driven by a 24-year-old man. </P> <P>The senior was taken to hospital in serious condition, where he remained Sunday morning. </P> <P>The central traffic unit continues to investigate the incident. </P> <P>No charges have been laid and alcohol does not appear to be a factor in the collision, but police said they're investigating whether speed may have played a role. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 4 injured in Winnipeg crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Sunday, April 11, 2010 | 4:49 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One person was critically injured and three others wounded in a crash between a pickup truck and a car at Ellice Avenue and Wall Street in Winnipeg on Sunday.</P> <P>Winnipeg police Const. Jason Michalyshen said the "fairly significant" incident took place at 3 p.m.</P> <P>A CBC News cameraman on the scene said emergency crews had to use the Jaws of Life to extract people from the car, which appeared to have been T-boned on the passenger side by a newer model GMC pickup truck.</P> <P>Footage showed the front end of the pickup was heavily damaged in the crash.</P> <P>Both airbags in the car — its make couldn't immediately be distinguished — had deployed due to the force of the impact. A large amount of blood could be seen on the passenger side.</P> <P>One person was listed in critical condition in hospital, another in unstable condition, police said. Two others were in stable condition.</P> <P>One of the more seriously injured people appeared to be a boy between 8 and 12 years old.</P> <P>Police couldn't immediately say how old or what gender the victims were.</P> <P>A number of police units are on-scene and traffic along the usually busy route is being diverted.</P> <P>Police said the area of Ellice Avenue between Goulding and Erin Streets has been blocked off. Motorists are advised to avoid the area.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/11/man-crash-ellice-wall.html#ixzz0ktPaewuU">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/11/man-crash-ellice-wall.html#ixzz0ktPaewuU</A></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man injured crossing Main Street
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Sunday, April 11, 2010 | 10:55 AM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An elderly pedestrian was seriously injured after being hit by a vehicle in Winnipeg's North End early Sunday, police said.</P> <P>Police said that shortly before 12:25 a.m. the 73-year-old man was hit by a vehicle travelling north on Main Street near Machray Avenue.</P> <P>The man was trying to cross Main Street when he was hit, police said.</P> <P>He remains in serious condition in hospital. Police didn't identify him.</P> <P>Police blocked off part of Main Street where the man was struck and remained there into Sunday morning to investigate what happened.</P> <P>The part of the street he was crossing is not an intersection and there is no crosswalk, police said.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/11/man-man-hit-main-street.html#ixzz0ktPrPFZp">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/11/man-man-hit-main-street.html#ixzz0ktPrPFZp</A><BR></P>

--30--

NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: School Bus Collides With Truck
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
There's been a collision between a school bus and a truck at the intersection of Academy Road and Wellington Crescent. There are no passengers on the school bus. An ambulance has arrived at the scene to tend to the driver of the truck.<BR>

Title: 30-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI touted as copter sponsor
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed Apr 14 2010   Page: B1
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance would make an ideal sponsor for Winnipeg's police helicopter because the aircraft can detect drunk drivers, enforce street- racing legislation and all but eliminate police-car crashes, according to an internal police report. </P> <P>The city's first police helicopter could help cut down MPI's costs by monitoring traffic "from a surreptitious point of view," according to June 2009 police report obtained by the Free Press under freedom-of-information legislation. </P> <P>The city will spend $3.5 million this year to purchase a police helicopter, while the province has agreed to cover the $1.3-million annual operating cost. </P> <P>The city has invited corporations to sponsor the aircraft but has yet to sign any deals. It has not made any formal proposal to Manitoba Public Insurance about the helicopter, MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said. </P> <P>But a 37-page report prepared for senior police executives describes the Crown corporation as the ideal partner for the vehicle. The report cites the apprehension of impaired drivers and observation of street racers as potential police helicopter functions, in addition to the vehicle serving as an eye in the sky to marshal patrol cars more effectively, as police Chief Keith McCaskill has repeatedly stated. </P> <P>The helicopter will also be used to manage car and foot chases, search for lost children and Alzheimer's patients, manage crowds, escort VIPs and serve as a visual deterrent against crime, states the report, which also includes a comparative analysis that concludes a helicopter is far more useful than a fixed-wing aircraft when it comes to policing. </P> <P>The document is significant because the Free Press and other media have been asking the city to release reports that justify the purchase of the police helicopter since late November, when Premier Greg Selinger and Mayor Sam Katz announced their intention to create a helicopter unit to assist the Winnipeg Police Service. </P> <P>Documents requested by the Free Press in December were completely severed -- that is, blacked out -- upon their release in January, as the police service wanted politicians to review the information first. But the police subsequently released new versions of the same documents with only moderate edits. One section of the report that remains partly severed is a discussion about pilot training. The police service expects to encounter "some extreme problems in terms of reliability and continuity of training" that apparently stem from the fact helicopter pilots are "very transient in nature" and are "driven by opportunity and financial reward." The report also predicts citizens will be concerned about the noise created by the helicopter during its first few months in operation. To mitigate against this concern, the police have selected the quietest helicopter that's useful for policing -- the Eurocopter EC 120B Colibri -- and plan to establish a telephone line and email address that will allow residents to directly reach the flight unit. The police also plan to offer "select members of the community and local leaders" rides on the helicopter so they can spread positive word of mouth. "On-board equipment such as the rear-view monitor and internal radio communications allow for a very involved experience for the persons riding along," the report states. The rear- view monitor is "great for training and strategic ride-alongs." </P> <P>Members of the media will also be invited on board. "Perception of a police helicopter is generally very positive. By inviting the media and creating a transparent process, they would be encouraged to research and develop stories based on the mass of information available," the report states. </P> <P>The police also plan to engage in a public education campaign "to address issues such as privacy rights and noise concerns, while highlighting the level of safety and response times an aerial support unit can achieve." </P> <P>The police must also develop a means to address "nighttime light contamination" from a 30-million candlepower light "that can illuminate half a square block or the area the size of a bicycle."</P>

--30--

Title: 31-Jul-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man killed in SUV rollover
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Tuesday, April 13, 2010 | 8:49 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 69-year-old man was killed Tuesday when the vehicle he was in rolled over on a provincial highway just south of Blumenort, Man.</P> <P>A 31-year-old woman driving a 2002 Toyota Rav 4 lost control of the vehicle at about 2 p.m. CT on Highway 12, RCMP said.</P> <P>The vehicle rolled into a ditch at the side of the road and the man was thrown from inside.</P> <P>He was rushed to a nearby hospital where he was pronounced dead, police said.</P> <P>He was not wearing a seatbelt, which contributed to his death, RCMP said.</P> <P>The driver remained in the vehicle until help arrived. She was taken to hospital in Winnipeg and is listed in stable condition.</P> <P>Police did not identify the dead man, as they are still trying to notify his family.</P> <P>Alcohol is not suspected to be a factor in the rollover, RCMP said.</P> <P>Police are continuing to investigate.</P> <P>Blumenort is about 45 kilometres southeast of Winnipeg.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/13/man-killed-rollover-blumenort.html#ixzz0l4uuprXU">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/13/man-killed-rollover-blumenort.html#ixzz0l4uuprXU</A></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RCMP investigate fatal MVA near Blumenort
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Steinbach RCMP are investigating a fatal single vehicle accident Tuesday afternoon on Highway #12 just south of Blumenort, Manitoba.</P> <P>Police say a 2002 Toyota Rav4 driven by a 31 year old female with a 69 year old male passenger was traveling south when the driver lost control rolling the vehicle into a ditch. </P> <P>The passenger was thrown from the vehicle and transported to Hospital in Steinbach, Manitoba where he was pronounced dead. The driver was taken to the Ste. Anne Hospital and then transported to the Winnipeg Health Sciences Center in stable condition. </P> <P>No names have been released..</P> <P>Alcohol is not a factor. The passenger was not wearing a seat belt and Police say that was a contributing factor to the fatality.</P>

--30--

Title: 2-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Tamperers beware ; Fines in works for removing airbag, disabling immobilizer
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The NDP government plans to impose fines of up to $5,000 for removing airbags from vehicles and for disabling or tampering with immobilizers. </P> <P>Transportation Minister Steve Ashton said the proposed legislative changes, contained in the Highway Traffic Amendment Act, are necessary to increase safety and to fight auto theft. </P> <P>"We're worried that in some cases immobilizers are being removed as part of remote starter installations," Ashton said. "This apparently has been happening." </P> <P>Ashton said he understands it is cheaper and faster to disable an immobilizer rather than work around it when installing a remote starter, but disabling immobilizers defeats the purpose of Manitoba Public Insurance's anti-theft immobilizer program. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said the insurer has also heard of people deliberately having their immobilizers disabled because, in some cases, remote starters may not work with them or because some people simply don't want the immobilizer. </P> <P>"Our position is that an effective immobilizer is critical to combating auto theft," Smiley said, noting MPI supports the proposed legislation. </P> <P>New offence </P> <P>Ashton said the bill is aimed at commercial repair shops and isn't intended to be used against anyone who accidentally disables their immobilizer during the course of unrelated repairs. </P> <P>He said it remains to be seen how the law will affect people who have already deliberately tampered with their immobilizers, but pledged to have that issue addressed. </P> <P>When the bill passes -- as it is sure to do with a majority government -- it will create a new summary offence for tampering with airbags as well as immobilizers. </P> <P>Ashton said there have been problems in other jurisdictions with people removing airbags from vehicles to sell as a standalone, used product. Smiley said that has not been a major issue in Manitoba, but said MPI supports the move nonetheless. </P> <P>The new law will allow people to remove airbags from vehicles if they're being scrapped or recycled and to get permission from Transport Canada to have their airbags disabled under certain circumstances. </P> <P>The bill will come into effect the day it passes, if and when that happens. </P>

--30--

Title: 3-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Helicopter buzz coming soon
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Thu Apr 15 2010   Page: A12
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Like a bottle of fine red wine, that police helicopter just keeps getting better with age. When the city originally proposed spending $3.5 million for a whirlybird last year, the benefits were described in relatively modest terms: It would help in tracking car thieves, managing car chases, traffic enforcement and finding missing people. </P> <P>Today, it is much, much improved. According to a report obtained by the Free Press under freedom-of-information legislation, the helicopter could also search for lost children and Alzheimer's patients, manage crowds, escort VIPs and serve as a visual deterrent against crime. Criminals will apparently be running for cover, or stopping their anti-social behaviour, at the very sound of its approach. </P> <P>Other information not previously disclosed says the helicopter will have a rear-view monitor, which will be "great for training and strategic ride-alongs. " There will even be a new phone number that can be used by people upset with all the commotion associated with operating a helicopter in an urban environment. </P> <P>There's no doubt a helicopter could serve a useful purpose from time to time, but it still seems like an extravagant toy, the perfect gift for the city that has everything. </P> <P>The problem is Winnipeg could probably use more of the basics, like more boots on the ground and more foot patrols in the downtown. </P> <P>The report identifies Manitoba Public Insurance as the ideal sponsor for the helicopter. It sort of makes sense, particularly if it can be shown that helicopter enforcement will reduce insurance costs and lower premiums. MPI already supports the auto-theft unit and the police Checkstop program during the Christmas holiday season because it believes it pays dividends in the end. </P> <P>The real value of a police helicopter, however, is harder to measure, and it is not clear that it will suppress car racing or speeding, although it may help police on the ground make arrests. </P> <P>The idea of going to the public trough for support, however, is getting a little tiring. The city is buying the helicopter and the province is paying for its operation, so do we really need another government agency supporting a service that the city doesn't truly need and can't afford? </P> <P>The city hopes to have the bird up and running for the busy summer crime season. Since it's going to be part of the family now, the next step will be to give it a nickname. Whirlypeg and Chopper the Copper are out, but we're open to suggestions. </P>

--30--

Title: 4-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Proposed Amendment to Help Stop Car Theft
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
The Manitoba government is proposing an amendment to the Highway Traffic Act that would make it an offence to tamper with a vehicle's anti-theft device or its airbag system. The Minister responsible Steve Ashton says the move addresses MPI concerns that electronic immobilizers have been knowingly tampered with during the installation of remote starters.<BR>There's also been a run on people removing airbag systems from vehicles to sell them.

--30--

Title: 5-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man. proposes fines for immobilizer tampering  Fines upped to a maximum of $5,000
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Wednesday, April 14, 2010 | 5:54 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Motorists and mechanics caught taking shortcuts to install remote car starters by bypassing their vehicle's immobilizer will face hefty fines under an amendment to Manitoba's Highway Traffic Act, the province said on Wednesday.</P> <P>An alarming trend of immobilizer tampering to more quickly and cheaply install remote starters for vehicles has been noticed, making affected cars and trucks more vulnerable to theft, Transportation and Infrastructure Minister Steve Ashton said.</P> <P>"Electronic immobilizers have knowingly been tampered with during installation of remote starters because it is cheaper and easier to disengage the immobilizer when installing a remote starter than to work around it, making the anti-theft devices useless," Ashton said.</P> <P>"In other cases, immobilizers have been disabled or completely removed during the course of service and repairs."</P> <P>The practice flies in the face of a long-standing push by Manitoba Public Insurance to crack down on auto theft by requiring vehicles to have immobilizers installed.</P> <P>The public insurer said the resulting drop in auto theft since 2005 has saved ratepayers about $60 million.</P> <P>Under the amended law, it would be an offence to tamper with an immobilizer device. The maximum new fine if convicted would be $5,000.</P> <P>The province wants to extend the same penalty to people who remove or tamper with airbag systems in vehicles.</P> <P>Ashton said "industry representatives" have noticed an issue where the safety systems are being removed from vehicles to resell them.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/14/man-hta-fines-immobilizers.html#ixzz0lAozqbjN">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/14/man-hta-fines-immobilizers.html#ixzz0lAozqbjN</A><BR></P>

--30--

<P>Speed is considered a factor in a single-vehicle crash which killed a 69-year-old man near Blumenort on Tuesday afternoon, RCMP say. </P> <P>Police identified the victim as David Allen. </P> <P>Allen was a passenger in a southbound Toyota Rav4, driven by his 31-year-old wife, when it veered on to the gravel shoulder and rolled just south of Blumenort on Highway 12, Steinbach RCMP said. </P> <P>Allen wasn't wearing a seatbelt and was ejected from the vehicle, police said. </P> <P>His wife was in stable condition in hospital, RCMP said. </P> <P>The couple recently moved to Steinbach from B.C., police said. </P> <P>Blumenort is about 55 km southeast of Winnipeg.</P>

Title: 7-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Prof touts 3-D camera to help keep streets safer  Would boost maintenance response
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: By ROSS ROMANIUK, Winnipeg Sun  Last Updated: April 15, 2010 7:39am
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A new 3-D camera would help the city more quickly respond when wet or icy streets pose a safety problem, says its developer.</P> <P>A University of Manitoba professor hopes his camera is adopted by road maintenance crews to dramatically reduce slip-and-slide crashes and save lives.</P> <P>Ahmed Shalaby, a researcher of technology to improve pavement design, held a presentation at U of M on Wednesday evening to outline his work in developing a revamped sort of camera which can capture multiple images of a section of street surface under various kinds of light.</P> <P>“It’s basically a camera with lighting from precise directions that are angled to the surface. The idea is that by looking at how light reflects from it, we can combine these images to generate a 3-D map of the surface,” said Shalaby, a civil engineering professor.</P> <P>“We take three images from the same camera location, with lighting coming from different directions in each of the images. We put this together in a 3-D image of the surface. </P> <P>“That tells us if the surface would have enough friction, or would be a trouble spot and become slippery if it gets wet — that kind of thing.” </P> <P>And though an image is “good for one point in time,” he added, “in the future, this could be mounted on a vehicle and be able to take images at travel speed — as you’re driving on the road.” </P> <P>For now, his device is really only “a two-foot-by-two-foot box, and a camera mounted on top,” in a combination he said is not that complicated.</P> <P>The idea is to help street maintenance officials detect patches of pavement where sand or salt is needed, or sections that should be altered to increase their friction “and give vehicles more traction and more ability to stop,” said Shalaby, who is working with two graduate students on the technology.</P> <P>“You would be able to control a vehicle better.” </P> <P>Shalaby gave a lecture on his ideas concerning “safe, smart and sustainable” streets last night at the U of M.</P>

--30--

Title: 8-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Jaffer plea deal details revealed
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: CBC.CA News   Tue Apr 13 2010, 11:05pm ET   Section: Canada
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Crown felt it had no choice but to drop charges of cocaine possession and drunk driving against former Conservative MP Rahim Jaffer in favour of a guilty plea on a lesser charge, due to how police handled the case, CBC News has learned. </P> <P>According to sources close to the case, police made two fateful decisions: repeatedly denying Jaffer access to his own lawyers and a strip search after he was pulled over on a rural road on Sept. 11 in the southern Ontario community of Palgrave, northwest of Toronto. </P> <P>In early March, Jaffer pleaded guilty to the lesser charge of careless driving ? incurring a $500 fine, demerit points on his driver's licence and a voluntary $500 charitable donation ? in a deal that sparked public outcry and questions over whether justice had been served. </P> <P>A veteran Ontario Provincial Police constable pulled Jaffer over at 12:45 a.m. in the early hours of a Friday. She had clocked his grey Ford Escape driving 93 km/h in a 50 km/h zone. </P> <P>As noted in an agreed statement of fact, Jaffer acknowledged having two beers in the prior two hours when asked about the smell of alcohol on his breath by OPP Const. Kim Stapleton when he was pulled over. A so-called "blow test," which is used to determine whether a breathalyzer is necessary, came up positive. </P> <P>As a result, Stapleton handcuffed the former rising star of the Conservative Party and placed him in her cruiser. According to sources, she then went back to the Ford Escape and grabbed Jaffer's sport jacket from the passenger seat. </P> <P>She noticed a bag inside one of the pockets ? what would later be determined to be about a gram of cocaine, a small amount but a banned substance for which possession is a federal crime. </P> <P>Calls to lawyers </P> <P>At the nearby OPP detachment in Caledon, police made their first fateful decision. </P> <P>As required, Jaffer was given the opportunity to exercise his legal right to contact a lawyer before submitting himself to a breathalyzer test. </P> <P>He tried to contact two lawyers in Calgary, but couldn't reach them and left a message. Police then suggested he call a 1-800 line offering 24-hour legal aid. </P> <P>When he called, he received their typical advice: Take the breathalyzer test. By law, police must administer the test ? which can take about 20 minutes and involves two samples ? within two hours after pulling over a driver. </P> <P>Midway through the test, one of Jaffer's Calgary lawyers called the detachment several times but was told he must wait because the breathalyzer was being administered, sources say. The second lawyer also returned Jaffer's call in that time and was told it was too late. </P> <P>While Jaffer did speak to legal aid, legal experts say he should have been given the opportunity to speak to counsel of his choice, especially if there was time for the breathalyzer test to be restarted. </P> <P>"It's hard to imagine a good reason they wouldn't let the lawyer talk to the suspect," veteran Toronto defence lawyer Scott Cowan, who was not involved in the case, told CBC's chief correspondent Peter Mansbridge in an interview. "As long as the suspect is being diligent, there's no reason not to give him a meaningful opportunity to speak to his lawyer." </P> <P>Both Jaffer's breathalyzer tests registered slightly over .10, above the legal limit of .08 blood-alcohol concentration. </P> <P>Strip search questioned </P> <P>Shortly after the breathalyzer, police made another key decision: to strip search the former MP, an act Cowan argues wasn't "defensible at all" in the Jaffer case. </P> <P>For police to justify a strip search, they must have "reasonable grounds" to believe someone in custody is hiding something illegal or something that could hurt themselves or the police. </P> <P>The "highly intrusive, invasive procedure" that can involve full nudity and opening up body cavities should only be undertaken when "absolutely necessary," Cowan said, adding it is typically used on those who have criminal records, have committed violent acts or could be a danger to others in a jail cell. </P> <P>"Here it seems there is no reason even to think that, no identifiable reason to call even the existence of a potential threat," said Cowan, noting Jaffer had no previous record, was apparently co-operative and was being released from jail, thereby posing no danger to other inmates. Nothing was found in the strip search. </P> <P>It was shortly before dawn that Friday when the former MP was released from the Caledon detachment ? his driver's licence suspended and criminal charges of speeding, drunk driving and drug possession laid against him. </P> <P>On March 9 in an Orangeville court, Crown attorney Marie Balogh stated that there "was no reasonable prospect of conviction." The Crown dropped the federal criminal charges and Jaffer plead guilty to a less serious provincial charge of careless driving. </P> <P>As a result he paid a $500 fine, made a $500 contribution to a charity, received six demerits on his driver's licence, but most importantly he walked away with no criminal record. </P> <P>"Child's play compared to a criminal conviction and a year-long driving prohibition," Cowan said of the punishment, which may have cost Jaffer up to $5,000 in car insurance. But he escaped a year-long driving prohibition. </P> <P>Plea bargains common: expert </P> <P>Sources tell CBC that the Crown took the deal to the OPP as a courtesy, hoping the force would agree to it as well, but the police wanted a trial. </P> <P>Even though the plea bargain went ahead, garnering swift condemnation from the public and federal opposition parties, experts say such deals are a necessary part of the court process. </P> <P>Sue Chapman, a former Crown attorney, said that while the public is automatically suspicious of deals, about 95 per cent of all cases are concluded that way. </P> <P>"And the system would grind to a halt if that weren't the case," said Chapman, who was not involved in the Jaffer case. "You can't run trials in relation to everything. It's a high-stakes game for both sides. [Plea bargains are] are essential for the system." </P>

--30--

Title: 13-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Minnedosa RCMP investigate vandalism
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: By Clp. Brian Huff  Minnedosa RCMP
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Minnedosa members responded to 20 calls for service this past week. Members were called to the Personal Care home when an elderly visitor became unreasonable. I believe the matter was resolved informally.</P> <P>Spring is in the air and we have received a number of calls regarding people driving with reckless abandon. What may seem like harmless fun is actually quite dangerous in a municipal setting and we take the safety of our community and those who live here seriously. If you choose to race around, not stop at stop signs or squeal your tires, you will be charged. Your vehicle may also be impounded for a MPI safety inspection and, for those on intermediate licenses, say good by to them<BR>until you’re 18.</P> <P>We have also had some vandalism in our community over the past weekend. Suspects blatantly displayed their lack of intelligence by spray painting derogatory comments on the Frontier Sign in the south end and again in the Heritage Park. Black spray paint was used. I am asking that anyone with information to please contact our detachment.</P> <P>We were called to a large grass fire just north of Minnedosa in the valley on Saturday. Probably the largest fire I have witnessed since my days of working with Natural Resources, it took mere minutes for it to travel a mile before jumping Hwy. #10. The highway was closed for a short while because of the lack of visibility and we simply needed the room for the fire suppression equipment and firefighters to concentrate on doing their job safely. I have to commend the multiple fire crews from neighbouring communities, volunteers and everyone involved who banded together and did what needed to be done, saving at least two families from devastation. I am sure words cannot begin to express our thanks.</P>

--30--

Title: 15-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: NDP and Manitobans being lazy
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sun Apr 18 2010   Page: 11   Column: Editorial
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Once again the embarrassing numbers are out showing how awful Manitoba's record is in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. </P> <P>Embarrassing may not describe things aptly enough; abysmal and horrendous is much better. </P> <P>As if a risky taxpayer-funded deal for a new football stadium and running five more years of deficit budgets isn't bad enough, this government is a complete failure on the environment. </P> <P>Environment Canada has just released its annual National Inventory Report, a 582-page document detailing and accounting for the country's GHG emissions. It shows in 2008 -- the most recent data available -- Manitoba's emissions climbed to an all-time high of 21.9 megatonnes (Mt). That's up almost a percentage point over the previous year and roughly 25% above the Kyoto target of 6% below 1990 levels, which the province has pledged in law to reach by 2012. </P> <P>We need to drop our annual emissions by 4.4 Mt to reach the goal. That's equivalent to taking 841,300 vehicles off the road in a province where, according to MPI, there are only 749,522 vehicles. </P> <P>We've come to expect this news every spring. </P> <P>Every year we're told to expect better numbers next year. It's time the province outright said they've failed miserably at reducing emissions. They need to find a whole new strategy. In previous years, former energy minister Jim Rondeau tried to cleverly and colourfully spin the bad numbers. </P> <P>"We found all the things that would be causing the issues and started to address the increases. I see (emissions) trending downwards now," he told the Sun in June 2008. And last year he said "there's been a delay in implementing the programs and seeing the results." Well that's getting closer to the truth. This year, it sounds like someone down on Broadway actually cares. </P> <P>"We're going to have to find ways to get big reductions. That's going to be difficult and expensive and in the current environment that's going to be a challenge too," current environment minister Bill Blaikie said. </P> <P>Obviously the government needs a swift kick in the behind. But so do Manitobans. </P> <P>Curt Hull, project co-ordinator with Climate Change Connection, a provincial environmental group, is right when he blames all of us as well. He says Manitobans are not making the smart choices they must, like taking public or alternative transportation instead of driving gas-guzzling SUVs. </P> <P>The NDP have been out to lunch on creating an effective plan to deal with this, no doubt about it. </P> <P>But it's like the crime rate. </P> <P>Everyone needs to contribute. </P> <P>Don't jump in your car so much, walk instead. Stop being so lazy. Or take a bus. </P> <P>Start now or you're being as inept as the NDP. </P>

--30--

Title: 16-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the Editor column: IMMOBILIZE OUR LEADERS
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Mon Apr 19 2010   Page: 8   Section: Editorial/Opinion
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Re: 'Tamperers beware,' April 15. </P> <P>What a province we live in and what a country. Can't make a dent in car theft, make everyone put in a immobilizer and if the car owner has it bypassed fine them $5,000. That's a heck of a lot more than the thieves get for a punishment. Too many crimes involve guns so make criminals of every citizen who doesn't register their guns. Criminals misuse bear spray so ban all sales, legitimate ones as well as criminal purchases. Here is the final solution, put all the honest citizens in protective custody (jail) and let the criminals and their enablers -- the liberal judges and politicians -- run the streets. </P> <P>GRANT L. HOOKE <BR>BRANDON <BR>You shouldn't have to play with your immobilizer once it's in. </P>

--30--

Title: 17-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Charges laid in fatal rollover
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Saturday, April 17, 2010 | 2:11 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 24-year-old woman has been charged in connection with a fatal rollover in Winnipeg that happened April 4.</P> <P>The crash followed a police pursuit that reached dangerously high speeds, according to reports at the time. Police have not confirmed those reports, but have said that speed would be a part of their investigation.</P> <P>The car crashed and rolled along Century Street in Winnipeg's King Edward neighbourhood.</P> <P>Police said a 28-year-old man died as a result of the 4 a.m. CT crash near the intersection of St. Matthews Avenue and Century. Family members identified him as Jerome Bender.</P> <P>Police said they had stopped the vehicle, prior to the pursuit, for an unspecified traffic violation, but the driver took off.</P> <P>The crash took place a few minutes later.</P> <P>Bender was rushed to hospital in critical condition, but succumbed to his injuries.</P> <P>The female driver required medical treatment for non-life-threatening injuries.</P> <P>The police investigation continued and the charges were announced Friday.</P> <P>Ashley Dineen Klingzahn, 24, has been charged with failing to stop a vehicle being pursued by police, criminal negligence causing death and driving without a licence.</P> <P>She was arrested Friday and detained in custody. No date for a court appearance was announced.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/17/mb-fatal-rollover-charges-10417.html#ixzz0lYD7nlqX">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/17/mb-fatal-rollover-charges-10417.html#ixzz0lYD7nlqX</A></P>

--30--

Title: 18-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Woman charged in car accident that killed partner
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Friday, April 16, 2010 | 8:05 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The 32-year-old female driver of a vehicle involved in a rollover in central Manitoba that killed her common-law husband has been charged with impaired driving causing death.</P> <P>Police have not released the woman's name but said she faces several other charges.</P> <P>The accident happened around 5 a.m. Friday on Highway 10, just east of the community of Swan River, about 450 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.</P> <P>RCMP suspect the wheel of the pick-up truck the woman was driving caught the edge of the road, causing her to lose control. The truck flipped and ended up in a ditch.</P> <P>The driver's 26-year-old partner, who was a passenger, was ejected from the vehicle and later pronounced dead at the Swan Valley Health Centre.</P> <P>Police said the man, who was from Briggs Spur, east of Swan River, was likely not wearing a seatbelt. They did not release his name.</P> <P>The woman was transported to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.</P> <P>She appeared before a justice of the peace and was ordered to return to court June 16.</P> <P>She was released from custody, but one of the conditions of her release is that she not get behind the wheel of a vehicle.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/16/mb-rollover-man-killed-manitoba.html#ixzz0lYDX9anZ">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/16/mb-rollover-man-killed-manitoba.html#ixzz0lYDX9anZ</A></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Aug-13
