Title: 20-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: More Manitoba crime victims claiming funeral costs under government programs
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Tue Apr 20 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ It's a hidden cost of rising crime _ the financial compensation needed to pay the bills for items like caskets or funeral flowers. </P> <P>Statistics from Manitoba Justice indicate more and more families that have lost a loved one to a criminal act are claiming for funeral costs. </P> <P>Families whose relatives are the victim of homicide or of criminal negligence causing death can apply for up to $5,400 for funerals. </P> <P>The Compensation for Crimes program pays up to $100,000 to crime victims, after they make claims for costs ranging from permanent disability, ambulance costs, counselling services or damaged clothing. </P> <P>Approximately $3.8 million was spent compensating victims in 2009/2010, with about $247,600 provided to about 50 families who made claims for funeral expenses. </P> <P>That's a jump from about $152,600 paid out five years ago to 39 families. </P> <P>Curtis Monkman of Prairieland Aboriginal Funeral Home on Selkirk Avenue, said he handled services for at least three of the city's 30 homicides last year. </P> <P>''A loss of a loved one is always traumatic, no matter who it is and where they're from... but victims of crime, it's even harder because it's a sudden death. It's a tragic death, and it's unexpected,'' said Monkman. </P> <P>Compensation of $5,400 won't buy a lavish funeral, but Monkman said he'll design services around the funding available. </P> <P>Holly Kolevris, a court support worker for Manitoba Organization for Victim Assistance _ a non-profit organization that works with victims of crime _ said funeral funding is significant for these families. </P> <P>Many of the families she accompanies to court for homicide trials in Winnipeg live below the poverty line, she said. </P> <P>Two months ago, she started stocking cheap soup in her Osborne Street office so she'd have a way to feed people who couldn't afford cafeteria food and were filling up on coffee. </P> <P>''It's really sad,'' she said. ''I've had so many families who didn't have money for lunchtime. It's like, 'OK, where do I spend my money. Bus fare to get to court or do I buy a coffee?'''</P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance also pays up to $7,467 for funerals for drivers or passengers who die in vehicle collisions. </P> <P>That also extends to Manitoban pedestrians and cyclists who are fatally struck. </P> <P>An MPI spokesman said the non-profit Crown Corporation pays about 120 funeral-related claims annually. </P> <P>(Winnipeg Free Press) </P>

--30--

Title: 21-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Older drivers steer thyselves
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Tue Apr 20 2010 Page: A10
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>There is ample data that show older drivers, especially those who are 80 years and older, have spectacularly high rates of accidents. That data feed directly into the public campaign for mandatory testing whenever an elderly driver causes a spectacular accident. </P> <P>Ontario bent to the campaign and justified it with data in that province that indicated the rate of collisions rises dramatically the closer a driver is to 80 years old and older. Now 80-year-olds in that province are "invited" to an interview at the Ministry of Transportation, where it is decided if further testing is required. Anyone who refuses to show up for the chat forfeits their driving privileges. </P> <P>The clamour for mandatory testing rose again in Manitoba last week when a 93- year-old driver backed over an elderly man, who died as a result. Suggestions include "de-graduating" licences for the elderly, mirroring the restrictions on licences for new drivers, typically the very young, who also have high collisions rates. </P> <P>But Manitoba, like most jurisdictions in North America, has resisted the campaign due to a dearth of reliable studies that examine the factors that link old age and risk -- some researchers warn of an inherent bias in studies that do not control for environment (urban versus highway), as driving in the city is riskier. </P> <P>A 2005 Australian-led study found that when comparing the number of kilometres driven, the risk is elevated only for the elderly who drive less than 3,000 kilometres per year, a group that accounted for just more than 10 per cent of older drivers in the study. </P> <P>The collision data from police in Manitoba indicate young drivers are overwhelmingly much higher risks on the road, but the graph is a poor gauge as it does not consider who was at fault. MPI relies on driving records and reports by physicians and optometrists -- who are bound to report when a physical condition is likely to interfere with driving ability -- and family members when deciding whether to pull someone in for an interview. </P> <P>The population of elderly drivers is rising. Medical and physical conditions are associated with risk on the road, but it is too great a burden to place on doctors to screen for those elderly people who pose a risk. Greater pressure, coupled with an aggressive education campaign, should be put on family members and aging drivers themselves to recognize when deteriorating health may make them dangerous behind the wheel.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Convert your Enhanced Identification Card   To an enhanced driver’s licence at no cost on your first renewal this year
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Sentinel Courier, Pilot Mound, MB Tuesday, April 20, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitobans who have an Enhanced Identification Card (EIC) are reminded that they can trade it in for an Enhanced Driver’s Licence (EDL) at no additional cost on a one-time only basis as part of their first driver’s licence renewal.</P> <P>“There is no charge to the card holder if the conversion is done with their first driver’s licence renewal,” said Marilyn McLaren, President and CEO of Manitoba Public Insurance. “It’s a quick and easy process for the cardholder. The transaction can be carried out at any Autopac agent in Manitoba.”</P> <P>The EDL, which is good for at least five years, is a one-piece licence to drive that has additional enhanced features to meet entry requirements for travelling to the U.S. by land and water only. Under new travel regulations a passport or other approved documents are required to travel into the U.S.</P> <P>Manitobans who don’t have an EIC, but want to upgrade to an EDL can do so at anytime. Those individuals would be required to pay an additional $30 (administration fee) and attend an interview.</P> <P>Manitobans can also at any time convert their current driver’s licence to the new, one-piece driver’s licence.</P> <P>“If they want to convert their licences outside their renewal date, there will be an administration fee of $10,” explained McLaren. “There is no charge if the conversion is carried out with the driver’s licence renewal.”</P> <P>Manitobans who have questions about the new one-piece driver’s licence, enhanced driver’s licence or Manitoba Public Insurance’s new, multi-year renewal system are encouraged to visit their Autopac agent.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 23-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Organ Donation: Something to think about  MPI Press Release
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Sentinel Courier, Pilot Mound, MB Tuesday, April 20, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Families who were committed to seeing the wishes of their loved ones fulfilled led to 26 kidney transplants and four lung transplants being performed in Manitoba last year, according to Sybil Stokoloff, communications coordinator with Transplant Manitoba – Gift for Life Program.</P> <P>All that because people signed their organ donation cards. </P> <P>“Becoming an organ donor is as easy as signing a blue organ donor card,” said Stokoloff. “It takes about two seconds to sign and it’s a legacy which will live on for years and years.” </P> <P>With National Organ and Tissue Donor Awareness Week running from April 18 to 25, Stokoloff said there is no better time to think about becoming an organ donor, take action by signing a blue organ donor card and talk to your family about your decision. In other words: think, sign, tell.</P> <P>“The family discussion is important because you don’t want your decision to be a surprise during a tragic time,” she said. “Educate your family and explain to them that while it may not be right for everyone, it is right for you.”</P> <P>Everyone has the potential to be an organ donor, explained Stokoloff. Generally, organ donors are healthy people who have suffered an injury to the brain resulting in brain death. The health of the donor, not the age, is the most important thing considered.</P> <P>“You have the potential to save many lives when you sign a donor card,” says Stokoloff.</P> <P>The blue organ donation card, which easily fits in a wallet, is available at any Manitoba Public Insurance outlet or Autopac agent, or you can download one from the Transplant Manitoba-Gift of Life Program website at transplantmanitoba.ca.</P> <P>“Donating your organs can change the lives for so many who wait for a second chance at life,” says Stokoloff. “Please sign a donor card and make organ donation your gift for life.”</P> <P>For more information, go to the web site at transplantmanitoba.ca or phone Stokoloff at 787-1897.</P>

--30--

Title: 24-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Dying man's dream on wheels taken from him
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed Apr 21 2010   Page: B1
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>ALL Stefan Bambrick can do these days is laugh. It keeps him from crying. </P> <P>Last Sunday night, Bambrick took his prized possession -- a black 1998 Dodge Avenger he picked up a month ago and had been working on feverishly ever since - - out for the maiden cruise of the season. </P> <P>"It was the first cruise night I was able to enjoy in a long time," an upbeat Bambrick said Tuesday. "It was great. My car got all kinds of looks. I was feeling pretty proud. </P> <P>"My condition usually doesn't allow me to stay out to do these kinds of things, so it was a good time." </P> <P>The sports car is an important part of therapy for the St. James resident, who has terminal cancer. </P> <P>Bambrick, 27, said entering the Avenger in a car show this summer is on his "bucket list," and he was looking forward to showing it off to fellow auto buffs. </P> <P>But now he's been robbed of that opportunity. </P> <P>Following the cruise night, Bambrick decided to crash at his girlfriend's home in the Maples. Just after midnight, he parked his car in the driveway and locked the doors and the couple went to bed. The next morning, his girlfriend woke him up with bad news. </P> <P>"She came back upstairs and told me it was gone," Bambrick said, his tone now serious. "It wasn't forced entry. There was no glass around, so they probably popped the locks. </P> <P>"The worst part about this is that I had an immobilizer appointment (set for) the next day." </P> <P>Pouring money and sweat into the car had been a major distraction for Bambrick, giving him a reason to crawl out of bed in the morning and do something that brings him joy. </P> <P>Bambrick is battling reoccurring melanoma. Two years ago, he had a four-inch area of malignant cells removed from his left cheek and appeared to beat the disease. The cancer has since returned, however, and has spread to his bones and lungs. </P> <P>With treatments unsuccessful -- including a trip to Pittsburgh for an experimental procedure that proved too intense for Bambrick to handle -- doctors say he is in an "incurable situation" and has about seven years to live. </P> <P>"I know I only have a few years left," he said. "That's why this is important to me." </P> <P>Bambrick filed a police report and met with Manitoba Public Insurance Tuesday, but the issue isn't the money -- even though he's dished out about $10, 000 souping up the car. His disappointment comes from having put so much time and energy into the project, only to have someone steal it. </P> <P>And he's not holding his breath for a happy ending. </P> <P>"I have a feeling I'm not going to see it again," he said. "It's probably already been stripped and gutted... I'm sure I've already lost it all. </P> <P>"I'm not angry, I'm more depressed than anything. Being a terminal cancer patient, I'm unable to work and that car was the only thing that was fun for me. "</P>

--30--

Title: 25-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg teen car thief to be sentenced for crash that killed taxi driver
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Tue Apr 20 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ Manitoba probation officials say they repeatedly overlooked breaches of court orders from a teenage car thief in the weeks before he stole an SUV and killed a city cab driver. </P> <P>The admission came Tuesday at a sentencing hearing for the boy, who pleaded guilty to criminal negligence causing death in the March 2008 crash that killed Antonio Lanzellotti. </P> <P>The Crown wants the 16-year-old sentenced as an adult and have requested he serve 23 months of jail. </P> <P>The Winnipeg teen is seeking to remain in youth court and be given eight more months behind bars. </P> <P>Queen's Bench Justice Lea Duval has reserved her decision. </P> <P>Cheryl Dyck, who served as the boy's probation officer, testified he was given probation for previous convictions and was caught violating his curfew, but the incidents were never reported to police. </P> <P>On the night of March 29, 2008, the boy had been drinking and consuming drugs with a large group of youths. </P> <P>When police showed up the youth sped away in a stolen vehicle, driving through two red lights before slamming into the taxi. </P> <P>Lanzellotti, 55, died instantly and a passenger in the cab was seriously injured. </P> <P>The Crown agreed to drop a manslaughter charge in exchange for his guilty plea.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Probation cited in fatal crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed Apr 21 2010   Page: B1
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba probation officials admit they repeatedly overlooked breaches of court orders from a 14-year-old high-risk car thief in the weeks before he got behind the wheel of a speeding, stolen SUV and killed a city cab driver. </P> <P>The admission came Tuesday at a sentencing hearing for the boy, who pleaded guilty to criminal negligence causing death and bodily harm for his role in the March 2008 crash that killed Antonio Lanzellotti. </P> <P>"Probation services gave him enough rope to hang himself," Crown attorney Brent Davidson told court. "If he had just listened to what the court told him to do, Antonio Lanzellotti would still be alive." </P> <P>The Crown is seeking an adult sentence against the teen, who comes from a prominent family of criminals with strong ties to the Mad Cowz street gangs. They have requested another 23 months of jail, in addition to just over two years of time already spent in custody they concede should be given double-time credit. On paper, it would be noted as a six-year sentence. </P> <P>The teen -- who is now 16 and can't be named unless an adult sentence is imposed -- is asking to remain in youth court and be given eight more months behind bars. Queen's Bench Justice Lea Duval has reserved her decision. </P> <P>Cheryl Dyck, who served as the boy's probation officer, testified Tuesday how the teen was originally sentenced on Feb. 8, 2008 on charges including car theft, drug offences and numerous breaches of court orders. The boy was given probation and placed on the most stringent youth criminal supervision program in Manitoba. His conditions included abstaining from alcohol and a nightly 10 p. m. curfew. </P> <P>Dyck admits her department caught the teen violating his curfew on several occasions but never reported the incidents to police, who could have arrested him and detained him in custody on new charges. Instead, they upgraded his status to "high-risk" but allowed him to remain free in the community. Dyck said it's not uncommon to ignore initial violations of young offenders. </P> <P>"Once a pattern of non-compliance is established then we breach the client," she testified. </P> <P>On the night of March 29, 2008, the boy had been drinking and consuming drugs with a large group of youths loitering around a downtown apartment building armed with two stolen vehicles. The group scattered when they saw police headed their way. </P> <P>The boy was driving a Chevy Avalanche containing six other young offenders. He began racing a stolen Silverado that had the other seven youths, court was told. The boy reached speeds of 139 km/h -- the legal limit is 60 km/h -- and blew through two red lights on Portage Avenue before slamming into the taxi being driven by Lanzellotti at the corner of Portage and Maryland Street. </P> <P>Lanzellotti, 55, died instantly. He suffered a massive skull fracture, broken ribs and legs and trauma to his brain and chest. A passenger in the cab was seriously injured. </P> <P>The boy was ejected from the SUV and seriously injured. He initially denied any responsibility, telling police he was innocently walking down the street when he was struck by flying debris. He later admitted to being in the car but claimed another youth was driving. Police got him to admit the truth when DNA off the driver's side airbag was a perfect match to him. The Crown agreed to drop a manslaughter charge in exchange for his guilty plea. </P> <P>Dyck told court the boy has made great progress during his two years in youth custody but remains a medium risk to reoffend. She said his biggest obstacle is his own criminally entrenched family, although several relatives have since been deported to Africa. </P> <P>"He has the ability, we believe, to learn from what happened and benefit from what we're teaching him," said Dyck. "I think he's way better equipped now to deal with the issue he's going to face when he gets out." </P> <P>The Crown supports having the boy serve the rest of his adult sentence in a youth facility because of the various treatment and programming options available to him. But Davidson said the limits of a youth sentence don't express strong enough condemnation for the crime he committed. </P> <P>City police Det.-Sgt. Kevin Kavitch testified Tuesday about the high rate of car theft in Winnipeg at the time of Lanzellotti's death. He provided statistics showing the vast majority of offenders are youths who deliberately try to engage police in high-speed chase, putting all on the road in danger. Kavitch said between Jan. 1, 2006 and the day Lanzellotti died, police in the stolen auto unit arrested 519 people, of whom 417 were young offenders.</P>

--30--

Title: 28-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man dead after crashing stolen ATV
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Wed Apr 21 2010   Page: 17   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 26-year-old Grunthal man has died from injuries sustained in an accident involving two all-terrain vehicles near Steinbach Monday night, including one reported stolen four years ago, RCMP say. </P> <P>Three people were transferred to Health Sciences Centre in Winnipeg, where the man died Tuesday afternoon. </P> <P>RCMP identified the deceased man as Nathan Taylor and say he was operating the stolen ATV. It had been taken from a residence in the RM of Ste. Anne in 2006. </P> <P>Investigators believe speed and visibility are factors in the accident but alcohol is not. </P> <P>The collision occurred on Road 33 East in the Rural Municipality of Hanover about 9 p.m. Steinbach RCMP said a northbound four-wheeler, operated by Taylor, rear-ended a stationary four-wheeler, which was occupied by a Grunthal couple in their 30s. </P> <P>Taylor was wearing a helmet but the others weren't, police said. </P>

--30--

Title: 29-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sentence cab driver killer as adult: Crown
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 16-year-old boy who was behind the wheel of a stolen sport utility vehicle that killed cab driver Antonio Lanzelotti should be sentenced as an adult to six years in prison, a judge was told Tuesday. </P> <P>The boy -- who was 14 years old at the time of the March 2008 crash -- has pleaded guilty to criminal negligence causing death and criminal negligence causing bodily harm. </P> <P>The boy has already served two years in custody. The maximum youth sentence he can get is two years custody and one year community supervision. </P> <P>"A sentence of three years is simply not sufficient to hold (him) accountable," argued Crown attorney Brent Davidson. </P> <P>The boy's probation officer had testified he repeatedly violated a court-ordered curfew and skipped school before the fatal crash. The breaches were never reported to police. </P> <P>Davidson said the boy has shown he is unwilling to accept super vision. "If he simply would have been able to comply with his probation order he would not have been involved in this incident ... (and) Antonio Lanzelotti would still be alive," he said. </P> <P>Defence lawyer Evan Roitenberg said the boy should serve just one more year in custody. "The young man who met with a probation officer and said it was nobody's fault but mine has expressed nothing but genuine remorse," he said. </P> <P>The boy and six other youths were in a stolen Chevrolet Avalanche, racing a stolen Chevrolet Silverado pickup when the Avalanche blew through two red lights and hit Lanzelotti's cab.</P>

--30--

Title: 30-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man dies after crashing ATV into 2 others
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Tuesday, April 20, 2010 | 8:07 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Manitoba man has died from injuries sustained when he crashed his all-terrain vehicle into two parked ATVs near the town of Sarto on Monday, RCMP reported.</P> <P>Police said 26-year-old Nathan Taylor of Grunthal, Man., was pronounced dead in hospital at 3:25 p.m. CT on Tuesday.</P> <P>On Monday, Taylor was speeding on his ATV on Road 33 East in the Rural Municipality of Hanover and crashed into two parked ATVs, police said.</P> <P>The crash sent Taylor, along with the drivers and passengers of the other ATVs flying.</P> <P>Three people in all were taken to hospital in Winnipeg for treatment.</P> <P>Taylor was wearing a helmet when he crashed, police said.</P> <P>They did not describe the nature of the injuries the other ATV riders sustained or say what condition they are in.</P> <P>The ATV Taylor was riding was reported stolen in 2006, police said.</P> <P>The investigation into the incident is continuing.</P> <P>Sarto is located 61 kilometres southwest of Winnipeg.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/20/man-atv-crash-dies-taylor.html#ixzz0ljslZC8l">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/20/man-atv-crash-dies-taylor.html#ixzz0ljslZC8l</A></P>

Title: 31-Aug-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Fatal ATV collision near Sarto
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 26 year old man from Grunthal has died as a result of injuries he received Monday night after an ATV collision on Road 33 East in the RM of Hanover near Sarto, Manitoba.</P> <P>Steinbach RCMP report an ATV traveling at a high rate of speed struck two parked all terrain vehicles.</P> <P>Nathan TAYLOR, another man and a woman were transported to hospital for treatment. Taylor succumbed to his injuries Tuesday afternoon at the Health Sciences centre. Police have determined the ATV operated by Taylor had been stolen from the RM of Ste. Anne in 2006.</P> <P>Excessive speed and visibility were factors in the collision.     An investigation is continuing.</P>

Title: 1-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Have your say
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed Apr 21 2010   Page: A11
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Autopac rates unfair </P> <P>I just purchased car insurance for a 1994 Honda Civic. I bought for $500. My basic insurance was $630 with merit discount. Registration was $117, plus $35 PST. This is absurd. Autopac, the sole provider, is not providing a competitive rate for its long-time customers. Go ahead. Place ads on the Cop Chop. I'll pay for it. </P> <P>J. THOMAS TIERNEY <BR>Winnipeg </P> <P><BR>Old-aged drivers </P> <P>RE: Death raises concerns over aging drivers' ability, April 17. Older drivers bring maturity, responsibility, judgment and experience to the road. The effects of aging, however, may take their toll on physical and mental capabilities. Older drivers will likely outlive their driving ability. There is a need for older drivers and their families to become aware of the driving and transportation options available to them. </P> <P>The Transportation Options Network for Seniors informs and educates Manitobans on the transportation options. Studies show more people fear losing their drivers licence over getting cancer. </P> <P>Considering your transportation options early is important for maintaining independence and healthy aging. </P> <P>LISA TINLEY <BR>Transportation Options Network for Seniors</P>
