Title: 3-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Making a mockery of justice
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Thu Apr 22 2010   Page: A3   Section: Top Story
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The court records lay out the breaches of his probationary order in mind-numbing detail. </P> <P>All told, a 14-year-old high-risk offender was able to thumb his nose at the law 24 times without any consequences, making a mockery of court orders and exposing a provincial policy to overlook breaches. The revelations surrounding the latest twist in the city's war with deadly car thieves now has Manitoba's justice minister on the defensive, arguing probation officials properly handled the high-profile case that ultimately led to tragedy. </P> <P>"Frankly, if a kid is five minutes late for an appointment with a probation officer, or a kid because of his home life is late for school one day, I don't think Manitobans want that to be a reason for more criminal charges to be laid, " Andrew Swan said Wednesday. </P> <P>The teen -- who can't be named under the Youth Criminal Justice Act -- has pleaded guilty to driving the speeding, stolen SUV that killed city cab driver Tony Lanzellotti on March 29, 2008. His probation officer told court this week they failed to report numerous breaches by the youth in the weeks preceding the deadly crash because they regularly give young offenders plenty of discretion. </P> <P>The Free Press has learned of at least 24 incidents between Feb. 15 and March 27 where the youth was in violation of a judge's Feb. 8 order -- including 18 days of skipping school and six examples of ignoring his nightly curfew. None of the violations was ever reported to police, which could have resulted in him going back into custody. </P> <P>Manitoba Tory Leader Hugh McFadyen said Wednesday Lanzellotti might be alive today if the court order had been properly enforced. </P> <P>"That should just be a no-brainer," McFadyen said. "Those ones have to be enforced immediately on the first breach. No tolerance, no leeway, no discretion whatsoever." </P> <P>But Swan said he supports having a probation officer's "professional judgment" determine when a young offender is reported to police for violating a probation order. </P> <P>Cheryl Dyck, the youth's probation officer, told court Tuesday how they will only report breaches to police if there is a "pattern of non-compliance." Crown attorney Brent Davidson, who is seeking an adult sentence of six years for the killer teen driver, suggested that will likely come as a surprise to many in the justice system, including the judges who hand down such orders. </P> <P>"Have you ever seen a judge issue a discretionary probation order, where they leave it up to the accused whether they want to comply with it all of the time or just some of the time?" Davidson asked. </P> <P>"I can't speak to the guidelines we follow," replied Dyck. Davidson later told court probation services gave the teen "enough rope to hang himself." </P> <P>Dyck said offenders are often treated differently, depending on their risk level and criminal history. In this case, the youth began as a medium risk but was upgraded to high after his supervisors started catching him breaching probation. </P> <P>Dyck said the boy's father initially called Feb. 25 to say he was regularly ignoring his curfew by fleeing the house after checking in nightly with probation officials. Dyck said they agreed to call a meeting but that never happened until March 26. By then, the youth had already been caught on five other occasions out past curfew and several times had missed school, which he was required to attend. </P> <P>Dyck said he abided by his curfew on the nights of March 26, 27 and 28. </P> <P>"He was at home and got back on track," she told court. On March 29, the boy called in to say he was home on time -- then fled the house as his father had previously reported. He began drinking and consuming drugs with a large group of youths loitering around a downtown apartment building armed with two stolen vehicles. The group scattered when they saw police headed their way. The boy was driving a Chevy Avalanche containing six other young offenders. He began racing a stolen Silverado that had the other seven youths, court was told. The vehicle the teen was driving reached speeds of 139 km/h -- the legal limit is 60 km/h -- and blew through two red lights on Portage Avenue before slamming into the taxi being driven by Lanzellotti at the corner of Portage Avenue and Maryland Street. </P> <P>Lanzellotti, 55, died instantly. He suffered a massive skull fracture, broken ribs and legs and trauma to his brain and chest. A passenger in the cab was seriously injured. </P> <P>The issue surrounding the level of discretion probation officers have in not breaching an offender was the hot-button topic in question period at the Manitoba legislature Wednesday. The Opposition Progressive Conservatives grilled Swan and Premier Greg Selinger over what they said was a symptom of the NDP's mismanagement of the province's justice system. But Swan told reporters the federal Youth Criminal Justice Act, and how it handcuffs law enforcement and the courts in locking up bad kids, was to blame. </P> <P>"We all struggle, frankly, with the Youth Criminal Justice Act," he said. "Every provincial government, whatever political stripe, has been calling on the federal government to take steps so that individuals who we believe are committing serious and violent crimes aren't released back onto the streets, which is what happens, unfortunately in our view, in too many cases." </P> <P>Swan added he's asked his officials to look at how other provinces monitor young offenders on bail or probation, and if any further changes should be made to how Manitoba does it. Swan said a zero-tolerance policy on breaches, as the Tories have demanded, is not on the horizon. "There is not a single province in Canada that has gone down that path," he said. "We manage risk. One could say there should be no bail anywhere. There could be no parole federally. No government has moved down that road. The important thing is for our probation officers to manage the risk of people in the community." </P> <P>Swan said over the past year, probation officials have brought in a new system to better monitor high-risk violent and repeat offenders. </P> <P>"They will then receive more attention from probation services and make it more likely breaches will be found and there will be a remedy out there," he said. </P> <P>The teen, who is now 16, is asking to remain in youth court and be given eight more months behind bars. Queen's Bench Justice Lea Duval has reserved her decision until later this spring.</P>

--30--

Title: 4-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba Tories slam Doer government over car thief's probation breaches
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Wed Apr 21 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ The Manitoba Tories are slamming the Justice Department over the handling of a teen who was driving a stolen SUV that crashed into a taxi, killing the driver. </P> <P>Antonio Lanzellotti, 55, died and a passenger was injured in the crash in Winnipeg in March 2008. </P> <P>In December 2009, the teen pleaded guilty to charges of criminal negligence causing death and criminal negligence causing bodily harm. </P> <P>The teen's probation officer testified at his sentencing hearing Tuesday that her department caught the teen violating his curfew a number of times, but didn't report those breaches to police. </P> <P>Tory Justice critic Kelvin Goertzen told the legislature Wednesday that Lanzellotti might still be alive if probation officers had reported the breaches of the teenage auto thief, who was 14 at the time of the fatal crash. </P> <P>Premier Greg Selinger replied that the probation department has changed the way it operates in the past year. </P> <P>``The department now follows a new risk management approach where they allocate additional, more intensive resources to cases that are considered to be high risk,'' said Selinger. </P> <P>Goertzen said the teen ``who was breaching his orders might have been sitting in a jail cell instead of racing down Portage Avenue in a stolen vehicle'' had probation officers reported the breaches. </P> <P>Tory Leader Hugh McFadyen said it was the Justice Department's ``policy of neglecting these situations and failing to enforce court orders that directly led to this very sad and significant tragedy.'' </P> <P>The family of another man who died after a stolen vehicle crashed into his car said a tougher stance is needed. </P> <P>Kamil Andrzejczak's father Zdzislaw died after his car was hit by a stolen Hummer in December 2009. </P> <P>Andrzejczak said he's angered about multiple breaches by car thieves being allowed and said only one breach should be considered acceptable. </P> <P>He also said that not reporting breaches teaches young offenders that there are no consequences for their actions. </P> <P>The province said it is not currently considering a zero tolerance approach, something the opposition said should be adopted. </P> <P>The Crown is hoping to raise the teen in the Lanzelloti case to adult court. The judge has reserved her decision. </P> <P>The Crown agreed to drop a manslaughter charge in exchange for his guilty plea. </P>

--30--

Title: 5-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: One person taken to hospital after MVA
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One person was taken to hospital in unstable condition Wednesday afternoon following a two vehicle collision at Arlington street and Selkirk avenue..</P> <P>Police say a pick-up truck hit a car just after 3:30pm.    The car narrowly missed hitting a nearby Drug store.</P> <P>The accident tied up traffic for a couple of hours.</P>

--30--

Title: 6-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Have Your Say: Stolen sticker
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri Apr 23 2010   Page: A15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Once again the honest consumer takes the hit for the criminal. This weekend I noticed my Autopac sticker was stolen off my plate! Who thinks of doing that? </P> <P>I drove around most of the weekend paranoid that I might be stopped and, God forbid, ticketed for this missing sticker. </P> <P>I proceeded directly to an Autopac dealer Monday afternoon to ensure that I had the sticker replaced, only to find out that I had to pay $15 to get a new one! </P> <P>So I pay my outrageous insurance premium every year, I pay my deductible if I am vandalized and I pay $15 for a $2 sticker because it is the responsible thing to do, unlike stealing someone's sticker off their plate. </P> <P>Why is the consumer penalized for obeying the rules? Aside from it being a pure money grab, it is a sure-fire way to ensure that the dishonest people are out driving. When they kill someone, who will pay their liability to that family? </P> <P>My guess is not MPI if the insurance is invalid. </P> <P>VICKI GOWER <BR>Winnipeg <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Mr. Swan defends too much
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri Apr 23 2010   Page: A14
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>There are breaches of probation orders and serious breaches of probation orders and there are patterns of breaches that reveal a non- compliance serious enough to call in the police. At face value, the 14-year-old car thief who pleaded guilty to killing a Winnipeg cabbie while on a joyride fits two points of that bill. He should have been reeled back into court before he got behind the wheel the night of March 29, 2008, and sent the SUV speeding down Portage Avenue with lethal force. </P> <P>Justice Minister Andrew Swan, under fire for his department's handling of this case, insists minor breaches cannot be reason to turn in a youth on probation. Tory Opposition Leader Hugh McFadyen fired back at Mr. Swan for the way the system mishandled the youth, giving him enough rope not to hang himself, but to kill an innocent man. </P> <P>Both men are right, but they are also both wrong. Mr. Swan ought to recognize the discretion exercised by the probation officer and the leniency provided to the youth led to a needless tragedy. Mr. McFadyen, meanwhile, insists Manitoba needs to impose zero tolerance on repeat car thieves and throw the book at them whenever they break court-ordered conditions of probation. </P> <P>Mr. McFadyen's position is unworkable and unnecessary. A high-risk youth on probation who is late for school (using Mr. Swan's example) is not a proven risk to the public but he is technically in breach of a court order. The issue with the 14-year-old is apparent -- he broke his conditions 24 times. His repeated truancies should have been warning enough the stringent supervision and program he was under was not enough; the numerous occasions in which he phoned his supervisor from home to comply with his 10 p.m. curfew and then bolted -- even after his father reported to probation on his late-night sojourns -- ought to have triggered a call to the police long before his probation officer decided to ratchet up monitoring shortly before March 29. </P> <P>The justice minister believes that the officer worked appropriately, that probation services need the discretion to exercise judgment in these cases. While it is difficult to argue with the latter point, at least in the abstract, this particular case gives a worrisome peek into the workings of the system, which the minister believes is not under undue stress. If caseloads are not the issue, then case management is, at least in this case. </P> <P>Mr. Swan says there have been changes in the last year that will result in better monitoring of high-risk, violent and repeat offenders, making it more likely breaches will be detected. He also blames the Youth Criminal Justice Act, which the province has repeatedly criticized as too lenient on car thieves and other young offenders. </P> <P>The fact is in this case it is difficult to point the finger at the YCJA because there were abundant opportunities to return the car thief to court. His return date with a judge came woefully late. If this wasn't considered a case of a serious breach, then Mr. Swan needs to explain, by his department's policy, what is. Then a serious talk can happen about necessary reforms that, short of rewriting the YCJA, could keep the public safe from young offenders who feel free to thumb their noses at the law because of weaknesses in a probation system that is supposed to ensure they comply with it.</P>

--30--

Title: 8-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: NDP targets probation rules
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri Apr 23 2010   Page: A3   Section: Top Story
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Attorney General Andrew Swan on Thursday ordered a meeting of Manitoba's top law enforcement officials to deal with questions surrounding how probation officers monitor high-risk young offenders. </P> <P>Swan said the meeting between himself, Winnipeg police Chief Keith McCaskill, RCMP assistant commissioner Bill Robinson and senior Crown and probation officials will happen as soon as can be arranged. </P> <P>News of the meeting came on the second day of a political firestorm sparked by the sentencing hearing for a 16-year-old boy who's charged with driving a stolen SUV that ran a red light and slammed into a taxi driven by Tony Lanzellotti, killing him instantly on March 29, 2008. </P> <P>The Free Press reported Thursday the boy, a repeat car thief, violated a probation order against him 24 times without anyone taking action over his repeated breaches. </P> <P>The opposition Progressive Conservatives say the revelation exposes a policy by probation officers to overlook breaches rather than holding young offenders immediately accountable. </P> <P>Swan said the meeting will air out any problems with how probation is enforced. </P> <P>"We want their advice on the best way we can do that in a way to make sure offenders comply with court orders and also preserve public safety," Swan said. </P> <P>The Tories say there are similar cases of probation officers turning a blind eye to offenders who are in breach before going on to commit another crime, but Swan said he could not speak to that. </P> <P>Swan also said provincial court judges, the people who sign probation orders, will not be part of the meeting as the focus will be on how such orders are enforced. </P> <P>"The system is not perfect and it needs to be improved," Swan said. </P> <P>Progressive Conservative Leader Hugh McFadyen said the top-level meeting smacked of NDP damage control. </P> <P>"They're late to the game," McFadyen said. </P> <P>"They've known about the facts of the Lanzellotti case and issues with probation services as we understand it now for more than a year. So it's quite clearly being done after media outcry, after public outcry." </P> <P>McFadyen said Swan should immediately order a directive that a the province have a zero-tolerance policy when it comes to monitoring high-risk young offenders on probation. </P> <P>Swan has already said a zero-tolerance policy won't work and that probation officers should have discretion when to "breach" an offender. </P> <P>Cheryl Dyck, the youth's probation officer, told court Tuesday they will only report breaches to police if there is a "pattern of non-compliance." </P> <P>Crown attorney Brent Davidson, who is seeking an adult sentence of six years for the teen driver, suggested that will likely come as a surprise to many in the justice system, including the judges who hand down such orders. </P> <P>The teen is asking to remain in youth court and be given eight more months behind bars. </P> <P>Queen's Bench Justice Lea Duval reserved her decision until later this spring. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teen drivers endorse MPI driver ed program
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Nine of 10 Driver Education students say the course helped them to be a more careful driver, according to a survey conducted by Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI).</P> <P>The telephone survey polled Driver Education students and their parents about the program they had recently completed.</P> <P>The survey was conducted last November and reported the following:<BR>• More than nine in 10 teen drivers agree that the Driver Education course is valuable training for new drivers and would recommend the Driver Education course to their friends.<BR>• More than eight in 10 agree that young drivers who take the Driver Education course are more skilled than young drivers who do not take the course.<BR>• More than half agree that if they had not taken the Driver Education course, they would have had more accidents by now.</P> <P>“Driver experience and providing a solid base of safety are key components to properly preparing our teen drivers,” said Lou Gervino, Manager of Driver Education and Training with MPI.</P> <P>“This survey confirms that our program is accomplishing its goals and objectives both in the classroom and within the car. The Driver Education Program incorporates best practices from other jurisdictions and continuously reviews the program.”</P> <P>Program began in 1966<BR>The High School Driver Education (HSDE) program has existed since 1966 and has been administered by Manitoba Public Insurance since 1987 with the support of partner organizations and Manitoba high schools. The program is designed to raise awareness in young drivers of road safety issues and teach them the appropriate skills for driving on Manitoba roads.</P> <P>All full-time Manitoba high school students over the age of 15-1/2 are eligible to attend the program, explained Gervino. Students receive 34 hours of in-class instruction, eight hours of behind-the wheel training and eight hours of in-car observation.</P> <P>Every year over 12,000 Manitoba high school students participate in the program which is offered in 150 high schools across the province.</P> <P>“Overall, youth have a high regard for the benefits and outcomes associated with the HSDE Program,” said Gervino. “The survey also confirmed that adults have a high degree of awareness of the program and share a high regard for the benefits and outcomes associated with it.”</P> <P>Some of the adult responses were:<BR>•Nine in 10 adults agree that the program is valuable training for new drivers and that they would recommend the Driver Education course to their friends and the program helps students be more careful drivers.</P> <P>•More than eight in 10 adults agree that young drivers who take the Driver Education course are more skilled than young drivers who do not take the course.</P> <P>“A key component of the Driver Education Program is parental involvement and assisting the young driver to gain driver experience,” said Gervino. “The Driver Education Program is continuously evolving to mirror the challenges which drivers face on a daily basis.”</P>

--30--

Title: 10-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI announces enhanced license upgrades
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance has announced licence upgrades that should lead to a smoother drive — at least when it comes to navigating red tape.</P> <P>Manitobans who have an Enhanced Identification Card can trade it in for an Enhanced Driver’s Licence at no extra cost on a one-time only basis.</P> <P>“There is no charge to the card holder if the conversion is done with their first driver’s licence renewal,” said Marilyn McLaren, president and CEO of MPI.</P> <P>The EDL, which is good for at least five years, is a one-piece licence that has additional enhanced features to meet entry requirements for travelling to the U.S. by land and water only.</P> <P>Under new travel regulations, a passport or other approved documents are required to travel into the U.S. </P> <P>Manitobans who don’t have an EIC can upgrade to an EDL at anytime, but they will be required to pay an additional $30 administration fee and attend an interview.</P> <P>Manitobans can also convert their current driver’s licence to the new, one-piece licence at any time.</P> <P>“If they want to convert their licences outside their renewal date, there will be an administration fee of $10,” McLaren said. “There is no charge if the conversion is carried out with the driver’s licence renewal.”</P> <P>Anyone who has questions about the new one-piece driver’s licence, enhanced driver’s licence or MPI’s new, multi-year renewal system should contact their Autopac agent.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg police investigate whether homicide, stolen vehicle hit-and-run related
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Sat Apr 24 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ Winnipeg police are investigating whether the city's latest homicide may be linked to a stolen vehicle that reportedly struck a pedestrian, a cyclist and a police cruiser in a bizarre hit-and-run. </P> <P>Police say a man was discovered lying in the street with stab wounds around 4 a.m. and later died in hospital. </P> <P>Relatives have identified the victim as Ronnie Kakegamic, a 21-year-old father of three. </P> <P>Emergency crews found Kakegamic laying on a curb bleeding heavily. </P> <P>``They were pumping his chest, he wasn't breathing at all,'' said witness Robert Thacker. </P> <P>Paramedics tried to use CPR to revive the victim but he died after being rushed to hospital in critical condition. </P> <P>Family members say Kakegamic was at a house party on Flora Avenue when he was allegedly attacked. </P> <P>``He just came out of nowhere and started fighting with him,'' said the victim's aunt Pauline Meekis as she recalled the scene. </P> <P>Meekis said she and other family members returned inside of the house and didn't see what happened next. </P> <P>It is believed Kakegamic, bleeding badly, managed to get on a bike and pedal away. </P> <P>The injured victim went several blocks before collapsing. </P> <P>Witnesses say a large group of people were gathered around the man when police and paramedics arrived. </P> <P>According to police several people were taken into custody. </P> <P>No charges have been laid. </P> <P>Just an hour before the stabbing, police were chasing a stolen car that had been involved in a number of hit and runs in the same area. </P> <P>The suspects were caught after ramming a police cruiser. </P> <P>Police are investigating whether there is a link between the two incidents. </P> <P>Over a dozen people have been taken in for questioning in connection with the two incidents. </P>

--30--

Title: 12-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: When the story won't go away
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sat Apr 24 2010   Page: A16   Section: Top Columnist
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The call came, as I expected it, first thing in the morning. The woman's voice was soft and polite and determined. She is a relative of Antonio Lanzellotti, the man who was killed two years ago by a kid driving a stolen SUV. </P> <P>She has called the newsroom before, asking us to stop running Mr. Lanzellotti's photo. She has always been polite, she has always spoken with intelligence and the conviction that comes from a strong moral compass. </P> <P>This time, she wanted to buy the rights to a Free Press photo: the one that depicts the two mangled vehicles -- one of them Mr. Lanzellotti's taxicab -- at Portage Avenue and Maryland Street March 30, 2008. </P> <P>It was the scene of a terrible crime. </P> <P>The other vehicle in the picture, a Chevy Avalanche, had been stolen less than 48 hours earlier. A 14-year-old auto thief had been at the wheel, high on drugs and booze, showing off for his friends packed into another stolen vehicle. He blew through two red lights on Portage Avenue, reaching speeds of 139 km/h before crashing into Mr. Lanzellotti's cab at that intersection, instantly killing the 55-year-old father and seriously injuring his passenger. </P> <P>The young woman called to buy that crash-scene photo so that it would never be published again, so her family would stop feeling the pain that image wields. </P> <P>There are many good days to be in the news business. </P> <P>This was not one of them. </P> <P>This was a day when you say things like "it's a news photo," "it's on the public record," "it's simply not something we can ignore." A day you invoke other public photos invoking private grief -- the Challenger explosion, the Crystal Taman roadside memorial, the cherubic face of Phoenix Sinclair. </P> <P>What you cannot say is that you will stop writing the stories, and printing the photos. </P> <P>Mr. Lanzellotti was killed just months after Winnipeg's preposterously high auto-theft rate began to decline. We in the "auto theft capital of Canada" suffered through long months when cars were getting stolen about every 30 minutes. </P> <P>Though the numbers were at long last declining in the spring of 2008, the behaviour of the young car thieves appeared to be getting even more reckless, according to police. Youths were goading them into dangerous car chases, they said, thumbing their noses at authorities and a system that bore no consequences. </P> <P>The night that Mr. Lanzellotti was killed, 14 young people were packed into the two stolen vehicles. </P> <P>The Free Press launched a year-long investigation of this particular fatal crash and all of the youths arrested. Three of the paper's best reporters followed those kids as they slowly plowed through the Manitoba court system, to chronicle how they fared. The story ran March 29, 2009. It revealed that, of the 14, most ended up being given supervised probation and a few weeks in custody (on top of time already spent in jail). One is already back in jail, in fact, charged with driving a stolen Hummer that struck and killed another innocent Winnipeg motorist Dec. 11, 2009. </P> <P>The reporters know all of these kids' names, where they live, where they went to school. Because of the Youth Criminal Justice Act, their names or their photos or their criminal records -- anything that might identify them -- cannot be published. That's why a headline Wednesday laboriously referred to the "boy who killed the cabbie." </P> <P>That's why all that remains, ironically, in the public domain is the victim's name, the victim's face, and the scene of this terrible crash. </P> <P>"I'm so sorry," I told the woman on the phone. It does not help to say this. </P> <P>You're sorry the family has suffered this great loss, you're sorry that the media continues to pick at a scar that can't heal. You're sorry that yet again you have used a painful image to illustrate a painful story. </P> <P>But this story -- now a matter of public record, shaping public policy, the target of public outrage -- will not go away. </P> <P>This week it hit the news because the Crown is seeking to have that 14-year- old driver given an adult sentence of another 23 months in jail, which is tougher than he would get as a now-16-year-old young offender. The teen's lawyer is seeking eight more months behind bars. </P> <P>During the sentencing hearing, the teen's probation officer testified that in 2008, just weeks before the fatal crash, the boy had been placed on the most stringent youth criminal supervision program in the province. </P> <P>And then he proceeded to breach that probation -- 24 times -- before getting behind the wheel of that stolen SUV and forever changing the Lanzellotti family's life. </P> <P>Every parent knows the basic rules of disciplining a child. Consequences matter. </P> <P>Without them, any punishment is meaningless. This youth continually flouted the law, and got away with it right up until he limped away from that horrific crash. </P> <P>We cannot pretend it didn't happen. We cannot dismiss it like one of the young offenders did when she heard that Mr. Lanzellotti had died. </P> <P>"Wrong time, wrong place," she shrugged. "It's not like it's a big deal anyways." </P> <P>That one photo of Mr. Lanzellotti puts a face to a terrible loss. The images of the crash scene have the power to instantly convey the enormity of the offence. Photos bear witness, and have us all bear witness, to the fact that this was very much "a big deal." </P> <P>That is why I cannot promise the paper will stop investigating the story of how one man died and 14 got away. And it's why I cannot promise the paper will stop running those photos. They are part of the public record, and the only images that document this crime. </P> <P>I can only promise we will try to be as sensitive as we can. We don't use photos gratuitously, and we will not in future. We'll use them, however, when the story can't be told without them. </P> <P>We believe we are doing this for the right reasons. </P> <P>But that's cold comfort to the people who loved and lost Mr. Lanzellotti. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Rollover won't result in charges
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Sat Apr 24 2010   Section: Local
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>No charges are pending for a rollover that sent a Brandon man and a two-year-old child to hospital. </P> <P>A 2004 Chevrolet Venture van was heading east on Highway 45 on Tuesday afternoon when it hit the shoulder. The driver over-corrected, police said, and the van rolled several times before coming to a rest in the ditch. </P> <P>A 21-year-old man, a passenger in the vehicle, and a two-year-old child were rushed to the Health Sciences Centre in Winnipeg. </P> <P>Police said the child had non-life-threatening injuries but, as of the evening of the crash, the man was in intensive care. </P> <P>The 26-year-old woman who was driving the van didn't require hospitalization. </P> <P>Both adults were wearing seatbelts and the child was properly restrained in a car seat, police said. </P> <P>No one was ejected from the vehicle. </P> <P>Alcohol and road conditions were not factors. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver arrested after hitting tree
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Sat Apr 24 2010   Section: Local
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 45-year-old man was arrested for drunk driving after the driver of a vehicle struck a tree, fled the scene and was found lying in a ditch nearby, police say. </P> <P>Around 3:50 a.m. yesterday, a taxi driver reported a that a vehicle collided with a tree at the corner of 34th Street and Pacific Avenue. The vehicle had sustained significant front end damage, and the driver was gone when police arrived. </P> <P>The canine unit was called to the scene to assist in locating the driver out of concern for the person's welfare. </P> <P>The man was located in a ditch a short distance away. The driver showed signs of intoxication and refused medical attention for possible injuries to his upper body. </P> <P>The suspect was arrested for impaired driving and supplied breath samples more than three times the legal blood-alcohol limit. </P> <P>The suspect, who is from Germany, is to appear in court next week. </P>

--30--

Title: 15-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Heckuva magic trick ; Man thwarts cuffs, crashes cruiser -- with cop inside
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>What's this guy's next trick going to be? </P> <P>In a contortionist-like move, a flexible Alberta man slipped his handcuffed hands -- which were behind his back -- under his bottom half to the front of his body so he could steal a Winnipeg police car during a bizarre incident Friday, police allege. </P> <P>The man allegedly took the marked cruiser, a Ford Crown Victoria, and a police officer on a short but wild ride before crashing into a concrete wall in an alley in Weston about 9 a.m. </P> <P>Here's the twist -- police had the man, a suspected john, and a female passenger, a suspected sex-trade worker, in custody because they were drinking and allegedly caught in a sex act in a parked car, sources say. </P> <P>The crash occurred in a back lane between the 1200-block of Alexander Avenue and the wall of an industrial park, just east of Winks Street. </P> <P>The suspect's rental car, a Chevrolet Cobalt, was stopped in the alley on the west side of Winks. Police would only say there was alcohol consumption going on within the car. </P> <P>The man, who allegedly gave police a fake name, was put in the back of the police car, which belongs to the central traffic unit, while officers spoke to the female. </P> <P>That's when the man pulled his Houdini-like escape. </P> <P>"He wiggled the handcuffs under his butt and pulled his legs through so he could get his arms in front of him," a source said. </P> <P>The man climbed between the bucket seats -- this police car is one of few without a plastic dividing shield -- to the driver's seat, where he started the ignition with keys left inside, according to information provided by police and sources. </P> <P>Police spokeswoman Const. Jacqueline Chaput said a male officer hopped in the passenger seat as the man peeled out at a high rate of speed. The man allegedly assaulted the officer as the pair struggled for control of the wheel, Chaput said. </P> <P>The cruiser veered into a concrete wall about a block away, causing significant damage to its front end. </P> <P>The suspect was injured when he struck his head on the windshield, Chaput said. </P> <P>The officer suffered hand and leg injuries, sources said. </P> <P>Chaput said the outcome could have been worse had the officer not intervened. She said charges are pending against the man, whose name wasn't released. </P> <P>Police didn't say if the female will be charged as well. </P>

--30--

Title: 16-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Woman hit by truck dies
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sat Apr 24 2010   Page: 10   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 42-year-old woman was killed when she was struck by a vehicle while walking on a highway in northern Manitoba late Tuesday, RCMP say. </P> <P>Mounties didn't release the woman's name. She was a resident of Cross Lake, about 520 km north of Winnipeg. </P> <P>RCMP said the collision occurred on Provincial Road 374 about 11 p.m. </P> <P>The woman was walking when she was struck by a westbound 2001 GMC Sierra pickup truck driven by a 50-year-old man from the area, police said. </P> <P>Visibility was limited due to darkness and blowing dust, RCMP said. Alcohol and speed are not considered factors, police said, and no charges are anticipated. </P> <P>Just the day before, Anthony Allan Halcrow was stabbed to death at a home in Cross Lake. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen car 'crime spree' ended in early a.m. crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sun Apr 25 2010   Page: 3   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A stolen car tore a path of destruction through the core area and North End early Saturday, hitting a pedestrian, a cyclist, a police cruiser and possibly a taxi in separate collisions before cops collared its driver and passengers. </P> <P>The mayhem began after the vehicle was stolen about 2:40 a.m. in the 400-block of Maryland Street by a group of suspects, who took the car on what police Insp. Kendra Rey described as a "crime spree" involving a number of hit-and-run crashes. </P> <P>Police chased the suspects during part of their rampage, which saw the car ram a cruiser just before 4 a.m. around the intersection of Selkirk Avenue and Powers Street -- right about the time cops and paramedics responded to a fatal stabbing about a block away. </P> <P>Police didn't say whether the incidents are connected. </P> <P>Amber Williams came out of her home on Pritchard Avenue -- near where the slain 21-year-old man had collapsed after being stabbed -- about 6 a.m. </P> <P>"This whole area was full of cop cars," she said. "I can't believe we slept through this." </P> <P>After striking the police cruiser on Selkirk Avenue, said Rey, the stolen vehicle became "inoperable" nearby and cops were able to apprehend its occupants. </P> <P>No one involved in any of the collisions was seriously injured, Rey said, adding police are investigating the incident.</P>

--30--

Title: 18-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Have Your Say: Unlicensed
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Mon Apr 26 2010   Page: A11
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I drive down Pembina Highway daily and have noticed an increasing number of cars driving around with no licence plates in view -- at least two cars per day on Pembina alone in the hour or so I am out. </P> <P>I find this even more disturbing as many of these cars are speeding or driving recklessly in traffic. </P> <P>Is this because there are fewer police cars on the streets because photo radar cameras are doing the job catching the violators (well, not the ones with no plates)? </P> <P>I am amazed people have the guts to drive around town without a licence plate but I guess there is little fear of getting caught. </P> <P>Some days I see the same car or truck as the day or week before so I know there isn't anyone catching these particular people. </P> <P>Pay attention to the number of vehicles being operated without plates this week. You may be shocked. I think it is time for more police presence on our busiest roads. </P> <P>LORI NOVAK <BR>Winnipeg <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Head-on collision injures two
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two people were transported to hospital in critical condition after a head-on collision between two cars on St. Mary's Road south of the Perimeter Highway on Sunday morning. </P> <P>The two sedans collided about four km south of the intersection at approximately 6:40 a.m., sending both drivers to hospital. Both remained in hospital in stable condition Sunday afternoon. </P> <P>St. Mary's Road remained closed between Courchaine and Richardson roads -- a stretch that extends into the Rural Municipality of Richot -- until about 2:30 p.m., Winnipeg police said in a media release. </P> <P>Police said it appears one car was headed north on St. Mary's and the other south when one crossed into the opposite lane of traffic. </P> <P>Both drivers, an adult man and woman, were the sole occupants of their respective vehicles. </P> <P>Police are investigating the collision. </P> <P>It's the second serious motor vehicle crash in less than two months on the curvy stretch of road. During the early morning hours of Feb. 28, 18-year-old Tyler Dacquay was killed when his pickup truck collided with another truck head-on at almost the same spot on St. Mary's Road. The 20-year-old driver of the other pickup survived with minor injuries. </P> <P>"Another accident? That's a dangerous spot," said an area resident who was forced to find a detour by the police road block late Sunday morning. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: St. Mary's Rd. near Floodway re-opened after collision
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>St. Mary's Road near the floodway has been re-opened to traffic, following a horrific head-on collision early Sunday morning...</P> <P>Around 6:40 am, two vehicles travelling in opposite directions on St. Mary's Rd collided when one vehicle crossed into the oncoming vehicle's lane. </P> <P>The lone occupants of both vehicles are reported in stable condition in hospital.</P>

--30--

Title: 21-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Victim slain minutes after averting death
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Tue Apr 27 2010   Page: A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE city's latest homicide victim escaped death once early Saturday morning, but it caught up to him minutes later. </P> <P>Minutes before medical officials and police found stabbing victim Ronnie Jeffery Kakegamick bleeding in the street, the young man fled from two teenage boys who went on an unrelated stolen car spree, said police. </P> <P>On Saturday at about 2:40 a.m., police said, two teenage boys bear-sprayed an 18-year-old man in a Pontiac G6 on the 400 block of Maryland Street before taking off in the car. An hour later, police said, the stolen car hit another car on the 400 block of Ross Avenue. </P> <P>The thieves then sped towards the North End where they hit another cyclist and veered towards another group of cyclists, said police, almost hitting them. One of those cyclists was Kakegamick, who managed to flee the stolen car but ended up in a fight on Flora Avenue after he escaped. Police said a 17-year-old boy stabbed Kakegamick after the two got into a verbal argument and he collapsed at about 4 a.m. near Powers Street and Pritchard Avenue. Kakegamick later died in hospital, leaving a pregnant girlfriend and three small children. </P> <P>"I don't recall ever seeing an incident quite like this," said Winnipeg Police Service spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen. Kakegamick was the city's fifth homicide victim of the year. </P> <P>Michalyshen said Kakegamick said was "minding his own business" when the stolen car targeted him and other cyclists he was with. He also said Kakegamick's stabbing was not linked to the car theft, which was "traumatizing" for those involved and also could have had disastrous results. </P> <P>"Thankfully, I'm not reporting any more severe injuries," he said. </P> <P>Friends have set up a public Facebook group looking for donations to help pay for Kakegamick's funeral expenses. </P>

--30--

Title: 22-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man accused of stealing cop car
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Tue Apr 27 2010   Page: 17   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Charges have been formally laid against a 28-year-old man who allegedly stole a Winnipeg police cruiser during an arrest last week. </P> <P>Police said a handcuffed suspect was able to steal the car when he slipped the cuffs under his bottom half to bring his hands in front of him while he was in the back seat. </P> <P>He then climbed between the cruiser's bucket seats to the driver's seat, police said. Being a central traffic unit vehicle, it didn't have a plastic dividing shield. </P> <P>The keys were in the ignition. An officer hopped in the passenger seat to stop the suspect and was taken on a short but wild ride as the pair struggled for control of the wheel before the car crashed into a concrete wall. </P> <P>The incident occurred in a back lane in the 1200-block of Alexander Avenue on Friday at 9 a.m. </P> <P>Officers came upon the male and a female in a rental car, which was parked in the back lane. The male gave police a fake name, was arrested and put in the cruiser's back seat. </P> <P>He and the police officer were injured in the crash. </P> <P>Torben Timothy Campbell, 28, of no fixed address, is charged with theft over $5,000, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle causing bodily harm, assaulting a peace officer, two counts of uttering threats, and other offences. </P>

--30--

Title: 23-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Leila Avenue reopens after crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Monday, April 26, 2010 | 3:47 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A serious car crash involving a pedestrian caused police to close eastbound Leila Avenue between Watson Street and McPhillips Avenue on Monday afternoon.</P> <P>Police had asked motorists to avoid the area, but said at 3: 40 p.m. that the street had reopened.</P> <P>Police have not commented on any injuries in the crash, but media reports said a woman in her 60s was injured and rushed to hospital in unstable condition.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/26/man-leila-crash-avoid.html#ixzz0mJ07J0QK">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/26/man-leila-crash-avoid.html#ixzz0mJ07J0QK</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 24-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teens used car as a weapon: police
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Monday, April 26, 2010 | 2:42 PM CT   CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police Monday described a chaotic rampage by teenagers in a stolen car in the city's North End on Saturday.</P> <P>They were using the car as a weapon, police said.</P> <P>Police said an 18-year-old was in his car on the 400 block of Maryland Street when a group of teenagers smashed the car window, sprayed him with beer, hauled him out and then beat him up.</P> <P>They then took his car and went on a rampage through the city's North End, hitting a taxi and a police cruiser, and actually aiming at pedestrians and cyclists, hitting one man on a bike, police said.</P> <P>"They were driving the vehicle in a dangerous manner, at high rates of speed, and with no regard for public safety — in fact well beyond that," said Const. Jason Michalyshen.</P> <P>In a tragic coincidence, Ronnie Kakegamic, 21, was among a group of cyclists they tried to crash into with the car.</P> <P>Not long after that, he was stabbed to death in what appears to be an unrelated incident.</P> <P>Meanwhile, two boys aged 15 and 16 face a long list of charges in connection with the stolen vehicle.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/26/northend-chaos.html#ixzz0mJ0Ycoic">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/26/northend-chaos.html#ixzz0mJ0Ycoic</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Charges laid in police car theft
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Monday, April 26, 2010 | 3:38 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police announced charges on Monday against a man who they say stole a police cruiser and crashed it, injuring an officer and himself in the process.</P> <P>Torben Timothy Campbell of no fixed address has been charged with a slew of offences including theft over $5,000, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle causing bodily harm and assaulting a peace officer.</P> <P>Police allege that on Friday, a 28-year-old suspect was being held in the back of a cruiser car on Alexander Avenue when he managed to wriggle his handcuffed hands out from behind him, crawl into the driver's seat and put the vehicle in drive.</P> <P>An officer jumped in the car as it sped off in an effort to stop the escape.</P> <P>The cruiser smashed into a concrete fence, injuring the suspect, who required a trip to hospital.</P> <P>An officer in the passenger seat also suffered non-life-threatening injuries in the crash. He remains in hospital, police said.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/26/man-cruiser-car-arrest-charges.html#ixzz0mJ0gjb9G">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/04/26/man-cruiser-car-arrest-charges.html#ixzz0mJ0gjb9G</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Court to rule on PUB-MPI spat
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed Apr 28 2010   Page: A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE Public Utilities Board is seeking help from the courts to get more information about Manitoba Public Insurance's operations. </P> <P>Earlier this month, the PUB asked the Manitoba Court of Appeal to rule on whether it can require MPI to disclose overall revenues and costs. </P> <P>MPI only wants to provide costs and revenues relating to the provision of basic Autopac insurance, while the PUB wants everything -- including services in which MPI competes with the private sector. </P> <P>Brian Smiley, a spokesman for MPI, said the corporation believes in the PUB's rate-setting role, adding that it "results in true accountability and transparency." </P> <P>"Our opinion is that we're fully complying with how the legislation is written," Smiley said. </P> <P>In the legislature Tuesday, the Tories accused the Selinger government of wasting tax dollars by allowing a court battle to occur instead of simply directing the Crown corporation to be accountable. </P> <P>"They (the PUB) shouldn't have to go to court to get information that properly belongs to the public," Conservative Leader Hugh McFadyen said afterwards. </P> <P>Andrew Swan, the minister responsible for MPI, defended the auto insurer's refusal to disclose information that would compromise its competitive position.</P>

--30--

Title: 27-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: PUB asks Appeal Court to pry open MPI's books
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Wed Apr 28 2010   Page: 3   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Public Utilities Board is turning to the courts in its fight to open part of the books belonging to Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>For over six years, the provincial regulatory body has been requesting to see financial data on the public auto insurer's non-regulated competitive areas of business, including MPI's optional extended lines of insurance. </P> <P>On April 16, the PUB filed its case with the Manitoba Court of Appeal. </P> <P>'Better decision' </P> <P>"We've asked the court to state whether or not they agree with the board to require MPI to disclose the corporation's actual and projected financial information," said PUB associate board secretary Hollis Singh. </P> <P>The PUB, which regulates MPI's basic Autopac rates, argues MPI's refusal to open the books is forcing the regulator to accept MPI's word on its financial situation. Singh said all MPI's expenses and assets -- whether in regulated or non-regulated divisions -- are co-mingled. </P> <P>"This would help the board make a better decision," Singh said. </P> <P>In its 2004 and 2005 rate applications, MPI had provided the PUB with the disputed data and the auto insurer also in those years transferred excess retained earnings from the extension lines of insurance into its basic, regulated division. Both the disclosure and the transfers have since ceased. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said the corporation believes the unregulated side of its operations are not the PUB's business. </P> <P>"We absolutely believe in the (regulatory) process," Smiley said. </P> <P>"We fully comply with what legislation requires us to disclose." </P> <P>When questioned in the house about the court case by Tory MLA Mavis Taillieu Tuesday, Justice Minister Andrew Swan, who is responsible for MPI, said the corporation's position "is quite reasonable." </P> <P>"I certainly respect the work the PUB does in dealing with monopolies, but MPI has a competitive line of business." Swan later said outside the house that MPI has every right to have that information protected. </P> <P>Tory Leader Hugh McFadyen disagreed. "It's a public company. It belongs to the people of Manitoba. There's no reason at all for the government and MPI to be as secretive as they are being."</P>

--30--

Title: 28-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Utilities board and Manitoba Public Insurance square off in court
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press - Broadcast News   Wed Apr 28 2010   Section: Western Regional News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - The Public Utilities Board is seeking help from the courts to get more information about Manitoba Public Insurance's operations. </P> <P>Earlier this month, the PUB asked the Manitoba Court of Appeal to rule on whether it can require MPI to disclose overall revenues and costs, as well as corporation policies and decisions. </P> <P>MPI only wants to provide costs and revenues relating to the provision of basic Autopac insurance. </P> <P>However, the PUB wants information on everything, including services in which the public insurer competes with the private sector. </P> <P>Brian Smiley, a spokesman for MPI, said the corporation believes in the PUB's rate setting role, adding that it ``results in true accountability and transparency.'' </P> <P>The Opposition Tories are accusing the government of wasting tax dollars by allowing a court battle to occur instead of simply directing the Crown corporation to be accountable.</P>

--30--

Title: 29-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Struck by SUV, boy recovering
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Wed Apr 28 2010   Page: 14   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A seven-year-old boy is recovering after he was struck by an SUV in Winnipeg on Monday night, city police say. </P> <P>The collision occurred on Broadway near Honeyman Avenue, on the fringe of West Broadway and Wolseley, about 9:20 p.m. </P> <P>Police said the boy was walking across Broadway from north to south at a crosswalk when he was struck by a westbound Hyundai Santa Fe. </P> <P>The boy, who was with at least one adult, was rushed to hospital in unstable condition but was later upgraded to stable. </P> <P>As part of the investigation, police are looking into whether the crosswalk's lights were activated and functioning properly, if the boy crossed when it was safe to do so, and whether there was any fault on the driver, a 31-year-old woman. </P> <P>There is no indication at this point the driver did anything wrong, police said. </P> <P>Broadway's westbound lanes were closed until about 11:45 p.m. as officers investigated. </P> <P>The boy was one of two pedestrians struck by vehicles at controlled crosswalks in Winnipeg on Monday. </P> <P>In the afternoon, a 69-year-old woman was struck by an eastbound Mercury Marquis car on Leila Avenue, just west of McPhillips Street, in front of Seven Oaks General Hospital. </P> <P>She was initially in unstable condition but was upgraded to stable. The car was driven by a 64-year-old man, police said. </P> <P>Charges haven't been laid in either incident. Police continue to investigate both matters. </P>

--30--

Title: 30-Sep-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver held after chase
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Wed Apr 28 2010   Page: 8   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A male is in custody after he allegedly led Winnipeg police officers on a brief chase, which ended when a stolen car was rear-ended by a police cruiser Tuesday afternoon. </P> <P>Police spotted the car, a 2009 Pontiac G5, near Charles Street and Anderson Avenue and tailed it, resulting in a brief pursuit, said spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen. </P> <P>Officers arrested the male driver after the car was rear-ended by a cruiser on Charles Street near Church Avenue in the North End about 1:20 p.m. </P> <P>No one was seriously injured, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>Charges are pending against the stolen car's driver, he said. </P> <P>Michalyshen said the car was reported stolen from the St. Boniface area on Tuesday between 11:20 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. </P>

--30--

Title: 2-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Fatal accident near Brandon under investigation
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Brandon RCMP are investigating a fatal accident Wednesday at a commercial business in the R-M of Daly at the old Air Force base just outside Rivers.. </P> <P>Police say just prior to noon an employee was working on a roof of an old Hanger building when he fell about 7 meters. </P> <P>The man was transported by Ambulance to the Brandon Regional Health Center where he succumbed to his injuries shortly after 1:00 P.M. </P> <P>The 58 year old Male, from the Rivers area, was a long time employee of Devonridge Farms. His name has not been released.</P>

--30--

Title: 3-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Top Story
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Thu Apr 29 2010   Page: A3   Section: Top Story
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>They were promoted as a new weapon in the province's war on youth crime, a high-tech way to keep track of the worst young offenders. </P> <P>However, less than half of those outfitted with the electronic tracking devices kept them on to complete their probation. </P> <P>Justice Minister Andrew Swan says figures tracking the success of the GPS- equipped tracking devices since April 2008, show of the 49 teens outfitted with the electronic monitors, 29 removed them before the completion of their term. Two kids removed their devices four times. </P> <P>Swan said the electronic monitoring was only meant to be a pilot project -- it's not a final answer to how probation officers and police monitor high-risk youths living under a court order. </P> <P>"The technology is not perfect," Swan said. "We know there are young offenders who remove the bracelets, some of them more than once. That's a frustration." </P> <P>The province has spent $540,000 on the monitoring project in the past two years and has budgeted $310,000 for 20 kids to wear the anklets this year. The province bought 20 anklets at $2,500 each. </P> <P>Swan said the province has asked a researcher from the University of Manitoba to determine whether it's getting a bang for its buck. </P> <P>U of M criminology professor Rick Linden, who is overseeing the project, said the anklets should only be seen as "one tool in the toolbox." </P> <P>He said the research underway is compiling data on the number of breaches recorded for kids ordered to wear the anklets and the number of breaches for kids who did not. They will also be interviewing many of the kids who wore the anklets. </P> <P>Linden said in other cities, the anklets were not a fix-all. </P> <P>"It's not going to be the major cure to auto theft or anything else," Linden said. "The resource isn't just the cost of the monitors. You've also got to have the resources to respond quickly. It may be that extensive probation is more cost-effective. We don't know yet." </P> <P>The U of M study should be finished in June. </P> <P>Swan said he did not know yet if it will be released to the public. </P> <P>"Once we have that information that'll inform us whether we continue the program at its current level, whether we expand the program or whether we go in a different direction," he said. </P> <P>The NDP brought in the anklets two years ago under pressure from the Progressive Conservatives to do more to cut down Winnipeg's high auto theft rate. </P> <P>Then justice minister Dave Chomiak said at the time the anklets would also allow officials to monitor chronic car thieves much in the same way as phoning them or knocking on their door to make sure they're living up to court-imposed curfews. </P> <P>The belt and ankle-bracelet devices allow an offender to be released from custody as long as the offender follows court orders. The specifics of the order are programmed into the GPS tracking software, such as where the offender lives, works or goes to school. Any deviation from that will signal a nearly instant violation, allowing police to be dispatched. </P> <P>The anklets form part of the Winnipeg Auto Theft Suppression Strategy, which is now into its fourth year and responsible for a 70 per cent drop in car theft since 2004. </P>

--30--

Title: 4-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Radar aim exposed ; Reports show it's not safety, just profit
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Thu Apr 29 2010   Page: 5   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The city's photo radar profits fell dramatically in 2009 after the Winnipeg Sun exposed last year how photo enforcement officers were ticketing motorists in construction zones when there was no risk to workers. </P> <P>The new data comes from the city's 2009 photo enforcement annual report released Wednesday which also shows a massive spike in speeding tickets issued by police through conventional means. </P> <P>Photo radar infractions skyrocketed in 2008 to 118,692 in part because police began aggressively targeting construction zones, even when no workers or safety concerns were present. </P> <P>Controversy </P> <P>The Sun stories in the spring of 2009 exposing the misuse triggered a firestorm of controversy with then justice minister Dave Chomiak and Mayor Sam Katz vowing to crack down on confusing speed limit signs and inappropriate use of photo radar. </P> <P>Within months, photo radar tickets began to fall. And according to the annual report, tickets were down 44% last year compared with 2008. </P> <P>Last year the number of photo radar infractions issued from mobile vehicles dropped to 66,383. </P> <P>The number of speeding infractions from intersection cameras was also down in 2009, but only slightly to 34,611 from 38,620 in 2008. </P> <P>The drop in photo radar tickets resulted in a steep revenue decline for the city last year. Profits from photo enforcement plummeted to $4.9 million, down from a peak of $8.8 million the year before -- the largest photo enforcement jackpot the city has experienced since the launch of the program in 2003. </P> <P>Meanwhile, in obvious anticipation of the revenue decline following the photo radar controversy, police ramped up speeding tickets handed out the old fashion way. </P> <P>Speeding tickets issued through conventional means soared last year 44% to 21,977, up from 11,441 the year before. It's by far the highest number of conventional speeding tickets issued by police since the city began issuing photo enforcement reports in 2004. </P> <P>The report does not say how much more revenue that raised for city coffers. </P> <P>So, is photo enforcement truly about safety, or is it about the money? </P> <P>The focus certainly seems to more on revenue than safety. </P> <P>For example, for the sixth year in a row, the city's photo enforcement annual report provides no data whatsoever on whether the implementation of photo radar has reduced collisions or injuries. </P> <P>The stated objective of the program expressed in the annual report is to "reduce collisions and injuries by reducing red-light running and excessive speeding." Yet the report again contains no data to show how photo radar has achieved that in the areas deployed, including in construction zones. </P> <P>The report continues to provide collision data where the 12 original intersection cameras were installed to compare year-over-year statistics. But that data is only police-reported collisions and doesn't include crashes reported to Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>A Winnipeg Sun investigation last year showed collision rates reported to MPI at the 12 intersections were substantially higher than what the city was reporting to the public. </P> <P>Looks like this thing continues to be more about cold hard cash than safety. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man charged in stolen vehicle rampage
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A third person has been arrested in connection with a stolen vehicle that was taken on a rampage in Winnipeg last weekend.</P> <P>A 30-year-old man has been charged with robbery with a weapon, unauthorized possession of a weapon, mischief and possession of weapon for a dangerous purpose.</P> <P>He has been detained in custody.</P> <P>Two boys, aged 15 and 16, were arrested shortly after the incident and face a long list of charges.</P> <P>According to police, a group of people approached an 18-year-old man who was in a car on the 400 block of Maryland Street around 2:30 a.m. Saturday.</P> <P>They allegedly smashed out a window then bear sprayed the driver and pulled him from the car.</P> <P>They allegedly beat him up then stole the car and drove around the city's North End, hitting a taxi and a police cruiser, and aiming the vehicle at pedestrians and cyclists, hitting one man on a bike, police said.</P> <P>The 18-year-old man who was beaten and sprayed was treated in hospital for upper body injuries and later released.</P> <P>Police did not provide information on the condition of the cyclist who was struck by the car.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Boy crashes ATV, injuring 3 cousins ; No helmets; 2-year-old in intensive care
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Fri Apr 30 2010   Page: 7   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Three children are in hospital, including one in intensive care, after an all-terrain vehicle crash near La Broquerie Wednesday. </P> <P>The ATV was apparently being operated by a 13-year-old male who was carrying three young relatives as passengers on the gravel Twin River Road in the RM of La Broquerie when it crashed about 6 p.m. Wednesday. </P> <P>Steinbach RCMP said the passengers were all siblings who were cousins of the operator, including a 10-year-old girl and her two brothers, aged one and two. </P> <P>The two-year-old boy remained in the Winnipeg Children's Hospital intensive care unit Thursday. </P> <P>The ATV operator and his one-year-old cousin also remained in the same hospital in stable condition. The female passenger was treated and released Wednesday from a hospital in Ste. Anne. </P> <P>According to Mounties, all the children reside in the RM of La Broquerie. </P> <P>RCMP said none of the youths on the ATV were wearing helmets when they were thrown during the single-vehicle accident. </P> <P>The accident occurred on the gravel road between the town of La Broquerie and Marchand about 65 kilometres southeast of Winnipeg. </P> <P>RCMP are continuing to investigate the incident. </P> <P>Under the province's Off-Road Vehicle Act, people must wear helmets while operating ATVs and the vehicles are not allowed to be driven on public roads. </P> <P>Children are also required to be supervised by adults while operating off-road vehicles.</P>

--30--

Title: 7-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Safety official urges more prevention and training
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri Apr 30 2010   Page: A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>AN ATV crash Wednesday involving four children raised the hackles of the head of Manitoba's safety organization, who's been waiting five years for the province to lay down the law. </P> <P>"This is a horrific situation but at the end of the day we as a province need to start to look at some of the things we could do to put basic guidelines in place to prevent this kind of stuff," said Mike Waite, executive director of Safety Services Manitoba. </P> <P>In 2005, Safety Services was part of a group that asked the provincial government to establish tougher standards around the licensing and training of drivers of off-road vehicles such as ATVs and snowmobiles, vehicle registration and the enforcement of any new legislation. </P> <P>"That's gone absolutely nowhere," Waite said Thursday. </P> <P>"We'd spent a great deal of time putting it together," he said. "It identified all the challenges... It said you have to be trained and a have registered number on the (ATV)," he said. </P> <P>In the meantime, the number of ATVs in Manitoba nearly doubled to 21,000 in 2008 from 11,000 in 2004. </P> <P>"Other provinces have moved in this direction and tightened up controls," he said. "Unfortunately, we have not." </P> <P>In the meantime, Safety Services continues to offer ATV rider programs. The problem is, the people who need it aren't signing up, said Waite. </P> <P>"It's frustrating, from a safety service provider's perspective," he said. "Rarely do we get participation from families." </P> <P>The next ATV rider course is May 29 in Stonewall, for those 14 and older. For information, contact Safety Service Manitoba at 949.1085, 1-800-661-3321 or go to safetyservicesmanitoba.ca </P>

--30--

Title: 8-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: ATV crash sends four kids to hospital
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri Apr 30 2010   Page: A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>LA BROQUERIE -- Some skid marks, some broken twigs and a few RCMP footprints -- that's all that's left now to mark the site where four young children flew off an ATV driven by a 13-year-old boy. </P> <P>It could have been worse. </P> <P>At 6 p.m. on Wednesday, Steinbach RCMP were called to the scene of the crash on Two Rivers Road, where a one-seat ATV loaded with children had careened off the dirt-and-gravel path. Injured in the accident were the 13-year-old driver and his passengers, a 10-year-old girl, a two-year-old boy and a one-year-old infant. None of the children was wearing a helmet. </P> <P>By Thursday, the girl had been released from Ste. Anne Hospital. The other children were still being treated at Health Sciences Centre, where two were in stable condition and one was in the intensive care unit. Although RCMP couldn't confirm the type of injuries sustained, Steinbach RCMP Cpl. Rob Lasson said the lack of helmets "played a big factor in their injuries." </P> <P>In front of the family's home, on a lawn studded by a stroller and children's toys, sat another ATV, emblazoned with a factory sticker announcing it was not to be driven by anyone under age 16, the law in Manitoba for four- wheel-drive vehicles. For all other ATVs, children under 14 cannot operate the vehicle except under the supervision of a parent or adult guardian. Helmets are also legally required. </P> <P>As to why this particular ATV was being operated by a child without a helmet, a man at the family's home couldn't say. But he did offer some good news: the kids in hospital were doing "all right," and their parents were finding faith to carry them through. "They're doing good that I know of," said Mike James, who identified himself as the brother of one of the children and uncle of the others. "They pray, they go to church and believe in God." </P> <P>The children usually wore helmets while riding ATVs, James said. He was not at the home at the time of the accident and did not know why the kids weren't wearing helmets on Wednesday night or how the children came to be driving the vehicle. </P> <P>Up and down Twin Rivers Road, residents said they only heard about the crash from media reports. One man, who lives near the crash site, said he often saw a young boy driving an ATV up to his driveway, but that the child usually drove no more than "six or seven miles an hour." Still, the man said the idea of allowing young children to control the vehicles concerned him. "I certainly wouldn't let my kids be doing that," he said. </P> <P>RCMP are investigating how the 13-year-old driver came to be driving four children around in an ATV designed to seat only one and how he lost control of the vehicle. It's not an easy incident to investigate. The aftermath of the crash, which came only nine days after another ATV accident in the area killed 26-year-old Nathan Taylor, was difficult for the attending police to process. "There's a lot of emotions involved," Cpl. Lasson said, "for RCMP as well as for the family." </P> <P>Lasson hopes education will make it so RCMP don't have to see more children injured like that again. "You have a 12-, 13-year-old kid (driving), and you can get (ATVs that are) 1,000 CCs now," he said, noting that it's "becoming more acceptable" for people to drive ATVs around rural roads, including kids under parental supervision. "We want to try and educate people to abide by the laws of the Offroad Vehicle Act... but it doesn't always work and tragedies like this occur." </P>

--30--

Title: 10-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 4 children hurt in ATV crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Four children — aged one, two, 10, and 13 — were sent to hospital after crashing an ATV in southeast Manitoba.</P> <P>The children were all thrown from the machine, which was being driven by the 13-year-old boy. None of them were wearing helmets, RCMP said.</P> <P>The incident happened at about 6 p.m. on Twin Rivers Road in the Rural Municipality of La Broquerie, about 55 kilometres southeast of Winnipeg.</P> <P>The 10-year-old, a girl, was transported to Ste. Anne's hospital where she was treated and released. The other three children — all boys — are still being treated at Winnipeg's Health Sciences Centre.</P> <P>The teen and the one-year-old are in stable condition but the two-year-old is listed in intensive care.</P> <P>The cause of the accident is still under investigation and no additional information is available.</P> <P>The RCMP are stressing the importance of abiding by the laws of the Off-Road Vehicle Act, which requires people to wear helmets and not operate off-road vehicles on public roadways.</P> <P>Wednesday's crash occurred just nine days after 26-year-old Nathan Taylor was killed when his ATV crashed into two parked ATVs near the town of Sarto, about 60 kilometres southwest of Winnipeg.</P>

<P>Your Minnedosa members picked up the pace by responding to 31 calls for service this past week. If<BR>you happen to see someone hopping along on one crutch, kindly inform them to hop on up to the detachment.
