Title: 14-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Too soon to scrap bracelets
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sun May 2 2010   Section: Editorial/Opinion
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Just more than a year ago local police and government officials celebrated Winnipeg's first "auto-theft-free" day with much of the credit given to Manitoba's auto-theft-suppression strategy, and notably its ankle-bracelet monitoring program. </P> <P>This controversial pilot project -- in place since 2008 -- sees the most serious chronic teen auto thieves outfitted with the GPS-equipped bracelets, while they serve their sentences in the community. The devices are tracked by satellite and sent to a monitoring station. </P> <P>If this device is tampered with or the teen leaves a specified area, officials and police are notified. </P> <P>It's way too early to determine if it's worked here in Manitoba despite critics consistently ridiculing the program and laughing at the government every time a teen removes one. </P> <P>It's an excellent way to track these punks and prevent them from stealing over and over again. </P> <P>It's only been in place two years. How could anyone possibly measure its success in such a short time? </P> <P>Recent musings by Justice Minister Andrew Swan that he might pull the plug on the program are troublesome. Nobody should have concluded it would be perfect. </P> <P>Why this sudden change of heart by Swan? </P> <P>It's because recent statistics reveal that nearly 60% of young offenders ordered to wear a bracelet took it off, forcing police to hunt them down and rearrest them. </P> <P>That's prompted Swan to ask researchers from the University of Manitoba to study whether taxpayers' money is being well spent with this program. </P> <P>But you can look at it another way. Almost half did not and have been closely monitored. </P> <P>A poll in Friday's Winnipeg Sun showed 60% of the respondents think the province should keep the program. </P> <P>And the opposition Conservatives do too, saying it works and pointing out many other jurisdictions are expanding their programs. </P> <P>They cite a recent in-depth study from the U.S. Department of Justice that shows electronic monitoring significantly reduces reoffending rates across all age groups. That study examined 22 years of electronic monitoring in Florida. </P> <P>Less than three years is too soon to end this program. If the NDP do end it, what do they replace it with? You need some sort of monitoring program or we'll just revert back to having these punks stealing cars right and left, with no one keeping track of them. </P> <P>Government's are notorious for giving up on good ideas for political reasons. </P> <P>Swan's right to get a report card on this. </P> <P>But he shouldn't cave in to pressure to end it.</P>

--30--

Title: 15-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Charges laid in car chase
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sat May 1 2010   Page: 4   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Charges have been laid against a Winnipeg man who allegedly stole a car, led police on a brief high-speed chase and caused a three-vehicle crash Thursday. </P> <P>Police said it's a case of good fortune no one was seriously injured given the high speeds and danger to the public. At one point the man behind the wheel of the stolen car drove onto a sidewalk near pedestrians in an attempt to elude officers, police said. </P> <P>The ordeal began when officers spotted the stolen Saturn, which had stolen Alberta licence plates, near Portage Avenue and Arlington Street at about 10:50 a.m. </P> <P>The car wasn't reported missing by its owner -- the suspect's girlfriend or female friend, who didn't give him permission to use it -- but the plates were entered into a computer system and matched a truck, police said. </P> <P>Officers tried to stop the car, which wasn't registered or insured, but the male driver took off, reaching speeds of 80 km/h or more, and drove recklessly, police allege. </P> <P>A brief pursuit was abandoned due to safety concerns. </P> <P>The stolen car got into a crash with two other vehicles on St. Matthews Avenue near Strathcona Street a short time later. </P> <P>Police said the suspect ran away but was apprehended in a yard nearby. He was allegedly in possession of a small amount of prescription pills, which he doesn't have a prescription for. </P> <P>Michael Ryan Duke, 24, is charged with several offences, including theft under $5,000, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle and flight from police.</P>

--30--

Title: 16-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Pay insurance or take the bus
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: National Post   Sat May 1 2010   Section: Financial Post Investing
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I think of my car insurance like a utility bill. I have to pay it. My only other choice is to sell my car and take the bus. Frankly, I'd rather freeze in the dark. </P> <P>That car-or-bust attitude leaves me at the mercy of auto insurance companies who can jack up my rates at their discretion. Every traffic accident or traffic fine is not just an immediate hit on my household income, but a potential black mark for years to come. </P> <P>But even with a perfect driving record, can I escape rate hikes? The perception among most consumers is that car insurance rates are always on the rise. </P> <P>They are basically right. Automobile insurance rates were up 5.5% in March from a year ago, Statistics Canada says. The overall consumer price index was up only 4% during the same period. </P> <P>Go back a decade and you'll find auto insurance prices have risen 67%, while the consumer price index is up about 22% over the same time frame. </P> <P>"We are pretty much sitting at a high level. It's not the all-time high, but pretty close," said Daniel Cheung of Statistics Canada. </P> <P>Is there anything you can do about it? "You can shop around," says Jim Davidson, a car broker and owner of carsmart.ca."I suggest you should contact insurance companies directly if you are looking for the cheapest quote you can find." That advice seems a little strange -- a car broker suggesting people avoid insurance brokers. "Yes, it's a little funny for me to say. Their rates are a little higher, but people get other advantages from dealing [with insurance brokers]. It's one-stop shopping for all your needs. " </P> <P>He suggests that before you even buy your car you should try to get an estimate of what the insurance will be. "You can do all that online now," says Mr. Davidson. </P> <P>There may be no way to avoid accidents, but you can prevent them from becoming part of your driving record. "Pay for the little stuff out of pocket," says Mr. Davidson. </P> <P>Anything under $1,000 counts as little stuff. And since you are paying for everything under $1,000, the deductible -- the amount of money you have to pay out of pocket before making a claim--should be less than $1,000. </P> <P>Henry Blumenthal is vice-president and chief underwriter at TD Insurance. He says there are a number of factors that determine your auto insurance rate, starting with where you live. </P> <P>"It depends on what we project in terms of accident risk and severity and all those things," he says, adding rates are lower in rural areas than congested cities. </P> <P>Anti-theft systems in your vehicle are another way to lower your premium. "In Quebec, it can lower your premium by up to 25%. If you are in Montreal, you are close to the port, the most exposed area [in Canada] for auto thefts. Thieves put the cars in a container and they are gone. We've seen our cars show up in Africa and they haven't even taken the plate off," Mr. Blumenthal says. </P> <P>"As a general concept, females are better drivers than males," says Mr. Blumenthal, adding there is one age group among females that is considered higher risk, but he won't identify the group. </P> <P>So, I can move to the country, get a cheaper car, pay for an alarm system, get a sex change -- or watch my rates go up. At least I can shop around.</P>

--30--

Title: 17-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Tories put crime bills back on table;
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The North Bay Nugget   Mon May 3 2010   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Conservative government is re-introducing three key crime bills this week after previous versions of the bills were killed when Prime Minister Stephen Harper prorogued Parliament earlier this year. </P> <P>Among the bills will be the government's drug bill, which caused controversy when it was last introduced for seeking to impose mandatory six -month sentences for people convicted of growing five or more pot plants. </P> <P>Senators changed that bill , much to the disappointment of Justice Minister Rob Nicholson, who will introduce the drug and auto theft bills back into the Senate this week. </P> <P>"They had most of last year to deal with our drug bill," Nicholson said. "The auto theft bill sat there for over six months so they've had the bill issue for quite some time so they should be able to deal with it expeditiously." </P> <P>Nicholson says that while he was unsuccessful in getting the drug bill through the Senate "the way we wanted it" last time he will put pressure on the opposition parties to keep his tough-on-crime provisions intact this time with the help of newly appointed Tory senators. </P> <P>The third bill, dealing with white-collar crime, will be introduced into the House of Commons.</P>

--30--

Title: 18-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Ankle bracelets: Program works in U.S., Tory says
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press  By: Bruce Owen   1/05/2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Print E–mail Share This Report Error Manitoba would have better success at monitoring high-risk car thieves wearing GPS-equipped electronic ankle bracelets if it put more resources into the program, Manitoba's Progressive Conservatives say.</P> <P>Tory justice critic Kelvin Goertzen said the experience in the United States shows electronic monitoring works in reducing re-offence rates for all levels of offenders across all age groups.</P> <P>He cited a recent study done by the Center for Criminology and Public Policy Research at Florida State University, which examined the 22-year history of electronic monitoring in Florida.</P> <P>It found electronic monitoring reduces the likelihood of an inmate failing to follow a community supervision court order. The reduction in the risk of failure is about 31 per cent, relative to offenders placed on other forms of community supervision, the study found.</P> <P>It also said approximately one in three offenders under electronic monitoring would have served time in jail if not for the electronic surveillance option available to the courts. Given that it costs six times more to jail an offender in a Florida state prison than to put them on electronic monitoring, the study found the bracelets to be a cost-effective way of dealing with many offenders. It recommended expanding the program.</P> <P>Florida has used different forms of electronic monitoring for more than 25 years. Last year, it had 2,933 offenders on GPS electronic monitoring.</P> <P>By comparison, Manitoba has up to 20 young offenders under electronic monitoring at any given time.</P> <P>Goertzen said the success of electronic monitoring depends on having the police resources available to respond quickly to breaches. Offenders who remove or tamper with the anklets must also face stiffer penalties.</P> <P>The province's electronic bracelet monitoring program has been under fire after the Free Press reported a probation officer allowed a high-risk young offender to return to the community without wearing a court-ordered electronic ankle bracelet.</P> <P>Attorney General Andrew Swan recently released figures that indicate the benefit of electronic monitoring is mixed at best. Since April 2008, 29 of the 49 high-risk young offenders fitted with the monitors removed them before the completion of their terms. Two of the teens removed their devices four times. Swan said the NDP has recruited a University of Manitoba researcher to review the program which will cost taxpayers $850,000 over three years.</P> <P>Manitoba's program is similar to one run in Nova Scotia, which has used electronic monitoring on adult and young offenders since 2006. Last year, the Nova Scotia Department of Justice said electronic monitoring has, "shown to be an effective tool to assist in the monitoring of appropriate high-risk youth on house arrest."</P>

--30--

Title: 22-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police car smashed in morning chase
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press  By: Staff Writer   4/05/2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - Police are investigating an early morning car chase that ended with two cars smashed and at least one person injured.</P> <P>The incident apparently started about 7 a.m. with a vehicle speeding through an alley near the intersection of Boyd Avenue and Arlington Street.</P> <P>That vehicle apparently broadsided another vehicle, injured an occupant who was later removed from the scene on a backboard.</P> <P>A police car was also smashed on its front end near the intersection of Mountain Avenue and Arlington, and traffic was snarled in that area about 7:30 a.m.</P> <P>Police were investigating a vehicle that seems to have been abandoned at Sinclair, south of Boyd, to see whether it was responsible for the crashes.</P>

--30--

Title: 23-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Trucks collide on highway near Oakpoint
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press  By: Staff Writer   4/05/2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Traffic was tied up on Highway 6 north of Oakpoint Monday afternoon after a pick-up truck rear-ended another truck.</P> <P>The RCMP said a passenger in the first pick-up was thrown from the vehicle after it was struck from behind.</P> <P>The first truck, which had been travelling northbound of Highway 6, had slowed to turn west off of Highway 6, about one kilometre north of Oakpoint. It was struck from behind by the other pick-up truck shortly after 3 p.m.</P> <P>Both the passenger and driver of the first truck were taken to Eriksdale Hospital and then transferred to the Health Sciences Centre. Both are listed in stable condition.</P> <P>The two occupants in the trailing pick-up were treated at Eriksdale Hospital and released.</P> <P>The collision remains under investigation.</P>

--30--

Title: 24-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Testing drivers
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Have Your Say: Winnipeg Free Press Wed May 5 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>MPI statistics quoted on aging driver abilities cited three age groups. Were adjustments made for the differing numbers of drivers in each category? Were adjustments made for the fewer kilometres travelled by older drivers? </P> <P>Unless such variations were taken into consideration, these statistics are meaningless. </P> <P>I am a 75-year-old car driver, one of four siblings, all in our 70s, all holding driver's licences. Two of us no longer own cars. One of us uses her car for short jaunts only, and often chooses to walk or bus it. </P> <P>For myself, I gave up cross-country trips three years ago at age 72. Now I put about 5,000 kilometres a year on my car, compared to 20,000 in younger years. I notice this is typical in my age group. </P> <P>Personally, I would be more than willing to take a yearly driving test, and would very much like to see everyone my age and older do so, as I'm sure "the older, the better" is not the case. </P> <P>Recently, my granddaughter, a new driver of 18, corrected my driving (God love her) and she was right -- I'd made a careless turn. So yearly tests would serve as reviews to sharpen up our skills, us oldies. </P> <P>RUTH WOOD <BR>Winnipeg<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Tories reintroduce auto-theft bill
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Wed May 5 2010 Page: A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>OTTAWA -- Stealing a car could soon stop being considered on par with shoplifting -- at least when it comes to the justice system. </P> <P>Federal Justice Minister Rob Nicholson reintroduced a bill Tuesday that seeks to make auto theft a separate offence in the Criminal Code. It also sets out a six-month mandatory minimum sentence for a third conviction of auto theft. </P> <P>The Manitoba government has been lobbying for years to give auto theft its own presence in the criminal code, often noting it is illegal to steal a cow but stealing a car is still considered just simple property theft. </P> <P>The charge laid for stealing a car right now depends on how much the car was worth -- theft over $5,000 or theft under $5,000. It often has meant car thieves are charged with the same offence on paper that goes to teenagers caught stealing makeup or a pack of gum. </P> <P>Theft under $5,000 has a maximum sentence of six months in jail while theft over $5,000 has a maximum sentence of 10 years. Neither offence has a mandatory minimum sentence. </P> <P>This is the second time around for this particular bill. Nicholson first introduced it a year ago and it was debated and passed at second reading in the House of Commons last fall. However it died on the order paper when Prime Minister Stephen Harper prorogued Parliament in December. </P> <P>It now has to start from scratch. </P> <P>Manitoba Attorney General Andrew Swan said he is pleased Ottawa is making another effort to make auto theft a stand-alone crime. </P> <P>But he said the Harper government could go even further by designating it a violent crime, not a property crime as it is considered now. </P> <P>Swan said in Manitoba stolen cars too often end up in crashes where innocent people, including police officers, are hurt or killed. </P> <P>"When someone steals a car too many times there are tragic consequences," he said. </P> <P>At least eight Manitobans have been killed in collisions involving stolen cars since 2004. Unlike in many other cities where car theft is the realm of organized criminals trafficking in expensive vehicles, the vast majority of car thefts in Winnipeg involve joyriding teenagers. </P> <P>Efforts to target repeat offenders have helped cut car-theft rates drastically in Winnipeg but there is still a long way to go. </P> <P>In 2009, approximately six cars were stolen in Winnipeg every day, down 75 per cent since 2004. </P> <P>Swan also said he wants to see how Ottawa amends the Youth Criminal Justice Act so that repeat thieves can be kept in custody longer. </P> <P>Swan meets with his western Canadian counterparts in Vancouver next week to review what Ottawa is doing on the anti-crime front and to present their own ideas of what more should be done to enhance public safety. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man took stolen truck on rush-hour rampage, say cops
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Wed May 5 2010 Page: 3   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An 18-year-old man is in custody after allegedly taking a stolen truck on a spree of mayhem in the North End early Monday and ramming two police cruisers, crashing into another car and putting a man in hospital. </P> <P>The rampage began hours after the GMC Sierra pickup was stolen from a home on Governor's Court in Garden City about 12:25 a.m. </P> <P>City police saw the truck driven in the North End shortly after 6 a.m., then spotted it again about 7:10 a.m. and tried to stop it around Boyd Avenue and McKenzie Street. </P> <P>When officers left their cruiser to approach the truck, the suspect allegedly drove toward them and smashed into the police car. </P> <P>"It was very dangerous for them. Thankfully, they weren't injured," Const. Natalie Aitken told reporters on Tuesday, adding the suspect later drove the pickup into another police cruiser. </P> <P>"It is a fairly large vehicle. And this individual did make a conscious effort to directly drive the vehicle at two police cars, as well as at officers when they exited the vehicle." </P> <P>As cops chased the pickup immediately after the first collision, the truck hit an older-model Chevrolet Corsica around Boyd and Arlington Street. A 47-year-old man in the Corsica was injured and taken to hospital in stable condition. </P> <P>"It's concerning, for sure. This is at 7 a.m. It was very busy on the roads," Aitken said of the rush-hour rampage in the midst of "civilians who happened to just be going to work." </P> <P>"It was definitely very dangerous for everyone on the streets," she said. </P> <P>The pursuit continued, with the pickup's driver backing into the second cop cruiser around Arlington and Boyd before driving away. </P> <P>Following the second collision with the cruiser, police stopped chasing the truck due to safety concerns. Shortly after, the suspect -- now on foot -- was arrested by police on a nearby street. </P> <P>"The vehicle was dumped," Aitken said. "He was found in close proximity." </P> <P>No officers were injured in the crashes. </P> <P>The suspect, whose name hasn't been released, is charged with dangerous driving, theft over $5,000, fleeing from police, three counts of leaving the scene of an accident and four counts of assault with a weapon. The assault charges stem from the alleged use of the truck to hit four officers -- two in each cruiser. </P> <P>"One was towed into our lot. The other one was able to drive," Aitken said of the damage to the police cars. </P> <P>Police continue to investigate. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car thieves target couple a third time
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Wed May 5 2010 Page: A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE third time definitely wasn't a charm for Jackie Monch. </P> <P>Already victimized twice by car thieves in the past decade, the 45-year-old Garden City woman and her fiance couldn't believe their eyes early Monday morning when they looked outside and saw that their GMC Duramax truck was gone. </P> <P>They had only parked it on the front street minutes before. </P> <P>In its place was a stolen van, still running, with headlights on and windshield wipers going from side to side. Apparently, a thief in the van followed the couple home and promptly traded up for the truck when given the opportunity. </P> <P>"I've had enough... it's absolutely unsettling," said Monch. "Police told us they do target these vehicles because they're built so tough, they will challenge the police and they will ram the vehicles with them." </P> <P>Police said the diesel truck was indeed used as a weapon on Tuesday, slamming into a pair of police cruisers and endangering the lives of four officers. During a pursuit, the truck also hit another vehicle, injuring one occupant. A 47-year-old man went to hospital in stable condition. </P> <P>"Why are all these thugs allowed to be on the streets stealing?" said Monch. "Now, instead of taking a sedan-type of car, you've got a big truck that you can wreak havoc with on our streets." </P> <P>Monch said police told her the stolen van was actually involved in a high- speed pursuit in the North End before it ended up parked in front of her home. </P> <P>After the Duramax went missing, police noticed it at about 7 a.m. around Boyd Avenue and McKenzie Street. Winnipeg Police Service spokeswoman Const. Natalie Aitken said police tried to stop the truck, before it aimed at a cruiser and slammed into it. </P> <P>The truck then took off with police in pursuit before hitting a Chevrolet Corsica near Arlington Street and Boyd Avenue, injuring the man. The stolen truck then hit a second police cruiser with two officers inside, and fled. </P> <P>Aitken said she couldn't speak to whether a trend stealing big trucks exists, but said she was concerned for the officers and for public safety. </P> <P>"It was pretty clear, it was driven right at them... any kind of vehicle would cause serious harm to them," Aitken said. </P> <P>The truck was abandoned at Sinclair Street and Boyd Avenue. </P> <P>Police arrested a male teenager nearby a short time later. The 18-year-old is charged with dangerous driving, theft over $5,000, flight from police, three counts of leaving the scene of an accident and four counts of assault with a weapon. </P> <P>He remains in custody. Police did not release his name. </P> <P>Monch is irate because it's the third time either she or her partner have been targeted by car thieves. About seven years ago, a thief took off in her Firebird from outside a Maples apartment building. </P> <P>Monch reported that theft to police but tracked it down herself on Sinclair Street. </P> <P>"I had a hate-on for someone stealing my car," she said. </P> <P>Her boyfriend also lost another vehicle about 10 years ago to car thieves, she said. </P> <P>"(It's) dangerous for everyone -- not only our officers, who it's evident they're targeting -- but also civilians who happen to just be going to work," said Aitken. </P>

--30--

Title: 28-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hit-and-run in Steinbach
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Sunflashes Column The Winnipeg Sun Wed May 5 2010   Page: 17   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A pedestrian in Steinbach was the victim of a hit-and-run early Saturday. </P> <P>RCMP said a male pedestrian was walking on Main Street sometime between 12:20 a.m. and 1 a.m. when he was apparently struck by a vehicle which fled the scene. </P> <P>The pedestrian was found injured in a ditch along Main Street's westbound lanes and was transported to hospital. </P> <P>A Steinbach RCMP spokesman said the victim sustained serious but non-life threatening injuries, including broken bones in the incident. </P> <P>Steinbach RCMP are asking for the public's help to identify the vehicle involved in the incident. Anyone with information regarding the vehicle's description is asked to contact Steinbach RCMP at (204) 326-4452 or to contact Crime Stoppers at 1-888-222-8977 (TIPS). </P>

--30--

Title: 29-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 2 cars smashed in police chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Officers walk past a damaged police cruiser and another car that was struck by a stolen vehicle Tuesday morning. (CBC)A man was sent to hospital Tuesday after his car crossed the path of a police chase in Winnipeg's North End.</P> <P>The pursuit, which began just after 7 a.m., also left a police cruiser damaged.</P> <P>It started when police spotted a stolen vehicle at Boyd Avenue and McKenzie Street.</P> <P>The vehicle rammed the police cruiser then sped away along Boyd and crashed into another car at the intersection with Arlington Street.</P> <P>The stolen vehicle again fled the scene but police stopped to check on the people inside the car that was hit.</P> <P>Paramedics were called to help a man, who was removed on a stretcher and taken to hospital.</P> <P>Emergency crews help remove a man from a car that was hit during a police chase. (CBC)He was listed in stable condition, police said.</P> <P>None of the officers were hurt when their cruiser was rammed.</P> <P>The stolen vehicle was found abandoned a short while later near Boyd Avenue and Sinclair Street.</P> <P>Police are still searching for suspects</P>

--30--

Title: 30-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: New property crime legislation focuses on auto theft, trafficking
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Vancouver Sun Wed May 5 2010 Page: A8 Section: Westcoast News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Car thieves and fencers of stolen property could face stiffer penalties under new legislation introduced by the federal government Tuesday targeting property crime. </P> <P>Justice Minister Rob Nicholson said trafficking in stolen property has been identified as a primary activity for organized criminals in Canada. </P> <P>And he said auto theft affects more individual Canadians and businesses than any other crime. </P> <P>"Our government is taking action to protect Canadians, their property and their communities," Nicholson said. "Auto theft is estimated to cost Canadians more than $1 billion each year, and the dangerous driving that sometimes results makes Canadian roads unsafe. Auto theft is also one of the criminal enterprises on which organized crime depends." </P> <P>The proposed legislation creates a separate Criminal Code offence for "theft of a motor vehicle," which would carry a mandatory prison sentence of six months after a second conviction. </P> <P>It also includes a new offence for altering, destroying or removing a vehicle identification number or VIN -- a common practice among Lower Mainland crime rings that have been targeted by the Insurance Corp. of B.C. in civil suits. </P> <P>The new law would make it an offence to traffic in property obtained by crime and to possess such property for the purpose of trafficking. </P> <P>Right now, it is a Criminal Code offence to possess stolen property, but there is no trafficking provision. </P> <P>The proposed legislation would also give the Canada Border Services Agency power to identify and prevent stolen property from leaving the country, therefore reducing the exportation of stolen vehicles from Canada by organized crime. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 31-Oct-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Distracted driving - are you ready to take the pledge?
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>On April 26th, 2010 Carberry Collegiate’s TADD Group (Teens Against Destructive Decisions) held a ‘No Phone Zone’ presentation. The ‘No Phone Zone’ was started by Oprah Winfrey, and has inspired others around the world. The ‘No Phone Zone’ was created because of the numerous accidents related to distracted driving. The TADD group made a ‘No Phone Zone’ banner for the students to sign, as well as a pledge to take. The pledge included three different options that the students were allowed to choose. It included no texting while driving or no texting and using hands free phoning or no texting or phone use. TADD hopes that by doing this presentation the students and staff at Carberry Collegiate will be encouraged to make safer and smarter decisions when behind the wheel.</P> <P>MPI points out that distractions are the cause of almost 30 per cent of “at-fault” fatal collisions. Keep yourself, your passengers and others on the road safe by avoiding these common driver distractions.</P> <P>Hand-held cell phones: You are four times more likely to be in an accident when talking on a handheld cell phone. If your phone rings while you’re driving, let your passenger take the call or let it go to voicemail.</P> <P>Texting: A recent study shows that drivers who are texting spend nearly five seconds looking at their cell phones – enough time at typical highway speeds to cover more than the length of a football field. Don’t read or send texts when you’re driving. </P> <P>Eating and grooming behind the wheel: Give yourself extra time in the morning or at lunch so you don’t have to eat or groom on-the-go. </P> <P>Adjusting the radio or music player: Changing radio stations, CDs and iPods while driving makes you six times more likely to have an accident. Save stereo adjustments for red lights.</P> <P>Roadside distractions: Slow down but resist the urge to watch when passing any roadside distraction. Stay in control and avoid dangerous distractions when driving. Together we can all reduce risk on Manitoba’s roads and highways.</P> <P>When you drive a motor vehicle, you take on a life-or-death responsibility – not just for yourself, but for your passengers and everyone else on the road.</P> <P>That responsibility deserves your full attention. Distractions can dramatically increase your risk of an accident, with potentially fatal results.</P> <P>It’s the RCMP who get to see every accident, from fender-bender to fatal. They point out that “Every year some 1,000 Canadians are killed and nearly 6,500 are seriously injured in jurisdictions policed by the RCMP. Traffic crashes are the leading cause of death among the youth of this country.</P> <P>“In 2009, there were 76 fatal collisions in Manitoba. So far this year, the RCMP has responded to 19 fatal collisions.</P> <P>“While speed, alcohol and the failure to wear seatbelts and/or helmets account for many fatal crashes, driver inattention — including the use of cellular phones or similar electronic communication devices continues to be a great concern to the RCMP. The only safe way to drive is to stay focused to the road” On the Road? Off the Phone.</P>

--30--

Title: 1-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Advantage, chopper ; Collisions, injury likely would have been avoided
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Thu May 6 2010   Page: 5   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A police pursuit of a stolen vehicle Monday that resulted in several collisions and one injury is a perfect example of how a police helicopter could have prevented harm against an innocent bystander and avoided damages to several vehicles. </P> <P>Police have announced they will be getting a chopper later this year. Here's one example of how it can benefit law enforcement and the safety of the community: </P> <P>Police received a report just after midnight of a stolen truck from a home on Governor's Court. The vehicle was spotted by police several hours later at 6:11 a.m. around Parr Street and Alfred Avenue. However, the vehicle got away from cops. </P> <P>No option </P> <P>An hour later, police spotted the truck again around Boyd Avenue and McKenzie Street. Because Winnipeg has no aerial support, they had no option but to try to stop the stolen vehicle at street level. Predictably, the driver of the stolen truck rammed the vehicle into a police cruiser and took off, triggering a dangerous, high-speed chase. </P> <P>Police pursued the stolen truck the old-fashioned way -- driving at high speeds through city streets -- and as is often the case, the stolen vehicle collided with another vehicle, injuring an innocent bystander. </P> <P>The victim, thankfully, didn't sustain life-threatening injuries. Not this time. He was transported to hospital in stable condition. </P> <P>But that wasn't the end of the chase. As police advanced on the stolen vehicle, the truck slammed into a second police cruiser car and took off again. </P> <P>Police gave chase once more at dangerously high speeds but eventually aborted the pursuit due to officer and public safety concerns. </P> <P>Fortunately, a police investigation led to the arrest of an 18-year-old suspect a short time later. </P> <P>This is the old way of trying to collar dangerous car thieves. The public and officers are put at risk, someone gets hurt and there is usually extensive property damage. </P> <P>The new way of apprehending stolen vehicles spotted by police will be from the air when the Winnipeg Police Service launches its helicopter program later this year. </P> <P>If police had a helicopter this week, this story would likely have unfolded very differently. </P> <P>Once police spotted the stolen vehicle at 6:11 a.m., the police chopper would have been called in immediately. If it was in the air at the time, the helicopter would have locked onto the stolen vehicle location immediately with its GPS guided camera. </P> <P>At that point, ground crews would have been called off, there would have been no need for a high-speed chase and the chopper would have followed the stolen vehicle until it eventually stopped and the driver got out somewhere. At that point, ground crews and usually a K-9 unit would have moved in for a safe, controlled arrest. </P> <P>If the helicopter wasn't in the air at the time, there would have been a slight delay, maybe 10 minutes or so for the chopper to get airborne from its hangar. </P> <P>The chopper would have picked up the stolen vehicle with its GPS even from several kilometres away, instructed ground patrols to back off and taken over the pursuit in a safe, controlled manner. </P> <P>In all likelihood, an injury and one or more collisions would have been avoided. </P> <P>Police didn't release the dollar amount of the damages to the vehicles, but it's easily in the thousands. As far as the injury to the innocent bystander goes, you can't put a price tag on it. It's simply an example of where aerial support for police could have helped keep the public and police officers safer. </P> <P>Just one of the many benefits of a police helicopter, coming to a neighbourhood near you very soon.</P>

--30--

Title: 2-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Drunken mom drove kids to school, court told
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Thu May 6 2010   Page: 4   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg woman pleaded to be released on bail Wednesday, three days after police arrested her allegedly driving her children to school while drunk. </P> <P>"I will do anything, I miss my children horribly," said Colleen Denysiuk. "I don't want people to look at me and think I'm a horrible mother. I want a better life." </P> <P>Court heard Denysiuk allegedly rear-ended another vehicle and drove off without exchanging particulars with the other driver. Police saw the collision and followed her to a nearby school where she dropped off her two young children. </P> <P>Police arrested Denysiuk, who registered blood-alcohol readings of .322 -- more than four times the legal limit for driving. </P> <P>"The facts of this offence are outrageous," said Crown attorney Raegan Rankin. "She is so very lucky (she didn't) hurt anybody. Her children deserve better, so do any other children walking to school at nine in the morning." </P> <P>Denysiuk, 42, claimed she hadn't been drinking for 24 hours prior to her arrest and was "baffled" at her blood-alcohol readings. Denysiuk said she had been ill and was taking cough medications. </P> <P>"This has been a wake-up call, a very sobering experience both literally and figuratively," said her lawyer, Ian McNaughton. </P> <P>Judge Ray Wyant said he didn't believe the cough medicine excuse for a second and urged Denysiuk to commit herself to quit drinking. </P> <P>"A reading of .3 would kill almost anyone in this room who wasn't an experienced drinker," Wyant said. "You put (your children's) lives at risk not only on this occasion but probably every other time you drove a motor vehicle impaired and you put the lives of other mom's children at risk, too." </P> <P>Wyant agreed to release Denysiuk on $2,500 bail on the proviso she undergo a program of alcohol addiction counselling. </P> <P>Publication bans are used frequently in bail hearings that prohibit details of the case be heard. None were requested in this instance.</P>

--30--

Title: 3-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Thieves smash car into store
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Wednesday, May 5, 2010 | 1:17 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Someone drove through the entrance of an electronics store in Winnipeg Wednesday morning and made off with merchandise.</P> <P>The manager of The Source By Circuit City said the thieves didn't take much but they did leave a lot of destruction in their wake.</P> <P>The incident happened around 2 a.m. and the manager, who didn't want his name used, was called in at 4 a.m. to clean up.</P> <P>The parking lot and sidewalk in front of the store, at 3635 Portage Ave. in the city's Crestview neighbourhood, was still littered with pieces of glass at 8 a.m.</P> <P>It is the third such incident in the city in the past week.</P> <P>Two stores smashed into last week<BR>Last Thursday, a vehicle drove through the front window of a liquor store in the city's Charleswood neighbourhood. The thieves jumped out and grabbed some alcohol before speeding off once again.</P> <P>About 10 minutes later, a car smashed into World Custom Audio Video and Automation on Portage Avenue.</P> <P>Police say thieves used a stolen car and made off with some electronics.</P> <P>The vehicle and some of the stolen property has been recovered.</P> <P>No arrests have been made in either of last week's robberies.</P> <P>Police have not said whether they believe any of the so-called smash-and-grab incidents are related.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/05/mb-smash-grab-electronics-store-winnipeg.html#ixzz0n9Z7UBrx">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/05/mb-smash-grab-electronics-store-winnipeg.html#ixzz0n9Z7UBrx</A></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Mba-Computer-Glitch
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press - Broadcast News Thu May 6 2010 Section: Western Regional News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - The computer system at Crown-owned Manitoba Public Insurance is down for the second day in a row. </P> <P>Brian Smiley, an MPI spokesman, says company technicians worked through the night on the problem, which extends to offices across Manitoba. </P> <P>Smiley says customers are not affected because transactions are being done on paper and will be entered into computers when the system is back online. </P> <P>As well, no policies will be suspended or late fees charged because of the problem. </P> <P>Smiley says the company hopes to have its computer system up and running again soon. (CJOB) <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Some Autopac Brokers Turning Away Business In Light of Computer Problems
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Many autopac brokers throughout the city are turning away business in light of computer problems at MPI.<BR>But as CJOB's Lorne Edwards reports, they don't have to.</P>  <P>One broker told us while they can process any transaction on paper,&nbsp; some customers may be required to bring additional information into the office in order to complete the transaction.&nbsp; He suggests customers call their broker to find out what that information is before they come in.<BR>--30--</P>

Title: 6-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Former city officers rip long-gun registry
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Fri May 7 2010 Page: A12
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>OTTAWA -- Putting criminals behind bars for longer will do more to prevent gun violence in Canada than the long-gun registry, three former Winnipeg cops told a House of Commons committee Thursday. </P> <P>"(The gun registry) is not a particularly useful tool for investigating crime," said Jack Tinsley, a former inspector with the Winnipeg police. </P> <P>Eliminating early parole and house arrest would keep criminals from committing crimes, he said, while the gun registry just tracks numbers of guns by people who have chosen to register them. </P> <P>Tinsley also said returning to the system of firearms licensing control in place before the gun registry would be more effective in keeping guns out of the hands of people who will use them to kill because it required face-to-face interviews with police and background checks with spouses. </P> <P>"Very few potentially dangerous persons slipped through the cracks in that era," he said. </P> <P>At the same hearing, representatives of women's shelters and a victim of the 1989 Montreal massacre that compelled the gun registry in the first place pleaded with Parliament not to eliminate it. </P> <P>Nathalie Provost, one of the 28 people shot by Marc Lepine at cole Polytechnique on Dec. 6, 1989, said the firearms registry recognizes it is a privilege to own a gun and privilege comes with responsibility. </P> <P>The gun Lepine used, said Provost, is an unrestricted long gun and if the gun registry is abolished, that weapon that killed 14 women and injured 14 others would no longer need to registered. </P> <P>"For me there is no logic to that," she said. </P> <P>The three officers were speaking on their own behalf, not as representatives of the Winnipeg police. Last week, a Winnipeg Police Service spokesman told the Free Press the gun registry had proven to be an important and valuable investigative tool. </P> <P>Prior to the hearing Thursday, the Canadian Association of Police Chiefs, Canadian Police Association and the Canadian Association of Police Boards held a press conference to continue pressuring Parliament not to scrap the long-gun registry. The third group has already appeared at the committee, while the first two will appear at a later date. </P> <P>Tinsley said they do not represent all police and said in fact, more officers have not come forward in favour of eliminating the registry for fear of retribution by their police chiefs. </P> <P>Dave Shipman, who retired from the Winnipeg Police Service a decade ago after 25 years and now works as a gang and organized crime investigator for Manitoba Public Insurance, said officers on the street don't use the gun registry. </P> <P>"I have yet to talk to a serving street cop, I'm talking the average constable attending call after call after call, time after time, who has checked the registry or even knows how to use it," said Shipman. </P> <P>He said the gun registry was an "ill-thought out" response to the Montreal Massacre, and did not stop the gun rampage by Kimveer Gill at Dawson College in Montreal in 2006. </P> <P>Heidi Rathglen, who witnessed Lepine's shooting in 1989 as a student at cole Polytechnique, said in fact the weapons Gill used were registered and the gun registry helped police identify him and the weapons he had as the shooting was still underway. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg woman accused of driving kids to school while she was drunk
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press Thu May 6 2010 Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ A Winnipeg woman accused of driving her children to school while she was drunk is pleading to be let out of jail. </P> <P>Colleen Denysiuk says she wants to be released on bail so she can be with her kids. </P> <P>Court heard Denysiuk allegedly rear-ended another vehicle and left rather than talk to the other driver. </P> <P>Police saw the collision and followed her to a nearby school where she dropped off her two young children. </P> <P>Police say she was arrested after a breath test showed she had more than four times the legal alcohol limit in her blood stream. </P> <P>The 42-year-old woman says she hadn't been drinking for 24 hours and is baffled by the blood alcohol reading. </P> <P>Denysiuk told court she had been ill and was taking cough medications. </P> <P>``I will do anything. I miss my children horribly,'' she said in her plea for bail. ``I don't want people to look at me and think I'm a horrible mother. I want a better life.'' </P> <P>Crown lawyer Raegan Rankin said the facts of the case are ``outrageous.'' </P> <P>``She is so very lucky (she didn't) hurt anybody. Her children deserve better. So do any other children walking to school at nine in the morning.'' </P> <P>Denysiuk's lawyer, Ian McNaughton, said his client has been given a wake-up call. ``This has been a ... very sobering experience both literally and figuratively.'' </P> <P>Judge Ray Wyant said he didn't believe the cough medicine explanation and urged Denysiuk to commit herself to quit drinking. </P> <P>``A reading (like this) ... would kill almost anyone in this room who wasn't an experienced drinker,'' Wyant said. ``You put (your children's) lives at risk not only on this occasion, but probably every other time you drove a motor vehicle impaired. And you put the lives of other mom's children at risk, too.'' </P> <P>The judge agreed to release Denysiuk on $2,500 bail on the condition she get counselling for alcohol addiction. </P> <P>Publication bans that prohibit details of a case to be reported are used frequently in bail hearings. None was requested in this instance.</P>

--30--

Title: 8-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: ‘Wasted’ drives home message
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: MADD Canada and MPI team up to combat impaired driving South Mountain Press May 7, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>With proms and graduation parties just over six weeks away, MADD Canada is teaming up with Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) to keep high school students safe from impaired driving. The two are delivering Wasted, a powerful new program which shows students just how easily a night of fun with friends can turn to tragedy when alcohol and drugs are mixed with driving.</P> <P>“Wasted”, MADD Canada’s 2009-2010 High School Multi-Media Assembly Program, is currently touring high schools across the province.</P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance is sponsoring 60 presentations of Wasted in high schools across Manitoba. It is also bringing Fini, MADD Canada’s first French High School Multi-Media Assembly Program, to Manitoba, with presentations at five high schools.</P> <P>Shown on three large screens, Wasted tells the story of teenage friends Jake, Kelly and Drew, and illustrates how their lives are changed forever when one wrong decision leads to a horrific car crash. As the program ends, students see the sheer magnitude of impaired driving with a moving montage of victims’ photos - more than 600 people, from babies to grandparents, who have been killed or seriously injured in impaired driving crashes.</P> <P>“Manitoba Public Insurance is proud to join this effort to promote safe and sober driving habits among youth,” said Ward Keith, MPI Executive Director of Driver Safety and Regulatory Control. “Helping young people understand and appreciate the dangers of impaired driving, and encouraging their commitment to sober driving not only enhances their safety, but makes our roads safer for all Manitobans.”</P> <P>Getting young people to truly appreciate the message and apply it in their own lives can be challenging, said MADD Canada National President Margaret Miller. “Teens and young adults never think they will be involved in a crash,” noted Miller. “But the fact is that young people have limited experience with driving, limited experience with drinking and they tend to take more risks than experienced drivers. It is a potentially lethal combination.”</P> <P>The statistics clearly show that alcohol-related crashes take a disproportionate toll on young drivers. Road crashes are the number one cause of teen death in Canada and alcohol is a factor in 45 percent of those crashes. In 2006, 16 to 25 years olds constituted only 13.2 percent of the population, but accounted for 33.4 percent of the total alcohol-related crash deaths. </P> <P>The High School Multi-Media Assembly Program is one of MADD Canada’s largest and furthest-reaching programs. With Wasted and Fini expected to reach one million high school students across Canada by the end of the 2009-2010 school year, MADD Canada hopes to enlist all young adults in the effort to end impaired driving.</P> <P>“We want every young person who sees the program to understand that they have the power to stop impaired driving,” Miller said. “The deaths and injuries caused by impaired driving are 100 percent preventable. Every young person needs to know that when they make the right decisions - whether it’s deciding not to drive while impaired, not letting a friend drive impaired, or not accepting a ride from someone who has been drinking or doing drugs - they are saving lives and preventing injuries.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI still trying to find fix for computer problem
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Sat May 8 2010   Section: Local
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A computer glitch continued to plague Manitoba Public insurance yesterday, causing service problems for its Autopac agents. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said the computer problem is "probably the longest disruption we've had in more than a decade." </P> <P>Smiley said the problem with the Autopac Online system began Wednesday afternoon. </P> <P>Autopac agents use the system for transactions at their businesses. </P> <P>When transactions are completed, they're sent into a "holding database" and then eventually into a "purge bin". </P> <P>"For some reason, the information is not moving from the holding database to the purge bin, causing the whole system to literally slow down to a crawl," Smiley said. </P> <P>The system was shut down to prevent it from crashing which could result in the loss of client information. </P> <P>As of yesterday afternoon, the problem still wasn't fixed and posed a problem for 306 Autopac agents throughout the province. </P> <P>Agents were only able to supply limited service to customers -- they could still renew driver's licences, Autopac policies and issue beginner's permits. </P> <P>Registration stickers couldn't be issued but temporary paperwork proving registration could. </P> <P>Police agencies, including the Brandon Police Service, were also notified. </P> <P>However, Smiley assured that customers will not be charged late fees or overdue interest and no policies will be suspended. </P> <P>In addition, no non-policy financing agreements were to be cancelled last night. </P> <P>Public inquiries can be directed to MPI's call centre at 985-7000 or toll-free 1-800-665-2410. </P> <P>MPI's last computer disruption was on March 4 and lasted one day.</P>

--30--

Title: 10-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Computer glitch continues for third straight day at Manitoba Public Insurance
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Fri May 7 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ For the third straight day, computer problems are continuing to plague Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>Officials there say only limited service is being offered to customers. </P> <P>Anyone trying to renew their insurance or trying to register a new vehicle is being warned that the information has to be entered manually so will take longer. </P> <P>The agency says it can't process new driver's license photos until the problem is fixed. </P> <P>Customers won't be charged late fees or overdue interest because of the glitch. </P> <P>But there's no word on when MPI may be able to fix the problem. </P>

--30--

Title: 11-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police chopper delayed to fall
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sat May 8 2010   Page: A3   Section: Top Story
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg's first police helicopter won't take to the skies before October, police Chief Keith McCaskill said Friday as the city confirmed the awarding of a $3.49-million contract to purchase the aircraft. </P> <P>The Winnipeg Police Service hoped to have a Eurocopter Canada E-120B Colibri up in the air in time to patrol the city during the summer, when the most serious street crimes tend to occur. </P> <P>But it will take six months for the slightly used, French-made aircraft to be outfitted in Fort Erie, Ont., for police work and then shipped to Winnipeg, McCaskill said. </P> <P>Three police officers must also be trained to operate on-board equipment such as the aircraft's spotlight, thermal-imaging camera, police radios, public address system and GPS mapping system. </P> <P>Two civilian pilots must also be hired, McCaskill said. </P> <P>"The sooner we can get it in the air, the better," said the chief, explaining the city has already laid a tremendous amount of groundwork for the aircraft in a short period of time. </P> <P>"Last year at this time, we had no concept this would occur." </P> <P>The City of Winnipeg is covering the cost of acquiring the helicopter and its on-board equipment. The province has agreed to cover the $1.3-million annual cost of operating the vehicle, which is intended to allow police to more efficiently marshal resources on the ground during incidents such as foot chases. </P> <P>The helicopter may also be used to apprehend impaired drivers and street racers, search for lost children and Alzheimer's patients, manage crowds, escort VIPs and serve as a visual deterrent against crime, according to an internal police report obtained by the Free Press under Freedom of Information legislation. </P> <P>That same report touted Manitoba Public Insurance as a potential sponsor. But the city is still looking for a corporate sponsor for the aircraft, Mayor Sam Katz said Friday. </P> <P>Justice Minister Andrew Swan, meanwhile, joked the province is already sponsoring the helicopter to the tune of $1.3 million a year. </P> <P>Earlier this year, Katz and Swan were at loggerheads over operating funding for the chopper. A handful of city councillors also questioned the need for the aircraft, given the absence of a report justifying the purchase. </P> <P>That debate has subsided, as even mayoral candidate Judy Wasylycia-Leis said she won't second-guess the decision to buy a police helicopter. </P> <P>But on Friday, she said she's concerned about the timing of its first flight, which may occur weeks or days before the Oct. 27 civic election. </P> <P>"It's interesting timing," she said at an event to introduce Kevin Chief, the man she wants to be her successor as NDP MP for Winnipeg North. "There are a lot things the mayor is doing right now that evoke the comment, 'interesting timing.' </P> <P>"Suddenly, he's available to go on regular radio shows. Suddenly, he's showing up at events and suddenly the helicopter is in the air at around the time of the election. </P> <P>"It tells me he knows he's got a real challenge with me and he's trying to make up for lost ground." </P> <P>Wasylycia-Leis said while she has questions about how the decision to purchase a helicopter was made, she believes it's needed to enhance safety. </P> <P>"We're not going to speak against something that has been decided," Wasylycia-Leis said. "I think a lot of the public wanted more information than they actually got, but my understanding is the helicopter will provide an important service for Winnipeg. </P> <P>"I'm certainly not going to revisit history and question that decision." </P>

--30--

Title: 12-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI making progress with computer issues
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Computer problems this week have had Manitoba Public Insurance working at less-than full strength. </P> <P>But MPI says this morning that they are making progress in getting their computer systems back to full capacity.</P> <P>As of Saturday morning, MPI offices and 140 Autopac Agents throughout the province are able to conduct full business transactions.</P> <P>MPI is asking customers with transactions that are not urgent, to please wait until operations are back at full capacity.</P> <P>Any customers with questions can contact MPI’s Call Centre at 985-7000 or toll free at 1-800-665-2410.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI computer problems continue
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sun May 9 2010   Page: 16   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance continued to struggle Saturday with problems that have affected its computer system since Wednesday. </P> <P>However, the Crown corporation said 140 of its 306 Autopac agents across the province are now fully able to conduct business transactions. </P> <P>On Thursday MPI announced insurance brokers were not able to access the online system because of a problem with its data banks, forcing them to serve customers through paper transactions that would later be entered into MPI's computer system. </P> <P>On Saturday, MPI asked motorists to wait until the problems have been fixed before trying to process a transaction, unless the situation is urgent. MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said a driver's licence about to expire would be an example of an urgent transaction. </P> <P>MPI says customers won't be charged late fees or overdue interest until the computer problems have been fixed. </P> <P>Insurance policies will not be suspended and no non-policy financing agreements will be cancelled, MPI says. </P> <P>Anyone with questions can call MPI's call centre at 985-7000 or 1-800-665-2410. </P> <P>MPI has publicly apologized for any inconvenience the situation has caused motorists.</P>

Title: 14-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Carman's electrified over new sets of wheels
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Mon May 10 2010   Page: A2
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Beep, beep, Steinbach. Get out of the way. </P> <P>Carman wants to be the first to inherit the moniker of The Automobile City. But in this case it's electric vehicles, specifically low-speed electric vehicles. </P> <P>Carman wants to allow low-speed electric vehicles on its streets -- but not on the two highways that split the town -- under an upcoming provincial pilot project. </P> <P>Innovation, Energy and Mines Minister Dave Chomiak told local officials Carman has the authority to permit low-speed or non-conforming vehicles on its streets for test purposes. About a dozen other rural communities also want to do the same thing, but Carman appears to have an advantage over all of them -- it has Northland Machinery. </P> <P>The company assembles custom electric golf carts stylized as Hummers, Cadillac Escalades and California Roadsters. </P> <P>John Barrett, co-owner at Northland, said the company is working with Transport Canada to get federal approval to register two of its rechargeable battery golf cart models as low-speed vehicles. </P> <P>Once that's done, it still needs the green light from the province so the golf carts can putter off the green of the Carman Golf Club and hit the pavement in the town of about 3,000 people, he said. </P> <P>"I'm hoping we'll have something on the streets of Carman this spring," Barrett said. "With proper use, these vehicles are clean-running and can be used on the golf course and the street." </P> <P>The custom golf carts come equipped with a windshield, turn signals, seat belts and even a horn. Their top speed is limited to 40 kilometres and hour or 25 miles per hour. </P> <P>Carman Mayor Bob Mitchell and Conservative MLA Blaine Pedersen said if the town gets approval, it'll take a few gas-guzzlers off the road. </P> <P>"I see no reason why I couldn't drive one of them down to my office," Mitchell said. </P> <P>The Selinger government put together a working group to come up with rules on how to deal with such requests. One of the issues is whether the low-speed vehicles -- which have fiberglass bodies -- meet federal crash-test standards and can be insured. Manitoba Public Insurance has a seat at the table. </P> <P>Pedersen said the province should move more quickly -- the working group hasn't met yet -- because some Carman residents are already driving their carts on the road and a couple have been stopped by the RCMP. </P> <P>"The sooner we move on this the better," he said. </P> <P>Pedersen and Mitchell said other provinces and U.S. states have allowed low- speed electric vehicles on the road with restrictions and there haven't been problems. For example, they're not allowed on streets where the speed limit exceeds 50 km/h. </P> <P>"In Carman, you can get all around town without going on the highway," Pedersen said. </P> <P>Carman's large retired population could use the carts to run errands in town. For example, a two-car couple could get rid of one of their vehicles to use the electric cart more often. </P> <P>Mitchell said some older residents with mobility problems operate small scooters. One man gets stuck periodically at a pedestrian crossing on the railway tracks and needs a push to get going again. </P> <P>"I see the cart as being safer than using a mobility scooter," he said. "It has better traction." </P> <P><A href="mailto:bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca">bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>Scoot on over </P> <P>LOW-SPEED electric cars are waiting final approval before hitting Manitoba streets but electric bikes and scooters have been allowed for years. </P> <P>Electric scooters have a range of about 50 kilometres before the battery needs recharging. </P> <P>Transport Canada classifies an electric scooter as a power-assisted bicycle, not a motor vehicle. The top speed is restricted to 32 km/h and it can be pedalled like a bicycle. This means a driver's licence and insurance are not required. Users are encouraged to wear a helmet and obey the rules of the road. If used as a substitute for a car, a $2,000 scooter can pay for itself in four months. </P>

--30--

Title: 15-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg officer struck by stolen vehicle
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Sun May 9 2010   Section: Latest News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- A stolen car clipped a Winnipeg police officer working a speed trap Saturday, sending the officer to hospital with minor injuries. </P> <P>Police said officers were doing routine traffic enforcement in the morning when one of them tried to flag down a speeding Chevy Cobalt sedan. </P> <P>Instead of stopping, the vehicle appeared to veer directly toward the officer and struck him, police said. </P> <P>The officer went to hospital but wasn't badly injured, suffering scrapes and bruises and an injury to an extremity, according to police. </P> <P>The driver of the vehicle, which was later confirmed stolen from the Selkirk area, sped away for a distance, abandoned the car, then fled on foot. </P> <P>Police continue to investigate.</P>

--30--

Title: 16-Nov-13

NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Sat May 8 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ A Winnipeg police officer received minor injuries when a stolen car clipped him while he was working a speed trap. </P> <P>Officers were doing routine enforcement Saturday morning when one of them tried to flag down the speeding car. </P> <P>Police say that instead of stopping, the vehicle appeared to veer directly toward the officer and struck him. </P> <P>The officer sustained scrapes and bruises. </P> <P>The driver of the vehicle later abandoned it and fled on foot. </P> <P>Police are still investigating and no arrests have been made.</P>

Title: 17-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen car driven into Winnipeg police officer
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Saturday, May 8, 2010 | 4:21 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police say the driver of a stolen car intentionally rammed into an officer who was trying to flag the motorist down Saturday morning.</P> <P>The officer suffered what were described as minor injuries, but was taken to hospital for treatment.</P> <P>Police said the incident happened Saturday around 10 a.m. CT.</P> <P>Police were doing traffic enforcement in the area of Dufferin and Salter streets when an officer spotted a speeder and went to flag the vehicle down.</P> <P>However, instead of complying, the motorist drove straight for the officer, who was knocked to the ground.</P> <P>Police said a male suspect at the wheel continued for a short distance, then stopped the car and took off on foot.</P> <P>Police were still looking for the suspect. They were able to determine that the car was stolen.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/08/mb-police-officer-injured-1058.html#ixzz0nX3HQyKT">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/08/mb-police-officer-injured-1058.html#ixzz0nX3HQyKT</A></P>

--30--

NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Flash: Speeder hits police officer
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sun May 9 2010   Page: A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A stolen car clipped a Winnipeg police officer working a speed trap Saturday morning, sending the officer to hospital with minor injuries. </P> <P>At about 10:10 a.m., officers were doing routine traffic enforcement near Dufferin Avenue and Salter Street when one of them tried to flag down a speeding Chevy Cobalt. Instead of stopping, the Cobalt appeared to veer directly toward the officer and struck him. </P> <P>The officer went to hospital but wasn't badly injured, suffering scrapes and bruises and an injury to an extremity. </P> <P>The driver of the Cobalt, which was later confirmed stolen from the Selkirk area, sped down Flora Avenue, abandoned the car and fled on foot. </P> <P>Police are still investigating. </P>

Title: 19-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes column: STOLEN CAR STRUCK OFFICER AT SPEED TRAP
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sun May 9 2010   Page: 16   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police are searching for a suspect after a stolen car struck an officer Saturday. </P> <P>The incident happened about 10:10 a.m. in the area of Salter Street and Dufferin Avenue while officers were using photo radar to catch speeders. </P> <P>Const. Jason Michalyshen, a spokesman for the Winnipeg Police Service, said one officer was trying to flag down a speeding red Chevrolet Cobalt when the car headed toward him and knocked him down, causing minor injuries. </P> <P>The car, which was later determined to be stolen, was abandoned nearby on Flora Avenue and the driver fled the scene on foot. The vehicle had been stolen from the Selkirk area, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>Police were searching Saturday for a male suspect described as white in appearance. <BR></P>

Title: 20-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Autopac back online for urgent renewals
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Tue May 11 2010   Page: 14   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance took another step Monday to getting its computer system fully back online. </P> <P>The Crown corporation has been struggling since last Wednesday with a problem its technicians are continuing to grapple with. As of Monday, all of MPI's 306 Autopac agents had access to the online system, but were limited to one terminal each. </P> <P>"We've been working on it all weekend long," said MPI spokesman Brian Smiley. "It's the first time in over a decade we've had this long a delay or computer problem. It's highly unusual." </P> <P>Last Thursday MPI announced insurance brokers were not able to access the online system because of a problem with its data banks becoming overloaded, forcing them to serve customers through paper transactions that would later be entered into MPI's computer system. </P> <P>By Saturday, MPI had 140 of the 306 agents online. The public insurer is continuing to ask motorists to wait until the problem is solved before conducting all but urgent transactions with MPI. </P> <P>An example of an urgent transaction would be renewing a driver's licence that is about to expire, Smiley said. </P> <P>Smiley said if the system withstands Monday's increased load that more terminals could be brought online for agents Tuesday. He said no data has been lost as technicians have been able to safely shut down and restart the system as they attempt to find the root of the problem. </P> <P>Smiley said customers won't be charged late fees or overdue interest while the computer problems continue. Insurance policies will not be suspended and no non-policy financing agreements will be cancelled, MPI says. </P> <P>Anyone with questions can call MPI's call centre at 985-7000 or 1-800-665-2410. </P>

--30--

Title: 21-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen car a murky detail in police shooting
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Tue May 11 2010   Page: A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE family of a 42-year-old Winnipeg tattoo artist shot by police said they were baffled to hear reports the Cadillac the man was driving was stolen. </P> <P>Winnipeg Police Service officers shot and killed Lance Trevor Muir after they responded to a report of a break-and-enter at 143 Langside St. at about 9 a.m. Sunday. </P> <P>Residents heard a series of shots and a large bang as a black Cadillac crashed into a garbage bin in a Langside alley near Sara Avenue. Pulled from inside the vehicle was Muir, a former Spartans gang associate. </P> <P>He was completing a methadone program and lived in a Young Street rooming house after he was released for a failed 1996 execution-style shooting. </P> <P>His sister, Melanie Backman, said Muir had been driving the car for about a month and told her it belonged to a friend. He drove her to work on Friday in the car, she said. </P> <P>Police have not confirmed the Cadillac was stolen but sources told the Free Press it was reported to them that way. </P> <P>"He had car keys and everything. He told me it was just a friend of his who let him borrow it from time to time so that he (could) get around," she said. </P> <P>On of Muir's friends lived in the basement suite at 143 Langside, where the break-and-enter was reported. Residents in the neighbourhood said they saw a man with a crowbar and a pillowcase in the area before the shooting happened. </P> <P>Muir was convicted in 1997 of attempted murder and then charged in connection with drug smuggling at Saskatchewan Penitentiary. Backman said her brother had recently shown signs of improvement after he "got wrapped up in the wrong element" when he was younger. </P> <P>"He was always a genuine friend, he would always give the shirt off his back if you needed it; he would always help you out if you needed it, but at the same time, he was a very troubled soul," she said. </P> <P>The police service did not say Monday if the Cadillac was stolen, if it veered at officers or if Muir threatened officers with a weapon like a crowbar. Earlier this year, Eric Daniels was threatening officers with a machete on Sargent Avenue when they shot and killed him. </P> <P>Mike Sutherland, Winnipeg Police Association president, said the officers involved in Sunday's shooting will suffer serious trauma after the incident. He said police shootings happen when officers are "left with no options." </P> <P>"It's very emotional, it's very stressful, it's very difficult," he said. </P> <P>Sutherland, a former homicide investigator, said he was familiar with Muir from his time in the service due to an "extensive history of police contact." He said officers involved in police shootings undergo an intense amount of scrutiny and "armchair quarterbacking." </P> <P>The homicide unit will investigate the incident. An inquest will be mandated under the Fatality Inquiries Act to examine the circumstances. </P> <P>Later this year, the investigation of shootings by city police will fall to a special unit under the soon-to-be-formed Manitoba Police Commission. </P> <P>Commission members will be named later this spring, Justice Minister Andrew Swan said on Monday. The commission's investigative unit will be established later this year. </P> <P>Winnipeg Police Service Chief Keith McCaskill said Monday he didn't have details on the shooting. </P> <P>McCaskill said the decision not to release details was to protect the "integrity of the investigation." </P> <P>"We believe in trying to get the information out as soon as we can but not at the expense of the investigation, so what I'm basically saying is that I let the investigators do what they should be doing," he said. <BR></P>

--30--
