Title: 23-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driven to Distraction: Think About What You’re Doing Behind the Wheel
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Western Canadian, Manitou, Manitoba  Tuesday, May 11, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The next time you’re driving down the highway and your hand-held cell phone rings, remember this: you’re four times as likely to get in to an accident if you answer it. If you’re texting, your chances increase to 23 times.</P> <P>Need to read that text while on the highway? A recent study by the Virginia Tech Transportation Institute shows that drivers who are texting spent nearly five seconds looking at their cell phones - enough time at typical highway speeds to drive the length of a football field.</P> <P>Driver distractions contribute to 80 per cent of all crashes, according to an American study. And while hand-held cell phones are cited as the number-one cause of all driver distractions today, they aren’t the only thing causing people to take their eyes off the road.</P> <P>“Whether you’re driving around the block or across town, it’s important to keep your focus on your driving,” says Clif Eden, manager of Road Safety at Manitoba Public Insurance. “It’s something that’s in your control.”</P> <P>Other driver distractions include eating while driving, grooming and even talking to your passengers. And that’s just inside the vehicle. Outside distractions, such as rubbernecking an accident or trying to communicate with another driver, are involved in 30 per cent of all at-fault fatal accidents, according to a recent American study.</P> <P>“Many accidents involving distracted drivers are preventable,” says Eden. “Driving requires full attention. Not just for your own safety, but for that of your passengers and everyone else on the road.”</P> <P>In many cases, you can identify distracted drivers by how they’re driving. They’re the people who are often driving slower than the rest of traffic or drifting from one side of the lane to the other. They’re the ones who are likely to miss a traffic sign or fail to signal. And they’re the ones putting themselves and other drivers, cyclists and pedestrians at risk.</P> <P>Fortunately, driving distracted is entirely preventable. Drivers can reduce their risk of getting into an accident by turning off their phones while driving or getting someone else to make, or take, the call, and by leaving enough time in the morning or at lunch so you don’t have to eat or shave on-the-go. And while human curiosity makes it tempting to stare at a roadside crash, motorists should exhibit extreme caution when passing by a crash scene. Rubber necking is a definite no-no.</P> <P>“Even adjusting your radio or changing your CD player increases your risk of a collision by six times,” says Eden. “We all have an opportunity to reduce the risk of a collision by keeping our eyes on the road and our hands on the wheel.”</P>

--30--

Title: 24-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hog heaven? You won't find it here
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed May 12 2010   Page: A2
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Ah, spring: the return of robins, geese -- and hogs. </P> <P>But the owners of these hogs -- the two-wheeled, motorized ones -- argue they may soon be as extinct as the passenger pigeon because they believe Manitoba Public Insurance rates are too high. </P> <P>Ted Hector, owner of Thunder Road Motorcycles, says what hurts most is local bikers are only a province away from where they would pay less for their insurance. </P> <P>"I know a guy who would pay $250 in Saskatchewan, but pays $1,400 here," Hector said. </P> <P>"And it gets worse. I know many that come here with the army wanting to insure their bikes. They usually find they're going to pay double to triple here. For a young person to get a bike on the road now would be impossible. </P> <P>"There's no question they're trying to get rid of motorcycles in this province." </P> <P>The number of motorcycle registrations with MPI appear to bear that out. </P> <P>In 1986 there were 16,798 registrations, but by 1998 it had dropped to 7,929. A news release by MPI in December stated there are now 2,900 motorcycles here. It also said motorcycles overall would see a 4.9 per cent increase in insurance rates, but 30.8 per cent of them would see rates drop. Teulon resident Cal Popoff just bought his 1978 Honda CB 750 last year, but it wasn't until this year that insurance-rate shock set in. </P> <P>Popoff said he pays $1,036 to insure his bike for the precious few months when there's no snow here. </P> <P>But Popoff knows if he lived in Saskatchewan, he'd only pay around $410. </P> <P>"It just doesn't make sense," Popoff said. </P> <P>"MPIC seems hell-bent on jacking it to the motorcycle driver... if MPIC is going to claim it's giving us the best rates available then it better make sure it's across the board." </P> <P>But MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said all the insurer is doing -- and has been doing it since the Public Utilities Board made a ruling in 1996 -- is to stop cross-subsidization. </P> <P>Smiley said the idea is to make motorists in each vehicle category pay for their own collision repairs and bodily injury claims. </P> <P>"What drives motorcycle costs are bodily injury claims," he said. </P> <P>"For every $1 in premium, we used to pay nearly $1.30 in cost -- that's now down to about $1.15. We know a single vehicle motorcycle crash sees about $13, 000 to $14,000 in claims while a single vehicle car crash is about $3,000. </P> <P>"It's not to say motorcycles are unsafe, but the operator doesn't have a ton of steel surrounding them." As for Saskatchewan's bargain rates, Smiley said that's because other motorists' insurance premiums subsidize motorcycle rates. </P> <P>Tony Playter, a spokesman for Saskatchewan's vehicle insurer, Saskatchewan Government Insurance (SGI), confirmed that. </P> <P>Playter verified motorcycle rates are subsidized by owners of passenger vehicles. </P> <P>A report produced for the Saskatchewan government during last year's rate hearings stated insurance rates for motorcycles would have to go up by 139.9 per cent to break even for their claims. </P> <P>"Our motorcycle rates are not where they need to be," Playter said. "But we had a rate increase in November and the effects haven't taken effect yet." </P> <P>Those rates will see a maximum increase of 12.5 per cent for light passenger vehicles. </P> <P>But for motorcycles, it means increases of up to 24 per cent for sport motorcycles and 15 per cent for other motorcycle types. </P> <P>Smiley pointed out that while overall motorcycle insurance rates went up by 4.9 per cent, 30.8 per cent of motorcyclists -- mostly in Winnipeg -- will see a drop in insurance rates. </P> <P><A href="mailto:kevin.rollason@freepress.mb.ca">kevin.rollason@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>Getcher motor runnin' </P> <P>2006 Honda CB600F, valued at $8,500 </P> <P>Insurance in Saskatchewan: $1,412 </P> <P>Insurance in Manitoba: $3,300 in Winnipeg, $2,400 in rural areas </P> <P>2010 all-purpose motorcycle rates for Winnipeg: </P> <P>Touring, more than 500 CC engine displacement, declared value from $14,001 to $20,000: $1,652 (includes 25 per cent discount) </P> <P>Sport, more than 500 CC engine displacement, declared value from $14,001 to $20,000: $2,348 (includes 25 per cent discount) </P>

--30--

Title: 25-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'Dream car' wrapped up in tragedy
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed May 12 2010   Page: B1
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Her dream car is likely sitting in a compound somewhere, tagged as evidence, its windshield dotted with bullet holes and its front end crumpled. </P> <P>She's certain there are bloodstains inside it now -- left over from a deadly police-involved shooting Sunday that claimed the life of a 42-year-old former biker named Lance Trevor Muir. </P> <P>The Winnipeg woman, who would only identify herself as Lynn, said Tuesday she hopes she never has to see the classy, black 2003 Cadillac CTS again. </P> <P>"I don't want it back," said Lynn, who reported the vehicle stolen exactly three weeks before the fatal shooting in West Broadway. "It'd be bad superstition. </P> <P>"After what happened in there... no way." </P> <P>Driving alone in the Cadillac on Sunday around 9 a.m., Muir stopped to break into a home in the 100 block of Langside Street. </P> <P>Officers responding to the call shot and killed him. </P> <P>The Winnipeg Police Service says the Cadillac was stolen, but wouldn't say if it veered at officers or if Muir threatened officers with a weapon, possibly a crowbar. </P> <P>WPS Chief Keith McCaskill said Monday a decision not to release details of the shooting was to protect the "integrity of the investigation." </P> <P>Lynn said the car was stolen on Sunday, April 18 from the parking lot of the McDonald's restaurant on Portage Avenue and Sherbrook Street. </P> <P>She wasn't there when it happened. Her mother and grandmother had borrowed the car and stopped for a bite when a man who looked like Muir stole a purse with the keys inside. By the time the women ran outside, the Cadillac was already stolen. </P> <P>Since then, she's made daily inquiries to the police about the car, only to be told it hadn't been recovered. </P> <P>But on Sunday she received calls from four different friends telling her they'd just seen the black Caddy on the TV news. </P> <P>"They said the vehicle involved on Langside is mine," Lynn said. "I couldn't believe it." </P> <P>But she's disappointed investigators didn't do more to locate the stolen car in the first place. </P> <P>Police would not comment on how they tried to track the Cadillac after it was stolen or whether Sunday's shooting could have been prevented if they'd found the car earlier. A spokeswoman said the theft is still part of the investigation. </P> <P>Only a year ago, Lynn travelled to Toronto to buy the car for $15,000 and then invested nearly $2,000 more on alarm and navigation systems. </P> <P>"It was immaculate," she said, adding she's disappointed investigators didn't do more to locate the stolen car in the first place. "I loved that car. It was my dream car." </P> <P>Lynn isn't sure if the vehicle will be written off. Police haven't released the vehicle to Manitoba Public Insurance, she said. </P> <P>On Sunday, area residents said they heard a series of shots and a large bang as the car crashed into a garbage bin in a Langside alley near Sara Avenue. Pulled from inside the vehicle was Muir, a former Spartans gang associate. </P> <P>An acquaintance said Muir was completing a methadone program and lived in a Young Street rooming house after being released from prison after a 10-year sentence for a failed 1996 execution-style shooting. </P> <P>On Monday, his sister, Melanie Backman, told the Free Press Muir had been driving the Cadillac for about a month and told her it belonged to a friend. He drove her to work just this past Friday in it, she said. </P> <P>The homicide unit is investigating the incident.</P>

--30--

Title: 26-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cops: boy stole truck
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Wed May 12 2010   Page: 7   Section: News

A male youth was seen fleeing the truck and was taken into custody a short time later. </P> <P>The 12-year-old Grand Rapids resident was arrested and has been charged with possession of property obtained by crime as well as numerous Highway Traffic Act offences. </P>

Title: 27-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cadillac driven by slain ex-biker stolen last month: owner
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A luxury car being driven by an ex-biker when he was fatally shot by Winnipeg police on the weekend was stolen last month, the car's owner says. </P> <P>Lynn, who wouldn't give her last name, said her prized car is in the police service's possession but she doesn't want it back if it's not a write-off. </P> <P>"They shot him in my vehicle and pulled him out," Lynn said Tuesday. "I definitely don't want it back." </P> <P>The car, a 2003 Cadillac CTS, was allegedly driven toward police in an alley near Langside Street and Sara Avenue on Sunday morning. At least one officer opened fire because he or she believed lives were in jeopardy, a source said. </P> <P>Lance Muir, who was in the driver's seat, died after he was hit by at least one bullet. At least three shots pierced the windshield. The car ended up crashing into garbage bins and a wooden pole. </P> <P>Police say they encountered Muir, a 42-year-old former member of the now-defunct Spartans outlaw motorcycle gang who did time for attempted murder, after he broke into a home. </P> <P>Police spokeswoman Const. Natalie Aitken said two officers directly involved in the matter are on paid administrative leave. </P> <P>Lynn said she and Muir never met. She's upset with Muir's family's claim the car belonged to a friend. </P> <P>Lynn said the car was stolen while her mom and grandma were using it April 18. </P> <P>She said the women were inside a McDonald's restaurant at Sherbrook Street and Portage Avenue when they were approached by a man. </P> <P>"He came up to my mom and asked for money but she said she didn't have any," Lynn said. </P> <P>The man returned to his seat and continued to stare at the women, Lynn said. </P> <P>Lynn said her mom was distracted when the man got up and walked out, and didn't realize he swiped her purse, which contained the Cadillac's keys, identification and other things, as he walked by. </P> <P>He used the keys to steal the car in the parking lot, Lynn said. </P> <P>Lynn said she didn't know the car was involved in the shooting until a friend saw it in a news report. She said police confirmed it was her car.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Semi driver killed in Kenora crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Tuesday, May 11, 2010 | 3:25 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 47-year-old man from Ontario was killed Tuesday in a fiery crash on Highway 17A near Kenora.</P> <P>The man was driving a semi-trailer at about 3 a.m. when it veered out of the eastbound lanes, then crossed the westbound lanes and hit an embankment, according to the Ontario Provincial Police.</P> <P>The semi then burst into flames and was destroyed.</P> <P>The driver, who name was not released, was unable to get out of the vehicle, police said.</P> <P>He was from Cardinal, Ont., located south of Ottawa near the U.S. border.</P> <P>The highway was closed for several hours but has since reopened. However, the OPP caution that the passing lane may still be closed for the next day as the investigation continues.</P> <P>Kenora is located about 200 kilometres east of Winnipeg, in Northwestern Ontario.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/11/mb-kenora-crash-semi-manitoba.html#ixzz0nigFUJHn">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/11/mb-kenora-crash-semi-manitoba.html#ixzz0nigFUJHn</A><BR></P>

Title: 29-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crime awareness sessions to be held in west Winnipeg
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Winnipeg Police Service is holding a series of upcoming crime awareness presentations in local communities to increase public awareness and participation.</P> <P>WPS constables will explain the latest information on Neighbourhood Watch, frauds and scams, personal safety, E-Watch, Citizens on Patrol and general crime awareness.</P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance representatives will also be in attendance. They will demonstrate Speed Boards and hold a Qand-A about vehicle speed safety.</P> <P>Everyone in attendance will receive an 80-page Crime Prevention Handbook and Neighbourhood Watch stickers.</P> <P>Sturgeon Heights Collegiate at 2665 Ness Ave., will host one of the sessions on May 27 with registration beginning at 6:30 p.m.</P> <P>Another session is slated for June 1 at Westminster United Church at 745 Westminster Ave., with registration beginning at 6:30 p.m.</P> <P>For more information, contact the Winnipeg Police Community Relations Unit at 986-6322.</P>

Title: 30-Nov-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI limiting access to online system
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Thu May 13 2010   Page: B2   Section: Columns
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>MANITOBA Public Insurance has debugged its Autopac On-Line system, which crashed over the weekend, leaving motorists unable to renew their automobile insurance. </P> <P>However, to insure the system does not crash again, the provincial insurer is limiting access to the system by insurance agents during peak hours of 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. </P> <P>In a news release, MPI is asking motorists who need to renew their insurance to visit their agents after 5:30 p.m., when the AOL system will be less stressed. </P> <P>The AOL system failed over the weekend but by Saturday, MPI's main offices and 140 of the province's 306 Autopac agents were back online. </P> <P>The failure was caused by a problem with one of MPI's data banks. </P> <P>Autopac staff were still able to serve customers the old-fashioned way -- using paper transactions, which will later be input into MPI's computer system. </P> <P>MPI stated that anyone who was not able to renew their insurance as a result of this computer problem will not be suspended or charged overdue interest. </P>

--30--

Title: 1-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Autopac encourages evening visits, thanks patient customers
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance said Wednesday the computer problems that it has been experiencing since last week are now solved, although people are still being asked to visit their Autopac agents in the evening. </P> <P>"As a cautionary measure, during the peak usage hours of 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., Manitoba's 306 Autopac agents will have limited access to the Autopac On-Line (AOL) system," stated a release issued by MPI Wednesday. </P> <P>"Autopac agents throughout the province now have full access to Manitoba Public Insurance's computer system every evening at 5:30, and on weekends. Customers, who patiently have waited to carry out their transactions, are encouraged to visit their local Autopac agent during this time. </P> <P>"Customers will not be charged late fees or overdue interest, nor will policies be suspended, and no non-policy financing agreements will be cancelled due to the processing delay," the release stated. </P>

--30--

Title: 3-Dec-13

NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Thu May 13 2010   Page: 3   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Four people, including a newborn baby, were sent to hospital Wednesday afternoon after their small sedan collided with a fuel tanker truck on Route 90. </P> <P>Witnesses said the westbound silver Honda Civic appeared to collide with the truck just after the light turned green for northbound traffic on Century Street at Wellington Street about 3 p.m. </P> <P>"It seemed like the car just came out of nowhere," said Brad Bowles, who was waiting at the light while heading north. "The truck hit the car on the driver's side and just spun it right around." </P> <P>Witnesses immediately called 911. </P> <P>An adult male and female were taken to hospital in stable condition, as were a child under five years of age and an infant. </P> <P>The male driver of the truck, from Paul's Hauling Ltd., did not appear to be injured in the collision. </P> <P>The intersection remained closed, with northbound traffic on Century rerouted to St. James Street, as emergency personnel cared for occupants of the car and police investigated the incident.</P>

Title: 5-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Woman pleads guilty in 'horrific' crash
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Wednesday, May 12, 2010 | 6:42 PM CT  By James Turner, CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg woman has admitted to being behind the wheel of a vehicle that killed two pedestrians in a "horrific" downtown crash during evening rush hour nearly two years ago.</P> <P>Court documents obtained by CBC News on Wednesday show that Lucy Muthoka, 52, has entered guilty pleas to two charges of dangerous driving causing death.</P> <P>Muthoka was arrested and charged with two counts of criminal negligence causing death on Dec. 11, 2008. The Crown has stayed the more serious charges in exchange for her guilty pleas, court records show.</P> <P>William Halcrow, 57, and his friend, James Ross, 58, were killed after being struck by an erratically driven Subaru Forester near the corner of Donald Street and St. Mary Avenue on the early evening of June 29, 2008.</P> <P>Nicole Pringle and her husband said at the time that they were driving south on Donald Street when her husband had to stop to let the Subaru cut in front of theirs. It then appeared to accelerate and drive the wrong way into one-way traffic, she said.</P> <P>"[It] hit the first pedestrian, who flew up in the air, and continued to go quickly and hit another pedestrian," Pringle said.</P> <P>"At that point, there were also several vehicles that were crunching into each other and hubcaps flying in the air and it was just — it was horrific."</P> <P>Halcrow and Ross were from the Cross Lake reserve in northern Manitoba and had come to the city for medical treatment.</P> <P>Efforts by passersby and paramedics to revive the men at the frantic crash scene were unsuccessful.</P> <P>Another man, David Matsubara, was also injured and suffered a broken shoulder and a lacerated skull. Documents show the Crown has dropped a charge of criminal negligence causing bodily harm relating to his injuries. </P> <P>14 year maximum<BR>A pre-sentencing report examining Muthoka's personal background and circumstances has been ordered and she is due back in court on June 30.</P> <P>Muthoka faces a maximum sentence of 14 years in prison.</P> <P>She has never been held in custody for the offences and has been out in the public without issue since her arrest. Police demanded at the time that she surrender her passport.</P> <P>The investigation into the fatal crash was complex, police previously said.</P> <P>A fire hydrant was hit, causing a water main break that spewed hundreds of litres of water into the chaos.</P> <P>So much water seeped into the pavement that it buckled, challenging collision reconstruction investigators to reconstruct the soggy scene and figure out what happened.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/12/man-crash-halcrow-muthoka-guilty.html#ixzz0noVM8g3R">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/12/man-crash-halcrow-muthoka-guilty.html#ixzz0noVM8g3R</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Was your car accident a set-up?; That crash might not be as innocent as it seems. Here's how to avoid being caught in a staged collision
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Globe And Mail   Thu May 13 2010   Page: G8   Section: Globe Megawheels
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P><A href="mailto:globedrive@globeandmail.com">globedrive@globeandmail.com</A> </P> <P>A reader writes: </P> <P>I was involved in a minor accident. My Dodge Neon hit under the back bumper of a GMC Jimmy, in which no damage was done to either vehicle, not even a scratch. The other driver claimed under his insurance for major chrome bumper damage that existed prior to the incident. </P> <P>I took a video showing that the height of both vehicles, showing my car is lower than his bumper! It's hardly conceivable that my car caused any damage, given where it hit, and it wasn't his bumper. </P> <P>I want my insurance to review the case and drop the 'at-fault' label. Prior to the crash, my auto insurance premium was $1,100 a year. Post-crash, it's more than $4,500. </P> <P>Any help would be greatly appreciated. </P> <P>It's hard to imagine that there are people purposely crashing into other drivers for profit, but it's true. </P> <P>Last year these staged accidents caused more than $3-million in fraudulent claims in the Greater Toronto Area alone, with the police braking up nine major auto collision rings. </P> <P>Staged accidents are occurring mostly in major cities but are predominately in Ontario, according to the Insurance Bureau of Canada. If you're a victim of a staged accident you need to know how to spot the signs and report it to your insurance company so they don't deem you to be at fault. If you wait until your policy renews to fight the increase, it's a lot harder. </P> <P>A staged car accident is not easy to recognize or to avoid if you don't know what to look for, and the perpetrators getting more sophisticated, working with two or even three cars setting you up. There may also be people on the street that will approach you to set you up with auto body shops, lawyers and doctors or even act as a witness. This witness may not be on your side, be careful who you trust. </P> <P>In this case, it appears you may be the victim of a "swoop and squat." This is where a car suddenly cuts in front of you and the driver slams on the brakes. If you rear end the car, you're at fault. </P> <P>Often this car will also contain passengers, all pretending to have painful neck or back injuries. The owner of the vehicle will then make large collision and injury claims even though the damage was minimal. Sometimes a second car is used to pull in front of you to slow you down, and then the "crash car" swoops in between, slams on their brakes, causing you to hit them. </P> <P>There's also the "drive down," where you may be either driving down an on- ramp or merging into traffic when a slower vehicle in front of you "waves" you over to pass them. As you're passing this car side swipes you, blaming you for the accident. </P> <P>In parking lots, someone may beckon you to drive out of your space and then he or she will intentionally drive into you, claiming they were waving at a fly in the car, not you. </P> <P>Then there's the "sideswipe," which often happens in double lanes. If you drift into the other lane, even a little, the car next to you will purposely hit your car, and you'll be at fault for the accident. </P> <P>To avoid a staged collision, never tailgate, and allow plenty of distance between you and the car ahead in case they decide to suddenly jam on their brakes. If you're being waved on, let the other car go first. </P> <P>These staged accidents are designed to make it look like it's your fault, and your insurance rate will be affected. If you have tickets or a previous accident it may even initiate a cancellation by your insurance company. </P> <P>At the scene of the accident, use your intuition. If you feel you're the victim of a staged accident, you probably are. Be your own crime scene investigator. </P> <P>The possible players who could be involved in this accident insurance scam may range from the driver of the car and people in the vehicle, a stranger on the street, tow-truck driver, mechanics, auto dealers, doctors, rehab physicians, and lawyers. </P> <P>The car crashers get money for staging the crash. The tow truck driver will get a kickback from the repair shop. The auto body shops bill for additional damage. The doctors, chiropractors and lawyers might bill for extra services, or visits that never occurred. </P> <P>In the event of a collision, call the police to the scene. Get a police report with the officer's name, especially if the damage is minor. If the officer's notes state that there was just a small scratch or dent, and the driver attempts to claim for serious injuries or car damage this will be evidence supporting any claim that the accident was staged. Tell police if you have any suspicions. </P> <P>Watch carefully how the passengers of the other car behave. If they're standing around joking and then suddenly act injured when the police arrive, this is another indication something's wrong. </P> <P>Count how many passengers were in the other car. Get their names and phone numbers. It's common for people who weren't even in the vehicle to claim for injuries so ask to see the claim report and look to see if additional names have been added. </P> <P>Take pictures or video of the other car's damage it received and its passengers. Meet with the adjuster, show them the pictures, and tell them you feel this was a staged accident. You must fight not to be deemed at-fault for the accident. If the adjuster doesn't agree with you, escalate it to the ombudsman in the insurance company. Don't wait until your policy renews. </P> <P>Be suspicious if the tow truck driver recommends a particular repair facility without being asked. If a stranger tries to steer you to a body shop, doctor, chiropractor or lawyer, this too could be a sign of staging. Get the names, addresses and phone numbers of these service providers. Then give this information to your insurance company. </P> <P>Car accidents are bad enough without being set up.. So make sure it really was an accident.</P>

--30--

Title: 7-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: New flexibility allows insurance coverage more tailored to you
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Hamilton Spectator   Thu May 13 2010   Page: W17   Section: Wheels
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>On Sept. 1, auto insurance in Ontario will be more flexible and consumers may be able to save money. </P> <P>With new provincial government changes, drivers will get more choice in the amount of coverage they can select when they buy or renew their auto insurance policies. </P> <P>According to the insurance industry regulator, the Financial Services Commission of Ontario (FSCO), the changes mean that drivers should think carefully about what they would need in the event that they are injured in an auto accident. If you buy or renew your auto insurance after Sept. 1, you will be given a choice of buying a new standard package of statutory accident benefits with lowered coverage and costs. You will also be given the option of buying extra coverage. Insurance companies provide an array of accident benefits prescribed by law. The following table compares some standard coverages currently in effect with those under the new standard to take effect Sept. 1, 2010, to illustrate where drivers could make additional choices: </P> <P>Property damage options are also offered in the changes, according to FSCO. For example, insurance companies provide "direct compensation-property damage" to cover your vehicle and damaged property after an auto accident, to the extent that you are not at fault. Drivers will be able to choose a $300 deductible or a $500 deductible which will reduce their premium cost. With this option, the driver would pay the first $300 (or $500) in repair costs, with the insurer paying the balance. </P>

--30--

Title: 8-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hog hell for city bikers Letter of the day
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri May 14 2010   Page: A15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I have ridden a motorcycle for nearly 40 years and have never had an accident or a claim as a result. This year, I have two vintage motorcycles, one with a sidecar, which are licensed and insured and which I use for recreation and short trips. I doubt I'll cover more than 2,000 kilometres this summer, yet my MPI premium for both is about $3,500 for the season. </P> <P>Today, an inexperienced rider can take and pass the written test to get a beginner's motorcycle licence. MPI has advised me that if that person is not subject to the graduated licensing program and already has a driver's licence, then they can start driving on the street without any formal training immediately. </P> <P>A modern 1,000cc motorcycle can easily exceed 250 km/h and accelerate to 100 km/h in under three seconds. And it can be purchased and legally driven on the road by a rider with no formal training. This is a recipe for one disaster after another. </P> <P>One solution is to make a substantial training program mandatory and to restrict learners to much less powerful motorcycles for at least one year. This is done in England, where my premiums would be less than $500 per year but, far more importantly, the human costs would be greatly reduced. </P> <P>ANDERS BRUUN <BR>Winnipeg </P> <P>Re: Hog heaven? You won't find it here, May 12). </P> <P>Again another article about motorcycle insurance rates and again MPI justifying the increases, yet no one is taking any initiative to make any changes to the current system. It would be interesting to know the percentage of motorcycle accidents involving other motorists. Or the percentage of accidents involving new riders. </P> <P>Why isn't motorcycle insurance subsidized by other motorists when the accident is caused by other motorists? I'd still be riding my 1999 Honda F4 if it weren't for a motorist in a truck making an illegal left turn in front of me. It was his actions that cost MPI over $60,000 to take care of my injuries, rehab and cost of my totalled bike. Why then does a pedestrian who is injured by a vehicle and who may not even contribute to MPI have their costs subsidized by MPI? </P> <P>Another question I'd like to see answered is why a graduated system like they have in the United Kingdom is not being put into effect? For example, limit displacement and horsepower for new riders. Seems like money is the bottom line and not safety after all, despite what MPI advertisements claim. We have motorcycle courses that teach riders how to ride safely and be ready to react to the daily dangers on Winnipeg roads, but nothing is being done about the terrible driving habits of most Winnipeg drivers. <BR>Red-light and mobile cameras and arbitrary no-parking zones generate revenue, despite it being questionable whether the cameras improve safety. It seems to me it's not cost-effective to pull drivers over and fine them for changing lanes without signalling, making improper turns and merging improperly to name a few. Hey, MPI, speed isn't the only thing that kills. </P> <P>HOWIE CHYMYSHYN <BR>Winnipeg <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI Agents Back On Line
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Autopac Agents throughout the province now have full access to Manitoba Public Insurance's Autopac Online computer system. After a series of progressive repairs, MPI has successfully corrected its system issues which had limited AOL access for Agents. The issue was a technical, data base problem that was causing a backlog relating to transactions.

--30--

Title: 10-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Long-weekend traffic
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It’s the one we’ve all been waiting for: the May long weekend. Unlike other long weekends throughout the year, this one can set the tone for all the rest. After months of being confined to the indoors, the anticipation of getting out of town for “May long” can make us all overly eager when we hit the road.</P> <P>“This weekend is the annual kick off for many cottagers and campers,” says Clif Eden, Road Safety Manager of Manitoba Public Insurance. “We encourage everyone to drive safely so you can enjoy it for years to come.</P> <P>“We see an increase in traffic-related fatalities and injuries every long weekend compared to other weekends in the year. We all need a heightened awareness on the highway when we’re heading to and from the lake or cottage on long weekends.”</P> <P>According to Manitoba Public Insurance claims statistics, 36 people were killed between 2004 and 2008 in traffic collisions on the long weekends from May to September. Another 1,710 people were injured or seriously injured - many deaths and injuries that could have been avoided.</P> <P>These crashes can be attributed to many factors, says Eden, citing heavier traffic volumes and a general level of impatience among drivers. The best approach to the long-weekend drive is to make the journey as important as the destination.</P> <P>“Keep yourself, your family and those around you safe by driving defensively,” says Eden. “Make it a weekend you won’t forget – for all the right reasons.”</P> <P>In addition to heavier traffic, the increase in long-weekend traffic accidents could also be caused by people not buckling up, distracted drivers and, of course, driving while impaired. Speeding is also a contributing factor, says Eden.</P> <P>“Stay alert, plan an appropriate amount of travel time and slow down,” suggests Eden. “Excessive speeds reduce the amount of time you have to respond to hazards and make decisions.”</P> <P>The May long weekend should be the beginning of a fun-filled summer. Safe driving is the beginning of that journey.</P>

--30--

Title: 11-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driven to distraction: Think about what you’re doing behind the wheel
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE next time you’re driving down the highway and your hand-held cell phone rings, remember this: you’re four times as likely to get in to an accident if you answer it. If you’re texting, your chances increase to 23 times.</P> <P>Need to read that text while on the highway? A recent study by the Virginia Tech Transportation Institute shows that drivers who are texting spent nearly five seconds at a time looking at their cell phones, enough time at typical highway speeds to drive more than the length of a football field.</P> <P>Driver distractions contribute to 80 percent of all crashes, according to an American study. And while handheld cell phones are cited as the number one cause of all driver distractions today, they aren’t the only thing causing people to take their eyes off the road.</P> <P>“Whether you’re driving around the block or across town, it’s important to keep your focus on your driving,” says Clif Eden, manager of road safety at Manitoba Public Insurance. “It’s something that’s in your control.”</P> <P>Other driver distractions include eating while driving, grooming and even talking to your passengers. And that’s just inside the vehicle. Outside distractions, such as rubbernecking an accident or trying to communicate with another driver, are involved in 30 percent of all at-fault fatal accidents, according to a recent American study.</P> <P>“Many accidents involving distracted drivers are preventable,” says Eden. “Driving requires full attention, not just for your own safety, but for that of your passengers and everyone else on the road.”</P> <P>In many cases, you can identify distracted drivers by how they’re driving. They’re the people who are often driving slower than the rest of traffic or drifting from one side of the lane to the other. They’re the ones likely to miss a traffic sign or fail to signal. And they’re the ones putting themselves and other drivers, cyclists and pedestrians at risk.</P> <P>Fortunately, driving distracted is entirely preventable. Drivers can reduce their risk of getting into an accident by turning off their phones while driving or getting someone else to make, or take, the call, and by leaving enough time in the morning or at lunch so you don’t have to eat or shave on-the-go.</P> <P>And while human curiosity makes it tempting to stare at a roadside crash, motorists should exhibit extreme caution when passing by a crash scene. Rubber necking is a definite no-no.</P> <P>“Even adjusting your radio or changing your CD player increases your risk of a collision by six times,” says Eden. “We all have an opportunity to reduce the risk of a collision by keeping our eyes on the road and our hands on the wheel.”</P>

--30--

Title: 12-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver guilty in deaths of men from Cross Lake
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri May 14 2010   Page: A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg woman has admitted to killing two pedestrians in a horrific downtown crash. </P> <P>Lucy Muthoka, 52, pleaded guilty to two counts of dangerous driving causing death for the June 25, 2008 incident at the intersection of Donald Street and St. Mary Avenue. </P> <P>Muthoka has been free on bail since police arrested her and laid charges in December 2008. The matter has been adjourned to June 30 and she will learn her fate once pre-sentence reports and victim-impact statements have been completed, likely after the end of June. </P> <P>William Halcrow, 57, and James Ross, 58, were killed instantly after being hit by Muthoka's Subaru Forester. The two friends were from the Cross Lake reserve in northern Manitoba and were in Winnipeg for medical treatment. Several bystanders who witnessed the crash -- and narrowly avoided being hit -- tried frantically to revive the men, as did firefighters and paramedics. </P> <P>Friends told the Free Press at the time that Muthoka is a devoutly religious single mother who was driving home from work when she was involved in the catastrophic string of events. They said the Kenyan woman "was blank" about the details of the crash. She has no prior criminal record. </P> <P>Just prior to the collision that killed the men, Muthoka had rear-ended a truck stopped at a light, police allege. That pushed the truck forward and injured pedestrian David Matsubara, 49, who witnesses said became pinned against another vehicle. He suffered a broken shoulder and lacerated skull. </P> <P>Muthoka also hit a fire hydrant, which caused hundreds of litres of water to quickly flood the area and hampered the police investigation because it was difficult to re-create the scene and figure out the sequence of events.</P>

--30--

Title: 13-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver accepts deal in double fatality
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg woman responsible for a horrifying car crash that killed two people and seriously injured a third has pleaded guilty to two counts of dangerous driving causing death. </P> <P>Lucy Muthoka, 52, was originally charged with criminal negligence causing death. She entered guilty pleas to the reduced charges last March. A sentencing date has not yet been set. Muthoka is not in custody. </P> <P>Cross Lake First Nation residents Billy Halcrow, 57, and James Ross, 58, died in the collision at Donald Street and St. Mary Avenue on June 25, 2008. </P> <P>Muthoka was behind the wheel of a Subaru Forester, leaving the Millennium Library parkade, when her vehicle accelerated suddenly on Donald Street, Crown attorney Zane Tessler told court last March. </P> <P>The southbound vehicle swerved across the road as it approached the St. Mary Avenue intersection, where it rear-ended a truck stopped at a red light. The truck was pushed into the intersection and struck a male pedestrian, seriously injuring him. Muthoka's vehicle continued through the intersection, striking Halcrow and Ross. </P> <P>Alcohol and drugs were not factors in the collision, said defence lawyer Saul Simmonds. "Lack of experience is what has her here today," Simmonds said. </P> <P>"If by some stretch of the imagination there would be some physical or mechanical reason disclosed in the future, (the Crown) will re-evaluate whether or not we should be here," he said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Slow and easy the key to safe spring driving
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>SPRING in Manitoba can mean wet, slippery roads. And wet, slippery roads can lead to dangerous driving conditions.</P> <P>“Thousands of collisions and many injuries happen every year because drivers don’t adjust their driving to the road conditions,” said Clif Eden, manager of road safety programming for Manitoba Public Insurance. “Most of these collisions and injuries are completely preventable.”</P> <P>In wet conditions the average stopping distance for most automobiles is twice that on a dry road. Throw in poor visibility caused by a dirty windshield or bad weather and stopping distance can be even greater.</P> <P>To stay safe and avoid a collision, special precautions are needed. Slow down and leave extra distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you. It takes longer to stop or adjust on wet, dirty roads. In particular, do not follow large trucks or buses closely; the spray from their wheels will dirty your windshield and reduce your visibility.</P> <P>Replace old or brittle windshield wipers. Worn wipers will not clear water and grit from the windshield, causing streaking and smearing that could dangerously obstruct your view. Also make sure your running lights or headlights are on when driving on dark, overcast or foggy days.</P> <P>Avoid puddles by driving around or taking a different route. If you have to drive through standing water on a road and you do not know how deep it is or what is underneath, go slowly. If it is deeper than the bottom of your doors turn around and find another route. Deep water can ruin your car’s electrical system and an unseen pothole or obstruction can cause hundreds, even thousands of dollars in damage to your car.</P> <P>After driving through water, your brakes can lose some of their stopping power. When traffic allows, pump your brakes lightly a few times to dry the brake linings.</P> <P>Please do not splash pedestrians. Being splashed with a wave of cold, dirty water is not much fun.</P> <P>Eden added, “As the old saying goes, ‘it’s not rocket science.’ To stay safe when road conditions aren’t the greatest, slow down and take some extra precautions. It could prevent a collision or something far worse.”<BR>(Excerpted from of The Manitoba Driver, distributed by Manitoba Public Insurance)</P>

--30--

NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Long weekend is a tough one on driving stats  Heavier traffic volumes, driver distraction combine for increase in number of accidents

Title: 17-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the Editor column: SULLEN OVER SURCHARGE
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sun May 16 2010   Page: 11   Section: Editorial/Opinion
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I have always been a strong supporter of MPI since its inception. But after recently being ripped off by them, I'm not so sure any more. </P> <P>My wife was involved in a minor parking lot incident resulting in very minimal damage, which I decided wasn't worth claiming. After being requested to make a report, she was informed that even though she wasn't at fault she would be subjected to a 50% fault claim against her deductible and a $200 surcharge would be applied to her driver's license. </P> <P>I can understand the 50% fault claim, but why the surcharge? She is not even making a claim. All of this in spite of a clean driving record for over 20 years. </P> <P>I am sure MPI would like to have every accident declared 50-50 so they can benefit from a $200 surcharge from each client. </P> <P>How does MPI justify a $200.00 surcharge from each party when the ruling is fault is 50/50? I would think each party should be assessed $100 each. </P> <P>STAN GRABOWECKY <BR>WINNIPEG <BR>A day without someone complaining about MPI is like a day without sunrise. </P>

--30--
