Title: 19-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Two charged after stolen car crashes
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sat May 15 2010   Page: A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>TWO men were arrested after a stolen car crashed on Charles Street early Friday morning. </P> <P>Police said two people broke into a vehicle at about 2:15 a.m. in the 100 block of Kirlystone Way. </P> <P>The pair then went into a residence and took a purse with keys to a second vehicle, police say. </P> <P>Police tried to stop the stolen vehicle, which was totalled after the thieves crashed it into a fence and parked vehicle in the 200 block of Charles Street. </P> <P>The men then fled on foot. </P> <P>Two suspects were later arrested. Police said there was $11,500 in damage to vehicles and property. </P> <P>Two 18-year-old men are charged with mischief under $5,000, theft under $5, 000, break and enter, theft over $5,000, joyriding, possession of break-and- enter tools, two counts of failing to comply with conditions of an undertaking, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle, impaired driving and flight from a police officer. </P>

--30--

Title: 20-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Speeders get lecture ; Tickets don't have 'same impact' as kids' reprimand
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Turns out there is one way to talk your way out of a traffic ticket -- let a student do the talking. </P> <P>The bargain was for one day only, however. </P> <P>Winnipeg police officers and Ecole Tache students teamed up to deliver an anti-speeding message to Winnipeggers in a unique way Friday afternoon. </P> <P>Armed with a radar gun, officers enforced a strip of eastbound Provencher Boulevard near Langevin Street -- in a school and playground area where the speed limit is 50 km/h -- and offered scofflaws an awfully generous choice. </P> <P>Option one: accept the ticket, a fine of at least a couple hundred bucks and a drop in their driver safety rating. </P> <P>Option two: receive a lecture from a Grade 6 student -- in front of reporters and cameras -- about the perils of speeding and escape the penalty. </P> <P>You can guess which route offenders chose. </P> <P>In the first hour of the two-hour Talk or Ticket exercise, police stopped three drivers for speeding -- most were travelling about 15 km/h over the limit -- and all three chose the less-costly talk, which turned out to be a tad embarrassing for them. </P> <P>"It was really humbling. I wasn't paying attention (to my speed) and I'm really embarrassed to say that," said Heather Abrahamson, the second person to be pulled over. </P> <P>Abrahamson, who was clocked at 67 km/h in the St. Boniface location, escaped a $266.75 fine but learned her lesson through the lecture, she said. </P> <P>"I don't think a ticket would have held the same impact," she said. </P> <P>The safety lecture was delivered by Danica Chateauneuf, 11. "Knowing all this could lead to changes, it was a really good experience," she said. </P> <P>Classmates Caitlyn Kruk, 11, and Sam Cerilli-Boucher, 12, also delivered the message. </P> <P>"Speeding is really dangerous for everyone," Kruk told a reporter. "(Motorists) should know how speeding can hurt people ... but sometimes they don't listen." </P> <P>"I know these people can learn speeding is bad and it can kill people," Cerilli-Boucher added. </P> <P>Separately, Brent Polson and Brian Waldner were caught driving 16 km/h over the speed limit, not realizing their mistake until it was too late. </P> <P>"From now on I'll probably slow down a little bit more and be careful around school zones," Waldner said. </P> <P>Const. Henry Burzynski, a school education officer, said the stretch of Provencher is a concern because speeders are a problem there and two schools and two crosswalks are nearby. </P> <P>Police selected Ecole Tache, which is near Friday's enforcement zone, to host the event. The three students were picked based on essays they submitted to their teacher. </P>

--30--

Title: 21-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: JUDGE HANDS MAN 14-MONTH DRIVING BAN
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Sat May 15 2010   Section: Local
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A former councillor for the Rolling River First Nation has been fined and banned from driving for impaired driving. </P> <P>Nelson J. Bird pleaded guilty in Brandon court on Thursday to driving with a blood-alcohol level over the legal limit. </P> <P>Court heard that on Feb. 13, a Brandon tow truck driver called police with a report of an impaired driver and officers stopped a vehicle on the 900-block of Middleton Avenue. </P> <P>The driver, identified as Bird, appeared intoxicated and police found 15 cans of beer in the vehicle. </P> <P>Bird was arrested and tests showed that he had a blood-alcohol level well over the legal limit. </P> <P>Defence lawyer Hymie Weinstein said Bird had been a Rolling River councillor for 12 years up until April. </P> <P>Bird, 63, has two prior convictions for drinking and driving, and for the latest offence Judge Shauna Hewitt-Michta fined him $2,000 and banned him from driving for 14 months. </P>

--30--

Title: 22-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg woman pleads guilty to reduced charges after killing two pedestrians
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Fri May 14 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ A Winnipeg woman has pleaded guilty to two counts of dangerous driving causing death following an accident that killed two pedestrians. </P> <P>Lucy Muthoka had been charged with criminal negligence causing death, but the 52-year-old woman entered guilty pleas to the reduced charges last March. </P> <P>Court heard Muthoka was driving her sport utility vehicle out of the downtown library parkade in June 2008 when the SUV suddenly sped up. </P> <P>The vehicle rear-ended a truck and continued through an intersection where it struck and killed Billy Halcrow and James Ross, two men in their late 50s from the Cross Lake First Nation in northern Manitoba. </P> <P>Defence lawyer Saul Simmonds says lack of experience was a factor in the crash. </P> <P>Muthoka is not in custody and returns to court June 30th. (Winnipeg Sun) <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 23-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Smarter than lead-footers
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sat May 15 2010   Page: B1
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It was a police traffic stop like no other. When police pulled over speeders in St. Boniface Friday afternoon, the drivers were given a choice: a $200-plus ticket or a stern lecture from a sixth grader. </P> <P>The public awareness event by the Winnipeg Police Service dispatched three cole Tache students to the side of Provencher Boulevard under the watchful eye of Const. Henry Burzynski, a school resource officer. </P> <P>Sam Cerilli-Boucher, 12, Caitlyn Kruk, 11, and Danica Chateauneuf, 11, eyed the cars whizzing by. Each clutched a typed, two-page statement listing the risk of speeding. </P> <P>"Speeding is very dangerous. A car is a moving weapon. You lose control in a split second just because you're going over the speed limit," said Sam. He didn't have a prepared statement like the girls but listed off his speech rapid- fire. </P> <P>"You're a danger to yourself and others. </P> <P>"You cause grief to your family because you hit someone or you were hit." </P> <P>So, did speeders choose to pay the $200 fine or endure a grim reprimand from a child? </P> <P>Of three drivers police caught going more than 65 kilometres per hour during the two-hour event, all chose to listen to the students rather than face a hefty fine. One was a grandmother. </P> <P>Another was a man in his 20s who drove a pickup truck. </P> <P>The third was a man in his 30s in a sports utility vehicle. </P> <P>"We're trying to get a voice out there other than the police for people to slow down," said Burzynski, who said there are four schools in the area. "What better way than to have kids from your neighbourhood who are directly impacted by speeding, especially in areas like this where they're close to school?" </P> <P>It's the first time the program's been done in Manitoba. </P> <P>Police from the central traffic unit and community relations unit adapted it from a similar program for high school students in Toronto. </P> <P>Students here were selected from their Grade 6 class after writing statements about the dangers of speeding. </P> <P>Thus, what police call the "talk or ticket" approach was launched. </P> <P>To make it safe for the young people, central traffic unit officer Const. Tony Bettens stood behind a beige sedan, flagging cars that were going above the 50 km/h limit on Provencher near Rue Langevin. </P> <P>After Bettens spoke with the vehicle's driver and assessed their safety level, drivers exited to a grassy patch where the sixth graders waited to deliver their wisdom. </P> <P>Burzynski said the program humbles drivers, including repeat offenders -- known in slang as "frequent flyers" -- into obeying traffic laws. </P> <P>Recently, Burzynski busted a bad driver who had an open bag of marijuana and scales on his front seat after a routine traffic stop, he said. </P> <P>Besides, said Danica, speeders also have to deal with issues like poor environmental effects from heavy fuel consumption. </P> <P>So, will she speed when she gets her driver's licence? </P> <P>"I don't want to," she said. </P> <P>But 12-year-old Sam said despite his earlier grave warnings, it's a possibility. </P> <P>"Most people get a speeding ticket once in their life," he said. </P> <P>Not on Friday, at least, for three drivers. </P>

--30--

Title: 24-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 18-year-olds arrested after police foot chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two 18-year-old men are facing several charges after a short overnight crime spree in Winnipeg ended with a police pursuit Friday morning. </P> <P>Police said two male suspects broke into a vehicle in the 100-block of Kirlystone Way in East Kildonan, followed by a garage and house. </P> <P>In the house, the pair stole a purse containing keys to a second vehicle, which they stole and used to crash into the vehicle they broke into, police said. </P> <P>Officers spotted the vehicle a short time later and attempted to stop it but the driver took off, leading police on a short pursuit. </P> <P>Police said the driver, who was allegedly intoxicated, lost control of the vehicle and it crashed into a fence and a parked vehicle in the 200-block of Charles Street in the North End. </P> <P>The suspects, who were arrested nearby after a short foot chase, caused an estimated $11,500 damage to the vehicles, police said. </P> <P>The men face more than a dozen charges. Their names weren't released as the charges haven't been formally laid. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Let's see some ID ; Decals will help chopper direct squad cars from sky
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeggers may notice something different about the police service's squad cars. </P> <P>To prepare for the arrival of a helicopter this fall, city police are applying rooftop decals to their marked cruisers, including general patrol, canine, traffic, street crime and tactical support team vehicles. </P> <P>This, so the helicopter crew can quickly identify police vehicles on the ground and know which ones to direct from 300 metres in the air. Otherwise the crew would be staring down at blank white roofs. </P> <P>"We need the cars to be recognized from our operational altitude," said police Const. Nick Paulet, one of two officers who studied the feasibility of a police helicopter and are now tasked with its implementation. </P> <P>Rooftop decals will be particularly helpful in directing officers during pursuits or emergencies such as a shooting, which require the response of several units. </P> <P>Decals are being applied to more than 120 police vehicles at a cost of about $7,000, Paulet said. </P> <P>So far the numbers have been added to about two dozen. They're being applied while the cars are out of service -- for an oil change, for example -- at the police service's Princess Street garage, so there will be no disruptions or shortages, Paulet said. </P> <P>Car 404, for example, has "404" applied to its roof in large font. "TC1" is applied to TAC1, a tactical support team car. </P> <P>The chopper -- a Eurocopter EC-120B Colibri, also known as a Hummingbird -- won't be in Winnipeg's airspace until October at the earliest so there's no rush to complete the process, Paulet said. </P> <P>Government has budgeted for three civilian pilots, three officers -- a supervisor and two tactical flight officers -- and a maintenance engineer, although the latter position might be contracted out, Paulet said. They will form the flight operation unit. </P> <P>The civilian pilots will receive some police training, Paulet said. </P> <P>One officer has been selected and is in training but the other positions haven't been filled, Paulet said. </P> <P>It's not yet known where the helicopter will be based. Paulet said the chopper is budgeted for 1,000 flight hours per year. </P> <P>The aircraft is being assembled at Eurocopter's Fort Erie, Ont., plant and is almost brand new, having been in the air for only five hours, Paulet said. Earlier this month, city and provincial officials announced the purchase of the US$2.4-million helicopter. </P> <P>It has a large cabin and an extremely low noise signature compared to other models. Police say it can travel across the city in less than four minutes at a speed of 200 km/h. </P> <P>The helicopter will be equipped with all kinds of high-tech police gadgetry, including a thermal imager, spotlight, and video downlink to allow police on the ground to view video images of what the chopper crew is seeing from the air. </P>

--30--

Title: 26-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver's licences should help nab crooks: Goertzen ; Give it a rest, Tom
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A provincial Tory MLA is hoping to keep driver's licences out of the hands of Manitobans with outstanding warrants for serious offences. </P>  <P>Kelvin Goertzen, the Progressive-Conservative MLA for Steinbach, said Monday he hopes to table his private member's bill this week to create legislation he says could easily take advantage of the province's driver licensing system to put more criminals behind bars. </P>  <P>"It would be for indictable offences," Goertzen said. "The most serious offences under the Criminal Code -- violent offences, assaults, sexual offences, anything carrying the possibility of jail time." </P>  <P>Goertzen said the system would likely not be costly as it would only involve the sharing of information between Manitoba Public Insurance, police forces and Manitoba Justice. </P>  <P>"It's one more tool to try to deal with those who are running from the law or avoiding dealing with outstanding warrants," he said. "It gives them one more incentive to deal with the issues. I don't expect it to be a silver bullet, but it would be an important tool." </P>  <P>Goertzen said the move could at least allow those with warrants to be better tracked. </P>  <P>"This is something that would put a road block in the normality of their lives, and hopefully we'd capture some of them," he said. </P>  <P>Currently, licence renewal can be suspended for those with outstanding child support payments, outstanding Highway Traffic Act penalties and unpaid parking fines, Goertzen said. </P>  <P>Goertzen said there are currently between 10,000 and 12,000 outstanding warrants in the province and he said pending warrants for indictable offences likely number in the thousands. </P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 27-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Getting personal
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>not often that I use this space to offer up a first-person &#8220;rant&#8221; but you can blame an article in the Winnipeg Free Press about the high cost of insurance for motorcycles in Manitoba for this one. </P>  <P>It is so high that Saskatchewan would have to raise its rates more than 1,000 per cent to catch up. </P>  <P>The reason, according to MPI, is that motorcycle insurance rates are not subsidized by Manitobans who don&#8217;t ride motorcycles, the way other vehicles are.</P>  <P>That means that all motorcycle insurance claims are paid only by the people who ride motorcycles, not by people who don&#8217;t. And since the people who do ride is relatively small, and since claim costs &#8211; especially injury claims &#8211; are high, insurance premiums for motorcycles have to be high to cover those costs. Even for those who have never had a claim in some 30 years of riding.</P>  <P>Doesn&#8217;t MPI understand that it&#8217;s cars and trucks that do all the damage when they hit motorcycles? They must be real boneheads if they don&#8217;t. Besides, wasn&#8217;t our government-run insurance program put in place for the equal treatment of and for the benefit of all the people of Manitoba? Yet motorcyclists are being singled out and treated with extreme prejudice.</P>  <P>Some ABATE (All Bikers Aimed Towards Education) members have said for years that Marilyn McLaren, now the head of MPI, just hates motorcycles and wants to get as many of them off the road as possible. (probably had a run in with some bikers in her youth that scarred her forever.) There seems to be some truth to that since the number of motorcycles registered in this province has been indeed dropping as the cost of insurance has gone up.</P>  <P>if that&#8217;s true, MPI needs a new CEO.</P>  <P>Preferably a biker.</P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 28-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Warrants should bar licence, MLA says
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A Conservative MLA wants to prevent people with outstanding warrants for indictable offences from renewing their driver's licence. </P>  <P>Steinbach MLA Kelvin Goertzen said Monday he will introduce a private member's bill in the legislature to that effect in the coming days. </P>  <P>The government already has rules in place to suspend the driver's licences of people behind in their family support payments, Goertzen noted. "So I think in today's world of technology this is something that can be done," he added. </P>  <P>The MLA said he didn't know how many people might be affected by such a provision, although he noted that there are 10,000 to 12,000 outstanding warrants at any one time.</P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 29-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Road Safety Week: Pay attention, it's a circus out there
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>From cell phones and GPS to mp3 players and your morning coffee, distracted road users is an issue facing all Canadians. </P>  <P>Whether you are a driver, a motorcyclist, a pedestrian or a cyclist, road user distractions affect everyone. </P>  <P>During national Road Safety Week the Canada Safety Council wants everyone to take precautions while they are out and about. </P>  <P>Keep your eyes on the road and on other road users. Be vigilant and stay aware of your surroundings at all times. </P>  <P>During the spring and summer months is it especially important for car and truck drivers to keep their eyes on the road, as vulnerable road users (pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists) are more prevalent on Canadian roads. </P>  <P>They are at greater risk of potential injury or death should they become involved in a collision on Canada's roadways. </P>  <P>Vulnerable road users make up approximately 25 per cent of road users killed or seriously injured each year in traffic crashes. </P>  <P>In 2007, 662 vulnerable road users were killed and 3,485 were seriously injured. </P>  <P>Drivers must be aware of pedestrians crossing at intersections and people coming out between parked cars, especially small children. Drivers must also share the road with cyclists and motorcyclists. </P>  <P>If you are distracted by a ringing phone or trying to program your GPS it becomes harder to react and avoid potential collisions with vulnerable road users. It is essential to limit your distractions behind the wheel to ensure the safety of you, other drivers and vulnerable road users. </P>  <P>Quebec, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and Labrador, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba all have hand-held cell phone legislation in effect. Within the past year Ontario, B.C., and PEI have gone a step further and introduced a ban on all hand-held devices, not just hand-held cell phones. </P>  <P>Distracting activities that take your eyes off the road are more likely to lead to collisions. </P>  <P>This law makes it illegal for drivers to talk, text, type, or dial using hand-held cell phones and other hand-held communication and entertainment devices. </P>  <P>This includes using GPS, mp3 players (iPods), and entertainment devices with a display screen visible to the driver while he or she is driving. These devices can be used if programmed before starting to drive. </P>  <P>Teens and young adults under 35 are the most frequent users of cell phones while driving. </P>  <P>Studies show that a driver using a cell phone is four times more likely to be in a crash than a driver focused on the road. </P>  <P>Other studies show that dialing and texting carries the highest degree of risk of all cell phone-related activities. </P>  <P>A driver is 23 times more likely to get into a collision if they are texting or typing behind the wheel. Text messaging takes driver's eyes away from the road for 4.6 seconds over a six-second interval. </P>  <P>This compares to driving an entire length of a football field without looking at the road while travelling 90 kilometres per hour. </P>  <P>Canada Safety Council urges you to always make driving your first priority. </P>  <P>Hands-free is not risk free. When you're talking on a telephone, whether it's hands-free or hand-held, the attention is to the conversation and less on the road. </P>  <P>It's the conversation, and the depth of the conversation, that's distracting. </P>  <P>Don't let your emotions or work get in the way of your safety and the safety of other road users while behind the wheel. </P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 30-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man politician seeks to keep criminals from getting behind the wheel
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Tue May 18 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ A Conservative member of the Manitoba legislature wants to prevent people with outstanding warrants for serious offences from renewing their driver's licence. </P> <P>Kelvin Goertzen says he hopes to introduce a private member's bill this week that would take advantage of Manitoba's driver licensing system to put more criminals behind bars. </P> <P>Goertzen says the legislation would not be costly as it would only involve the sharing of information between Manitoba Public Insurance, police forces and Manitoba Justice. </P> <P>He says the bill could at least allow people with warrants for offences, such as assault, to be better tracked. </P> <P>Goertzen estimates there are currently about 10,000 to 12,000 outstanding warrants in the province. </P> <P>Under existing regulations, licence renewal can be suspended for those with outstanding child support payments, outstanding Highway Traffic Act penalties and unpaid parking fines. (Winnipeg Sun)</P>

--30--

Title: 31-Dec-13
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Road safety week: Unsafe driving takes deadly toll
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed May 19 2010   Page: B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>If the police warnings don't get you to drive safely, then maybe the mounting death toll on the city's streets and provincial highways will. </P> <P>As the Winnipeg Police Service and RCMP launched a provincewide blitz Tuesday to crack down on speeders, impaired drivers and those without seatbelts, the sobering statistics show traffic fatalities are on track to outpace last year's total of 11. Already, there have been nine traffic-related deaths on Winnipeg's streets. </P> <P>"Speeding, if you can reduce that and get people to wear their seatbelts, we wouldn't be going to people's doors, I would say, 40 per cent of the time," said Staff Sgt. Mark Hodgson of the WPS's central traffic unit. </P> <P>The campaign for Canada Road Safety Week will have city police and about 75 RCMP detachments doing traffic stops just in time for the first long weekend of the summer. </P> <P>"Just don't get behind the wheel if you've been drinking, plain and simple," said RCMP Insp. Mark LeMaistre, who runs RCMP D Division traffic services. </P> <P>LeMaistre said Mounties were surprised to learn there have already been 21 deaths in their jurisdiction this year. </P> <P>About 60 per cent of the 93 deaths the RCMP handled in Manitoba in 2009 were related to drivers or passengers who weren't buckled in. </P> <P>Some of those drivers involved in those crashes also exhibited other high- risk behaviours like speeding or drinking. </P> <P>WPS Insp. Jim Poole said officers will also focus on parents who do not properly buckle up their children before driving. </P> <P>"Kids don't have a choice, parents do," said Poole. </P> <P>The RCMP's top traffic officer in Manitoba takes it one step farther. </P> <P>LeMaistre supports measures that would target drunk drivers, like random breathalyzers by police. </P> <P>Hodgson said crash fatalities carry a heavy economic cost, as well as a human toll. </P> <P>He said figures given to him by Manitoba Public Insurance indicate there's a cost of about $246,000 associated with each crash death. </P> <P>He pointed to the deaths of Adam Gattinger and Tyler Musey, who died in January after a blue Infiniti G35 struck a hydro pole on Bishop Grandin Boulevard at a high speed. </P> <P>"If we can reduce two of those (deaths), not only will we reduce the amount of grief and horror that would be put on those families but the fact of the matter is, we would probably be doing a service for the rest of Manitobans," he said. </P> <P><A href="mailto:gabrielle.giroday@freepress.mb.ca">gabrielle.giroday@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>Sobering statistics </P> <P>How many traffic deaths do police deal with? </P> <P>2010: Nine deaths, so far, in Winnipeg, 21 deaths city in RCMP jurisdiction* </P> <P>2009: 11 deaths in Winnipeg, 93 outside city in RCMP jurisdiction </P> <P>2008: 15 deaths in Winnipeg, 86 outside city in RCMP jurisdiction </P> <P>(*Numbers reported do not include rural police forces like Brandon Police Service or Altona Police Service) </P>

--30--

Title: 1-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Checkstops come after increase in fatalities
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>They're as predictable during May long weekend and the days leading up to it as a spike in gas prices. </P> <P>Already faced with an increase in fatalities in 2010, police agencies across Manitoba are conducting checkstops now through the end of the Victoria Day weekend to catch impaired drivers, speeders and seatbelt scofflaws, and encourage safe driving. </P> <P>Manitoba has recorded more fatalities during the opening five months of 2010 compared with the same period in 2009, largely due to people not buckling up, said RCMP Insp. Mark LeMaistre. </P> <P>"If they were wearing their seatbelts, the injuries may have been minimal," LeMaistre said Tuesday. </P> <P>Seatbelt negligence, speed and alcohol account for a large number of preventable road fatalities, police say. </P> <P>"Last year, 60% of those deaths were from unrestrained occupants," LeMaistre said. </P> <P>Ottawa is floating the idea of random breathalyzers, which LeMaistre said he supports because it would make Canada's roads safer. </P> <P>This week, the message offered by police is don't drive if you've been drinking, buckle up and slow down. </P> <P>LeMaistre, the officer in charge of the RCMP's traffic services division, and Winnipeg police Insp. Jim Poole said checkstops will be set up in strategic areas or hotspots where people are known to drink alcohol and drive aggressively. </P> <P>Canada wide </P> <P>Police will also be checking boats on lakes and rivers. </P> <P>The goal of the annual Road Safety Week, which began Tuesday and ends Monday, is to prevent fatal and injury collisions. </P> <P>Locally, the Canada-wide campaign kicked off with checkstops at Highway 9 and the North Perimeter Highway. </P> <P>The campaign is held during the week of May long weekend because it's the unofficial kickoff to summer. </P> <P>More people are driving and collisions are more frequent during this particular weekend, said Poole, who oversees Winnipeg's central traffic unit. </P> <P>So far in 2010, nine people have died in crashes in Winnipeg and 20 in RCMP jurisdiction. </P> <P>Of those 20, about 45% weren't wearing a seatbelt, LeMaistre said. </P> <P>In 2009, there were 11 fatalities in Winnipeg and 93 in RCMP-policed areas, which average 90 to 95 deaths per year, LeMaistre said. </P> <P>There's also a financial cost. Manitoba Public Insurance says a speed-related fatality costs its ratepayers almost $247,000 on average. The cost covers death benefits, vehicle payouts, funeral expenses and other things, MPI says.</P>

--30--

Title: 2-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Deplorable delay ; Long-awaited photo radar report to be issued after civic election
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Wed May 19 2010   Page: 5   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A long-awaited independent report on the effectiveness of Winnipeg's photo enforcement program has been delayed again. </P> <P>And it's not expected to be completed until late 2010, well after the October civic election. </P> <P>The city and police have been promising since 2005 to commission an in-depth analysis on whether photo radar and red-light cameras -- introduced in 2003 -- are meeting their long-term goals of reducing collisions and injuries. </P> <P>The city hired the Traffic Injury Research Foundation to perform the study. After numerous delays, the study was supposed to be complete by 2009. But a year later, there's still no report and police officials now say it won't be finished until late 2010 at the earliest. </P> <P>"Setbacks related to the ongoing development and testing of monitoring equipment resulted in delays with the expected completion date now being late 2010," police say in their 2009 photo enforcement annual report. </P> <P>Under a conditions of authority agreement between the city and the province, police are supposed to produce annual statistics on how photo enforcement is reducing collisions and injuries, including the severity of injuries. </P> <P>However, the annual reports from police have been grossly incomplete with no collision and injury data whatsoever related to photo radar and limited crash and injury numbers for intersection cameras. </P> <P>Despite that, the province has refused to enforce the terms of the agreement, allowing the annual reports to be submitted late and without the required data and analysis. </P> <P>It's something the city auditor's department pointed out as far back as 2006 in its own review of the city's photo enforcement program. </P> <P>The auditor concluded that until controlled studies and analysis were carried out for photo enforcement, police would be unable to conclude whether the program is achieving its long-term goals. </P> <P>"Without this key performance information in the future, the WPS will not be able to demonstrate that the photo enforcement program has achieved its stated outcomes," the audit report stated. </P> <P>Four years later, there's still no report. </P> <P>Meanwhile, the city has expanded photo enforcement in the absence of that performance information. Police doubled the number of mobile photo radar vehicles to 10 from five in 2006. And they've increased the number of intersection cameras to 33 from 30 which rotate through 50 locations, up from 48 in 2006. </P> <P>Why would the city expand a traffic enforcement program without the demonstrated evidence it's reducing collisions and injuries? </P> <P>It certainly lends credence to the argument the program is more about the money than about safety. The city knows with certainty that by expanding photo radar and red-light cameras they will increase revenues. What they don't know is whether the expansion will reduce collisions and injuries. </P> <P>Does planting a photo radar vehicle on Portage Avenue, Pembina Highway or McPhillips Street in a "school zone" on Sundays in July really reduce collisions and injuries? </P> <P>If it does, there is no data to support it. </P> <P>Police have massively expanded photo radar in construction zones, even when no workers are present. </P> <P>It has made money for them. But the city has no statistics at all to demonstrate how that has reduced collisions and injuries to construction workers. </P> <P>The city has a responsibility to ensure that data is gathered and made public. </P> <P>And the province has an obligation to enforce its conditions of authority agreement with the city. </P> <P>After all, photo radar exists under provincial legislation. </P> <P>And so far, there is no evidence this program is working.</P>

--30--

Title: 3-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police cracking down on road safety
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Tuesday, May 18, 2010 | 5:01 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police in Manitoba are warning the public that they'll be cracking down on driving infractions over the May long weekend.</P> <P>Police said they will be setting up roadside checkstops to ensure drivers are sober, not speeding and that they and their passengers are using seatbelts.</P> <P>Winnipeg police are cautioning the public that fatal crashes appear to be up this year.</P> <P>There were 11 fatal crashes in the city in 2009, but already this year there have been nine, police said.</P> <P>The extra enforcement measures began on Tuesday and will continue through next Monday, police said.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/18/man-driving-infractions-police.html#ixzz0oNarENiC">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/18/man-driving-infractions-police.html#ixzz0oNarENiC</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Mountie accused of filing fake MPI claim
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Thu May 20 2010   Page: 4   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Mounties have charged one of their own after an officer allegedly tried to commit automobile insurance fraud while he was off-duty last summer. </P> <P>Houman Shoaai, a 39-year-old corporal stationed in Elphinstone, is accused of filing a fraudulent Autopac claim to Manitoba Public Insurance on July 7, 2009, RCMP said Wednesday. </P> <P>He faces a charge of attempted fraud over $5,000. </P> <P>Shoaai has been an RCMP officer for about 10 years, said spokeswoman Sgt. Line Karpish. </P> <P>Police said Shoaai filed a claim with the Crown corporation following a collision involving a personal vehicle near Elphinstone, about 270 km northwest of Winnipeg in Western Manitoba. </P> <P>Alleged inconsistencies in Shoaai's claim spurred a follow-up investigation by MPI's special investigation unit and a referral to Manitoba Justice, RCMP said. </P> <P>Neither the RCMP or MPI would reveal specific details of the alleged fraud or collision. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said bogus claims are usually detected by an adjuster and referred to the investigative unit, comprised of 25 former police officers. </P> <P>Code of conduct </P> <P>Smiley said investigators probe 3,000 claims per year and about 100 of those result in criminal charges, although many customers voluntarily withdraw a claim when it doesn't progress. </P> <P>Shoaai has been assigned to administrative duties, meaning he won't be responding to complaints or dealing with the public, and an internal disciplinary process has been initiated while the case is before the courts, Karpish said. </P> <P>RCMP officers are required to follow a code of conduct laid out in the RCMP Act, Karpish said. Violations of the code may result in informal or formal discipline, ranging from counselling or a reprimand to a dock in pay or dismissal, Karpish said. </P> <P>Yellowhead RCMP members served Shoaai with a summons to appear in a Minnedosa provincial courtroom June 29. RCMP described Shoaai as a regular member of the police force.</P>

--30--

Title: 5-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In brief: Mountie faces charge
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Thu May 20 2010   Page: A9
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>AN RCMP corporal has been charged with attempted fraud over $5,000 for his role in an alleged auto insurance fraud. </P> <P>In a statement, RCMP said a Manitoba Public Insurance investigation revealed that Cpl. Houman Shoaai, 39, filed an Autopac claim after a collision involving a personal vehicle near Elphinstone. The claim was later found to have inconsistencies that triggered the MPI investigation. The case was referred to Manitoba Justice. </P> <P>Shoaai was off duty when the alleged incident occurred. </P> <P>He will appear in a Minnedosa court on June 29 and has been re-assigned to administrative duties while RCMP pursue an internal disciplinary process. </P>

--30--

Title: 6-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letter of the day: Picking on bikers
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Thu May 20 2010   Page: A15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Re: Hog Heaven? You won't find it here (May 12). Brian Smiley attempts to justify Manitoba Public Insurance's outrageous motorcycle insurance premiums by claiming they're required to avoid cross-subsidization (car drivers paying for motorcycle claims). What he doesn't mention is that MPI's calculations are based on an unfair model. </P> <P>The no-fault system used by MPI means that regardless of who caused the accident, collision repairs and injury claims come out of the damaged vehicle's account. For example, a motorcyclist and a car are involved in an accident with the car at fault (U.S. statistics show this is the case in 70 per cent of motorcycle accidents). Car claims come out of the car pot of money while motorcycle claims come out of the motorcycle account. </P> <P>A much fairer system would be to assign fault, with all costs related to the accident assigned to the at-fault vehicle. This would go a long way to reducing the costs attributed to motorcycles' share of claims. The fact that this isn't the case indicates to me MPI has no problem sticking it to the motorcyclist. We're a rapidly shrinking minority the public has little sympathy for, and our protests can be safely ignored. </P> <P>Further proof of MPI's agenda of removing motorcycles from Manitoba's streets? Just to get their licence, a new motorcyclist must face five written and practical tests, including a mandatory training program costing either $275 (eight-hour course) or $350 (21-hour course). Any novice who has taken this course will tell you that it's a miserable, stressful experience that's rarely passed the first time, and is often enough to put them off biking for good. Couple this with the sky-high insurance costs and it's a wonder any motorcycles are out there. But I'm sure MPI has a few more ideas. </P> <P>John Jorgenson <BR>Winnipeg </P> <P>Kudos to Manitoba Public Insurance for not having motorists subsidize noisy, outdated contraptions. </P> <P>Motorbikes are an unnecessary, dangerous and evil irritant that we can do without. If they ever had a best-before date, it has long since past. </P> <P>KEN HOLT <BR>Winnipeg</P>

--30--

Title: 7-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CRIME-Collision-Fraud
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press - Broadcast News   Wed May 19 2010   Section: Western Regional News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>ELPHINSTONE, Man. - A Manitoba RCMP officer has been charged with attempted fraud in connection with an alleged off-duty incident involving a collision claim for a personal vehicle. </P> <P>RCMP say the charge follows an investigation by Manitoba Public Insurance into a claim filed last summer for an accident near the community of Elphinstone. </P> <P>They say inconsistencies in that claim led to a further investigation by the Crown-owned insurance company and subsequent referral to Manitoba Justice. </P> <P>Mounties were told last month about the investigators' findings and an independent Crown opinion that was sought by the insurance company. </P> <P>Cpl. Houman Shoaai of Elphinstone was charged on Monday and will appear in a Minnedosa courtroom on June 29. </P> <P>Shoaai has been reassigned to administrative duties and will face an internal disciplinary hearing. </P>

--30--

Title: 8-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Mountie accused of auto fraud sues MPI Insurance investigation was 'high-handed and arrogant,' officer says
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Wednesday, May 19, 2010 | 8:16 PM CT  James Turner, CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Mountie accused of attempted fraud after claiming he lost control of his SUV and ended up in a lake says he was humiliated and embarrassed by the insurance company's investigation into the incident.</P> <P>Cpl. Houman Shoaai, 39, has initiated a lawsuit against Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI), court documents obtained by CBC News show.</P> <P>The officer claims he was driving his Hummer H3 when he swerved to miss a deer on a road, lost control and wound up in a lake near the community of Elphinston, where he is posted.</P> <P>The RCMP announced Wednesday that Shoaai has been charged with attempted fraud over $5,000 in connection with the incident that occurred July 7, 2009, about 260 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.</P> <P>An initial investigation into his $20,750 insurance claim, conducted by MPI, found inconsistencies and led to a further investigation, RCMP said.</P> <P>Ultimately, Crown prosecutors recommended charging Shoaai on April 22. MPI sought an independent Crown opinion in the case, police said.</P> <P>'Unsavory individual'<BR>But in the lawsuit filed by Shoaai on March 11 — more than two months before he was criminally charged — the officer alleges that the public insurer's investigation violated his privacy and caused him "humiliation and embarrassment" when a female friend was approached regarding the probe.</P> <P>The lawsuit claims that MPI illegally ran his name through a national police database "or other police sources" and obtained a financial background check without his consent.</P> <P>Shoaai also alleges that the insurance investigator assigned to the case approached his friend and told her he was an "unsavoury individual."</P> <P>She was told he "had a record for spousal abuse and had escaped conviction by taking out a $20,000 loan and paying off the complainant," the lawsuit alleges.</P> <P>Financial woes alleged<BR>The insurance investigator is also alleged to have disclosed that Shoaai "was deeply in debt," and proceeded to provide the woman with intimate details about his personal finances.</P> <P>Shoaai's relationship with the woman has been "adversely affected," the documents said.</P> <P>MPI denied Shoaai's insurance claim in a Feb. 3 letter, saying he had wilfully made a false statement to the public insurer.</P> <P>Shoaai disputes this and claims that MPI refuses to provide the proof that he did.</P> <P>The allegations in the lawsuit have not been proven in court and no statement of defence has been filed yet. No court date to hear the lawsuit has been set.</P> <P>Shoaai is seeking reimbursement from MPI for the Hummer, along with undisclosed damages for breach of contract and for acting in a "high handed and arrogant" manner.</P> <P>He is scheduled to make his first court appearance in Minnedosa on the attempted fraud charge on June 29.</P> <P>RCMP said Shoaai has been assigned to desk duties while an internal disciplinary review of his performance takes place.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/19/ramp-attempted-fraud-lawsuit-mpi-shoaai.html#ixzz0oTSSgWo7">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/19/ramp-attempted-fraud-lawsuit-mpi-shoaai.html#ixzz0oTSSgWo7</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Mountie accused of fraud suing MPI ; Says friend was told private details
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Mountie accused of attempted auto insurance fraud is suing Manitoba Public Insurance, claiming the Crown corporation humiliated and embarrassed him and overstepped its duty during the investigation. </P> <P>Houman Shoaai, a 39-year-old RCMP constable, claims MPI wrongfully obtained and shared private information about him and withheld the results of its investigation, resulting in breaches of privacy and contract. </P> <P>He filed a statement of claim in the Court of Queen's Bench in March but the public insurer has yet to file a statement of defence. </P> <P>Shoaai claims MPI "has been high-handed and arrogant in its dealings" with him. </P> <P>This week, RCMP charged Shoaai with attempted fraud over $5,000 and moved him to administrative duties. His Autopac claim allegedly contained inconsistencies, police said. </P> <P>Lost control </P> <P>Court documents reveal new details about the off-duty crash involving Shoaai's 2007 Hummer H3 in July 2009. </P> <P>Shoaai claims he was driving near Elphinstone, where he's stationed, when he swerved to avoid a deer, lost control and went into a lake. Elphinstone is about 270 km northwest of Winnipeg. </P> <P>The Hummer, valued at $20,750, was a total loss, according to documents. </P> <P>MPI's special investigation unit probed the Autopac claim and gave its findings to the RCMP. MPI rejected the claim in February and accused him of providing false information, documents state. </P> <P>Shoaai fired back, suggesting MPI didn't investigate fairly or objectively, used illegal or improper investigation methods, failed to advise him of the investigation's results, and failed to maintain confidentiality and privacy. </P> <P>Shoaai claims MPI obtained private and confidential information from the Canadian Police Information Centre or other police sources, and financial information through a credit investigation. </P> <P>An MPI investigator allegedly shared details with Shoaai's female friend in Dauphin, telling her he had a record for spousal abuse and escaped conviction by taking out a $20,000 loan to pay off the complainant. </P> <P>The investigator allegedly told the woman Shoaai was an "unsavoury" individual and deeply in debt, and shared details of his finances and transactions, documents state. </P> <P>Shoaai claims the investigator gave false and misleading information to the woman and adversely affected his relationship with her. </P> <P>He is seeking various types of damages, including $20,750 to cover the vehicle. </P> <P>None of the allegations has been proven in court. </P> <P>Shoaai and MPI declined comment. </P>

--30--

Title: 10-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RCMP officer faces charge  Attempted fraud alleged after investigation by MPI
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A member of the Yellowhead RCMP Detachment Area has been formally charged with attempted fraud over $5,000.</P> <P>The 39-year-old Corporal - who is a member of the Elphinstone detachment - was charged with the offense on Monday, May 17 after an investigation that began in 2009.</P> <P>RCMP Media Relations spokesperson Line Karpish said an investigation conducted by the Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) Special Investigation Unit alleges that on July 7, 2009, the off-duty officer filed an Autopac claim relating to a collision involving a personal vehicle near Elphinstone. Inconsistencies to the claim led to a follow up investigation by MPI and subsequent referral to Manitoba Justice.</P> <P>On April 22, 2010, RCMP D Division was notified by MPI of the investigation findings as well as the results of an independent Crown opinion also sought out by MPI.</P> <P>The man is slated to make his first court appearance in Minnedosa on June 29.</P> <P>Sgt. Karpish said an internal disciplinary process has been initiated, and the officer has been reassigned to administrative duties.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Long weekend traffic is a perfect storm on highways
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>IT’S the one we’ve all been waiting for: the May long weekend. Unlike other long weekends throughout the year, this one can set the tone for all the rest. After months of being confined to the indoors, the anticipation of getting out of town for “May-long” can make us all overly eager when we hit the road.</P> <P>“This weekend is the annual kick-off for many cottagers and campers,” says Clif Eden, road safety manager of Manitoba Public Insurance. “We encourage everyone to drive safely so you can enjoy it for years to come.</P> <P>“We see an increase in traffic-related fatalities and injuries every long weekend compared to other weekends in the year. We all need a heightened awareness on the highway when we’re heading to and from the lake or cottage on long weekends.”</P> <P>According to Manitoba Public Insurance claims statistics, 36 people were killed between 2004 and 2008 in traffic collisions on the long weekends from May to September. Another 1,710 people were injured or seriously injured, many deaths and injuries that could have been avoided.</P> <P>These crashes can be attributed to many factors, says Eden, citing heavier traffic volumes and a general level of impatience among drivers. The best approach to the long-weekend drive is to make the journey as important as the destination.</P> <P>“Keep yourself, your family and those around you safe by driving defensively,” says Eden. “Make it a weekend you won’t forget—for all the right reasons.”</P> <P>In addition to heavier traffic, the increase in long-weekend traffic accidents could also be caused by people not buckling up, distracted drivers and, of course, driving while impaired. Speeding is also a contributing factor, says Eden.</P> <P>“Stay alert, plan an appropriate amount of travel time and slow down,” suggests Eden. “Excessive speeds reduce the amount of time you have to respond to hazards and make decisions.”</P> <P>The May long weekend should be the beginning of a fun-filled summer. Safe driving is the beginning of that journey.</P>

--30--

Title: 12-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: May long weekend check stops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>RCMP and Several Law Enforcement Partners Team up for Road Watch Check stops.</P> <P>In conjunction with National Road Safety We e k , the Westman Traffic Services unit will be hosting a check stop on May 21, in the Brandon area. The check stop is a Manitoba Public Insurance funded “Road Watch” project to aid in prevention death and injury on Manitoba highways over the May long weekend.</P> <P>Members from Virden, Souris, Minnedosa Detachments along with the Whitehead Police Service, Rivers Police Department and Compliance Inspectors from the Manitoba Department of Transport will be conducting the check stop throughout the day.</P> <P>The primary objective of the check stop is to improve the safety of the motoring public by apprehending impaired drivers, enforcing the speed limit, ensuring all motorists are wearing their seat belts and detecting vehicle defects.</P>

--30--

Title: 13-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stopping killers on the road
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Fri May 21 2010   Page: A4
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba's plan to get drivers to stay off their cellphones has the United Nations on side. </P> <P>Both the province and the UN, and even television personality Oprah Winfrey, say there's a new a killer on the road as too many drivers use mobile devices when they should keep both hands on the wheel. </P> <P>Next month, Manitoba will pass a law that bans cellphone use and texting while driving. The province and police are discussing the timetable for officers to begin issuing tickets. The proposed fine for talking or texting on a handheld device will be $191 . </P> <P>Transportation Minister Steve Ashton said Thursday he wants police to act as soon as possible now that the UN has said it wants governments around the world to crack down on yakking and driving. </P> <P>"One thing I suggest, by the way, is that people who want to continue to have access to the cellphones when driving, they had better start getting their hand's-free devices or getting used to pulling over to the side of the road, because very shortly, there will not be any options. It will be the law." </P> <P>Ashton said the province will soon announce when police will start issuing tickets. </P> <P>United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said this week he supports a global safety campaign, led by the U.S. and Russia, to get drivers on every street and highway to put down the phone and keep both hands on the wheel. </P> <P>The UN said driver distraction -- mainly through the use of mobile phones -- is one of the emerging challenges of road safety as wireless technology expands. Ban Ki-moon said up to 90 per cent of people use mobile phones while driving in some countries. </P> <P>At the same time, studies say using a mobile phone increases the risk of a crash by about four times. "A culture in which driving while distracted, on the phone, or text messaging, is unacceptable," he said. "Unacceptable in the eyes of the law and the public. </P> <P>"I want every driver in the world to get the message: Texting while driving kills. No SMS is worth an SOS." </P> <P>Ashton said the UN's move is a recognition cellphone use distracts drivers. "When you see accident rates as much as four times greater among people using cellphones or texting devices, it's a growing problem." </P> <P>Of the 93 deaths in rural Manitoba in 2009, more than half involved speed or drivers and passengers who weren't buckled in. So far, 21 people have been killed this year. Eleven people died on Winnipeg streets last year, and nine have been killed so far this year. </P> <P>What's missing is exact data on collisions caused by drivers too busy talking or firing off a text -- people in accidents won't admit they were on a cellphone call when they crashed. </P> <P>But experts say that doesn't matter. </P> <P>U.S. transportation secretary Ray LaHood said at the UN that drivers who send and receive texts take their eyes off the road for an average of four seconds, going the length of a football field without paying attention. A football field is 120 metres long. </P> <P>That's enough for the UN to prohibit its employees from texting while driving UN vehicles, following a move by U.S. Barack Obama last year to direct federal employees not to engage in texting while driving government vehicles. The U.S. is also looking at prohibiting texting by drivers of commercial vehicles. Truck and bus drivers who text while driving commercial vehicles may be subject to civil or criminal penalties of up to $2,750. </P>

--30--

Title: 14-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police warn drivers about photo radar
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Thursday, May 20, 2010 | 4:34 PM CT  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>As Winnipeg's construction season begins, police are advising motorists about how they'll be using photo radar in construction zones.</P> <P>Const. Raymond Howes said Thursday that photo radar can be set up at any hour of the day, seven days a week in long-term construction zones where the speed limit has been reduced.</P> <P>However, in other construction areas where the speed limit has not been reduced, photo radar can only be used when workers are present.</P> <P>"As long as [it's] properly signed when there's a permanently reduced speed zone, then photo enforcement will take place," Howes said.</P> <P>"It can also take place in zones where there is no reduction of speeds … [but] the signs have to be quite specific as to beginning of construction and end of construction.</P> <P>Howes said photo radar will not be used in short-term construction areas, but police officers can still do traffic enforcement there.</P> <P>Under provincial law, construction zones must have signs indicating where the zone starts and ends for photo radar tickets to be legal.</P> <P>Controversy in previous years<BR>The use of photo radar has been a hot topic since provincial court justice of the peace Norm Sundstrom dismissed nine photo radar tickets in early 2009.</P> <P>According to provincial law, the temporary speed limit when passing construction zones is 60 kilometres per hour. Although the drivers had exceeded that limit, they were not going faster than the regular 80 km/h speed limit for that particular roadway, and there were no workers present.</P> <P>Without the workers, there was no safety issue, so the regular speed limit should apply, Sundstrom ruled.</P> <P>The province disagreed and was set to appeal until it realized it would likely lose on a technicality. A sign declaring the temporary speed limit must be set up at the start of a construction zone as well as at the end. A sign had only been placed at the beginning of the construction zones where the drivers had been photographed.</P> <P>Around 867 tickets yet to be paid were cancelled by the government as a result of the technicality.</P> <P>The rest of the 60,000 tickets that had been paid were not refunded. </P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/20/man-photo-radar-construction-zones.html#ixzz0oZIli3JP">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/20/man-photo-radar-construction-zones.html#ixzz0oZIli3JP</A><BR></P>

--30--
