--30--

Title: 16-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stay safe this weekend
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: CHRIS KITCHING  The Central Plains Herald Leader  May 22, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG — They’re as predictable during May long weekend and the days leading up to it as a spike in gas prices. </P> <P>Already faced with an increase in fatalities in 2010, police agencies across Manitoba are conducting checkstops now through the end of the Victoria Day weekend to catch impaired drivers, speeders and seatbelt scofflaws, and encourage safe driving.</P> <P>Manitoba has recorded more fatalities during the opening five months of 2010 compared with the same period in 2009, largely due to people not buckling up, said RCMP Insp. Mark LeMaistre.</P> <P>“If they were wearing their seatbelts, the injuries may have been minimal,” LeMaistre said on May 18.</P> <P>Seatbelt negligence, speed and alcohol account for a large number of preventable road fatalities, police say.</P> <P>“Last year, 60% of those deaths were from unrestrained occupants,” LeMaistre said.</P> <P>Ottawa is floating the idea of random breathalyzers, which LeMaistre said he supports because it would make Canada’s roads safer. </P> <P>This week, the message offered by police is don’t drive if you’ve been drinking, buckle up and slow down.</P> <P>LeMaistre, the officer in charge of the RCMP’s traffic services division, and Winnipeg police Insp. Jim Poole said checkstops will be set up in strategic areas or hotspots where people are known to drink alcohol and drive aggressively.</P> <P>Police will also be checking boats on lakes and rivers.</P> <P>The goal of the annual Road Safety Week, which began on May 18 and ends Monday, is to prevent fatal and injury collisions.</P> <P>Locally, the Canada-wide campaign kicked off with checkstops at Highway 9 and the North Perimeter Highway.</P> <P>The campaign is held during the week of May long weekend because it’s the unofficial kickoff to summer.</P> <P>More people are driving and collisions are more frequent during this particular weekend, said Poole, who oversees Winnipeg’s central traffic unit.</P> <P>So far in 2010, nine people have died in crashes in Winnipeg and 20 in RCMP jurisdiction.</P> <P>Of those 20, about 45% weren’t wearing a seatbelt, LeMaistre said.</P> <P>In 2009, there were 11 fatalities in Winnipeg and 93 in RCMP-policed areas, which average 90 to 95 deaths per year, LeMaistre said.</P> <P>There’s also a financial cost. Manitoba Public Insurance says a speed-related fatality costs its ratepayers almost $247,000 on average. The cost covers death benefits, vehicle payouts, funeral expenses and other things, MPI says.</P>

--30--

Title: 17-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Road Safety Week: A Good Time To Evaluate Your Driving
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Sentinel Courier Pilot Mound  May 25, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>About 90 people are killed on Manitoba roadways every year. Sadly, many of those deaths could have been prevented if someone had adjusted their driving behavior.</P> <P>The goal of Canada’s Road Safety Week, is for all drivers to self-evaluate, (and self-correct) their behavior while on the road. If you find yourself speeding, slow down. If you notice (or your wife notices) that you don't use your signals very often - make the correction. Wear your seatbelt. Don’t drink and drive. Drive to road conditions. </P> <P>During Road Safety Week in Manitoba, the RCMP will be conducting beefed-up traffic enforcements throughout the province. Manitoba Public Insurance is once again funding the RoadWatch program, which provides funding for police to conduct additional impaired driving roadside checks throughout the summer. Motorists can expect to see checkstops beginning this long weekend.</P> <P>“Any time someone decides to drink and drive, speed or just fail to signal, they potentially threaten the lives of others,” said Clif Eden, Road Safety Manager for Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>“Every year at this time, Manitoba Public Insurance join forces with law enforcement to raise awareness of this important truth. The timing of Road Safety Week has been strategically chosen, as it takes us into the first summer long weekend.”</P> <P>In addition to police road-side checks, another awareness activity to be launched during Road Safety Week is SpeedWatch, an annual program carried out in partnership with community volunteers. Armed with large speed-reader boards, concerned citizens will once again take to Manitoba streets and roadways to make neighbours aware of how fast they are driving.</P> <P>“More people are traveling and traffic crashes are more frequent,” said Eden. “Drivers can arrive at their destinations safely by making some minor driving adjustments.”</P>

--30--

Title: 18-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Time to fight back against the 'hogwash'
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Tue May 25 2010   Page: 11   Section: Editorial/Opinion
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>As taxpayers we can lay down and be used as doormats by our provincial government or we can fight back. It's time to do the latter. The province's new Reckless Spending Act is the first reason to rise up and speak out. </P> <P>OK so it's not exactly called the Reckless Spending Act, but that's essentially what it translates into. </P> <P>What the province is planning to do, through legislation, is no different than giving a reckless friend your credit card for the weekend. </P> <P>The government is trying to change the balanced budget law to allow it to rack up debt year after year until 2014 -- even though our economy is growing. Even cheekier, the legislation will reduce the current deficit spending penalty on cabinet ministers from a 40% pay reduction down to 20%. </P> <P>It's a shame really: just as no family would go out and buy a pair of Corvettes after a breadwinner lost his or her job, the original legislation helped ensure the government wouldn't be so irresponsible either. If we don't speak out, all the money will have to be paid back -- with significant interest. </P> <P>HOGWASH </P> <P>Fortunately, there is something you can do. </P> <P>First, call your MLA and tell them you want the budget balanced next year. Don't accept any hogwash government response about "oh no that would mean we'd have to cut health care." That's fear-mongering and nonsense. </P> <P>The government has been on a spending spree for a decade now, a pace that has increased at double the combined rate of inflation and population growth. To balance the budget, they would only have to reduce next year's spending levels by $448 million or approximately 3.3%. </P> <P>If they can't find 3.3% to trim after years of skyrocketing spending, then they're not trying very hard. </P> <P>Why not cut unnecessary expenditures like the $31-million grant to build a polar bear house in Winnipeg? What about cancelling the $3 million Greyhound bus grant or the $260 million they're going to loan to a U.S. wind power company? </P> <P>Another cut that should be made is to MLAs' personal expense accounts -- specifically the fact they are indexed for inflation. </P> <P>Yes, that's right, at some point our politicians chose to protect their expense accounts from inflation but they didn't do the same for taxpayers' incomes. </P> <P>Beyond calling your MLA, you can actually speak at the legislature in front of the committee that is reviewing the proposed changes. </P> <P>Consider it a healthy living exercise: you can show up and vent your frustrations and government members have to listen to it. A quick scan of <A href="http://www.taxpayer.com">www.taxpayer.com</A> will provide you with plenty of other examples of ways to save money. </P> <P>Most importantly, don't forget that if enough of us speak out, they'll have to respond to the problem. After all, there's a whole apparatus of politicians, political staff and others that are dependent on their cushy government jobs. </P> <P>If push comes to shove then they'll do what is necessary to keep the public happy and retain their jobs. Remember a decade ago when we as taxpayers rose up and forced them to return MPI's $20-million surplus back to drivers? We can do it again. </P> <P>It's time to speak out.</P>

--30--

Title: 19-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Vehicle imports soaring
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sun May 23 2010   Page: A9   Section: Sunday
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A strong loonie and a revived Canadian economy have prompted thousands of Manitobans to cross the line looking for deals on pickup trucks and cars. </P> <P>The Canada Border Services Agency said almost 3,300 vehicles were imported into Manitoba from the U.S. during the month of April -- more than double the number during the same period last year. </P> <P>Andrew Klatt, chief of operations for the southern Manitoba district of the CBSA, said Manitobans aren't shy about shopping for vehicles -- new or used -- across the border. </P> <P>The CBSA has been holding monthly workshops at its downtown Winnipeg Main Street office to help people navigate the rules and paperwork necessary to bring a vehicle into Canada. </P> <P>"It can be a real positive experience," Klatt said. </P> <P>John Carey, president of the Manitoba Motor Dealers Association, cautioned that bringing in a vehicle from the United States can be a tricky business, adding consumers should avail themselves of all the information they can. </P> <P>"I've seen some horror stories," said Carey, of Focus Hyundai. "It can be a real frustrating experience if you don't understand the full implications. It's not something someone should do without having a good understanding of the rules and regulations involved." </P> <P>Natalie Rochon, a CBSA senior service-compliance officer, said U.S. Customs requires all the paperwork to be faxed to their offices 72 hours before you bring the vehicle to the border. </P> <P>She said U.S. Customs is a stickler on the 72-hour requirement. </P> <P>Vehicle importing includes not just cars and trucks but also motorcycles, RVs, ATVs and trailers. </P> <P>Klatt advised Canadians not to try to scam the CSBA by getting a fake receipt for a lower value. </P> <P>"We do check the vehicle's value and the consequences just aren't worth the couple hundred bucks in savings you might get," Klatt said. </P> <P>Once at the border, the Canadian buyer will be issued a vehicle import form, which has to be filled out at the border crossing and cannot be filled out ahead of time. </P> <P>The CBSA will collect any applicable duties, levies and GST. </P> <P><A href="mailto:aldo.santin@freepress.mb.ca">aldo.santin@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>The Ins and outs of crossing the line </P> <P>There are a lot of dos and don'ts associated with vehicle importing, and the CBSA workshops simply explain them to you. You can also ask questions by calling 1-800-461-9999 or online at <A href="http://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca">www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca</A> </P> <P>Only vehicles manufactured for the American market can be brought into Canada through this process. To import a vehicle from another country, you have to check with the CBSA, the Registrar of Imported Vehicles and Transport Canada to see if it's eligible. </P> <P>All vehicles less than 15 years old have to meet Canadian safety standards -- did you know that daytime running lights aren't a requirement in the U.S.? </P> <P>All cars made in Canada, the U.S. and Mexico are exempt from the 6.1 per cent duty. </P> <P>All motorcylces, regardless of where they are made, are exempt from duty. </P> <P>You can tell from the vehicle's VIN number where it was made: If the first number is 1 through to 5, it means it was made somewhere in North America. </P> <P>Not all border crossings will process vehicle exports/imports. The Emerson/ Pembina crossing does. </P> <P>Canadian buyers need to obtain what's known as a title document for any used vehicle brought into Canada; title documents aren't available for new vehicles but the dealer will provide buyers with the manufacturer's statement of origin, which must be presented to Canada customs. </P> <P>Also needed are the sales receipt and something called a recall clearance letter. </P> <P>You'll have to make arrangements with Manitoba Public Insurance to get temporary insurance. </P> <P>The vehicle must pass federal inspection and you'll have to get all modifications completed before the Registrar of Vehicles issues more documents that you'll need before you go to Autopac to get permanent insurance.</P>

--30--

Title: 20-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Checkstops focus on drunk drivers
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Sat May 22 2010   Page: 14   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It seems obvious, but police agencies have to deliver the sobering message time and time again -- don't drink and drive. </P> <P>This Victoria Day weekend, city police will be conducting checkstops and saturation patrols -- focusing on places where people are drinking, be it nightclubs or social events -- through Monday during Canada Road Safety Week. Police are also looking for speeders, aggressive driving, and lack of seatbelts. </P> <P>Checkstops are also being conducted in rural Manitoba. </P> <P>Police are asking motorists to call 911 if they spot a suspected impaired driver. </P> <P>So far in 2010, impaired drivers have been involved in half of 20 fatal collisions in RCMP jurisdictions. </P> <P>Since Tuesday, Winnipeg police have ticketed more than 640 people for speeding and 170 for seatbelt negligence.</P>

--30--

Title: 21-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police have yet to apprehend car thief
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Sun May 23 2010   Section: Local
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police are still looking for the suspect or suspects who stole a vehicle from a night club parking lot early Saturday morning. </P> <P>Just after 3:30 a.m., police received a report that a vehicle had been taken from the lot on the 1100-block of 18th Street. The complainant reported that she had left her purse in an area she felt was safe, and later returned to find that someone had taken it. </P> <P>A short time later, the complainant noticed that her vehicle had been taken from the lot. The investigation revealed that the vehicle was observed leaving the parking lot just a few minutes earlier. </P> <P>The vehicle is described as a black 2010 GMC Sierra crew cab truck with the Manitoba licence plate ERY 389. </P> <P>Anyone with information is asked to call Crime Stoppers at 727-8477.</P>

--30--

Title: 22-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Collision on Manitoba-Ontario boundary sends several to area hospitals
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press   Sun May 23 2010   Section: Western Regional General News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>FALCON LAKE, Man. _ Five people were taken to hospital on Sunday after a head-on collision east of Winnipeg. </P> <P>RCMP said the crash involving a car and a sport utility vehicle occurred just before 3:30 a.m. on a stretch of the Trans-Canada Highway, approximately one kilometre west of Falcon Lake, Man. </P> <P>An eastbound car veered into the westbound lane and slammed head-on into a sport utility vehicle, police said. </P> <P>Emergency crews used the Jaws of Life to free the driver of the eastbound car, a 17-year-old girl, who is a resident of Falcon Lake. </P> <P>RCMP said she was transported to Lake of the Woods District Hospital in Kenora, Ont., and was later airlifted to Winnipeg's Health Sciences Centre in critical condition. </P> <P>The two male passengers in the car, a 17-year-old from Rennie, Man., and a 16-year-old from Landmark, were taken to the hospital in Kenora with non-life threatening injuries. </P> <P>The two occupants of the SUV, a 50-year-old female driver and a 52-year-old male passenger, were taken to hospital in Steinbach, Man., with non-life threatening injuries. RCMP Cpl. Rob Taylor said they are a married couple from Steinbach. </P> <P>The highway was closed for about three hours as the RCMP investigated the collision. </P> <P>Police say alcohol is not a factor in the collision.</P>

--30--

Title: 23-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Trans-Canada head-on collision injures five
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Mon May 24 2010   Page: 4   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Five people were taken to hospital after a head-on collision in Whiteshell Provincial Park on Sunday. </P> <P>Falcon Beach RCMP said the crash involving a car and a sport utility vehicle occurred about 3:25 a.m. on a two-lane section of the Trans-Canada Highway, approximately one kilometre west of Falcon Beach. An eastbound Buick Century veered into the westbound lane and slammed into a BMW X5 SUV, police said. </P> <P>FOUR OTHERS INJURED </P> <P>Emergency crews used the Jaws of Life to free the driver of the eastbound car, a 17-year-old girl from Falcon Lake. RCMP said she was transported to Lake of the Woods District Hospital in Kenora, Ont., and later airlifted to Winnipeg's Health Sciences Centre in critical condition. </P> <P>The two male passengers in the car, a 17-year-old from Rennie, Man., and a 16-year-old from Landmark, were taken to the Kenora hospital with non-life threatening injuries. </P> <P>The two occupants of the SUV, a 50-year-old woman and a 52-year-old male passenger, were taken to Steinbach's Bethesda Hospital with non-life threatening injuries. RCMP Cpl. Rob Taylor said they are a married couple from Steinbach. </P> <P>The highway was closed to traffic as RCMP investigated the accident for about three hours. </P> <P>Police say alcohol is not a factor in the collision.</P>

--30--

Title: 24-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Several injured in head-on collision
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Sunday, May 23, 2010 | 9:24 AM CST  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Several people were injured early Sunday morning in a head-on collision just west of Falcon Beach, RCMP say.</P> <P>A car veered into oncoming traffic and hit an SUV, police said. Emergency crews had to call out the Jaws of Life to extricate the driver of the car from the wreckage.</P> <P>The driver and two passengers were rushed to the hospital in Lake of the Woods. The occupants of the SUV were taken to the hospital in Steinbach.</P> <P>There is no word on the condition of any of the crash victims.</P> <P>Police said they do not believe alcohol was a factor in the crash, but their investigation continues.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/23/mb-falcon-beach-collision.html#ixzz0owoZ0Ydu">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/23/mb-falcon-beach-collision.html#ixzz0owoZ0Ydu</A></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Red-tape speed bump ; Cheap U.S. cars come with pricey duties, headaches
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Mon May 24 2010   Page: 4   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Purchasing a lower-priced vehicle in the U.S. might seem like a smooth ride, until you hit red-tape speed bumps. </P> <P>That's what many motorists in Manitoba and across Canada are finding -- the hard way -- when trying to take advantage of their currency's strength at dealerships south of the border and bringing their new wheels home. </P> <P>To help buyers avoid bureaucratic and paperwork roadblocks with their new cars, trucks and vans when returning to their home country, the Canada Border Services Agency is trying to steer them straight. </P> <P>"Usually, they're matters that they didn't research ahead of time. Or they come to the border and don't realize that the vehicle actually can't be imported to Canada," Andrew Klatt, one of the CBSA's chiefs of operation for southern Manitoba, said recently after helping run a monthly Winnipeg public seminar on the subject. </P> <P>"Or they don't have an appropriate bill of sale to substantiate what they paid for the vehicle. We certainly need that, as well." </P> <P>Klatt's main message is that it's easier to avoid border hassles by knowing in advance what paperwork is required, and what excise taxes and duties apply. </P> <P>The buyer's first task -- through a check with Transport Canada's Registrar of Imported Vehicles at <A href="http://www.riv.ca">www.riv.ca</A> -- is to ensure that the vehicle can even be brought into Canada. If possible, the buyer should determine which documents are needed to get it home. Those include a bill of sale and a certificate for a transfer of the vehicle's title. The title paper, as well, must be stamped by U.S. authorities. </P> <P>And the seller of the vehicle should notify the appropriate U.S. officials at least 72 hours before the new Canadian owner arrives with it at the border. </P> <P>Winnipeg dealerships, of course, want to keep customers at home. And Nott Autocorp Ltd. is among those offering words of caution to Manitobans looking south. </P> <P>Dealership owner Trevor Nott calls purchases in the U.S. a "buyer-beware kind of process," even with some vehicles south of the border priced $15,000 less than in Canada. </P> <P>"I've heard of every nightmare under the sun, like the buyer couldn't get a title or the border wouldn't let them through," said Nott, whose vehicles are mostly from the U.S. "For people doing it for the very first time, it can be a very difficult process. And it could end up costing them much more money." </P> <P>Cross-border losses of warranties and Canadian requirements for certain kinds of speedometers and day running lights are other snags for buyers in the U.S., Nott said. </P> <P>The CBSA's next Winnipeg seminar is June 17. Information on registration is available at <A href="http://www.cbsa.gc.ca">www.cbsa.gc.ca</A> or 1-800-461-9999.</P>

--30--

Title: 26-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Vehicle thefts down significantly for city
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Penticton Western News   Thu May 20 2010   Page: 00A4   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Penticton has witnessed a dramatic 80 per cent reduction in the number of vehicle thefts reported for the month of February. </P> <P>Last February there were 25 theft of vehicle incidents reported to ICBC, the highest amount they have seen in the past six years in Penticton. That number has dropped to just five this year. ICBC credits more education on safety to car owners and a crackdown by police over the Olympics for the drop. </P> <P>Sgt. Rick Dellebuur of the Penticton RCMP detachment attributes the downward trend to two specific things. </P> <P>"There were two individuals who were prolific car thieves that were picked up and have been incarcerated. Certainly it has been a benefit focusing our effort on auto crime, but getting those two offenders made a difference," said Dellebuur, adding that at least one of the offenders was caught with the bait car. </P> <P>Dellebuur said the help that Citizens On Patrol have provided has also been a benefit for RCMP. Using data from the RCMP crime analyst to determine the high-risk areas, Citizens on Patrol direct their efforts and eyes to those areas and report suspicious findings. Dellebuur said they are especially effective during Christmas, watching over parking lots and providing education to remind people to lock their cars and hide their valuables. </P> <P>"Auto crime tends to go up and down. It can depend on who is in jail and depends on the police. The police have been working quite a bit on auto crime and in Penticton they have incredible volunteers that work with the Citizens on Patrol," said Christine Silver, ICBC road safety co-ordinator. </P> <P>"They have done an incredible job, they work closely with the police and they have been doing a great job for sure. I think it has helped because people know that they are always out there and aware of what they are doing for the community." </P> <P>Silver said the stats have not been released yet for March or April but added with auto crime it can take awhile for people to report things. </P> <P>On Monday, Solicitor General Michael de Jong announced strategically placed bait cars and a high priority on thwarting car thefts helped send the stats to a 14-year low during the 2010 Olympic Winter Games. The February provincial totals - 730 vehicle thefts and 1,335 auto break-ins - were 64 and 71 per cent lower respectively than the 2,030 thefts and 4,645 break-ins in February 1996. Compared to February of last year, there were 210, or 22 per cent, fewer thefts and 680, or 15 per cent, fewer break-ins in February 2010. </P> <P>"We warned car thieves that bait cars would be everywhere during the Games, and it appears they got the message," said de Jong. "This success is all the more impressive given the number of visitors' vehicles in B.C. during this time. " </P> <P>A report from the provincial government shows that since bait cars hit B.C. roads in 2004, ICBC's stolen vehicle claims have been cut in half to $47 million in 2009 from $98 million in 2003, while break-in related claim costs have fallen to $17 million from $27 million. </P>

--30--

Title: 27-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police dole out 106 tickets at checkstops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A speeder who did 123 km/h in a 60 km/h zone is among 106 tickets handed out by city police during an annual checkstop program. </P> <P>Brandon Police Service Sgt. Bruce Klassen also noted that city's worst collision hot spot, the Daly Overpass, was one site for a checkstop. </P> <P>"We're trying to get people to slow down," Klassen said of the bridge yesterday as the BPS released statistics from this year's Canada Road Safety week. </P> <P>Police stopped 1,275 vehicles and handed out a total of 106 tickets during five Manitoba Public Insurance sponsored checkstops May 18-24. </P> <P>The project targets aggressive drivers and 25 tickets were issued for speeding, 20 for invalid driver's licences and three disqualified drivers were caught. </P> <P>In addition, four motorists were driving unregistered vehicles and there were 40 offences in which motorists failed to have insurance or a certificate for insurance. </P> <P>Last year, police caught 28 speeders, 15 people with invalid driver's licences, two people driving while disqualified, six unregistered vehicles and logged 24 failures to have insurance or certificates of insurance. </P> <P>One of this year's checkstops was set up at the foot of the Daly Overpass at the corner of Maple Avenue and 18th Street. </P> <P>The bridge and area is collision-prone due to the limited visibility caused by the crest of the arching bridge, momentum while travelling downhill and traffic congestion. </P> <P>The 18th Street bridge, which spans the Canadian Pacific Railway tracks, is statistically the most likely location for a fender bender, and last year 60 crashes were recorded there. </P> <P>As a result, police urge motorists to slow down. Officers, for example, recorded one vehicle's speed at 72 km/h in that 50 km/h zone. </P> <P>Another checkstop was held at First Street and Queens Avenue. There's a crosswalk in the area and that spot is a source of many speeding complaints, Klassen said. </P> <P>The speeder who was doing 123 km/h in the 60 km/h zone was caught on Richmond Avenue East and received an $850 fine. </P>

--30--

Title: 28-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Robber saved clerk from stabbing
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Brandon man who has pleaded guilty to robbery with violence actually stopped a young co-accused from stabbing a store clerk, court has heard. </P> <P>Jesse M. Anthony's timely shove spared the woman from a knife wound, Crown attorney Garry Rainnie said. </P> <P>"Mr. Anthony, in effect, helped stop the youth from stabbing the victim, pushing the youth aside," Rainnie told Judge Krystyna Tarwid in Brandon court yesterday. </P> <P>Anthony, 19, pleaded guilty to robbery with violence, and Tarwid set sentencing for July 5 to allow preparation of a pre-sentence report. </P> <P>Rainnie said Anthony and other suspects left Brandon in a stolen vehicle and stopped in Alexander at Stahl's Food Mart on March 15. </P> <P>They then entered the shop and milled around before one of them grabbed liquor from a shelf and left the store. </P> <P>The alert clerk quickly managed to lock the door with the other robbers inside and told them to go retrieve the liquor. </P> <P>One male left but then returned to tell the clerk: "You're not getting your liquor back, this is a robbery!" </P> <P>Another male then ran behind the counter, pushing buttons on the till and swearing at the clerk because he couldn't open the till. </P> <P>He was told to push the "cash" button as a youth armed with a knife and Anthony, armed with a screwdriver, stood beside the clerk. </P> <P>The youth, who was pointing his knife toward the clerk's stomach, made a stabbing motion toward the woman, but Anthony pushed him away. </P> <P>"Nobody gets hurt," Anthony said before the crooks fled with about $800. </P> <P>At the time, police said the bandits also fled with liquor and Rainnie told court yesterday that the suspects then drove to a gas bar at the Sioux Valley Dakota Nation. </P> <P>There, they bought a number of items and were caught on video surveillance. </P> <P>That footage helped police identify suspects, and four males were arrested at a Brandon home later that day. </P> <P>Anthony, who also pleaded guilty to breach of probation by failing to report to his probation officer between Oct. 2, 2009, and Jan. 11, 2009, remains in custody as he awaits sentencing. </P> <P>Three male youths still face charges in connection with the robbery. </P>

--30--

Title: 29-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Lead-foot drivers caught during checkstops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police officers ticketed 940 motorists for speeding during Canada Road Safety Week. </P> <P>This doesn't include photo enforcement tickets. </P> <P>Police focused on speeding, seatbelts, aggressive driving and impaired driving during the campaign, which began May 18 and ended Monday, the last day of May long weekend. </P> <P>No fatal collisions occurred in Winnipeg during the week. The goal is to prevent injuries and fatalities via awareness and enforcement. </P> <P>City police officers laid charges or issued tickets to about 1,600 people. </P> <P>In addition to the lead-foot drivers, two were arrested for impaired driving, seven received 24-hour licence suspensions for having a blood-alcohol level just below the legal limit, and 214 were ticketed for occupant restraint offences such as seatbelt negligence. </P> <P>Some parents were ticketed for failing to properly restrain their children, police said. </P> <P>Police said the level of non-compliance of seatbelts is a concern. </P> <P>Winnipeg's compliance rate is about 87%, which is below the national average of 92%, said Staff Sgt. Mark Hodgson of the central traffic unit. </P> <P>"Most of the excuses are 'I just forgot' or 'I just got in my car.' It's not that big of an effort to put (a seatbelt) on," Hodgson said. </P> <P>Failing to wear a seatbelt increases one's risk of being seriously injured or killed in a crash, he said. </P>

--30--

Title: 30-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Drivers given 940 tickets
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police officers ticketed 940 motorists for speeding during Canada Road Safety Week.</P> <P>This doesn't include photo enforcement tickets.</P> <P>Police focused on speeding, seatbelts, aggressive driving and impaired driving during the campaign, which began May 18 and ended Monday, the last day of May long weekend.</P> <P>No fatal collisions occurred in Winnipeg during the week. The goal is to prevent injuries and fatalities via awareness and enforcement.</P> <P>City police officers laid charges or issued tickets to about 1,600 people.</P> <P>In addition to the lead-foot drivers, two were arrested for impaired driving, seven received 24-hour licence suspensions for having a blood-alcohol level just below the legal limit, and 214 were ticketed for occupant restraint offences such as seatbelt negligence.</P> <P>Some parents were ticketed for failing to properly restrain their children, police said.</P> <P>Police said the level of non-compliance of seatbelts is a concern.</P> <P>Winnipeg’s compliance rate is about 87%, which is below the national average of 92%, said Staff Sgt. Mark Hodgson of the central traffic unit.</P> <P>“Most of the excuses are ‘I just forgot,’ or ‘I just got in my car.’ It’s not that big of an effort to put (a seatbelt) on,” Hodgson said.</P> <P>Failing to wear a seatbelt increases one’s risk of being seriously injured or killed in a crash, he said.</P> <P>One of the alleged impaired drivers was caught near Smithfield Avenue and Jones Street in West Kildonan on Saturday.</P> <P>Police said the male provided blood-alcohol samples of .18 and .17, more than twice the legal limit, was in possession of liquor, and violated a recognizance which prohibited him from possessing or using alcohol or illegal drugs and not entering a place where liquor is sold, aside from a restaurant with a liquor licence.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 31-Jan-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg's drivers love photo enforcement
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>We love our photo radar despite getting nailed by the speed-catching cameras and all the hullabaloo generated a year ago over speed enforcement in construction zones. </P> <P>That's the result of a 2009 public opinion poll done on Winnipeg's photo enforcement program that the Traffic Injury Research Foundation (TIRF) released Wednesday. </P> <P>The poll found almost 80 per cent of Winnipeggers said they believed photo enforcement makes the public more aware about speeding while 81 per cent support its continuation. </P> <P>Support for photo radar remains high at about 74 per cent even among those who've been caught speeding by the cameras. Seventy-one per cent also said they believed the program improves road safety in Winnipeg. </P> <P>Last year police and the province came under heavy fire when it was revealed a number of speeding offences would be dismissed because construction zones weren't marked with proper signs signalling the end of the speed-reduced zone. </P> <P>TIRF's poll is part of an ongoing study into the overall effectiveness of photo enforcement and whether it's made streets safer since its introduction in 2002. TIRF is a national, independent, charitable road safety institute. </P> <P>Ward Vanlaar, lead researcher and vice-president of research at TIRF, said in a statement the actual percentage of respondents reporting concern about overall road safety was only 54 per cent. That indicates it's considered a mid- level priority to the public, he said. </P> <P>He said the poll showed people are more concerned about specific road-safety issues, such as drinking and driving (89 per cent) and running red lights (78 per cent). Slightly fewer people reported high levels of concern about speeding (60 per cent). </P> <P>Vanlaar also said 95 per cent of Winnipeggers interviewed knew about photo radar. </P> <P>The TIRF study into whether Winnipeg's photo enforcement program reduces crashes and injuries has been delayed for several months because of data collection issues, Winnipeg Police Service Patrol Sgt. Kirk Van Alstyne said Wednesday. </P> <P>Van Alstyne said data recorded from the cameras and collision data collected by TIRF from other sources had to be put into a single format. The report is not expected to be finished until late 2010. </P> <P>TIRF also said studies in other provinces, states and countries that have photo radar have found reductions in average speed, speeding violations, red- light-running violations, speeding collisions and right-angle crashes. Other studies say the cameras have caused minor increases in rear-end crashes at intersections with cameras. </P> <P>There are now 10 mobile photo radar vehicles that clock speeders in school zones and near playgrounds in Winnipeg and 33 intersection cameras that rotate through 50 locations to catch speeders and red-light runners. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Poll details, please ; Don't blindly accept spin on photo radar
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Traffic Injury Research Foundation put out a press release Wednesday saying Winnipeggers overwhelming support photo enforcement, which includes photo radar and red light cameras. </P> <P>The poll is part of an overall assessment of Winnipeg's photo enforcement program commissioned by the Winnipeg Police Service and paid for by taxpayers. </P> <P>The assessment has been plagued with lengthy delays over the past few years, including a 2009 completion date that was missed, which has since been pushed back to late 2010. </P> <P><STRONG>Defends delays </STRONG></P> <P>Responding to criticism of that in this column, the TIRF and WPS issued a press release praising the effectiveness of photo enforcement, lauding its so-called widespread public support and defending the delays of the assessment report. </P> <P>Yet, amazingly, they won't release a copy of the public opinion poll, they won't tell us who performed the survey and they refused to disclose how much it costs. </P> <P>Were respondents asked about photo radar or intersection cameras, or both? It's an important distinction. Were they asked questions like: "Do you believe photo radar is designed more for revenue reasons or for safety ones?" </P> <P>We don't know, because they won't release the poll. </P> <P>The press release goes on to cite "studies" in other jurisdictions that prove photo enforcement works. </P> <P>"While some have raised concerns about the effectiveness of photo enforcement programs, a review of the literature, completed in 2009, shows that there is ample evidence that photo enforcement does have an overall positive effect," the press release says. "These include studies completed in Ontario, California, Virginia, British Columbia, Arizona, Singapore, and Victoria, Australia." Yet they won't disclose the specifics of those studies so we can read them ourselves. </P> <P>"Many of the studies we reviewed found significant decreases in average speed, speeding violations, red light running violations, speeding collisions, and right-angle crashes, with some studies finding minor increases in rear-end crashes, which are often much less severe than right-angle crashes," said TIRF lead researcher Ward Vanlaar in the press release. </P> <P>Great. Break out the studies so we can have a look at them ourselves. I'm dying to see the proof that parking photo radar vehicles on Pembina Highway, Portage Avenue and McPhillips Street and ticketing people on Sunday mornings doing 74 in a 60 reduces collisions and injuries. </P> <P>I look forward to that data. </P> <P>In the meantime, I'm not going to blindly accept unsubstantiated poll findings, crash data or any other conclusions until I see the raw statistics and polling questions myself. </P> <P>This is a classic case of "just trust us." WPS brass and TIRF seem to be more concerned about how they're going to spin all this data than what the data actually says. </P> <P>In fact, it appears TIRF has already made up its mind about how wonderful photo radar and red light cameras are even though they haven't completed their study. That's very worrisome for an assessment process that is supposed to be independent and evidence-based. </P> <P>Since the WPS and TIRF have already opened up a can of worms about a public opinion poll and studies in other jurisdictions, they should at least make those parts of the assessment public immediately, even if they don't release the rest of the report until later this year. </P> <P>If they don't, it proves Wednesday's press release was little more than a public relations exercise. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 2-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Most back photo radar ; 81% of 'Peggers want program to continue: poll
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A poll has found roughly four out of five Winnipeggers want the city to continue its photo enforcement of traffic violations, including about three-quarters of drivers who admit to receiving a speeding ticket through it. </P> <P>The poll, which surveyed 750 Winnipeg drivers during the height of the photo radar controversy in May 2009, was released Wednesday by the Ottawa-based Traffic Injury Research Foundation. </P> <P>The survey was conducted as part of a larger evaluation of Winnipeg's photo enforcement program TIRF is performing on behalf of the Winnipeg Police Service. </P> <P>"The photo enforcement program garners rather high levels of support among people from (Winnipeg)," states a release issued by TIRF Wednesday. </P> <P>"About 80% think the photo enforcement safety program makes the public more aware of the issue of speeding, 81% support the continuation of the photo enforcement safety program and 71% believe the program helps improve road safety in Winnipeg. </P> <P>"Even among those who have previously been caught for speeding and received a ticket, the level of support for the continuation of the program is still high at about 74%." </P> <P>Mayor Sam Katz said he was pleasantly surprised by the numbers. </P> <P>"I would not have expected it to be that high," said Katz. "It appears the vast majority of Winnipeggers agree with the action that has been taken, and that is very gratifying to see." </P> <P>Katz said his personal belief in the program has always been "unwavering" and the poll's results show people are getting the message that the important thing is to just slow down. </P> <P>Staff Sgt. Mark Hodgson, the officer in charge of the WPS's central traffic unit, said police asked TIRF to evaluate the photo enforcement program -- which includes mobile photo radar and stationary intersection cameras -- and TIRF decided to do the poll as part of that. </P> <P>"What we really want to know is if what we're doing is effective and what can be done to be more effective," Hodgson said. </P> <P>A spokeswoman for TIRF said Wednesday the evaluation is still ongoing, and therefore the organization would not be commenting on the poll, providing its results in full or providing any further information beyond the press release. </P> <P>According to TIRF, the poll's results can be considered accurate within plus or minus 3.6%, 19 times out of 20. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 3-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cyclist Struck
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
It's amazing she was able to walk away. Winnipeg police say a cyclist was struck by a vehicle on the westbound Portage Avenue ramp onto Route 90 early Wednesday afternoon. The windshield of the vehicle shows the cyclist was hit hard. However police say she didn't seem to suffer any serious injuries. She was on her feet after the crash, even though she was taken from the scene to hospital by ambulance. Her condition was upgraded to stable from serious. <BR>

Title: 4-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driven to distraction
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The next time you’re driving down the highway and your hand-held cell phone rings, remember this: you’re four times as likely to get in to an accident if you answer it. If you’re texting, your chances increase to 23 times.</P> <P>Need to read that text while on the highway? A recent study by the Virginia Tech Transportation Institute shows that drivers who are texting spent nearly five seconds looking at their cell phones – enough time at typical highway speeds to drive the length of a football field.</P> <P>Driver distractions contribute to 80 per cent of all crashes, according to an American study. And while hand-held cell phones are cited as the number-one cause of all driver distractions today, they aren’t the only thing causing people to take their eyes off the road.</P> <P>“Whether you’re driving around the block or across town, it’s important to keep your focus on your driving,” says Clif Eden, manager of Road Safety at Manitoba Public Insurance. “It’s something that’s in your control.”</P> <P>Other driver distractions include eating while driving, grooming and even talking to your passengers. And that’s just inside the vehicle. Outside distractions, such as rubbernecking an accident or trying to communicate with another driver, are involved in 30 per cent of all at-fault fatal accidents, according to a recent American study.</P> <P>“ Many accidents involving distracted drivers are preventable,” says Eden. “Driving requires full attention. Not just for your own safety, but for that of your passengers and everyone else on the road.”</P> <P>In many cases, you can identify distracted drivers by how they’re driving. They’re the people who are often driving slower than the rest of traffic or drifting from one side of the lane to the other. They’re the ones who are likely to miss a traffic sign or fail to signal. And they’re the ones putting themselves and other drivers, cyclists and pedestrians at risk.</P> <P>Fortunately, driving distracted is entirely preventable. Drivers can reduce their risk of getting into an accident by turning off their phones while driving or getting someone else to make, or take, the call, and by leaving enough time in the morning or at lunch so you don’t have to eat or shave on-the-go. And while human curiosity makes it tempting to stare at a roadside crash, motorists should exhibit extreme caution when passing by a crash scene. Rubber necking is a definite no-no.</P> <P>“Even adjusting your radio or changing your CD player increases your risk of a collision by six times,” says Eden. “We all have an opportunity to reduce the risk of a collision by keeping our eyes on the road and our hands on the wheel.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Remember FIDO: Forget it, drive on ; Best advice to handle road issues
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I recently took part in a driver's-education media challenge through MPI to promote the driver's-ed challenge Saturday at the Red River Exhibition grounds. </P> <P>Although I was only there in support of my colleague Rena Jae (she needed some lessons), a few things dawned on me as I left the grounds. </P> <P>Aside from the fact driving is indeed a skill, driving is also a form of transportation that is quicker than walking, riding a bike or taking a bus. </P> <P>I know that sounds elementary, but when you implement it into everyday driving habits of people, we often forget what a privilege it is to be able to get from one destination to another while operating a motor vehicle. </P> <P>Now be honest when I ask this question: when was the last time you got at least a little frustrated (or a lot) while driving in your vehicle? Someone driving too slow, someone took your lane, red light, or a pedestrian crawling through a crosswalk? </P> <P>The possibilities are endless as far as what drives us up the wall on a daily basis when it comes to driving. </P> <P>The good news is you're driving, and you will arrive to your destination much faster than most other modes of travel. </P> <P>Believe me, coming from someone who used to have his fair share of road issues, including excessive speeding (lost my licence for three months for it), road rage (got into some altercations over it), and waving selective fingers out my window while using my horn, it's not worth it. </P> <P>Relax, you'll get there. </P> <P>I learned a very valuable acronym during my rehabilitation: FIDO, meaning "forget it, drive on." </P> <P>These four simple words have brought me back to a state of enjoyment when it comes to driving. I smile more, I'm less agitated when I get out of the vehicle, and most of all, I put myself in less danger while on the road. </P> <P>I'm not writing to tell you how you should drive. I'm the last person in the world to do so. But I would like to remind you to relax a little. </P> <P>As my father always says, "I may not be the best driver on the road, but I certainly know I'm not the worst!" </P>

--30--

Title: 6-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: No support here for our lazy policing
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It's a little hard for me to swallow that roughly four out of five Winnipeggers surveyed about their thoughts on the city's photo radar enforcement campaign think it's great. </P> <P>A love affair with photo radar vans and red-light cameras? How can that be after all the shenanigans that's gone on with the management of this cash grab -- oops I mean safety program. </P> <P>The city is raking in millions from drivers, some of it legit (because heavy-footed drivers should be ticketed by someone) but a large part of it is a money grab thanks to the photo radar in construction zones with no workers present nightmare. </P> <P>The numbers surprise me and I'm not convinced this poll is worth the paper it's printed on. Considering the pollsters won't release the full results or comment on the poll when asked by a Sun reporter, I agree with Tom Brodbeck that this whole exercise is more like a public relations exercise. </P> <P>The poll was done by the Ottawa-based Traffic Injury Research Foundation (TIRF) on behalf of the Winnipeg Police Service. </P> <P>The number that needs to be taken to task is the claim that 81% of the respondents support the continuation of these photo enforcement programs. Among those saying yes to this question are many who have received a ticket, according to the pollsters. </P> <P>This all seems a little too fishy to me. Like Brodbeck says you can't trust these guys without all the numbers to back up their claims. Officials claim the "evaluation" is still ongoing and won't comment beyond what was in Wednesday's press release. That press release predictably presented the numbers spun the way TIRF and most likely the city and Winnipeg Police want them. </P> <P>That's the way pollsters and the organizations that hire them work, so it's not unexpected. </P> <P>I always chuckle when these major, important surveys come out. You never seem to be able to find anyone who actually took part in them. </P> <P>Since I wasn't one of the 750 Winnipeggers surveyed (a pathetically anemic sampling by the way) here's how I feel. </P> <P>The city should scrap the whole photo radar program but keep red-light cameras. Cops standing at intersections watching drivers try to make it on an amber is not a good use of police resources. </P> <P>But the photo radar vans should be mothballed in favour or bodies -- more traffic cops to stop vehicles, check drivers, question them and actually hand them a ticket. </P> <P>I've said this before. </P> <P>Photo radar is lazy policing, simple as that. On top of that there's no clear-cut proof it's made the streets safer. </P> <P>Here's some tasty food for thought. During Canada Road Safety Week (May 18 to May 24) Winnipeg police officers ticketed 940 motorists for speeding. They were focusing on speeding, aggressive driving and impaired driving during the campaign. </P> <P>Good old fashioned police work did this. Why can't we cancel photo radar, and use that money we pay that company to run it for us to hire more traffic cops? </P> <P>The old police spot check is the still the best way to nail speeders and bad drivers. </P> <P>Not only do you nab drivers for these offences but you can find stolen property, drugs, drivers with outstanding warrants etc., simply by this in-your-face style of policing. </P> <P>Put that in your survey. </P>

--30--

Title: 7-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Have Your Say: Motorcycle insurance
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A recent letter regarding motorcycle rates in Manitoba contained several factual errors. Motorcycle rates are determined by a number of actuarial-driven factors. A primary factor in motorcycle rates is bodily injury costs associated with a motorcycle/motor vehicle crash. Manitobans would be interested to know the average injury claim for motorcycle crashes costs MPI and its ratepayers about $43,000. In comparison an average injury in an automobile crash costs about $9,700. </P>  <P>Last year in Manitoba, about 460 motorcycle claims were opened by Manitoba Public Insurance. Regardless of who is at fault, costs associated with a motorcycle/vehicle crash are charged 50-50 between the vehicle categories involved. This adjustment has resulted in savings for motorcycle owners. In our 2010 General Rate Application, approximately 2,900 motorcycle owners saw a decrease in their insurance premium. </P>  <P>It's true there is no cross subsidization of rates in Manitoba. The Public Utilities Board supports this system. </P>  <P>Saskatchewan Government Insurance recently raised motorcycle premiums 15 to 25 per cent, compared to Manitoba's average of five per cent. </P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 8-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Drunk driver kills dad in Manitoba rollover, RCMP say
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 68-year-old man is dead and his 37-year-old son is facing charges of impaired driving after a pickup truck crashed and rolled in a ditch Friday night, Manitoba RCMP say.</P> <P>Members of the Carman detachment of the RCMP, along with local EMS, were sent to the crash around 10 p.m. CT.</P> <P>Police say a 2008 Ford truck was on a gravel road in the Rural Municipality of Dufferin when it slid off the roadway and rolled over. They said the roads were wet.</P> <P>Emergency crews at the scene found the older man, a passenger in the truck, had died in the crash.</P> <P>No name was released but police said he was from the area.</P> <P>They added that the driver, who is from Winnipeg, was arrested for impaired operation of a motor vehicle causing death.</P> <P>He was released from custody and is set to appear in court, in Carman, on July 7.</P> <P>There were no other passengers and no other injuries reported.</P> <P>Police said that, in addition to the element of impaired driving, speed was a factor in the crash.</P> <P>Carman is about 85 kilometres southwest of Winnipeg.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/29/mb-fatal-rollover-10529.html#ixzz0pW2ukmoG">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/29/mb-fatal-rollover-10529.html#ixzz0pW2ukmoG</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Son charged after dad killed in Carman crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- A 68-year-old man is dead and his 37-year-old son was charged with impaired driving following a single-vehicle accident Friday night near Carman. </P> <P>RCMP said a 2008 Ford truck travelling on a wet gravel road in the Rural Municipality of Dufferin slid off the roadway and rolled. </P> <P>A passerby spotted the truck in the ditch at about 10 p.m. and called 911, said RCMP spokesman, Const. Miles Hiebert. </P> <P>The 68-year-old male passenger from the RM of Dufferin was pronounced dead at the scene. </P> <P>The driver from Winnipeg, the 37-year-old son of the deceased, was not injured, Hiebert said. There were no other passengers in the truck. </P> <P>He has been released from custody and is to appear in court in Carman Court July 7. Alcohol and speed are considered to be factors, RCMP said. </P> <P>Police continue to investigate. No further information will be released at this time pending notification of next of kin. </P>

--30--

Title: 10-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crash kills dad, charges laid
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg man is facing charges of drunk driving causing death after a single-vehicle crash in rural Manitoba Friday night that claimed the life of his father. </P> <P>RCMP say the 37-year-old man, whom police did not publicly identify, was arrested after the pickup truck he was driving slid off a wet gravel road in the Rural Municipality of Dufferin near Carman and rolled over about 10 p.m. Friday. </P> <P>The man's 68-year-old father, a passenger in the truck, died in the crash. Police said he lived in the RM of Dufferin. </P> <P>RCMP said both alcohol and speed are believed to have been factors in the rollover. </P> <P>The driver was not injured and there were no other passengers in the vehicle. </P> <P>The driver was released from police custody pending a July 7 court date in Carman, where he will face a charge of impaired driving causing death. </P> <P>If convicted, he faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. <BR></P>

Title: 12-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Dragged by truck 20 blocks, man dies
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A pedestrian died after being dragged more than 20 blocks underneath a pickup truck. </P> <P>The 42-year-old man was jaywalking Saturday evening, when he was struck by a Dodge Dakota, police said. </P> <P>The driver stopped but couldn't find the victim. </P> <P>Meanwhile, a Ford F150 had pulled up and stopped behind the Dodge. </P> <P>The Ford driver went to pass the Dodge, and the pedestrian's clothing caught on the truck's undercarriage, police said. The Ford travelled 27 blocks before the driver was alerted to the ghastly scene. </P> <P>Emergency responders rushed the injured pedestrian to hospital where he died. </P> <P>The Ford driver has been arrested on suspicion of impaired driving. </P>

Title: 13-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba premier says tab for flood damage will run well over $1M
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ Heavy rains over the weekend caused more than $1 million in damage to hundreds, if not thousands, of homes in Manitoba, Premier Greg Selinger said Monday. </P> <P>“We've asked all the municipalities to compile (damage estimates) and do their impact statements,'' Selinger told a news conference near the floodway control structure south of Winnipeg. </P> <P>He said the province believes flood damage will be great enough to trigger Disaster Financial Assistance Program payments of up to $200,000 to homeowners affected by overland flooding. </P> <P>Those with backed-up sewers will have to rely on private insurance coverage, the premier said. </P> <P>Meanwhile, any municipality with flood related expenses exceeding $5 per capita will have all their costs covered by the provincial and federal governments. </P> <P>Water Stewardship Minister Christine Melnick said in the legislature Monday that the weekend rains have been characterized as a “one-in-50-year event.'' </P> <P>During a 28.5-hour deluge that lasted from 7:30 a.m. Saturday morning until Sunday at noon, roughly a third of Winnipeg received more than 92 millimetres of rain. </P> <P>Melnick and Selinger toured the hard-hit community of Emerson on Monday, where hundreds of basements were flooded. </P> <P>“It's such a big event,'' Selinger said, describing the scope of the rain damage. “It's gone all the way from The Pas... to Emerson. When you take a look at the magnitude of this weather event, we don't think there will be any problem meeting the minimum thresholds'' for disaster relief. </P> <P>The floodway was activated on Sunday, and Selinger said Monday that the Water Stewardship Department would decide “in the next 24 hours'' whether to increase the flow. </P> <P>Other communities to suffer significant damage included Sprague, Stuartburn, Lac du Bonnet and the area around Dominion City. </P> <P>The province said in a flood report issued late Monday that extensive overland flooding continues in many areas of southern Manitoba due to runoff from the recent rains on already saturated ground. </P> <P>Most streams that have particularly high levels were to begin falling slowly by late Monday. </P> <P>Meanwhile, Manitoba Public Insurance had received 325 vehicles claims stemming from the rain and flooding as of 3:30 p.m. Monday, with about 300 of those from Winnipeg vehicle owners. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said rain and water damage can play havoc with a vehicle's electrical system, adding each vehicle will be examined closely. </P> <P>The Winnipeg Regional Health Authority was asking storm-affected residents to throw away contaminated items that cannot be cleaned. Clothes, furniture, toys and carpets contaminated with sewage or floodwater should be discarded, said Dr. Sande Harlos. </P> <P>She also warned Winnipeggers of the dangers posed by flooded basements, which include electrocution, infection and even the drowning of small children or pets. </P> <P>In Emerson, about 165 millimetres of rain fell during a three-hour period, said Mayor Wayne Arseny. </P> <P>“You can't prepare for something like that,'' Arseny said. “The storm knocked down trees that knocked out our power and we lost our pumps and that was that. Our systems were overwhelmed.'' </P> <P>On Monday, yard after yard was piled high with a lifetime of memories and valuables destroyed by the rain _ photographs, televisions and appliances, books, wet carpets. </P> <P>“The water was over my knees,'' said Rick DeBlois, owner of the eight-unit Emerson Apartments. “It just poured up through the toilets and drains.'' </P> <P>“We had just finished our basement,'' Heather Graham said as she stood in her yard next to the pile of memories now ready to be hauled away with the trash. </P> <P>“I went into the basement at 10 o'clock and stepped into sewer water up to my knee,'' Graham said. “We lost everything that was down there... kids' photographs, my husband's and my high school yearbooks.'' </P> <P>Graham said several neighbours came by Sunday to help carry water-damaged items from her basement. </P> <P>“Their own basements flooded and they came by to help us,'' Graham said. “Everyone in this town has pulled together. It's so nice.'' <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Rains trigger disaster program
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Heavy rains over the weekend damaged hundreds, if not thousands, of homes in Manitoba, triggering disaster relief programs, Premier Greg Selinger said Monday. </P> <P>"We've asked all the municipalities to compile (damage estimates) and do their impact statements," Selinger told a news conference near the floodway control structure south of Winnipeg. </P> <P>He said the province believes flood damage will be great enough to trigger Disaster Financial Assistance Program payments of up to $200,000 to homeowners affected by overland flooding. Those with backed up sewers will have to rely on private insurance coverage, the premier said. </P> <P>Meanwhile, any municipality with flood related expenses exceeding $5 per capita will have all their costs covered by the provincial and federal governments. </P> <P>Water Stewardship Minister Christine Melnick said in the legislature Monday that the weekend rains have been characterized as a "one-in-50-year event." </P> <P>She and Selinger toured the hard-hit community of Emerson on Monday, where hundreds of basements were flooded. </P> <P>"It's such a big event," Selinger said, describing the scope of the rain damage. "It's gone all the way from The Pas... to Emerson. When you take a look at the magnitude of this weather event, we don't think there will be any problem meeting the minimum thresholds" for disaster relief. </P> <P>The floodway was activated on Sunday, and Selinger said Monday that the Water Stewardship Department would decide "in the next 24 hours" whether to increase the flow through Duff's Ditch. </P> <P>Other communities to suffer significant damage included Sprague, Stuartburn, Lac du Bonnet and the area around Dominion City. </P> <P>The province said in a flood report issued late Monday that extensive overland flooding continues in many areas of southern Manitoba due to runoff from the recent rains on already saturated ground. </P> <P>Most streams that have particularly high levels are cresting but were to begin falling slowly by late Monday and more rapidly later this week. These include the Morris and La Salle rivers, Sturgeon Creek, the Roseau River near Dominion City, the Little Saskatchewan River near Rivers and many other small streams. </P> <P>The Red River in downtown Winnipeg was expected to crest at 18.5 feet late Monday or early today. That would put The Forks walkway under about 10 feet of water. </P> <P>The Assiniboine River is high but Water Stewardship officials expect the river to remain within its banks. </P> <P>Meanwhile, Manitoba Public Insurance had received 325 vehicles claims stemming from the rain and flooding as of 3:30 p.m. Monday, with about 300 of those from Winnipeg vehicle owners. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said rain and water damage can play havoc with a vehicle's electrical system, adding each vehicle will be examined closely. </P> <P>"Depending on the depth of water, the vehicle could be written off," Smiley said. "Generally, the rule of thumb is if water reaches the dash then the vehicle is written off. "But so many vehicles today have elaborate electrical systems that even if the water gets to the sub-floor, the vehicle could be written off, too. </P> <P>"Any vehicle that gets any water will be looked at closely." <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Roblin Review readers should know
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>To the editor,</P> <P>A recent column published in the Review, regarding motorcycle rates in Manitoba omitted a number of facts which accurately explain how motorcycle rates are set in Manitoba.</P> <P>Roblin Review readers should know that no vehicle classes in Manitoba are subsidized. Not passenger cars. Not big trucks. And not motorcycles.</P> <P>Fact is, motorcycles are treated like every other vehicle group. The public Utilities Board and Manitoba Autopac rate payers also support this system of rate setting.</P> <P>In fact, motorcycle rates are determined by a number of statistically-driven, actuarially sound factors. a primary factor in motorcycle rates is bodily injury costs associated with a motorcycle/motor vehicle crash.</P> <P>The columnist should have informed Review readers that the average injury claim for motorcycle crashes costs MPI and its ratepayers about $43,000. In comparison an average injury in an automobile crash costs about $9,700.</P> <P>Last year in Manitoba about 460 motorcycle claims were opened by Manitoba Public Insurance. Regardless of who is at fault, costs associated with a motorcycle/ vehicle crash are charged 50-50 between the vehicle categories involved. This adjustment has resulted in savings for motorcycle owners. In our 2010 general rate application, approximately 2,900 motorcycle owners saw a decrease in their insurance premium.</P> <P>It’s also important to set the record straight, regarding the columnist’s suggestion that MPI CEO/President Marilyn McLaren “hated” motorcycles. Review readers should know that Manitoba Public Insurance has worked very closely over the years with the Coalition of Manitoba Motorcycle groups, in efforts to address the concerns of motorcycle owners and riders.</P> <P>Review readers should also know that Saskatchewan Government Insurance recently raised motorcycle premiums 15 to 25 per cent, compared to Manitoba’s average of five per cent.</P> <P>Sincerely,<BR>Brian Smiley<BR>Media Relations Coordinator<BR>MPI</P> <P>ED’s Note: Thanks for the response Brian, now they know. Wonder how many motorcyclists think MPI is treating them fairly though.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 16-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man arrested for hitting officer with stolen car
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 38-year-old man has been charged for hitting a Winnipeg police officer with a stolen vehicle.</P> <P>The officer was part of a unit that had set up a radar-enforced speed trap on May 8 around Salter Street and Dufferin Avenue in the city's North End.</P> <P>A speeding vehicle was spotted and the officer signalled for the vehicle to pull over but the driver instead accelerated towards the officer, who tried to get out of the way.</P> <P>The officer was struck and the driver of the vehicle fled the scene, police said.</P> <P>The officer was treated and released from hospital for non-life-threatening injuries to his upper and lower body.</P> <P>It was later determined the vehicle had been stolen.</P> <P>The man was located and arrested by the RCMP Saturday in the city of Selkirk, just north of Winnipeg.</P> <P>He is charged with theft, assault and numerous other offences and has been detained in the Winnipeg Remand Centre.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/31/mb-stolen-vehicle-officer-hit-arrest-winnipeg.html#ixzz0pbotncUP">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/05/31/mb-stolen-vehicle-officer-hit-arrest-winnipeg.html#ixzz0pbotncUP</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Another cuffed man steals cruiser
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>For the second time in as many months, a suspect slipped his handcuffed hands in front of his body and stole a police cruiser while in the custody of a Manitoba police force. </P> <P>The latest incident occurred while Brandon Police Service officers were dealing with a disturbance in the western Manitoba city Saturday afternoon. </P> <P>The small, flexible man, who was allegedly intoxicated, took the marked car on a short joyride before he was arrested a second time. </P> <P>It was a brief but potentially dangerous situation, said Brandon police spokesman Const. Ron Burgess. </P> <P>"Anyone who's in that state of mind to steal a police cruiser, there's no telling what they're capable of," Burgess said. </P> <P>The man's initial arrest occurred when officers encountered him and a hysterical woman at a home in the 1100-block of Sixth Street at 4:40 p.m. </P> <P>He was arrested for failing to abstain from alcohol, a condition of his probation order, police said. </P> <P>The man was handcuffed, put in the back of a police car on the side of the road, and left unattended while two officers spoke to the woman and attempted to calm her down, police said. </P> <P>While the officers were distracted, the man managed to get his hands, which were behind his back, in front of his body and crawl through a narrow opening in a plastic shield dividing the front and rear passenger compartments, Burgess said. </P> <P>"You'd have to be small-statured (to crawl through)," he said. </P> <P>In the front seat, the man damaged police property and drove off, clutching the steering wheel with his cuffed hands, police said. </P> <P>The keys were left in the car's ignition. </P> <P>Burgess said the man was in possession of the cruiser for about two minutes and was stopped without incident or further damage a few blocks away in the 1700-block of Aberdeen Avenue. He was taken into custody again. </P> <P>Police said a 21-year-old Brandon man was charged with breach of probation, escaping lawful custody, theft over $5,000, impaired driving, driving with a blood-alcohol level over .08, and driving while prohibited. </P> <P>In April, a Winnipeg Police Service cruiser was stolen when a man performed a similar escape. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 18-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Charge in hit-run
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>City police have charged a 38-year-old Selkirk man who allegedly struck an officer with a stolen car during a speed trap in May. </P> <P>The hit-and-run collision occurred at Salter Street and Dufferin Avenue in the North End on May 8 at 10:10 a.m. </P> <P>Police said a northbound vehicle was speeding, so an officer, who was on foot, attempted to signal the driver to pull over. The suspect allegedly accelerated the vehicle towards the officer, struck him and fled in the car, police said. </P> <P>The officer was treated in hospital for non-life threatening injuries to his upper and lower body. </P> <P>Police found the red Chevrolet Cobalt, which was stolen in the Selkirk area, abandoned on Flora Avenue a short time later. The suspect fled on foot. </P> <P>A suspect was arrested in Selkirk by the RCMP on Saturday and turned over to the Winnipeg police stolen auto unit. </P> <P>Dale Adam Chopek is charged with assault with a weapon, assaulting a peace officer, theft under $5,000, driving while disqualified, failing to stop at an accident scene, and possession of property obtained by crime. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: ICBC considers rate drop; NDP says Liberals took profits for general revenue
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>ICBC's investments are doing so well that the government-run auto insurer wants to give its customers a break on insurance rates. </P> <P>The Insurance Corporation of B.C. asked the B.C. Utilities Commission on Monday for permission to reduce basic auto insurance rates by 1.9 per cent. </P> <P>BCUC is responsible for regulating basic drivers' insurance rates in B.C. </P> <P>The number of claims ICBC has had to pay out is down, but the average cost of claims has risen -- especially in the area of bodily injuries suffered in car crashes, which gets more expensive every year. </P> <P>ICBC showed a net profit of $563 million for 2009, up from its $497-million profit a year earlier, spokesman Adam Grossman told The Province. </P> <P>While ICBC president Jon Schubert thanked the province's motorists for "their smart driving that has helped us control our claims costs and apply for this rate reduction," the company's annual report shows its investments accounted for nearly all of the 2009 profit. </P> <P>Of its $563-million profit last year, ICBC investment income made $532 million. </P> <P>The report credits "the recovery in the capital markets [and] maintaining stable income from [ICBC's] conservative fixed-income portfolio" for the windfall. </P> <P>Mike Farnworth, the New Democrats' ICBC critic, linked ICBC's request for lower premiums to what he called the Liberals' "guilty conscience" over transferring $778 million of ICBC profits into the government's general revenue in the March budget. </P> <P>"They're taking $778 million out [of ICBC's profits] and giving $39 million back." <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba premier says tab for flood damage will run well over $1M
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Whitehorse Daily Star Tue Jun 1 2010 Page: 11 Section: Environment   Dateline: WINNIPEG   Source: Canadian Press
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- Heavy rains over the weekend caused more than $1 million in damage to hundreds, if not thousands, of homes in Manitoba, Premier Greg Selinger said Monday. </P> <P>"We've asked all the municipalities to compile (damage estimates) and do their impact statements," Selinger told a news conference near the floodway control structure south of Winnipeg. </P> <P>He said the province believes flood damage will be great enough to trigger Disaster Financial Assistance Program payments of up to $200,000 to homeowners affected by overland flooding. </P> <P>Those with backed-up sewers will have to rely on private insurance coverage, the premier said. </P> <P>Meanwhile, any municipality with flood related expenses exceeding $5 per capita will have all their costs covered by the provincial and federal governments. </P> <P>Water Stewardship Minister Christine Melnick said in the legislature Monday that the weekend rains have been characterized as a "one-in-50-year event." </P> <P>During a 28.5-hour deluge that lasted from 7:30 a.m. Saturday morning until Sunday at noon, roughly a third of Winnipeg received more than 92 millimetres of rain. </P> <P>Melnick and Selinger toured the hard-hit community of Emerson on Monday, where hundreds of basements were flooded. </P> <P>"It's such a big event," Selinger said, describing the scope of the rain damage. "It's gone all the way from The Pas... to Emerson. When you take a look at the magnitude of this weather event, we don't think there will be any problem meeting the minimum thresholds" for disaster relief. </P> <P>The floodway was activated on Sunday, and Selinger said Monday that the Water Stewardship Department would decide "in the next 24 hours" whether to increase the flow. </P> <P>Other communities to suffer significant damage included Sprague, Stuartburn, Lac du Bonnet and the area around Dominion City. </P> <P>The province said in a flood report issued late Monday that extensive overland flooding continues in many areas of southern Manitoba due to runoff from the recent rains on already saturated ground. </P> <P>Most streams that have particularly high levels were to begin falling slowly by late Monday. </P> <P>Meanwhile, Manitoba Public Insurance had received 325 vehicles claims stemming from the rain and flooding as of 3:30 p.m. Monday, with about 300 of those from Winnipeg vehicle owners. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said rain and water damage can play havoc with a vehicle's electrical system, adding each vehicle will be examined closely. </P> <P>The Winnipeg Regional Health Authority was asking storm-affected residents to throw away contaminated items that cannot be cleaned. Clothes, furniture, toys and carpets contaminated with sewage or floodwater should be discarded, said Dr. Sande Harlos. </P> <P>She also warned Winnipeggers of the dangers posed by flooded basements, which include electrocution, infection and even the drowning of small children or pets. </P> <P>In Emerson, about 165 millimetres of rain fell during a three-hour period, said Mayor Wayne Arseny. </P> <P>"You can't prepare for something like that," Arseny said. "The storm knocked down trees that knocked out our power and we lost our pumps and that was that. Our systems were overwhelmed." </P> <P>On Monday, yard after yard was piled high with a lifetime of memories and valuables destroyed by the rain -- photographs, televisions and appliances, books, wet carpets. </P> <P>"The water was over my knees," said Rick DeBlois, owner of the eight-unit Emerson Apartments. "It just poured up through the toilets and drains." </P> <P>"We had just finished our basement," Heather Graham said as she stood in her yard next to the pile of memories now ready to be hauled away with the trash. </P> <P>"I went into the basement at 10 o'clock and stepped into sewer water up to my knee," Graham said. "We lost everything that was down there... kids' photographs, my husband's and my high school yearbooks." </P> <P>Graham said several neighbours came by Sunday to help carry water-damaged items from her basement. </P> <P>"Their own basements flooded and they came by to help us," Graham said. "Everyone in this town has pulled together. It's so nice." <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 21-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In Brief: Victim in fatal rollover identified
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Wed Jun 2 2010 Page: B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE victim of a fatal rollover on Sunday night near Hamiota has been identified by RCMP as 35-year-old Teena-Joy Adams of Shoal Lake. </P> <P>Shoal Lake RCMP arrived at the scene around 9 p.m. Sunday evening and found Adams trapped in the vehicle. She was extracted from the vehicle by emergency crews on the scene, but later died of her injuries. </P> <P>A 17-year-old passenger was also taken to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. </P> <P>A preliminary investigation has revealed the vehicle lost control after hitting a pothole and then rolled. Alcohol is not a factor in the accident.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Police identify rollover victim
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Wed Jun 2 2010   Page: 16 Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Mounties have identified a 35-year-old woman who died in a rollover in western Manitoba on the weekend. </P> <P>Police said Teena-Joy Adams of Shoal Lake died in the single-vehicle crash. </P> <P>The vehicle rolled on Provincial Road 355, about six kilometres east of Highway 21, near Hamiota on Sunday, RCMP said. </P> <P>Adams was trapped and extricated by emergency personnel, police said. </P> <P>A 17-year-old passenger suffered non-life threatening injuries. </P> <P>RCMP said the vehicle hit a pothole, resulting in the driver losing control and the vehicle rolling. <BR></P>

--30--

NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RCMP name woman killed in rollover
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: By CHRIS KITCHING, Winnipeg Sun  Last Updated: June 1, 2010 1:37pm
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Mounties have identified a 35-year-old woman who died in a rollover in western Manitoba on the weekend.</P> <P>Police said Teena-Joy Adams of Shoal Lake died in the single-vehicle crash.</P> <P>The vehicle rolled on Provincial Road 355, about six kilometres east of Highway 21, near Hamiota on Sunday, RCMP said.</P> <P>Adams was trapped and extricated by emergency personnel, police said.</P> <P>A 17-year-old passenger suffered non-life threatening injuries.</P> <P>RCMP said the vehicle hit a pothole, leading the driver to lose control and the vehicle to roll.<BR></P>
