Title: 24-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Flashing purple lights for funeral cars now OK
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE flashing purple lights are an unmistakable symbol for funeral processions across the province. And until Wednesday, they were illegal. </P> <P>But now Manitoba Public Insurance officials say they'll allow funeral operators to have the lights on their vehicles to improve road safety in the province. </P> <P>The move came after funeral operators like Richard Wojcik went to MPI and requested a rule change. </P> <P>Wojcik, the owner of Wojcik's Funeral Chapel, said he was angry after being ticketed twice by police for having the lights on his vehicles. He estimated the company spent about $8,000 outfitting two Crown Victorias with purple light bars across their roofs to lead funeral processions. </P> <P>He was irate when police contacted him in 2009 and told him he was breaking the law -- especially since he'd had the lights on one car since 2004. He said the light is a visible and symbolic indicator to other drivers to "slow down." </P> <P>"You cannot miss that vehicle coming down a street," said Wojcik. </P> <P>Now, funeral operators can apply for a free permit to install the lights and will only be allowed to flash them when leading a procession. </P> <P>The lead vehicle in a funeral procession in Winnipeg must slow down or halt at red lights and stop signs, checking for safety before proceeding. After that vehicle passes through the intersection, the convoy of vehicles has the right- of-way over the other vehicles at the intersection. </P> <P>Police said earlier this year the law caused a traffic hazard because motorists in a procession might have been confused about the right-of-way. One officer said it was only a "matter of time" before a fatality occurred. </P> <P>MPI sent a letter Wednesday to about 55 funeral operators informing them the change is to "increase the visibility of funeral processions and, in doing so, alert other road users to the special right-of-way provisions." </P> <P>Flashing purple lights will only be allowed for funeral vehicles leading processions, not for motorists interested in jazzing up their vehicles. </P> <P>"They're distinctive, they're eye-catching... studies have shown that the flashing purple lights are very distinctive. They are even more so distinctive than the usual red and blue that (emergency vehicles) are using now," said MPI spokesman Brian Smiley. </P> <P>MPI said in the letter policing agencies will also be notified about the rule change. </P> <P>Sgt. Doug Safioles of Winnipeg Police Service's central traffic unit said he hopes the lights will improve the general safety of funeral processions. </P> <P>"Most police don't support funeral processions going through red lights... it's just so dangerous," he said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Flashing purple lights will officially mark funeral processions
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba motorists could soon see flashing purple lights on vehicles of funeral operators during a procession, Manitoba Public Insurance announced today. </P> <P>“For maximum visibility these distinctive flashing purple lights will be placed on vehicles of funeral operators,” said Ward Keith, Registrar of Motor Vehicles. </P> <P>“After a thorough review it was concluded that these lights are quite distinct and make funeral processions much more noticeable to other motorists. The use of purple lights would be beneficial to those funeral vehicles leading a procession.” </P> <P>With safety at the forefront, it was determined that funeral service providers, wishing to use flashing purple lights may now do so by applying for a special lighting permit which will be issued by the Registrar. There is no charge to the permit, which has no expiration date, but is vehicle specific. </P> <P>Historically, vehicles in a funeral procession would activate their headlights to indicate to other motorist that they were a part of a funeral procession. As daytime running lights became required equipment on all vehicles in Canada a number of years ago, virtually all vehicles now have their headlights illuminated whenever they are being driven, so funeral processions are no longer as readily identifiable as they once were, explained Keith. </P> <P>The use of purple flashing lights on funeral vehicles will now be a visual reminder to motorists that a funeral procession is in progress. Currently, Manitoba's Highway Traffic Act states that local governments can create by-laws to provide for the right of way of processions. </P> <P>The general rule is that once the lead vehicle in the procession has ensured that it is safe to proceed, the procession may proceed through a red light or stop signs. Other motorists are to give the right of way to the vehicles in the procession. </P> <P>Other Canadian jurisdictions ? Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Prince Edward Island, and Nova Scotia ? all permit the use of flashing purple lights on funeral vehicles. </P> <P>Manitoba's Highway Traffic Act currently prohibits the use of purple lights on any vehicle. However, the legislation also contains a provision that allows the Registrar of Motor Vehicles to issue a Special Lighting Permit. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Purple lights approved for Manitoba funeral processions
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - Manitoba Public Insurance says it has decided to let funeral operators use flashing purple lights on their vehicles in the interest of improving road safety in the province. </P> <P>Until now, the lights have been illegal in Manitoba, although they have been used in Alberta, Saskatchewan and Nova Scotia. </P> <P>The move came after funeral operators including Richard Wojcik went to MPI and requested a rule change. </P> <P>Wojcik, the owner of Wojcik's Funeral Chapel, says he's been ticketed twice by police for having the lights on his vehicles. </P> <P>He estimates his company spent about $8,000 outfitting two Crown Victorias with purple light bars across their roofs to lead funeral processions. </P> <P>He says the lights are a visible and symbolic indicator to other drivers to ``slow down'' out of respect for the procession.</P>

--30--

Title: 27-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI Introduces Flashing Purple Lights For Funeral Processions
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Manitoba Public Insurance says flashing purple lights may soon identify approaching funeral processions. A review has found flashing purple lights are so distinct, they'll do a better job alerting motorists. The lights will be on the vehicles leading the procession. A special lighting permit will be granted at no charge.  Five other provinces have already been using flashing purple lights. That list includes Alberta, Saskatchewan and Ontario.<BR>

--30--

Title: 28-Feb-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police investigating serious overnight crash on Cavalier
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- City police are still at the scene of a serious crash in west St. James this morning.</P> <P>A black Honda Civic crashed into a tree sometimes around 1:30 a.m., on Cavalier Drive near Morgan Crescent, and one person went to hospital with severe injuries.</P> <P>The vehicle is on the boulevard of a home in the 700 block of Cavalier.</P> <P>"I was in the basement -- the carpet got wet from the weekend -- and I heard a big bang," said Roger DeFreitas.</P> <P>"I thought it was something in the backyard. Then the dog started barking and we could see the car right in front of the house.</P> <P>"There was just one person in it. I looked in and it was a young kid. He was still breathing, then the cops came and they handled it."</P> <P>About four cruiser cars are still at the scene this morning.</P> <P>A stretch of Cavalier between Ness and Fairlane avenues remains closed to traffic as collision analysts investigate.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Here & There: RCMP OFFICER FACES CHARGE
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
A member of the Yellowhead RCMP Detachment area has been formally charged with attempted fraud over $5,000. The 39-year old Corporal who is a member of the Elphinstone detachment was charged May 17 after an investigation that began in 2009. MPI Special Investigation Unit alleges that on July 7, 2009 the off-duty officer filed an Autopac claim relating to a collision involving a personal vehicle near Elphinstone. Inconsistencies to the claim led to a follow up investigation by MPI and subsequent referral to Manitoba Justice. The man is slated to make his first court appearance in Minnedosa on June 29. <BR>

--30--

Title: 2-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car-theft suspects nabbed ; Monitoring bracelet played key role
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Here's one way to give yourself away. </P> <P>One of three 16-year-old boys accused of going on an auto-theft spree while armed with a sawed-off shotgun was wearing an electronic monitoring bracelet on his leg, allowing authorities to track and locate the thieves, police say. </P> <P>Winnipeg police were alerted at some point and caught up with the suspects -- two are Level 4 offenders or chronic thieves in the Winnipeg Auto Theft Suppression Strategy -- who led officers on a brief but dangerous pursuit. </P> <P>Police spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen said the suspects reached speeds of 140 km/h as they fled in a stolen Chevrolet Avalanche in a 70 km/h zone on Century Street. </P> <P>'Enjoy the challenge' </P> <P>Police said the suspects stole, attempted to steal or damaged eight vehicles Tuesday between 8 p.m. and 11:30 p.m., mostly in northwest Winnipeg. The trio would steal a vehicle, drive it around and dump it for a new one. </P> <P>"This is the high that some of these offenders get," Michalyshen said. "They enjoy the challenge." </P> <P>The incidents occurred in the 1300 block of Redwood Avenue, first 100 block of Greenhoven Crescent, first 100 block of Larkspur Drive, first 100 block of Stillmeadow Cove, 300 block of Inkster Park Drive, first 100 block of Foyle Street and 100 block of Ostafiew Farm Road. </P> <P>At some point, a monitoring centre in Georgia became aware of a breach by the bracelet-wearing suspect -- possibly a curfew -- and notified probation services, who called police. </P> <P>The male is wearing the bracelet, a GPS device, as a condition of a previous auto theft conviction. </P> <P>Officers located the suspects near Corydon Avenue and Carpathia Street in Tuxedo on Wednesday at 1:30 a.m. but the driver took off and drove recklessly, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>Police aborted the pursuit due to safety concerns. </P> <P>The suspects abandoned the vehicle on Eckhardt Avenue in Tyndall Park. Two were arrested nearby. A third was arrested later in the day. </P> <P>The trio is facing several charges for theft, gun possession and court breaches, police said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 3-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car wrapped around Crestview tree
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>City police are investigating whether speed and alcohol were factors when a car crashed into a tree in Winnipeg early Thursday, sending a young man to hospital with serious injuries. </P> <P>A witness said she smelled alcohol in the dark-coloured Honda Civic when she checked on the injured driver, who was the lone occupant. The car's passenger side wrapped around a tree on the west boulevard of the residential street. </P> <P>The driver, whose age wasn't released, was in unstable condition when he was rushed to hospital but was later upgraded to stable, said police spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen. </P> <P>Michalyshen said police are exploring whether the driver was impaired. </P> <P>The single-vehicle crash occurred on Cavalier Drive at Morgan Crescent in Crestview about 1 a.m., jolting residents Brent Johnson and Patricia Clark from their sleep. </P> <P>"I heard the squealing of the brakes and then all of a sudden I heard this big crash," Johnson said. </P> <P>Johnson told Clark, his wife, to call 911. Clark approached the car while she was on the phone with a 911 call-taker. </P> <P>"She told me to check to see if he was responding. All I could smell on him was alcohol and he wasn't responding at all," Clark said. "He was breathing heavily." </P> <P>Clark doesn't think the male, who looked to be in his 20s, was wearing a seatbelt because he was lying across the front seats of the crumpled car. </P> <P>"His top half was on the passenger side and his lower half was on the driver's seat," Clark said. </P> <P>Emergency personnel arrived quickly, she said. </P> <P>Clark believed the car was travelling northbound at the time of the crash. Damage to its passenger side was extensive. </P> <P>Clark said the collision doesn't surprise her because she often sees speeding vehicles on the stretch of Cavalier where it occurred. </P> <P>Police closed Cavalier Drive between Ness and Fairlane avenues until 9:50 a.m. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver-testing services in rural Manitoba
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Rural Manitobans are seeing changes in the way Manitoba Public Insurance does business when it comes to obtaining a driver’s licence.</P> <P>Full time driver testing and licensing services will be offered in 10 major rural communities as compared to the four rural locations that provided services prior to Manitoba Public Insurance assuming responsibility for driver and vehicle licensing functions in 2004. These 10 communities are Winnipeg, Brandon, Portage la Prairie, Dauphin, Thompson, Steinbach, Winkler, The Pas, Selkirk, Beausejour and Arborg (Gimli for commercial class testing). The changes provide more choice of appointment times and allow for more road tests to take place at these locations.</P> <P>Manitobans living in “mobile or satellite testing” communities have two options available: book a testing appointment in their community, or book an appointment in the nearest major testing centre. Geographic studies report that 73 per cent of rural Manitobans live within 50 Km of a Manitoba Public Insurance service centre.</P> <P>For the 25 per cent of rural Manitobans living more than 50 km from one of these centres, the changes are not an improvement. The website (<A href="http://www.mpi.mb.ca">www.mpi.mb.ca</A>) shows that testing is available in Killarney twice per month, in Glenboro once a month, and in Pilot Mound once very two months. In addition, road testing for classes 1, 2 & 3 is no longer available in the satellite communities, but has been centralized in larger rural centres.</P> <P>Class 1 vehicles are semi-trailers. Testing in service centre locations allows for test conditions that more closely replicate the challenges that these units encounter while driving in major urban centres across Canada and the United States.</P> <P>Commercial road tests will now be offered in the following 13 Manitoba communities: Winnipeg, Brandon, Portage, Dauphin, Thompson, Steinbach, Swan River, The Pas, Selkirk, Beausejour, Gimli, Winkler, and Churchill.</P> <P>Class 2 vehicles include school buses and buses. For the safety of Manitoba children, it is incumbent on Manitoba Public Insurance to ensure that school bus drivers are appropriately challenged and better prepared for driving scenarios that may be encountered in and around Manitoba.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Flashing lights will warn of funeral cars
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>MANITOBA motorists could soon see flashing purple lights on vehicles of funeral operators during a procession, Manitoba Public Insurance announced yesterday.</P> <P>“For maximum visibility these distinctive flashing purple lights will be placed on vehicles of funeral operators,” said Ward Keith, registrar of motor vehicles.</P> <P>“After a thorough review it was concluded that these lights are quite distinct and make funeral processions much more noticeable to other motorists. The use of purple lights would be beneficial to those funeral vehicles leading a procession.”</P> <P>With safety at the forefront, it was determined that funeral service providers wishing to use flashing purple lights may now do so by obtaining a special lighting permit which will be issued by the registrar. There is no charge to the permit, which has no expiration date, but is vehicle specific.</P> <P>Historically, vehicles in a funeral procession would activate their headlights to indicate that they were part of a funeral procession. As daytime running lights became required equipment on all vehicles in Canada 20 years ago, virtually all vehicles now have their headlights on whenever they are being driven, so funeral processions are no longer as readily identifiable as they once were, explained Keith.</P> <P>The use of purple flashing lights on funeral vehicles will now be a visual reminder to motorists that a funeral procession is in progress. Currently, Manitoba’s Highway Traffic Act states that local governments can create by-laws to provide for the right of way of processions.</P> <P>The general rule is once the lead vehicle in the procession has ensured it is safe to proceed, the procession may proceed through a red light or stop signs. Other motorists are to give the right of way to the vehicles in the procession.</P> <P>Other Canadian jurisdictions—Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Prince Edward Island, and Nova Scotia—all permit the use of flashing purple lights on funeral vehicles.</P> <P>Manitoba’s Highway Traffic Act currently prohibits the use of purple lights on any vehicle. However, the legislation also contains a provision allowing the registrar of motor vehicles to issue a special lighting permit.</P>

--30--

Title: 6-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Construction begins on new MPI service centre  Will house all of Selkirk MPI services including driver licence testing, vehicle repairs
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Construction on a new Manitoba Public Insurance service centre has begun in Selkirk, and the auto insurance company is promising the new building will be more convenient for customers.</P> <P>MPI communications representative Brian Smiley explains the new building, which saw preliminary construction started last week, will not only house an Autopac claim centre but will also be a one-stop destination for all MPI services.</P> <P>The new building will sit on a vacant patch of land on the east end of Manitoba Avenue, beside Selkirk GM.</P> <P>“It’s going to be a full-service centre where the customer will be able to go in and have all their MPI needs serviced,” Smiley explained. “Instead of going to different locations, it will all be in one place and it will greatly reduce the amount of travelling for customers.”</P> <P>The 28,000 square foot building is expected to be completed next year, and is one of four new MPI service centres currently planned for Manitoba.</P> <P>Two centres are currently being constructed in the south end of Winnipeg, as well as another that has recently been completed on Main Street in the city’s north end.</P> <P>Selkirk’s new service centre will also house the insurance agency’s drivers licencing testing, where customers can go to either write their written drivers test or take their road test.</P> <P>It will also be the location where drivers can meet with insurance agents to go over claims and have their vehicles repaired, as well as serve as another Autopac location where customers are able to renew both their license and insurance.</P> <P>Selkirk currently has several Autopac outlets around the city, but only has one claim centre that is located in the north end of the city on Sophia Avenue.</P> <P>The decision to pool all of Autopac’s services into one location is all part of MPI’s new service model since their merger with Manitoba Driver Vehicle Licensing.</P> <P>“When we merged with Driver Vehicle Licensing in 2004, we created a business plan that would merge all our staff and services under one roof,” said Smiley. “As we evolve as a cooperation, we’re looking at how we can better serve Manitobans and customers in Selkirk.</P> <P>When construction on the new MPI service centre is completed, Smiley says operations will cease at the current claim centre on Sophia Avenue and that the building and property will likely be sold.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI stresses positives of testing changes  More appointments, less waiting time, says government insurer  Crossroads This Week
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>More appointment dates. Less waiting time. Even greater customer convenience.</P> <P>These are a few of the new changes which rural Manitobans are now seeing after Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) improved the way it does business when it comes to obtaining a driver’s licence.</P> <P>“These adjustments were the result of an extensive business process review,” explained Ward Keith, Registrar of Motor Vehicles for MPI. “We’ve added nearly 800 more road and written test appointments through our satellite mobile communities.</P> <P>“The review reported that appointment dates were often going unused in some communities, while other communities needed more appointment dates due to increased demand.”</P> <P>Full time driver testing and licensing services will be offered in 10 major rural communities as compared to the four rural locations that provided services prior to MPI assuming responsibility for driver and vehicle licensing functions in 2004. These 10 communities are Winnipeg, Brandon, Portage la Prairie, Dauphin, Thompson, Steinbach, Winkler, The Pas, Selkirk, Beausejour and Arborg (Gimli for commercial class testing).</P> <P>These changes are designed to provide more choice of appointment times and allow for more road tests to take place, said Keith.</P> <P>Manitobans living in “mobile or satellite testing” communities have two options available: book a testing appointment in their community, or book an appointment in the nearest major testing centre. Geographic studies report that 73 percent of rural Manitobans live within 50 km of an MPI service centre.</P> <P>This is what MPI calls your catchment area - it’s where you can access more test appointments than before.</P> <P>“If Manitobans living in the satellite testing community choose to take their test elsewhere, their travelling time will be kept to minimum,” said Keith.</P> <P>Another change following the review is that road testing for classes 1, 2 and 3 will now be centralized in larger rural centres to maximize MPI staff productivity and increase the capacity to offer more road tests to customers.</P> <P>“Moving the class 1, 2 and 3 to the larger centres will also enhance the quality of driver testing standards for commercial licence classes,” explained Keith.</P> <P>Class 1 vehicles are semitrailers which by their very nature present a road risk that mandates the highest testing standards possible, said Keith. Testing in service centre locations allows for test conditions that more closely replicate the challenges that these units encounter while driving in major urban centres across Canada and the United States. Offering a more robust practical road test will enhance driver skill and ensure a higher degree of safety on roadways.</P> <P>Class 2 vehicles include school buses and buses. </P> <P>Commercial road tests will now be offered in 13 Manitoba communities: Winnipeg, Brandon, Portage, Dauphin, Thompson, Steinbach, Swan River, The Pas, Selkirk, Beausejour, Gimli, Winkler, and Churchill.</P> <P>“By having people write their tests at satellite mobile communities and service centres, we’re able to serve all customers equally well,” said Keith. “Previously, testing service in some smaller communities was unused, while some larger communities required more appointment dates.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 8-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Keep safety in mind
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Teulon Elementary is asking drivers to slow down and watch the road carefully when passing the intersection of Beach Rd. and Main St. in Teulon before and after school.</P> <P>The school, along with the Teulon Elementary Parent’s Association, set up one of Manitoba Public Insurance’s “School Zone Speed Watch” reader boards at the corner last fall to record driver’s habits at the school crossing and principal Gloria Yaremkiewich says the results are alarming.</P> <P>“We’re very, very concerned,” she says of the intersection, pointing out that of the 486 cars clocked, 292 were going over the 50 km/h speed limit. “That’s more than 60 per cent of the cars, and that’s not at all safe for our kids.</P> <P>“It would be really, really nice if people would just be more careful.”</P> <P>Of the speeding vehicles, 95 were clocked at 60-69 km/h, 26 passed going between 70-79 km/h and 15 blew by travelling between 80-89 km/h.</P> <P>Yaremkiewich, who’s been with the school for three years, says she really wasn’t very surprised with the results of the survey.</P> <P>“I think it’s quite common really,” she says, adding it’s not just speeding that has the school worried. “Even if the lights are flashing, and the crossing guards are out, people are also still turning to go down Main St.</P> <P>“If drivers on both sides of the crosswalk don’t wait for the lights to turn off, it’s very dangerous for the kids crossing and for our patrols.”</P> <P>Teulon Elementary asks drivers to watch out</P> <P>The problem has motivated the Interlake School Division to pay for adult crossing guards to go out with the school’s young patrols in the morning and after school, which Yaremkiewich says makes a big difference.</P> <P>“The School Division saw the importance of it, and we were able to hire two crossing guards, which is so good,” she says. “The safety of our children is a very big concern in the entire division.</P> <P>“It’s lucky that we have the adults on to help, but even the adults are coming to me and saying there are vehicles going through against the lights.”</P> <P>The school has been reminding parents to slow down and respect the crossing guards through their newsletter, and also forwarded the numbers from their reader board to the Teulon RCMP detachment, who have been keeping on eye on the intersection.</P> <P>The school patrols are at the corner from 8:30-8:50 a.m. and again after school at 3:30 p.m., and Yaremkiewich hopes drivers will keep their speeds down and their eyes open for the flashing lights at the crosswalk.</P> <P>“People have to help keep our kids safe, that’s our main goal here,” she says. “That’s why we reinstated our patrol program, to help get these kids across safely.</P> <P>“Now people have to be aware that if the lights are flashing or if you see an orange flag, please come to a stop and wait.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Insurance brokers unite with new name
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>EARLIER this week, a new insurance brokerage name was announced in Selkirk -- One Insurance Group. </P> <P>Residents of Selkirk, Teulon, Birds Hill, Stonewall and a few other communities close to the Perimeter who have long patronized their local insurance agencies might be surprised to know their brokers were already part of this new group and that it has actually been around for several years. </P> <P>Dale McMillan's father started McMillan Insurance in Selkirk in 1953. When Dale took over the business in the mid-'90s they bought agencies in Stonewall and Oakbank. Earlier this decade, Teulon was added, then more recently Birds Hill and Middlechurch, Warren and then two agencies in north Winnipeg. </P> <P>All of them kept their own names, but McMillan said it finally came time to let everyone know they were all part of the same group, thus the name change to One Insurance Group. </P> <P>"The smaller mom-and-pop operations were losing markets because many insurance companies demand a certain volume for a broker to have access to their product," McMillan said. </P> <P>Reid Henderson, general manager of the business, said, "We started to realize that some of our clients didn't know they could visit a location much closer to them rather than drive all the way to Selkirk to conduct business because they didn't know we had so many locations." </P> <P>The One Insurance consolidation play is part of a larger process that has been underway for some time. Earlier this year, Wyatt Dowling Insurance was formed with a merger of those two longstanding firms. </P> <P>Last summer, Horizon Insurance merged with Ryan Gateway to form an 18- location operation. </P> <P>MIG Insurance has also been buying independent agencies in Winnipeg, Portage la Prairie and southern Manitoba so it now owns nine locations and manages two others. </P> <P>Pamela Gilroy-Rajotte, president of the Insurance Brokers of Manitoba, said the surge in mergers and acquisitions was taking place all across the country. </P> <P>"Volume commitments are complicated," she said. "Little mom-and-pop operations were down to the point where they did not have enough to survive. So they became part of a larger group in order to do that." </P> <P>Gilroy-Rajotte said consolidation also means greater depth of service when it comes to human resources and the ability for firms to deploy more resources on specialty areas and provide broader coverage. </P> <P>But many say they believe the level of mergers and acquisitions will be tailing off now that Manitoba Public Insurance has adopted a five-year renewal policy on auto insurance in the province. </P> <P>Although agencies will still receive annual commissions on Autopac renewals, they will not be at the same levels. </P> <P>McMillan said that's going to mean a new model for putting a value on independent agencies will have to emerge and he said it will probably take a bit of time for that to sort itself out. </P> <P>"We'll probably be a little more conservative now when it comes to acquisitions," he said. "There might be a little more due diligence." </P> <P>David Schioler, CEO of the Insurance Brokers Association of Manitoba, said while revenue streams for brokerages may be affected by the MPI changes, there was plenty of work done to ensure consumers will be well-served by the changes. </P> <P>"And this new arrangement was certainly not meant to put anyone out of business," he said. </P> <P><A href="mailto:martin.cash@freepress.mb.ca">martin.cash@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>Manitoba's largest insurance brokers </P> <P>-- Horizon-Ryan Gateway -- 18 locations <BR>-- Wyatt Dowling Insurance Brokers -- 11 locations <BR>-- Ranger Insurance Brokers -- 10 locations <BR>-- One Insurance Group -- 10 locations <BR>-- MIG Insurance Group -- nine locations <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teenager sentenced for crash that killed cabbie
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- A high-risk car thief who was just 14 when he killed a Winnipeg cab driver while at the wheel of a speeding, stolen SUV will not be given an adult sentence. </P> <P>Queen's Bench Justice Lea Duval ruled Friday the boy, now 16, will remain under the authority of the Youth Criminal Justice Act. </P> <P>She gave him the maximum sentence of two years closed custody, followed by one year of community supervision. Duval also exercised her discretion under the act and gave the teen no credit for more than two years of time already served. </P> <P>He was also given a 10-year driving prohibition. The youth pleaded guilty earlier this year to criminal negligence causing death and bodily harm for his role in the March 2008 crash that killed Antonio Lanzellotti. </P> <P>The teen and six other youths were racing a stolen truck when their sport utility vehicle blew through two red lights and hit Lanzellotti's cab. Lanzellotti, 55, died instantly. </P> <P>A passenger in the cab was seriously injured. </P> <P>An agreed statement of facts filed in court says the SUV was going almost 140 kilometres an hour at the time of impact. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cabbie's killer to be jailed two more years
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A high-risk Winnipeg car thief has received the maximum youth sentence -- and no credit for pretrial custody -- for killing a Winnipeg cab driver with a speeding, stolen SUV. </P> <P>The teen, who was 14 at the time of the deadly March 2008 crash, was given two years' closed custody followed by one year of community supervision Friday. Queen's Bench Justice Lea Duval also exercised her discretion under the Youth Criminal Justice Act and said no time will be deducted off his sentence for the more than two years of time already spent behind bars. She also imposed a 10- year driving prohibition. </P> <P>The boy, who is now 16, pleaded guilty earlier this year to criminal negligence causing death and bodily harm for his role killing Antonio Lanzellotti. </P> <P>"I'm sorry for what happened. I wasn't thinking back then, I was 14 years old, I wasn't thinking of my future. Now I am. I know that wasn't the right thing I was doing," he said Friday in court. The boy's father also apologized to the Lanzellotti family. </P> <P>The Crown was seeking an adult sentence against the teen, who comes from a prominent family of criminals with strong ties to the Mad Cowz street gang. Prosecutor Brent Davidson had requested another 23 months of jail. Duval essentially imposed the exact sentence the Crown was seeking, just under the guise of a youth disposition. The teen -- who could have been named if an adult sentence was imposed -- was seeking just eight more months behind bars. </P> <P>At his sentencing hearing earlier this spring, probation officials admitted the teen breached an existing probation order 24 times in the weeks preceding the deadly crash. However, they used their own discretion and decided not to report any of the breaches to police. The revelation prompted an outcry in the provincial legislature and a review of current policies and procedures. </P> <P>On the night of March 29, 2008, the boy had been drinking and consuming drugs with a large group of youths loitering around a downtown apartment building with two stolen vehicles. The group scattered when they saw police headed their way. The boy was driving a Chevy Avalanche containing six other young offenders. He began racing a stolen Silverado that contained the other seven youths, court was told. The boy reached speeds of 139 km/h -- the legal limit is 60 km/h -- and blew through two red lights on Portage Avenue before slamming into the taxi being driven by Lanzellotti at the corner of Portage and Maryland Street. </P> <P>Lanzellotti, 55, died instantly. He suffered a massive skull fracture, broken ribs and legs and trauma to his brain and chest. A passenger in the cab was seriously injured. </P> <P>Probation officials say the boy has made great progress during his two years in youth custody but remains a medium risk to reoffend. They say his biggest obstacle is his own criminally entrenched family, although several relatives have since been deported to Africa. Several others were in court Friday, including an older half brother who made gang signs and shouted obscenities upon leaving court. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Adult sentence denied ; Two more years in custody for cabbie-killing driver
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A teenage boy behind the wheel of a stolen sport utility vehicle that killed city cab driver Antonio Lanzellotti has been sentenced to two years custody and one year community supervision. </P> <P>The boy, who was 14 at the time of the crash, previously pleaded guilty to criminal negligence causing death and criminal negligence causing bodily harm. His sentence is the maximum allowed under the Youth Criminal Justice Act and is on top of two years he has already spent in custody. </P> <P>Justice Lea Duval rejected a Crown request the youth be sentenced as an adult. </P> <P>The boy was one of 13 youths and one adult arrested in connection with the March 2008 crash. The boy and six other youths were in a stolen Chevrolet Avalanche, racing a stolen Chevrolet Silverado pickup, when the SUV blew through two red lights and hit Lanzellotti's cab at the intersection of Maryland Street and Portage Avenue. Lanzellotti died instantly. </P> <P>The youth suffered a dislocated hip in the crash. When police found him walking down Portage Avenue he claimed he had been injured by flying debris from the crash. Later, while in custody, he admitted being a passenger in the Avalanche and identified a different suspect as the driver. </P> <P>DNA evidence </P> <P>The youth didn't admit he was the driver until police confronted him with evidence his DNA was found on the steering wheel airbag. </P> <P>The youth offered a short apology in court. </P> <P>"I wasn't thinking back then," he said. "I was young, I was still 14 years old." </P> <P>Several of the youth's family members were present in court for sentencing, including known gang members. Outside court one of the gang members said: "Four years, not a bad deal for a life." </P> <P>A sentencing hearing in April generated a firestorm of controversy after the youth's probation officer testified he repeatedly violated a court-ordered curfew and skipped school before the fatal crash. The breaches were never reported to police. </P> <P>"If he simply would have been able to comply with his probation order he would not have been involved in this incident ... (and) Antonio Lanzellotti would still be alive," Crown attorney Brent Davidson told court. </P> <P>The youth is the last of the 14 accused to be sentenced in the crash.</P>

--30--

Title: 13-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Gimli man, 20, was headed home before fatal crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Gimli area continues to mourn a young man who died tragically in a single-vehicle crash Thursday. </P> <P>Evan David John King, 20, was killed when his car landed in a water-filled ditch north of the Interlake town. </P> <P>King's parents are Richard and Joann King. Together, they own King's Flooring and Furniture Gallery in Gimli, and Joann King has been the Rural Municipality of Gimli's chief administrative officer for years. On Saturday she spoke to reporters about Evan for the first time. </P> <P>"I'd like everybody to know he was truly loved," she said. </P> <P>As of Saturday night more than 400 people had joined a memorial group dedicated to Evan King on Facebook, a social networking website. </P> <P>King spent Wednesday night with friends in Gimli watching Game 3 of the NHL final, his mom said. </P> <P>"He was a real sports fan," she said. "He was cheering for Chicago." </P> <P>Evan, who worked at the Husky gas station in Gimli and lived with his parents, called one of his brothers a little before midnight and said he would be home in about 20 minutes, his mom said. The next morning RCMP and the local fire chief went to his family's home to tell them what happened. </P> <P>Police were called to the crash scene on Highway 222 approximately 3 kilometres north of Camp Morton at 5:10 a.m. Thursday after a motorist spotted a car upside down in the west ditch. </P> <P>King was wearing a seatbelt at the time. An autopsy is pending. </P> <P>"We think maybe he swerved to miss a deer or something and hit the soft shoulder," Joann King said. </P> <P>Evan King is survived by his parents and three siblings. A celebration of his life will take place Friday at noon at Fraserwood Hall in Fraserwood, Man. </P> <P>Donations to the Evan King Scholarship Fund can be made through the Gimli Credit Union, P.O. Box 1139, Gimli. </P> <P>Gimli is roughly 75 kilometres north of Winnipeg. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Train strikes woman ; Later dies of her injuries in hospital
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A woman was struck by a train in River Heights on Saturday and taken to hospital in critical condition, where she died of her injuries. </P> <P>Winnipeg police and emergency responders rushed to a Canadian National Railway track just south of Taylor Avenue and west of Waverley Street about 3 p.m., after being called about the incident that apparently occurred behind the Reh-Fit Centre fitness complex. </P> <P>Police confirmed the CN Rail train struck a pedestrian, though few details were given. </P> <P>WITNESSES </P> <P>"One person has been conveyed to hospital in critical condition," police spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen said Saturday afternoon, adding it was uncertain whether investigators had identified the victim. </P> <P>Though Michalyshen said he couldn't specify the victim's sex, witnesses around the scene said it was a woman who was taken by ambulance to St. Boniface General Hospital. </P> <P>Police said Saturday night that the death was a result of suicide. </P> <P>City cops and CN police examined the cordoned-off scene, which had tape reaching into a large section of the Reh-Fit Centre's parking lot on Taylor Avenue. </P> <P>While investigators combed the track site for evidence, traffic officers closed a section of Waverley Street to traffic north and south of Taylor. </P> <P>Michalyshen couldn't specify the crash site, though he said it appears to have been in the area of "roughly the 1300-block" of Taylor. </P> <P>Members coming and going from the fitness centre were surprised to learn a woman had been hit by the train. </P> <P>The scene of the collision is near the site of a highly publicized incident involving a train on the same track more than three years ago. </P> <P>Around noon on a weekday in April 2007, Winifred Lindsay, then 89, was trying to cross the track near Waverley on a scooter when she fell off and became pinned beneath it as a train approached. </P> <P>Driving separately, Deborah Chiborak and Gerard Beernaerts -- operating a Winnipeg Transit bus -- saw Lindsay on the track and ran from their vehicles, pulling the senior from the track just before the train roared past. </P> <P>Chiborak and Beernaerts were later awarded Canadian Medals of Bravery and medals from the U.S.-based Carnegie Hero Fund Commission because of their actions. </P> <P>Meanwhile, a male pedestrian was transported to hospital in critical condition last night after he was hit by a vehicle at the intersection of Sargent Avenue and Furby Street about 8:40 p.m. Sargent was shut down between Sherbook and Spence streets. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>RED VAN SOUGHT AFTER HIT-AND-RUN </P> <P>City police are looking for the driver of a red minivan after a pedestrian was struck and sent to hospital in critical condition Saturday night. </P> <P>The 41-year-old man was hit by a westbound vehicle on Sargent Avenue near Furby Street in Winnipeg's core area about 8:40 p.m. </P> <P>While the victim was initially assessed as critical due to possible upper body and head injuries, he was later upgraded to stable and remained in hospital Sunday. </P> <P>Police said that according to witness accounts, the driver involved stopped after the collision to check on the victim's condition, but as more people gathered at the scene he fled the area in his vehicle. </P> <P>Police continue to investigate. </P> <P>CRASH INTO DITCH KILLS MAN </P> <P>A man is dead after a single-vehicle crash on Highway 6 this weekend. </P> <P>RCMP were called to the scene about 15 km north of Grand Rapids shortly before 10 a.m. after motorists came across it. </P> <P>The driver was found dead in the vehicle and was its lone occupant, Grand Rapids RCMP said. </P> <P>The man has been tentatively identified as a 46-year-old from Lake Manitoba First Nation. </P> <P>A preliminary investigation indicates the vehicle was heading south on Highway 6 when it drifted onto the southbound shoulder, RCMP said. The driver over-corrected and the vehicle crossed the highway and went into the northbound ditch, rolling several times. </P> <P>Speed is considered a factor in the crash, police said, adding the driver was not wearing a seatbelt. </P> <P>An autopsy is scheduled for Monday at Health Sciences Centre in Winnipeg. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 16-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man critically injured in hit and run
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police are on the hunt for the driver of a red van involved in a hit and run that critically injured a man in the city's Spence Neighbourhood.</P> <P>Police said a 41-year-old man was hit on Sargent Avenue near Furby Street at about 8:40 p.m. CT Saturday.</P> <P>The driver stopped for a short period and checked on the victim's condition, but fled after more people gathered near the scene, police said.</P> <P>Paramedics rushed the victim to the hospital in critical condition. On Sunday, his condition stabilized.</P> <P>Police continue to investigate.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/06/man-hit-and-run-van-search.html#ixzz0qAklSzZ3">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/06/man-hit-and-run-van-search.html#ixzz0qAklSzZ3</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Make graduation safe
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: By Manitoba Public Insurance  Submitted Article Central Plains Herald-Leader • Saturday, June 5, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Grad means different things to different people. But no matter what memories you hold, one sentiment holds true for everyone: it’s the first day of the rest of your life. Don’t ruin it by drinking and driving or letting someone else do the same.</P> <P>Drinking and driving kills. It maims. It affects thousands of people every year.</P> <P>Here in Manitoba, about 30 people are killed every year in alcohol-related collisions, according to Manitoba Public Insurance statistics. And more than half of them are between the ages of 16 and 25.</P> <P>Just as disturbing is the fact that drivers aged 16–24 continue to be over-represented in the total number of alcohol-impaired driving convictions. Even though drivers in that same age group represent only 14.1 per cent of licensed drivers in Manitoba, they account for more than double that proportion of all impaired driving convictions at almost 31 per cent.</P> <P>And the statistics don’t tell the whole story. With each person killed in an alcohol-related crash, there are others who are deeply affected. Parents. Siblings. Friends. Co-workers.</P> <P>In its annual appeal to high school students, Manitoba Public Insurance partnered once again this year with MADD Canada to deliver a hard-hitting program on the dangers of impaired driving to students in 65 schools across the province. The multi-media assembly program, Wasted, enables both organizations to deliver an in impactful message to a very targeted audience.</P> <P>“With safe grad season nearly upon us, we need to continue to get the message out to the students that driving while impaired has far-reaching consequences and no one is immune to the risk,” says Clif Eden, manager of Road Safety for Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>“We want to help young people understand the dangers while encouraging a commitment to sober driving.”</P> <P>The message is clear: stay safe this grad season. Don’t drink and drive. Don’t let a friend drive while impaired and don’t get into a vehicle with someone who has been drinking.</P> <P>“It’s an important decision that can affect the rest of a person’s life,” said Eden. “We want all Manitobans to work together to make our roads safer.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 18-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Flashing purple lights approved for funeral processions
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba motorists could soon see flashing purple lights on vehicles of funeral operators during a procession, Manitoba Public Insurance announced today.</P> <P>For maximum visibility these distinctive flashing purple lights will be placed on vehicles of funeral operators, said Ward Keith, Registrar of Motor Vehicles. After a thorough review it was concluded that these lights are quite distinct and make funeral processions much more noticeable to other motorists. The use of purple lights would be beneficial to those funeral vehicles leading a procession. With safety at the forefront, it was determined that funeral service providers, wishing to use flashing purple lights may now do so by applying for a special lighting permit which will be issued by the Registrar. There is no charge to the permit, which has no expiration date, but is vehicle specific.</P> <P>Historically, vehicles in a funeral procession would activate their headlights to indicate to other motorist that they were a part of a funeral procession. As daytime running lights became required equipment on all vehicles in Canada a number of years ago, virtually all vehicles now have their headlights illuminated whenever they are being driven, so funeral processions are no longer as readily identifiable as they once were, explained Keith. The use of purple flashing lights on funeral vehicles will now be a visual reminder to motorists that a funeral procession is in progress.</P> <P>Currently, Manitoba’s Highway Traffic Act states that local governments can create by-laws to provide for the right of way of processions.</P> <P>The general rule is that once the lead vehicle in the procession has ensured that it is safe to proceed, the procession may proceed through a red light or stop signs. Other motorists are to give the right of way to the vehicles in the procession.</P> <P>Other Canadian jurisdictions — Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Prince Edward Island, and Nova Scotia – all permit the use of flashing purple lights on funeral vehicles.</P> <P>Manitoba’s Highway Traffic Act currently prohibits the use of purple lights on any vehicle. However, the legislation also contains a provision that allows the Registrar of Motor Vehicles to issue a Special Lighting Permit.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Improved Driver-Testing Services In Westman/Parkland Area
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: More appointment dates. Less waiting time. Even greater customer convenience.  The Sentinel Courier, Pilot Mound, MB Tuesday, June 8, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>These are a few of the new changes which rural Manitobans are now seeing after Manitoba Public Insurance improved the way it does business when it comes to obtaining a driver’s licence.</P> <P>“These adjustments were the result of an extensive business process review,” explains Ward Keith, Registrar of Motor Vehicles, Manitoba Public Insurance. “We’ve added nearly 800 more road and written test appointments through our satellite mobile communities.</P> <P>“The review reported that appointment dates were often going unused in some communities, while other communities needed more appointment dates due to increased demand.”</P> <P>Full time driver testing and licensing services will be offered in 10 major rural communities as compared to the four rural locations that provided services prior to Manitoba Public Insurance assuming responsibility for driver and vehicle licensing functions in 2004. These 10 communities are Winnipeg, Brandon, Portage la Prairie, Dauphin, Thompson, Steinbach, Winkler, The Pas, Selkirk, Beausejour and Arborg (Gimli for commercial class testing).</P> <P>These changes are designed to provide more choice of appointment times and allow for more road tests to take place, explained Keith.</P> <P>Manitobans living in “mobile or satellite testing” communities have two options available: book a testing appointment in their community, or book an appointment in the nearest major testing centre. Geographic studies report that 73 per cent of rural Manitobans live within 50 Km of a Manitoba Public Insurance service centre.</P> <P>This is what MPI calls your catchment area - it’s where you can access more test appointments than before, all just a short drive away.</P> <P>“If Manitobans living in the satellite testing community choose to take their test elsewhere, their travelling time will be kept to minimum,” said Keith.</P> <P>Another change following the review is that road testing for classes 1, 2 & 3 will now be centralized in larger rural centres to maximize Manitoba Public Insurance staff productivity and increase the capacity to offer more road tests to customers.</P> <P>“Moving the class 1, 2 and 3 to the larger centres will also enhance the quality of driver testing standards for commercial licence classes,” explained Keith.</P> <P>Class 1 vehicles are semi-trailers which by their very nature present a road risk that mandates the highest testing standards possible, said Keith. Testing in service centre locations allows for test conditions that more closely replicate the challenges that these units encounter while driving in major urban centres across Canada and the United States. Offering a more robust practical road test will enhance driver skill and ensure a higher degree of safety on roadways.</P> <P>Commercial road tests will now be offered in the following 13 Manitoba communities: Winnipeg, Brandon, Portage, Dauphin, Thompson, Steinbach, Swan River, The Pas, Selkirk, Beausejour, Gimli, Winkler, and Churchill.</P> <P>“By having people write their tests at satellite mobile communities and service centres, we’re able to serve all customers equally well,” said Keith. “Previously, testing service in some smaller communities was unused, while some larger communities required more appointment dates.”</P> <P>Class 2 vehicles include school buses and buses. For the safety of Manitoba children, it is incumbent on Manitoba Public Insurance to ensure that school bus challenged drivers are appropriately challenged and better prepared for driving scenarios that may be encountered in and around Manitoba.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stay Safe This Grad: Make the Right Decision
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Sentinel Courier, Pilot Mound, MB Tuesday, June 8, 2010  MPI Press Release
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>- Grad means different things to different people. But no matter what memories you hold, one sentiment holds true for everyone: it’s the first day of the rest of your life. Don’t ruin it by drinking and driving or letting someone else do the same.</P> <P>Drinking and driving kills. It maims. It affects thousands of people every year. Here in Manitoba, about 30 people are killed every year in alcohol-related collisions, according to Manitoba Public Insurance statistics. And more than half of them are between the ages of 16 and 25.</P> <P>Just as disturbing is the fact that drivers aged 16 – 24 continue to be over-represented in the total number of alcohol-impaired driving convictions. Even though drivers in that same age group represent only 14.1 per cent of licensed drivers in Manitoba, they account for more than double that proportion of all impaired driving convictions at almost 31 per cent.</P> <P>And the statistics don’t tell the whole story. With each person killed in an alcohol-related crash, there are others who are deeply affected. Parents. Siblings. Friends. Co-workers.</P> <P>In its annual appeal to high school students, Manitoba Public Insurance partnered once again this year with MADD Canada to deliver a hard-hitting program on the dangers of impaired driving to students in 65 schools across the province. The multimedia assembly program, Wasted, enables both organizations to deliver an impactful message to a very targeted audience.</P> <P>“With safe grad season nearly upon us, we need to continue to get the message out to the students that driving while impaired has far-reaching consequences and no one is immune to the risk,” says Clif Eden, manager of Road Safety for Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>“We want to help young people understand the dangers while encouraging a commitment to sober driving.” The message is clear: stay safe this grad season. Don’t drink and drive. Don’t let a friend drive while impaired and don’t get into a vehicle with someone who has been drinking.</P> <P>“It’s an important decision that can affect the rest of a person’s life,” says Eden. “We want all Manitobans to work together to make our roads safer.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 21-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Carjacker who ran over woman gets 3 years
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: CBC.CA News Mon Jun 7 2010, 10:22pm ET Section: Canada
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A man who comes from a family of habitual car thieves has been given a three-year jail term for the violent carjacking of a woman in the city's North End last fall. </P> <P>The 22-year-old pleaded guilty to robbery during an afternoon provincial court hearing in Winnipeg on Monday. </P> <P>CBC News is not identifying the man in order to report on his extensive youth criminal record, as well as those of underage members of his family involved in stealing cars and driving them dangerously. </P> <P>Susan Everett, 43, was dragged, pummelled and run over by the man, who brazenly stole her idling car when she left it unattended in the back lane behind her home on Sept. 4, 2009. </P> <P>When the man jumped into Everett's new Pontiac Vibe and began driving away, the woman reached into the driver's side window and grabbed onto the car's steering wheel to try and stop him from driving off. </P> <P>Court heard on Monday that Everett's feet were protruding from the window as the car sped away. </P> <P>Despite the woman's pleas for the driver to stop, the man sped off. He punched Everett twice in the face as she clung to the car and dragged her about 60 metres before running over her leg when she let go of the wheel and fell into the street. </P> <P>At the time she was run over, the car was travelling at about 60 km/h, court heard. </P> <P>Everett suffered a number of scrapes, bruises and abrasions, and has been unable to work in the months since the incident occurred, court heard. </P> <P>"My body has been seriously injured as well as my heart and my head," she said in a victim impact statement read in court. </P> <P>Everett said her peace of mind has been "ripped away," even though she and her husband have spent $1,000 on extra security measures at their home. </P> <P>"I get a pit in my stomach every time I turn down my alley," she told Judge Kathlyn Mary Curtis. </P> <P>"I'm very angry this has happened to me. My husband and I live a quiet life," Everett said. </P> <P>The man drove the car to an area outside Winnipeg where it was recovered and eventually returned to Everett. The robber was arrested on Sept. 5 and has been behind bars ever since. </P> <P>'Bad day' triggered violence </P> <P>According to the man's lawyer, he was staying with relatives just a few houses away from Everett's home and woke up late for work after drinking alcohol the night before. </P> <P>After he got into a heated argument with his aunt, he left the house "in a huff, quite upset," Greg Hawrysh said. </P> <P>He saw the running vehicle and jumped into it on "impulse," Hawrysh said. </P> <P>The man is sorry for what happened after that, the lawyer told court. </P> <P>"He wants to be a better person," Hawrysh said. "He doesn't want to hurt people anymore ? he doesn't want to hurt himself anymore." </P> <P>Curtis was told that as a teenager in Surrey, B.C., the man was convicted of a number of auto-theft related offences along with possession of stolen property and dangerous driving. </P> <P>The judge said she didn't buy the man's excuse for the "terrible thing" he did. </P> <P>"It doesn't cut it," Curtis said. "Explaining that it was a really bad day isn't good enough." </P> <P>The man was given double-time credit for the nine months spent in custody after his arrest, meaning he has 18 months left to serve. Curtis also ordered him to serve a three-year probation term after he is released. </P> <P>In a short address to the court, the man said Everett doesn't have to be afraid of him and that he has no plans to bother her again. </P> <P>"I feel terrible. I'm sorry," the man said. </P> <P>Curtis suggested the robber's words rang hollow. </P> <P>"I don't know how much comfort that is to her," the judge said. </P> <P>Relatives known for car theft </P> <P>Although he has a different surname, the man's cousins are known in the justice system as the most prolific car thieves in Winnipeg's history. </P> <P>They are linked to a number of high-profile stolen vehicle incidents and have garnered more than 180 auto theft-related convictions. </P> <P>The man's 17-year-old cousin was arrested in December and charged with manslaughter in connection to a fatal crash that killed 47-year-old Zdzislaw Andrzejczak, a city mechanic. He remains in custody pending trial. </P> <P>Andrzejczak died shortly after a stolen 2005 Hummer H2 drove through a stop sign in the North End and slammed into his small car. </P> <P>Another male relative was Manitoba's first teen auto thief to be given an adult sentence by a judge for his crimes. </P> <P>Some of the man's cousins have been sued by Manitoba Public Insurance to recoup losses incurred from their auto-theft-related crimes, court records show. </P> <P>More than $165,000 in civil court judgments have been awarded to MPI against two cousins. Other claims against additional family members remain before the courts. <BR></P>

--30--

NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car thief gets three years
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 22 year old man has been given a three-year jail term for the violent carjacking of a woman in Winnipeg's North End last fall.<BR>He pleaded guilty Monday to robbery during an afternoon provincial court hearing.<BR>43 year old Susan Everett was dragged, pummeled and run over by the man, who stole her idling car when she left it unattended in the back lane behind her home on Sept. 4, 2009.</P> <P>After the man jumped into Everett's vehicle and started driving away, the woman reached into the driver's side window and grabbed onto the car's steering wheel to try to stop him.<BR>Despite her pleas to stop, the man sped off. He punched Everett twice in the face as she clung to the car and dragged her about 60 metres before running over her leg when she let go of the wheel and fell into the street.<BR>Everett suffered several scrapes, bruises and abrasions, and has been unable to work in the months since the incident occurred.<BR>The man was given double-time credit for the nine months spent in custody after his arrest, meaning he has 18 months left.
