Title: 23-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Portage woman killed after driving through red: RCMP
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A woman was killed Monday evening when she apparently drove through a red light on the highway just west of Portage la Prairie. </P> <P>The accident occurred at a corner that within a few years will have no traffic lights at all. </P> <P>RCMP said the 41-year-old woman drove her 1998 VW Jetta through a red light at the intersection of the Trans-Canada Highway and Highway 16 about 9 p.m. Monday. Witnesses told police the woman was turning north through the red light when a 2009 Buick Allure proceeded through a green light eastbound and hit her. </P> <P>The woman was killed in the accident. </P> <P>A 48-year-old male passenger was also hurt, as was the driver of the Buick. </P> <P>RCMP did not identify the woman who died but did say she is a resident of Portage la Prairie. </P> <P>In October 2007, the federal and provincial governments announced a $50-million building project to transform the junction from a light-controlled, at-grade intersection to a grade-separated overpass. </P> <P>However, construction on that project is not expected to start in earnest until 2012, with a scheduled completion date of 2014. </P> <P>"When the project was announced, the timelines were stated and it was noted that interchanges and overpasses (involve) a very complicated design process and the project was planned to be constructed in a seven-year timeframe," a spokesman for Manitoba Infrastructure and Transportation said Tuesday. </P> <P>"It is on schedule, at this point in time." </P> <P>Dillon Consulting developed a number of different design options and presented them to the public last year during open-house meetings. </P> <P>The project is currently in the functional design phase. Detailed design and environmental approval will follow, with construction coming thereafter, the spokesman said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 24-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Legislature takedown ; Car-theft suspect nabbed after chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>There was a lot of excitement outside the Manitoba Legislature Tuesday, and it had nothing to do with politics. </P> <P>Around noon Tuesday, police officers tackled a suspect on the front steps of the Legislature following a brief foot chase across the legislature's grounds. </P> <P>The man had been running from police after crashing a stolen Pontiac Sunfire into a flower bed in front of Government House, the residence of Manitoba's lieutenant-governor. </P> <P>"The guy came flying by at about 80 (km/h)," said witness Shawn Ward, who was doing curb repair near Assiniboine Avenue and Kennedy Street at the southeast corner of the Legislature's grounds. </P> <P>Ward said the car drove the wrong way up Kennedy -- a one-way street -- narrowly missed a woman in a wheelchair crossing the street, skipped off his bobcat's bucket and hit a pile of chunks of concrete the crew had broken out of the curb, sending some heavy chunks flying. The car came to a stop in a flower bed. </P> <P>"I should go buy a lottery ticket tonight. Five feet over and I could have been dead," Ward said of the car that zoomed by him. </P> <P>Kerry Coates, manager of Legislative security, said he then saw the man running across the grass on the grounds headed for the building's front entrance. </P> <P>Another witness said he saw police officers tackle the man on the landing at the top of the front stairs. "I bet you he would have made an attempt to come into the building. Wouldn't that have been something?" the witness said. </P> <P>The witness said the man was struggling with police during the takedown "about as much as he could with three cops on him." </P> <P>The witness said he counted 11 police cars in front of the building, including some on the front lawn. </P> <P>Const. Natalie Aitken, a spokeswoman for Winnipeg police, said that just before the crash, the stolen Sunfire was involved in two other minor accidents at the corners of Main Street and St. Mary Avenue, and at Main and Broadway. </P> <P>Aitken said police first spotted the car near Ellice Avenue and Furby Street, where they began following it. From there, they stayed on the suspect's tail until he crashed in front of Government House. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car theft suspect arrested near Legislature
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Tuesday, June 8, 2010 | 5:35 PM CST CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A man who fled from police after ditching a stolen car was arrested just outside the Manitoba Legislature on Tuesday, police said.</P> <P>Shortly after noon, officers on patrol in Winnipeg's West End spotted a stolen vehicle near Ellice Avenue and Furby Street.</P> <P>Police said the officers followed the car for a short time until the driver ditched it near Kennedy Street and Broadway.</P> <P>After a foot chase, the suspect was arrested. Police didn't identify him nor give his age</P> <P>The stolen car was involved in minor collisions with other cars at the intersections of St. Mary's Avenue and Main Street and Broadway and Main, police said.</P> <P>There were no injuries reported.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/08/man-stolen-car-legislature.html#ixzz0qMQngbBa">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/08/man-stolen-car-legislature.html#ixzz0qMQngbBa</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Lucky no one killed ; Boost charges in car chases
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Wed Jun 9 2010   Page: 5 Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Lt.-Gov. Philip Lee had an unexpected lunch guest Tuesday after some moron allegedly stole a vehicle and raced the wrong way up Kennedy Street -- a busy one-way road -- landing on Lee's front lawn. </P> <P>The suspect crashed into the bucket of a small, stationary tractor doing construction work in front of Government House. The stolen Pontiac Sunbird hit a piece of concrete the size of a hefty watermelon, sending it flying through the air at least a dozen meters. That's how fast this idiot was going. </P> <P>He then fled on foot and was dumb enough to think he could evade police by running up the front steps of the Legislature, hoping he could get in the front doors. </P> <P>Even if he did, he would have quickly been tackled by security guards inside the building. </P> <P>But this genius didn't get that far. He was tackled by Winnipeg police officers at the top of the stairs and led away in handcuffs. </P> <P>Just another day at the Manitoba Legislature? </P> <P>Not really. </P> <P>These dangerous car chases -- some of them now in broad daylight -- have gotten completely out of hand. </P> <P>We won't remember this one much in the future because luckily nobody got hurt. </P> <P>Shawn Ward, who was working construction in from of Government House, could have been killed after the Pontiac narrowly missed him as it turned onto Kennedy from Assiniboine Avenue. </P> <P>There was a woman nearby in a wheelchair. And there were the usual number of people on the sidewalk over the noon-hour in a busy part of Winnipeg. </P> <P>By chance, no one was driving southbound on Kennedy at the time and no one happened to be on the sidewalk where the suspect lost control of the vehicle. </P> <P>Hang on to that four-leafed clover. </P> <P>We only remember these car chases when people die or are seriously injured. But seeing first-hand the immediate aftermath of this chase on the grounds of the Legislature was a real eye-opener. </P> <P>How fast does a small car like a Pontiac Sunbird have to be travelling to send a heavy piece of concrete a dozen meters through the air? It's not a big car. </P> <P>This guy was basically driving a weapon through a busy city street. </P> <P>As far as I'm concerned, when you steal a vehicle and drive it recklessly at high speeds through busy city streets teeming with people, you should be charged at the very least with attempted murder. That's if you don't kill someone. </P> <P>If you kill someone, you should be charged -- at a minimum -- with second-degree murder. </P> <P>Because you know, or you ought to know, that driving a vehicle at high speeds through busy streets like this guy did is like standing in the middle of a road and randomly shooting a firearm. </P> <P>Maybe you'll hit someone and maybe you won't. </P> <P>It's not that much different. </P> <P>But somehow I think very little will happen to the driver of this Pontiac Sunbird. If convicted, we'll likely see the usual slap on the wrist from our justice system while people's lives were put at risk. Our justice system doesn't take high-speed vehicle flights seriously even when people are killed. </P> <P>I can only imagine the degree of leniency that will be meted out in a case like this. </P>

--30--

Title: 27-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: No-fault insurance really means less coverage
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Sudbury Star Wed Jun 9 2010   Page: A10 Section: Editorial/Opinion
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Unless you're a lawyer or are familiar with insurance laws you probably don't understand the car insurance coverage you have or need. </P>  <P>This will get worse come Sept. 1, when Ontario's new no-fault benefits laws come into force. </P>  <P>If you are in a car accident you're entitled to make a claim for no-fault benefits. These benefits cover such things as medical/ rehabilitation costs, income loss and caregiver expenses. </P>  <P>As of Sept. 1, these benefits will be restricted and reduced save in cases of catastrophic injury. </P>  <P>The claim for no-fault benefits is made against your insurer, not the insurer of the other vehicle, regardless of who caused the accident. </P>  <P>If you are a pedestrian or cyclist and involved in a car accident but don't have car insurance, the claim for benefits is against the insurer of the car. </P>  <P>You can also sue the other driver or owner for negligence and claim money for such things as pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, future loss of income and additional medical rehab payments not included in the no-fault benefits. But the law doesn't permit such a claim unless your injuries are "serious and permanent". </P>  <P>Worse, an automatic $30,000 is deducted from any award under $100,000. </P>  <P>To qualify as serious and permanent, the harm must be permanent and the injury must substantially interfere with one's ability to continue with their employment, or substantially interfere with most of one's usual daily activities. </P>  <P>That prejudices retirees, children, students and the unemployed, according to personal injury lawyer Adam Wagman. </P>  <P>Since most claims don't involve injuries that are serious and permanent, accident victims are usually left with a claim for only no-fault benefits. </P>  <P>That's why you need to know the precise amount of these benefits so you can decide if you have adequate coverage. </P>  <P>Ontario's insurance regulator, the Financial Services Commission of Ontario, has ordered car insurers to explain the massive changes looming for car owners effective Sept. 1. You'll soon be receiving a document titled Changes to Ontario Auto Insurance Give You More Choice. </P>  <P>What "more choice" means is that your coverage is automatically reduced but you'll have the option of paying more premiums to beef up your no-fault benefits. </P>  <P>According to personal injury lawyer Darcy Merkur, only 3% of car owners have purchased the currently available optional coverage and "it is unrealistic to think that motorists will suddenly understand the need to purchase optional coverage to properly protect themselves in the event of a motor vehicle accident." </P>  <P>But if you don't purchase optional coverage and are in an accident after Sept. 1, you'll have far less benefits than before. </P>  <P>Worse, if you don't own a car and don't have car insurance, you'll have no ability to purchase the optional coverage. </P>  <P>According to Patrick Brown, Past President of the Ontario Trial Lawyers Association, the new law "creates an injustice" for pedestrians, cyclists and public transit users who don't own a car. </P>  <P>He adds, "perhaps the greatest injustice of this new law falls upon children. If a parent doesn't own a car there will be less coverage for their children hurt in a car accident." </P>  <P>Brown argues "if laws are to be changed, why not protect the most vulnerable first? Let's not forget that people who do not drive are consumers as well". </P>  <P>According to Wagman, promises by Ontario's finance minister to modify the law to benefit both consumers and insurers haven't been kept, the new laws are one-sided and many innocent accident victims in need of income protection, medical treatment and rehab will suffer. Yes, but now we have more choice, don't we? </P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 28-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stay Safe This Grad: Make the Right Decision
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Western Canadian, Manitou, Manitoba  Tuesday, June 8, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Grad means different things to different people. But no matter what memories you hold, one sentiment holds true for everyone: it’s the first day of the rest of your life. Don’t ruin it by drinking and driving or letting someone else do the same.</P> <P>Drinking and driving kills. It maims. It affects thousands of people every year.</P> <P>Here in Manitoba, about 30 people are killed every year in alcohol-related collisions, according to Manitoba Public Insurance statistics. And more than half of them are between the ages of 16 and 25.</P> <P>Just as disturbing is the fact that drivers aged 16 - 24 continue to be over-represented in the total number of alcohol-impaired driving convictions. Even though drivers in that same age group represent only 14.1 per cent of licensed drivers in Manitoba, they account for more than double that proportion of all impaired driving convictions at almost 31 per cent.</P> <P>And the statistics don’t tell the whole story. With each person killed in an alcohol-related crash, there are others who are deeply affected. Parents. Siblings. Friends. Co-workers.</P> <P>In its annual appeal to high school students, Manitoba Public Insurance partnered once again this year with MADD Canada to deliver a hard-hitting program on the dangers of impaired driving to students in 65 schools across the province. The multi-media assembly program, Wasted, enables both organizations to deliver an impactful message to a very targeted audience.</P> <P>“With safe grad season nearly upon us, we need to continue to get the message out to the students that driving while impaired has far-reaching consequences and no one is immune to the risk,” says Clif Eden, manager of Road Safety for Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>“We want to help young people understand the dangers while encouraging a commitment to sober driving.”</P> <P>The message is clear: stay safe this grad season. Don’t drink and drive. Don’t let a friend drive while impaired and don’t get into a vehicle with someone who has been drinking.</P> <P>“It’s an important decision that can affect the rest of a person’s life,” says Eden. “We want all Manitobans to work together to make our roads safer.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 29-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Already a fugitive ; Legislature chase suspect violated release terms: cops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 45-year-old Winnipeg man who allegedly led police on a pursuit in a stolen car, which ended on the steps of the Legislature Tuesday, was already a wanted man. </P> <P>The suspect, Blaine George Hanson, was a fugitive because he violated conditions of his statutory release less than a week after he got out of prison earlier this year, city police and Crime Stoppers say. </P> <P>Hanson was granted statutory release, which is automatic to all offenders once they serve two-thirds of a federal sentence, on March 11. </P> <P>He was ordered to live in a halfway house in Winnipeg while he completed the remainder of a three-year, three-month sentence for obstruction of justice, possession of goods obtained by crime and other offences. </P> <P>Four days later, Hanson walked away from the halfway house and didn't return, resulting in the warrant being issued March 15. </P> <P>His name and photo were included in the Winnipeg Sun's monthly Crime Stoppers wanted column in late March but police didn't catch up with him until Tuesday. </P> <P>The pursuit began when police spotted the stolen Pontiac Sunfire near Ellice Avenue and Furby Street about noon. </P> <P>Police said the male driver refused to pull over and fled. </P> <P>Minor collisions </P> <P>The car was involved in two minor collisions near St. Mary Avenue and Main Street and Broadway and Main Street. No one was injured but the vehicles sustained about $7,500 in damage, police said. </P> <P>Witnesses said the car drove into a flower bed in front of Government House, the residence of Manitoba's lieutenant-governor, on Kennedy Street and was abandoned by the male, who took off on foot. </P> <P>Witness Shawn Ward, who was repairing a curb, said the car was travelling about 80 km/h the wrong way on Kennedy, a one-way street. </P> <P>The car narrowly missed a woman in a wheelchair, skipped off the bucket of a skid-steer loader, and hit a pile of concrete broken off the curb before it was dumped. </P> <P>Police tackled and arrested the male on the Legislature's front steps following a brief foot chase across the grounds, witnesses said. </P> <P>Hanson is charged with flight from police, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle, driving without a licence, possession of property obtained by crime and three counts of failing to remain at the scene of an accident and exchange particulars, police said Wednesday. </P> <P>He was wanted on warrants for revocation of statutory release and possession of property obtained by crime, police said. </P> <P>Hanson is in custody at the Winnipeg Remand Centre. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorcycles and noise
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Thu Jun 10 2010 Page: A15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I am thrilled that the city is considering passing a bylaw and purchasing test equipment to target and objectively measure overly loud motorcycles. When the bylaw is passed, I will donate $100 toward the cost of the equipment. I am sure there are others who would join me. I am a former motorcycle-shop employee, and the former owner and avid rider of six motorcycles, including a Harley. Motorcycles have enhanced my quality of life. But aggressively loud bikes, throttle-blipped without consideration for others' feelings, diminish it. </P> <P>DAN TORBIAK <BR>Winnipeg </P> <P>Why do I get the feeling the city and province just don't want motorcycles on the roads. With the outrageous fees MPI charges, now this. How can they target one group? There are cars and trucks with louder exhausts. Maybe they should ban lawn mowers, snow blowers, snowmobiles, trains, airplanes and the heavy equipment that works on the street. Maybe they should also ban outdoor concerts and tell the Bomber fans they can only cheer to a certain decibel. Maybe we should all start living like the Amish, back to the horse and buggy. </P> <P>JIM ZAGOZEWSKI <BR>Riverton <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 31-Mar-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Victim's mom wants driver to lecture on dangers of speeding
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Thu Jun 10 2010   Page: B3
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 22-year-old man may not go jail for driving a speeding Chevy Cobalt that crashed and killed his friend. </P> <P>If the victim's mother gets her way, Ashten Milne will end up lecturing high school students on the dangers of speeding. </P> <P>Milne was in court Wednesday. A car he was driving flipped on PR 227 in the RM of Woodlands and killed his friend Nolan Kunz, 21, in June 2008. </P> <P>Milne and another friend initially told police Kunz was the driver, but police investigated and Milne was charged with dangerous driving causing death. </P> <P>He pleaded guilty last November to the charge. Police determined the car was going over 160 km/h when it crashed. </P> <P>"It was beyond stupid, it was criminal," Crown attorney Joyce Dalmyn told the court. </P> <P>Kunz's widowed mother wasn't in court, but Dalmyn said the woman "felt sorry" for Milne. </P> <P>Dalmyn and defence lawyer Sarah Inness submitted a joint recommendation to Judge Robin Finlayson for no jail time for Milne. If accepted, Milne would receive three years' supervised probation, a nightly curfew, a drug and alcohol ban and a driving prohibition. </P> <P>Finlayson reserved the sentencing decision. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Victim's mom intercedes ; Dangerous driver caused death
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg man responsible for killing his friend in a high-speed car crash should not go to jail, says the dead man's mother. </P> <P>Ashten Milne was in court Wednesday to be sentenced for a June 15, 2008 crash that killed 21-year-old Nolan Ryan Kunz. </P> <P>"He has to pay for what he did, but jail doesn't do any good," Crown attorney Joyce Dalmyn quoted Tamy Kunz as saying. "What happened wasn't intentional. It wasn't what Ashten wanted to happen. It was stupid." </P> <P>Milne, 22, pleaded guilty to dangerous driving causing death in exchange for a joint Crown and defence recommendation he be sentenced to three years supervised probation. </P> <P>Dalmyn said inconsistent statements by a second passenger in the vehicle who claimed at one time Kunz was behind the wheel weakened the Crown's case against Milne. </P> <P>Dalmyn said Tammy Kunz believes her son's killer should remain free in the community where he can speak to students about the dangers of reckless driving. </P> <P>Judge Rob Finlayson adjourned sentencing for at least three months, saying he needed more evidence to show Milne won't be a danger to the community. </P> <P>Medium risk </P> <P>According to a pre-sentence report, Milne has been assessed as a medium risk to re-offend due to alcohol abuse, a history of anti-social behaviour and other factors. He has refused all offers of counselling and continues to drive even though he doesn't have a licence. </P> <P>"Normally, people like you with no record are assessed as a low risk," Finlayson said. "It's on your shoulders now. You may be hesitant to reach out for help, but now is the time to do it." </P> <P>Court heard Milne, Kunz and a third man had been at a wedding social in Warren and left in Milne's 2005 Chevy Cobalt sometime before 2 a.m. </P> <P>Police estimate Milne was driving at least 160 km/h when he lost control of the vehicle and crashed on PTH 227. A picture taken on Kunz' cellphone showed an odometer reading of 220 km/h. </P> <P>Paramedics found Kunz in a ditch, 30 metres from where the vehicle came to rest. </P> <P>The wedding social bride-to-be, a nurse, drove by the scene before paramedics and stopped to administer CPR. </P> <P>Alcohol was not a factor in the crash, Dalmyn said. </P> <P>"(Milne) was driving at a ridiculous speed," she said. "It was a young man showing off, showing how fast his car could go." <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 2-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Thu Jun 10 2010   Page: 17 Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Cyclist killed by truck in The Pas </P> <P>A cyclist was wearing headphones when he was struck and killed by a cement truck in The Pas on Monday afternoon, RCMP say. </P> <P>It's believed the headphones may have caused a distraction. </P> <P>The man's name wasn't released. </P> <P>RCMP said the crash occurred at Fischer Avenue and Third Street in the shortly before 12:30 p.m. </P> <P>Witnesses told police the 36-year-old male cyclist was going through the intersection when he was hit by a cement truck, which was travelling through a green light, RCMP said. </P> <P>Girl's condition upgraded </P> <P>An 11-year-old girl struck by a car in Southdale on Tuesday has been upgraded to stable from critical con-dition in hospital, Winnipeg police say. </P> <P>The collision occurred on Shamrock Drive, between Beaverhill Boulevard and Cliffwood Drive, about 5:52 p.m. Police said the girl was crossing the street when she was struck by a west-bound car driven by a 30-year-old man. </P> <P>No charges are pending, police said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 3-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Judge balks at sentence for killer driver
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Wednesday, June 9, 2010 | 5:08 PM CST
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Manitoba judge has refused to endorse a recommendation that a 22-year-old man be given a suspended sentence and probation for killing his best friend in a high-speed vehicle rollover.</P> <P>Ashten Milne appeared in a Winnipeg courtroom on Wednesday expecting Judge Rob Finlayson to approve a joint recommendation between his lawyer and the Crown that he serve three years of supervised probation after pleading guilty to dangerous driving causing the death of a young Pine Falls man.</P> <P>Nolan Kunz, 21, was killed on the morning of June 15, 2008 after being thrown out of a speeding Chevy Colbalt that careened out of control and rolled into the ditch along Provincial Road 227 not far from Pine Falls.</P> <P>Just minutes before the incident, Kunz, Milne and another man were at a social at a nearby town, court heard. </P> <P>However, police found that alcohol was not a major contributing factor in the fatal rollover.</P> <P>RCMP investigating the incident determined that at the time the car left the road it was travelling between 161-173 km/h.</P> <P>Milne wasn't charged until nearly a year after the rollover, when police obtained enough evidence to support charges against him.</P> <P>Police initially were told that Kunz was driving, but in the months after the crash, it became apparent through interviewing witnesses and Milne's friends that he was behind the wheel.</P> <P>'Frequent liar'<BR>"He lied to get himself off the hook," Crown attorney Joyce Dalman told court Wednesday.</P> <P>She also described Milne as "a frequent liar."</P> <P>However, problems with the case prompted Dalman and lawyer Sarah Innes to reach a deal where Milne would plead guilty in exchange for a suspended sentence.</P> <P>Finlayson balked at the deal, saying he was troubled by a pre-sentencing report showing that Milne poses a risk to become reinvolved with the criminal justice system.</P> <P>Finlayson withheld his verdict for three months so another report can be done into Milne's efforts to get a job, obtain counselling and seek other help for addictions issues.</P> <P>"Mr. Milne, it's on your shoulders now," he said.</P> <P>Under the terms of the proposed probationary sentence, Milne would be bound by a nightly curfew, have to perform hours of community service and abstain from drugs and alcohol completely for three years.</P> <P>He would also have to complete any counselling that his probation officer orders him to take.</P> <P>A two-year driving prohibition is also being sought.</P> <P>Victim's mom doesn't want jail time<BR>Kunz's mother did not appear in court for the hearing because "she can't bear to be here," Dalman said.</P> <P>Despite her anguish at losing her son, she doesn't want Milne to go to jail, Dalman added.</P> <P>"He has to pay for what he did, but jail doesn't do any good," Dalman said the mother told her.</P> <P>She told the prosecutor that she'd be happy to see Milne be forced to go and speak to high school students about what he did.</P> <P>Kunz was described in court as a winter sports fanatic who made efforts to rally the interests of youth in the community toward snowboarding.</P> <P>Milne declined to comment when asked by Finlayson if he had anything to say.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/09/man-milne-dangerous-driving.html#ixzz0qSDhm9FS">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/09/man-milne-dangerous-driving.html#ixzz0qSDhm9FS</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: NDP government not living up rural Manitoba’s expectations
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Letter to the Editor</P> <P>Manitoba families are experiencing firsthand the effects of NDP waste and mismanagement. After wasting $14 million on an enhanced driver’s licence that few Manitobans wanted, the NDP government cut services, including the reduction of driver’s licence testing in dozens of communities across the province.</P> <P>The decision to reduce driver’s licence testing in dozens of communities across the province has left hundreds of Manitobans without a viable option for obtaining a driver’s license.</P> <P>Folks are now being forced to drive hundreds of extra kilometers at their own cost, just to take a written or road test. To make matters worse, the NDP government is running advertisements in rural newspapers claiming they are increasing services - a statement that is blatantly false.</P> <P>The truth is that driving services have been cut across Manitoba while the NDP government wastes millions of dollars on enhanced ID cards nobody wants.</P> <P>The truth is that the NDP continues to treat rural Manitobans like second-class citizens.</P> <P>Despite the NDP’s total disregard for rural Manitobans, Progressive Conservatives will continue to fight on your behalf. We will continue to raise this issue in the legislature over the coming weeks and months to ensure your voices are heard.</P> <P>Mavis Taillieu,PC MLA for Morris<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI enjoys a bumper year for profits
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE province's auto insurer saw a big improvement in its bottom line last year. </P> <P>For the year ended Feb. 28, Manitoba Public Insurance made a profit of $86.9 million after suffering a loss of $6.5 million the previous year, MPI announced in its annual report Thursday. </P> <P>MPI said its overall claims costs increased by $13.1 million -- a rise of less than two per cent -- to $736.5 million. The cost of injury claims last year increased by $8.9 million or 4.3 per cent compared with the previous year.</P>

--30--

Title: 6-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Clarification on the Selkirk MPI Service Centre
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A recent article published in The Journal, regarding MPI’s new service centre, unfortunately contained a number of statements which need clarification.</P> <P>Written in the subhead and within the article, the writer stated “vehicle repairs”. This would leave Journal readers with the very real impression that this service centre will carry out vehicle repairs. This is not accurate. In fact, vehicles will be brought to the service centre to have the damages estimated by one of our staff , with the customer then going to the auto body shop of their choosing for repairs.</P> <P>The article also inaccurately stated “drivers can meet with insurance agents” at the new service centre. The new Selkirk service centre will not have insurance agents on the premises; which is consistent with all MPI service centres. Selkirk and area residents are serviced by a number of Autopac Agents, who work in partnership with Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>Selkirk and area residents are encouraged to continue visiting their local Autopac Agent who will be more than happy to discuss all their auto insurance needs, in addition to assisting the customer with all their driver licencing needs.</P> <P>Brian Smiley<BR>Manitoba Public Insurance<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cement truck rolls, driver hospitalized
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One person was reportedly sent to hospital after a cement truck rolled onto its side on the southbound Perimeter Highway near Wilkes Avenue Thursday about 1:30 p.m. </P> <P>Traffic on the southbound Perimeter Highway was limited to one lane over the Wilkes Avenue overpass as towing crews worked to right the large truck that laid on its driver side on the shoulder of the road. </P> <P>The vehicle's driver was taken to hospital while a second person from the truck sustained minor injuries. </P> <P>The extent of the driver's injuries was not known. </P> <P>Diesel fuel spills </P> <P>The Winnipeg Fire Department's Hazardous Material Response Unit was called to the scene as diesel fuel spilled onto the roadway. </P> <P>The RCMP's Headingley traffic unit kept the south Perimeter Highway turn-off onto Wilkes Avenue closed for several hours. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Alleged car thief caught red-handed
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police swooped in and nabbed an alleged car thief early this morning, before the car was even started. </P> <P>At about 6 a.m. Thursday, an area resident called to report that a man was trying to break into a vehicle in a south-end trailer park. </P> <P>When officers arrived, they found the suspect inside a white 2002 Chrysler, apparently while he was attempting to start the car. </P> <P>A 27-year-old Brandon man is to be released with a court date later this morning, on charges of attempted vehicle theft and mischief to property. </P>

--30--

Title: 10-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI applies to issue rebates, cut premiums
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Sat Jun 12 2010   Section: Regional
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- Manitoba Public Insurance is flush with cash and says it's time to give some of it back to drivers. </P> <P>More than 700,000 vehicle owners will see a rebate cheque of $115 early next year, if the public regulator approves. </P> <P>MPI detailed the rebate on Friday after it submitted its 2010-11 rate application to the Public Utilities Board. </P> <P>About two-thirds of Manitoba drivers will also receive a reduction in premiums next year, most for less than $50. </P> <P>CEO Marilyn McLaren said MPI collected $92 million more than it needed last year as good weather and fewer stolen vehicles meant fewer costly claims. </P> <P>McLaren also said MPI's rate stabilization fund sits at $240 million. Even though MPI will draw down $92 million, the fund will remain at a comfortable level. </P> <P>"There's no business need for us to hang onto more than the maximum," she said. "Manitobans get some of the money back that they paid in that year because we simply didn't need it all to pay claims." </P> <P>Driving that surplus are several factors, she said. </P> <P>There were fewer crashes and therefore fewer damage and injury claims paid out, thanks to a short and milder winter. Plus, auto theft is down 75 per cent from its peak in 2004-06. </P> <P>"You've got maybe 2,500 to 3,000 thefts a year compared with 10,000 during that time," she said. "The claims costs are down an equivalent amount." </P> <P>Also, the stock and investment markets have rebounded, which helps MPI's bottom line, she said. </P> <P>McLaren also said the proposed rebate is also due to the PUB's decision last year that reined in MPI's new driver safety rating program, which when fully in place will see good drivers pay less in insurance and poor drivers pay more. </P> <P>PUB said it wanted MPI to move slowly because it was unsure how the change in assessing premiums would affect MPI's financial bottom line. </P> <P>Next year's proposed rate application calls for 650,948 Manitoba drivers to pay less for basic compulsory coverage while 106,434 will pay the same amount. About 206,630 will pay more. Most increases and decreases will be less than $50. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba Crown auto insurer drives to profitable year after suffering loss
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Canadian Press Fri Jun 11 2010   Section: Business
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ There has been a big improvement in the bottom line of Manitoba's Crown auto insurer. </P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance says it made a profit of $86.9 million for the year ending Feb. 28 after suffering a loss of $6.5 million the previous year. </P> <P>MPI says overall claims costs rose less than two per cent to just over $736 million. </P> <P>The company also says the cost of injury claims last year increased by $8.9 million, or 4.3 per cent, compared with the previous year. </P> <P>The cost of vehicle damage claims fell by just $300,000 from the previous year. </P> <P>The figures are contained in the company's annual report, released Thursday by the provincial government.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Rebate from MPI? ; Hopes to cut rates by 4%, but many will pay more
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Most Manitobans will pay a little less for vehicle insurance next year, though a fancy trailer could mean hauling around a hefty premium cost. </P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance is applying to the provincial Public Utilities Board to drop premium rates by an average of 4% in 2011-12, and to provide an average $115 rebate per vehicle to its customers. </P> <P>MPI president Marilyn McLaren said Friday that the reasons for the proposed overall rate cuts and/or rebates include the past mild and short winter that helped ease up on weather-related claims costs, the Crown corporation's well-funded rate stabilization reserve, and recently strong income of $96.3 million on the insurer's investments. </P> <P>"If we have more than we need for rate stability purposes in the savings account, so to speak, we apply for rebates," McLaren told reporters, adding service efficiencies, a continuing drop in vehicle thefts and a projected cut in claims costs in 2011 are helping MPI lessen the financial burden for its customers. </P> <P>"Injury claims are costing a little bit less than we thought they would." </P> <P>If the application made on Friday is approved, however, not all drivers will get the financial break. </P> <P>Trailer, moped rate hike </P> <P>About 11% of MPI customers will pay the same rates that they are currently, while 21% -- approximately one in five vehicle owners -- will pay more. </P> <P>Among the vehicles costing more to insure, motorcycles will see an overall 1% rate increase and trailers will be walloped with an average 9.8% hike. </P> <P>Though most utility trailers and those used for boats, snowmobiles and the like will be spared much of a rate hike, owners of camper trailers -- particularly higher-end models -- will be generally hit hard, some with increases well above the 9.8% average. </P> <P>That, said McLaren, is largely because of Manitoba's hail storms in the past few years. </P> <P>"Those travel trailers are badly damaged by hail," she said. "That costs a lot, so we need to raise the rates so we can cover the costs of those losses for people." </P> <P>Not all motorcyclists are being whacked in their wallets. McLaren pointed out that about 4,200 motorcycle owners -- most of them living in Winnipeg -- will receive a premium decrease of between 1% and 5%. </P> <P>But the motorcycle category includes what McLaren calls "mopeds," some of which will be hit with a 25% rate increase. </P>

--30--

Title: 13-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Fewer crashes help drive MPI rebates
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Sat Jun 12 2010   Page: A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance is flush with cash and says it's time to give some of it back to drivers. </P> <P>More than 700,000 vehicle owners will see a rebate cheque of $115 early next year, if the public regulator approves. MPI detailed the rebate on Friday after it submitted its 2010-11 rate application with the Public Utilities Board. </P> <P>About two-thirds of Manitoba drivers will also receive a reduction in premiums next year, most for less than $50. </P> <P>CEO Marilyn McLaren said MPI collected $92 million more than it needed last year as good weather and fewer stolen vehicles meant fewer costly claims. </P> <P>McLaren also said MPI's rate stabilization fund sits at $240 million. Even though MPI will draw-down $92 million, the fund will remain at a comfortable level. </P> <P>"There's no business need for us to hang onto more than the maximum," she said. "Manitobans get some of the money back that they paid in that year because we simply didn't need it all to pay claims." </P> <P>Driving that surplus are several factors, she said. </P> <P>There were fewer crashes and therefore fewer damage and injury claims paid out, thanks to a short and milder winter. Plus, auto theft is down 75 per cent from its peak in 2004-2006. </P> <P>"You've got maybe 2,500 to 3,000 thefts a year compared with 10,000 during that time," she said. "The claims costs are down an equivalent amount." </P> <P>Also, the stock and investment markets have rebounded, which helps MPI's bottom line, she said. </P> <P>Progressive Conservative MPI critic Mavis Taillieu said Friday she was leery that MPI wants to send out rebate cheques in a provincial election year. The next election is Oct. 4, 2011. </P> <P>Taillieu also said MPI is not completely open about its financial health as the PUB has had to go to the Manitoba Court of Appeal to rule on whether it can require MPI to disclose overall revenues and costs. </P> <P>MPI only wants to provide costs and revenues relating to basic Autopac insurance while the PUB wants everything -- including services in which MPI competes with the private sector. </P> <P>The Tories have accused the Selinger government of wasting tax dollars by allowing the court battle to drag on instead of ordering MPI to be accountable. </P> <P>Andrew Swan, the minister responsible for MPI, defended the insurer's refusal to disclose information because it would compromise its competitive position. </P> <P>McLaren said the proposed rebate is also due to the PUB's decision last year that reined in MPI's new Driver Safety Rating program, which when fully in place will see good drivers pay less in insurance and poor drivers pay more. </P> <P>PUB said it wanted MPI to move slowly because it was unsure how the change in assessing premiums would affect MPI's financial bottom line. </P> <P>McLaren said part of the rebate is money that would have gone to premium discounts last year had the PUB not intervened. Next year's proposed rate application calls for 650,948 Manitoba drivers to pay less for basic compulsory coverage while 106,434 will pay the same amount. About 206,630 will pay more. Most increases and decreases will be less than $50. </P> <P>She also said it's tough to predict if there will be another rebate in 2012. </P> <P>"If we have more than we need for rate-stability purposes in the savings account... we apply for rebates," she said. </P> <P><A href="mailto:bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca">bruce.owen@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>It all rides on numbers </P> <P>Driver Safety Rating is MPI's way to reward good drivers and make bad drivers pay more. </P> <P>Drivers who've haven't had an at-fault crash in 15 years or longer got a 25 per cent discount when DSR was introduced last March. Next year, the discount goes up to 30 per cent. </P> <P>People who have 11, 12, 13 or 14 merits will see discounts rise respectively to 26 per cent, 27 per cent, 28 per cent and 29 per cent from 25 per cent. </P> <P>If the rate application is approved: </P> <P>63 per cent of Manitobans getting rate decreases will see premiums drop by $50 or less </P> <P>37 per cent getting rate decreases will see premiums drop by more than $50 </P> <P>premiums will stay unchanged for about 11 per cent of drivers </P> <P>premiums will go up for about 21 per cent of drivers with most seeing a hike of less than $20 </P> <P>For rides on two wheels: </P> <P>MPI wants a 1.02 per cent overall increase for motorcycle rates. If approved, the average premium will be $1,078. However, 4,235 motorcycle owners, most of them registered in Winnipeg, will see a rate decrease. Motorcyclists in rural southern Manitoba will see an increase because, as a group, they have more serious injuries. Moped owners will also see premiums go up to reflect the cost of claims paid out by MPI. There are about 10,000 registered motorcycles/mopeds in Manitoba. </P> <P>Campers and motorhomes: </P> <P>MPI says summer hailstorms have resulted in big claims. It's asking for a 9. 8 per cent increase for trailers and motorhomes because of those rising costs. </P> <P>Claims costs in 2009-10: </P> <P>MPI saw a total of 269,135 claims at a cost of $628.4 million. The value of the average claim dropped $101 to $2,335. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car's high-speed flight ends in crash with semi
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Instead of pulling over for RCMP on Friday night, a young man allegedly turned a car into a missile while "flying" down a highway east of Winnipeg. </P> <P>Though his flight from the Mounties on the Trans-Canada Highway ended with a crash into a semi-trailer truck, cops say it's fortunate that no one was killed. </P> <P>"This guy was travelling at a high rate of speed," Const. Jason Michalyshen, spokesman for Winnipeg police, said Saturday of the 1990 BMW's westbound drive into the city at about 11:15 p.m., where the limit is mostly 90 km/h. </P> <P>'EXTENSIVE DAMAGE' </P> <P>"Let's just say it looks like maybe more than double the speed limit," he added of the suspect. "He was flying." </P> <P>The 21-year-old Winnipeg resident -- the BMW's lone occupant -- continued down the Trans-Canada and Fermor Avenue with an RCMP cruiser behind him until he lost control of the car at the intersection with Lagimodiere Boulevard. </P> <P>That's where the big rig was in his way, as the car began to turn north. </P> <P>"He was unable to make a turn as he approached Lagimodiere," Michalyshen said of the crash, in which the BMW struck the trailer. </P> <P>"His vehicle sustained extensive damage, and he was conveyed to hospital in stable condition." </P> <P>The driver and a passenger in the semi-trailer were apparently not injured. </P> <P>It's lucky, said Michalyshen, that the car didn't hit other vehicles "or kill anyone" on its route into Winnipeg. The car's driver is facing a charge of dangerous operation of a vehicle -- a criminal offence. His name was not made public, pending a court appearance slated for late August. </P> <P>The car was not stolen. </P> <P>"It does not appear that there were any signs of this individual drinking," Michalyshen pointed out. </P> <P>"But he's facing a Criminal Code charge, as opposed to a Highway Traffic Act charge. ... When you start getting into those kinds of speeds..." </P> <P>NO CHASE </P> <P>The charge was handled by city cops, despite the car having been followed by RCMP before the crash. </P> <P>As with most such collisions, city police and Mounties stressed that no actual chase occurred. </P> <P>"Our guys picked him up speeding just as he was coming into town," said RCMP Const. Miles Hiebert. </P> <P>"He pulled into the city before they could stop him, so they were just following him." </P> <P>Michalyshen said RCMP simply kept watch from behind, adding that "there's no indication that they were pursuing the vehicle." <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Wearing helmet is 'last line of defence' for cyclists
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun Sun Jun 13 2010   Section: Local
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>On his bike seven days a week for fun, for fitness and for commuting, Aaron Check always wears a bicycle helmet. </P> <P>As an employee at A&L get active, Check has seen what happens to bicycle helmets in accidents. </P> <P>"We see helmets that are cracked in half because a cyclist or a driver did something wrong. The head went through the windshield or hit the pavement and the helmet cracks, as it's supposed to, but the cyclists are walking away," he said. </P> <P>It is not a myth that helmets work. </P> <P>Dr. Lynne Warda, the medical director of IMPACT, the Winnipeg Health Region's Injury Prevention Program, stated in a recent press release that "bicycle helmets reduce the risk of head injury by up to 85 per cent, and the risk of brain injury by up to 88 per cent." </P> <P>Despite the safety record of helmets, Check said that it is one of those items that many consumers really need to be persuaded to purchase. </P> <P>"A lot of adults just disregard them because of the way helmets look. As someone who rides in town all the time, I know when you're in traffic, you're easily in someone's blind spot. The helmet is the last line of defence between you and the pavement or a vehicle." </P> <P>Another proponent of wearing a helmet is Andre Dagenais, another bicycle aficionado. </P> <P>She has cycled in at least four Canadian provinces, the United States and in France. </P> <P>It is only lately that she has started wearing a helmet. </P> <P>"In Europe, people are starting to wear helmets, but what I've noticed is that roads there are more secure than ours because riding a bike is in the culture. Drivers know what to look for and if you take a country like the Netherlands, they have a spectacular network of bike paths. The paths here are mainly for leisure as opposed to accommodating a mode of transportation," said Dagenais, who not only uses a bike to get around town, but also cycles 15 kilometres two to four times per week. </P> <P>"Personally, I sometimes use the helmet for its purpose, which is protecting the head, but sometimes it's just to keep my hair down. Also, all my friends tell me to wear my helmet because they've witnessed so many head injuries. So it's really important." </P> <P>She added that though cyclists may wear a helmet, it does not give them licence to ride their bike less safely. </P> <P>"As soon as we provide an aid for people, like a helmet, then they aren't as careful because they rely on that aid," she said. "It's like winter tires on a car. Just because I have winter tires doesn't mean I don't have to worry about my speed, like the winter tires are supposed to do the job for me. Regardless, you need to drive carefully." </P> <P>Though it is not mandated by law, Check said that it is only common sense to wear a helmet while cycling. </P> <P>"A lot of people tend to think: 'I'm just going for a spin around the block. I don't want to mess up my hair. It's not worth it.' For me, it seems the most logical course of action," he said. "When people (who wear helmets) get tagged by a car, they're walking away instead of being taken away in a stretcher." </P> <P>The choices of helmets now are wide ranging, not only in colour and fit, but also in style. </P> <P>"They're so easy to wear," Check said. "Looking a certain way is one thing, but not being to live to enjoy riding because you're injured in an accident is foolish." </P> <P>Sidebar: </P> <P>When worn properly, a helmet can protect you from a head injury if you are in a bike crash or a fall. </P> <P>Here are some guidelines for proper fit. </P> <P>* When fitting a helmet, there should be two fingers between your helmet and eyebrow. </P> <P>* The straps should form a V shape around your ears. </P> <P>* Tighten the chin strap until only one finger fits between your chin and the strap. </P>

--30--

Title: 16-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: TRAFFIC ACCIDENT INJURES 4
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun Sun Jun 13 2010   Page: 17 Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Four people were injured in a traffic accident Friday about 11 p.m. at the intersection of Bishop Grandin and Lakewood boulevards in Southdale. </P> <P>All four victims -- two in both the Chrysler Sebring and Mitsubishi Lancer -- were taken to hospital in stable condition, said police Const. Jason Michalyshen. </P> <P>One of the drivers was trying to turn north onto Lakewood from eastbound Bishop Grandin amid street construction equipment and barriers, when the vehicle struck the other that was heading west. </P> <P>Michalyshen said "there might have been some construction equipment that obstructed the view a bit," leading to the crash.</P>

--30--

Title: 17-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police vehicles hit, teens arrested
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press Mon Jun 14 2010 Page: A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>TWO 15-year-old boys were arrested following a high-speed chase involving a stolen vehicle early Saturday evening. </P> <P>Winnipeg's stolen auto unit followed a suspected stolen Chevy Malibu on Gilbert and Tyndall Avenue around 9 p.m. Additional officers were called in to pull over the Malibu, but the vehicle sped away at a high speed. </P> <P>"When officers tried to safely pull over the vehicle for a traffic stop they sped away," said Jason Michalyshen, WPS Public Information Officer. "They were going 90 km/h in a 50 km/h zone." </P> <P>When police tried to stop the vehicle, the driver drove into the path of a police car and lost control, striking a hydro pole near Ellice and Garfield. </P> <P>One occupant was arrested on the scene, and another who attempted to flee was arrested shortly after. </P> <P>Michalyshen said there was damage to an unmarked police car, a police cruiser and the stolen vehicle. Police also found a container of bear spray in the stolen car. </P> <P>One 15-year-old has been charged with theft under $5,000, possession of a weapon for dangerous purpose, dangerous driving, flight from police, and driving without a licence. He was detained in custody. </P> <P>A second 15-year-old is facing charges of theft under $5,000 and possession of a weapon for a dangerous purpose. He was released on a promise to appear.</P>

--30--

Title: 18-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen car hits pole ; High-speed chase ends when teen driver spins out
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two teens have been charged after a stolen car, being pursued at high speeds by Winnipeg police, slammed into a hydro pole in the West End Saturday. </P> <P>About 9 p.m. Saturday, members of the Winnipeg Police Service Stolen Auto Unit spotted the 1999 Chevrolet Malibu in the Gilbert Park neighbourhood and followed the vehicle south, calling in other police units. </P> <P>WEST END </P> <P>Police attempted to stop the vehicle, but the occupants fled at a high rate of speed. Police pursued the vehicle into the West End and again attempted to stop the stolen car. The chase ended when the vehicle veered into the path of a police cruiser and struck a pole near Ellice Avenue and Garfield Street. </P> <P>One suspect was apprehended at the crash scene while another fled on foot but was arrested nearby. Police also seized a can of bear spray from the stolen vehicle. </P> <P>Police said both suspects are known to police but that neither had previous charges for auto theft. </P> <P>No one was injured in the incident but police said the car hit speeds of up to 90 km/h as it was driven through residential areas. </P> <P>Neighbours said they heard a car travelling at a high rate of speed down a back lane before hearing it slam into the pole. They said numerous police cruisers and unmarked vehicles were in pursuit. </P> <P>"It was a matter of seconds," said Garfield Street resident Amber Mang. </P> <P>Mang said the Malibu sustained serious rear end damage as it appeared to have spun and collided backwards with the pole. She said one unmarked police truck sustained minor damage. </P> <P>Describing the suspects as "skinny little guys," Mang said she saw both taken into custody. </P> <P>"When they did catch them it was a struggle to get them in," Mang said. "There were two cops fighting each of them to the ground." </P> <P>Mang said she had been planning to leave for an errand in her car moments before the incident but was delayed due to a child's temper tantrum. </P> <P>"I'm kind of glad we stayed home," she said. "We might have been involved in that." </P> <P>Winnipeg Police Service public information officer Const. Jason Michalyshen said the Stolen Auto Unit had been patrolling the Gilbert Park area due to the fact there had been recent vehicle thefts in the area. He said the vehicle was stolen in the West End before it was spotted in Gilbert Park. </P> <P>15-YEAR-OLDS CHARGED </P> <P>A 15-year-old male has been charged with theft under $5,000, possession of a weapon for a dangerous purpose, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle, flight from police and driving without a licence. He has been detained in police custody. </P> <P>A second male, also 15, charged with theft under $5,000 and possession of a weapon for a dangerous purpose. He has been released on a promise to appear. </P> <P>This is the second time in two days a vehicle crashed after being pursued by police. </P> <P>On Friday, a 21-year-old male fled when RCMP attempted to stop him on the Trans-Canada Highway east of Winnipeg. Reaching speeds of double the speed limit, the driver slammed his 1990 BMW into a semi-trailer truck near Lagimodiere Boulevard and Fermor Avenue. The 21-year-old was not seriously injured and nor were occupants of the semi-trailer. The BMW's driver is facing Criminal Code offences including dangerous operation of a vehicle. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen-vehicle crashes raise safety concern
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Sunday, June 13, 2010 | 2:24 PM CST CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two collisions involving stolen vehicles Saturday evening have Winnipeg police concerned about dangerous driving by thieves.</P> <P>"It's one thing when a stolen vehicle is stolen, but it's a completely different thing when stolen vehicles are being operated in an unsafe manner," said Const. Jason Michalyshen. "That puts everybody's safety at risk."</P> <P>The first collision happened just before 9 p.m. on Higgins Avenue under the Slaw Rebchuk Bridge.</P> <P>Police said a stolen car rammed into the back of a minivan, causing fuel from the van to spill onto the road. Higgins was closed while a hazardous-materials team cleaned up the wreckage and fuel.</P> <P>The street has since reopened.</P> <P>The male behind the wheel of the stolen car suffered injuries and was treated in hospital. His name has not been disclosed, but he was arrested and is still in police custody.</P> <P>At about 9:30 p.m. another crash, in which a police cruiser collided with a stolen car, was reported.</P> <P>Plainclothes police in the city's west end had been pursuing a suspected stolen vehicle. A marked cruiser took over the chase and a short time later the cruiser and suspect car collided near Ellice Avenue and Garfield Street.</P> <P>No one was hurt in that incident. Two 15-year-old boys were arrested.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/13/mb-stolen-collisions-risks.html#ixzz0qpjcZ1Tu">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/13/mb-stolen-collisions-risks.html#ixzz0qpjcZ1Tu</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car flips on Lagimodiere near North Perimeter; 2 sent to hospital
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two males have been sent to hospital after their vehicle flipped over into the ditch near the Perimeter at Highway 59 Sunday evening.</P> <P>A caller to CJOB earlier reported seeing an overturned 2009 Chevy Cavalier in the ditch on southbound Hwy 59 near the cloverleaf shortly before 9 pm Sunday.</P> <P>RCMP Constable Miles Hiebert tells CJOB what happened...</P> <P>Road conditions in the area were normal, but Constable Hiebert says speed might be a factor in the rollover.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 21-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Wpg. Police Involved In High Speed Chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Winnipeg Police were involved in a high speed chase last night involving yet another stolen vehicle.<BR>Around 9 o'clock, officers spotted a Chevy Malibu believed to be stolen vehicle near Gilbert Avenue and Tyndall Avenue.<BR>When they tried to pull it over, the vehicle sped off with police in pursuit.<BR>Police say during the pursuit the car veered into the path of a police cruiser and then crashed into a hydro pole in the near of Ellice Avenue and Garfield Street.<BR>There were no injuries but police have arrested two 15 year old males in connection with the incident.

--30--

Title: 22-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man must repay proceeds of MPI fraud, plus fine, for $19K
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg man has been fined $3,000 and ordered to pay Manitoba Public Insurance $16,000 in restitution after he insured a car knowing it would be "stolen" and trashed just days later. </P> <P>Gerald Pierce, 21, pleaded guilty last week to one count of fraud over $5,000. </P> <P>Court heard Pierce insured the 1999 Chevrolet Suburban in August 2008 and produced a bill of sale for $17,500. Eight days later he reported the vehicle stolen from the rear of his Winnipeg residence. </P> <P>Police found the vehicle a day later near the intersection of Dawson Road and Messier Street. The vehicle had sustained damage to the driver's side door and steering column and the speedometer and odometer had been removed, said Crown attorney Vic Bellay. </P> <P>MPI wrote off the vehicle and cut Pierce a cheque for $16,050, based in large part on his claim the vehicle had 151,000 kilometres on it. </P> <P>MPI investigators later ruled the theft suspicious, noting the damage to the steering wheel column was merely cosmetic. Further investigation revealed the actual odometer reading to be 250,000 kilometres. </P> <P>Pierce confessed to police, saying his brother had asked him to insure the vehicle in exchange for $600. </P> <P>"He was told the plan was to register the vehicle, damage it and then make a claim," Bellay said. </P> <P>Defence lawyer Chris Sigurdson said Pierce was desperate for money and succumbed to pressure from his brother. </P> <P>"He went into this with his eyes open," Judge John Guy responded. </P>

--30--

Title: 23-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Truck collides with train
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Tue Jun 15 2010   Page: B2
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The screeching and skidding of train brakes, unusual on quiet Leclaire Road south of Winnipeg, snapped Charlie Lohr's attention away from his morning coffee and out to his window. </P> <P>He looked outside just in time to watch in horror as metal train parts flew into the air, thrown there after an eastbound garbage truck collided with a southbound CP cargo train at an uncontrolled intersection, derailing 12 cars and plunging the truck into a nearby ditch. The accident occurred at about 7 a. m. Monday. </P> <P>"I could see the parts and pieces of the train heading in every direction, north, south, up and down," Lohr said. "Cars were heading into the field." </P> <P>The crash between the garbage truck and the train, which was loaded with sulphur and sulphuric acid, could have ended in human and environmental tragedy. Incredibly, nobody was seriously hurt in the accident, and no toxic chemicals were spilled. </P> <P>After witnessing the derailment, Lohr -- whose driveway sits about 50 metres off of Leclaire Road in the RM of Ritchot -- rushed down to the accident site while his wife dialled 911. There, he found the Johnson Waste garbage truck lying on its side, submerged in about two metres of water in the ditch. Lohr feared the worst when he saw two legs sticking out of the bullrushes -- until one of the man's feet moved. "I went 'are you OK?' And all of a sudden his eyes opened up," Lohr recalled, hours after the crash. </P> <P>Lohr pulled the man out from underneath the stream of hydraulic fluid leaking from the crippled truck, as a train engineer rushed to the site with an emergency kit. The garbage truck driver, a 43-year-old man from Oakbank, was transported to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. That nothing worse occurred, Lohr said, was "miraculous." </P> <P>RCMP and CP police are investigating the incident. None of the cars carrying dangerous materials was affected by the impact; the derailed cars were primarily empty, RCMP said. Lohr was evacuated from his home as a precaution on Monday morning, while authorities investigated the environmental impact of the diesel fuel leaking from the damaged vehicles. He was allowed to return home almost four hours after the crash.</P>

--30--

Title: 24-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Disaster avoided ; Truck hits train, driver lives, no leak of hazardous cargo
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: BY CHRIS KITCHING, WINNIPEG SUN,   RM OF RITCHOT
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A disastrous situation was avoided when a garbage truck crashed into the side of a freight train hauling hazardous materials south of Winnipeg on Monday. </P>  <P>Officials say it was a fortunate outcome because the truck driver, a 43-year-old Oakbank man, escaped with non-life threatening injuries and the CP Rail train's hazardous cargo -- including sulphur and sulphuric acid -- didn't leak, although a dozen empty rail cars derailed and at least 4,000 litres of diesel fuel spilled from a locomotive's ruptured fuel tank. </P>  <P>It appears the driver wasn't wearing a seatbelt and, ironically, that might have spared him from serious injury or death, said St. Pierre-Jolys RCMP Cpl. Paul Manaigre. </P>  <P>"He may have been slightly thrown from the vehicle through the windshield, which may have saved his life," he said. "This could have been much worse." </P>  <P>The collision occurred at an uncontrolled crossing on Leclaire Road, about three kilometres east of Provincial Road 200 (St. Mary's Road), at 7 a.m. The crossing is 15 kilometres south of Winnipeg in the Rural Municipality of Ritchot. </P>  <P>Broken arm </P>  <P>The front-loading garbage truck, which was eastbound, belongs to Winnipeg company Johnson Waste Management. </P>  <P>Company resident Jack Johnson said the driver suffered a broken arm but was being examined to find out whether he had any additional injuries. </P>  <P>Johnson said he's thankful and relieved the man survived. He said the man was heading to a landfill near the rail crossing. </P>  <P>Manaigre said it appears the man noticed the southbound train, travelling 40 km/h, at the last second and veered to the right. </P>  <P>The truck struck the second of two locomotives, spun into the ditch and rolled onto its side, he said. </P>  <P>Manaigre said officers haven't interviewed the driver but the preliminary investigation suggests the man didn't see the train on his left, for whatever reason. </P>  <P>RCMP will look into things such as driver inattention and whether the man's vision was obstructed by the sun as it was low on the horizon. </P>  <P>A house nearby was evacuated as a precaution. </P>  <P>CP Rail spokesman Jeff Johnson said 26 of the train's 86 cars were empty. </P>  <P>Johnson said the diesel spill doesn't pose any environmental or public safety concerns. </P>  <P>He said the collision serves as a cautionary tale and reminder to motorists and pedestrians to be alert at rail crossings.</P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 25-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CP train collides with truck near Winnipeg
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Monday, June 14, 2010 | 12:23 PM CST  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A home was evacuated and a man sent to hospital after a Canadian Pacific Railway freight train and garbage truck collided south of Winnipeg.</P> <P>The crash happened just after 7 a.m. CT Monday at an uncontrolled crossing on Leclaire Road, just east of Highway 200 in the Rural Municipality of Ritchot, about 15 kilometres south of the city.</P> <P>The crash caused about 12 train cars to derail. The train had some empty cars but was also hauling sulphur and sulphuric acid, RCMP said.</P> <P>None of the dangerous goods leaked but some diesel fuel did.</P> <P>The driver of the garbage truck, a 43-year-old man from Oakbank, Man., was transported to hospital with non life-threatening injuries.</P> <P>A house in the area was evacuated and an environmental impact is being done, said RCMP.</P> <P>The collision is being investigated by RCMP with assistance from the Canadian Pacific Police Service (CPPS), a private police force enforcing safety and policing along Canadian Pacific Railway properties and rail lines.</P> <P>Leclaire Road is currently closed to traffic around the collision scene.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/14/mb-train-truck-collide-derail-manitoba.html#ixzz0qvSoxLGq">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/14/mb-train-truck-collide-derail-manitoba.html#ixzz0qvSoxLGq</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Digital speed signs coming to city streets
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Read your speed and slow down -- this is the message Winnipeg officials are spreading as they launch a new safety tool in the fight against speeding. </P> <P>Seven digital radar speed signs have been installed at five locations to let motorists know if they're speeding through the school, playground or construction zone and serve as a visual reminder to slow down. </P> <P>Each solar-powered sign flashes a driver's speed in yellow or red on an LED display if it is faster than the speed limit. </P> <P>Mayor Sam Katz and others who launched the one-year, $100,000 pilot project Tuesday hope this will convince people to slow down in these areas and elsewhere. </P> <P>"This is anything but a cash grab," said Katz, taking a jab at critics of radar and photo enforcement. </P> <P>The signs don't take photos and tickets won't be issued as a result of a speed being displayed, the city said. </P> <P>Occasionally, a police officer will be nearby conducting radar enforcement to nab speeders. This was the case when Katz, police Chief Keith McCaskill and Brad Sacher, the city's director of public works, launched the awareness initiative outside Montrose School in River Heights. </P> <P>"If we can save one life, it's more than worth it," Sacher said. </P> <P>Nearby resident Charlotte Katz, who isn't related to the mayor, welcomed the sign on westbound Grant Avenue at Montrose Street. </P> <P>"It's important because the traffic is really heavy and fast here," she said. "I hope it works." </P> <P>Signs are posted in both directions on Inkster Boulevard near Inkster School and Provencher Boulevard near Provencher Park. </P> <P>One is on eastbound Grant Avenue near John Dafoe School and one is on westbound Bishop Grandin Boulevard in a construction zone. </P> <P>In a year, the city will review the project and decide whether to expand. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P><STRONG>Three nabbed for vandalism</STRONG> </P> <P>Police have arrested three males for their alleged roles in an auto theft and vandalism spree in Winnipeg this month. </P> <P>The males, aged 14, 18 and 22, are facing various charges. </P> <P>Police said the suspects came to officers' attention when they were spotted in a stolen vehicle near Hartford Avenue and McKenzie Street in West Kildonan on June 7. </P> <P>The vehicle was allegedly being driven dangerously and at excessive speeds, and it collided with a vehicle. </P> <P>Police said the suspects abandoned the vehicle nearby and fled on foot but a 14-year-old boy was arrested in the area. </P> <P>Two other males escaped. Early Monday, the pair allegedly vandalized eight parked vehicles by puncturing locks and smashing windows, stole items within, and attempted but failed to steal two vehicles, police said. </P> <P>Uniform officers and a canine unit arrested two men, aged 18 and 22, in the 200 block of Machray Avenue a short time later, police said. </P> <P><STRONG>Multi-vehicle crash on Lag</STRONG> </P> <P>Two people were taken to hospital in stable condition following a multi-vehicle crash in the St. Boniface area Tuesday morning, Winnipeg police say. </P> <P>The crash, which involved two or three vehicles, occurred at Lagimodiere Boulevard and Marion Street at 8:20 a.m. One of those vehicles, a Jeep, rolled, police said.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Rail line active after collision
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The site of a collision between a train and a garbage truck south of Winnipeg Monday has been cleaned up and the rail line is back in service, a spokesman for CP Rail said Tuesday. </P> <P>The accident occurred about 7 a.m. Monday at an uncontrolled crossing about 15 km south of Winnipeg along CP's Emerson subdivision line. </P> <P>The crash occurred when a garbage truck drove into the second of two locomotives that were leading the train, said CP Rail spokesman Mike LoVecchio. The impact overturned the garbage truck, derailed about a dozen train cars and ruptured a locomotive's fuel tank, spilling about 4,000 litres of diesel. </P> <P>Another CP spokesman, Kevin Hrysak, said the spill has been contained and cleaned up, adding company officials believe there will be no significant environmental impact. </P> <P>LoVecchio said the line was cleared of disconnected rail cars and back in service shortly after 10 a.m. Tuesday. </P> <P>The driver of the garbage truck, a 43-year-old Oakbank man, was thrown from the vehicle and suffered a broken arm, but no life-threatening injuries. No one else was hurt. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 29-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba drivers gear up for new cellphone rules
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Manitoba is just days away from new rules covering cellphone use by drivers.</P>  <P>While it's still not clear exactly what the new rules will say &#8212; the NDP government has been fine-tuning the legislation for months &#8212; a couple of things are certain: Drivers will be barred from text messaging entirely, and hands-free technology such as Bluetooth will be required for drivers who want to drive and talk on the phone at the same time.</P>  <P>Transportation Minister Steve Ashton said he expects drivers will quickly accept the new rules, as they did with legislation mandating seatbelt use.</P>  <P>"I fully expect that the vast majority of Manitobans are going to comply with the law," he said.</P>  <P>"Who wants to get a ticket for upwards of $191 when for half the price you can get a hands-free set-up or even pull over."</P>  <P>Manitoba is one of the last provinces to introduce such cellphone legislation.</P>  <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/15/man-cell-phone-ban.html#ixzz0r1K35cBk">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/15/man-cell-phone-ban.html#ixzz0r1K35cBk</A><BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 30-Apr-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Party autos target ; Many had open alcohol, mechanical problems: police
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Party buses, limousines and taxis were targeted for open alcohol and mechanical problems during a round of random roadside inspections last weekend, Winnipeg police say. </P> <P>Five party buses were stopped and all five failed an inspection but weren't taken off the road because the violations didn't pose a safety hazard to passengers or others on the road, said police spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen. </P> <P><STRONG>Repeat offender </STRONG></P> <P>He was unaware of the specific violations but said at least one company is a repeat offender. </P> <P>Police conducted 11 inspections Saturday to make sure the vehicles meet industry safety standards and passengers weren't drinking alcohol, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>Two vehicles had serious equipment violations and were removed from the road, he said. </P> <P>One of those vehicles had problems with its steering and braking system, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>A source said a stretch Hummer limousine was one of the two vehicles placed out of service. </P> <P>Michalyshen said police handed out 13 tickets, including offences under the Liquor Control Act and Highway Traffic Act. </P> <P>Police and other agencies, including Manitoba Public Insurance and Manitoba Liquor Control Commission, occasionally spend a night or weekend targeting public passenger vehicles such as taxicabs, limousines and party buses. Police say it's done in the name of safety. </P> <P>Last year, several buses were pulled off the road and barred from returning until various equipment violations were corrected. </P> <P>The violations ranged from faulty brakes and seats positioned sideways to objects blocking emergency exits and a pole blocking the aisle.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Noise testing could help motorcyclists avoid tickets
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>With Winnipeg police handing out $231 tickets for motorcycles that are too noisy, drivers may want to know how loud is too loud. </P> <P>Police are looking to help. The police traffic unit is considering free ways motorcyclists can test the legality of their vroom-vroom. </P> <P>"We're definitely looking into testing opportunities," said Mark Hodgson, Staff Sgt. of the Winnipeg Police Service's central traffic unit. "But we don't know when yet." </P> <P>Police have started using hand-held sound testers to gauge engine noise. A motorcycle or car engine over 92 decibels can get ticketed under the Highway Traffic Act. </P> <P>Winnipeg Police is in the process of helping draft a bylaw that will further cement noise restrictions for motorcycles and cars. </P> <P>Hodgson said he has been in talks with members of the Manitoba Association of Auto Clubs, and that they have been cooperative and positive about the new changes. </P> <P>"I think they are happy to be involved in the process," said Hodgson. </P> <P>However, motorists who are looking to get their rides tested sooner just may have the ear of a few Winnipeg businesses. </P> <P>Dale Kellington, manager of technical services at Winnipeg's Industrial Technology Centre, said they too are looking into ways in which they could test vehicles. </P> <P>"We have the technology to do pre-compliance testing," said Kellington. "We are just working out the logistics." </P> <P>Corporate Health Works founder Norma McCormick said her company is also equipped to test vehicles. </P> <P>The company provides services as compliance consultants and advocates to make workplaces more safe. </P> <P>"We do have hand-held equipment here that could be used to test noise levels, " said McCormick. "We thought we could then hand out a sheet that said the motorcycle passed and was compliant." </P> <P>But Hodgson warns that such tests are not a guarantee against getting a ticket. </P> <P>"You don't want a situation where people pass their compliance test and then change their muffler right after," said Hodgson. "It's positive that people are concerned with testing, but the testing conditions need to be up to standard." <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 2-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Speed signs should make less tickets
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
