<P>I would like to think that it is common sense that everyone in our city wants safer streets. </P> <P>There have been countless educational campaigns alerting Winnipeggers to the dangers of speed and I would hope that the message is getting through to all motorists to just slow down. </P> <P>This week I was pleased to be joined by police Chief Keith McCaskill and the director of public works Brad Sacher in launching a new initiative that we hope will remind Winnipeggers to drive slower in areas such as school zones, playground, and construction zones. </P> <P>The City of Winnipeg has played a major role in educating the public on the dangers of speed and the need for us to respect our speed limits for the safety of all motorists, pedestrians, and cyclists. </P> <P>Whether it has been through extensive safe streets campaigns encouraging you to raise your right foot, or letting you know that safe driving is a choice, not a skill, we remain committed in letting all drivers know the potential tragic consequences they face by flouting the law. </P> <P>Knock on the door </P> <P>I know nobody likes to receive a traffic ticket but I think it's much better than receiving a knock on the door from the Winnipeg Police Service informing you a loved one has been injured in a speed-related collision. </P> <P>So we will continue to work with our stakeholders to find new ways to educate the public and do our part to ensure motorists are abiding by the rules of the road. </P> <P>Winnipeg will soon see seven new electronic driver feedback signs in strategic locations around our city including Inkster Boulevard near Inkster School, Grant Avenue near JB Mitchell and John Dafoe Schools, Provencher Boulevard near Provencher Park and Notre Dame Community Club and Bishop Grandin Boulevard near the construction zone. </P> <P>These signs consist of a standard posted speed limit sign along with a solar powered LED display and radar unit. This pilot project is meant to provide real-time speeds to drivers as a way of informing them as to the importance of travelling the posted speed limit in vulnerable areas such as school, playground and construction zones. </P> <P>These signs are a constant visual reminder to motorists to slow down, which in turn helps to improve safety on our streets. </P> <P>We have seen the positive results experienced in other cities where these signs exist and we're really pleased to introduce this type of traffic calming to Winnipeg neighbourhoods where our department believes they will be most effective. </P> <P>Our department will evaluate the program after a year to see if it is having a positive impact on our city streets. </P> <P>It is possible if a benefit is demonstrated, this program may be expanded to other areas of the city as well. </P> <P>The bottom line is these signs encourage all Winnipeggers to think twice when they speed. There is no arguing or any excuses to make with a sign. The solution is simply to just slow down. </P> <P>And what's the best way to fight a photo radar ticket? Just slow down. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 3-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crash victim in hospital
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One person was rushed to hospital in unstable condition after a motorcycle and car collided in south Winnipeg on Wednesday. </P> <P>The crash occurred on Scurfield Boulevard near Waverley Street shortly after noon. </P> <P>The injured person's age and gender weren't available. </P> <P>Police continue to investigate the cause of the crash. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Woman struck on Main near Sutherland, southbound lanes closed
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- City police are investigating this morning after a female was hit by a vehicle on Main Street.</P> <P>The collision occurred around 2:30 a.m. near the corner of Main and Sutherland Avenue. The woman was rushed to hospital in "very serious condition," according to a police spokesman.</P> <P>A mangled bicycle lies on the sidewalk in front of the New West Hotel. Inside the yellow police tape, an older, grey sedan sits on Main with a smashed windshield.</P> <P>Police have closed the southbound lanes of Main between Dufferin and Higgins avenues until further notice.</P> <P>Traffic analysts are currently at the scene of the collision.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CAA tips for young drivers
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: Liz Peters, Public and Government Affairs Manager, CAA Manitoba
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Summer break is just around the corner, and thousands of Manitoba teens will be officially on vacation, many taking to the roads with friends in the family car.</P> <P>There is sure to be some celebrating graduates and others just thrilled by the arrival of summer break, but regardless of the occasion, CAA Manitoba is reminding parents and teens about the countless road safety challenges facing new drivers and what you can do to overcome them.</P> <P>According to MADD Canada, car accidents are the leading cause of death among teenagers and serious injury than any other age group. The same studies conclude that young drivers are over-represented in road crashes – especially during the summer months.</P> <P>So before handing over the keys this summer, talk to your teen about the top 10 deadliest teen driver mistakes – to protect themselves, but also everyone else using our roads.</P> <P>1. Risk taking – Know that it can happen to you. Car crashes are the leading cause of injury and death for people ages 15 to 20. It’s not just about you: Crashes affect pedestrians, passengers and other drivers, as well as their families. You don’t want to do something you’ll regret the rest of your life.</P> <P>2. Cell phones – Focus on driving. Save the phone calls, text messaging and other gadgets for after the driving is done. Talking on a cell phone while driving can double reaction time.</P> <P>3. Not wearing a seat belt – Always use your seat belt and insist all passengers do to. About two-thirds of teens killed in vehicle crashes were not wearing safety belts. Wearing a seat belt reduces your chances of being hurt or killed in a crash by 45 per cent.</P> <P>4. Driving under the influence – Stay sober. Of 16- to 17-year-old drivers killed in crashes, one in six would have been considered legally intoxicated by adult standards.</P> <P>5. Speed – Stick to the speed limit. One-third of teen fatalities involve speeding. Obeying the speed limit reduces the severity of a crash you can’t avoid.</P> <P>6. Rowdy riders – Don’t load up your car with friends. Adding one teen passenger to a vehicle increases a teen driver’s crash risk by a whopping 50 per cent. With two or more teen passengers, the crash risk increases fivefold.</P> <P>7. CD players – Turn the music off while learning to drive. Research shows that adjusting the radio is the most common distraction for drivers between the ages of 16, and driving and channel-surfing don’t mix.</P> <P>8. Late-night cruising – Don’t drive late at night. Teen crash rates at night (9 p.m. to 6 a.m.) are twice as high as daytime rates.</P> <P>9. Peer pressure – Make good choices and don’t be afraid to “speak up.” Before you get in a car with a friend, ask: Is this a person you trust? Is he in the right frame of mind to drive safely? Are you prepared to speak up if he drives dangerously?</P> <P>10. Overconfidence – Inexperience and overconfidence can lead to crashes when new drivers encounter unfamiliar or unexpected situations. Parents should supervise and monitor their teen drivers, even after they get their license.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man. cell phone ban starts July 15  Smoking in cars with child passengers also prohibited
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Drivers caught texting or using handheld cellphones in Manitoba face steep fines as of July 15.</P> <P>That's when a law banning those activities comes into effect, Transportation Minister Steve Ashton announced Thursday.</P> <P>"We know the hazards that distracted drivers create on our roads. Talking on a hand-held cellphone and texting are major distractions while driving and we're moving to make our roads safer for all Manitobans," Ashton stated in a government news release.</P> <P>A public-education, multimedia campaign was launched in September 2009 to prepare motorists for the changes, but the date for the new law had not yet been announced.</P> <P>Under the amendments to the Highway Traffic Act, motorists face a fine of almost $200 if caught breaking the new law.</P> <P>No smoking with kids in car<BR>The amendments also ban smoking in vehicles when children under the age of 16 are present. That fine is also about $200.</P> <P>"Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant," said Manitoba Public Insurance CEO and president Marilyn McLaren.</P> <P>"Text messaging or using a handheld cellphone while driving are both identified forms of driver distraction that can lead to a crash."</P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island have comparable laws and Alberta recently introduced legislation banning the use of handheld cellphones while driving.</P> <P>Several jurisdictions also have laws prohibiting smoking in vehicles with children present, including British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick.</P> <P>Manitoba's legislation allows the use of cellphones while driving to make telephone calls, provided they are equipped as hands-free devices and used in a hands-free manner.</P> <P>The law also allows use of a handheld cellphone to call the police, fire or ambulance service in an emergency.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/17/mb-cell-phone-ban-manitoba.html#ixzz0rD28MK4w">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/17/mb-cell-phone-ban-manitoba.html#ixzz0rD28MK4w</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: RCMP, MPI team up for bike rodeo  Young Shoal Lake students learn the rules of the road
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Shoal Lake youngsters saddled up to test their bike smarts and skills this week in a safe, fun environment.</P> <P>Grade 1, 2 and 3 students learned how they can have fun and stay safe riding their two-wheeled vehicles at a Cycle Safely Bike Rodeo on Monday, June 14, sponsored by the Shoal Lake RCMP in partnership with Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI).</P> <P>Just in time for the summer cycling season, children were instructed on various safety components including traffic signs, bicycle helmets, bike riding skills and knowing how to be seen during a two-part presentation involving both theory and practice.</P> <P>“According to school officials, the last time such an event was held in town was around seven years ago,” said Cst. Stacy Wiens, who serves as the school’s liaison officer. “It’s a great way to become involved with the youth of the community and get an important safety message out there.”</P> <P>MPI Community Relations Representatives, Krista Carter and Marlana Clayton, were also on hand to teach the young cyclists the tenets of safer cycling and importance of helmet use. Basically, studies have shown that when properly worn, an approved helmet can reduce the risk of sustaining a head injury by 85 percent.</P> <P>Along with school staff Audrey McKerchar, Louis Langevin and Bonnie Arnfinson - also assisting the younger students were Matthew Short, Reggie Waddell, Natasha Rupa and Jayln Gapka, members of the Shoal Lake Peer Helpers Group.</P> <P>Prior to being escorted to the hotel parking lot for the practical component of the presentation, the children learned about rules of the road (signs, signaling and safety tips), helmet fit, bike fit and condition at the school.</P> <P>From a road perspective, the boys and girls practiced their riding skills such as turning, braking, use of hand signals and recognizing road signs. Instructional sessions included the importance of stopping at stop signs, yielding to pedestrians in a crosswalk, and safety at a railway track including walking their bike across it.</P> <P>According to Manitoba Health Sciences – IMPACT Data, every year, about 100 cyclists are hospitalized in Manitoba and several are killed.</P> <P>Especially for children under 15 years old, IMPACT Data indicates that most bike injuries happen when the child: rides out of a driveway without stopping; goes through stop signs or red lights; turns or swerves to the left without checking; falls off the bike because of poor riding skills or because the bike is not in good condition.</P> <P><STRONG>Parents have a role</STRONG> <BR>Parents are encouraged by MPI to take note of the following cycling safety tips for children:</P> <P>Ensure your child wears appropriate clothing – shoes and gloves that fit.</P> <P>Dress them in light colored clothing when they go riding. Put reflective stickers on helmets and bikes.</P> <P>Teach them the rules of the road and ensure that they follow such rules.</P> <P>Teach them to keep their eyes and ears open. Do not permit them to wear earphones while riding.</P> <P>Write down the serial number of your child’s bike and keep it at home. Teach your children to always lock their bikes when they are not riding it.</P> <P>Install racks, never allow them to carry other items when riding.</P> <P>Make sure the bike is well-maintained. Regularly check brakes, pedals, chains, bearings and other parts to ensure that in case of any emergency, the bike can stop quickly.</P> <P>Teach your children how to conduct themselves in the event of an emergency. Teach them how to seek help, the facts, witness information and to pass such information to you immediately.</P> <P>With the end of the school year just around the corner, drivers are also reminded to keep watch for youngsters enjoying their summer break by either cycling or walking. By sharing the road, it can be a safe and happy holiday!<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 8-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stay safe this grad by making the right decision
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Grad means different things to different people. But no matter what memories you hold, one sentiment holds true for everyone: it’s the first day of the rest of your life. Don’t ruin it by drinking and driving or letting someone else do the same.</P> <P>Drinking and driving kills. It maims. It affects thousands of people every year. </P> <P>Here in Manitoba, about 30 people are killed every year in alcohol-related collisions, according to Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) statistics. And more than half of them are between the ages of 16 and 25.</P> <P>Just as disturbing is the fact that drivers aged 16-24 continue to be over-represented in the total number of alcohol-impaired driving convictions. Even though drivers in that same age group represent only 14.1 percent of licensed drivers in Manitoba, they account for more than double that proportion of all impaired driving convictions at almost 31 percent.</P> <P>And the statistics don’t tell the whole story. With each person killed in an alcohol-related crash, there are others who are deeply affected. Parents. Siblings. Friends. Coworkers.</P> <P>In its annual appeal to high school students, Manitoba Public Insurance partnered once again this year with MADD Canada to deliver a hard-hitting program on the dangers of impaired driving to students in 65 schools across the province. The multi-media assembly program, Wasted, enables both organizations to deliver an in impactful message to a very targeted audience.</P> <P>“With safe grad season nearly upon us, we need to continue to get the message out to the students that driving while impaired has far-reaching consequences and no one is immune to the risk,” said Clif Eden, manager of Road Safety for MPI. </P> <P>“We want to help young people understand the dangers while encouraging a commitment to sober driving.”</P> <P>The message is clear: stay safe this grad season. Don’t drink and drive. Don’t let a friend drive while impaired and don’t get into a vehicle with someone who has been drinking.</P> <P>“It’s an important decision that can affect the rest of a person’s life,” said Eden. “We want all Manitobans to work together to make our roads safer.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hang up that phone ; Drivers must go hands-free, stop texting, smoking with kids
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba drivers have less than a month to talk on their cellphones while driving or legally smoke in the car with kids. </P> <P>Transportation Minister Steve Ashton announced Thursday that as of July 15, a new law will come into effect that prevents drivers from talking on hand-held cellphones or texting while driving. </P> <P>The same law also forbids smoking in vehicles while anyone younger than 16 is inside -- even if the windows, sunroof or convertible top are open. </P> <P>The standard fine for violating any of these provisions will be $199.80. </P> <P>"As of July 15 you will have three choices," Ashton said. "You can either pull over, use hands-free or risk getting a ticket." </P> <P>Sgt. Line Karpish, a spokeswoman for Manitoba RCMP, said officers, as with any other law, will use their discretion in deciding whether to issue tickets, but will not be observing any sort of grace period. </P> <P>"It is our view that there's been a fairly lengthy campaign for awareness," Karpish said. "The public should be prepared to be ticketed." </P> <P><STRONG>Enforceable</STRONG> </P> <P>Karpish said Mounties will be enforcing the new law much as they would an offence like driving without a buckled seatbelt. </P> <P>"If our members see it, they can act on it," she said. </P> <P>Winnipeg police did not respond to a request regarding their enforcement plans. </P> <P>Mike Mager, president of CAA Manitoba, said the auto club wholeheartedly supports the new law but wants to ensure there is enough enforcement to deter drivers from breaking it. </P> <P>"We certainly don't want people to go back to their old habits," he said, adding he feels the fine is stiff enough to act as a deterrent. </P> <P>Ashton predicted 95% of Manitobans would comply with the law as soon as it comes into force. </P> <P>The NDP government introduced the law in November 2008 and passed it June 11, 2009, but have been conducting a public awareness campaign that includes TV ads in recent months as an "educational" component to warn the public about the dangers of distracted driving in the lead-up to enforcement. </P> <P>It will spend $125,000 over the next four weeks continuing that effort. </P> <P>Manitoba joins several other provinces that already have laws banning either in-car cellphone use, in-car smoking or both. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man injured in ATV trail crash ; Air search finds pair near Thompson
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Mounties and others searched by air and ground to locate two men who were involved in a serious all-terrain vehicle crash near Thompson in northern Manitoba on Wednesday evening. </P> <P>A 43-year-old Thompson man, who was wearing a helmet which covered his face, was seriously injured, RCMP said Thursday. </P> <P>Trail conditions may have been a factor in the single-vehicle crash, RCMP said. </P> <P>Police became aware of the collision on a trail when one of the men used a cellphone to call the Thompson detachment at 6:45 p.m. </P> <P>The caller told police the pair was south of Thompson but their exact location wasn't known. </P> <P>The call was interrupted by poor reception so police were unable to gather all the information from the caller. </P> <P>Officers scoured the area by vehicle, thinking the crash occurred on a road, but soon learned the collision involved a four-wheeler on a trail. </P> <P>The seriously injured occupant was being cared for by the second man. </P> <P>Two hours later, an RCMP aircraft located the pair while police officers, firefighters and Manitoba Conservation officers conducted a ground search. </P> <P>The men were three kilometres down a trail south of Thompson, RCMP said. </P> <P>Police said the injured man was taken to hospital in Thompson and then flown to Winnipeg for further treatment at Health Sciences Centre. </P> <P>He is in stable but serious condition, RCMP said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cyclist killed in North End collision
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A woman was killed in a collision in the North End early Thursday, Winnipeg police say. </P> <P>The crash occurred on southbound Main Street near Sutherland Avenue about 2:30 a.m. </P> <P>A car struck the woman. It's believed she was riding a bicycle at the time. A twisted bicycle was on the west sidewalk in front of the New West Hotel as police investigated at the scene. The car sustained damage to its windshield. </P> <P>Police didn't release the woman's name or age. Police closed southbound Main between Dufferin and Higgins avenues for several hours. </P>

--30--

Title: 12-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teacher killed in crash 'role model and friend'
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Manitoba teacher killed in a two-vehicle crash Wednesday is being remembered as a well-liked man who inspired and respected his students. </P> <P>George Forsyth, 54, died of his injuries in hospital after the collision, which injured four fellow teachers as they commuted to work in two communities. </P> <P>At what should be a celebratory time as the school year winds down, the collision has shaken staff and students at Roseau Valley School in Dominion City, where Forsyth, a Winnipeg resident, was a teacher for 22 years. </P> <P>"He impacted a lot of kids' lives. He was a solid teacher," said Tim Mendel, superintendent of Border Land School Division. </P> <P>Three of the surviving teachers work at the kindergarten to Grade 12 school about 100 kilometres south of Winnipeg. </P> <P>Grief counsellors were brought in to the school, where Forsyth taught business and computer-related classes. </P> <P>Current and former students and co-workers opened a Facebook group in Forsyth's memory. </P> <P>"Thank you for being a teacher, role model, reference and friend," a former student wrote. </P> <P>The collision occurred at Highway 23 and Provincial Road 200 shortly before 8:10 a.m. </P> <P>RCMP said a Volkswagen Jetta, occupied by Forsyth and three co-workers, was southbound on PR 200 when it collided with an eastbound Dodge Neon. </P> <P>RCMP said the Jetta, driven by a 28-year-old Winnipeg woman, went into the ditch and rolled. </P> <P>Mendel said the Neon was being driven by a 28-year-old Morris woman who teaches at Shevchenko School in Vita. </P> <P>He said four of Forsyth's co-workers came upon the crash. </P> <P>"I think the shock of this was when they left there they thought everyone was OK," Mendel said. </P> <P>The initial report was the injuries weren't life-threatening but everyone was taken to hospital and it was realized Forsyth's injuries were severe, Mendel said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: System failed us all ; Cabbie-killer finally getting help in custody
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The case of the young offender who crashed a stolen vehicle into Antonio Lanzellotti's cab in 2008, killing him, exposes the myth young offenders who spend time in youth detention are more likely to adopt a life of crime than they would serving their sentences in the community. </P> <P>Queen's Bench Justice Lea Duval documents in her written ruling -- which is now available online -- how community corrections failed miserably in the case of the teen who killed Lanzellotti and how the offender is far better off behind bars than on the street. </P> <P>The youth started getting into trouble with the law when he was 13. </P> <P><STRONG>Poisonous home </STRONG></P> <P>His parents are divorced and his father had no control over him. The youth has seven siblings, all of whom have criminal records, the written ruling says. Some family members are also gang members. </P> <P>It's about as poisonous an environment as you can get. </P> <P>Despite that, the courts continued to choose community sentencing for the youth, including probationary sentences, even though court orders were repeatedly breached. </P> <P>The youth showed little to no signs of complying with repeated court orders, including curfews, attending school and abstaining from drugs and alcohol. </P> <P>The youth was under intensive community supervision and was appointed a street mentor. </P> <P>None of it worked, namely because of the negative influences of criminality around him. And then a man was killed. </P> <P>The youth's probation officer says he never benefited from the type of controlled programming that's only effective in cases like these when the offender is incarcerated. </P> <P>"She notes that because he has never been sentenced as a young offender to a custodial sentence, he has not had the benefit of programming available for sentenced youth," writes Duval. </P> <P>In other words, despite all the good intentions of trying to turn the youth around through community sentencing, he was actually deprived of real help in a secure facility, away from the negative influences around him. </P> <P>"(The probation officer) stated that were it not for his family relationships, (the youth) would not be considered a high risk to re-offend, but rather a medium risk," wrote Duval. </P> <P>It wasn't until the youth spent some time at the Manitoba Youth Centre in pre-sentence custody that he started to show signs of improvement, Duval writes. </P> <P>The youth exhibited exemplary behaviour while in custody, was doing school work, expressed remorse and understanding of his crimes and showed signs of wanting to change his life. </P> <P>You can't do that when you're hanging out with criminals on the street. In a secure facility, you're protected from the toxic environment that steered you down the wrong path in the first place. </P> <P>"The Manitoba Youth Centre Resident Progress Review indicates that (the youth) has attained the 'trust level' in the unit, the highest level that can be achieved," the court document says. "To obtain this designation, (the youth) must have proved himself over a lengthy period of time, showing a desire to change his life and role model positively within the unit on a daily basis." </P> <P>Why would you want to send this kid -- who is now 16 -- back to the streets anytime soon when he's making this kind of progress in a secure facility? Unfortunately, they will send him back in two years. </P> <P>"It is evident that once released into the community, (the youth) will be faced with serious negative peer pressure," writes Duval. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police watching for lead-foots on Taylor Avenue
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Be careful, drivers. Winnipeg Police Service members will be enforcing speed limits Monday morning at construction sites on Taylor Avenue between Waverley and Wilton streets.</P>  <P>The speed limit in this zone is 60 km/h.</P>  <P>Construction will be ongoing for the next four months and enforcement will be employed in this area at different times throughout the four-month period. </P>  <P>The Winnipeg Police Service is requesting that motorists driving through this area respect the speed limit and "Just Slow Down". Construction workers deserve a safe work environment.</P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 15-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hands-free avoids fine
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg cellphone users are rushing to hook themselves up with hands-free units, to avoid the long arm of the law.</P> <P>Following the Manitoba government’s announcement last week that it will become illegal on July 15 to use cellphones while driving, except when using hands-free devices, motorists have barraged retailers with inquiries about gadgets that would let them make and receive calls without paying fines of about $190.</P> <P>“We’re getting calls and people coming in all the time,” said Barry Olinyk, general manager at Advance Electronics. “We’ve been gearing up for this for months.” </P> <P>Three major kinds of systems are available for hands-free calling, Olinyk says, though they come in several brands and makes with prices varying widely.</P> <P>The most popular hands-free units, so far, are “visor-clips” that make it easy for their users to answer calls when behind the wheel.</P> <P>“You simply touch a button on the visor. And you talk. Instead of through your cellphone, it comes through a speakerphone, which is just like a garage door opener,” Olinyk said, noting the systems have a price range of about $49 to $139.</P> <P>Headsets using Bluetooth in-ear speakers are another type, generally priced between $29 and $150, depending on features, styles and charging capabilities. </P> <P>“When someone phones and you’re in your vehicle, you just touch a button on the side of the Bluetooth,” Olinyk said. “You can hear that person in your ear, and have a conversation. You don’t have to be holding your phone or anything.” </P> <P>Perhaps the most advanced devices for hands-free calling, however, connect to the vehicle’s stereo system. They also come in various models.</P> <P>“When the phone rings, you hear it through your car speakers. And when you talk, there’s a microphone built in — it goes where your visor is. It mutes the stereo automatically. Upper-end vehicles are starting to come with these. And you can buy these as options and put them into your own vehicle,” Olinyk said, adding the stereo hook-ups produce the best sound.</P> <P>He pointed out that because hand-held cellphone use while driving has been illegal for some time in several other provinces, there’s been plenty of opportunity for retailers here to see and respond to what’s happened elsewhere in Canada.</P> <P>“We’ve learned from other markets what to do, and what not to do,” Olinyk said of his staff. “We’ve been amassing a huge inventory for months now.” </P>

--30--

Title: 16-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: My children still have a father’: driver’s wife
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The family of a Saskatchewan farmer is extremely thankful for the actions of a Winnipegger who rescued the 47-year-old from his burning tractor last week.</P> <P>Maciek Adamski was driving back to Winnipeg late last Wednesday and put his own life at risk to pull the injured farmer — Neil Paulgaard — from his tractor, which had been involved in a fiery crash with a tractor-trailer on the Trans-Canada Highway about five kilometres east of Wolseley, Sask.</P> <P>While both drivers were taken to hospital with non-life threatening injuries, RCMP said Adamski’s actions in pulling the farmer away from his tractor likely saved his life, as the farm vehicle exploded less than a minute later.</P> <P>Paulgaard’s wife, Kelly, said Sunday she is thankful their three kids still have a dad.</P> <P>“Maciek was there to pull him away and save his life,” she said. “It’s like God sent an angel. It’s just wonderful.</P> <P>“I’m feeling very grateful, especially on Father’s Day, that my children still have a father.” </P> <P>Kelly Paulgaard said her husband remains in hospital in Regina with first- and second-degree burns to his hands and head.</P> <P>“It’s going to take a while, but he’s healing,” she said.</P> <P>The family runs a mixed grain and cattle operation with about 3,000 acres of land near Wolseley. Paulgaard said her husband was returning home from towing a piece of machinery to a welding shop to be repaired when the collision occurred.</P> <P>Paulgaard said she has spoken on the phone to Adamski and hopes she and her husband will see him in person when the Winnipegger next travels west.</P> <P>“We’re definitely going to keep in touch,” Paulgaard said.</P>

--30--

Title: 17-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Drunk driver who killed woman seeks lighter term
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg man claims he has been unfairly punished for a drunk driving crash that killed an innocent motorist. </P> <P>Hugo Sergio Ruizfuentes, 42, appeared before the Manitoba Court of Appeal Friday seeking to overturn the six-year penalty he received last fall. Defence lawyer Mike Cook said his client should have been given between three and four years behind bars. </P> <P>"Parity with other sentences in other cases demands his sentence be reduced," Cook told the Free Press. </P> <P>Elaine Stoller, 63, was killed in December 2008 while driving through the intersection of Grant Avenue and Waverley Street. A witness told police Ruizfuentes ran three consecutive red lights and was speeding before hitting Stoller's vehicle, which had the right of way. Police tested Ruizfuentes three hours after the crash and found his blood-alcohol content was .12, 50 per cent higher than the legal limit of .08. </P> <P>Ruizfuentes, a married father of three, didn't fight the case at trial and pleaded guilty to impaired driving causing death. He had no prior criminal record but several previous driving infractions which were cited by the judge. </P> <P>Cook argued Friday the judge "overemphasized" his client's Highway Traffic Act record while not giving him enough credit for quickly admitting responsibility, showing remorse and wanting to use the tragedy as a teaching tool for others. Ruizfuentes has already approached Mothers Against Drunk Drivers about doing a series of talks to young drivers about the deadly mistake he made. <BR>"Who better to speak than a man who's been through this?" said Cook. He called Ruizfuentes a "good man who did a horrible thing." <BR>Stoller was a beloved mother, grandmother and community figure who founded the Women's Endowment Fund of The Jewish Foundation of Manitoba. She was on her way home from work and just days away from a Mexican vacation when she was killed. </P> <P>The appeal court has reserved its decision.</P>

--30--

Title: 18-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crash claims fry guy's livelihood
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Tue Jun 22 2010   Page: A5
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>She was a film star known for her irresistible scent, a fixture in the Exchange District and just outside Canad Inns Stadium. </P> <P>But the morning the famous Goldies Fries truck headed toward the first Winnipeg Blue Bombers' pre-season game of 2010, the ubiquitous fry cart was history -- the victim of a crash that claimed both her mechanical life and the livelihood of owner Darryl Leiman. </P> <P>On Monday, Leiman wiped tears from his eyes with a crumpled napkin as he stood in front of a humble hotdog cart he'll now be using to try to rebuild his business. </P> <P>He was on his way to the football game nine days ago when a 19-year-old woman crashed into the truck at Ellice Avenue and Erin Street. The truck, a 1974 International, was totalled. </P> <P>"It was just like a nightmare," said Leiman, 54. </P> <P>"My life has changed in two seconds." </P> <P>Since 1988, Leiman has built up a steady customer base, who came to his truck near Old Market Square. He proudly calls himself the "french fry guy" and has nicknamed his truck 'Betsy,' regaling the days she starred in the 2004 Canadian television film Zeyda and the Hitman. </P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance offered him $2,500 for the truck, but he said the years of labour he's put into the truck is worth far more. </P> <P>The truck and its equipment will cost at least $30,000 to replace, he said. </P> <P>"I just want my life back. I just want to rebuild, that's all," he said. </P> <P>"This is just like a lightning bolt. It just hits you." </P> <P>Police said the woman who crashed into Leiman's truck went through a red light and complained the sun was in her eyes. </P> <P>The crash has led to financial disaster, said Leiman. </P> <P>"I have no benefits. I don't have a nice, steady government job," he said, adding his life was "washed away" with the crash and his regular income was gone. "I do it because I like being down here with the public." </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said people who disagree with the worth of the vehicle have "certain room" to negotiate with adjusters. </P> <P>"Some people have sentimental value for a vehicle and then obviously, from our perspective, we're looking at a book value," he said. </P> <P>Leiman's not giving up. </P> <P>He said he's happiest when serving fries -- made from red potatoes grown by a Hutterite farm -- to a big lineup outside the truck. This week, fries were off the menu as Leiman stood in the rain selling hotdogs with a borrowed cart. </P> <P>"I don't want to break down right now, but this has been very difficult for me," he said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI uncovers fraud
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg man must write a letter of apology to the president of Manitoba Public Insurance after pleading guilty to fraud under $5,000.</P> <P>Brent Disbrowe-Bear was given a conditional discharge on his guilty plea, but was ordered by a judge to write a letter of apology for his criminal actions. Disbrowe-Bear, now 21, was also sentenced to 15 months probation and perform 120 community service hours within one year. He was also ordered to pay restitution of $240.</P> <P>Court was told that on January 19, 2008 Disbrowe-Bear reported that his vehicle was stuck by another motor vehicle as it was located in a parking stall at his apartment complex.</P> <P>An investigation by MPI’s Special Investigation Unit discovered that a witness had seen a vehicle collide with a snowbank and stop sign. the witness was able to provide the licence plate of the vehicle and part of a front spoiler which had been left at the crash scene.</P> <P>Last year MPI’s SIU investigated about 2,750 claims, resulting in savings of nearly $9.3 million for the public auto insurer and its ratepayers. </P> <P>Anyone knowing someone who is involved in auto insurance fraud is encouraged to MPI’s tips Line at 1.877.985.8477. All calls are anonymous.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Think before you drive
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Grad means different things to different people. But no matter what memories you hold, one sentiment holds true for everyone: it’s the first day of the rest of your life. Don’t ruin it by drinking and driving or letting someone else do the same.</P> <P>Drinking and driving kills. It maims. It affects thousands of people every year.</P> <P>Here in Manitoba, about 30 people are killed every year in alcohol-related collisions, according to Manitoba Public Insurance statistics. And more than half of them are between the ages of 16 and 25.</P> <P>Just as disturbing is the fact that drivers aged 16 – 24 continue to be over-represented in the total number of alcohol-impaired driving convictions. Even though drivers in that same age group represent only 14.1 per cent of licensed drivers in Manitoba, they account for more than double that proportion of all impaired driving convictions at almost 31 per cent.</P> <P>And the statistics don’t tell the whole story. With each person killed in an alcohol-related crash, there are others who are deeply affected. Parents. Siblings. Friends. Coworkers.</P> <P>In its annual appeal to high school students, Manitoba Public Insurance partnered once again this year with MADD Canada to deliver a hard-hitting program on the dangers of impaired driving to students in 65 schools across the province. The multi-media assembly program, Wasted, enables both organizations to deliver an in impactful message to a very targeted audience.</P> <P>“With safe grad season nearly upon us, we need to continue to get the message out to the students that driving while impaired has far-reaching consequences and no one is immune to the risk,” says Clif Eden, manager of Road Safety for Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>“We want to help young people understand the dangers while encouraging a commitment to sober driving.”</P> <P>The message is clear: stay safe this grad season. Don’t drink and drive. Don’t let a friend drive while impaired and don’t get into a vehicle with someone who has been drinking.</P> <P>“It’s an important decision that can affect the rest of a person’s life,” says Eden. “We want all Manitobans to work together to make our roads safer.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 21-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: New Law Banning Hand-Held Cell Phones to Take Effect July 15
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Smoking in Cars with Child Passengers Also Prohibited  Treherne Times, June 21, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Drivers caught texting or using handheld cellphones could face a fine of almost $200 under a new law that takes effect July 15 under amendments to the Highway Traffic Act, Infrastructure and Transportation Minister Steve Ashton announced June 17.</P> <P>“We know the hazards that distracted drivers create on our roads. Talking on a hand-held cellphone and texting are major distractions while driving and we’re moving to make our roads safer for all Manitobans,” said Ashton.</P> <P>A public-education, multimedia campaign has reminded motorists that if they are on the road, they should stay off the phone and text devices. Under the amendments, motorists may also face a fine of almost $200 for smoking in vehicles when children under the age of 16 are present.</P> <P>“Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant,” said Manitoba Public Insurance CEO and president Marilyn McLaren. “Text messaging or using a hand-held cellphone while driving are both identified forms of driver distraction that can lead to a crash.”</P> <P>“This new law will help refocus motorists on what should be their top priority – driving – as it only takes a split second to have an accident, “ said CAA Manitoba President and CEO, Mike Mager. “Driving requires close attention and CAA Manitoba has always reminded motorists about the dangers of distracted driving and that is why we support this new law as it requires motorists to shut out those distractions.”</P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, and Prince Edward Island have comparable laws and Alberta recently introduced legislation banning the use of handheld cellphones while driving. Several jurisdictions also have laws prohibiting smoking in vehicles with children present including British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick.</P> <P>Manitoba’s legislation allows the use of cellphones while driving to make telephone calls, provided they are equipped as hands-free devices and used in a hands-free manner. The law also allows use of a hand-held cellphone to call the police, fire or ambulance service in an emergency.</P> <P>More information is available at <A href="http://www.gov.mb.ca/seethesigns">www.gov.mb.ca/seethesigns</A>.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'Invincible' teens a driving concern
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Mon Jun 21 2010   Section: Local
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The freedom and sense of maturity that comes with getting behind the wheel for the first time is an important rite of passage for 16-year-olds across Canada. </P> <P>Unfortunately, it's in those first years as a new driver that teenagers are most at risk of getting into a car accident. </P> <P>New drivers are three times more likely to have an accident than experienced drivers, Manitoba Public Insurance reports. In 2008, nearly 10 per cent of all roadway fatalities involved youth ages 16 to 19 years old. </P> <P>Road crashes are the No. 1 cause of teen death in Canada and alcohol is a factor in 45 per cent of those crashes, Mother's Against Drunk Driving reports. In 2006, 16 to 25 years olds constituted only 13.2 per cent of the population, but accounted for 33.4 per cent of the total alcohol-related crash deaths. </P> <P>"I wish these numbers were a surprise to me but they're not," local MADD past-president Judith Jordan told the Sun. </P> <P>"They still think they're invincible ... every time we thought we'd made some progress, (an accident) would happen and all you could do is just keep repeating the message, hoping it sunk in somehow." </P> <P>Peer pressure and the growing number of external distractions drivers face further compounds any hazards for still-green drivers. </P> <P>Throughout his 30-plus career as a claims adjuster with MPI and now as owner of the Wheat City Driving School, Ross Mann says a teenager's perception behind the wheel is far from developed. </P> <P>"They just don't understand the consequences," he said. "If they see a hole where the city has dug up the street, they'll drive through it at 50 kilometres unless you tell them to slow down ... They're more concerned about going the speed limit over the care required ... and they're definitely not adjusting for the conditions." </P> <P>As the season of graduation parties and summer road trips approaches, CAA is reminding parents and teens about the countless distractions and road safety challenges new drivers face. </P> <P>CAA spokesperson Liz Peters says targeting those who are handing over their car keys is just another way to make sure young drivers get the message. </P> <P>"At the end of the day we all need to take it upon ourselves to be responsible," she said. "Inexperience and overconfidence leads to crashes ... there's unfamiliar things happening in the car around you when you're all the sudden in the drivers seat." </P> <P>CAA is encouraging parents to take time to address the statistics about how teens are getting into accidents at a far higher level than any other age group. </P> <P>"It really just comes down to how kids are thinking about their responsibility behind the wheel. And making it crystal clear to them that it's a privilege not a right."</P>

--30--

Title: 23-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitobans can now drive in France
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Brandon Sun   Mon Jun 21 2010   Section: Latest News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Drivers in France and Manitoba are now able to exchange their driver's licences thanks to a reciprocal arrangement signed last year, the province announced today. </P> <P>"This agreement allows for easier transition during a relocation," said Premier Greg Selinger, who is also minister responsible for francophone affairs. "This is great news for both jurisdictions and especially for Manitoba, where more and more francophone immigrants are choosing to establish their businesses and start a new life with their families." </P> <P>Reciprocity allows individuals from other jurisdictions to exchange a valid out-of-province driver's licence for an equivalent-class Manitoba licence without undergoing the usual knowledge and road tests. Likewise, Manitobans who relocate to France are afforded the same exchange privileges. In all cases, vision and medical standards for each jurisdiction continue to apply. </P> <P>Prior to entering into a reciprocal arrangement with another country, an assessment of several factors is undertaken to retain the integrity of the driver's licence program in Manitoba. These include consideration of foreign driver's licence and testing standards, language differences, record keeping, terminology and the application of graduated driver-licensing provisions. </P> <P>This agreement is the culmination of several years of discussion between Manitoba and the Republic of France. </P> <P>France already has reciprocal arrangements with four other provinces: Alberta, Ontario, Quebec and Prince Edward Island. New Brunswick allows for unilateral exchange of French driver's licences. </P> <P>On June 15, a new reciprocal agreement was also signed by Manitoba with Northern Ireland. </P> <P>Prior to the additions referred to above, Manitoba had reciprocity arrangements with Germany, the Republic of South Korea and the Republic of Austria for passenger vehicles. There are also reciprocity arrangements with Switzerland, The Isle of Man and the United Kingdom of Great Britain (excluding Northern Ireland) for both passenger vehicles and motorcycle driver's licences. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: On the road…off the phone
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Drivers caught texting or using hand-held cellphones could face a fine of almost $200 under a new law that takes effect July 15 under amendments to the Highway Traffic Act, Infrastructure and Transportation Minister Steve Ashton announced today.</P> <P>"We know the hazards that distracted drivers create on our roads. Talking on a hand-held cellphone and texting are major distractions while driving and we're moving to make our roads safer for all Manitobans," said Ashton.</P> <P>A public-education, multimedia campaign has reminded motorists that if they are on the road, they should stay off the phone and text devices. Under the amendments, motorists may also face a fine of almost $200 for smoking in vehicles when children under the age of 16 are present.</P> <P>"Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant," said Manitoba Public Insurance CEO and president Marilyn McLaren. "Text messaging or using a hand-held cellphone while driving are both identified forms of driver distraction that can lead to a crash."</P> <P>"This new law will help refocus motorists on what should be their top priority – driving – as it only takes a split second to have an accident, " said CAA Manitoba president and CEO, Mike Mager.</P> <P>"Driving requires close attention and CAA Manitoba has always reminded motorists about the dangers of distracted driving and that is why we support this new law as it requires motorists to shut out those distractions."</P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, and Prince Edward Island have comparable laws and Alberta recently introduced legislation banning the use of hand-held cellphones while driving. Several jurisdictions also have laws prohibiting smoking in vehicles with children present including British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick.</P> <P>Manitoba's legislation allows the use of cellphones while driving to make telephone calls, provided they are equipped as hands-free devices and used in a hands-free manner. Title: 27-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cellphone use dials up trouble for employers
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>DRIVERS caught talking on their cellphones after next month's ban comes into effect won't be happy with their tickets but the fines they'll face could be a drop in the bucket compared to the hit their employers might take. </P> <P>The Manitoba legislation, which goes live July 15, gives rise to a related issue -- are employers liable for the damages caused by their employees who get in accidents while talking on their cellphones? </P> <P>The answer, according to Scott Hoeppner, a lawyer at Thompson Dorfman Sweatman LLP, depends on where the accident takes place. Within Manitoba's borders, the province's no-fault insurance kicks in, which bars any legal action related to injuries suffered in a motor vehicle accident. </P> <P>If it's in Ontario, Alberta, the Maritimes or the majority of U.S. states, however, all of which are "fault" jurisdictions, companies should be "very concerned," he said. </P> <P>"If the employer provided the device to the employee, it's likely they'll be directly liable (for any damages). If the employer hasn't provided the device, but the employee is using it in the course of their duties, like a sales rep would, then there's a good chance the employer will be vicariously liable," he said. </P> <P>Hoeppner said the difference between direct and vicarious liability is in degrees of separation but they both mean the company is "on the hook." </P> <P>Employers won't be completely at the mercy of their law-breaking employees, he said. </P> <P>They can protect themselves by establishing and enforcing an internal policy that stipulates employees will comply with all provincial and state laws with respect to hand-held devices and driving, a protocol to be followed by all employees for retrieving and responding to messages and disciplinary measures for non-compliance. </P> <P>There is some grey area, however. If an employee is on the road in the U.S. and gets in an accident while talking to their spouse, the employer might claim that such a call has nothing to do with their job. The employee, on the other hand, might say that checking in with their family is part of doing business. </P> <P>"If you get in an accident on the way to a ball game while talking on your phone, companies will say, 'this was on your own time, we're not vicariously liable.' The really risky ones are where you're directly involved and trying to close a deal with a client on the phone. Then I think the employer is going to be in some trouble," he said. </P> <P>Bison Transport, one of Canada's leading trucking companies, isn't taking any chances and hasn't for several years. It recently reissued its policy forbidding the use of any handheld device by its drivers, including CB radios, while on the road. Garth Pitzel, Bison's director of safety and driver development, said having a blanket policy is safer because not only are drivers not distracted while driving, they don't have to worry about different rules in different states and provinces. </P> <P>"We run 110 million miles a year. We want to make sure the drivers are in the best position to operate them as safely as possible at all times," Pitzel said. </P> <P>Drivers can use wireless devices provided it's done hands-free or by voice activation. A new technological advancement recently adopted by Bison will read messages to drivers while they're behind the wheel. If it's urgent, they can pull over and deal with the situation. </P> <P>Brian Smiley, media relations coordinator with Manitoba Public Insurance, said it will cover cellphone-related crashes for individuals in the province. </P> <P>"It would be looked at no differently than speeding and going through a red light. Whether they were on their cellphone or not buckled up, there would still be coverage provided with the crash. Where you'll feel the pinch is you'll probably be ticketed by police," he said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: City cops to crack down on off-road vehicles
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Some Winnipeggers living on the city's fringe are fed up with unruly off-road vehicle operators. </P> <P>So are police. </P> <P>In response to a spike in complaints, police are warning Winnipeggers not to operate off-road vehicles within city limits. </P> <P>The use of dirt bikes, four-wheelers or similar vehicles in Winnipeg is outlawed year-round by a city bylaw, except in some outlying, sparsely populated areas. </P> <P>The ban also applies to snowmobiles. </P> <P>An individual convicted of violating the bylaw faces a fine of up to $1,000 and/or up to six months in jail. </P> <P>Using their own off-road vehicles to patrol, Winnipeg police officers are stepping up enforcement after receiving several complaints from residents in Transcona, St. James and south St. Vital about unsafe speeds, erratic driving, off-road vehicles on city streets, underage riders without supervision, and noise. </P> <P>In many cases, the vehicles are being operated by kids, said central traffic unit patrol Sgt. Kevin Cisaroski. </P> <P>In Transcona, most complaints this spring have been about dirt bikes going through a residential neighbourhood near Gunn Road to exit and enter the city, Cisaroski said. </P> <P>"They're not driving and staying within city limits. They're using a path to get out of the city," Cisaroski said. </P> <P>Instead, people must load the off-road vehicle on to a trailer or truck and transport it outside the city to the place where they intend to ride, he said. </P> <P>Off-road vehicles must be registered and display a licence plate with a valid sticker, a driver must possess a valid driver's licence when crossing a road, the occupants must wear approved helmets, and children under 14 must be supervised at all times by a parent or an adult approved by the parent, police said. </P>

--30--

Title: 29-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In Brief: Police caution ATV drivers
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>OFF-ROADERS and ATV enthusiasts take note: Winnipeg police are reminding you not to ride off-road vehicles inside city limits. </P> <P>Police say their warning comes after a surge in complaints and accidents, some fatal, from all areas of the city, including Transcona, St. James and South St. Vital. </P> <P>Driving off-road vehicles such as dirt bikes, quads and snowmobiles is against the law, police said. Getting caught could cost violators a fine up to $1,000 or six months in jail, police said. </P> <P>Residents have complained about unsafe speeds, erratic driving behaviour, underage riders without supervision and noise nuisance by off-roaders. </P> <P>All off-road vehicles must be registered and display a licence plate with a valid sticker, police said. </P> <P>Drivers must also possess a valid driver's licence even when crossing a road and wear approved helmets. Children under 14 must be supervised by an adult. Vehicles are not allowed on frozen waterways or ponds in the city, police said. </P>

--30--

Title: 30-May-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: It's about the noise
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Having read and listened to the dialogue about motorcycle noise tickets I thought it time to wander, perhaps leap, into the fray. </P> <P>This issue is not about a specific group being targeted for being a specific group. It is not about vintage motorcycles. It is not about MPI rates for motorcycles, a separate issue, nor is it about straight pipes saving lives -- myth, myth, myth. It is not about motorcyclist stereotypes. </P> <P>It is simply about offensive and unnecessary noise. I live about 75 metres away from a normally quiet bridge crossing the Red River. There are only two noises in my neighbourhood that will bring a backyard conversation to a screeching halt. These noises require that I wait until they abate before I can continue talking with my guests -- one being the sirens associated with our emergency vehicles, the other the din emitted by those who insist on revving up their motors as they cross this bridge. Yes, 95 per cent of these drivers are riding motorcycles. I guess the police service will have to target that 95 per cent. </P> <P>I suggest the police do not only monitor an idling vehicle for the 92- decibel limit. That level is relatively easy to put up with. It is the 120-plus decibels being driven down my ear canal that is truly offensive. Why in heaven's name do you insist on screaming at me with your bike on a regular basis? Would you like it? </P> <P>Bravo to those who have spoken up about this matter. Try it and you will likely receive nasty looks and words from those riding the two-wheeled assault (to the senses) weapons. </P> <P>RICHARD KLIEWER <BR>Winnipeg </P>

--30--

Two occupants of the eastbound car and three occupants of the other vehicle were transported to hospital with non life threatening injuries.</P> <P>The investigation is continuing..<BR></P>

Title: 1-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg crash kills driver
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The 49-year-old driver of a car died in hospital Tuesday after crashing into a hydro pole in Winnipeg.</P> <P>It happened around 9:30 a.m. CT when his vehicle rolled then hit the pole, police said. They did not identify him.</P> <P>Vehicle and pedestrian traffic was blocked on Waverley Street between Bison Drive and Lee Boulevard while police investigated the scene. Police said the cause of the crash is still under investigation.</P> <P>The streets have since reopened.</P> <P>Investigators are asking anyone with information about the crash to call police at 204-986-6271.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/22/mb-crash-waverley-winnipeg.html#ixzz0rgGWt36E">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/22/mb-crash-waverley-winnipeg.html#ixzz0rgGWt36E</A></P>
