Title: 2-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crash injures five
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Five people were taken to hospital following a head-on crash near Falcon Lake in eastern Manitoba on Tuesday, RCMP say. </P> <P>The injuries weren't life threatening, police said. </P> <P>RCMP said the crash occurred on the two-lane portion of the Trans-Canada Highway at 3:15 p.m., resulting in a highway closure lasting two hours. </P> <P>Police said a westbound Chevrolet Malibu crossed the centre line into the path of an eastbound Pontiac G6. </P> <P>Two occupants of the G6 and three in the Malibu were taken to Lake of the Woods District Hospital in Kenora and Ste. Anne Hospital, southeast of Winnipeg. </P>

--30--

Title: 3-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Homicide now alleged in fatal crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Provincial prosecutors are seeking to prove a fatal highway crash that killed two young Manitoba women was a homicide and have upgraded charges against the alleged drunk driver accused of killing them.</P> <P>RCMP officers have rearrested Cory Sidney Kipling and charged him with two counts of manslaughter in connection to the deaths of cousins Tina Jones, 18, and Tiffany Abraham, 19. An RCMP spokeswoman said the charges were laid at the request of the Crown.</P> <P>The women, both from Manitoba's Black River First Nation, were killed on Highway 59 near Scanterbury, Man. after a van slammed into their small car on Jan. 28, 2009.</P> <P>Abraham's mother and two passengers in the van were injured in the crash, but survived.</P> <P>Kipling, 28, made an appearance in court to face the harsher charges this week. Kipling is also charged with impaired driving causing death and bodily harm and dangerous driving causing death and bodily harm.</P> <P>Police allege the van was stolen in Winnipeg before the crash, and that Kipling was drunk and behind the wheel when it slammed into the victims' car.</P> <P>If convicted of manslaughter, Kipling faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. There is no mandatory minimum sentence. He has been in custody since his arrest on Jan. 29, 2009, one day after the deadly crash.</P> <P>Abraham and Jones were University of Manitoba students. People living in Black River - about 100 kilometres north of Winnipeg - lauded the young women for their service work.</P> <P>Friends told CBC News after the crash that Abraham was an organizer of a provincially-funded program on the reserve aimed at keeping youth away from drugs and gangs.</P> <P>Kipling is also facing charges of possession of property obtained by crime and failing a court-ordered condition to abstain from alcohol.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/24/man-fatal-crash-scanterbury-kipling-manslaughter.html#ixzz0rruvedkm">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/24/man-fatal-crash-scanterbury-kipling-manslaughter.html#ixzz0rruvedkm</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Charges upgraded to manslaughter
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>CHARGES have been upgraded against a man allegedly responsible for the deaths of two teens when he crashed into their vehicle last year. </P> <P>Provincial prosecutors hope to show the crash caused by alleged drunk driver Cory Sidney Kipling was a homicide. An RCMP spokeswoman said they laid the enhanced charge of two counts of manslaughter on June 1 at the request of the Crown. </P> <P>RCMP said a Plymouth Voyageur collided with a Dodge Neon carrying Trisha Jones, 18, and Tiffany Abraham, 19, near where Highway 59 meets Highway 304 in the RM of St. Clements on Jan. 28, 2009. The two teens died in the crash. </P> <P>Abraham's mother, 35-year-old Merele Bird, was treated and released at Selkirk and District General Hospital. </P> <P>The Plymouth Voyageur was allegedly stolen from the Winnipeg area before the crash, police said at the time. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: New cell phone law to take effect July 15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Drivers caught texting or using hand-held cellphones could face a fine of almost $200 under a new law that takes effect July 15.</P> <P>“We know the hazards that distracted drivers create on our roads. Talking on a hand-held cellphone and texting are major distractions while driving and we’re moving to make our roads safer for all Manitobans,” said Transportation Minister Steve Ashton.</P> <P>A public-education, multimedia campaign has reminded motorists that if they are on the road, they should stay off the phone and text devices. Under the amendments, motorists may also face a fine of almost $200 for smoking in vehicles when children under the age of 16 are present.</P> <P>“Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant,” said Manitoba Public Insurance CEO and president Marilyn McLaren.</P> <P>“Text messaging or using a hand-held cellphone while driving are both identified forms of driver distraction that can lead to a crash.”</P> <P>“This new law will help refocus motorists on what should be their top priority -driving- as it only takes a split second to have an accident,” said CAA Manitoba president and CEO, Mike Mager.</P> <P>“Driving requires close attention and CAA Manitoba has always reminded motorists about the dangers of distracted driving and that is why we support this new law as it requires motorists to shut out those distractions.”</P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, and P.E.I have comparable laws and Alberta recently introduced legislation banning the use of hand-held cellphones while driving. Several jurisdictions also have laws prohibiting smoking in vehicles with children present including British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia, P.E.I. and New Brunswick.</P> <P>Manitoba’s legislation allows the use of cellphones while driving to make telephone calls, provided they are equipped as hands-free devices and used in a hands-free manner.</P> <P>The law also allows use of a hand-held cellophane to call the police, fire or ambulance service in an emergency.</P> <P>More information is available at <A href="http://www.gov.mb.ca/seethesigns">www.gov.mb.ca/seethesigns</A>.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cell phone law in effect on July 15  Talking and texting will be against the law while driving a vehicle
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Drivers caught texting or using hand-held cell phones could face a fine of almost $200 under a new law that takes effect July 15 under amendments to the Highway Traffic Act.</P> <P>“We know the hazards that distracted drivers create on our roads. Talking on a hand-held cell phone and texting are major distractions while driving and we’re moving to make our roads safer for all Manitobans,” said Infrastructure and Transportation Minister Steve Ashton.</P> <P>A public-education, multimedia campaign has reminded motorists that if they are on the road, they should stay off the phone and text devices. Under the amendments, motorists may also face a fine of almost $200 for smoking in vehicles when children under the age of 16 are present.</P> <P>“Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant,” said Manitoba Public Insurance CEO and president Marilyn McLaren. “Text messaging or using a hand-held cell phone while driving are both identified forms of driver distraction that can lead to a crash.”</P> <P>“This new law will help refocus motorists on what should be their top priority -driving - as it only takes a split second to have an accident,” said CAA Manitoba president and CEO, Mike Mager. “Driving requires close attention and CAA Manitoba has always reminded motorists about the dangers of distracted driving and that is why we support this new law as it requires motorists to shut out those distractions.”</P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, and Prince Edward Island have comparable laws and Alberta recently introduced legislation banning the use of hand-held cell phones while driving.</P> <P>Manitoba’s legislation allows the use of cell phones while driving to make telephone calls, provided they are equipped as hands-free devices and used in a handsfree manner. The law also allows use of a hand-held cell phone to call the police, fire or ambulance service in an emergency.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg boy killed when struck by tow truck near neighbourhood playground
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - A young Winnipeg boy has been killed after being hit by a tow truck across from a busy neighbourhood playground. </P> <P>Several witnesses allege the vehicle went through a four-way stop sign and hit the boy, who was riding his bike. </P> <P>Witnesses said the boy was in kindergarten, and was about five years-old. </P> <P>They say he was killed instantly. </P> <P>Throngs of neighbourhood children were playing in the nearby park at the time, including friends of the victim who went for an ice cream with the boy just one hour earlier. </P> <P>A woman phoned 911 while her husband covered the boy's body with a shirt. </P> <P>She and other witnesses allege the tow truck driver attempted to flee the scene, but was restrained by a group of area residents until police arrived. </P> <P>Other witnesses said the driver was in the truck sobbing. </P> <P>The boy's family arrived at the accident scene shortly after 8 p.m. hugging and sobbing as police told them what happened.</P>

--30--

Title: 8-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Woman sent to hospital in crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A woman was taken to hospital for an upper-body injury, but was treated and released, after a two-vehicle collision Thursday night in Brandon. </P> <P>One of the vehicles had flipped over onto its roof. </P> <P>Police were called to the 2300-block of Brandon Avenue around 9:30 p.m. on Thursday, where they found a 2001 Jeep TJ on its roof and blocking traffic. </P> <P>An investigation revealed that the Jeep had been travelling west on Brandon Avenue when a 2006 Dodge Ram pickup truck pulled out from the curb in front of the Jeep. The Jeep collided with the driver's side of the pickup and flipped onto its roof, before skidding to a stop. </P> <P>The 23-year-old Brandon woman driving the Jeep was transported to Brandon Regional Health Centre where she was treated and released for an injury to her upper body. </P> <P>The 21-year-old Brandon man driving the pickup submitted to a roadside screening test for alcohol, which resulted in a 24-hour driver's licence suspension. The male subject was also charged under the Highway Traffic Act for turning from a direct line when unsafe to do so.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: A happy child mourned
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>His Mohawk haircut earned him the nickname "Sparky" and he loved riding his bike and playing with his friends. </P> <P>Five-year-old Kristian Mercer's life was cut tragically short Friday evening when he was struck by a Dr. Hook flatbed tow truck across from a busy playground at Charles Street and Manitoba Avenue. </P> <P>Police said the boy was riding his bike south on Charles Street at 7 p.m. when he was hit by the truck travelling westbound on Manitoba Avenue. He was killed instantly. </P> <P>Winnipeg police won't release further details, but confirmed the 52-year-old tow truck driver was interviewed and released, and that "no charges have been laid at this time." </P> <P>Officials from Dr. Hook Towing declined to speak with the Free Press. </P> <P>Kristian's death has prompted an outpouring of grief from neighbourhood residents who say there should be an increased police presence and speed bumps to force drivers to slow down. </P> <P>Residents complain drivers routinely speed through area streets, including some drivers who are cruising for sex-trade workers as young as eight. </P> <P>"They need to be putting up more signs and speed bumps and we need a bigger police presence here," said Rebecca, who did not want her last name used. "(The sex-trade workers) are bringing a lot more traffic." </P> <P>Several witnesses allege a tow truck ran through a four-way stop sign and hit Kristian, crushing his head between the truck's wheels. Throngs of neighbourhood children were playing in nearby Pritchard Park at the time, including friends of Kristian's who had gone for an ice cream and played tag with the boy in the hours leading up to his death. </P> <P>Chasity Thomas's younger sister was in the park and saw the horrific crash. She and other witnesses said Kristian's father was hysterical and had to be restrained by at least six police officers who didn't want him to see the gruesome scene. Thomas said her father took off his shirt to cover Kristian's head and body. </P> <P>"He had his whole life ahead of him," she said. "He's such a nice boy." </P> <P>On Saturday morning, a crowd of neighbourhood children gathered to lay flowers, stuffed animals and handmade cards next to a Styrofoam cross just steps away from where Kristian died. </P> <P>Thirteen year-old Brandon Woodhouse lit two blue candles at the memorial and said he watched the tow truck run through a stop sign and drag the boy down the street. "We're cruising around (on our bikes) and half an hour later we split up and all I saw was a tow truck coming," he said. "(The truck) didn't even bother to stop. It dragged him down the road." </P> <P>Kristian's family declined to comment Saturday and area neighbours who spoke with his relatives said they are overcome with grief and struggling to process the tragic loss of their youngest child. </P> <P>Kristian had just graduated from nursery school at David Livingstone, and a school official who knocked on the family's door Saturday afternoon confirmed grief counsellors and other crisis supports will be available for students on Monday. </P> <P>Manitoba House drop-in centre coordinator Rachel Wood said she never saw Kristian without a smile on his face, and that he will be missed by the entire neighbourhood. </P> <P>"He was very energetic and he was always in a good mood," Wood said, noting Kristian loved to play, read books and sometimes just sit and talk. "He was full of life. All of the kids in the neighbourhood are really going to miss him." <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver didn't stop? ; Enforce traffic laws: boy's neighbours
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Residents of a North End neighbourhood want tighter traffic controls in their area after a five-year-old boy was hit and killed by a tow truck on Friday evening. </P> <P>Some witnesses of the collision that killed Kristian Mercer as he rode a bicycle at the corner of Charles Street and Manitoba Avenue suggested more tragedies will follow in the area if the city doesn't clamp down on drivers who speed or run stop signs. </P> <P>Nelson Roulette, whose 11-year-old son saw the horrific collision between the Dr. Hook Towing vehicle and the child at about 7 p.m., was baffled by the mishap. Several witnesses claimed the truck didn't stop at the intersection -- controlled by stop signs -- while kids played nearby. </P> <P>"I don't know how you miss a four-way stop. I don't understand that," Roulette said at the scene. </P> <P>While nearby residents gathered to talk about the crash that instantly killed Mercer, young friends of the victim crowded around a memorial of flowers, cards, toys and stuffed animals placed on a curb. </P> <P>Among the items was a styrofoam cross, adorned with "RIP" and a decal depicting a soccer ball. </P> <P>Relatives of Kristian -- whom some kids said had the nickname Sparky -- have struggled to deal with his death, which came a day after he finished kindergarten. </P> <P>"Obviously, it's horrible. It's unbelievable," said Jack Mercer, a cousin of Kristian's mother. </P> <P>"Nobody is too happy right now. He was a good happy kid, five years old. And he was very good-looking." </P> <P>Another relative, refusing to give his name, said he's "pretty shocked" about the loss. </P> <P>The crash occurred when the boy was riding south on Charles and hit the truck as it was westbound on Manitoba. </P> <P>City police said they interviewed the truck's 52-year-old male driver and released him. No charges have been laid while a traffic collision unit investigates, said Insp. Kendra Rey. </P> <P>Police said they will provide no further information until Monday. </P> <P>An employee at Dr. Hook said the company is "not making any comment" until at least Monday. </P> <P>The victim's immediate family, whom witnesses said were not with him when the crash occurred, couldn't be found at their nearby house on Selkirk Avenue. </P> <P>Those who saw the crash and its aftermath said it was a grisly scene. </P> <P>"I came and saw everything," Julio Villegas said of the boy's injuries. "It was really bad, his face. The damage was bad." </P> <P>Chip Deschamps, 12, said the sight was "indescribable." </P> <P>Organizers of Manitoba House, a nearby drop-in centre, said they're considering pushing the city to better control reckless drivers. </P> <P>"We'll see what we can do," said a woman with the group, refusing to give her name. </P>

--30--

Title: 11-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Grieving dad trying to stop drunk drivers
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It's been more than seven years since Patrick Mowbray was killed by a drunk driver, yet for his father, Doug Mowbray, every day is still a struggle. </P> <P>Patrick, who had moved to Dryden for the summer to work as a tree planter after finishing the school year at the University of Manitoba, had decided to surprise his family by coming home to Roland, Man., for the weekend. </P> <P>He never made it. </P> <P>"I got a call at 4:30 in the morning that he'd been killed," said Mowbray, a teacher in southern Manitoba. "It still doesn't seem real and it's been seven years. It's tough every day getting up and going to work or doing whatever I have to do and thinking about Patrick. You see your son lying in the morgue and it's hard." </P> <P>That's why Mowbray decided to get involved with Mothers Against Drunk Driving Canada (MADD). Not only does it allow him to meet with others who have had similar experiences, it gives him the chance to try to prevent such tragedies by sharing Patrick's story. </P> <P>Mowbray, now president of MADD Canada's Winnipeg chapter, travels around Manitoba speaking to school groups about drinking and driving. </P> <P>"I don't want anybody else to go through this. Hearing the horror stories that these families are going through, it's just absolutely terrible," Mowbray said. </P> <P>About four people a day are killed and 200 injured in Canada as a result of impaired driving. </P> <P>"Imagine how much heartache that is," Mowbray said. </P> <P>But he believes students are getting the message -- it's a different age group that isn't. </P> <P>"The kids know for the most part... to have a designated driver. The ones that are my age are the ones that are not getting the message," he said. </P> <P>The man who killed Patrick was 47. He died at the scene. </P> <P>In addition to speaking to schools and groups, Mowbray reaches out to other victims, offering support and a shoulder to lean on, and lobbies the government for stricter drunk-driving laws and sentences. He also participates in a group which, twice a year, cleans up the ditches on the highway where Patrick was killed. He said the group collects hundreds of beer cans and alcohol bottles tossed out of car windows by drivers and their passengers. </P> <P>Mowbray said MADD is desperate for new volunteers and needs board members as well as people willing to help with fundraising and highway cleanup. </P> <P>"It's heart-wrenching to think that if we don't get these volunteers coming out that we might have to close our doors. We really need volunteers," Mowbray said. </P> <P>If you would like more information about MADD Canada's Winnipeg chapter, please call Bev at 896-6233. You can also visit the organization online at www. madd.ca. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Grieving residents want speed bumps, police
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: Byline: Jen Skerritt and Nick Martin
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>RESIDENTS of the area where a five-year-old boy died Friday are demanding speed bumps and more police to slow down traffic. </P> <P>Speed bumps work, Coun. Mike Pagtakhan (Point Douglas) said Sunday evening. </P> <P>"In terms of a solution for slowing traffic down, traffic-calming strategies have helped in River Heights and in the Tecumseh Street area around (Health Sciences Centre)," said Pagtakhan. </P> <P>"It's just brutal, what happened," Pagtakhan said. </P> <P>Pagtakhan, chairman of the protection and community services committee, also raised the possibility of auxiliary police officers being assigned to the neighbourhood more frequently. </P> <P>Five-year-old Kristian Mercer's life was cut tragically short Friday evening when he was struck by a Dr. Hook flatbed tow truck across from a busy playground at Charles Street and Manitoba Avenue. </P> <P>Police said the boy was riding his bike south on Charles Street at 7 p.m. when he was hit by the truck travelling west on Manitoba Avenue. He was killed instantly. </P> <P>Winnipeg police confirmed the 52-year-old tow truck driver was interviewed and released. </P> <P>Police said Sunday the investigation is continuing and no charges have been laid. Police said no further details would be released until at least this morning. </P> <P>Officials from Dr. Hook Towing declined to speak with the Free Press. </P> <P>Kristian's death has prompted an outpouring of grief from neighbourhood residents who say there should be an increased police presence and speed bumps to force drivers to slow down. </P> <P>Residents complain drivers routinely speed through area streets, including some drivers who are cruising for sex-trade workers as young as eight. </P> <P>"They need to be putting up more signs and speed bumps and we need a bigger police presence here," said Rebecca, who did not want her last name used. "(The sex-trade workers) are bringing a lot more traffic." </P> <P>Pagtakhan said residents could approach the public works committee if they want speed bumps installed. The city does a traffic analysis and requires support of 70 per cent of a block's residents, he pointed out. Speed bumps cannot be installed on a bus route. </P> <P>Several witnesses allege a tow truck ran through a four-way stop sign and hit Kristian, the truck's wheels running over his head. Throngs of neighbourhood children were playing in nearby Pritchard Park at the time, including friends of Kristian's who had gone for an ice cream and played tag with the boy in the hours leading up to his death. </P> <P>Chasity Thomas's younger sister was in the park and saw the horrific crash. She and other witnesses said Kristian's father was hysterical and had to be restrained by at least six police officers who didn't want him to see the gruesome scene. Thomas said her father took off his shirt to cover Kristian's head and body. </P> <P>On Saturday morning, a crowd of neighbourhood children gathered to lay flowers, stuffed animals and handmade cards next to a Styrofoam cross just steps away from where Kristian died. </P> <P>Thirteen-year-old Brandon Woodhouse lit two blue candles at the memorial and said he watched the tow truck run through a stop sign and drag the boy down the street. "We're cruising around (on our bikes) and half an hour later we split up and all I saw was a tow truck coming," he said. "(The truck) didn't even bother to stop. It dragged him down the road." </P> <P>Kristian's family declined to comment Saturday and area neighbours who spoke with his relatives said they are overcome with grief and struggling to process the tragic loss of their youngest child. </P> <P>Kristian had just graduated from nursery school at David Livingstone School, and a school official who knocked on the family's door Saturday afternoon confirmed grief counsellors and other crisis supports will be available for students and staff this morning. </P>

--30--

Title: 13-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Two cop cars smashed during chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 39 year old man is in custody after a car chase last night that resulted in two police cruisers being hit.</P> <P>The chase began just before midnight at Redwood and Hespeler. The suspect vehicle went on to hit the two police cars before a spike belt was deployed, which ended the chase at Henderson and Springfield.</P> <P>The driver was arrested and charges will be laid. Police can not confirm any injuries at this time.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Serious trauma: cops ; Police offer aid for kids, others who witnessed young boy die after truck hit him
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>City police are offering help to several young kids and others who watched a five-year-old boy die when he was struck by a flatbed tow truck on a North End street Friday night. </P> <P>Most witnesses to the fatal collision were kids, including many friends around the same age, or young adults, said Const. Natalie Aitken, a Winnipeg police spokeswoman. </P> <P>They watched the crash at Manitoba Avenue and Charles Street and saw Kristian Mercer's horrific injuries. </P> <P>"I can't imagine how traumatizing it would be," Aitken said. "They need to seek help if they need it." </P> <P>Parents can call the victim assistance program at 986-6350 if their children need to speak to someone, Aitken said. </P> <P>The scene also took an emotional toll on emergency personnel, she said. </P> <P>Few adults witnessed the crash, Aitken said Monday. </P> <P>This is posing a challenge to investigators as they wade through statements from the young witnesses to make sure the information they provide is accurate. </P> <P>The 52-year-old male driver, a Dr. Hook Towing employee, was interviewed and released. It hasn't been decided whether charges are warranted. </P> <P>Police are asking people for patience because these types of investigations take some time to complete. </P> <P>Investigators believe a vehicle may have travelled east on Manitoba, stopped at the corner and turned south on to Charles just before the crash. </P> <P>Police are asking that vehicle's occupant or occupants to call investigators at 986-6271. </P> <P>The corner is controlled by a four-way stop. </P> <P>Aitken said police haven't confirmed whether the flatbed truck, which was westbound on Manitoba, stopped at the stop sign. Witnesses claimed the driver didn't stop. </P> <P>It doesn't appear the driver was speeding or intoxicated, Aitken said. </P> <P>A Dr. Hook representative declined comment. </P> <P>It was unclear whether Mercer, who was riding his small bicycle south on Charles, was supervised by an adult. </P> <P>Area residents have called for new safety measures such as speed bumps near the intersection, which is bordered by a playground. There has been talk of starting a petition to lobby city hall. </P> <P>Meanwhile, police took a moment Monday to correct inaccurate reports or claims by witnesses. </P> <P>Aitken said the driver stopped at the scene, called for help using his two-way radio and didn't attempt to flee. </P> <P>"The tow truck driver made every effort to stop once they were aware of it," Aitken said. </P> <P>The driver had just finished his shift and was driving to a nearby business, she said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Tow truck driver 'destroyed' after five-year-old's death
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>While a family grieves the loss of a little boy, a friend of the tow truck driver who ran over the child says the collision has left the driver devastated. </P>  <P>Rick Patterson said Monday the 52-year-old driver with Dr. Hook Towing is a father and grandfather who is "destroyed" by Friday's fatal incident in the North End that claimed the life of five-year-old Kristian Mercer. </P>  <P>"Picture yourself running over a little kid and then everybody pointing the finger and blaming you," said Patterson, 46, who's known the driver since he was 17 years old. </P>  <P>Winnipeg police made it clear Monday the driver has not been charged in the death of the boy, adding the man did not attempt to leave the scene, as had been previously reported. </P>  <P>The child was riding a bike Friday evening when he was struck by a flatbed tow truck across from a busy playground at the intersection of Charles Street and Manitoba Avenue. </P>  <P>The boy was killed instantly. </P>  <P>Patterson said the driver hasn't slept since the collision. </P>  <P>"I don't think he'll ever come back (to work)," said Patterson. </P>  <P>Police said he used his two-way radio to call for help after he realized he hit the boy, and did not flee the crash scene. </P>  <P>Patterson said his friend is so upset he's not focusing on the possibility he could still face charges, as the investigation into the fatality continues. </P>  <P>"His prime concern is not what's going to happen to him... it's what he's done." </P>  <P>Police said it's still unclear whether the driver stopped at a four-way stop at Charles and Manitoba before the boy was hit. </P>  <P>Police questioned and then released the driver. </P>  <P>Part of the challenge for investigators will be interviewing children who witnessed the terrible crash. </P>  <P>"Most of our witnesses to this incident are small, very small, children or young adults," said Const. Natalie Aitken, spokeswoman for the Winnipeg Police Service. </P>  <P>"We actually do not have very many adults who have witnessed this." </P>  <P>Aitken said investigators are searching for a vehicle that travelled eastbound on Manitoba Avenue and stopped at Charles Street just before the crash. </P>  <P>The victim's family lives on Selkirk Avenue, about 250 metres from the park. </P>  <P>Family and friends have posted handwritten messages at a roadside memorial set up to honour the life of the little boy, thanking mourners for their gifts of flowers, stuffed animals and handwritten cards. </P>  <P>Kent Dueck, executive director of Aberdeen Avenue's Inner City Youth Alive, said the area needs better traffic signage and speed bumps, as well as vigilant monitoring of children who attempt to navigate the streets themselves. </P>  <P>About 60 to 100 kids come to the centre every day, and Dueck said the kids need better crosswalks. </P>  <P>Luis Escobar, manager of transportation for the city's public works department, said the public has not made any requests for a traffic study to determine if speed bumps or other traffic-calming measures are needed near where the crash occurred.<BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 16-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man arrested after police pursuit
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 39-year-old man was arrested after leading police on a pursuit of a stolen car.</P> <P>The chase began just before midnight Sunday on Hespeler Avenue near Beatrice Street in the city's Elmwood neighbourhood.</P> <P>It ended on Henderson Highway and Springfield Road in the city's North Kildonan neighbourhood after the stolen car drove over a spike belt.</P> <P>Speeds reached about 80 kilometres an hour, police said.</P> <P>A police cruiser and the stolen vehicle both have minor damage.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/28/mb-stolen-car-pursuit-winnipeg.html#ixzz0sFMiR1Mb">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/28/mb-stolen-car-pursuit-winnipeg.html#ixzz0sFMiR1Mb</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: B.C. to tighten drinking-driving rules
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>B.C. authorities kicked off the annual Counterattack campaign Monday to combat drinking-and-driving, this year targeting a new set of impaired drivers. </P> <P>Starting this fall, drivers who are tested and caught in what's now called the "warning range" of .05 to .08 blood alcohol will face an immediate three-day driving ban and $200 fine for a first offence. </P> <P>During the summer, police will be reminding people who test within that range that the new penalties will be in effect within months. </P> <P>The legal blood alcohol limit before impaired driving charges can be laid is .08 </P> <P>Driving with a blood-alcohol content between .05 and .08 means you are seven times more likely to be involved in a fatal crash than if you were driving without having consumed any alcohol at all, the Insurance Corp. of B.C. (ICBC) said in a release. </P> <P>The new law will come as a shock to those who feel having a few drinks is acceptable before getting behind the wheel, according to ICBC's Nicholas Jimenez. </P> <P>"A lot of people today have internalized this notion that, 'I would never drive drunk, but absolutely I can drive after a couple of beers,'" said Jimenez. </P> <P>"But what we're trying to say is that even after your first drink, you're drinking and driving, and the new tools the government has put in place in terms of legislation are going to make sure you feel that." </P> <P>There are about 5,000 alcohol-related crashes in B.C. every year, causing about 155 deaths and 3,000 injuries, according to ICBC's website. </P> <P>The government of B.C. has not specified when this fall the new drinking and driving regulations would take effect. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 18-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 250 vehicles in province torched every year: MPI
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A cruel firing. A nasty divorce. Unpaid drug debts. They're all reasons why arsonists torch about 250 vehicles in the province each year, according to Manitoba Public Insurance. </P>  <P>Investigators with MPI say they regularly see vehicles destroyed by arsonists, often as a mode of payback. </P>  <P>"There's a multitude of reasons why," said George Murray, a former Winnipeg Police Service officer who's worked as a fire investigator for MPI's special investigation unit since 2007. </P>  <P>"Relationship problems, drug problems, financial reasons, getting back (at) an employer (who) fires somebody, just guys who want to get that person out of their hair." </P>  <P>MPI said they see about 1,200 claims per year for vehicles wrecked by fire, but officials suspect only some are directly linked to arson. </P>  <P>Most blazes are caused by faulty repair work or electrical problems. </P>  <P>Murray and his two fellow investigators examine vehicle wreckage for evidence the blaze was intentionally set, looking for tip-offs like unusual burn patterns or accelerants that show someone intentionally lit the car on fire. </P>  <P>"To say it was arson, you can pretty well do most of the time," he said. "Who committed the act is the tough part." </P>  <P>In an estimated 20 per cent of cases, investigators successfully determine the fire is an arson and who is responsible. That opens the door for MPI to pursue the arsonist in civil court, or for the driver to potentially face criminal charges. </P>  <P>Murray said it's not necessarily a vehicle's owner or insurance claimant that may be responsible for lighting a fire. About 60 to 70 per cent of those arsons are not started by the vehicle owner, Murray estimated. </P>  <P>"The suspect can be anybody," he said, saying investigators don't "fixate" on the owner. </P>  <P>"Not every car fire is the owner trying to burn their vehicle." </P>  <P>He said the chances of successfully solving an arson case have improved with the increased use of vehicle immobilizers. That's because arsonists light vehicles on fire where they're parked, instead of taking them and abandoning them in remote places. </P>  <P>If firefighters can quickly arrive and out the blaze, evidence survives. </P>  <P>"If there's nothing left to investigate, there's nothing you can do," he said. "You have to have some kind of evidence that you can look at." </P>  <P>Investigators at the MPI's special investigations unit also probe suspicious claims of hit and run, auto theft, or staged collisions. </P>  <P><A href="mailto:gabrielle.giroday@freepress.mb.ca">gabrielle.giroday@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P>  <P>Dude, did you burn my car? </P>  <P>Investigators look at some of these factors to determine if a vehicle fire was arson: </P>  <P>Presence of accelerants. That's fancy lingo for materials like turpentine or diesel fuel in places they normally shouldn't be. </P>  <P>Burn patterns or pooling of accelerants on car seats or carpets. </P>  <P>The owner's history. Investigators might take a long look at criminal records or credit history for background. </P>  <P>Investigators look at marks made during the fire to see where it started. That's what investigators call the "seat" of the fire. <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 19-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Fiery confession ; Man admits torching car of girlfriend's father but judge puzzled
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg man has been fined $750 after admitting he torched a car belonging to his girlfriend's father nearly five years ago. </P> <P>Jessie Krause, 26, pleaded guilty last week to fraud under $5,000. </P> <P>Krause came forward to police last October and confessed his part in the insurance scam, court was told. </P> <P>"Without his confession, they had no case," said defence lawyer Don Mokriy. </P> <P>Judge Ray Wyant commended Krause for his honesty but was clearly puzzled as to what motivated him to confess to the crime. </P> <P>Krause provided a tearful, confusing explanation that seemed to suggest his confession was connected to an ongoing custody battle and an effort to regain his driver's licence. </P> <P>Krause's then father-in-law asked him in August 2005 "if he could help him get rid of his vehicle so he could claim the insurance money," Crown attorney Vic Bellay told court. Krause agreed to "steal" the man's 1995 Crown Victoria and set it on fire for $100. </P> <P>On Sept. 26, 2005, the older man called Krause and said "this would be a good day to burn the vehicle," Bellay said. The man provided Krause with gloves and two roadside flares. Krause then drove the car to a parking lot in East St. Paul where he ignited the flares in the front and back seats. A passerby reported the fire to East St. Paul police. </P> <P>The older man reported the vehicle stolen and Manitoba Public Insurance paid him $3,400. </P> <P>The older man has denied any involvement in the fraud, court heard. He has not been arrested and the matter remains under investigation. </P> <P>Krause has already begun repaying MPI, Mokriy said. </P> <P>"It seems to me it was a lot to do for a little bit of money," Wyant told Krause. "It looks like you are shouldering the full responsibility at this point." </P> <P>MPI investigates approximately 250 fire claims a year, many of which turn out to be arson. </P> <P>According to an MPI news release, fire investigators last year saved the public insurer $2 million in claims later determined to be the result of arson or faulty mechanical repairs. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg tow truck driver who ran over boy, 5, said to be 'destroyed'
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - A friend of the tow truck driver who hit a child riding a bicycle in a Winnipeg neighbourhood says the man is devastated by what happened. </P> <P>Rick Patterson says the 52-year-old driver with Dr. Hook Towing is a father and grandfather who is ``destroyed'' by the collision that killed five-year-old Kristian Mercer. </P> <P>The boy died instantly Friday evening when he was struck by a flatbed tow truck across from a busy playground. </P> <P>Police have made it clear that the driver has not been charged. </P> <P>They say he used his two-way radio to call for help after he realized he had struck the boy and did not flee the crash scene, as had been reported. </P> <P>Patterson said the driver hasn't slept since the collision. </P> <P>"Picture yourself running over a little kid and then everybody pointing the finger and blaming you,'' said Patterson, 46, who's known the driver since he was 17 years old. </P> <P>"I don't think he'll ever come back (to work).'' </P> <P>Patterson said his friend is so upset he's not focusing on the possibility he could still face charges. </P> <P>"His prime concern is not what's going to happen to him... it's what he's done.'' </P> <P>Police have questioned the driver, but said it's still unclear whether he stopped at a four-way stop before the boy was hit. </P> <P>Part of the challenge for investigators will be interviewing children who witnessed the terrible crash, said a police spokeswoman. </P> <P>"Most of our witnesses to this incident are small, very small, children or young adults,'' said Const. Natalie Aitken. "We actually do not have very many adults who have witnessed this.'' </P> <P>The boy's family lives about 250 metres from the park where the accident occurred. Family and friends have posted handwritten messages at a roadside memorial. </P> <P>Kent Dueck, executive director of Aberdeen Avenue's Inner City Youth Alive, said the area needs more traffic signs and speed bumps, as well as vigilant monitoring of children who attempt to navigate the streets themselves. </P> <P>Luis Escobar, manager of transportation for the city's public works department, said the public has not made any requests for a traffic study to determine if speed bumps or other measures are needed. near where the crash occurred.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 21-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Boy survives being thrown from truck
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 23-month-old child who was ejected from a pickup truck in a two-vehicle crash near Miami last week wasn't restrained in a child car seat, RCMP say. </P> <P>The child has been released from a Winnipeg hospital and is expected to make a full recovery despite being thrown from the truck, police said Tuesday. A pet dog was killed. </P> <P>The toddler was taken to Boundary Trails Health Centre near Morden and Winkler and then Health Sciences Centre in Winnipeg after the collision. </P> <P>Carman RCMP said the child was in an eastbound pickup truck driven by his 27-year-old father when it went through a stop sign at Road 29 North and was struck on the passenger side by a northbound car Friday at 9:30 a.m. </P> <P>The intersection is about six kilometres north of Miami, which is about 100 kilometres southwest of Winnipeg. RCMP said the toddler's father and a 17-year-old boy who was driving the car suffered minor injuries but a dog in the pickup truck was killed. </P> <P>Alcohol, weather and road conditions aren't considered contributing factors. </P> <P>Charges haven't been laid but the investigation continues. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Getting back at the boss or an ex often reason for vehicle arsons: MPI
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - Manitoba Public Insurance says nasty divorces, fired employees and unpaid drug debts are some reasons why 250 vehicles are torched in the province each year. </P> <P>Investigators with the Crown-owned insurance company say they regularly see vehicles destroyed by arsonists who have vengeance in mind. </P> <P>George Murray, who works as an MPI fire investigator, says about 60 to 70 per cent of the arsons are not started by the vehicle owner. </P> <P>In an estimated 20 per cent of cases, investigators successfully determine the fire is an arson and who is responsible. </P> <P>Murray says vehicle immobilizers are helping investigators because the devices force arsonists to torch vehicles where they sit, meaning more evidence if the fire is doused in time. </P> <P>MPI gets about 1,200 claims every year for burned vehicles, but most of the fires are caused by electrical problems or faulty repair work. (Winnipeg Free Press) <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 23-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Party-bus checks set ; Inspections ruining business, says owner
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>City police are holding another round of roadside inspections of privately owned party buses, limos and taxis -- the kind of inspections one local owner and critic says is ruining his business. </P> <P>Daniel Hince, owner of A-List Transportation, said his stretch Hummer limousine has been OK'd during inspections by Manitoba Public Insurance and a General Motors garage, yet it fails Winnipeg Police Service's random inspections and is taken off the road. </P> <P>"They're going to do it again and ruin our Saturday," Hince said. "Our vehicle is safe." </P> <P>Hince said the limo passed an MPI inspection about a week before it failed a police inspection and was towed June 12. </P> <P>Police told him the vehicle failed because of issues with its steering system. Hince said MPI and GM inspections found no steering problems. </P> <P>Police spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen said a commercial passenger vehicle is taken off the road if it fails inspection due to a serious mechanical problem. </P> <P>Police served notice Wednesday the vehicle inspection unit and its partners, including MPI and the Taxicab Board, is conducting inspections this weekend. </P> <P>Police say they aren't party poopers -- the inspections are done in the name of safety and no one is unfairly targeted. </P> <P>Officers will be looking for vehicles that don't meet industry safety standards, or where passengers are drinking alcohol. </P> <P>Hince said the spat has been costly -- he's spent hundreds of dollars on independent inspections, towing fees, costs to return the vehicle to service and cancelled bookings -- and he's considered following others who left the industry. </P> <P>He got rid of his party bus months ago. </P> <P>Eleven vehicles were inspected by police June 12. </P> <P>Five party buses failed but weren't taken off the road because the violations didn't pose a safety hazard to passengers or other vehicles, police said. </P> <P>Two vehicles had serious mechanical violations and were towed, police said. Hince's limo was one of the two. </P> <P>Thirteen tickets were handed out for offences under the Liquor Control Act and Highway Traffic Act, police said. </P> <P>The inspections don't just extend to companies. For example, police can inspect a bus owned by a citizen who uses it to shuttle buddies to an event, Michalyshen said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 24-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen truck batters house ; Driver fleeing from police
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A stolen pickup truck plowed into a West End house early Saturday while its driver tried to evade city police, destroying the home's living room wall. </P> <P>Officers in several cars rushed to the home in the 800-block of St. Matthews Avenue about 4:40 a.m. and apprehended the driver, who had fled from cops with a passenger in the 2008 Dodge Ram -- hitting a police cruiser while doing so -- after being pulled over near the intersection of Portage Avenue and Lipton Street. </P> <P>"I heard the bang, and then police got out with their guns," nearby resident Bill Thomson said of the ruckus when the truck went through his neighbour's wall, after failing to make a turn from Banning Street onto St. Matthews. </P> <P>"It shattered the window and wrecked the wall below," Peter Ogrodnik, another neighbour, said of the vehicle. </P> <P>Neither the house's 83-year-old female owner nor the truck's two male occupants -- the alleged 16-year-old driver and 19-year-old passenger -- were injured, said police Const. Jason Michalyshen. </P> <P>Disturbance call </P> <P>Police had pursued the truck -- which was reported stolen hours earlier near Selkirk -- from the corner of Portage and Lipton after initially responding to a disturbance call involving the pickup on nearby Chestnut Street in Wolseley. </P> <P>"There were some youths in the area, yelling and screaming, as well as a vehicle being driven erratically," Michalyshen said of the scene in Wolseley. </P> <P>The truck was driven dangerously during the brief chase after its driver took off from where officers had pulled it over on Portage. </P> <P>"He went through several stop signs," Michalyshen said. </P> <P>A daughter of the homeowner said "the whole wall caved in" when the truck plowed into it. </P> <P>"It threw everything around in the living room," she said, asking that her name not be published. </P> <P>The crash occurred on the day that its owner was to host a family member from Italy for dinner. </P> <P>A police canine unit was used to chase down the suspects after they ran from the crash scene. The 16-year-old is in custody facing charges of theft over $5,000, fleeing from police, dangerous operation of a vehicle, assault with a weapon and other offences including a breach of a court order. </P> <P>Police released the truck's passenger without charges. </P>

--30--

Title: 25-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Collision sends man to hospital
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An elderly man was taken to hospital after his vehicle smashed into a garage in Brandon late Wednesday night. </P> <P>Police were called to the scene of the single-vehicle collision on Whiteshell Way about 11 p.m. </P> <P>The Brandon Police Service said the vehicle was headed west when the driver apparently hit the gas pedal instead of the brake and lost control. The vehicle hit the side of a garage, causing extensive damage to the structure and "considerable" damage to a vehicle inside the garage, police said. </P> <P>The 84-year-old driver was transported to the Brandon Regional Health Centre with a possible hand injury, police said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police chase in Winnipeg ends in charges
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 16-year-old youth faces a litany of charges after a high-speed police chase in Winnipeg early Thursday.</P> <P>Police responded around 4:40 a.m. to the 200 block of Chestnut Street in the Wolseley neighbourhood to investigate reports of a black pickup truck being driven erratically.</P> <P>When officers tried to pull the truck over at Portage Avenue and Lipton Street, it rammed a police cruiser and sped off. Later, following a short chase, the suspect vehicle went out of control and smashed into a house at Banning Street and St. Matthews Avenue in the West End.</P> <P>Both the truck, which was stolen, and the house were damaged extensively.</P> <P>No one was hurt.</P> <P>Police said the driver of the suspect vehicle, 16, took off on foot but was arrested a short time later with the help of a police dog.</P> <P>The youth faces numerous charges including theft over $5,000, flight from a police officer, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle, mischief and assault with a weapon.</P> <P>A passenger in the vehicle also was arrested but later released.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/01/mb-police-chase-crash.html#ixzz0sWwu0d9b">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/01/mb-police-chase-crash.html#ixzz0sWwu0d9b</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Perimeter Highway re-opens after rollover
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A garbage truck driver was injured when his vehicle rolled over on the south Perimeter Highway Wednesday afternoon.</P> <P>RCMP said about 4:30 p.m. on Wednesday the truck rolled over near the Brady Road Landfill site.</P> <P>Police, fire, and ambulance were at the scene and the westbound lane, partially blocked, was to be re-opened around 7 p.m.</P> <P>No other vehicles were involved in the collision.</P> <P>The driver of the garbage truck was taken to hospital with non life-threatening injuries.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/30/mb-garbage-truck-rollover.html#ixzz0sWx7Izmo">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/06/30/mb-garbage-truck-rollover.html#ixzz0sWx7Izmo</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Truck Crashes Into House After High Speed Chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Winnipeg police have 2 males in custody after a wild high speed chase this morning ended with a pickup truck crashing into the side of a house.<BR>Police say they tried to pull over a black truck driving erratically near Chestnut Street and Portage Avenue around 4:45 a.m.<BR>The vehicle wouldn't stop and the chase was on.<BR>The suspect vehicle blew through a couple of stop signs and finally crashed into a house at Banning Street and St. Matthews Avenue.<BR>There were no injuries, but the truck left a gaping hole in the side of the house.<BR>Police arrested 2 males after a short foot chase.<BR>

--30--

Title: 29-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: SHILO MAN DEAD AFTER SINGLE-VEHICLE CRASH
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Shilo man is dead after a pickup truck rolled near the western Manitoba community early Saturday. </P> <P>RCMP were called to the scene of the single-vehicle crash on Provincial Road 340, roughly 9.5 km south of Shilo, in the Rural Municipality of Cornwallis about 4:25 a.m. </P> <P>Police said a grey 1993 Toyota Tacoma was headed north from Wawanesa when the driver lost control and the truck rolled three times. </P> <P>The 21-year-old driver, a Shilo man, was pronounced dead in hospital. The truck's other occupant, a 21-year-old Brandon man, was treated in hospital for minor injuries and released. </P> <P>The name of the man killed is not being released pending permission from his family, RCMP said. </P> <P>Alcohol is suspected to have been a factor in the rollover, while poor driving and road conditions due to a violent thunderstorm taking place at the time are considered contributing factors, police said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Jun-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CAR RAMS INTO DOWNTOWN POLE
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>City police are investigating after a vehicle slammed into a pole near the intersection of Graham Avenue and Donald Street early Sunday. </P> <P>About 4:15 a.m., patrolling police spotted the vehicle being driven at a high rate of speed near Hargrave Street and St. Mary Avenue. Shortly after, the vehicle collided with the pole and several males ran away from the damaged vehicle, police said. </P> <P>Police continue to investigate but it had yet to be determined Sunday whether the vehicle was stolen. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Doctor dies in motorcycle crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Flin Flon doctor was killed in a motorcycle crash near the northern Manitoba city early Friday, RCMP say. </P> <P>Johannes Groenewald, 43, died when his northbound motorcycle went out of control, left the road and landed in a ditch. RCMP said the crash occurred on Highway 10 near the Schist Lake causeway, located south of Flin Flon, about 12:25 a.m. </P> <P>Groenewald was taken to hospital, where he was pronounced dead. An autopsy is scheduled. </P> <P>There were no other vehicles or passengers involved in the crash, RCMP said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 2-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Collision with freight train kills driver
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 28-year-old man was killed when his car collided with a freight train east of Dauphin on Canada Day, RCMP say. </P> <P>Wan Loan (Ronald) Chan of Dauphin died in hospital, police said. </P> <P>The crash occurred on a rural road about two kilometres south of Highway 20 on Thursday about 9 p.m. </P> <P>RCMP said a black Mitsubishi car was crossing the railroad tracks with it collided with an eastbound CN Rail train. Chan was extricated from the car and taken to Dauphin Regional Health Centre.</P>

--30--

Title: 3-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Alcohol may be factor in two-vehicle crash: cops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Alcohol is believed to have been a factor in a two-vehicle crash in Portage la Prairie on Thursday night. </P> <P>RCMP said the crash happened about 8:30 p.m. </P> <P>Police said a 1998 Ford Explorer headed south on the Yellowquill Trail failed to stop when crossing the Trans-Canada Highway. The sport utility vehicle was hit by a 2001 Pontiac Montana minivan headed east. </P> <P>The 45-year-old driver of the Montana and his three passengers -- an woman, 17-year-old girl and a 15-year-old male, all from Alberta --were transported to Portage General Hospital with non-life threatening injuries. </P> <P>The sole occupant of the SUV, a 35-year-old man from the Rural Municipality of Portage la Prairie, was also taken to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries. </P> <P>RCMP said charges are pending in the collision and alcohol is considered to have been a factor. </P>

--30--

Title: 4-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Data will show if law is working: CAA  Using handheld cell phones while driving illegal after July 15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Driving is a complex task - and using a cell phone or wireless device when you’re behind the wheel adds yet another distraction to the growing list that motorists already deal with, says CAA Manitoba President and CEO Mike Mager. He is optimistic Manitoba’s new law to ban the use of such devices while driving will have a positive effect on road safety. The law takes effect July 15.</P> <P>“It only takes a split second to have an accident,” Mager said. “That’s why CAA Manitoba has always reminded motorists about the dangers of distracted driving. We support this new law because it reminds motorists to shut out those distractions and focus on the main job while behind the wheel: driving.”</P> <P>Mager said CAA members - with almost 200,000 in Manitoba - overwhelmingly identified distracted driving as the number one road safety issue in a recent poll. Of all driver distractions, text messaging is particularly concerning because it requires an additional cognitive draw that most other distractions do not.</P> <P>Mager also says close monitoring of the number of infractions will be a key factor in the effectiveness of the new law.</P> <P>“We need to know just how serious a problem this is in Manitoba,” Mager said. “How else are we going to determine if the public is getting the message and acting on it?”</P> <P>Mager notes that other jurisdictions have passed similar laws, but don’t collect the data needed to get a detailed picture of what’s really ‘happening on the street.’ </P> <P>“We need information. That’s the tool that will tell us whether this law is actually working and help guide us in making it work even better in the future.”</P> <P>If analysis shows the ban isn’t working, Mager says the law will need to be re-examined, possibly strengthened with demerits or extended to graduated licensees to add a further deterrence factor.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: MAN CRUSHED TO DEATH BENEATH CAR HE WAS FIXING
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 45-year-old Winnipeg man was found crushed to death Monday morning beneath a vehicle he was apparently working on. </P> <P>The man was found pinned beneath a vehicle behind a business on Gunn Road, located in north Transcona on the border between the city and the RM of Springfield. </P> <P>RCMP Const. Miles Hiebert said "there are indications that the man may have been at the location for a number of days before being located." </P> <P>He was found about 7 a.m. Monday morning. </P> <P>Hiebert said the initial investigation has found that the man appeared to be working underneath the vehicle when the jack supports gave way and the vehicle fell on him. </P> <P>The man is not associated with the business and appeared to be using the space behind the building to do the repairs, Hiebert said. </P> <P>The man's name has not been released. </P>

--30--

Title: 6-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Have your say: MADD not a pawn
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Re: Drunk driver who killed woman seeks lighter term (June 19). On behalf of the board, members and volunteers of the Winnipeg Chapter of MADD Canada (Mothers Against Drunk Driving), let me clarify a few of the items that appeared in the above story. </P> <P>The MADD Winnipeg Chapter and MADD Canada office have had no contact with Hugo Sergio Ruizfuentes or his lawyer. If either of them had actually contacted MADD, they would have been told we do not accept support or assistance of any kind from criminals convicted of impaired driving or those charged with the crime in the furtherance of our mission, which is to stop impaired driving and support victims of this violent crime. </P> <P>Please don't lose sight of the true victims in this case. The Stoller family has lost forever their mother and grandmother. The larger Winnipeg community has lost a dedicated community member as a result of this preventable crime. </P> <P>MADD Canada and MADD Winnipeg chapter have always sought out the involvement and support of the broader community because impaired driving affects all of us. We refuse, however, to be used as pawns by anyone who is seeking to lighten their court-imposed sentence by invoking our name. </P> <P>DOUG MOWBRAY <BR>MADD Winnipeg Chapter <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Nude man hit by Pembina bus wore only a gold bracelet
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A naked man who was apparently hit by a bus on Pembina Highway Monday morning was taken to hospital in unstable condition. </P>  <P>The incident occurred shortly after 10 a.m. Monday on Pembina right at the Jubilee underpass. </P>  <P>A woman who assisted the man at the scene said he was breathing but unconscious, and was covered in bruises and scrapes. </P>  <P>The woman said -- although she didn't witness the accident -- that it appeared he had jumped over the guardrail off a grassy berm at the northwestern corner of the underpass, landing directly in the path of a bus that was southbound on Pembina. </P>  <P>FEW OFFERED HELP </P>  <P>She said the man appeared to be in his 20s. </P>  <P>"He was completely naked except for a gold bracelet on his wrist," said the woman, who didn't want her name used. </P>  <P>The woman said a few people helped out during the bizarre scene, with one woman taking it upon herself to direct traffic away from the man and another trying to cover him up with a shirt. </P>  <P>The woman herself went to help the injured man. </P>  <P>"I put my hand over his mouth and I felt hot air," she said. "I was prepared to do CPR but once I knew he was breathing I just tried to comfort him. I just kept squeezing his hand and talking into his ear." </P>  <P>The woman said few people offered to help the man in the seven-plus minutes it took for the paramedics to arrive. </P>  <P>"It was pretty upsetting," she said. "What bothered me is nobody would do anything." </P>  <P>A police spokesman said officers are investigating the incident and releasing more information as it becomes available. <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 8-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Investigation unit saves you cash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance and its ratepayers saved more than $2,000,000 last year as the result of successful fire investigations by the public auto insurer’s Special Investigation Unit (SIU).</P> <P>Of the nearly 250 vehicle fire investigations, SIU investigators were able to determine many of these vehicle fires were the direct result of arson, or faulty mechanical repairs.</P> <P>MPI’s SIU has three investigators dedicated exclusively to vehicle fire investigations. These investigators - all former members of the Winnipeg Police Service - have extensive field experience, in addition to successfully completing several vehicle fire investigation courses. These fire investigators also have the necessary experience and credentials to testify as an “expert” witness in a criminal trial.</P> <P>“Vehicles typically don’t go up in flames,” explained SIU director Tim Arnason. “When a fire claim is opened our SIU staff will attempt to determine both causation and origin. Many fire claims are confirmed not to be the fault of the vehicle owner, but a mechanical issue.”</P> <P>Fire investigation is only one component of the SIU, which investigates any claim deemed to be of a suspicious nature: bodily injury, hit and run, auto theft, vandalism, suspected staged accidents or other forms of auto insurance fraud.</P> <P>Last year the SIU investigated about 2,750 claims, resulting in savings of nearly $9.3 million for the public auto insurer and its ratepayers.</P> <P>Anyone knowing someone who is involved in auto insurance fraud is encouraged to call MPI’s TIPS Line toll-free 1.877.985.8477.</P> <P>All calls are anonymous.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: IMPAIRED DRIVING acquittal Mountie's actions in arrest 'excessive'
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>BRANDON -- A Brandon man has been acquitted of impaired driving on his snow machine because an RCMP constable went too far when he pulled his gun on the accused, a provincial court judge has ruled. </P>  <P>Judge John Combs acquitted Joel Donald Kempthorne, 49, of impaired driving and driving with his blood alcohol level over the legal limit, because the arresting officer's actions were "excessive." </P>  <P>The judge said the nervous constable could have waited for backup to arrive, instead of trying to arrest Kempthorne and his buddy by himself. </P>  <P>"His doing so with his firearm pointed at them was, in my view, unnecessary and potentially very dangerous," Combs stated in a written decision delivered this week. </P>  <P>Kempthorne and his friend were arrested in the early morning of Jan. 6, 2008. </P>  <P>During his trial on Dec. 16, 2009 and March 24 of this year, Kempthorne testified that he and a friend went on a snowmobile ride. </P>  <P>He had a beer before leaving Brandon, then four drinks during two hours at a Carberry bar. </P>  <P>Kempthorne and his buddy then rode away from the bar, stopping just outside Carberry, where they had two beers each. </P>  <P>Kempthorne also swigged from a bottle of schnapps after his snowmobile got stuck at that spot. </P>  <P>It was then that he and his friend were arrested. Kempthorne testified that a pistol was put to his neck as he lay on the ground. </P>  <P>The arresting officer told court he pulled out his gun because he was concerned for his safety. He believed he was dealing with two riders who had "fled" after the officer spotted them in Carberry. </P>  <P>Combs ruled that the officer didn't have reasonable grounds to conclude Kempthorne was one of the elusive snowmobile riders. </P>  <P>At the time, Kempthorne was told he was being arrested after showing signs of impairment and because he was found with a quarter-full bottle of schnapps and a pair of beers. </P>  <P>Breathalyzer tests later placed his blood-alcohol level at more than double the legal limit. </P>  <P>Combs agreed Crown attorney Garry Rainnie proved Kempthorne's blood-alcohol level was over the legal limit when he rode his machine. </P>  <P>However, the evidence of impairment and the breathalyzer results can't be accepted, Combs ruled. </P>  <P>The gunpoint arrest was arbitrary and unnecessary and breached Kempthorne's rights under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the judge wrote. </P>  <P>"The public would be concerned if evidence was admitted which was obtained in the manner of this case." <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 10-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Have your say: Tired of MPI
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I am one of many Manitobans tired of overpaying for car and motorcycle insurance. Manitoba Public Insurance uses our own dollars to keep telling us how reasonable rates are. If that were true, the poor service we receive from MPI would surely match the rates. However, it is not true. </P> <P>If MPI is actually so fantastic, why do we not allow private insurers in to give consumers a choice? It's high time for the lumbering dinosaur that is MPI to sink into oblivion, and let consumers choose from private insurers. </P> <P>DAVID LEDUCHOWSKI <BR>Teulon </P>

--30--

Title: 11-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Polite purloiner of tires took time to say sorry
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Call this the Case of the Polite Purloiner. </P>  <P>Monday morning, Michelle McDonald peeked out the window of her Wolseley house, looked straight at the truck she had borrowed from her dad and realized something was very wrong. </P>  <P>"The two front tires were missing and the truck was up on blocks," the school teacher said. "This took some planning." </P>  <P>The truck isn't usually at her house. McDonald borrowed it from her dad to use while she was repairing her garage. Dad was out at the lake and she was supposed to come pick him up when she was done with her reno work. </P>  <P>Since McDonald doesn't own the truck, she doesn't think anyone was casing the vehicle or her house. It was a crime of opportunity, apparently committed by someone armed with concrete blocks and the tools needed to remove a tire. </P>  <P>She parked the Grand Cherokee sometime after 9 p.m. and saw it again at 7:30 a.m. A neighbour told her later he'd seen two men on the street around 3 a.m. He called police, but isn't sure if they responded. He couldn't provide a useful description of the pair. </P>  <P>After the shock wore off, McDonald took a closer look at the truck. </P>  <P>"There was a note on the windshield," she said. </P>  <P>In fact, the note was clearly written and here's the punchline: It was signed. </P>  <P>"Thanks for lending me your tires in a time of need," it read. "Much appreciated. Times get hard!" </P>  <P>(We'll call the Polite Purloiner Buddy as, for legal reasons, we aren't going to say whose signature was on the note.) </P>  <P>What kind of need? The kind where two of your tires go flat and you need to replace them in a hurry? The kind where times are hard for you, but not for someone else? Does this imply the tires are going to be returned? </P>  <P>McDonald Googled the name, but didn't come up with any matches. I did some minor sleuthing (by opening the phone book) and found one possible Buddy. </P>  <P>On Monday night, he was home with his family. He doesn't find it a little bit funny that someone would sign his name to the note. </P>  <P>"I have no idea how this happened," he said. "My friends wouldn't do it. That's just the oddest thing." </P>  <P>Buddy drives a Lincoln Mark LT truck. It has 37-inch tires. McDonald's truck tires were smaller. There is no reason to believe he stole the tires. </P>  <P>As a complete coincidence, the Manitoba Public Insurance website shows someone charged with fraud in the past whose name matches that of the signature left by the Polite Purloiner. </P>  <P>This is not to say there is any connection between that Buddy and the Buddy who supposedly stole the tires. </P>  <P>Who steals just the front tires from a truck? If it's kids out for a joyride, they'll take the vehicle. If they want to steal whatever's inside, they'll smash a window. In this case, all they wanted were the two tires. </P>  <P>A police source said this is not the first time tires have been stolen, although there's no crime wave. </P>  <P>"It truly is amazing what some people will steal," the source said. </P>  <P>McDonald has filed an Autopac claim. Monday morning, she was waiting for a tow truck to come pick up the truck. Dad's still stuck at the lake, so she's going to rent a car and pick him up. She was surprisingly calm about the whole thing. </P>  <P>When she reported the theft to police, she says the operator "sounded surprised" at the crime and the alleged letter of confession. </P>  <P>Of course she was surprised. If the Polite Purloiner who stole the tires and left the note put his real name on it, he belongs in the annals of dumb criminals. And if, as is likely, this was just a stupid prank and a thief used a false name, there are a few Buddys who would like a word with you. </P>  <P>Please return Michelle McDonald's tires in her time of need. Thank you. <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 12-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Girl, 4, hurt when SUV rear-ends semi
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A four-year-old girl was injured Wednesday morning when the SUV she was riding in rear-ended a semi on the Perimeter Highway. </P> <P>RCMP said Wednesday afternoon that the girl and a 54-year-old St. Andrews man who was driving the vehicle were taken to hospital with "undisclosed injuries." Mounties did not say whether the girl is related to the driver. </P> <P>The accident occurred about 9:30 a.m. Wednesday near the corner of Sturgeon Road and the North Perimeter, where the man's Ford Escape rear-ended a semi. </P> <P>The semi driver was not hurt. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MADD angry after drunk snowmobiler acquitted - Drove at more than twice the legal limit, but officer's tactics 'excessive'
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Manitoba judge's decision to acquit an intoxicated snowmobiler of drunk driving because of a police officer's tactics has angered members of the Winnipeg chapter of Mothers Against Drunk Driving.</P> <P>On Tuesday, Judge John Combs threw out the impaired-driving case against 49-year-old Joel Kempthorne by ruling the arresting officer used excessive force.</P> <P>Kempthorne and a friend were charged with impaired driving in January 2008 after they got stuck while out snowmobiling near Carberry, Man.</P> <P>Court heard at trial that the officer — who was out on patrol by himself — held his gun to Kempthorne's neck during the arrest over fears for his personal safety.</P> <P>Combs agreed that Crown attorney Gerry Rainey proved Kempthorne's blood-alcohol level was more than twice the legal limit.</P> <P>But he said the gunpoint arrest constituted "excessive force" by the officer and threw out the charges because the officer's conduct violated Kempthorne's fundamental rights.</P> <P>Combs's ruling sends the wrong message to drunk drivers, said MADD spokesman Gordon Kowalchuk.</P> <P>"It's unfortunate that the judge felt that that officer's actions were excessive and that led to the acquittal of a person that was apparently impaired, was operating a motor vehicle and posed a risk to himself and to other members of the public," Kowalchuk said.</P> <P>"It's extremely frustrating. Because if the court finds that the evidence of the impairment is proper and having [accepted] that alcohol has been consumed and that they were driving, it's just sad."</P> <P>The Crown has 30 days to file notice it intends to appeal Combs's ruling.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/07/man-madd-snowmobiler-acquitted.html#ixzz0t6BHl3UR">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/07/man-madd-snowmobiler-acquitted.html#ixzz0t6BHl3UR</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 2 injured after SUV hits semi
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A four-year-old girl and a man, 54, are in hospital after the SUV they were in crashed into the back of a semi-trailer on Winnipeg's outskirts Wednesday morning.</P> <P>RCMP said the crash happened on the north Perimeter Highway near Sturgeon Road just before 9:30 a.m. CT.</P> <P>Police said the man and the girl were in an SUV being driven by the man when it hit the rear end of the semi. Both he and the girl were taken to hospital, but police couldn't comment on the nature or seriousness of their injuries.</P> <P>Police did not identify the victims nor state their relationship to one another.</P> <P>The man is from the community of St. Andrews, just north of Winnipeg, RCMP said.</P> <P>The driver of the semi, a 38-year-old man from Arborg, was uninjured.</P> <P>No other vehicles were involved, police said, and their investigation continues.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/07/man-crash-perimeter-suv-semi.html#ixzz0t6BSdwpK">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/07/man-crash-perimeter-suv-semi.html#ixzz0t6BSdwpK</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Two Hurt In North Perimeter Crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
A 54-year old man and a 4-year old girl were taken to hospital Wednesday morning after a car collided with the back of a semi on the north perimeter near Sturgeon road. It happened around 9:30. RCMP say the man from St. Andrews, and the young girl suffered undetermined injuries. The 38-year old man from Arborg driving the semi was not hurt.  Police are still looking into the nature of the crash.<BR>
