Title: 16-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Autopac gives claim centre to aboriginal-based group
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Manitoba Public Insurance is donating its oldest Winnipeg claim centre to an aboriginal-based, non-profit group. </P>  <P>Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre will move into the King Street building in the North End as soon as possible after selling its current McGregor Street complex and completing renovations, executive director Diane Roussin said Thursday as the donation was announced by the public insurer. </P>  <P>While officially opening the Crown corporation's newest service centre in the 1200-block of Main Street, MPI brass told a crowd of dignitaries and its staff outside that the nearby, approximately 40-year-old complex at 445 King St. -- no longer needed -- will be an ideal site for the Ma Mawi organization to run its various programs for youths and families. </P>  <P>"We have the option of expanding our services and programs if we need that down the road," Roussin said at the new MPI complex. "Everybody wants to work as quickly as we can to get into the building." </P>  <P>Estimated by Roussin at about 17,000 square feet, the old MPI centre will hold offices, training, meetings and programs dealing with family violence, foster care, housing and other matters. </P>  <P>Though Ma Mawi runs programs aimed at preventing what Roussin calls "disruptive behaviours" among youth, MPI president Marilyn McLaren stressed that the donation of the building is not an effort to give the social agency more tools with which to curb vehicle thefts and help the corporation's bottom line. </P>  <P>"Manitoba Public Insurance is pretty pleased with what we've done in terms of auto theft reduction," McLaren said, adding such crimes have decreased "by the tune of about $20 million" per year. "This is not a financial decision." </P>  <P>Construction of the MPI centre on Main -- the first of three to open this summer in Winnipeg, with another slated for start-up in Selkirk next year -- cost about $10 million. <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 17-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI to list naughty auto firms online
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>MANITOBA'S auto businesses better watch out or they could end up on MPI's online naughty list. </P>  <P>Starting Thursday, any administrative sanctions against vehicle dealers, driver-training schools, vehicle and parts recyclers, inspection-station operators and qualified inspection mechanics will be made public on the Manitoba Public Insurance website. </P>  <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said the measure will inspire consumer confidence. </P>  <P>"It allows for customers to educate themselves and make informed consumer choices," Smiley said. "Hopefully it will inspire some companies to do a better job." </P>  <P>Permits are required by any individual or business that provides the services listed. </P>  <P>If these permits are suspended or have been cancelled for lack of due diligence, the names of offenders will now be displayed. </P>  <P>MPI's list currently includes only one business, Gotta-Go Auto Services, whose permit was suspended for inaccurate and incomplete inspections. </P>  <P>Gotta-Go Auto Services could not be reached for comment. </P>  <P>Liz Peters, the public and government affairs manager for CAA Manitoba, said Canadian Automobile Association customers have been advocating for this measure a long time. </P>  <P>"A car is a big purchase for a lot of people," Peters said, "and we constantly get asked questions about how they decide to choose a company." </P>  <P>But the naming and shaming of companies has some business owners wary of unintended consequences. </P>  <P>Leonard Selby owns Selby Truck Service, which performs vehicle inspections, among other things. </P>  <P>"I do good work and rarely have complaints, but this is a job performed by humans and sometimes we make mistakes," Selby said. </P>  <P>But he said what one inspector might pass, another might not, and some vehicles come to the shop with unknown and hidden problems. </P>  <P>"Of course, every inspector should get the major safety concerns," Selby said. "But there are cases when, in fact, the dealer is at fault and has sold a faulty product." </P>  <P>Smiley wants to assure businesses that many steps will be taken before businesses and individuals have their names posted online. </P>  <P>"We check out the history of each business, we check out the work they have done," Smiley said. </P>  <P>You can access the list at <A href="http://www.mpi.mb.ca/AdminDecisions/Sanctions.aspx">www.mpi.mb.ca/AdminDecisions/Sanctions.aspx</A> <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 18-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI reveals chiselers ; Begins identifying shoddy operators online
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Manitoba car dealers, driving trainers and various other providers of automotive-related services are losing a cloak of anonymity that had covered any of their provincial infractions from public view. </P>  <P>Manitoba Public Insurance has begun identifying shoddy operators online, to better protect consumers, their vehicles and their wallets. </P>  <P>"When people are going to part with their money, we want them to have the best information," Justice Minister and Attorney General Andrew Swan told the Winnipeg Sun on Thursday, soon after MPI's website began posting names of people, firms or services whose work has prompted sanctions imposed by the registrar of motor vehicles. </P>  <P>A change to the province's Drivers and Vehicles Act last month has enabled such information to be posted publicly, so that automobile dealers, salespeople, driving schools and their instructors, permit-holding inspection mechanics, vehicle recyclers and the like are identified when they break the law or certain business practices. </P>  <P>"The trend for consumer protection is to let people have the information, so they can make the right choice. And we agreed that until this law was passed, we weren't doing that on that front," said Swan, minister responsible for MPI. "If they're thinking of taking their car, for example, to get a vehicle inspection done, or go to a driver training school, they can see whether any sanctions have been included against those individuals or those companies." </P>  <P>Provincial sanctions might include permit suspensions, cancellations or renewal refusals. </P>  <P>The change is being applauded by the Canadian Automobile Association, whose nearly 200,000 Manitoba members have long asked for such information. </P>  <P>CAA Manitoba spokeswoman Liz Peters said anyone trying to purchase a vehicle or have one repaired is potentially spending a huge sum of money that shouldn't be put at risk simply because he or she doesn't know a service provider has shortcomings cited by the province. </P>  <P>"This is one of the biggest decisions that people anywhere in the country are making. It's a big financial cost to them," she said. "Posting the names of offenders and the businesses online means they will have that more complete information before they go ahead and make that big decision." </P>  <P>Though only one name and firm were listed on the website Thursday, Swan said that "eventually, there will be enough information for Manitobans to make the right choices." </P>  <P>Meanwhile, CAA Manitoba has a list of its approved mechanic shops on its website. <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 19-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI donates claim centre to Ma Mawi
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance has donated a former claims centre in Winnipeg's North End to a grassroots aboriginal group that provides parenting classes and children's activities. <BR>The public insurer said Thursday said its old Autopac claim facility at 445 King Street is being donated to the Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre as it officially opens a new MPI building at 1284 Main Street.</P> <P>Ma Mawi is currently headquartered in a cramped building on McGregor Street.</P> <P>The group also operates a number of satellite centres in the city that provide meals, pow-wow nights and other family support services to people.</P> <P>Volunteer Ken Pickering said the new digs delight him.</P> <P>"It's not going to be just the offices, they're going to other stuff in there as well … They have offices all over the place, but they have stuff for the kids there and that's what's needed around here," he said.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/08/man-mpi-donates-building-ma-mawi.html#ixzz0tBnJEVNH">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/08/man-mpi-donates-building-ma-mawi.html#ixzz0tBnJEVNH</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI To Post Sanctioned Auto Businesses/Services
NEWS_ITM_TXT: If you're in the automobile industry in Manitoba, there's a greater incentive today to stay "above board." An amendment to the Drivers and Vehicles Act is going to make it possible for consumers to see first hand.. who's been operating at less than reputable standards. MPI's website will post all administrative sanctions taken against vehicle dealers and salespeople, as well as driver-training schools, instructors, vehicle and parts recyclers, inspection station operators and qualified inspection mechanics. Business addresses and information about the infraction will also be posted. While the majority of complaints are resolved amicably, when operating permits are suspended or cancelled, the matter will be posted on the website.<BR>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 21-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorists encouraged to respect roadside emergency personnel
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>On any given day in Manitoba, dedicated members of rural fire departments attend to motor vehicle crashes, providing emergency roadside assistance. These highly trained individuals are called upon to work under extremely stressful situations which can become even more dangerous due to the actions of curious motorists.</P> <P>“It’s paramount for passing motorists to take caution when passing an accident scene, ” says Dan Thorsteinson, longtime chief of the Selkirk Fire Department. “ Some passing motorists become very distracted and rubber neck to see what’s going on.”</P> <P>Motorists coming upon an accident scene should immediately slow down and obey instructions provided by attending emergency personnel, says Clif Eden, Manager of Road Safety with Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>Even in a minor crash with no injuries, motorists need to exercise care and caution.</P> <P>“It’s recommended that both drivers exchange their particulars off the road and in a safe area away from other traffic,” says Eden. “ Exchanging information on the roadway creates a very real potential for injury to all parties. Safety needs to be observed at any traffic scene. ”</P> <P>An accident scene can be very dangerous with attending police and fire vehicles on site, in addition to the men and women who are trying to save lives.</P> <P>“The firefighters on the scene are completely focused on doing their jobs,” says Thorsteinson, who has been a firefighter in Selkirk for more than 25 years. “The firefighters are working on lifesaving equipment (jaws of life), getting equipment from the trucks or attending to injured people. In many ways, the crash scene is organized chaos.”</P> <P>The Association of Manitoba Municipalities (AMM), works very closely with the province’s volunteer fire departments. Adhering to roadside safety is a priority for not only the firefighters, but police and other motorists.</P> <P>“Municipalities have become increasingly concerned for the safety of firefighters while they are attending accident scenes,” says Doug Dobrowolski, President of the AMM.</P> <P>“These situations are stressful enough for our staff without being compromised by curious motorists. We sincerely hope drivers will take care when passing a crash scene, for everyone’s safety.”</P> <P>Some safety tips for motorists to remember:<BR>•when you hear an emergency siren behind you, move your vehicle to the right-side of the road and stop. Remain stopped until the emergency vehicle passes you.<BR>•always yield the right of way to emergency vehicles.<BR>•if you’re the first to arrive on a crash scene, park your vehicle in a safe area, ensuring it cannot be hit by passing vehicles. Immediately call 911 and be prepared to provide specific location details.<BR>• When passing a crash scene, obey all traffic enforcement directions. Detours around the scene will be conducted by police.<BR>• The law requires motorists to slow down and proceed with caution when passing emergency vehicles. When traveling on a multiple-lane road, motorists must change lanes when passing emergency vehicles.</P> <P>“An accident scene is very dangerous,” says Thorsteinson. “All steps are taken to minimize traffic around the scene and ensure emergency responders can work safely.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: New cellphone law - July 15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Amendments to Manitoba’s Highway Traffic Act (HTA) take effect July 15, making it illegal to use a hand-held cellphone while driving. Increased enforcement means that drivers who are caught talking or texting will have to pay for a $191 ticket in addition to their usual phone bill.</P> <P>“Distracted driving contributes to 30 per cent of all at-fault collisions and handheld cellphones are the number-one driver distraction,” said Clif Eden, manager of Road Safety at Manitoba Public Insurance. “We hope the amendments to the HTA will make drivers more aware of the risks of using their cellphones on the road.”</P> <P>The risks associated with talking and texting on a hand-held cellphone are real and they’re high. Current research suggests that drivers who text while driving are 23 times more likely to get in a collision. Even just talking on a hand-held phone increases the risk by four times. </P> <P>“Driving requires your full attention,” Eden said. “The risk of driver distraction just isn’t worth that phone call or text.”</P> <P>There are many ways drivers can avoid an expensive fine or, worse, a tragic accident. Turning the phone off, asking passengers to take the call or letting the calls go to voicemail will all contribute to safer roads. </P> <P>Using hands-free and wireless devices can also lower the risk. Bluetooth technology, headsets and wireless- enabled voice command in vehicles will all accommodate hands-free communication while on the road. But drivers should still be aware that even though they’re using their phones in a hands-free manner, their attention is still divided by talking on the phone and driving.</P> <P>“Using a cellphone in any way reduces your attention and concentration by 37 per cent,” said Eden. “The best way to avoid a costly fine while reducing your risk of a crash is to keep your focus on the road.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 23-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorists – watch for roadside emergency workers
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>On any given day in Manitoba, dedicated members of rural fire departments attend to motor vehicle crashes, providing emergency roadside assistance. These highly trained individuals are called upon to work under extremely stressful situations which can become even more dangerous due to the actions of curious motorists.</P>  <P>&#8220;It&#8217;s paramount for passing motorists to take caution when passing an accident scene,&#8221; says Dan Thorsteinson, long-time chief of the Selkirk Fire Department. &#8220;Some passing motorists become very distracted and rubber neck to see what&#8217;s going on.&#8221;</P>  <P>Motorists coming upon an accident scene should immediately slow down and obey instructions provided by attending emergency personnel, says Clif Eden, Manager of Road Safety with Manitoba Public Insurance.</P>  <P>Even in a minor crash with no injuries, motorists need to exercise care and caution.</P>  <P>&#8220;It&#8217;s recommended that both drivers exchange their particulars off the road and in a safe area away from other traffic,&#8221; says Eden. &#8220;Exchanging information on the roadway creates a very real potential for injury to all parties. Safety needs to be observed at any traffic scene.&#8221;</P>  <P>An accident scene can be very dangerous with attending police and fire vehicles on site, in addition to the men and women who are trying to save lives.</P>  <P>&#8220;The firefighters on the scene are completely focused on doing their jobs,&#8221; says Thorsteinson, who has been a firefighter in Selkirk for more than 25 years. &#8220;The firefighters are working on life-saving equipment (jaws of life), getting equipment from the trucks or attending to injured people. In many ways the crash scene is organized chaos.&#8221;</P>  <P>Some safety tips for motorists:<BR>&#8226; When you hear an emergency siren behind you, move your vehicle to the right-side of the road and stop. Remain stopped until the emergency vehicle passes you<BR>&#8226; Always yield the right of way to emergency vehicles<BR>&#8226; If you&#8217;re the first to arrive on a crash scene, park your vehicle in a safe area, ensuring it cannot be hit by passing vehicles. Immediately call 911 and be prepared to provide specific location details.<BR>&#8226; When passing a crash scene, obey all traffic enforcement directions. Detours around the scene will be conducted by police.<BR>&#8226; The law requires motorists to slow down and proceed with caution when passing emergency vehicles. When traveling on a multiple-lane road, motorists must change lanes when passing emergency vehicles.</P>  <P>&#8220;An accident scene is very dangerous,&#8221; says Thorsteinson. &#8220;All steps are taken to minimize traffic around the scene and ensure emergency responders can work safely.&#8221;<BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 24-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the Editor: Reader poses question to MPI
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Our own dollars are used by MPI to keep reminding us as consumers how great MPI’s rates are. If rates are so great, why does MPI allow no competition? I am tired of overpaying for poor service! I want a choice where and what insurance I buy for my vehicles. It’s time for the aging dinosaur that is MPI to allow competition into the province. Then we’ll see if MPI’s own propaganda is true! </P> <P>David Leduchowski<BR>Teulon, MB<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Seat belt facts
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Seat belts save lives! For safety reasons, make sure all vehicle occupants are buckled up.</P> <P>If safety concerns do not convince you to buckle up, remember if you are convicted of a seat belt offence you will face a $292 fine along with demerits on your licence. So here is a suggestion: make it clear to all passengers the car is not moving until everyone has their seat belt on correctly! As police officers, we have a mandate to keep our roads safe and therefore, we must encourage all occupants of motor vehicles to buckle up.</P> <P>Speaking of fines, please remember some new legislation which comes into effect July 15. Drivers caught texting or using hand-held cell phones while driving face a fine of $190. Motorists found smoking in a vehicle when children under the age of 16 are present face a fine of almost $200.</P> <P>If you have any questions or concerns, please contact us at 328-7430 or e-mail <A href="mailto:riversps@mts.net">riversps@mts.net</A>.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba IDs auto trade scofflaws
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Manitoba government has followed through on a promise to publish the identities of auto dealers, salespeople and others in the auto trade who break the rules and lose their work permits.</P> <P>On Thursday, the Manitoba Public Insurance's website identified the first offender to be punished since new consumer-protection laws for the auto industry came into effect.</P> <P>According to the Crown corporation, the work permit for Greg Puddifant, a mechanic at Gotta-Go Auto Services on Jarvis Avenue, has been suspended for three months. Puddifant, who conducted inaccurate or incomplete vehicle inspections, is suspended until Oct. 6.</P> <P>In April, the province changed the Drivers and Vehicles Act's public disclosure requirements based on stories produced by CBC News in Manitoba over the last two years. The regional investigative unit highlighted the need for legislative change in reports on unscrupulous vehicle dealers.</P> <P>Under provincial law, the provincial registrar of motor vehicles is responsible for issuing operating permits to auto dealers, mechanics and parts suppliers.</P> <P>The province changed the law so that in cases where permits are suspended or cancelled, the information is to be made public.</P> <P>The CBC's Alex Freedman found more than 90 used car dealers in the province were reprimanded for infractions in 2008-09, but the public was not told because of protection granted to the offenders under the Privacy Act.</P> <P>The more serious offences included tampering with a vehicle identification number and issuing safety-inspection certificates for cars unfit to drive.</P> <P>In one case, a Manitoba dealer was given a suspension of his operating permit for pre-signing inspection certificates without ever seeing the vehicles. Those certificates are used to prove a car is safe to drive when an owner registers it.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/08/man-auto-dealers-mpi-permits-identified.html#ixzz0tTQNfUPN">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/08/man-auto-dealers-mpi-permits-identified.html#ixzz0tTQNfUPN</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Manitou man dead after crash
NEWS_ITM_BYLN_TXT: BY WINNIPEG SUN AND QMI AGENCY
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A 29-year-old man was killed in a single-vehicle crash on Highway 3 near Darlingford early Saturday. </P>  <P>RCMP were called to the crash just west of the community about 5 a.m. </P>  <P>The driver and sole occupant of the vehicle was pronounced dead at the scene, police said. The man was from Manitou, which is west of Darlingford. That community is just west of Morden. </P>  <P>The cause of the crash is still under investigation. Alcohol is believed to have been a contributing factor in the incident, RCMP said. <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 28-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Time for some straight talk on hands-free cellphones
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>The Manitoba government's decision to ban hand-held cellphone use while driving is only half a solution. It makes no sense to forbid one kind of phone use and allow another. </P>  <P>The ban, which takes effect on Thursday, does not cover hands-free phones and it's tough to know why. You'll have both hands on the wheel, it's true, but you're still distracted. It doesn't matter how great a driver you might be, you can't concentrate on the road while listening to your boss shouting in your ear. </P>  <P>Dr. Louis Hugo Francescutti, head of the Alberta-based Coalition for Cellphone-Free Driving, says "The only ban that works is a total ban." </P>  <P>Of the new local prohibition he says, "Manitoba thinks they're doing something right but they're not. Hands-free is not going to work. The science is so strong yet policy-makers ignore the science." </P>  <P>Francescutti says something called inattentional blindness causes people to not see something in plain sight when they're distracted. </P>  <P>As for the argument a passenger is as distracting as a cellphone, he says that's not true. "The conversation with the passenger is different because the passenger is able to adjust the conversation, to notice things the driver might not, to react to the weather. They can see the red light approaching." </P>  <P>Francescutti says short-term distractions such as smoking while driving or drinking a bottle of water don't cause the same problems. </P>  <P>"No one is going to eat a burger or smoke a cigarette driving from Winnipeg to Brandon. Those aren't activities that last for two hours. But someone catching up on his work calls might." </P>  <P>In France, seven per cent of all fatal collisions are related to cellphone use, he says. </P>  <P>Manitoba Public Insurance stats bear this out. Using a cellphone while driving slows the driver's reaction time by 18 per cent, according to their website. Cellphone use doubles the risk of rear-end collisions. </P>  <P>Using a cellphone while driving reduces visual field attention. In other words, you're not looking around and anticipating what's coming. </P>  <P>Finally, MPI says, cellphone conversation increases the probability of a driver missing red lights. </P>  <P>These stats were only gathered for hand-held devices. According to Francescutti, the same results would be found with hands-free phones. </P>  <P>As for texting while driving, which also becomes illegal this week, you are 23 times more likely to have an accident. </P>  <P>Liz Peters, the Manitoba public affairs manager for the Canadian Automobile Association, says while the association is concerned about all forms of distracted driving, it hasn't been tracking the effects of hands-free devices. </P>  <P>"The only safe thing to do, whether you're answering the phone or passing a juice box to the back seat or putting on lipstick is to pull over," she says. </P>  <P>There are those of you who will argue the government shouldn't tell you what to do in the privacy of your vehicle. You're forgetting it already does. </P>  <P>That's why you have to wear a seatbelt, not drive under the influence of alcohol and observe the speed limit. </P>  <P>It's not like the government is trying to control your loud rap music as you drive down my street. Although I wish it would. This isn't a civil liberties issue. It's a safety issue. </P>  <P>If you know a certain behaviour leads to traffic accidents, you ban it. If you know an activity, such as smoking in a car that has a child in it, will harm the kid, you shouldn't be allowed to do it. We'll leave a full discussion of that new law for another day. </P>  <P>Suffice it to say I believe that law was overdue, too. </P>  <P>It's time to lobby the Manitoba government to ban all cellphone use while driving. There was a time, not that many years ago, when we didn't have cellphones. Somehow we survived. Most of us aren't so important we can't go for a 20-minute drive without speaking on the phone. </P>  <P>Trust me on this one. The life you save might be mine. </P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 29-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorists Encouraged to Respect Roadside Emergency Personnel
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Sentinel Courier, Pilot Mound, MB
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>On any given day in Manitoba, dedicated members of rural fire departments attend to motor vehicle crashes, providing emergency roadside assistance. These highly trained individuals are called upon to work under extremely stressful situations which can become even more dangerous due to the actions of curious motorists.</P> <P>“It’s paramount for passing motorists to take caution when passing an accident scene,” says Dan Thorsteinson, long-time chief of the Selkirk Fire Department. “Some passing motorists become very distracted and rubber neck to see what’s going on.”</P> <P>Motorists coming upon an accident scene should immediately slow down and obey instructions provided by attending emergency personnel, says Clif Eden, Manager of Road Safety with Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>Even in a minor crash with no injuries, motorists need to exercise care and caution.</P> <P>“It’s recommended that both drivers exchange their particulars off the road and in a safe area away from other traffic,” says Eden. “Exchanging information on the roadway creates a very real potential for injury to all parties. Safety needs to be observed at any traffic scene.”</P> <P>An accident scene can be very dangerous with attending police and fire vehicles on site, in addition to the men and women who are trying to save lives.</P> <P>“The firefighters on the scene are completely focused on doing their jobs,” says Thorsteinson, who has been a firefighter in Selkirk for more than 25 years. “The firefighters are working on life-saving equipment (jaws of life), getting equipment from the trucks or attending to injured people. In many ways the crash scene is organized chaos.”</P> <P>The Association of Manitoba Municipalities (AMM), works very closely with the province’s volunteer fire departments. Adhering to road-side safety is a priority for not only the firefighters, but police and other motorists.</P> <P>“Municipalities have become increasingly concerned for the safety of firefighters while they are attending accident scenes,” says Doug Dobrowolski, President of the AMM.</P> <P>“These situations are stressful enough for our staff without being compromised by curious motorists. We sincerely hope drivers will take care when passing a crash scene, for everyone’s safety.</P> <P>“Some safety tips for motorists to remember:<BR>•When you hear an emergency siren behind you, move your vehicle to the right-side of the road and stop. Remain stopped until the emergency vehicle passes you<BR>•Always yield the right of way to emergency vehicles<BR>•If you’re the first to arrive on a crash scene, park your vehicle in a safe area, ensuring it cannot be hit by passing vehicles. Immediately call 911 and be prepared to provide specific location details.<BR>•When passing a crash scene, obey all traffic enforcement directions. Detours around the scene will be conducted by police.<BR>•The law requires motorists to slow down and proceed with caution when passing emergency vehicles. When traveling on a multiple-lane road, motorists must change lanes when passing emergency vehicles.</P> <P>“An accident scene is very dangerous,” says Thorsteinson. “All steps are taken to minimize traffic around the scene and ensure emergency responders can work safely.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cell phone/Texting while driving ban takes effect Thursday
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The cell phone and texting while driving ban comes into effect in Manitoba later this week.</P> <P>Sergeant Doug Safioles tells CJOB the most blatant offenders will be ticketed...</P> <P>The ban takes effect Thursday. If you're caught, the fine will cost you close to 200 dollars.</P> <P>And the no smoking in the car with kids law comes into effect Thursday as well.<BR></P>

Title: 31-Jul-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Administrative Sanctions Against Businesses, Individuals Now Public to Manitobans
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Administrative sanctions taken against vehicle dealers and salespeople, driver-training schools and instructors, vehicle and parts recyclers, inspection-station operators and qualified inspection mechanics will now be made public to Manitobans, announced Attorney General Andrew Swan, minister responsible for Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI).</P>  <P>&#8220;This public process will give consumers the information to make informed decisions about businesses and individuals who have ignored established business rules and failed to conduct proper business actions,&#8221; said Swan. &#8220;The protection of consumers must always remain a priority and the publicizing of names and sanctions goes a long way in accomplishing this goal.&#8221;</P>  <P>This new amendment to the Drivers and Vehicles Act is consistent with the many other government-wide consumer protection efforts already established and enforced through the Let&#8217;s Make a Better Deal initiative, he added. </P>  <P>In addition to posting the names of those permit holders who receive administrative sanctions, other information on the MPI website will be their business addresses and a general statement regarding the infraction.</P>  <P>&#8220;The new amendment was a collaborative effort from a number of stakeholders,&#8221; said Ward Keith, registrar of motor vehicles, MPI. &#8220;Publicizing these sanctions against permit holders is also supported by the Manitoba Motor Dealers Association, the Manitoba Used Car Dealers Association and the Auto Recyclers of Manitoba, all of whom are committed to utmost professionalism in the industry.&#8221;</P>  <P>Administrative and enforcement actions typically result from information gathered through an audit/inspection of a permit holder&#8217;s operations by MPI staff or through information obtained from consumer complaints.</P>  <P>The majority of concerns are resolved amicably and with the full co-operation of the permit holder. However, when suspensions or cancellations of operating permits are required or when conditions are attached to permits, those actions will be made public via the MPI website.</P>  <P>Currently, permits, which are issued by the registrar of motor vehicles, are required by any individual or business who purchases or sells vehicles for compensation, buying or selling vehicles for the purpose of reselling them for scrap or parts, operating a driver-training school, providing driving instruction, conducting vehicle-safety inspections and issuing certificates of inspection.<BR><BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 1-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cellphones just one risk
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>As if breaking one bad habit isn't hard enough, Manitobans might need to consider going cold turkey on more than just cellphones while driving. </P> <P>The province's ban on cellphone use while driving, which begins Thursday, is only the "tip of the iceberg" when it comes to addressing distractions to drivers, says a former cop-turned driving instructor. </P> <P>"One thing that really, really bothers me is these people you see who drive with their dog on their lap and the dog has got their paws on the window," said Dane Wilson, owner of Crossroads Driver Training. "If (the driver) ever has to do an evasive manoeuvre, they wouldn't be able to do it, wouldn't be able to move their arms to avoid a collision. And I see that all the time." </P> <P>Driving distractions aren't uncommon sights on the streets -- eating, grooming, putting on makeup, even reading a print edition of the Free Press. </P> <P>And it doesn't help, Wilson said, when the cars of today are being built with more features, buttons and gadgets than ever before. Some now even have the Internet. </P> <P>"Where it's going to stop, I have no idea," Wilson said. </P> <P>It's why legislators in Alberta continue to craft their own distracted- driving legislation, which not only includes a ban on cellphone use, but reading, writing, even personal grooming. </P> <P>Alberta's Bill 16, introduced in mid-April, incorporates strict regulations on the use of cellphones, audio players, GPS systems, reading, writing and grooming in the car. It's being touted as the most comprehensive of its kind in Canada. </P> <P>Though it doesn't cover dogs, wayward drivers face a $172 fine with no demerits if they're caught. The bill is expected to be debated in the fall and could be in place as early as spring 2011. </P> <P>An Alberta Motor Association poll found 65 per cent of Albertans favoured legislation to cover distracted-driving activities beyond cellphones. Seventy- four per cent believed busted drivers should face cash fines. </P> <P>"We watch all of what's going on across Canada and want to make sure Manitoba is doing at least what the other provinces are doing," said CAA Manitoba president Mike Mager. "There's no question having something more comprehensive would be helpful. But what we've got right now is addressing the most significant problem. </P> <P>"We've got the most significant hurdle out of the way," he said. </P> <P>Manitoba's ban covers any handheld device used for calls, emails or text messages. It comes with a $199.80 fine. Drivers are able to use Bluetooth earplugs, a hands-free device that uses wireless technology. </P> <P>But specific amendments have quietly crept into the Manitoba's Highway Traffic Act over the years as the province tries to curb distracted driving. </P> <P>Video screens in sight of the driver aren't allowed. And you better take those headphones out of your ears if you're listening to your iPod or the radio. </P> <P>Prince Edward Island, the Yukon, the Northwest Territories and Nunavut are now the only provinces in Canada with no legislation or pending legislation on the issue. </P> <P>Either way, today's distractions are the inevitable result of the hyper- paced 21st century where we need our morning nicotine, our morning caffeine and to check our work voice mail before we even get to the office, Mager said. </P> <P>If you're in a traffic jam, "and sitting in your car, the natural reaction is, 'I'm sitting here, I'll go on my cellphone and go through a couple emails,' " Mager said. "We're multi-tasking all the time, so people just get in that mode and just do it without realizing the implications." </P> <P>Wilson said there's only so much he can teach his students before he sets them free with a crisp new licence in their wallet. </P> <P>"All my students have been talking about the law. Everyone's saying. 'There's no way I'm gonna talk when I'm on the road,'" he said. "We always talk about distracted driving and when they're in the car with me, they're 100 per cent concentrated. I just hound them and hound them (about it). </P> <P>"Once they do get their driver's licence, they're on the own," he said. "And you just hope it will carry on." </P> <P><A href="mailto:matt.preprost@freepress.mb.ca">matt.preprost@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>Here's what we know: </P> <P>Studies say using a cellphone increases the risk of a crash by about four times. Texting and driving increases the risk by 23 times, according to the Virginia Tech Transportation Institute. </P> <P>Here's what we don't know: </P> <P>How big the problem is in Manitoba. Manitoba Public Insurance hasn't been keeping stats, nor have Winnipeg police. Of course, to be fair, drivers don't always admit to the behaviour. </P> <P>Cellphones have been linked to at least one Manitoba death, a March 2001 crash on Highway 44 near Beausejour. Corey Barrett, a then-19-year-old driver, looked down to grab his cell--phone and crashed into the back of a stopped car with 41-year---old Terry Sachvie inside. Sachvie was killed instantly when her vehicle was pushed into the path of an oncoming truck. </P> <P>Distracted is a word for it: </P> <P>According to Jabra, a U.S.-based company that makes phone headsets, 15 per cent of people they surveyed in early April admitted to having sex or performing sexual acts while driving. Twenty-nine per cent admitted to kissing others while driving. </P> <P>It's worth noting Canada wasn't included in the survey, but here are some other highlights worthy of a chuckle and cocktail-party conversation: </P> <P>72 per cent admitted to eating food regularly while driving </P> <P>25 per cent admitted to styling their hair or changing clothes while driving </P> <P>13 per cent admitted they apply makeup while driving </P> <P>10 per cent admitted to reading newspapers or magazines while driving </P> <P>5 per cent admitted to playing video games </P>

--30--

Title: 2-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the Editor Column: MPI OUT OF CONTROL
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It is an outrage that MPI has donated the vacant claim facility on King Street to Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre. </P> <P>This was not their property to give away. It belonged to every Manitoban who pays insurance premiums. If the government wanted the deal to happen this property should have been sold to the province at fair market value. </P> <P>The funds paid to MPI should have been applied directly towards premium reduction. MPI appears to be completely out of control. An independent review is long overdue. </P> <P>ROBERT DRYBURGH <BR>WINNIPEG <BR>MPI giving us something back? Don't make us laugh. </P>

--30--

Title: 3-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driven to distraction ; New law should target texting, makeup & reading before cell calling
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I hope when police start enforcing the NDP's new cellphone ban for motorists that they also crack down on more serious distractions like drivers putting on make-up, shaving or reading while behind the wheel. </P> <P>Because there are far more potentially dangerous things drivers do while operating their motor vehicle than talking on cellphones. </P> <P>The province's ban on hand-held cellphones while driving kicks in Thursday. And police are expected to start enforcing it immediately, handing out Highway Traffic Act fines to anyone seen driving while holding a cellphone to their ear. </P> <P>But what about all those other distractions, like people digging through their purses or bags while driving? Are they going to crack down on those, too? I doubt it. </P> <P>What about drivers who are dumb enough to put on makeup while driving? Are they going to throw the book at them? </P> <P>How many times have you seen a driver shoving their face into the rear-view mirror to apply lipstick or mascara while doing 70 km/h down a main city thoroughfare? </P> <P>It's a lot more hazardous than talking on a cellphone I can assure you. </P> <P>How about reading while driving? </P> <P>I actually saw a driver reading a book on Broadway the other day, taking his eyes off the road for several seconds at a time while driving. </P> <P>Personally, I'd feel safer on the road with someone talking on a cellphone than reading a book. </P> <P>How about eating while driving? Are they going to bring the hammer down on people who stuff their faces while behind the wheel? </P> <P>I doubt too may drivers can concentrate on the road while loading up on cheeseburgers and fries and feeling around the car floor for a soft drink to wash down their grub. </P> <P>If they're going to bust us for talking on hand-held cellphones, they better charge us for operating our car radios, too because that's a far more serious distraction. </P> <P>When I talk on a cellphone while driving, my eyes don't leave the road. </P> <P>When a driver is fiddling around with his radio or CD player, his eyes can be off the road for two to three seconds at a time -- just enough time to slam into the driver in front of him. </P> <P>I'm all for cracking down on motorists who don't concentrate on the road while driving. </P> <P>And I support -- even pushed for -- the ban on smoking in vehicles while children are present, which is also part of this new law. </P> <P>Apparently we still need such a law for the few remaining morons who think it's OK to poison their kids' lungs with cigarette smoke. I just saw one about a month ago. </P> <P>But singling out cellphone use is just plain dumb. Talking on a cellphone is no different than talking to a passenger beside you. </P> <P>What they should do is crack down on real driver distractions, including texting, dialing numbers on your phone while driving and putting on lipstick or any other activity that causes a driver to take their eyes off the road. </P> <P>It's called common sense -- something that's lacking from this new law. </P> <P>The truth is, police already have laws they can use for motorists who drive carelessly. They should use those laws to target real carelessness and leave safe drivers alone. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Suspects In Custody In Stolen Vehicle Chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Two men and three youths have been taken into custody in connection with the high speed chase of a stolen vehicle. Police spotted the truck around 3 o'clock Tuesday morning near Salter and Church. The truck struck two police cars and took off. Officers followed for a short time, but aborted the chase. The truck was later found near Main and the Perimeter. With the help of the canine unit, the suspects were rounded up. One even tried to swim across the river to get away. He didn't.<BR>

--30--

Title: 5-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hang up, butt out ; Handheld cell, in-vehicle smoking ban begins
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>If you don't keep cellphones and cigarettes out of your hands while driving starting Thursday, you may be reaching for your wallet instead. </P> <P>That's the day police start enforcing the province's new law which bans handheld use of cellphones and other electronic devices while driving and prohibits smoking when children under 16 are present in vehicles. </P> <P>Manitoba's Infrastructure and Transportation Minister Steve Ashton announced the implementation of the new law during a news conference at the Legislature Wednesday. </P> <P>"It's about stopping the epidemic of distracted driving we're seeing because of handheld cellphones and texting devices," Ashton said. "It just makes sense to butt out when kids are present in a car." </P> <P>The new regulations allow use of cellphones via hands-free equipment while driving and drivers are permitted to call 911 in an emergency situation. </P> <P>Under the amendments to Manitoba's Highway Traffic Act, fines for both infringements have been set at $199.80. Drivers will not receive demerits if ticketed. </P> <P>Ashton cited data that shows texting drivers are 23 times more likely to be involved in a collision and that drivers talking on cellphones are four times more likely to get into crashes involving injury and twice as likely to be involved in a rear-end collision. </P> <P>"These are common sense laws," Ashton said. "It just makes sense to concentrate on the road while driving. It's going to be an adjustment for a lot of people." </P> <P>Manitoba becomes the ninth Canadian province to ban handheld cellphone use while driving and the sixth to outlaw smoking with children in vehicles. </P> <P>Starting Thursday, to be legally used while driving, a cellphone must be anchored and used hands-free via an earpiece or as a speakerphone. Drivers are only allowed the most basic manipulation of the device -- answering and ending calls with a single touch. But texting and e-mailing are not allowed. </P> <P>Drivers can legally use handheld devices, whether for phone calls or texting, if they pull off the road onto a shoulder or into a legal parking spot and come to a complete stop before using the device. </P> <P>Winnipeg Police Service Central Traffic Unit Sgt. Doug Safioles said officers will not be giving violators any kind of grace period. </P> <P>"We believe the education campaign by the province and Manitoba Public Insurance has been sufficient," Safioles said. "We will start enforcing as of Thursday morning." </P> <P>Safioles said no checkstops were planned but said officers will be vigilant. </P> <P>"Our enforcement activity will be looking for the obvious offender," Safioles said. "We're looking for someone who's driving improperly and using a cellphone or who's driving a vehicle and we can clearly see they're smoking and clearly see children." </P>

--30--

Title: 6-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI reports strong first quarter
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It's been a strong financial first quarter for Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>The province's public automobile insurer announced Wednesday a net income of $102.9 million for the three months which ended May 31. </P> <P>In a news release, MPI said the increased revenue -- up $5.2 million on the same quarter last year -- was fuelled by reduced claim costs which decreased over the period by $85.2 million to $105.4 million. </P> <P>Specifically, MPI said the decrease in claim costs is largely attributable to a $78.2 million drop in bodily injury claims. </P> <P>Physical damage claims were also down, largely due to the mild winter. </P> <P>Last month, MPI submitted its rate application to the Public Utilities Board and is requesting and overall basic insurance rate decrease of 4%. </P> <P>MPI has also submitted to the PUB a premium rebate that would mean, on average, a $115 rebate cheque for every policy holder next spring. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI Posts Strong 1st Quarter
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Manitoba Public Insurance has reported a healthy first quarter. The public auto insurer posted a net income of just over 102 million dollars, over 5-million more than last year. Vice-President of Corporate Finance Don Palmer says claim costs dropped largely because of a decrease in bodily injury claims. However physical damage claim costs also dropped because of an early end to winter. Palmer doesn't expect the trend to continue.  MPI has already applied for a rate decrease of 4 percent and a premium rebate of 92.2 million dollars. If approved, policy holders would get a cheque back worth an average of 115-dollars.<BR>

--30--

Title: 8-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg mulls lights at dangerous crossing
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Major changes are being proposed for what city officials say is the most dangerous pedestrian crosswalk along one of the busiest streets in Winnipeg.</P> <P>Mayor Sam Katz's Executive Policy Committee (EPC) approved a plan Wednesday to install new traffic lights along Osborne Street at Wardlaw Avenue near the heart of Osborne Village.</P> <P>The hope is that the new crosswalk lights — dubbed a half-signal — will provide more safety to pedestrians trying to cross Osborne, where between 1998 and 2007, 12 pedestrians were hit, according to a city report.</P> <P>Most recently, on Feb. 23, Estevan Calderon, 14, was struck by a car and severely injured while crossing at the crosswalk, which has been in place since 1968.</P> <P>At the time the teen was hit, people in the area called for the city to install a traffic light, saying the intersection was extremely dangerous.</P> <P>About 29,000 vehicles a day pass along Osborne headed north and south from the downtown area, the city report said. The sheer volume of traffic makes it one of the city's busiest routes.</P> <P>According to the report, the public works department wants to erect the new signal in 2011 at a cost of $105,000, not including maintenance of $5,000 a year.</P> <P>Won't delay traffic: report<BR>The new device will feature standard red, amber and green lights facing vehicle traffic headed north and south on Osborne.</P> <P>A pedestrian wanting to cross the street will press a button and the lights will switch to amber, then red, bringing cars to a full stop. The person crossing will be faced with automated and illuminated "Walk" or "Don't Walk" signs.</P> <P>Currently, the crosswalk has a series of overhead flashing amber lights, which are sometimes easy for drivers to miss. Motorists have also complained that pedestrians don't wait long enough for traffic to stop before walking into the roadway.</P> <P>The city report said pedestrians must wait for the north-south lights to turn completely red for the "Walk" signal to light up.</P> <P>At all other times, the north-south lights will remain green, allowing vehicles to pass freely. The city said it believes the new system will actually reduce delays.</P> <P>City council as a whole must still approve the plan and will consider it at a meeting next week.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/14/man-traffic-signal-city-hall.html#ixzz0tktesOUk">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/14/man-traffic-signal-city-hall.html#ixzz0tktesOUk</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: No cellphone safe while driving: researcher
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The ban on the use of hand-held cellphones in vehicles in Manitoba fails to tackle the real issue, says one researcher.</P> <P>Yoko Ishigami, a Killam Scholar in Dalhousie University's experimental psychology department, said the problem of phone usage and driving is about concentration and not about the device the driver is holding.</P> <P>"It's about attention/distraction, not about hands," she said. "It's kind of misleading that people ban only hand-held phones. It gives the wrong impression that it's okay to talk on the phone, which is not good at all."</P> <P>Ishigami said hands-free technology is not a safe alternative to using your cellphone while you drive.</P> <P>"It's dangerous to talk on the phone while driving. So, there's not a lot of difference between hands-free and hand-held," she said.</P> <P>The new legislation allows the use of cellphones while driving provided they are used in a hands-free manner.</P> <P>The law also allows use of a hand-held cellphone to call the police, fire or ambulance service in an emergency.</P> <P>Under the amendments to the Highway Traffic Act, motorists face a fine of almost $200 if caught breaking the new law, which takes effect Thursday.</P> <P>"Officers will be in their vehicles looking for somebody texting," said Sgt. Doug Safioles, who works with the traffic division of the Winnipeg Police Service.</P> <P>Also written into law starting Thursday is a ban on smoking in vehicles when children under the age of 16 are on board.</P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island have comparable laws, and Alberta recently introduced legislation banning the use of hand-held cellphones while driving.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/14/mb-cellphone-ban-ishigami.html#ixzz0tku2zbAS">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/14/mb-cellphone-ban-ishigami.html#ixzz0tku2zbAS</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: New driving laws in force
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Some new driving laws are now in force, and getting caught means a $200 ticket.  There will be bans on using cell phones and smoking behind the wheel when there are kids in the car. Transportation Minister Steve Ashton says the laws have some similarities and that's why the government chose to enact the rules on the same day.</P> <P>It is now  illegal to light up with children under 16 in the vehicle. Drivers will also have to stop texting and using hand-held cell phones. Hands-free devices are still okay for drivers, as long as it's a one-touch system.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car thief charged again after prison stint
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>MANITOBA justice officials hoped a dose of adult punishment and a stint in Stony Mountain penitentiary would slow one of the city's worst auto thieves. </P> <P>But the notorious offender is back behind bars this week after allegedly violating conditions of his statutory release and committing a series of new crimes, the Free Press has learned. </P> <P>Gene Soldat, 20, was arrested Wednesday after allegedly stealing a GMC pickup truck earlier this month. </P> <P>He was also accused of possessing break-in tools, driving while prohibited and was wanted on a warrant for revocation of his statutory release from federal prison. Three youth co-accused were also arrested. None of the new allegations has been proved and Soldat is presumed innocent. </P> <P>Records show Soldat returned to the community in late March after serving two-thirds of a sentence he received in 2008 when he was raised as a youth to adult court. Soldat was given three years in prison, in addition to the equivalent of two years spent in custody. He now faces the prospect of serving his remaining prison sentence in custody, in addition to any further time he might receive if convicted. </P> <P>Court was told at the time Soldat had 82 prior convictions over the past six years, nearly all for stealing cars and putting public safety at risk. His prior stints in jail were short, however, with Soldat being quickly released in the name of rehabilitation. </P> <P>Soldat's criminal ways made headlines in 2007 when Manitoba Public Insurance obtained a $110,000 judgment against him following one of the city's worst property crime sprees in recent history that involved several other young co- accused. </P> <P>In just the span of a few weeks beginning in late 2004, the boys were responsible for stealing five cars -- three of which were written off -- and damaging 38 others, including a police car that was destroyed in a high-speed crash. They also sent one car smashing through the window of an empty River Heights apartment block by pinning down the accelerator with a brick -- an incident the building realtor described as an act of "terrorism." A resident ended up trapped in the rubble of his own washroom when the roof collapsed. </P>

--30--

Title: 12-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba cell phone ban starts July 15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Smoking in cars with child passengers also prohibited </P> <P>Drivers caught texting or using handheld cellphones in Manitoba face steep fines as of July 15, 2010. </P> <P>That's when a law banning those activities comes into effect, Transportation Minister Steve Ashton announced Thursday. </P> <P>" We know the hazards that distracted drivers create on our roads. Talking on a handheld cellphone and texting are major distractions while driving and we're moving to make our roads safer for all Manitobans, " </P> <P>Ashton stated in a government news release. </P> <P>"Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant ." -Marilyn McLaren, Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>A public-education, multimedia campaign was launched in September 2009 to prepare motorists for the changes, but the date for the new law had not yet been announced. </P> <P>Under the amendments to the Highway Traffic Act, motorists face a fine of almost $200 if caught breaking the new law. </P> <P>No smoking with kids in car </P> <P>The amendments also ban smoking in vehicles when children under the age of 16 are present. That fine is also about $200. </P> <P>" Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant, " said Manitoba Public Insurance CEO and president Marilyn McLaren. </P> <P>"Text messaging or using a handheld cellphone while driving are both identified forms of driver distraction that can lead to a crash." </P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island have comparable laws and Alberta recently introduced legislation banning the use of handheld cellphones while driving. </P> <P>Several jurisdictions also have laws prohibiting smoking in vehicles with children present, including British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick. </P> <P>Manitoba's legislation allows the use of cellphones while driving to make telephone calls, provided they are equipped as hands-free devices and used in a hands-free manner. </P> <P>The law also allows use of a handheld cellphone to call the police, fire or ambulance service in an emergency. </P>

--30--

Title: 13-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Mba public insurer driving in the black as it steers toward rate decrease
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - Manitoba Public Insurance is reporting a healthy bottom line for the first quarter of 2010. </P> <P>The Crown company says its net income ending May 31 was $102.9 million _ $5 million more than the first quarter last year. </P> <P>MPI says the rosy financial picture can be attributed to a decrease in bodily injury claims and a short winter, which resulted in fewer damaged vehicles. </P> <P>But Don Palmer, MPI's chief financial officer, says in a statement that the decline will likely be offset later this year by an increase in claims during the winter months. </P> <P>MPI has applied to the province's Public Utilities Board for a rate decrease of 4 per cent and a premium rebate of more than $92 million. </P> <P>If approved, motorists can expect an average premium rebate of $115.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI is naming names
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Administrative sanctions taken against vehicle dealers and salespeople, driver-training schools and instructors, vehicle and parts recyclers, inspection-station operators and qualified inspection mechanics will now be made public to Manitobans.</P> <P>Attorney General Andrew Swan, minister responsible for Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI), made the announcement last week.</P> <P>“This public process will give consumers the information to make informed decisions about businesses and individuals who have ignored established business rules and failed to conduct proper business actions,” said Swan. “The protection of consumers must always remain a priority and the publicizing of names and sanctions goes a long way in accomplishing this goal.”</P> <P>This new amendment to the Drivers and Vehicles Act is consistent with the many other government-wide consumer protection efforts already established and enforced through the Let’s Make a Better Deal initiative, he added.</P> <P>In addition to posting the names of those permit holders who receive administrative sanctions, other information on the MPI website will be their business addresses and a general statement regarding the infraction.</P> <P>“The new amendment was a collaborative effort from a number of stakeholders,” said Ward Keith, registrar of motor vehicles, MPI. “Publicizing these sanctions against permit holders is also supported by the Manitoba Motor Dealers Association, the Manitoba Used Car Dealers Association and the Auto Recyclers of Manitoba, all of whom are committed to utmost professionalism in the industry.”</P> <P>Administrative and enforcement actions typically result from information gathered through an audit/inspection of a permit holder’s operations by MPI staff or through information obtained from consumer complaints.</P> <P>The majority of concerns are resolved amicably and with the full co-operation of the permit holder. However, when suspensions or cancellations of operating permits are required or when conditions are attached to permits, those actions will be made public via the MPI website.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Nuisance calls a growing problem in R.M.s - Municipalities asking MPI for compensation for false alarm calls
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>Macdonald has joined nine other rural municipalities in an appeal to Manitoba Public Insurance for compensation for responding to highway calls that turn out to be false alarms.</P>  <P>Macdonald fire chief Dwight Seymour said his department responds to more than a dozen accident scenes each year in which there is only minor damage to the vehicle and the driver or passengers are unharmed.</P>  <P>Seymour said most of the calls are made by passing motorists who are unaware if emergency services are required. It costs the municipality as much as $500 to respond to each call, he added.</P>  <P>&#8220;A lot of times we get calls from passersby that think a car that has hit the ditch needs assistance,&#8221; Seymour said. &#8220;This turn out to be nuisance calls, because when we get there no one is with the vehicle when we arrive.&#8221;</P>  <P>Macdonald is required to send at least two emergency services vehicles to each call at a cost of several hundred dollars. In addition, as many as 12 firefighters will respond to each call at a cost $12 an hour for each firefighter.</P>  <P>To make matters worse, emergency personnel sometimes respond to the same accident scene more than once because it is called in by two or more individuals.</P>  <P>Macdonald chief administrative officer Tom Raine said false alarms are becoming an increasing problem because of the growing use of cellular phones. </P>  <P>&#8220;There is no compensation when our emergency services have to respond to a call that turn out to be a false alarm,&#8221; Raine said. &#8220;So the municipalities around Winnipeg have decided as a group that we should make a request to MPI to perhaps compensate us for some of these false alarms.&#8221;</P>  <P>The group appealing to MPI also includes the rural municipalities of Rosser and Headingley. Raine said the municipalities have yet to receive a response from MPI.</P>  <P>MPI spokesperson Brian Smiley said it&#8217;s unlikely the municipalities will receive any further compensation from the Crown agency.</P>  <P>&#8220;We have a partnership with the Association of Manitoba Municipalities and we have an agreement in place with them that sets the fee structure for compensation,&#8221; said Smiley, adding the municipalities are fully aware of the terms of the agreement. </P>  <P>&#8220;It is clearly stated in this agreement that there is no compensation for false alarms.&#8221; Seymour said the best way of reducing the number of false alarms his department responds to is public education and clearly marking accident scenes to ensure no repeat calls are made.</P>  <P>&#8220;We&#8217;ve tried to standardize things between us and the RCMP to make sure a vehicle is taped visibly when we have attended a scene to minimize the amount of repeat calls,&#8221; Seymour said.</P>  <P>&#8220;MPI has also talked about doing education with the public by asking motorists not call-in a vehicle accident if there is tape on the vehicle.&#8221;<BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 16-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI investigations save ratepayers money
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) and its ratepayers saved over $2,000,000 last year as the result of successful fire investigations by the public auto insurer’s Special Investigation Unit (SIU).</P> <P>Of the nearly 250 vehicle fire investigations, SIU investigators were able to determine many of these vehicle fires were the direct result of arson, or faulty mechanical repairs.</P> <P>“Our fire investigators can determine if a fire was the result of arson. Where evidence proves owner involvement, the claim would be denied based on the conclusive findings,” said Tim Arnason, MPI’s director of SIU.</P> <P>“In other cases where causation of fires is attributed to faulty mechanical repairs, the corporation will seek recovery from the person or business responsible.”</P> <P>MPI’s SIU has three investigators dedicated exclusively to vehicle fire investigations. These investigators - all former members of the Winnipeg Police Service - have extensive field experience, in addition to successfully completing several vehicle fire investigation courses. These fire investigators also have the necessary experience and credentials to testify as an “expert” witness at a trial.</P> <P>“Vehicles typically don’t go up in flames,” explained Arnason. “When a fire claim is opened our SIU staff will attempt to determine both causation and origin. Many fire claims are confirmed not to be the fault of the vehicle owner, but a mechanical issue.”</P> <P>Fire investigation is only one component of the SIU, which investigates any claim deemed to be of a suspicious nature.</P> <P>Last year MPI’s SIU investigated about 2,750 claims, resulting in savings of nearly $9.3 million for the public auto insurer and its ratepayers.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Public listing good news for everyone
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Vehicles are something with which we are almost all familiar. Our vehicles play an important supporting role in our lives; they take us to work, on trips and help us more easily accomplish all of the things that we need or want to do.</P> <P>But, despite all the good things they do, sometimes they break down at inopportune times, no longer meet our needs or simply need to be replaced. For all we know about our cars, when it comes to what’s under the shiny paint, few of us know much about our four wheeled friends. </P> <P>This lack of knowledge sets up a classic case of asymmetric information in the relationship between current or prospective vehicle owners and the mechanics or dealers they rely upon. This situation can be exploited by unscrupulous mechanics or dealers and almost everyone knows of someone who feels they’ve been taken in a vehicle transaction.</P> <P>Apart from word of mouth, we know what some vehicle dealers and salespeople, driver-training schools and instructors, vehicle and parts recyclers, inspection-station operators and qualified inspection mechanics don’t follow the rules because they received administrative sanctions.</P> <P>These sanctions suspend the party’s license and prevent them from performing their automotive industry services.</P> <P>As of last week, the public will now be able to see those individuals and businesses that have received administrative sanctions from Manitoba Public Insurance in an easy to find and understand format.</P> <P>Following an amendment to the Drivers and Vehicles Act, this information is now available free to the public on MPI’s website. Previously, this information wasn’t nearly so accessible to the general public who had few ways of knowing if they were dealing with reputable parties. </P> <P>There are a few ways that an individual or business can be the subject of administrative and enforcement actions These actions typically result from information gathered through an audit or inspection of a permit holder’s operations by MPI staff or through information obtained from consumer complaints. Because the majority of concerns are resolved amicably and with the full co-operation of the permit holder, these cases will not be publicized through MPI’s website. However, for those cases which can’t be amicably or satisfactorily resolved, suspensions or cancellations of operating permits as well as conditions attached to permits, will be made public via the site.</P> <P>The site provides adequate information to help a vehicle owner. It provides the permit holder’s name and businesses address and the type of operation (such as inspection station or mechanic). The site also provides information about the violation, the sanction imposed and start and and end date of that sanction. This means that the consumer knows not only if there is a sanction presently in place, but if there have been any imposed in the past.</P> <P>Such a move benefits everyone and it’s not surprising that it has been supported by the Manitoba Motor Dealers Association, the Manitoba Used Car Dealers Association, the Auto Recyclers of Manitoba and Manitoba Automobile Association. </P> <P>The changes are obviously good news for consumers who now have one more way to gather information and ensure they are dealing with reputable parties.</P> <P>The changes are also good for the automotive industry which seems to be constantly fighting a perception of shady behaviour and sketchy characters. With such a public registry in place, there is a greater incentive for people to follow the rules and a greater reward for those who do.</P> <P>The list can be found through <A href="http://www.mpi.mb.ca">www.mpi.mb.ca</A>.</P>

--30--

Title: 18-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Reduced claims costs fuels MPI profit
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Fuelled by reduced claims costs, Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) reported net income of $102.9 million for the first quarter of 2010.</P> <P>For the three months ended May 31, 2010, earned revenues increased by $5.2 million over the same period last year, as the number and value of vehicles insured increased. Net income from operations increased from the previous year by $90.7 million due to improved underwriting results of $92.6 million offset by a $1.9 million decrease in investment income.</P> <P>Claims costs for the first three months decreased by $85.2 million to $105.4 million, explained Don Palmer, vice-president of corporate finance and chief financial officer. The significant decrease is largely attributable to a $78.2 million decrease in bodily injury claims. In addition, physical damage claims costs also decreased, attributed to winter ending earlier than normal.</P> <P>“This one-time decrease was due to an unusual release in claims reserves caused by a rise in interest rates,” said Palmer. “This decrease in claims costs is not expected to be sustained throughout the year.</P> <P>“Traditionally, the first two quarters of the fiscal year generate a profit, which is then offset by an increase in claims during the winter months,” said Palmer.</P> <P>Last month the corporation submitted its 2011/12 Basic insurance rate application to the Public Utilities Board (PUB), requesting an overall Basic insurance rate decrease of four percent and a proposed premium rebate of $92.2 million. If approved by the PUB, policy holders can expect to receive a cheque in the spring of 2011 of about $115 on average.</P> <P>If approved, this will be the 12th year out of the last 13 in which MPI had either held the line on, or decreased, the average rate paid by Manitobans for Basic auto insurance. The PUB is expected to rule on the application in late fall.</P> <P>“This will be the fifth rebate in 11 years,” said Palmer. “In total, more than $350 million has been given back to Manitobans. The public auto insurance model continues to achieve its founding objective - to provide the most comprehensive auto insurance at the most affordable cost.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: New law '$200 phone call' for many
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It turns out even the threat of a $200 fine wasn't enough to get some Winnipeggers to break the habit of driving while dialing on Day 1 of the new cellphone ban for motorists. </P> <P>"It's a good law and I was a dumb-ass, I shouldn't have been on the phone, it's just that simple," said Jeff, who didn't want his last name used, after police pulled him over near Osborne Village. </P> <P>Police said they ticketed 109 drivers on Thursday as part of what they call the biggest change Manitoba drivers have faced since seatbelts became mandatory more than 25 years ago. </P> <P>"Compliance seems to be very, very high," Sgt. Doug Safioles said at a checktop at River Avenue and Wellington Crescent Thursday afternoon. </P> <P>That's not to say that officers working that checkstop weren't kept busy. Jeff was one of the eight people caught flouting the law there early Thursday morning and over the noon hour. </P> <P>Despite his best efforts to quickly toss his cellphone into the passenger seat beside him, it was too late by the time he rounded the corner. </P> <P>"It was my bank that phoned me and I've trying to do some debt consolidation, they called and I just grabbed the phone to say 'I'm out driving, I can't answer the phone.' And right when I come around the corner, the cops were there, " he said. "It's just like c'est la vie, that's life." </P> <P>At least six other drivers were seen by a reporter in the area driving while talking on a phone, as well another woman texting while driving. </P> <P>Police strict orders to enforce this law. Forget about getting caught while talking or texting -- just being seen holding a cellphone will still net you a ticket. </P> <P>Police aren't required to get a search warrant for cellphone records and aren't required to seize the cellphone in order to prove it was transmitting at the time of the offence. This is why the element of the offence is 'holding' an electronic device so police officers do not have to seize phones at the roadside. </P> <P>An order tells officers to take detailed observations of what they see when they catch a driver with a cellphone. Officers will be able to present their notes in court as proof. </P> <P>The most common excuse from drivers heard from drivers Thursday? They simply forgot, said officers working the stop. </P> <P>"There are going to be legitimate people who've forgotten or it was an important call they thought was necessary to answer," Safioles said. "But it's a $200 phone call and you've got to go out and get a Bluetooth or hands-free device." </P> <P>Police considered giving warnings, but decided against it due to the recent flurry of media coverage, Safioles said. </P> <P>"We had thought of doing a grace period, but there has been so much media coverage, and so much publicity in print, on radio, on television, that we didn't feel it necessary," he said. </P> <P>It still didn't stop Gerardo Aguilar from claiming oblivion when he was pulled over by officers shortly after noon. The last media reports he saw were six months ago, claimed Aquilar who had been calling his son at the time he was busted. </P> <P>"Well, I never use the telephone while I'm driving," he said. "It happened that I'm taking these guys (in the van with him) to lunch, and so I invited my son. He's at home, and I'm telling him to be ready." </P> <P>The new law also forbids people from smoking when there are children under 16 in the vehicle. Police can ticket people if the vehicle is parked or moving, or even if the windows are open. </P> <P>One Winnipeg driver was busted for that on Thursday. </P> <P><A href="mailto:matt.preprost@freepress.mb.ca">matt.preprost@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>Excuses, excuses </P> <P>The Insurance Corporation of British Columbia asked police across B.C. to share drivers' top excuses for using a hand-held cellphone while driving in the six months since a ban was imposed in that province: </P> <P>1. It was an urgent work call! </P> <P>2. But I was stopped at a red light. </P> <P>3. I was just checking my voice mail - I didn't make a call. </P> <P>4. Driver: But I have it on hands-free! Police officer: Sir, it's not hands- free if it's in your hand. </P> <P>5. But it was my mom calling! </P> <P>6. I didn't know, I'm not from here. </P> <P>7. I drive better than most people -- not like the ones that eat while driving. </P> <P>8. I was just setting up my hands-free device. </P> <P>9. But it's my first time. Can't I just get a warning? </P> <P>10. It was my wife calling and I didn't dare ignore her. </P>

--30--

Title: 20-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Phone calls adding up ; Ticket-traps nab 109 drivers with handheld devices on law's first day
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A handful of Manitobans now have something to talk about. </P> <P>A total of 109 motorists were ticketed in Winnipeg on Thursday, the first day of Manitoba's new law banning the handheld use of cellphones for texting or talking while driving. </P> <P>Gerrardo Aguilar was one of the unlucky few. </P> <P>While he waited for an officer to write a ticket, Aguilar told reporters he was unaware the law is now in effect, despite a media blitz lasting months. </P> <P>"It surprised me so much. I think he got what he wanted," Aguilar said of the police officer who stopped him. </P> <P>The call landed him a $199.80 ticket but no demerits. </P> <P>"I never use the telephone while I'm driving. It's something that I'm not addicted to," Aguilar said. </P> <P>Jeff, who declined to give his last name, was caught moments later. </P> <P>"It's a good law and I was a dumbass," he said. </P> <P>The law bans drivers' handheld use of cellphones and other electronic devices. Hands-free devices are permitted. </P> <P>Another amendment to the Highway Traffic Act that took effect Thursday prohibits smoking in a vehicle when children under 16 are present. One driver was ticketed Thursday for that offence. </P> <P>Attention </P> <P>The goal is to keep motorists' attention on the road to prevent crashes, and protect the health of children. </P> <P>Aguilar was one of several motorists caught in a trap where River Avenue, a one-way westbound street, takes a 90-degree turn and becomes Wellington Crescent. </P> <P>It's a strategic spot for police because motorists slow down to negotiate the turn, allowing officers time to spot scofflaws and step out to stop them. </P> <P>"I didn't know" or "I forgot" were the most common excuses given Thursday but police weren't buying. </P> <P>Sgt. Doug Safioles of the central traffic unit said the number of tickets was fewer than expected. </P> <P>"We're not having a lot of luck today, which is a good thing," he said. "It's a $200 phone call. It's much cheaper to buy a wireless earpiece." </P> <P>Devices such as two-way or CB radios are OK to use while driving, Safioles said. </P> <P>In the hour a reporter was present at River Avenue, two people were caught violating the cellphone ban.
