At least five were caught without a seatbelt. </P> <P>For legal use, a cellphone must be anchored and a hands-free device must be used. Motorists are allowed to answer and end calls with a single touch. </P> <P>Handheld cellphone use is permitted when a driver pulls over and comes to a complete stop on the shoulder of a road or in a parking spot, or to call 911. </P>

--30--

Title: 21-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Death at rush hour ; Woman crossing McPhillips hit by SUV
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 46-year-old pedestrian was killed when she was hit by a sport utility vehicle while crossing a busy street during the morning rush hour Thursday. </P> <P>The woman was walking across McPhillips Street at Templeton Avenue when she was struck about 8 a.m. </P> <P>She was rushed to a nearby hospital but died of her injuries, Winnipeg police say. Her name wasn't released. </P> <P>A man said he was driving to work on northbound McPhillips when he saw a woman on the other side of the road fly into the air. </P> <P>"Oh God, it was just like a movie. I was in a state of shock," said the witness, who declined to give his name. "I'm 44 and I've never seen anything like that before." </P> <P>The woman was struck by a Chrysler Pacifica sport utility vehicle. Police said the woman was westbound on Templeton in a "pedestrian crossing area" when she was hit by the westbound vehicle, which was turning south onto McPhillips. </P> <P>Investigators believe a gold-coloured car might have been in the intersection moments earlier and are asking the driver to call police. </P> <P>At that location, the east-west road is a service road on the west side of McPhillips. Templeton is on the east side. </P> <P>The intersection is bordered by two car dealerships, a hardware store and lumber yard, and a tanning salon. </P> <P>The witness said several passersby had stopped to check on the woman and call 911 by the time he parked his vehicle. The woman wasn't moving or speaking, he said. </P> <P>'Can't be real' </P> <P>"I was like, 'This can't be real.' It took me five or 10 minutes to understand what was going on," the man said. </P> <P>The man said emergency personnel arrived quickly. </P> <P>CPR was performed before the woman was loaded into an ambulance, he said. </P> <P>The driver of the sport utility vehicle, which sustained damage to its front end, stopped at the scene. </P> <P>Witnesses said a woman, believed to be the driver, was sitting on the curb, crying, yelling and holding her head in her hands. </P> <P>Charges haven't been laid. The central traffic unit is investigating. </P> <P>McPhillips Street was closed for several hours after the crash. </P> <P>Police are asking witnesses who haven't talked to investigators to call 986-6271. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Pedestrian killed in Garden City crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 46-year-old woman was killed after being hit by a car in the Garden City neighbourhood Thursday morning.</P> <P>Police have blocked off the intersection of McPhillips Street and Templeton Avenue as they investigate the collision.</P> <P>The woman was struck by a vehicle at 8 a.m. CT and rushed to hospital where she was pronounced dead.</P> <P>There was no information available about the vehicle that hit her or its driver.</P> <P>The intersection is controlled by traffic lights.</P> <P>Police said just after 12:30 p.m. that they plan to have the intersection taped off for several more hours.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/15/man-crash-templeton-mcphillips-fatal.html#ixzz0tqkxfE5m">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/15/man-crash-templeton-mcphillips-fatal.html#ixzz0tqkxfE5m</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 23-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Suspect has 80-plus car theft convictions: cops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One of Winnipeg's most notorious convicted car thieves is back in custody after he allegedly stole a vehicle earlier this month. </P> <P>Gene Michael Soldat, who's still serving a five-year sentence for auto theft offences but was wanted for a parole violation, was arrested by the stolen auto unit in the North End on Wednesday night, city police confirmed Thursday. </P> <P>Soldat, 21, is accused of stealing a GMC pickup truck July 4 or 5. </P> <P>He was arrested in the 400-block of Flora Avenue. Several other suspects were previously arrested or are being sought, police said. </P> <P>Soldat was charged with theft over $5,000, possession of break-in instruments and driving while disqualified, said Winnipeg police spokeswoman Const. Natalie Aitken. </P> <P>A warrant was previously issued for parole revocation, police said. </P> <P>Soldat has one of the lengthiest car theft records in the province, racking up more than 80 convictions. </P> <P>He was convicted in November 2007 of three counts of possessing a stolen automobile and one count each of automobile theft, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle and flight from police. He was sentenced in April 2008 to five years in prison. </P> <P>In court, Justice Karen Simonsen described Soldat as an unrepentant car thief who shows little hope of rehabilitation. The crimes happened while he was a youth but he consented to being sentenced as an adult, meaning he was eligible to be sent to an adult facility and can be identified in the media. </P> <P>Later, Manitoba's court of appeal rejected Soldat's bid to overturn his conviction and sentence. He was previously convicted of using windshield scrapers to pin down the gas pedals of four stolen vehicles, sending them off like guided missiles. One struck a house and a second struck an apartment building, court was told. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 24-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver cellphone ban begins in Manitoba  Also banned: texting while driving, smoking with children in the car
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba on Thursday began enforcing its bans on using a cellphone while driving, texting while driving and smoking with children in the car.</P> <P>Violating any one of the amendments to the Highway Traffic Act will draw a $199.80 fine, the province said.</P> <P>“The message to Manitobans is this: when you’re on the road, keep your eyes on the road and your hands upon the wheel. And when there are kids in the car, butt out your cigarettes,” Infrastructure and Transportation Minister Steve Ashton said in a news release Wednesday.</P> <P>"There’s a direct connection between use of electronic devices and dangerous driving,” said RCMP Insp. Mark LeMaistre, of the Manitoba Association of Chiefs of Police.</P> <P>“Study after study has shown that drivers who talk or text on a hand-held electronic device while operating a motor vehicle significantly increased their crash risk."</P> <P>A government backgrounder said:</P> <P>• Cellphone use is the number one source of driver inattention. <BR>• Drivers who text are 23 times more likely to be involved in a collision. <BR>• Drivers who use cellphones are four times more likely to get into crashes serious enough to hurt themselves. </P> <P>Bans on smoking in a vehicle where a child under 16 is present help youth avoid starting the habit, said Dr. Annette Schultz, an assistant professor at the faculty of nursing at the University of Manitoba.</P> <P>Manitoba joins British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island in banning cellphone use while driving, and Alberta recently introduced similar legislation.</P> <P>British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick also ban smoking with a child in the car.</P> <P>The Manitoba law allows cellphone use while driving if the equipment is a hands-free device.</P> <P>The law also allows use of a hand-held cellphone in an emergency.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/15/manitoba-cellphone.html#ixzz0tql8uoQ6">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/15/manitoba-cellphone.html#ixzz0tql8uoQ6</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorists are reminded to respect emergency crews
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance is reminding rubbernecking motorists to respect roadside emergency personnel — especially in rural areas.</P> <P>“It’s paramount for passing motorists to take caution when passing an accident scene,” said Dan Thorsteinson, long-time chief of the Selkirk Fire Department.</P> <P>“Some passing motorists become very distracted and rubberneck to see what’s going on.”</P> <P>Every day in Manitoba, members of rural fire departments attend to motor vehicle crashes to provide emergency roadside assistance. These individuals often work in dangerous and stressful situations, which can be compounded by the actions of curious motorists.</P> <P>An MPI spokesperson said drivers coming upon an accident scene should immediately slow down and obey instructions provided by attending emergency personnel. Even in a minor crash with no injuries, motorists need to show care and caution.</P> <P>“It’s recommended that both drivers exchange their particulars off the road and in a safe area away from other traffic,” said Clif Eden, manager of road safety for MPI.</P> <P>“Exchanging information on the roadway creates a very real potential for injury to all parties. Safety needs to be observed at any traffic scene.”</P> <P>Emergency vehicles and equipment at the scene can also increase potential hazards.</P> <P>“The firefighters on scene are completely focused on doing their jobs,” Thorsteinson said. “(They are) working with life-saving equipment, getting equipment from the trucks or attending to injured people. In many ways, the crash scene is organized chaos.”</P> <P>Motorists are required to move to the right side of the road and stay stopped until emergency vehicles pass.</P> <P>If you are the first person to arrive at a crash scene, park your vehicle in a safe area so it cannot be hit by passing drivers. Call 911 immediately and be prepared to give specific location details.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba cell phone ban starts July 15
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Smoking in cars with child passengers also prohibited<BR>Drivers caught texting or using handheld cellphones in Manitoba face steep fines as of July 15, 2010.</P> <P>That’s when a law banning those activities comes into effect, Transportation Minister Steve Ashton announced Thursday.</P> <P>“We know the hazards that distracted drivers create on our roads. Talking on a handheld cellphone and texting are major distractions while driving and we’re moving to make our roads safer for all Manitobans, ”</P> <P>Ashton stated in a government news release.</P> <P>“Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant .” – Marilyn McLaren, Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>A public-education, multimedia campaign was launched in September 2009 to prepare motorists for the changes, but the date for the new law had not yet been announced.</P> <P>Under the amendments to the Highway Traffic Act, motorists face a fine of almost $200 if caught breaking the new law.</P> <P>No smoking with kids in car<BR>The amendments also ban smoking in vehicles when children under the age of 16 are present. That fine is also about $200.</P> <P>“Driving a motor vehicle requires the total concentration of a driver, as life-saving decisions are often made in an instant, ” said Manitoba Public Insurance CEO and president Marilyn McLaren.</P> <P>“Text messaging or using a handheld cellphone while driving are both identified forms of driver distraction that can lead to a crash.” </P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island have comparable laws and Alberta recently introduced legislation banning the use of handheld cellphones while driving.</P> <P>Several jurisdictions also have laws prohibiting smoking in vehicles with children present, including British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick.</P> <P>Manitoba’s legislation allows the use of cellphones while driving to make telephone calls, provided they are equipped as hands-free devices and used in a handsfree manner.</P> <P>The law also allows use of a handheld cellphone to call the police, fire or ambulance service in an emergency.</P>

--30--

Title: 27-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorists reminded to respect roadside emergency personnel
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>On any given day in Manitoba, dedicated members of rural fire departments attend to motor vehicle crashes, providing emergency roadside assistance. These highly trained individuals are called upon to work under extremely stressful situations which can become even more dangerous due to the actions of curious motorists.</P> <P>“It’s paramount for passing motorists to take caution when passing an accident scene,” said Dan Thorsteinson, long-time chief of the Selkirk Fire Department. “Some passing motorists become very distracted and rubber neck to see what’s going on.”</P> <P>Motorists coming upon an accident scene should immediately slow down and obey instructions provided by attending emergency personnel, says Clif Eden, Manager of Road Safety with Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>Even in a minor crash with no injuries, motorists need to exercise care and caution.</P> <P>“It’s recommended that both drivers exchange their particulars off the road and in a safe area away from other traffic,” said Eden. “Exchanging information on the roadway creates a very real potential for injury to all parties. Safety needs to be observed at any traffic scene.”</P> <P>An accident scene can be very dangerous with attending police and fire vehicles on site, in addition to the men and women who are trying to save lives.</P> <P>“The firefighters on the scene are completely focused on doing their jobs,” said Thorsteinson, who has been a firefighter in Selkirk for more than 25 years. “The firefighters are working on lifesaving equipment (jaws of life), getting equipment from the trucks or attending to injured people. In many ways the crash scene is organized chaos.”</P> <P>The Association of Manitoba Municipalities (AMM), works very closely with the province’s volunteer fire departments. Adhering to roadside safety is a priority for not only the firefighters, but police and other motorists. </P> <P>“Municipalities have become increasingly concerned for the safety of firefighters while they are attending accident scenes,” said Doug Dobrowolski, President of the AMM.</P> <P>“These situations are stressful enough for our staff without being compromised by curious motorists. We sincerely hope drivers will take care when passing a crash scene, for everyone’s safety.”</P> <P>Safety tips<BR>Some safety tips for motorists to remember:<BR>•When you hear an emergency siren behind you, move your vehicle to the right-side of the road and stop. Remain stopped until the emergency vehicle passes you.<BR>•Always yield the right of way to emergency vehicles.<BR>•If you’re the first to arrive on a crash scene, park your vehicle in a safe area, ensuring it cannot be hit by passing vehicles. Immediately call 911 and be prepared to provide specific location details.<BR>•When passing a crash scene, obey all traffic enforcement directions. Detours around the scene will be conducted by police.<BR>•The law requires motorists to slow down and proceed with caution when passing emergency vehicles. When traveling on a multiple-lane road, motorists must change lanes when passing emergency vehicles.</P> <P>“An accident scene is very dangerous,” said Thorsteinson. “All steps are taken to minimize traffic around the scene and ensure emergency responders can work safely.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI out of control
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It is an outrage that MPI has donated the vacant claim facility on King Street to Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre. This was not their property to give away. It belonged to every Manitoban who pays insurance premiums.</P> <P>I don’t have a problem with the group getting the building, but not in this way.</P> <P>If the government wanted the deal to happen this property should have been sold to the province at fair market value.</P> <P>The funds paid to MPI should have been applied directly towards premium reduction.</P> <P>MPI appears to be completely out of control.</P> <P>An independent review of MPI, its management and business practices has never been done and is long overdue.</P> <P>Robert Dryburgh, Winnipeg<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 29-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Woman to be charged in McPhillips pedestrian death
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 41-year-old woman is being charged in connection with a collision on McPhillips Street Thursday that left a pedestrian dead. </P> <P>Winnipeg police announced Sunday that an unidentified woman is facing a charge of criminal negligence causing death in relation to the crash that killed a 46-year-old woman who was crossing the street at McPhillips and Templeton Avenue on Thursday morning. </P> <P>The accused was driving a Chrysler Pacifica sport utility vehicle that hit the female pedestrian as the SUV turned from Templeton onto McPhillips shortly after 8 a.m. Thursday. </P> <P>Witnesses said the driver stopped and waited at the scene. She was seen sitting on the curb, crying, yelling and holding her head in her hands. </P> <P>Const. Natalie Aitken, a spokeswoman for Winnipeg police, said the driver was taken into custody the day of the crash but was released on a promise to appear in court. </P> <P>Her court date is set for Sept. 14. </P> <P>The woman has not technically been charged yet, Aitken said, noting the documents required to officially do so have yet to be filed. That is expected to happen before her first court appearance. </P> <P>Police have released neither her name nor the name of the 46-year-old victim. </P> <P>A witness told the Winnipeg Sun on Thursday that he saw the victim fly through the air after being hit. She wasn't moving or speaking when passersby tried to help her before the ambulance arrived, the witness said. </P> <P>The woman was rushed to hospital but died of her injuries.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car thief hits family ; Police beating didn't deter repeat offender
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>A beating by police wasn't enough to discourage Cody Bousquet from stealing cars, but at least he's keeping it in the family. </P>  <P>Bousquet, 19, gained notoriety after a surveillance video obtained by the Winnipeg Sun showed police punching, kneeing and shocking Bousquet with a Taser following a February 2009 high-speed chase in a stolen pickup truck. </P>  <P>He was sentenced last January to the double-time equivalent of 22 months time served and released from custody. </P>  <P>Bousquet was back in jail just two months later after stealing cars belonging to his grandmother, stepfather, and a cousin. </P>  <P>On Thursday, he pleaded guilty to three counts of stealing a motor vehicle and two counts of breaching a court order and was sentenced to 18 months in jail. </P>  <P>"One would have thought ... he would have learned a lesson but apparently not," said Crown attorney Mick Makar. "It's astounding. I think he is incorrigible at this point." </P>  <P>Defence lawyer Dan Manning argued Bousquet's criminal behaviour is "de-escalating." During his most recent arrest in March, Bousquet pulled over for police and was taken into custody without incident. </P>  <P>Bousquet's recent thefts came after he stole car keys from family members. </P>  <P>"We don't see him out on the street stealing cars," Manning said. </P>  <P>When arrested by police, Bousquet said simply: "I like to drive." </P>  <P>"It's really quite sad," Manning said. "He's a pretty nice guy but he's got some impulse control issues, I guess." </P>  <P>Bousquet is a danger to the public, said Judge Mary Kate Harvie. "If you're back again I can't see the court cutting you any slack whatsoever," she said. "We simply can't tolerate this kind of behaviour." </P>  <P>Makar made no direct reference Friday to the February 2009 surveillance video and what it showed, except to say "there were some issues with (Bousquet's) arrest." </P>  <P>After the video became public, Winnipeg police asked RCMP to investigate to determine whether the officers used excessive force. An independent Crown attorney from Ontario will decide whether criminal charges are warranted against the officers. </P>  <P>The officers argued the level of force was required to control and handcuff a resisting subject, court heard at a sentencing hearing last February. Bousquet struggled so police couldn't get control of his arms, swung, flailed around and tried to put his arms in his waistband, one officer claimed. </P>  <P>Judge Ray Wyant said he didn't see "any evidence of overt resistance" when he watched the video. <BR></P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 31-Aug-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun and QMI Agency
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P><STRONG>Osborne collision, fire</STRONG> </P> <P>A traffic collision in Osborne Village late Thursday night led to a fire in one of the two vehicles involved. </P> <P>Neither the crash, which happened about 11:30 p.m. at Osborne Street and Roslyn Road, nor the fire, caused any injuries, a city police spokeswoman said. </P> <P><BR><STRONG>One injured in St. B crash</STRONG> </P> <P>One person was in critical condition in hospital on Friday after a traffic crash in St. Boniface. </P> <P>The collision occurred at the intersection of Marion and Goulet streets shortly before noon, resulting in the victim's injuries. </P> <P>"I don't know how many vehicles were involved," a city police spokeswoman said. </P> <P>Police had no information on the type of vehicles involved in the crash. </P> <P><BR><STRONG>Brandonites defy cell ban</STRONG> </P> <P>Six drivers were ticketed in Brandon on Thursday on the first day of Manitoba's new cellphone ban, police in the western Manitoba city say. </P> <P>The law prohibits drivers from holding a cellphone to talk or text, or other handheld electronic devices, while a vehicle is in motion. Hands-free devices are permitted. </P> <P>Another Highway Traffic Act amendment that took effect Thursday bans smoking in a vehicle when children under 16 are present. </P> <P>The fine for both offences is $199.80. </P> <P>Brandon police said enforcement of the new law was to continue Friday. </P> <P>For legal use, a cellphone must be anchored and a hands-free device must be used. Motorists are allowed to answer and end calls with a single touch. </P> <P>Handheld cellphone use is permitted when a driver pulls over and comes to a complete stop on the shoulder of a road or in a parking spot, or to call 911. </P> <P><BR><STRONG>Charges in strange crash</STRONG> </P> <P>Charges have been laid in a strange crash involving two vehicles and a person in a wheelchair in Brandon, police said. </P> <P>No one was injured. </P> <P>The crash happened Wednesday at Victoria Avenue East and Dennis Street at 3:40 p.m. </P> <P>Brandon police said two vehicles stopped to allow a person in a wheelchair to cross Victoria Avenue at a crosswalk but a truck, which was westbound and pulling a trailer containing a Sea-Doo, didn't. </P> <P>A vehicle travelling on Dennis Street crossed Victoria Avenue, expecting all traffic to stop for the pedestrian, and was struck by the truck, police said. </P> <P>As a result of the crash, the Sea-Doo flew off the trailer and struck the wheelchair, knocking the person out of it, and then landed along some trees in the lot of a Lions Manor, police said. </P> <P>Police said the drivers will be charged under the Highway Traffic Act with failing to yield to a pedestrian at a crosswalk and proceeding before it was safe to do so. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver charged after car wrecks eatery
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A young Winnipeg man has been charged with dangerous driving after a crash caused $200,000 in damage to a restaurant. </P> <P>The 22-year-old's car allegedly slammed into the Marigold Chinese Food restaurant at 718 Osborne Street S. at 2:20 a.m. Thursday, police said. The entire front of the eatery is currently boarded up. </P> <P>Police said their investigation has shown the man was driving at "excessively high" speeds at the time his car allegedly hit the business. </P> <P>Police have also charged him with leaving the scene of an accident. </P> <P>He was released from custody on a promise to appear in court at a later date. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 2-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Charge laid in Winnipeg crosswalk death
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg motorist accused of killing a pedestrian at a crosswalk on one of the city's busiest routes will face a homicide-related charge in connection to the death. </P> <P>Police said the woman, 41, was arrested and charged with criminal negligence causing death following the Thursday crash, which happened at 8 a.m. CT at Templeton Avenue and McPhillips Street. </P> <P>A 46-year-old woman was killed by a vehicle turning left onto McPhillips as she crossed the street using a pedestrian crosswalk, police said. </P> <P>Police announced the charge on Sunday. The driver was released on a promise to appear in court at a later date. </P> <P>Police identified neither the driver nor the dead woman. </P> <P>A charge of criminal negligence causing death suggests police believe the woman's death occurred because the driver showed a reckless disregard for the safety of others. </P> <P>The driver faces a maximum sentence of life in prison if convicted. There is no mandatory minimum sentence. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 3-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Don’t Forget The New Laws Now in Effect Carry A $199.80 Fine
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Enforcement of Manitoba’s bans on talking on hand-held electronic devices, texting while driving and smoking in vehicles with children in the car is now in effect, Infrastructure and Transportation Minister Steve Ashton announced “ The message to Manitobans is this – when you’re on the road, keep your eyes on the road and your hands upon the wheel. And when there are kids in the car, butt out your cigarettes,” said Ashton. “We are increasing safety on our roads and promoting healthier living for children. And, now, those measures will be backed up with fines.”</P> <P>The amendments to the Highway Traffic Act, which were proclaimed into law, July 15, both carry a fine of $199.80.</P> <P>“There’s a direct connection between use of electronic devices and dangerous driving,” said RCMP Insp. Mark LeMaistre , of the Manitoba Association of Chiefs of Police. “Study after study has shown that drivers who talk or text on a hand-held electronic devices while operating a motor vehicle significantly increased their crash risk. In an effort to improve road safety and healthy living, the province has legislated two new laws that take effect today. Enforcement actions have begun province-wide and these new laws will carry a fine.”</P> <P>“The vehicle is one environment where parents can influence their children’s susceptibility to smoking in the future,” said Dr. Annette Schultz, an assistant professor in the faculty of nursing at the University of Manitoba and an investigator at the psychosocial oncology and cancer nursing research group at the St. Boniface Hospital Research Centre. “And our research suggests that enforced vehicle smoking bans support youth in maintaining a resolve to remain smoke free, regardless of the smoking status of the parent.”</P> <P>British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island have laws banning the use of handheld cell phones while driving and Alberta recently introduced such legislation. Several jurisdictions prohibit smoking in vehicles with children present, including British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick.</P> <P>Manitoba’s new law allows cellphone use while driving to make telephone calls if the equipment is a hands-free device and used in a hands-free manner. The law also allows use of a hand-held cellphone, in an emergency, to call the police, fire or ambulance service.</P>

--30--

Title: 4-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI reports strong first quarter
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Fuelled by reduced claims costs, Manitoba Public Insurance reported net income of $102.9 million for the first quarter of 2010.</P> <P>For the three months ended May 31, 2010, earned revenues increased by $5.2 million over the same period last year, as the number and value of vehicles insured increased. Net income from operations increased from the previous year by $90.7 million due to improved underwriting results of $92.6 million offset by a $1.9 million decrease in investment income.</P> <P>Claims costs for the first three months decreased by $85.2 million to $105.4 million, explained Don Palmer, vice-president of corporate finance and chief financial officer. The significant decrease is largely attributable to a $78.2 million decrease in bodily injury claims. In addition, physical damage claims costs also decreased, attributed to winter ending earlier than normal.</P> <P>“This one-time decrease was due to an unusual release in claims reserves caused by a rise in interest rates,” said Palmer. “This decrease in claims costs is not expected to be sustained throughout the year.</P> <P>“Traditionally, the first two quarters of the corporation’s fiscal year generate a profit, which is then offset by an increase in claims during the winter months,” said Palmer.</P> <P>Last month the corporation submitted its 2011/12 Basic insurance rate application to the Public Utilities Board, requesting an overall Basic insurance rate decrease of 4.0 per cent and a proposed premium rebate of $92.2 million. If approved by the PUB, policy holders can expect to receive a cheque in the spring of 2011 of about $115 on average.</P> <P>If approved, this will be the 12th year out of the last 13 in which Manitoba Public Insurance had either held the line on, or decreased, the average rate paid by Manitobans for Basic auto insurance. The PUB is expected to rule on the application in late fall.</P> <P>“This will be the fifth rebate in 11 years,” said Palmer. “In total, more than $350 million has been given back to Manitobans. The public auto insurance model continues to achieve its founding objective - to provide the most comprehensive auto insurance at the most affordable cost.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Chase suspects flee
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A stolen heavy-duty truck reached speeds of almost 120 km/h as its occupants fled from Winnipeg police officers Sunday. </P> <P>The vehicle later collided with a police car. </P> <P>Police said it was unsafe to initiate a pursuit because the truck was driven erratically over curbs, onto grass, and possibly the wrong way down a street. </P> <P>"It was an extremely dangerous scenario," said police spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen. </P> <P>An off-duty officer was the first to stop the stolen Ford F-350 truck. He or she saw it in the 1600-block of Pembina Highway at 6:50 p.m. </P> <P>Uniformed officers found it a short time later but it fled at a high rate of speed, heading north on Pembina. </P> <P>At 7:10 p.m., police spotted the truck near Keewatin Street and Logan Avenue. It then struck a police cruiser, causing extensive damage. </P> <P>No serious injuries were reported, police said. </P> <P>A spike belt was deployed at some point in the ordeal but Michalyshen did not know if it pierced any of the truck's tires. </P> <P>The suspects fled again. The truck was later found abandoned in the 1200-block of Jefferson Avenue. The suspects were gone. No one has been arrested. </P> <P>It's believed at least two people were in the truck. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police chase stolen truck
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police recovered a stolen truck but are still looking for the suspects involved in a high-speed chase Sunday.</P> <P>An off-duty officer noticed the vehicle just before 7 a.m. in the 1600 block of Pembina Highway.</P> <P>On-duty officers responded and attempted to stop the truck, which then sped away northbound on Pembina.</P> <P>The truck was located about 20 minutes later around Keewatin Street and Logan Avenue and crashed into a police cruiser before speeding off once again.</P> <P>The cruiser experienced extensive damage but no one was injured.</P> <P>The abandoned vehicle was later recovered in the 1200 block of Jefferson Avenue.</P> <P>No arrests have been made.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/19/mb-police-chase-stolen-truck-winnipeg.html#ixzz0uE9rDxWB">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/19/mb-police-chase-stolen-truck-winnipeg.html#ixzz0uE9rDxWB</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: The good news? We're no longer the auto theft capital
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>For the first time in years, Winnipeg isn't wearing Canada's auto theft crown. </P> <P>The unwanted and embarrassing auto theft capital title now belongs to Brantford, Ont., according to a Statistics Canada crime study released Tuesday. </P> <P>Per capita, Brantford, the birthplace of hockey legend Wayne Gretzky, had the most thefts and attempted thefts (686 per 100,000 residents) in 2009. </P> <P>Winnipeg's rate of 629 -- reflecting a 34% year-to-year drop in thefts and attempts -- put the city in third. Kelowna, B.C., has the country's second highest rate at 659. </P> <P>Winnipeg has had the worst or one of the worst auto theft rates for more than 15 years. </P> <P>The drop is a coup for police, probation officers and others who've been battling the city's car theft epidemic and seen gradual decreases. </P> <P>"We've been forecasting a drop (in the rankings) for a number of years and now we're seeing it," said Manitoba Public Insurance spokesman Brian Smiley. </P> <P>The credit is largely given to the Winnipeg Auto Theft Suppression Strategy, an intensive program which sees police and probation officers monitor Winnipeg's worst youth auto thieves -- who are responsible for the bulk of thefts -- when they're on probation. Slip-ups such as curfew breaches land them back behind bars. The program's architects say fewer cars are stolen when the worst offenders are locked up. </P> <P>Auto theft rates have dropped dramatically since the program began in 2005. </P> <P>In 2004, Winnipeg's worst year on record, almost 9,000 vehicles were stolen. Smiley said 2,200 were stolen last year. </P> <P>MPI's mandatory immobilizer program for at-risk vehicles was also credited for the decrease, which was met with cautious optimism. </P> <P>People are still stealing vehicles so there is still work to be done, Smiley said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 8-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Renewing city's war on crime
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Any doubt that crime should be front and centre in this fall's municipal election should have been erased with the discouraging revelation Winnipeg's ongoing war on crime has taken a turn for the worse. </P> <P>Sure, the overall crime rate shrank by 3%. And -- big news -- the city is no longer the auto theft capital of Canada, an impressive feat given the car theft epidemic that hit Winnipeg for much of this past decade. </P> <P>But with that small measure of good news came a whack of ugly statistics. </P> <P>Winnipeg's violent crime severity index -- which measures everything from murder to harassing phone calls -- was the highest of Canada's 33 biggest cities in 2009, jumping a gargantuan 15% at a time when most other population centres in the country saw a decline. In addition, we're killing the competition when it comes to homicides, with the highest per-capita rate amongst major cities. And the rate at which Manitoba kids are being accused of homicide went up, too. </P> <P>With all these stats in front of us, does anybody still think rapid transit is the issue most Winnipeggers want dealt with above all others? Didn't think so. </P> <P>Of course, there's enough blame to go around when it comes to the city's struggles with curbing violent crime. </P> <P>There's the federal Liberals and NDP, who have repeatedly watered down tough-on-crime legislation put forward by the Harper government, allowing out-of-touch judges to hand out lax sentences. And there's the NDP government, which has had a dozen or so failed gang strategies in the past decade. </P> <P>Both these things will undoubtedly be cited in the weeks ahead by Mayor Sam Katz as reasons for the city's struggles, with special emphasis put on how the challenger to his throne, Judy Wasylycia-Leis, was a member of the hug-a-thug crew on Parliament Hill up until recently. </P> <P>But Katz's record is similarly iffy. Over the past six years, he has spearheaded crime-fighting programs such as CrimeStat and Clean Sweep, initiatives that have unfortunately done little in the long-term to solving the problem. </P> <P>It was thought the recently-formed Gang Response and Suppression Plan, which mimics the strategy used to curb auto theft, would help when this year's crime stats come out next summer. But the Winnipeg Police Association said Tuesday the program's resources are limited and stretched thin, effectively muting any success it can have. </P> <P>Here's hoping Katz and Wasylycia-Leis recognize how badly Winnipeggers want to curb crime in their town and ensure police have the resources they need to run GRASP as it was intended. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Two charged after 3-year-old hurt in collision
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two men from Keeseekoownin First Nation face charges after a two-vehicle collision near Shoal Lake sent a three-year-old to hospital. </P> <P>Shoal Lake RCMP and emergency services personnel were called to the the intersection of Highway 354 and Bridge Road on Tuesday morning at about 9:30 a.m., </P> <P>Police say Jesse William Bone, 29, was driving a 1986 Chevrolet S10 pickup westbound on Bridge Road, and was struck when he attempted to cross the highway. The second vehicle, a southbound 1984 Chevrolet Cutlass, was allegedly driven by Lane Wilson, 23. </P> <P>Police say neither driver had a license, and neither vehicle was registered. </P> <P>The three-year-old, a passenger in the Cutlass, was apparently not in a proper child restraint, and was taken to Shoal Lake Hospital then transferred to Winnipeg with a serious leg injury. </P> <P>Bone and Wilson have both been charged with driving without a licence and operating unregistered vehicles. Bone has been also charged with proceed before safe to do so and Wilson has been charged with driving a motor vehicle when a child is improperly restrained.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Severe violent crime in city tops nation
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It's grim news for a city that once wore the murder capital of Canada crown. </P> <P>Now, Winnipeg has the title of the Canadian city with the most severe violent crime. </P> <P>A Statistics Canada survey on crime released Tuesday said Manitoba continues to have the highest homicide rate in Canada for the third year running. Winnipeg has the third-highest homicide rate in Canada, behind Abbotsford- Mission and Thunder Bay. </P> <P>It and Nunavut are the only Canadian territories or provinces to report an increase in crime severity. Gord Mackintosh, the province's acting justice minister, said the province has "serious concerns" about its homicide rate. </P> <P>The homicide rate can affect the city and province's rankings in other areas. </P> <P>"I think every time there is a murder it has a profound impact, sometimes on generations," he said. "Any crime, even a lower-level crime, is cause for concern." </P> <P>Statisticians use a system called the crime severity index (CSI) to show how crime impacts a city or province. The system was introduced last year and measures not only the number of crimes, but the seriousness of those offences, so an offence like a bicycle theft doesn't equate with a murder. The report says there were 443,000 violent incidents across Canada in 2009, or about one in five offences. </P> <P>The report said Manitoba has the highest violent-crime severity in Canada, increasing 10 per cent in 2009, driven by a surge in robberies. </P> <P>Winnipeg also had a 15 per cent increase in violent crime severity, meaning it has the most severe violent crime of any city of 100,000 people or more. </P> <P>For Progressive Conservative justice critic Kelvin Goertzen, the report is full of "bad news" he deems a "shocking disappointment." </P> <P>The report also said in 2009, Winnipeg had the highest rate of robbery in Canada, up 26 per cent. Winnipeg Police Service spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen acknowledged some of the report's findings are "frustrating" for officers. </P> <P>"When we're always focusing in on significant incidents, like stabbings, serious assaults, homicides, and so forth, it does place a significant impact on our resources," said Michalyshen. </P> <P>However, he pointed out there have been 10 homicides so far this year in the city compared with 16 at the same time last year. And Statistics Canada said violent crimes like homicide, serious assaults and sexual assaults declined across Canada in 2009. </P> <P>The report also noted Winnipeg is no longer the auto theft capital of Canada, after Brantford, Ont. claimed the dubious honour. </P> <P>In fact, the report said Winnipeg saw the largest decline -- 25 per cent -- in the rate of motor vehicle theft in 2009. </P> <P>The report is based on information collected by police services across the country from January to December 2009. </P> <P><A href="mailto:gabrielle.giroday@freepress.mb.ca">gabrielle.giroday@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P><STRONG>Among the lowlights</STRONG> </P> <P>Manitoba has had the highest homicide rate in Canada three years running </P> <P>Winnipeg has the third-highest homicide rate in Canada, behind Abbotsford- Mission and Thunder Bay </P> <P>Winnipeg has the third-highest crime severity index (CSI) of Canadian cities, behind Saskatoon and Regina </P> <P>Winnipeg has the highest violent CSI of all Canadian cities, as does Manitoba among Canadian provinces </P> <P>Winnipeg has the highest rate of robbery in Canada </P>

--30--

Title: 11-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Child badly injured in Manitoba crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A three-year-old child was seriously injured Tuesday after two unregistered vehicles allegedly driven by two unlicensed drivers collided on a Manitoba First Nation community.</P> <P>RCMP said at about 9:25 a.m., they were called to a car-truck crash on the Keeseekoowenin First Nation, located about 250 kilometres west of Winnipeg.</P> <P>Sgt. Bob Chabot said a pickup truck was travelling west across Highway 354 when a southbound car hit it. </P> <P>The child, who was in the car, was taken to hospital with a serious leg injury. The child was later transferred to hospital in Winnipeg for further treatment.</P> <P>The child was not riding in a proper child restraint, RCMP said.</P> <P>The male two drivers, 23 and 29, face charges under the Highway Traffic Act for driving without licences and operating unregistered vehicles, Chabot said.</P> <P>The 29-year-old was also cited for proceeding before being safe to do so. The 23-year-old faces an additional charge of driving when a child is improperly restrained, police said.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/20/man-crash-manitoba-child-injured.html#ixzz0uK0RVd6g">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/20/man-crash-manitoba-child-injured.html#ixzz0uK0RVd6g</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Court hears chronic car thieves video exploits during rampage across Prairies
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - A court is hearing details of what some justice officials have dubbed a “Bonnie-and-Clyde” style crime spree by two young chronic Winnipeg car thieves. </P> <P>Sentencing arguments are being heard in the case of a 16-year-old girl who has pleaded guilty to several charges after a rampage that stretched from Manitoba to Alberta. </P> <P>Court heard the girl and her 18-year-old boyfriend stole cars, gas and property during a one-month period last summer and made videos of their exploits. </P> <P>In two cases, a Hummer was burned near Winnipeg and an attempt was made to run down someone trying to stop a theft in eastern Saskatchewan. </P> <P>Crown lawyer Stephanie Hermiston says the case resembles a Hollywood fantasy story. </P> <P>The girl, who can't be named under the Youth Criminal Justice Act, will return to court Aug. 19, while the co-accused will also be in court.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cell phone ban now in place
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Motorists across the province are to be reminded that the enforcement of Manitoba’s bans on talking on handheld electronic devices, texting while driving, and smoking in vehicles with children in the car is now in place. Enforcement started last Thursday on July 15.</P> <P>“The message to Manitobans is this when you’re on the road, keep your eyes on the road and your hands on the wheel. And when your kids are in the car, but out your cigarettes,” said Infrastructure and Transportation Steve Ashton in a news release. “We are increasing safety on our roads and promoting healthier living for children.”</P> <P>The amendments to the Highway Traffic Act, which were proclaimed into last week, both carry a fine of $199.80.</P> <P>RCMP Inspector Mark LeMaistre from the Manitoba Association of Police Chiefs says there is a direct connection between the use of electronic devices and dangerous driving. He says study after study has shown that drivers who talk or text on a handheld electronic device while operating a motor vehicle significantly increased their crash risk. As a result of this, and in an effort to improve road safety and healthy living, the province has legislated the two new laws.</P> <P>Dr. Annette Schultz, an assistant professor at the University of Manitoba’s faculty of nursing, says the motor vehicle is one environment where parents can influence their children’s susceptibility to smoking in the future. She says their research indicates that enforced vehicle smoking bans support youth in maintaining a resolve to remain smoke free, regardless of the smoking status of the parent. </P> <P>Eight other provinces already have laws banning the use of handheld cell phones while driving, and several other jurisdictions also prohibit smoking in vehicles with children present. Manitoba’s new laws still allow cellphone use while driving to make telephone calls if the equipment is a hands-free device and used in a hands-free manner. The law also permits the use of a handheld cellphone to call police, fire, or ambulances in the event of an emergency.</P> <P>Studies have shown that cellphones are the number one cause of driver inattention and drivers talking on cellphones are nearly twice as likely to have rear-end collisions. Drivers who text are 23 times more likely to be involved in a collision.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI ups fee for safetying vehicles
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The fee for a government-authorized vehicle safety inspection -- commonly known as getting it "safetied" -- will go up by $10, starting Aug. 1. </P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance announced today that the fee will rise from $45 to $55 and will apply to safety inspections for cars, motorcycles and light trucks. </P> <P>“This is the first increase in nine years,” said Ward Keith, MPI's Registrar of Motor Vehicles. </P> <P>“Over the last decade some costs of doing an inspection have gone up. The increase is meant to help cover the costs incurred by the inspection station operator. As before, some inspection stations may charge less than the maximum.” </P> <P>The safety inspection doesn't include a detailed inspection of the engine or transmission and is not a guarantee of the overall quality of the vehicle. Prospective vehicle buyers are encouraged to take their vehicle to a mechanic of their choosing for a pre-purchase inspection. </P> <P>Vehicles which pass the government safety receive a Certificate of Inspection, explained Keith. </P> <P>“The COI is valid for a year,” said Keith. “Once your vehicle is certified safe, you receive a Certificate of Inspection (COI) which confirms the vehicle meets minimum safety requirements.” </P>

--30--

Title: 16-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Two dead in Kenora crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two people were killed and two others seriously injured after a Dodge Caravan left the Kenora bypass and struck a rock cut. </P> <P>The wreck occurred about 8 a.m. Thursday on Highway 17A near Jones Road, not far from Kenora. The westbound Caravan caught fire after leaving the highway for unknown reasons and hitting the rock. Due to the damage, the occupants were trapped inside the vehicle, said Ontario Provincial Police. </P> <P>OPP officials say a 46-year-old woman and 19-year-old man were killed while two other men, the 46-year-old male driver and an 18-year-old man, were taken to hospital in Thunder Bay with life-threatening injuries. It's not known if the victims were related to one another. </P>

--30--

Title: 17-Sep-14

NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- Two people who died and two more in critical condition following an horrific crash near Kenora on Thursday morning are all from Winnipeg, the Ontario Provincial Police said this morning.</P> <P>A 46-year-old woman and 19-year-old man died in the crash that happened around 8 a.m. on Highway 17A near Jones Road. The driver, a 47-year--old man, and an 18-year-old man are in hospital in Thunder Bay with life-threatening injuries.</P> <P>Both victims were taken to hospital in Thunder Bay.</P> <P>OPP say a westbound Dodge Caravan went off the highway, struck a rock cut and burst into flames. Longbow Lake and Kenora fire departments assisted  at the scene and had to extricate the occupants.</P> <P>Police haven't released the names of the victims as they attempt to locate next of kin.<BR></P>

Title: 18-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Battery-powered bikes roaring onto city streets
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Battery-powered bicycles are charging onto Winnipeg streets, as Manitoba's chief distributor for the vehicles heralds them as a simpler and lower-cost version of scooters. </P> <P>Mike Paille is touting the two-wheeled machines -- which run on batteries or pedal power -- as the next great thing to hit the province's roadways, in part because their users need no driver's licence, insurance or gasoline to ride them. </P> <P>And he says enthusiasm for his $699 battery bikes -- commonly described as "electric scooters" -- is gaining momentum among those looking for a practical, easy and earth-friendly way to get around. </P> <P>"This is the way to go. The only downside with it is that you don't get the physical activity that you do from a normal bicycle," Paille said Friday. </P> <P>Paille is using a storage area at City Wide Appliance Service as a base for his business, Mike's Bikes Canada, which he expects to take off among commuters seeking affordable, scooter-style travel at speeds no higher than 32 km/h. </P> <P>The batteries on the GIO 500W "e-scooters" he acquires through a Vancouver supplier take a 165-pound rider 60 to 80 kilometres before running dead. To charge it back up, Paille said, the machine is plugged "into a normal 110-volt outlet, and away you go. If your battery is completely dead, it takes between six and eight hours to fully charge it." </P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance spokesman Brian Smiley said the electric bicycles are increasingly popular, somewhat different than several other motorized two-wheelers and not actually scooters by definition. </P> <P>They have a limited engine size, and under Manitoba's Highway Traffic Act are not permitted on streets with speed limits of 80 km/h or higher. </P> <P>Smiley confirmed riders don't require insurance to use the machines. </P> <P>"But obviously they need to abide by the rules of the road," he said. "And they need to be very alert in terms of their driving. They're on two wheels and they're not protected by a ton of steel." <BR></P>

--30--

(CKDR) <BR></P>
