Title: 26-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cruisers curse police checks
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>He stood in front of a shiny imported Japanese sports car, the centre of attention in a row of vehicles jostling for looks at Canad Inns Transcona's cruise night event. </P> <P>But it wasn't 18-year-old Justin Tropea's hand-polished Fairlady-Z twin turbo grabbing the spotlight. It was the ticket he'd fastened to the front bumper of the car, along with a home-made sign spelling out his hatred for the Winnipeg Police Service. </P> <P>Tropea was one of about 100 Sunday-night drivers traffic officers pulled over and inspected as part of a ramped-up police presence. </P> <P>"They're purely picking on people with these cars and they need the money for whatever reason," said Tropea. "It's a money-grab." </P> <P>Police disagree, stressing inspections are about improving safety for people on the road and the quality of life of those living in areas near cruising strips. </P> <P>Patrol Sgt. Lou Malo, the central traffic unit's head of enforcement, said police use vehicle inspections as a way of clamping down on stunt driving and street racing, as well as vehicles not fit for city streets. And so on this latest sweep, Malo stood in a muggy parking lot as five police cruisers patrolled the area and escorted suspect vehicles into a lot at Nairn Avenue and Keenleyside Street. There, drivers waited for their dreaded turn on silver ramps. </P> <P>Once Manitoba Public Insurance inspectors working with police put those vehicles under scrutiny, odds were they would end up failing the inspection. </P> <P>"We're not targeting any particular person or any particular type of vehicle, " said Malo. </P> <P>He said a "single minor defect" in a vehicle inspection doesn't always mean a ticket or a tow-away, but he advises drivers keep a close eye on how they modify their cars to make sure they comply with vehicle standards. </P> <P>Malo warns drivers shouldn't assume their cars are legal under the Highway Traffic Act after they've been modified. "We don't control what the retailers can sell," he said. </P> <P>"There's the general assumption that if they sell it, it must be legal." </P> <P>Same goes for vehicle safeties done by local garages. "Just because it has a safety, doesn't mean it meets the requirements," said Malo. </P> <P>To wit, Tropea and his car, which landed him a $171.30 ticket at a Nairn Avenue inspection station for "seatbelts, headlamps, tail lamps and brake lights." Tropea said police targeted him for reasons like foreign-made seatbelts in the car that don't comply with Canadian standards but he feels are safe. </P> <P>Across the city Sunday night, officers also set up inspection stations on Main Street near Polson Avenue, Portage Avenue near Moray Street and on Pembina Highway. While some cruisers feel the inspections are fair game, others are frustrated by the police attention. </P> <P>"There's a lot of irate people," said Bob Chubala, Manitoba Association of Auto Clubs chairman, who went to a Main Street vehicle inspection site to watch the action. He said police pulled over more regular vehicles than street rods during the two hours he was there, but the Sunday-night enforcement has had an effect. </P> <P>"The intimidation factor is there, some guys aren't even taking their cars out on the weekends," he said. </P> <P>Adding fuel to the fire is the vitriol of local car enthusiasts who are members of the online car-cruising forum Winnipeg Heights, a website that has about 17,000 members. </P> <P>Forum member Andrea Shaffer said she was furious police set up the Nairn vehicle inspection station about three kilometres from where she and other forum members had a charity event. Five people leaving the event on Regent Avenue complained they were ticketed and she said she expects to hear about more. </P> <P>She said police shouldn't ticket cars that are safetied. "We felt targeted," she said. </P> <P>Police say they'll continue to do vehicle inspections throughout the summer and until the weather changes. </P> <P><A href="mailto:gabrielle.giroday@freepress.mb.ca">gabrielle.giroday@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P><STRONG>That's the ticket</STRONG> </P> <P>Traffic lowdown: If police pulled you over Sunday night, odds are you weren't leaving empty-handed. </P> <P>Vehicles inspected: 102 </P> <P>Number that passed the inspection: 3 </P> <P>Those that failed: 82 </P> <P>Number of vehicles towed: 17 </P> <P>Number of tickets given out for illegal equipment: 106 </P> <P>Number of tickets given out for other offences (speeding, no seatbelts or driving imprudently): 39 <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cruise night culling ; Inspections ensure motoring public's safety, say cops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Of the hundreds of vehicles cruising the usual strips on a Sunday night, some car buffs consider this ride the least popular. </P> <P>It gets stares from spectators, results in drivers nervously easing up on the gas pedal, and draws snide remarks from those who don't agree with its purpose. </P> <P>This unmarked brown police car, along with other Winnipeg police vehicles, gets a cool reception to the spectacle that is Sunday cruise night. </P> <P>A Winnipeg Sun reporter and photographer tagged along with an officer Sunday to find out what police encounter. </P> <P>Enforcement is a dividing issue. Many see the need. Others see police as an unnecessary nuisance and do their best to avoid them. </P> <P>The point isn't to harass or spoil the fun and the motive isn't a cash grab, said Const. Elmer Hanson of the vehicle inspection unit (VIU). </P> <P>"We do it for the safety of the motoring public, to ensure the vehicles that are using our roads are safe," he said. </P> <P>Based on a reporter's observations, police didn't single out so-called cruisers. Motorists of all stripes were ticketed. </P> <P>Still, some don't accept Hanson's explanation. Several people -- mostly young ones -- said they take issue with the police devoting so many resources and conducting roadside inspections. </P> <P>One group outside a Portage Avenue burger joint called it a waste of time and didn't seem to understand the reasoning. </P> <P>In a second group, Lisa Vander Kraake said enforcement might be scaring people away. </P> <P>Cruisers have spread out to Main Street or Regent Avenue but so have police. </P> <P>"It's the tuner crowd and the guys with dad's car who are the issue," Hanson said. </P> <P>Central traffic unit Sgt. Rob Riffel has heard every argument or excuse. </P> <P>Why don't police devote the time to catching "real" criminals? So what if a car has neon LED lights or blue headlights? </P> <P>Riffel's response is it's the job of police to make sure motorists behave and catch the ones who drive recklessly and endanger others. </P> <P>Equipment that doesn't meet safety standards can distract and pose a crash risk, he said. </P> <P>Riffel said a small percentage of drivers is causing the problems. </P> <P>The VIU's inspection sites are well-known. Word spreads like wildfire. People who have something to lose stay away. </P> <P>Portage Avenue near Moray Street is one of the spots. On Sunday, most vehicles here weren't the typical cruise night rides. </P> <P>Each was inspected by a team of Manitoba Public Insurance mechanics under Canada's Motor Vehicle Safety Standards. </P> <P>Kenny Kutchma's souped-up Chevrolet Blazer was reeled in for having tinted tail lights and other infractions. </P> <P>Kutchma was given a $171 ticket for illegal equipment and ordered to resolve the issues or risk losing his insurance. </P> <P>He left with a sour taste, not just because of the ticket. His encounter exposed issues with garages that conduct safeties. </P> <P>Kutchma said a garage passed the Blazer during an earlier safety. </P> <P>"(MPI is) telling me it's no good compared to their standards," he said. </P> <P>Kutchma said he wants garages to be more consistent with MPI's standards. </P> <P><A href="mailto:chris.kitching@sunmedia.ca">chris.kitching@sunmedia.ca</A> </P> <P><STRONG>THE SCORE</STRONG> </P> <P>Ticketing and more </P> <P>Enforcement figures from the most recent Sunday cruise night. The figures include so-called cruisers and motorists who were driving for purposes other than cruise night: </P> <P>- 102 vehicle inspections </P> <P>- Three passes </P> <P>- 82 failures </P> <P>- 17 vehicles taken out of service </P> <P>- 106 motorists ticketed for equipment violations </P> <P>- 36 tickets issued for other provincial offences, including speeding, seatbelt negligence and imprudent driving <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man killed in hit and run
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 22-year-old was killed after being hit by a vehicle that fled the scene in northern Manitoba.</P> <P>According to RCMP, officers were called at about 4:30 a.m. Saturday to Cross Lake, a remote area about 520 kilometres north of Winnipeg.</P> <P>Efforts to resuscitate the man were unsuccessful, police said.</P> <P>No arrests have been made.</P> <P>The man's name is being withheld pending notification of next of kin.</P> <P>Police continue to investigate and no further information is available at this time.</P> <P>Anyone with information regarding the incident is asked to contact the Cross Lake RCMP detachment at 204-676-2600 or Manitoba Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477 (TIPS).</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/26/mb-hit-and-run-island-lake-manitoba.html#ixzz0ut3bNeet">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/26/mb-hit-and-run-island-lake-manitoba.html#ixzz0ut3bNeet</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 29-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Vandals damage cars in Crescentwood
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Vandals damaged about 20 vehicles near Corydon Avenue and Kingsway Sunday night, police said.</P> <P>Officers were called to the area around 10 p.m. after residents reported hearing gunshots.</P> <P>A vehicle was seen cruising the area.</P> <P>Anyone with information is asked to call Crimestoppers at 786-8477 (TIPS) or 986-2877.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/26/mb-car-vandalism.html#ixzz0ut3jpqES">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/26/mb-car-vandalism.html#ixzz0ut3jpqES</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Sep-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba drunk driving charges jump 21%
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Last Updated: Tuesday, July 27, 2010 | 2:19 PM CST  CBC News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The number of Manitobans charged with impaired driving shot up 21 per cent last year.</P> <P>Statistics Canada reports that more 3,700 people were charged with driving while under the influence in Manitoba in 2009.</P> <P>That was second only to Prince Edward Island in terms of a percentage jump in the number of impaired driving charges in 2009 compared with a year earlier. PEI saw a 39 per cent increase in impaired charges, according to the federal agency.</P> <P>While Manitoba saw a sharp rise in the number of impaired charges in 2009, the province still had one of the lowest impaired rates in Canada as a percentage of the population, at 303 charges per 100,000 people. Neighbouring Saskatchewan, for example, had twice the rate (628) of charges per 100,000 people.</P> <P>Winnipeg police Sgt. Rob Riffel said it's mostly older people who aren't getting the message that drunk driving is a crime. Younger drivers are getting it.</P> <P>"For such a long time, it was regarded as a social problem, not a crime," said Riffel. "And I think now people are realizing it's the No. 1 criminal cause of death in Canada … it's a crime."</P> <P>Riffel says police are targeting bars and drinking establishments to catch more impaired drivers in the act.</P> <P>He said the upswing in the number of charges laid could be because police are doing a better job at catching them, but police know they aren't catching everyone who has been drinking and driving.</P> <P>Gord Kowalchuk of Mothers Against Drunk Driving says he hopes the number of people charged keeps going up.</P> <P>"There's 3,700 people in this province that have learned a lesson in some way, shape or form," said Kowalchuk.</P> <P>So far this year, one fatal crash in the city was caused by a drunk driver, and alcohol is suspected in two other deaths. Outside Winnipeg, the number is at least 10.</P> <P>He believes as today's young drivers get older the crime will become less prevalent.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/27/mb-drunk-driving-stats.html#ixzz0uz7h4dlw">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/27/mb-drunk-driving-stats.html#ixzz0uz7h4dlw</A></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: City family's return from vacation turns tragic
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Wed Jul 28 2010   Page: A7
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>DRIVING home from vacation turned into tragedy for a Winnipeg family following a horrific crash near Kenora last week. </P> <P>Chae Nyeo Hyeon, 46, and her son Jeseon Kim, 19, died after their westbound Dodge Caravan went off the highway, struck a rock cut and burst into flames on July 22. </P> <P>Her husband, Soo Hyun Kim, 47, and the couple's other son, Jewan Kim, 18, remain in Thunder Bay hospital with life-threatening injuries, Ontario Provincial Police said. </P> <P>The family from South Korea was returning home from a vacation in Toronto, said Bong-Hwan Kim, a spokesman for the local Korean community. </P> <P>"It's a real sad accident," said Kim, no relation to the victims. </P> <P>The family had recently signed a contract to take over a retail business in Winnipeg when they got back from Toronto, he said. </P> <P>The immigrants moved to Winnipeg a year ago and have no other family in the city, Kim said. With the help of Winnipeg police, next of kin were notified in South Korea, OPP said. </P> <P>The crash happened around 8 a.m. on Highway 17A near Jones Road. </P> <P>The family may have been tired from the 2,000-kilometre trek home, and unfamiliar with the notoriously dangerous stretch of highway in northern Ontario, Kim speculated.</P>

--30--

Title: 2-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Drinking and driving costs Saskatchewan RCMP commander prestigious award
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Canadian Press   Tue Jul 27 2010   Section: National general news
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>REGINA _ Questions are being raised about why an RCMP sergeant in Saskatchewan who rolled his vehicle after having at least five alcoholic drinks was not charged with impaired driving. </P> <P>Sgt. Warren Gherasim was commander of the detachment in Cut Knife, about 170 kilometres west of Saskatoon, when, on May 15, 2006, he conducted himself ``in a disgraceful manner that brings discredit on the force'' by drinking and driving, says a decision by an RCMP adjudication board. </P> <P>``Sergeant Gherasim's admission, the (indications) of impairment and the evidence of the odour of alcohol tip the balance in favour of finding that some level of alcohol impairment existed sufficient to contribute to the accident,'' the board said in its ruling dated March 20, 2008. </P> <P>``Six different members attended the accident scene or Sgt. Gherasim's residence, all but one subordinate to him in rank and four serving under him at Cut Knife. Several of these noted the odour of alcohol. </P> <P>``For a detachment commander, one of whose roles is to set an example, to drink enough and drive so that alcohol played a role in a subsequent accident, regardless of the fact that the circumstances were such that no breath demand was made, is disgraceful, and brings discredit on the force.'' </P> <P>The adjudication report noted that Gherasim worked his scheduled shift on the day in question and drank two beers with a colleague while golfing. The pair stopped later at the colleague's house and Gherasim had another beer. After watching a baseball game together, he had a ``couple of drinks.'' </P> <P>Gherasim has since apologized for his behaviour and been transferred to a different detachment, where he is handling administrative duties. He was given a reprimand, docked eight days' pay and taken out of the Officer Candidate program. </P> <P>He was also stripped of the Order of Merit of Police Forces he received in 2006 from the Governor General for his work in community-based policing in the Northwest Territories and for fugitive investigations across the country. </P> <P>Andrew Murie of Mothers Against Drunk Driving Canada read the report Tuesday. </P> <P>``There's no doubt that officer should have been given a roadside device,'' he said. ``And it's disappointing to groups like ourselves when there's any kind of situation that doesn't follow the normal process, especially when the evidence is there,'' he said in a telephone interview from Toronto. </P> <P>Saskatchewan RCMP Sgt. Carole Raymond said the attending officer didn't have grounds to ask Gherasim for a roadside test and there was insufficient evidence to lay charges. </P> <P>``It's something that we don't condone. We don't want our members drinking and driving, period, even if they are under or over ... we find this behaviour disgraceful.'' </P> <P>Bill Pitt, an Edmonton-based criminologist, law enforcement instructor and former Mountie, called the incident ``another nail in the coffin'' for the RCMP. </P> <P>``This is not a standard of policing that Canadians should have. Does it occur? Yeah, you bet it does.'' </P> <P>Pitt said charges weren't laid because ``people were looking for their careers, and properly so because they wouldn't have had one had they brought a sergeant up on impaired driving charges.'' </P> <P>A spokesman for the Canadian Professional Police Association did not want to comment because the RCMP are not members. </P>

--30--

Title: 3-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Second crash victim dies
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 52-year-old woman who was seriously injured in a motorcycle crash on the weekend has died of her injuries and become the second person to die from the collision, RCMP say. </P> <P>Police didn't release the Dugald woman's name. She died in hospital Wednesday. </P> <P>A 56-year-old Dugald man died Sunday, the day of the crash. RCMP didn't comment on their relationship or reveal their names. </P> <P>Both victims were on the motorcycle which collided with a car on a southern Manitoba highway Sunday about 9:30 a.m. </P> <P>RCMP said the motorcycle was westbound on Provincial Road 405 and the car southbound on Poirier Road. </P> <P>The intersection is northeast of Ile des Chenes in the Rural Municipality of Tache, about 26 km south of Winnipeg. </P> <P>Speed and alcohol are not considered factors and road conditions were reported to be good at the time, St. Pierre-Jolys RCMP said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Letters to the Editor Column: MAKE CYCLISTS ACCOUNTABLE
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Now that the politicians have bowed to a small group of cycle fanatics, what are we left with? </P> <OL> <LI>Bicycle-designated lanes that are rarely used, which translates to giving tax dollars to an elite minority. </LI> <LI>Cyclists can now pedal anywhere they like, in addition to the usual claiming of any part of a street and sidewalk. </LI> <LI>Cyclists can continue to ignore the rules of the road, cross against the light, make suicidal U-turns in front of cars, dart in front of cars, pedal three across so a car can't get by and my personal favourite, pedal at a walking speed, creating a lovely long line of frustrated motorists. </LI></OL> <P>It is time to make cyclists accountable. License every bicycle so when they are abusing their privilege, a motorist can report them by license plate number. For those cyclists who want to bike to work, make them pay for cycling insurance. </P> <P>And one more thing, no matter what the rules, when you put a car and a bike together, guess which one has an engine and is made of metal. </P> <P>ELAINE YACULA <BR>WINNIPEG <BR>Sounds like there's lots of rage on the roads these days. </P>

--30--

Title: 5-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI gets little flak over donation of building
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It's been a decade since Manitoba Public Insurance got flak for a donation to universities, but little flak materialized over a similar donation to an inner-city agency recently. </P> <P>Three weeks ago, MPI announced it was giving an obsolete call-centre building on King Street to the Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre, an established aboriginal youth and family agency. </P> <P>The building is assessed at $1.2 million and the donation raised some eyebrows, including those of local Canadian Taxpayers Federation director Colin Craig, who questioned how Ma Mawi was chosen and whether the donation is part of the insurance company's mandate. </P> <P>"They should have sold the building and used the proceeds to reduce rates," said Craig. </P> <P>A decade ago, there was a public revolt against an NDP government plan to use $20 million from Autopac's profits to fund crumbling universities. Drivers flooded call-in shows and editorial pages and then-premier Gary Doer was forced to abandon the plan. </P> <P>This time, no similar outrage materialized. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said the service centre had been in Lord Selkirk for 40 years and employees had been active in the neighbourhood. Instead of selling the building, it made sense to use it for the good of the community. </P> <P>MPI approached the United Way for some advice and then began working with Community Lead Organizations United Together (CLOUT), a coalition representing several inner city aboriginal organizations. CLOUT canvassed its members and found that Ma Mawi Wi most needed a new building. </P> <P>"This donation is a legacy that will serve aboriginal peoples for decades to come," said Smiley. </P> <P>It's not clear if MPI could have sold the building for full value, or how long it might have taken. In the meantime, it would have been stuck with a property tax bill of about $35,000 a year. </P> <P>A $1.2 million windfall for MPI amounts to just over a dollar extra per policy holder. </P> <P>Manitobans are already getting Autopac rebates worth roughly $115 next spring. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Price of safety going up
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A government-authorized vehicle safety inspection will increase by $10, Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) has announced.</P> <P>Starting Aug. 1 the cost of a vehicle safety inspection will be $55, up $10 from the previous fee of $45. The increase applies to safety inspections for cars, motorcycles and light trucks.</P> <P>“This is the first increase in nine years,” Ward Keith, Registrar of Motor Vehicles for MPI said.</P> <P>“Over the last decade some costs of doing an inspection have gone up. The increase is meant to help cover the costs incurred by the inspection station operator. As before, some inspection stations may charge less than the maximum.”</P> <P>The safety inspection doesn’t include a detailed inspection of the engine or transmission and is not a guarantee of the overall quality of the vehicle. Prospective vehicle buyers are encouraged to take their vehicle to a mechanic of their choosing for a pre-purchase inspection.</P> <P>Vehicles which pass the government safety receive a Certificate of Inspection (COI), explained Keith.</P> <P>“The COI is valid for a year,” said Keith. “Once your vehicle is certified safe, you receive a Certificate of Inspection (COI) which confirms the vehicle meets minimum safety requirements.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI calls drunk driving statistics alarming
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The consequences are devastating and far reaching but people are still drinking and driving.</P> <P>Brian Smiley of Manitoba Public Insurance told CJOB's Nighthawk he doesn't know why some people would take such a risk.</P> <P>He says the statistics are alarming..</P> <P>Smiley says of the 90 highway related fatalities in the province last year one third of them were alcohol related.</P>

--30--

Title: 8-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Have Your Say: Breathalyze them
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>After losing one of my best friends a few years ago to a drunk driver who ran a red light, it saddens me to know newly released statistics show an increase in drunk drivers. The Manitoba Liquor Control Commission and MPI continue to advertise, though unless the increase in numbers is due to a more vigilant approach by the police and RCMP, obviously the message is not getting across to those who continue to drink and drive. </P> <P>Although not all drinking takes place in pubs and bars, the owners of these establishments have to take more responsibility. Some employ bouncers to quell the rowdiness, but all should have a breathalyzer at the exit doors of their establishments. Human rights, they will cry. I believe all rights are lost when you are over the limit and try to drive. </P> <P>Naomi Finkelstein <BR>Winnipeg <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Third victim in crash near Kenora dies
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A third member of a Winnipeg family involved in a fiery crash near Kenora last week has died. </P> <P>Jewan Kim, 17, died of his injuries in a Thunder Bay, Ont., hospital Wednesday, according to an obituary. </P> <P>Kim's 46-year-old mother Chae Hyeon and 19-year-old brother Jeseon (Jeff) died the day of the July 22 crash on Ontario Highway 17A east of Kenora. </P> <P>A funeral service is being held for all three at Chapel Lawn Memorial Garden at 4000 Portage Ave. on Saturday at 10 a.m., the obituary states. </P> <P>The lone survivor is Soo Hyun Kim, 47, Hyeon's husband and the brothers' father. He was in critical condition in the same Thunder Bay hospital. </P> <P>Originally from Korea, the family was returning to Winnipeg from a vacation in Toronto when the collision occurred. </P> <P>Ontario Provincial Police said the family's minivan veered off the highway, which is a bypass around Kenora, struck a rock cut and caught fire. The family was in the process of taking over a local store, a friend said. </P> <P><STRONG>Struck cyclist survives attack</STRONG> </P> <P>A 36-year-old cyclist survived being struck by a stolen vehicle and stabbed or slashed by its occupants, who were armed with edged weapons, in Winnipeg's inner-city late Wednesday. </P> <P>Police said the victim was attacked when he and a second male were cycling northbound on Isabel Street near Elgin Avenue about 11 p.m. The second cyclist fled for his own safety. </P> <P>Police said several males jumped out of the stolen vehicle and assaulted the victim. He told police at least one of the males was armed with a machete. </P> <P>The suspects took off in the vehicle. No one has been arrested. </P> <P>Police said the victim suffered several upper-body injuries and was taken to hospital in serious condition. He was later upgraded to stable condition. </P> <P>Anyone who witnessed the incident or saw the suspects is asked to call police at 986-6668 or Crime Stoppers at 786-8477. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: In Brief: Third crash victim dies
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A third victim is dead after a horrific crash in Ontario last week involving a Winnipeg family. </P> <P>Jewan Kim, 18, died after the July 22 crash that also claimed the lives of his mother Chae Nyeo Hyeon, 46 and brother Jeseon (Jeff) Kim, 19. </P> <P>Jewan Kim was in hospital fighting for his life after the Dodge Caravan his family was in went off Highway 17A and hit a rock before bursting into flames. </P> <P>He died Wednesday at hospital in Thunder Bay, family friend Harry Yoon in Winnipeg told the Free Press. </P> <P>Hyeon's husband, Soo Hyun Kim, 47, remains in hospital, and has regained consciousness, Yoon said. </P> <P>"He has improved quite a bit but still has some lung damage" and a broken ribcage, said Yoon. </P> <P>A funeral for all three will be held Saturday. Family members from South Korea have arrived in Winnipeg. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man struck by SUV, beaten and stabbed
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A man in Winnipeg was hit by a stolen vehicle then attacked and stabbed by the people in that vehicle, according to police.</P> <P>The 36-year-old man is in hospital in stable condition.</P> <P>The incident happened just after 11 p.m. in the city's Centennial neighbourhood, near the corner of William Avenue and Isabel Street.</P> <P>Police say the man was walking when he was struck by an SUV. The vehicle then stopped and the people jumped out, beat the man and stabbed him in the upper body.</P> <P>Police have not released much information about the incident, but say it was not a random attack.</P> <P>No arrests have been made.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/29/mb-man-attacked-stabbed-winnipeg.html#ixzz0vAoyfvKJ">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/07/29/mb-man-attacked-stabbed-winnipeg.html#ixzz0vAoyfvKJ</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Zero alcohol tolerance for drivers under 21
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Ontario government is bringing in stricter rules for young drivers, including one that requires all drivers age 21 and under to have a zero blood alcohol level when they get behind the wheel. </P> <P>Starting Aug. 1, anyone age 21 or younger caught with even a low level of alcohol in their bloodstreams in a roadside test will face a 30-day license suspension and up to $500 in fines. </P> <P>The new rules also mean drivers in the graduated licensing system will face tougher penalties if they violate the conditions of their license, or if they are convicted of any Highway Traffic Act offences that carry four or more demerit points. </P> <P>The penalties for any of those infractions will be a 30-day license suspension for the first instance and 90-day suspension for a second instance. Further instances can lead to other penalties, including having the driver's license cancelled. </P> <P>Ontario Transportation Minister Kathleen Wynne said the new rules are designed to protect young drivers and others who share the road with them. The changes will help prepare young people for a lifetime of safe driving, she said. </P> <P>Margaret Miller, national president of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, said a zero blood alcohol rule for young drivers gives them a chance to get driving experience without taking unnecessary risks. </P> <P>"This will reduce impaired driving deaths and injuries among young drivers," she said. </P> <P>Another change that becomes effective Aug. 3 is that eligible drivers convicted of an impaired driving offence for the first time will be able to reduce their licence suspension if they agree to have an ignition interlock device installed in their vehicle, at their own cost. </P> <P>The province said that will help impaired drivers change their behaviour to prevent them from becoming repeat offenders. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crash survivor just 'wants to die'
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sat Jul 31 2010   Page: A3
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>THE Kim family wanted to have one last family vacation before taking over a grocery store in Selkirk and working seven days a week for the foreseeable future. </P> <P>Sadly, it will always be their last vacation together. </P> <P>Today -- just one day before the family was to take possession of Selkirk Groceries -- mom Chae Nyeo Hyeon, 46, will be laid to rest in a funeral at Chapel Lawn Memorial Garden, 4000 Portage Ave., along with her sons, 19-year- old Jeseon (Jeff) Kim and 18-year-old Jewan Kim. </P> <P>The mother and her two sons were in a Dodge Caravan being driven by her husband, Soo Hyun Kim, 47, on Highway 17A outside Kenora when it suddenly left the road, slammed into a rock cut and burst into flames on July 22. </P> <P>The mother and Jeseon died at the scene, while Jewan survived until July 28. The elder Kim is still recovering from his injuries in a Thunder Bay hospital. </P> <P>Family friend Harry Yoon said Soo Hyun Kim still has some lung damage, but the main thing preventing his transfer back to Winnipeg is waiting for an open bed in the intensive care unit at Health Sciences Centre. </P> <P>But it will take longer than that to heal the man's anguish. </P> <P>"He is conscious," Yoon said on Friday. "He knew his wife was dead, but he didn't know about his sons dying at first. Now he knows. </P> <P>"He says he wants to see his mom and then he wants to die with the rest of his family. That shows his emotional status at this point. </P> <P>"The whole Korean community here wants to help him." </P> <P>Catalina Yi, owner of Selkirk Groceries, confirmed she had sold the Kim family the business earlier this year and they were set to take it over this weekend. </P> <P>"This is very tragic, very bad," Yi said. "They are new in Canada." </P> <P>The Kim family came from Korea only last year through the provincial nominee program. Yoon said he first met Soo Hyun the year before that when the man came for seven days to see if he wanted to move to Manitoba. </P> <P>He said Soo Hyun spent six months looking for a business to buy while working at the Sun Food Mart on Donald Street. </P> <P>The family had just bought a house in the Richmond West development. The parents planned to commute to work at the Selkirk store while Jeseon started classes at the University of Manitoba next month and Jewan entered Grade 12 at St. James Collegiate. "They came here because of their kids -- the education costs are horrendous in Korea," Yoon said. </P> <P>As for how the collision occurred, Yoon said Soo Hyun can't remember much. </P> <P>"He remembers driving and all of a sudden something came right up to him. That's all he remembers." </P> <P>Yoon said one of his last conversations with Soo Hyun was about his plans to take his family to Toronto for a vacation. </P> <P>"He (Soo Hyun) was just so happy. That's why he went travelling. They had never been to Toronto so the father wanted to go. He said once he started a business he might not be able to move around." </P>

--30--

Title: 14-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Vehicles broken into in Landmark area
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police say 19 vehicles were broken into Thursday morning in the Landmark area.</P> <P>St. Pierre-Jolys RCMP said witnesses saw two males rummaging through parked unlocked vehicles that morning. After an area resident confronted the suspects, they drove away in a black two-door car that looked like a Mustang.</P> <P>Police said 19 vehicles were broken into in 14 different locations between 4 a.m. and 5:30 a.m. Thursday. The culprits stole a number of items including CDs, iPods, miscellaneous electronic equipment, loose change, and even “edible items”, RCMP said in a media release.</P> <P>Police advise motorists to lock their vehicles and keep their valuables out of view if they must be left in a vehicle.</P> <P>Anyone with information regarding the thefts is asked to call St. Pierre-Jolys RCMP at 1-204-433-7908.</P> <P>Landmark is about 40 km southeast of Winnipeg.</P>

--30--

Title: 15-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Still MADD Drunk driving jumps in last three years despite get-tough offensive
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sat Jul 31 2010   Page: A6
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It injures more than 200 people a day. </P> <P>And it costs Canada more than $2 billion a year just to clean up its crashes. </P> <P>Yet 30 years after Mothers Against Drunk Driving first made people think twice about impaired driving, thousands of Canadians still get behind the wheel when they're drunk. </P> <P>In the last three years, the number of recorded drunk-driving incidents jumped 16.4 per cent, to 88,630 incidents, according to Statistics Canada's 2009 crime statistics. It was the third year in a row the numbers went up, after a 13.2 per cent drop in the previous eight years. </P> <P>There was not a single province where the number of incidents in 2009 was actually lower than in 2006. </P> <P>In Manitoba, after a 38.6 per cent drop in drunk-driving incidents between 1998 and 2006, the number grew 29.2 per cent in the last three years. That despite a get-tough-on-drunk-driving offensive by the provincial government which has been lauded by MADD Canada and includes licence suspensions and vehicle impoundment and forfeiture as well as a zero-blood-alcohol limit for new drivers. </P> <P>"It's a myth that we've solved the impaired driving problem," said Robert Solomon, MADD Canada director of legal policy. "All we did is go from a situation that was outrageous to a situation that is really bad." </P> <P>There were 863 Canadians killed in 2007 by drunk drivers, and that doesn't include drug-impaired drivers or off-road vehicles. That is up from 815 in 2004, the lowest recorded number ever. </P> <P>The good news: It's down significantly from 1,296 in 1995. </P> <P>The bad news: It's the same number killed by drunk driving in 2000, meaning in seven years, zero progress has been made in reducing the number of people killed by drunk drivers, Solomon said. </P> <P>This despite a decade's worth of new provincial and federal laws that target drunk drivers including tougher sentences, licence suspensions, vehicle impoundment and forfeiture. And three other provinces besides Manitoba have a zero-blood-alcohol requirement for drivers during the first five years of being licensed. </P> <P>But Solomon says MADD research estimates the odds of being stopped by police are low. </P> <P>"Why do people drink and drive in Canada?" said Solomon. "Because they think they can't get caught." </P> <P>The first research on the effects of drinking before driving came more than 80 years ago, but it wasn't until 1980, when Mothers Against Drunk Driving was formed in the United States, that the issue took on political and societal importance. </P> <P>Anti-drunk driving groups began to appear in Canadian provinces throughout the 1980s, mainly led by the victims of drunk driving who wanted the public to notice the a problem. MADD Canada was formed in 1990. </P> <P>Decades later people know they shouldn't drink and drive, but thousands of Canadians are still doing it anyway. </P> <P>A survey by the Traffic Injury Research Foundation in 2009 showed 83 per cent of Canadians said drunk driving was a very or extremely serious problem. It found 15 per cent of Canadians admitted to driving after drinking anything and five per cent admitted they drove when they were over the legal limit. </P> <P>However, Sgt. Rob Riffel, the Winnipeg Police Services impaired-driving countermeasures co-ordinator, said he believes the number of people caught driving drunk is going up because police are better at catching them. He said Winnipeg no longer waits for drunk drivers to come to them and instead sets up checkstops outside bars and places they know people are drinking. </P> <P>Riffel said the perils of drunk driving haven't gotten through as much to older drivers. Young drivers, thanks to graduated licensing programs and drivers' education that hits the issue hard, are getting the message. "It's getting hammered into them that drinking and driving is a crime," said Riffel. "It's not a badge of honour." </P> <P>However, young drivers are still a big part of the problem. Manitoba Public Insurance says drivers between 16 and 24 years old accounted for 14 per cent of the drivers on the road in Manitoba but 30.7 per cent of all drunk-driving- related convictions in 2007. </P> <P>Manitobans between 25 and 44 account for 34 per cent of drivers on the road but 50 per cent of the drunk-driving-related convictions. </P> <P>A 2007 Health Canada survey found one in five Canadians between 15 and 24 reported driving after drinking and two in five reported driving after smoking marijuana. </P> <P>Solomon blames the lack of progress on aggressive advertising by the alcohol industry, media with a short attention span and a perception among the public that drunk-driving deaths are somehow less criminal than other offences such as murder or rape. He said it's made Canadian politicians slow to cut the criminal blood-alcohol limit and to introduce stronger measures such as random breath testing for all drivers whether or not police suspect drinking. </P> <P>"If you are killed in a drunk-driving crash, you are just as dead as if you're murdered," said Solomon. </P> <P>He said cutting the legal limit to 0.05 would bring Canada in line with most of Europe and Australia and New Zealand, where drunk driving deaths and crashes are far less frequent. </P> <P>In 2004, when Canada reported its lowest ever number of alcohol-related traffic deaths, the World Health Organization reported Canada had the highest percentage of car crashes where alcohol was involved, at nearly 40 per cent, higher than Slovenia, the U.S., Australia, New Zealand, Great Britain, France, Ireland, Denmark and more than a dozen other industrialized nations. </P> <P>The federal government appears reluctant to lower the limit. A House of Commons justice committee study of drunk driving last year recommended random breath tests but said the 0.08 limit should remain intact. </P> <P>Justice Minister Rob Nicholson said in his response to the report he accepts the recommendations in principle. His spokesperson said the minister is consulting with the provinces on the next steps to take. </P> <P>Solomon said he believes the government is about to move on the random breath testing, however, which he says will reduce incidents of drunk driving by as much as 15 per cent </P> <P>"It increases the perceived risk of apprehension," said Solomon.</P>

--30--

Title: 16-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: SUV rolls near Kenora
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>KENORA — Traffic was delayed on the Trans-Canada Highway near Kenora, Ont., on Saturday morning after a sport utility vehicle rolled and landed on its roof.</P> <P>Ontario Provincial Police were investigating the crash, which happened on Highway 17 West near the Keewatin Bridge.</P> <P>It’s not known whether anyone was injured in the crash.</P>

--30--

Title: 17-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: It's a bad bet to ask dealer to curb your addiction
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Winnipeg Free Press   Sat Jul 31 2010   Page: H2
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>IT is a curious situation when an addict asks his pusher, his dealer, to cut off his supply so that he won't use the stuff anymore. One suspects it doesn't happen very often, partly perhaps because in real life a drug dealer, for example, has no interest or incentive to cut off a regular customer, partly, perhaps, because most people, addicts or not, know this is not something that is likely to work as a cure. </P> <P>The only place it seems to happen with any sort of regularity is in government-run casinos. People with gambling problems, compulsive gamblers, gambling addicts -- whatever you want to call them -- can ask to be placed on self-exclusion lists. In effect or, more accurately, in theory, they believe they can control their habits by cutting themselves off. </P> <P>As two recent lawsuits in British Columbia indicate, however, it doesn't work particularly well and when it fails, it can fail spectacularly. In one case, a man joined the self-exclusion program but continued to gamble with the government. Over a period of almost three years, he says, he was never challenged once by casino authorities until he won $42,000 on a slot machine. Then self-exclusion kicked in. The casino refused to pay because he had requested that he not be allowed to play there. He is suing in the hope of getting the jackpot he says he won, even if he did not get the cure. </P> <P>The other case involves a woman who asked to be excluded from gambling joints but she, too, continued to attend for the next three years. She was not as lucky as the man, however. She didn't win any major jackpots, but she did manage to lose about $330,000 during her continuing visits. She is suing the lottery corporation because it did not stop her from gambling as she had asked it to do. </P> <P>The lesson here is don't ask your dealer to help you cure your addiction. And the corollary of that lesson is something that most addicts -- of any description -- already know: Only addicts can cure themselves. </P> <P>Police reputation cruisin' </P> <P>for bruisin' despite new cars </P> <P>Winnipeg police are abandoning the blue and white cruiser cars we have been familiar with in favour of some new colours -- black on white. </P> <P>Most Winnipeggers of a certain age remember, of course, the black-and-whites that served the police for a long time, but these colours and design make for a much racier-looking car. In fact, if you took the red lights off the roofs, they wouldn't look out of place as participants on Sunday cruise night, which might be an improvement over the role of persecutors of cruise-night enthusiasts that they appear to be playing now. </P> <P>Perhaps it was their regular exposure to cruise night -- there has been a strong police presence at the event in recent years -- that influenced the vote to jazz up their cars a bit. The old ones do a look a little shabby compared to some Sunday-night rides. </P> <P>Last Sunday's police presence was particularly dramatic, with well over 100 tickets issued for safety infractions, mostly to people who have modified or customized their cars and like to show them off on Sunday night. </P> <P>These were no ordinary spot checks, the kind most drivers have experienced, where you are pulled over for a broken tail light or some other safety failure. The cops set up ramps at several cruise locations to put the cars on so as to check their undercarriages. They were accompanied by Manitoba Public Insurance inspectors. </P> <P>Of 102 vehicles the police-MPI teams looked at, only three passed inspection. Even the smallest infractions were ticketed by cops who, according to reports, were frequently rude and belligerent. </P> <P>The police claim the checks were random and not an attempt to target cruisers. Rather, they were prompted by the need to improve safety on the roads and safety concerns of the public and to address noise complaints from residents who live near streets and facilities that cruisers use. But at the same time, they say, the inspections are intended to stomp out stunt driving and street racing. </P> <P>In their zeal, the police appear to have overlooked the fact that stunt driving and street racing are already against the law. Patrolling the streets and keeping order on them, which is what we sort expect from the police, would be a far more effective method than setting up roadblocks and inconveniencing everyone. </P> <P>Police forces never seem to be very good at figuring these things out however, and we should probably not blame individual officers so much as the administrators who set the policies that the street cops must enforce. </P> <P>On Tuesday, when they unveiled their new-look cruiser, the police also introduced a new motto: Building relationships. It sounds like a good motto, until you think of cruise night and the heavy-handed relationship the city is building with its automobile enthusiasts on Sunday nights. <BR>one to watch... </P>

--30--

Title: 18-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Garage, cars destroyed in fire
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The remnants of a garage fire late Sunday evening in the 100 block of Maryland Street. The Fire District Chief reported four cars and a garage were destroyed in the blaze, which also caused damage to the rear of one home. The cause is still under investigation.<BR>A fire Sunday night ravaged a property on Maryland Street, destroying four vehicles and razing a garage.</P> <P>The fire broke out in a garage at a home in the 100-block and spread to the back of the adjacent home, said District Chief Ted Kuryluk.</P> <P>Kuryluk said the blaze was fully involved by the time crews arrived on the scene shortly after 11 p.m. The fire was put out within an hour or so.</P> <P>Crews were still dealing with the aftermath at around 1:30 a.m. The garage on the property had burned to the ground, and a new car inside the garage and three cars parked nearby had been destroyed by the blaze.</P> <P>The cause is under investigation.</P> <P>The fire caused an estimated $85,000 in total damage to the home, the garage, the contents of both, and the three additional vehicles.</P>

--30--

Title: 19-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Fire wipes out garage, four cars
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Winnipeg fire crews have had to deal with a rash of fires over the August long weekend.<BR>The latest occured last night when fire destroyed 4 cars and a garage in the 100 block of Maryland Street.<BR>The fire also damaged the back of a nearby home.<BR>There were no injuries, but damage is estimated at 85 thousand dollars.<BR>The cause is under investigation.<BR>

--30--

Title: 20-Oct-14

NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Postmedia News   Sat Jul 31 2010  Dateline: OTTAWA   Source: Postmedia News; Winnipeg Free Press
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>OTTAWA - It kills more than 1,200 people a year. </P> <P>It injures more than 200 people a day. </P> <P>And it costs Canada more than $2 billion a year just to clean up its crashes. </P> <P>Yet, 30 years after Mothers Against Drunk Driving started trying to make people think twice about impaired driving, thousands of Canadians still get behind the wheel when they're drunk. </P> <P>In the past three years, the number of recorded drunk driving incidents jumped 16.4 per cent, to 88,630 incidents, according to Statistics Canada's 2009 crime statistics. It was the third year in a row the numbers went up, after a 13.2 per cent drop in the previous eight years. </P> <P>There was not a single province where the number of incidents in 2009 was actually lower than in 2006. </P> <P>``It's a myth that we've solved the impaired-driving problem,'' said Robert Solomon, MADD Canada director of legal policy. ``All we did is go from a situation that was outrageous to a situation that is really bad.'' </P> <P>There were 863 Canadians killed in 2007 by a drunk driver, and that doesn't include drug-impaired drivers or off-road vehicles. That is up from 815 in 2004, the lowest recorded number. </P> <P>The good news: It's down significantly from 1,296 in 1995. </P> <P>The bad news: It's the same number killed by drunk driving in 2000, meaning in seven years, zero progress has been made in reducing the number of people killed by drunk drivers, Solomon said. </P> <P>This despite a decade's worth of new provincial and federal laws that target drunk drivers, including tougher sentences, licence suspensions, vehicle impoundment and forfeiture, and in four provinces, a zero blood-alcohol requirement for drivers during the first five years of being licensed. </P> <P>But Solomon says MADD research estimates the odds of being stopped by police are low. </P> <P>``Why do people drink and drive in Canada?'' said Solomon. ``Because they think they can't get caught.'' </P> <P>The first research on the effects of drinking before driving came more than 80 years ago, but it wasn't until 1980, when Mothers Against Drunk Driving was formed in the United States, that the issue really started to pop up on the political and societal radar. </P> <P>Anti-drunk driving groups began to appear in Canada throughout the 1980s, mainly led by the victims of drunk driving who wanted the public to notice drinking and driving was a problem. MADD Canada was formed in 1990. </P> <P>Decades later, people know they shouldn't drink and drive, but thousands of Canadians are still doing it anyway. </P> <P>A national survey by the Traffic Injury Research Foundation in 2009 showed 83 per cent of Canadians said drunk driving was a very or extremely serious problem. That same survey found 15 per cent of Canadians admitted to driving after drinking anything and five per cent admitted they drove when they were over the legal limit. </P> <P>However, Sgt. Rob Riffel, the Winnipeg Police Services impaired driving countermeasures co-ordinator, said he believes the number of people caught driving drunk is going up because police are better at catching them. He said Winnipeg no longer waits for drunk drivers to come to them and instead sets up checkstops outside bars and places they know people are drinking. </P> <P>Riffel said the perils of drunk driving haven't got through as much to older drivers. Young drivers, thanks to graduated licensing programs and drivers' education that hits the issue hard, are getting the message. </P> <P>``It's getting hammered into them that drinking and driving is a crime,'' said Riffel. ``It's not a badge of honour.'' </P> <P>A 2007 Health Canada survey found one in five Canadians between 15 and 24 reported driving after drinking and two in five reported driving after smoking marijuana. </P> <P>Solomon blames the lack of progress on aggressive advertising by the alcohol industry, media with a short attention span and a perception among the public that drunk-driving deaths are somehow less criminal than other offences such as murder or rape. He said it's made Canadian politicians slow to cut the criminal blood-alcohol limit and to introduce stronger measures, such as random breath testing for all drivers, whether or not police suspect drinking. </P> <P>``If you are killed in a drunk driving crash, you are just as dead as if you're murdered,'' said Solomon. </P> <P>He said cutting the legal limit to 0.05 would bring Canada in line with most of Europe and Australia and New Zealand, where drunk-driving deaths and crashes are far less frequent. </P> <P>In 2004, when Canada reported its lowest ever number of alcohol-related traffic deaths, the World Health Organization reported Canada had the highest percentage of car crashes where alcohol was involved, at nearly 40 per cent, higher than Slovenia, the U.S., Australia, New Zealand, Great Britain, France, Ireland, Denmark and more than a dozen other industrialized nations. </P> <P>The federal government appears reluctant to lower the limit. A House of Commons justice committee study of drunk driving last year recommended random breath tests but said the 0.08 limit should remain intact. </P> <P>Justice Minister Rob Nicholson said in his response to the report he accepts the recommendations in principle. His spokesperson said the minister is consulting with the provinces on the next steps to take. </P> <P>Solomon said he believes the government is about to move on the random breath testing however, which he says will reduce incidents of drunk driving by as much as 15 per cent </P> <P>``It increases the perceived risk of apprehension,'' said Solomon. </P>

Title: 22-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cyclist collides with car
NEWS_ITM_TXT: Southbound traffic on Pembina Highway near Kelsey Avenue was diverted briefly Wednesday morning after a cyclist and vehicle collided. The condition of the cyclist is unknown.<BR><BR>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 23-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver charged after fatal Berens River crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Manitoba motorist has been charged with drunk driving causing death following a tragic weekend crash in Berens River.</P> <P>Court documents obtained by the Free Press show Alfred Bushie was arrested late Saturday night and has been detained in custody. He is accused of impaired driving, refusing a breathalyser and driving while disqualified in connection with the death of Dave Hudson.</P> <P>No other details are contained in the court documents. RCMP have not issued a press release, but a spokesperson confirmed the incident Tuesday afternoon and said further information would likely be provided by the end of the day.<BR><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 24-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man charged in Berens River drunk driving death
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>RCMP in the Manitoba First Nations community of Berens River have charged a man in connection with a fatal weekend crash. </P> <P>Alfred Bushie, 26, was arrested and charged with impaired driving causing death after a 2001 Chevrolet Cavalier crashed Saturday in the community, located 292 kilometres north of Winnipeg.</P> <P>Court documents identified the victim of the crash as David Brown Hudson.</P> <P>Bushie is also charged with driving while disqualified. He is being held at the Winnipeg Remand Centre.</P> <P>People in the community said many members of Hudson's family are in Winnipeg to plan his funeral.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Teen vehicle-theft suspects nabbed
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: The Winnipeg Sun   Wed Aug 4 2010   Section: News
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Three teenagers ended up in police custody early Tuesday morning after a pair of stolen vehicles were stopped by Winnipeg police. </P> <P>Patrolling police spotted the vehicles -- a black SUV and a pickup truck -- driving suspiciously together near Notre Dame Avenue and Weston Street about 4:30 a.m. Police attempted to stop the vehicles, but both refused to pull over. </P> <P>Police said a 17-year-old male jumped from the moving SUV and was immediately apprehended and taken into custody. </P> <P>The pickup truck was tracked to the Point Douglas area where it was stopped by police near Henry Street and the Disraeli Freeway by a police spike belt. </P> <P>Taken into custody </P> <P>Uniformed officers, with the help of a police dog, tracked down the two male occupants of the truck -- an 18-year-old and a 16-year-old -- nearby and took them into custody. </P> <P>Charges were pending yesterday against the three males. </P> <P>Police said the stolen auto unit is investigating the incident. </P> <P>"It's believed they had one stolen vehicle and then proceeded to steal another vehicle," said Winnipeg Police spokeswoman Const. Natalie Aitken. "The occupants in both separate stolen vehicles were known to one another." </P> <P>Aitken said all three suspects were previously known to police. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Motorist charged in death
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: In Briefs  Winnipeg Free Press   Wed Aug 4 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Manitoba motorist has been charged with drunk driving causing death following a tragic weekend crash in Berens River. </P> <P>Court documents obtained by the Free Press show Alfred Bushie was arrested late Saturday night. He is accused of impaired driving, refusing a breathalyzer and driving while disqualified in connection with the death of David Hudson. </P> <P>Bushie, 26, was allegedly behind the wheel of a 2001 Chevrolet Cavalier. </P> <P>He has been detained in custody at the Winnipeg Remand Centre. </P> <P>No other details are contained in the court documents, including whether Hudson was a passenger in Bushie's vehicle, riding in another vehicle or a pedestrian. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Victim run over by two cars
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Manitoba man killed over the weekend following a tragic crash in Berens River was hit and run over by two different cars, RCMP said Wednesday. </P> <P>Berens River RCMP found Dave Hudson, 32, lying in the middle of the road around 11:40 p.m. Saturday while the police were en route to a complaint of a stabbing at a residence on the First Nation. </P> <P>"There were two motor vehicle collisions, two separate cars, with very close proximity to each other," said RCMP spokesman Bob Hodyr. </P> <P>The RCMP's serious crime unit, along with Winnipeg's crime unit and forensics are working the investigation. </P> <P>An autopsy was performed Sunday at the St. Boniface Hospital, but the cause of death isn't being released at this time, RCMP said. </P> <P>Court documents obtained by the Free Press show Alfred Bushie was arrested late Saturday night. He is accused of impaired driving, refusing a breathalyzer and driving while disqualified in connection with the death. </P> <P>Bushie, 26, was allegedly behind the wheel of a 2001 Chevrolet Cavalier. He has been detained in custody at the Winnipeg Remand Centre. </P> <P>Berens River is about 273 kilometres north of Winnipeg, with a population of about 2,000. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Four roadway fatalities on long weekend
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Four people died on roadways policed by Ontario Provincial Police this holiday weekend -- three of them in Sudbury and Manitoulin. </P> <P>Across the province, the OPP laid 7,605 charges for various offences, among them 5,546 for speeding, 62 student driving, 368 seatbelt and 101 impaired driving charges between noon on Friday and midnight on Monday. </P> <P>On Friday about 10:50 p.m., a 47-year-old Garson resident Murray Braithwaite died after a pickup truck left the newly widened section of Highway 69 near Lovering Lake Road. </P> <P>Little Current resident Richard Alexander, 55, died after a single-vehicle crash on Highway 6 in Assiginack Township on Sunday morning. The van he was driving crashed about 7:12 a.m. Sunday. </P> <P>A male pedestrian died after being struck by a vehicle in M'Chigeeng First Nation about 2 a.m. on Monday. </P> <P>A 54-year-old Toronto man died after a single-vehicle collision on the Queen Elizabeth Way near Hamilton on Sunday morning about 2 a.m. </P> <P>One boater drowned over the weekend as a result of a marine collision. </P> <P>Sudbury and Espanola OPP laid 41 speeding charges and arrest two impaired drivers over the Civic Holiday weekend. </P> <P>Officers also investigated 19 collisions, issued 20 other charges under the Highway Traffic Act, two under the Liquor Licence Act and one charge under the off-road vehicle act. </P> <P>A single-vehicle collision happened Friday about 2:30 p.m. on Highway 17 just west of Wahnapitae. The 24-year-old female driver, from Sudbury, was treated at Sudbury Regional Hospital for minor injuries. She was charged with careless driving. </P> <P>Two vehicles struck a bear on Highway 17 in the westbound lanes of the divided highway on Saturday afternoon. No one was injured, police said. </P> <P>On Friday at 5 p.m., police were called about a tractor trailer in the ditch on Highway 17 at Hannah Lake Road. The male driver from Winnipeg had minor injuries, police said. He was charged with failing to drive in a marked lane. </P> <P>On Sunday about 9:07 a.m., police were called to a single-vehicle rollover on Highway 17 just west of the Highway 144 overpass. The driver fell asleep and lost control of the passenger van, hitting the shoulder. The van rolled. All five people in the van had minor injuries. The driver is facing charges. </P> <P>Espanola OPP were called to a collision where one driver did not remain at the scene Monday about 2:10 p.m. The crash happened on Highway 17 on the passing lane just east of McKerrow in Baldwin Township. </P> <P>The driver of a car was overtaking other eastbound traffic in the passing lane. The driver of a white GMC Acadia SUV suddenly pulled out to pass, causing the driver of the car to take evasive action, police said. In doing so, the driver of the car lost control when her vehicle caught the gravel shoulder. Her car rolled over and came to rest on its wheels in a driveway on Highway 17, police said. </P> <P>The driver of the SUV did not stop. The car was heavily damaged, police said. </P> <P>The 28-year-old Espanola woman who was driving the car was not injured. </P> <P>Anyone with information about the crash is asked to call Espanola OPP at 1-888-310-1122. </P> <P>On Sunday at 7:35 p.m., Sudbury OPP had a complaint about a driver swerving all over the road on Highway 17. Police found the vehicle and pulled it over. </P> <P>Police found open liquor in the vehicle. </P> <P>Kyle Yli-Renko, 24, of Onaping, was charged with impaired driving, over 80, drive a motor vehicle on a highway while using a hand-held wireless communication device and having liquor in an open container other than a licenced premises, residence or private place. He is to appear in court in Sudbury on Aug. 25. </P> <P>On Monday about 3:20 p.m., OPP officers conducting radar enforcement on Highway 17 stopped a vehicle travelling 147 km/h in a 100 km/h zone. The driver was pulled over and failed a roadside breath test. </P> <P>Roman Kozak, 55, of Toronto, was charged with over 80, speeding, class G1 licence holder unaccompanied by a qualified driver and novice driver with a blood alcohol concentration above zero. He is to appear in court in Sudbury on Aug. 18. </P> <P>"It's gratifying to see the efforts put in by the men and women of the OPP who focus on saving lives through enforcement," stated the new OPP Commissioner Chris Lewis in a press release. "Our strategy of both increased visibility and focusing on the three key areas of aggressive driving, drinking and driving and seatbelts remains effective." </P> <P>"OPP cracked down on irresponsible drivers over the entire weekend," stated Deputy Commissioner Larry Beechey. "All operators are responsible for their actions not just on the highways, but our waterways and trails and must take extra care and follow the rules." <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 29-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Wild ride results in charges for motorcycle rider
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A motorcycle rider with an illegal licence plate led police on a chase in the city's downtown core Wednesday. </P> <P>Police say at about 1 p.m. officers noticed a bent licence plate on a motorcycle being operated near York Avenue and Edmonton Street. Officers couldn't read it, so they tried to pull the man over. However, police say, the man kept driving and turned onto Main Street, where he hit a curb and lost control. </P> <P>Police say the man attempted to run away, but was eventually captured. After officers questioned the man, he gave them stolen identification. </P> <P>Police also allege the motorcycle was stolen earlier this year, and had two licence plates that were also stolen. </P> <P>Ryan Brackenbury faces charges including possessing cannabis and methamphetamine, two breaches of probation, three counts of possession of property obtained by crime, and flight from a police officer. </P>

--30--

Title: 30-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cabbie beaten, robbed ; Attackers in St. Vital each took taxi for a spin, say cops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg cab driver was assaulted and robbed of cash by two people who then took his taxi for a spin during a strange incident in St. Vital early Thursday. </P> <P>The 37-year-old man is the second taxi driver to be assaulted and robbed in as many days in Winnipeg. </P> <P>The victim in the latest incident was punched, kicked and robbed near St. Anne's Road and Beliveau Road on Thursday about 3:10 a.m. </P> <P>There was some kind of disagreement or altercation between the driver and two passengers inside the cab, so the driver pulled over and got out. </P> <P>The passengers -- a male and female -- got out and physically assaulted the cabbie, police said. </P> <P>Things then took a strange turn. </P> <P>One of the suspects took the cab for a short drive while the second stayed behind, police said. When the first suspect returned, the second took the car for a spin and brought it back. </P> <P>The pair eventually fled. </P> <P>The cab driver was nearby while the suspects took his vehicle for a ride, police said. </P> <P>He sustained injuries to his upper and lower body and was taken to hospital in stable condition. </P> <P>The cab was recovered by police. </P> <P>The violent act follows a series of assaults and robberies against cab drivers earlier this year. </P> <P>New security measures </P> <P>Phil Walding, general manager of Duffy's Taxi, said the local industry is waiting on the province to OK new security measures. </P> <P>Among them will be a new style of shield that wraps around the driver's seat but leaves room to escape through the passenger side in case of an attack or crash on the driver's side, Walding said. </P> <P>Strobe lights, which alert passersby to an emergency, may also be mandated, he said. </P> <P>"No matter how many safety measures we implement it's still going to be a dangerous job," Walding said. </P> <P>Anyone with information about Thursday's incident or the suspects is asked to call detectives at 986-2857 or Crime Stoppers at 786-8477. </P> <P>Police spokeswoman Const. Natalie Aitken said this incident isn't related to one that occurred in the North End on Wednesday at 5:45 a.m. </P> <P>A 46-year-old cabbie survived being stabbed and robbed of cash at Selkirk Avenue and Salter Street. No one has been charged. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 31-Oct-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man had stolen bike: cops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police say a male was arrested Wednesday about 1 p.m. in possession of a motorcycle, two licence plates and identification, which were all previously stolen. </P> <P>The suspect also had small amounts of marijuana and meth, police said. </P> <P>He caught the eye of central traffic unit officers because a licence plate on the motorcycle was bent so that it obscured the letters and numbers. </P> <P>Officers tried to stop the bike near York Avenue and Edmonton Street but the operator took off. </P> <P>Traffic was heavy at the time so the officers couldn't pursue the motorcycle but they did see the driver take a sharp turn on to southbound Main Street, strike a curb or median and fall off the bike, police said. </P> <P>The male was arrested after a brief foot pursuit. He allegedly gave officers stolen identification and claimed to be that person, police said. </P> <P>The motorcycle was reported stolen in June. Two licence plates attached to it were swiped off different vehicles, police said. </P> <P>Police said Ryan Lynden Brackenbury, 30, of Winnipeg is charged with possession of marijuana and methamphetamine, flight from police, impersonation, three counts of possession of property obtained by crime, two counts of breach of probation and three Highway Traffic Act offences, including driving while disqualified. </P> <P>Brackenbury is in custody. </P>

--30--

Title: 1-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cut passport prices to boost tourism: MP
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>OTTAWA -- A Manitoba MP says dwindling tourism between the United States and Canada could be improved if the two countries made it cheaper to get a passport. </P> <P>Elmwood-Transcona NDP MP Jim Maloway will introduce a resolution on Monday at the Midwest State Legislators Conference in Toronto. It will call for provincial and state politicians to push Prime Minister Stephen Harper and U.S. President Barack Obama to cut passport fees to stimulate tourism. </P> <P>He goes as far as to suggest they consider a limited-time two-for-one renewal of passports. </P> <P>"If we want to promote passport use, the one way to get people hooked on it is to get them a good price," said Maloway. </P> <P>It costs between $87 and $105 to get an adult Canadian passport and between $110 and $135 for an adult U.S. passport. However, Canadian passports are only valid for five years while U.S. adult passports are valid for 10 years. </P> <P>In Canada, children under 15 pay between $20 and $39 and U.S. children pay $105. Passports for children under 16 in both countries are valid for only five years, except passports for Canadian children under three years old, which are valid for three years. </P> <P>The Canadian government reports slightly more than half of Canadians have a passport. Estimates suggest in the U.S. the number is somewhere between 25 and 30 per cent. </P> <P>Statistics Canada shows the number of U.S. tourists crossing the Canadian border fell 15 per cent between 2007 and 2009, to 11.5 million from 13.5 million. Maloway said hunting and fishing lodges, which rely heavily on U.S. customers, have reported bookings down as much as 30 per cent. </P> <P>Maloway said the recession is partly to blame, but new U.S. border passport requirements are also at fault. </P> <P>The U.S. began requiring passports for entry by air in January 2007 and for entry by land in June 2009. In July 2008, the U.S. began issuing cheaper passport cards that Americans can use to re-enter the U.S. by land or sea. The cards cost between $30 and $55 and were designed with border communities in mind. </P> <P>A mere 2.7 million Americans, less than one per cent of the population, had applied for a passport card as of March. </P> <P>Some U.S. states and Canadian provinces, including Manitoba, are issuing security-enhanced driver's licences for use at land crossings. They are cheaper than a passport, but Maloway doesn't think delegating border security to the provinces is wise as it duplicates services already available at the federal level. </P> <P>He noted very few Manitobans have jumped onto the enhanced driver's licence bandwagon thus far. </P> <P>Maloway said he's been selling the idea of cheaper passports at a number of recent outings with U.S. and Canadian legislators including at a meeting in New Orleans and one of U.S. governors in Washington, D.C. </P> <P>"People seem to think it's a good idea on both sides of the border," he said. </P> <P>Maloway said the U.S. should take leadership on this issue since the passport rule at the border was a U.S. initiative. </P> <P><A href="mailto:mia.rabson@freepress.mb.ca">mia.rabson@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>PASSPORT FEES -- Canadians living in Canada: </P> <P>Adults and teenagers 16 and over$87 for a 24-page passport ($92 for 48 pages) </P> <P>Child 3-15 years$37 for 24 pages ($39 for 48 pages) </P> <P>Child under 3$22 for 24 pages ($24 for 48 pages) </P> <P>Canadians living in the U.S. or Bermuda: </P> <P>Adults and teenagers 16 and over$97 for 24 pages ($102 for 48 pages) </P> <P>Child 3-15 years$37 for 24 pages ($39 for 48 pages) </P> <P>Child under 3$22 for 24 pages ($24 for 48 pages) </P> <P>Canadians living abroad: </P> <P>Adults and teenagers 16 and over$100 for 24 pages ($105 for 48 pages) </P> <P>Child 3-15 years$35 for 24 pages ($37 for 48 pages) </P> <P>Child under 3$20 for 24 pages ($22 for 48 pages) </P>

--30--

Title: 2-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Woman struck by vehicle, portion of Portage closed
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A woman was struck by a vehicle early this morning as she crossed the eastbound lanes of Portage Avenue near Raglan Road.</P> <P>The pedestrian was taken to hospital in unstable condition. The woman's present condition isn't known at this time.</P> <P>The collision occurred around 1:30 a.m. Traffic investigators with the Winnipeg Police Service are still on the scene, and the eastbound lanes of Portage between Empress Street and Raglan are expected to stay closed through the morning rush hour.</P> <P>Drivers are advised to choose a different route to work this morning.</P> <P>Police say no charges have been laid.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 3-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Getting much less for your insurance buck
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>You probably received the notice in the mail over the past two weeks talking about changes to the Ontario insurance industry that will give you more "choice." </P> <P>You'll get choice all right. You'll get the choice to pay more for the same level of coverage you currently get in your existing policy. </P> <P>Recently the Financial Services Commission of Ontario (FSCO), which regulates the insurance industry, announced rate approvals that while holding rates flat in the short term, signal the beginning of a significant reduction in coverage levels starting in September. </P> <P>Ontario auto premium rates have increased an average of 15 per cent in two years, and more than 20 per cent at some companies. </P> <P>When Ontario Premier Dalton McGuinty came to power in 2003, he promised to reduce insurance premiums by 10 per cent. Another broken promise? </P> <P>The government has passed regulations to enact automobile insurance reforms effective September 1. It claims the reforms will provide consumers with more choice and flexibility to purchase coverage that best meets their protection needs and budgets. </P> <P>The Ministry of Finance, which oversees FSCO, claims the new reforms will stabilize the market and drive down rates. </P> <P>But critics of the new regulations are pointing out serious flaws. </P> <P>"Consumers are essentially paying about the same for insurance, but are getting much less protection," said Dale Orlando, president of the Ontario Trial Lawyers Association. </P> <P>"For example, in some cases medical and rehabilitation coverage is being reduced from $100,000 to $3,500. With such a dramatic decrease in coverage without a corresponding reduction in premium, we can only expect a corresponding increase in insurer profits. What consumers haven't been told is that they will face large premium increases after September 1 if they choose to buy options that may not even restore their protection to current levels." </P> <P>The Insurance Bureau of Canada claims costs for insurance have risen in Ontario due to the high number of costly claims. </P> <P>Frank Klees, MPP for Newmarket-Aurora, suggests the government crack down on the number of people driving without insurance. He estimates there are between 400,000 to 800,000 uninsured Ontario drivers. </P> <P>"For every person who doesn't pay premiums, it places a burden on the rest of the pool," he said. </P> <P>The Conservative MPP has put forward a resolution asking the government to develop a system to check the status of insurance when plates are renewed. </P> <P>"Instead of fiddling with coverage, they need to make sure drivers are paying for insurance, and put a system in place that can validate coverage in real time. Too many people are scamming the system." </P> <P>Now there's an insurance reform that makes sense.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg taxi drivers seek yet another tool to fight off assailants
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ Faced with a sharp increase in the number of cab drivers being carjacked, beaten and robbed, Winnipeg's taxi industry wants another weapon to fight off thieves _ high-tech immobilizers that can stop a running car. </P> <P>The Manitoba Taxicab Board, the province's regulatory agency, is eyeing new devices that can be remotely activated to cut off a vehicle's fuel supply. The car would simply run out of power after a few hundred metres. </P> <P>``There has been an immobilizer identified that will do exactly that,'' board chairman Bruce Buckley said Wednesday. ``We are now hoping to work with MPI (Manitoba Public Insurance) to see if there is some sort of arrangement we can do to incorporate that into their immobilizer program.'' </P> <P>MPI is the provincial Crown corporation with a monopoly on auto insurance. It already offers free basic immobilizers to owners of private vehicle models that are most popular with car thieves. The taxi industry wants the same subsidy for the new type of immobilizers which can stop running cars almost dead in their tracks. </P> <P>``We do not believe that the industry should be paying for them, because when we start talking about the carjacking of taxicabs ... that becomes a society issue,'' said Phil Walding, general manager of Duffy's Taxi service. ``These taxis can be taken and used in other crimes.'' </P> <P>MPI says it willing to discuss the issue, but is not making any commitments. </P> <P>``By our definition, those are not immobilizers,'' MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said. ``But having said that, we want what's best for the safety of taxi drivers as much as anyone does.'' </P> <P>The taxicab board has already mandated new security measures that will take effect in November, including large, L-shaped shields around drivers and bright rooftop distress signals. Cabbies who want even more security can opt for a full shield between the front and rear seats, but will then not be allowed to have passengers in the front section. </P> <P>The move follows a spate of crimes against cabbies, including an incident that saw one driver stabbed Tuesday morning over a $5 fare. </P> <P>Last week, another driver was punched and kicked by a man and a woman who stole his cab and drove away.
