Last winter, a driver was beaten so badly he suffered brain damage. </P> <P>Walding feels taxi drivers face more danger on the roads because their running vehicles are an easier target than parked cars, most of which are now equipped with immobilizers that prevent them from being hot-wired. </P> <P>``The pool of stealable vehicles (is) considerably smaller, which has turned people to looking at taxicabs,'' he said.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cops and cruising Letter of the day
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: Letters to The Editor  Winnipeg Free Press
NEWS_ITM_TXT: <P>The Winnipeg police force has found yet another way of slowing Sunday night traffic on Portage Avenue. On Sunday around 7:30 p.m. we ended up in a lane of traffic on Portage, travelling at 40 km/h when the speed limit is actually posted at least 20 km/h higher. This speed was maintained for quite some time. When we were finally able to safely change lanes and reached the head of this slow lane of traffic, we did not find an elderly couple out for a Sunday drive, a lost visitor to our city, or a Sunday night cruiser not wanting to harm their car on our terrible roads.</P>  <P>It was none other than Winnipeg's finest, a police cruiser. We're not sure if this is a new way of slowing traffic or just a new game the police force is playing with the drivers of Winnipeg. Come on, guys; you could give us tickets for driving that slow, as it can cause accidents just as speeding can. Stop playing games with the drivers of Winnipeg and get to work.</P>  <P><BR>VAL STEWART</P>  <P>Winnipeg</P>  <P>Building relationships: Well if the police force is trying to do that with the citizens of Winnipeg, then they surely failed with the cruising crowd on Sunday nights. Their fear-by-intimidation tactics brought on by Manitoba Public Insurance, Mayor Sam Katz, Greg Selinger's NDP party, which runs MPI and lets them get away with this brutal attack on Sunday night cruisers, and lastly the police chief himself, are nothing more than authoritarianism at its best.</P>  <P>I always thought we lived in a free democracy to do and enjoy our rights peacefully, according to the laws and the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Now we have three dictators who are simply harassing, intimidating, threatening and ticketing ordinary cruisers to stay off the streets in Winnipeg.</P>  <P>Anyone with half a brain can see that. It's time to go to city hall and the legislature and have a mass protest at this shameful act by the three people behind this unlawful act. If you are going to build a better relationship, then start by backing off on the cruisers and Sunday cruise nights and start doing your jobs stopping all the stabbings, shootings and gang-related activities.</P>  <P>After all, we are normal, tax-paying citizens who enjoy our one night out being with our friends. We're not the criminals. Sam Katz is playing with fire on this issue, as the civic election is a couple of months away. I know I won't be voting for a do-nothing mayor. I'm sure Judy doesn't have an issue with cruising on Sunday nights. Let's get with the program and leave the cruising public alone. That's how you can start building a better relationship.</P>  <P><BR>Will Tataryn</P>  <P>Winnipeg</P>  <P>Often it's said more out of facetiousness than fact, I'm sure, that those who don't know, teach. A similar observation, but one far more accurate, I think, would be "those who don't know, criticize."</P>  <P>Never was this more in evidence than in a letter to the editor, and published in the Aug. 5 edition of the Lance. It's heading was C'mon Winnipeg, it's time to make more noise.</P>  <P>The writer sought to take issue with the Winnipeg police department for becoming involved with vehicle cruise night. But surely, in the interest of public safety, they must.</P>  <P>Just as alcohol dependency is said to start with a beer, wouldn't it be understandable that motor vehicle abuse can all start with a minor infraction?</P>  <P>For example, allowing an increase in exhaust noise to "throaty" has resulted in vehicle tailpipes becoming bigger than down pipes, and to achieve maximum, ear-splitting effect, you have to put the pedal to the metal.</P>  <P>How irresponsible is that? Have we forgotten the horrific scene on St. Mary's Road when two workmen were run over and killed by a speeding car?</P>  <P>It's too bad all cruise-night participants have to be tarred by the same brush. But it's the dangerous big shots and show-offs who infiltrate that are the problem. It's they who are the killjoys, not the police.</P>  <P><BR>KEN HOLT</P>  <P>Winnipeg</P>  <P align=center>--30--</P>

Title: 6-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Pedestrian dies after collision with truck
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A woman has died after she was struck by a vehicle early this morning crossing the eastbound lanes of Portage Avenue near Strathcona Street.</P> <P>Louisa Sala, 20, of Sanikiluaq Harbour, Nunavut, was transported to the hospital in unstable condition and has since succumbed to her injuries, police said in a release.</P> <P>The investigation revealed that Sala had been walking in the roadway around 1:30 a.m. when she was struck by an eastbound pickup truck.</P> <P>Police closed eastbounds lanes of Portage Avenue between Empress and Raglan during the rush hour this morning while investigators worked at the scene.</P> <P>No charges have been laid against the truck's driver.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Traffic stop locates wanted man: RCMP
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A routine traffic stop led Mounties to find a stolen vehicle and a wanted criminal, said RCMP.</P> <P>Mounties say officers tried to pull over a black pickup truck on Brokenhead First Nation around 4:45 p.m. Tuesday for a "routine check" when they realized the vehicle had been reported stolen from Winnipeg.</P> <P>But RCMP say that when the emergency lights were activated, the driver fled the scene, triggering a brief pursuit that had to be called off for safety reasons.</P> <P>Mounties say they later found the vehicle in a remote, wooded area and eventually located its occupants.</P> <P>Two men and one woman were arrested on charges of possessing goods obtained by crime, said RCMP.</P> <P>The suspects included Leonard Desjarlais, 30, of Brokenhead First Nation, who was wanted on an Canada-wide warrant for parole violation, said RCMP.</P> <P>He is now in custody.</P>

--30--

Title: 8-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver seriously injured in crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Trans Canada Highway crash just past midnight Thursday sent two drivers to hospital, one with serious injuries, say Steinbach RCMP.</P> <P>RCMP say a semi-trailer unit was westbound on Highway 1 near the Lilac Resort around 12:30 a.m. when it collided with a northbound pickup truck that was about to turn into the westbound lane. Both vehicles rolled into the highway's north ditch as a result of the crash, said RCMP. </P> <P>Neither vehicle was carrying any passengers.</P> <P>The semi driver was released from hospital after being treated for minor injuries, while the pickup truck driver remains in serious condition at the Winnipeg Health Sciences Centre, Mounties said. </P> <P>The westbound lane of the highway was shut down for several hours.</P> <P>RCMP say alcohol is suspected to be a factor in the crash, which is still under investigation.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Safety or money?  Politicians deaf to benefits of adding second to amber lights
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>If adding one second to amber traffic lights in other cities has reduced the number of collisions at busy intersections, wouldn’t it be a good idea to try it here?</P> <P>The group WiseUp Winnipeg has been trying to send that message to politicians over the past few months after longer yellow lights in other jurisdictions in the U.S. have proven to reduce collisions.</P> <P>Trouble is, the group’s message has fallen on deaf ears in Winnipeg. </P> <P>Neither city council nor the provincial government have shown any interest at all in the collision-reduction strategy, despite repeated attempts by the group — founded in part by retired Winnipeg traffic cop Larry Stefanuik — to engage them on it.</P> <P>WiseUp Winnipeg even went as far as bringing Georgia congressman Barry Loudermilk to town to make a presentation on how his government passed a law that all red-light camera intersections must have an extra second added to the length of the yellow light.</P> <P>The longer yellow lights there and in other U.S. cities such as Mesa, Ariz., substantially reduced the number of collisions and red-light running infractions.</P> <P>It proved that giving motorists an extra second to stop made for safer intersections.</P> <P>Unfortunately, none of the invited politicians attended Loudermilk’s presentation in March and the event got very little media attention.</P> <P>A major study on red-light running and collisions by the Texas Transportation Institute in 2004 found, among other things, that lengthening the time of the amber significantly reduced collisions.</P> <P>“The data indicates that there is a trend toward fewer red-light-related crashes when the observed yellow duration is longer than the computed duration,” the report concluded.</P> <P>So why are our politicians so reluctant to look into this?</P> <P>Why not conduct a pilot project at one of the original red-light camera intersections in Winnipeg by lengthening the amber light and see what happens? The city has mountains of historical crash data to use for a comparative analysis.</P> <P>Red-light runners would still get ticketed. And the city would be able to determine if lengthening the yellow light actually helps.</P> <P>Right now the city claims amber lights are set at a minimum of four seconds.</P> <P>Try it at five seconds and see if it reduces infractions and collisions.</P> <P>The city would have nothing to lose by trying, unless they’re worried about losing money from their lucrative red-light cameras.</P> <P>Mayor Sam Katz has always said that photo enforcement is about safety, not money.</P> <P>Well, if we can reduce collisions and maybe save lives by lengthening the amber light, isn’t it worth a try?</P> <P>This isn’t some wild, unproven strategy to reduce collisions at intersections. It’s been tested in other cities and there is evidence that it works.</P> <P>Naturally some people are going to blow through red lights no matter what. And they should be fined heavily for it. </P> <P>In fact, we need more police presence at intersections to catch the serious red-light runners so they can hit them with demerits. Red-light camera infractions don’t result in demerits because police can’t identify drivers from a snapshot.</P> <P>No doubt icreasing amber light times would make red-light cameras less profitable. It may even cause them to lose money. </P> <P>So what? If photo enforcement is not about the money, that shouldn’t matter.</P> <P>I think the city should give it a shot.</P>

--30--

Title: 10-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Jammed phone lines frustrate new drivers
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>IF you're planning to book a driver's test any time soon, be prepared to be stuck in a telephone traffic jam at Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>MPI, which now oversees driver testing and licensing, has been plagued by a deluge of calls that has frustrated anyone trying to book an appointment. </P> <P>One woman who contacted the Free Press said it took her and her daughter over two months to get through to book an appointment, and it didn't happen until she spent an entire day calling roughly every half hour. </P> <P>"You can't get through on this line," said the woman, who didn't want her name used. "This is absolutely ridiculous.'' </P> <P>Once she finally got to speak to someone, it didn't take long to book a test for her daughter. But her daughter failed that test and the woman is dreading another round of incessant calls. </P> <P>On Wednesday, the woman said she'd already called about 25 times between 7:30 and 10 a.m., with no luck. </P> <P>"I don't know how much time they think people have to sit at home and dial this number," she said. "I'm at work. I can't keep phoning. It's unacceptable." </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said the phone line, which fields more than just driver test bookings, receives over 7,000 calls a month. He said MPI is aware of the backlog and regrets the inconvenience to customers. It's a problem that's been going on for many weeks, he said. </P> <P>"We're taking steps to try to ease the volume on this," Smiley said. </P> <P>Smiley said they are looking at having more staff to manage the line. A new operating process to reduce the problem should roll out next spring, Smiley said. </P> <P>For now, Smiley said to just keep dialing. </P> <P>"We absolutely apologize for any inconvenience. You've got to keep trying and that's basically the best tactic you can use." </P> <P>Abe Peters, owner and operator of A River Heights Driving School, has faced similar problems. He books several appointments in advance for his students and said he sometimes has to plan his day around making multiple calls to the line. </P> <P>"I've been trying different times of the day, whenever I get a chance," said Peters. He said a 20-minute wait with no success getting through is common. </P> <P>"It's something that you almost dread," he said of facing that recorded voice notifying callers of a higher-than-usual caller volume. </P> <P>"I think they just need to hire more people," he said.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: HOW TO ESCAPE A SINKING CAR
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Renowned for surviving frigid waters, an expert turns his sights to the cause of 10 per cent of all drownings, Patrick White reports<BR>The Globe and Mail </P> <P>In his latest bit of hair-raising research, the man known as "professor popsicle" became doctor dunk. </P> <P>Gordon Giesbrecht, the renowned University of Manitoba thermophysiologist known for personally testing the body's response to hypothermia more than 40 times and appearing on David Letterman to tread water in a vat of ice water, has retired from human ice-cube research in favour of something warmer, but no less terrifying. </P> <P>In the August issue of Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine, Dr. Giesbrecht publishes the results of some 100 vehicle submersions. </P> <P>In 30 of those, he played the hapless driver stuck in a sinking car. Supported by the Manitoba government, the research is intended to develop scientifically supported recommendations for people stuck in submerged automobiles, a scenario that accounts for 10 per cent of all drownings in Canada. </P> <P>It was a frightening study, fraying Dr. Giesbrecht's nerves on the first attempt. </P> <P>After a crane dropped him into a lake seated in a beat-up Ford Tempo, he calmly waited for the water to cover the door, operating on the common belief that the pressure inside and out would equalize, allowing him to easily swing the door open. </P> <P>It didn't. </P> <P>With the water rising past his neck, he reached his first conclusion: As long as there's any air left in the car, the pressure outside will be greater and the doors will be impossible to open. He took one big breath from the shrinking bubble of air inside, cranked open the window and made for the surface. </P> <P>"I got such a scare that first time," Dr. Giesbrecht said, noting that there was a scuba tank lying next to him in case he couldn't escape. </P> <P>"I'd been preparing for this moment for months, and it was all I could do to get out. For the average person, this would be tough; getting out is just not going to happen." </P> <P>Here are a few of Dr. Giesbrecht's hard-won recommendations that might improve your chances should you ever find yourself in a sinking car. </P> <P>1) Don't touch your cellphone. Some people have the impression a car will float long enough for them to call 911. A car will float for a minute, and you need to escape in that first minute. </P> <P>Beyond that, you'll have very little chance of getting out. </P> <P>2) Release your seatbelt. In panic mode, many people forget this step. </P> <P>3) Open or break a window. Don't bother with the door. If the electric windows short out, use a small hammer or small punch. And if you don't carry one of those, buy one soon. Dr. Giesbrecht keeps one mounted on his dash. </P> <P>4) Grab the kids. If you have younger passengers, unbuckle them starting with the oldest first. </P> <P>5) Get out, pushing the kids ahead of you. Dr. Giesbrecht found that it was possible to escape through a window, even with a torrent of water flowing in.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Swan gets behind wheel to unjam MPI phones
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The jammed phone lines at Manitoba Public Insurance will be unclogged next week, Manitoba Attorney General Andrew Swan said Thursday. </P> <P>Following a Free Press story detailing the frustration of people calling MPI trying to book a driver's test, Swan said he contacted management at the Crown corporation to get them to fix the problem. </P> <P>"There's nothing wrong with Manitobans demanding good service," said Swan, the minister responsible for MPI. "They were not getting exemplary public service." </P> <P>Readers told the Free Press it took them weeks, if not months, to get through to a human being at MPI to schedule a driver's test. </P> <P>"I don't know how much time they think people have to sit at home and dial this number," one woman said. "I'm at work. I can't keep phoning. It's unacceptable." </P> <P>Swan said he was told MPI has been beset by a high number of people calling to book a test. MPI oversees driver testing and licensing. </P> <P>An MPI spokesman said the line gets more than 7,000 calls a month and that MPI was looking at having more staff to manage it. </P> <P>Swan said MPI vice-president Dan Guimond told him more people are to be assigned next week to answer phones to reduce the bottleneck. </P> <P>Progressive Conservative MLA Mavis Taillieu (Morris) said Swan should have been aware of the problem before it appeared in the Free Press. </P> <P>Taillieu, the Tory critic on MPI, said she wrote to Swan July 27 saying she was fielding complaints about the problem. </P> <P>"This is supposed to be a well-managed corporation," Taillieu told the Free Press. </P> <P>"This does not speak well. It's not as if people have a choice where they can go."<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Ride out the storm
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>11Sadly, it was impossible to overlook all of the vacant parking spots. </P> <P>Although there were thousands of spectators lining the streets, it was obvious many of the 1,000-plus vehicles on display in past years would not be showing up. In the end, organizers John and Bev Dyck said there were only about 350 to 400 local cruisers who braved the storm to show and shine their cherished rides. </P> <P>The storm I'm referring to was certainly not due to the weather, as the sun was shining and it was cooking hot. Nope, the storm I refer to is the controversy that has been surrounding the local cruising scene. </P> <P>To get you up to speed, the Winnipeg Police Service and Manitoba Public Insurance have been setting up a vehicle-inspection unit on Sunday evenings, primarily on Portage Avenue or Main Street. Although numerous other everyday vehicles have also been targeted for inspection, a number of local cruisers in classic and special-interest vehicles have also been pulled over and subjected to comprehensive inspections. It seems Winnipeg's finest have been examining Sunday-night cruisers with a fine-tooth comb. </P> <P>While the police certainly have every right to inspect our cars, and I'm all for safe vehicles on our roads, this initiative has more than a few local cruisers hopping mad -- so mad that many folks I spoke with opted to leave their rides at home. In essence, they boycotted Cruz In Downtown because they were certain they'd have to run the vehicle-inspection gauntlet. </P> <P>It's not that these folks have unsafe cars. On the contrary, many of my friends in the hobby have vehicles that are better than new. But they're really not interested in being inconvenienced for hours on end while their prized vehicles are poked and prodded. </P> <P>One guy who chose to remain anonymous told me he's scared to take his grandkids out for ice cream in his old car because he doesn't want to be treated like a "common criminal" in front of the kids. </P> <P>As it turned out the only "police car" that had a significant presence at Cruz In Downtown was a makeshift Chevrolet Impala that Charlie Johnson entered in the burnout competition. The vehicle-inspection unit was nowhere to be seen. </P> <P>Although no one has gone on the record, my suspicion is the police mandate is aimed more at Sunday-night cruising than sanctioned car shows. So, if it stays that way, folks are boycotting events such as Cruz In Downtown for all the wrong reasons. </P> <P>From where I sit, Cruz In Downtown is about way more than simply a car show. It not only brings people downtown who support area businesses but, above all else, raises money for charity. In past years, tens of thousands of dollars has been donated to the Rainbow Society, a charitable organization dedicated to fulfilling the dreams of Manitoba children suffering from life-threatening illnesses. </P> <P>Last year's event raised enough money for a little girl and her family to take a dream trip to Disney World in Florida. This year, although the final number isn't in, it's a safe bet that less money was generated. Instead of moving forward, Cruz In Downtown, and the money it raises for the Rainbow Society has stalled, and that's a shame. </P> <P>Thanks to the cruising hobby in Manitoba big money is raised for charities each year. My friend, Pat Kaniuga, and I have called upon the local cruising community for the past four years with a Barrett-Jackson Collector Car Auction event that has raised more than $40,000 for the Children's Rehabilitation Foundation. Many other clubs, including the Fabulous 50s Ford Club of Manitoba and the Manitoba Street Rod Association, have raised thousands more for special- needs children. </P> <P>By the time you read this, Bob Chubala, chairman of the Manitoba Association of Auto Clubs (MAAC), will have met with representatives from MPI, Winnipeg police and local politicians. Chubala promises us MAAC is on our side and will plead our case passionately. But, ultimately, he has a simple message: Our responsibility as cruisers, both young and old, is to ensure our vehicles are safe and sound and are driven in a responsible manner. If you have concerns about your vehicle, take the time to learn the laws and make your vehicle right. </P> <P>And if you want to race, do it on the drag strip at Gimli. </P> <P>In the end, the 11th annual Cruz In Downtown was certainly not a failure. It was an absolute riot that kept many folks, including me, smiling all day long. But it could have been -- and should have been -- way bigger. </P> <P>My message is a simple one. In the future, don't boycott sanctioned shows such as Cruz In Downtown, instead opt to boycott cruising down Portage Avenue or Main Street on Sunday evenings. I agree it's a bummer -- cruising down Portage on a Sunday night used to be one of my favourite things to do. But it's clear that the powers-that-be, and many other Winnipeggers, do not support this. </P> <P>So, don't bury your car in the garage. Instead, choose to attend the many sanctioned MAAC car shows or fun-filled family events like the Sunday-night cruise shows at the Grant Park Pony Corral or the Tavern United on Regent Avenue. </P> <P>If you follow this lead, I have a sneaking suspicion that both the police and MPI will allow us to keep on cruising. We are, after all, the Cruising Capital of Canada!<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Katz-top cop parley may ease cruise night enforcement
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A recent conversation between the city's mayor and top cop -- and meetings with hobbyists -- may result in Winnipeg police tapping the brakes on Sunday cruise night enforcement. </P> <P>Mayor Sam Katz said police must be present to deter reckless driving but suggested officers are devoting time to minor infractions that would be better spent focusing on the small percentage of motorists who endanger the public. </P> <P>Katz said he expressed his opinion, not a directive, to police Chief Keith McCaskill recently. </P> <P>"I (said), in my opinion, when it comes to throwing the book at someone who's racing down Portage Avenue, absolutely," Katz said. "When it comes to going after someone with LED lights (on a vehicle) I don't get it, I don't understand it. I don't believe it's a good investment of some of our resources. </P> <P>"The chief said he would look into it. He got back to me and said they concurred ... he said, 'Yeah, I think we can make some changes,'" Katz said. </P> <P>What, if anything, has or may change in the police service's approach is unclear. An interview request wasn't granted. </P> <P>Katz said city hall didn't order the current enforcement approach. </P> <P>Enforcement on Sundays has been a contentious issue in 2010, largely due to vehicle inspections by police and Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>Some special interest vehicle owners have bemoaned the inspections, which they say unfairly target them and are excessive. Some have claimed they're cash grabs. </P> <P>Police previously denied the accusations and said the inspections are done to all types of vehicles to ensure they are safe. </P> <P>Hobbyists said the approach is scaring people away from cruise night and show and shines which raise money for charities, because they fear being ticketed or having their vehicles pulled from the road. </P> <P>Manitoba Association of Auto Clubs directors are having ongoing meetings with police and MPI on behalf of hobbyists to find a solution and a positive relationship to preserve the decades-old pasttime, said MAAC chairman Bob Chubala. </P> <P>Chubala said hobbyists wonder why, if the police are looking at all types of vehicles, they frequently occur on Sundays and not other days of the week. </P> <P>"There has to be a little bit of give and go with the inspections," Chubala said.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: No insurance, no plate renewal
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Starting Nov 2010, a new system will help improve road safety by keeping uninsured vehicles off Ontario's roads. </P> <P>A new electronic verification system, developed by the province and the Insurance Bureau of Canada will provide on-the-spot confirmation of valid insurance coverage during the licence plate renewal process.</P> <P>The ability to check for insurance in real-time means fewer uninsured vehicles on Ontario's roads and less risk to other drivers. </P> <P>In Ontario it is mandatory for all vehicles to have valid insurance coverage. Currently, drivers are required to provide proof of valid insurance when renewing their driver's licence plates. </P> <P>Drivers who have insurance or vehicle-information issues in their registration information will be notified in writing approximately 120 days prior to their licence plate expiration date - giving them time to correct or update their information. </P> <P>All vehicles on Ontario's roads must be insured. There are tough penalties for driving without insurance: a fine of up to $25,000 for a first offence, and double that with licence suspension for a second.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 16-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Alleged MPI fraudsters now face gang charges
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police have now charged the alleged masterminds of the province's biggest vehicle fraud in 40 years with being part of a criminal organization. </P> <P>Almost a year after police charged 26 people in connection with a massive Autopac fraud, police Det.-Sgt. Sandra Martin said, there are new serious charges laid -- three people were arrested on July 29 and charged with participating in a criminal organization and committing an offence for a criminal organization. </P> <P>Martin said a fourth person turned herself in for the same offences on Aug. 6, while a warrant has been issued for a fifth person. </P> <P>"There was a sophistication to how this was operating and for how long," she said on Friday. "It was organized. It wasn't just random events." </P> <P>Martin said it also marks the first time people have been charged with being in a criminal organization for being involved in a fraud. </P> <P>"We need to stop thinking in terms of criminal organizations always being bikers and street gangs," she said. "There are other ways to organize and become a gang." </P> <P>Brian Smiley, a spokesman for Manitoba Public Insurance, said the latest charges should send a strong message to people contemplating trying to defraud Autopac. </P> <P>Charges from the 10-month investigation, which concluded in August of 2009, allege people rolled back odometers, faked sales documents, staged fake collisions and hit and runs, and put together fake stolen-vehicle reports. </P> <P>MPI paid out $650,000 in claims during the fraud, alleged to have been committed starting in 2005. Another $150,000 in claims were not paid out. </P> <P>Smiley said about 60 high-end vehicles were part of the alleged fraud, mostly brought in from eastern provinces. </P> <P>"When a vehicle got into an accident, they would try to write the vehicle off with an odometer that says 40,000 kilometres instead of 240,000 because they would get a higher payout," he said. </P> <P>Charged with the latest offences are Quincy Adurogboye, 30, Maria Austria, 32, Lamont Sesay, 28, and Kaela Leigh Perry. 24. There is a warrant out for Norman Raymond Beardy, 41. </P> <P>Anyone with information is asked to call police at 986-6222 or CrimeStoppers at 986-TIPS (8477). <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Fraud charges a 1st ; MPI scammers prosecuted as criminal organization
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Rarely-seen criminal charges have been laid against five people who allegedly masterminded a massive auto insurance fraud against Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>The five -- three men and two women -- were previously arrested and have now been charged with participating in a criminal organization and committing an offence for a criminal organization, Winnipeg police said Friday. </P> <P>It's believed this is the first time these charges have been laid in a fraud investigation in Winnipeg, said Det. Sgt. Sandra Martin of the commercial crime unit. </P> <P>The investigation was dubbed Project Rollback. </P> <P>The scheme bilked MPI of $800,000 and was the largest fraud in its history, said spokesman Brian Smiley. It was uncovered by MPI. Police began a series of raids in August 2009, resulting in more than 35 arrests. </P> <P>Dozens of charges were laid but the new ones were recently authorized by the Crown after investigators went through a mountain of evidence, Martin said. </P> <P>Police said Quincy Adurogboye, 30, Maria Austria, 32, and Lamont Sesay, 28, were charged with the additional offences July 29. Kaela Leigh Perry, 24, was charged Aug. 6. An arrest warrant is out for Norman Raymond Beardy, 41, who police haven't located. </P> <P>Not only gangs </P> <P>Police are asking people with information about Beardy's whereabouts to call investigators at 986-6222 or Crime Stoppers at 786-8477. </P> <P>If convicted, the charge of participating in a criminal organization carries a maximum prison sentence of five years, while a charge of committing an offence for a criminal organization has a maximum of 14 years. </P> <P>The suspects are accused of buying luxury vehicles outside Manitoba, bringing them to the province, rolling back odometers to increase their value, doctoring sales records, staging collisions or hit-and-runs to make them write-offs, and making false stolen vehicle reports. The suspects allegedly collected Autopac payouts over several years. </P> <P>Police allege staff at two garages in Winnipeg and Selkirk rolled back the odometers and provided safeties so the vehicles could be insured. </P> <P>Martin said the scheme was operated as if it was a legitimate business. </P> <P>"There was a sophistication to the way it was operating," she said. </P> <P>By law, the suspects allegedly form an organized crime group. The Criminal Code defines an organized crime group as three or more people who commit serious crimes for some kind of gain. </P> <P>"We need to maybe stop thinking of criminal organizations as being bikers and street gangs," Martin said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 18-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Bad MPI planning
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>There's some good news for Manitobans who have endured endless frustration when calling Manitoba Public Insurance to book a driver's test. </P> <P>A story published by the Winnipeg Free Press earlier this week reveals that MPI, which now oversees driver testing and licensing, has been plagued by a deluge of calls -- causing consternation for anyone trying to book an appointment. </P> <P>Several callers have spent days, weeks, and in at least one case, months, attempting to get through to a human being on the other end of the line, just to book an appointment. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said the phone line, which fields more than just driver test bookings, receives more than 7,000 calls a month. He said MPI is aware of the backlog and regrets the inconvenience to customers. It's a problem that has been going on for many weeks, he said. </P> <P>Well after that story hit the printed page, Manitoba Attorney General Andrew Swan jumped into action and told media that the jammed phone lines will be unclogged next week. </P> <P>"There's nothing wrong with Manitobans demanding good service," Swan said. "They were not getting exemplary public service." </P> <P>Wow. Understatement. </P> <P>MPI has already indicated it planned to assign more people to answer the phone to reduce the bottleneck. </P> <P>That's all great, but we have to agree with MPI critic, Progressive Conservative Morris MLA Mavis Taillieu who said she wrote to Swan on July 27 that she had been fielding complaints about the problem already. </P> <P>"This is supposed to be a well-managed corporation," Taillieu said. "This does not speak well. It's not as if people have a choice where they can go." </P> <P>In the 2009-10 fiscal year, Manitoba Public Insurance earned $935.3 million in total earned revenues, including $21 million received from the provincial government as part of its agreement to provide services related to the Drivers and Vehicles Act operations. </P> <P>According to the corporation's 2009 annual report, MPI reported income from annual operations of $86.9 million. Its $96.3 million investment income helped reduce the cost of average basic Autopac premium by $103. MPI's basic plan also surpassed its goals by providing claimants with 86 cents in benefits for every $1 in premium -- which it states is "significantly" better than the national average. </P> <P>The same report boasts that these achievements were realized "without sacrificing customer service," as the company met or exceeded corporate-wide customer service standards 96 per cent of the time. </P> <P>Whoops! Either the industry standards have gone down, or MPI is mistaken when it says it hasn't sacrificed customer service. </P> <P>Surely, with all the millions in revenue flowing through the doors of MPI, it could afford to better staff a few phones on a regular basis. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Winnipeg police lay organized crime charges in auto insurance fraud
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ Police in Winnipeg allege organized crime was behind a string of fraud cases against Manitoba's Crown-owned auto insurer. </P> <P>Last year, Project Rollback revealed odometer fraud, sale document manipulation and staged car crashes that ripped off Manitoba Public Insurance to the tune of $800,000. </P> <P>Police say that after nearly a year of reviewing evidence, the Crown is laying additional charges of participating in a criminal organization and committing of an offence for a criminal organization against four people. </P> <P>Quincy Adurogboye, 30, Maria Austera, 32, Lamont Sesay, 28 and Kaela Leigh Perry, 24, all of Winnipeg, face the new charges. </P> <P>A warrant has been issued for Norman Raymond Beardy, 41, of Winnipeg. </P> <P>Police say the organized crime group received inflated MPI claim payouts as a result of the frauds. </P>

--30--

Title: 20-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Reprieve for cruise night? ; Cops mull shift from tickets to education
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It appears car enthusiasts fed up with the frequency of vehicle inspections by Winnipeg police and Manitoba Public Insurance on Sunday cruise nights might get a bit of a break. </P> <P>There were hints Friday the inspections won't be held as often on Sundays and the police service might shift some of the enforcement focus to education. </P> <P>Police Chief Keith McCaskill gave a delicate response to the topic. He wouldn't give a firm answer to whether the frequency will change. </P> <P>Instead, McCaskill said officers will still conduct equipment checks "from time to time. </P> <P>"The whole idea is to make sure people are safe," he said. </P> <P>He said the officers in charge of inspections will decide when and how often they occur. </P> <P>Patrols will continue and if a patrolling officer spots a vehicle with an obvious safety issue the vehicle will be stopped, McCaskill said. </P> <P>Voluntary clinics </P> <P>The inspections have come under fire by special interest vehicle owners who claim they are unfairly targeted because the inspections occur frequently on Sundays and not other days. They say the inspections are excessive. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said police ask MPI mechanics to conduct the checks but the decision to ticket someone is the police officer's. </P> <P>Manitoba Association of Auto Clubs directors are working with police and MPI to find a solution because fewer people are bringing their vehicles out for cruise night or charitable auto events. </P> <P>McCaskill said police are looking at teaming with MAAC to hold clinics where an owner can voluntarily have his or her modified vehicle inspected and not be ticketed on site for infractions. The person would be told what to repair for the vehicle to be street legal. </P> <P>The goal is to educate so people don't run into problems later, McCaskill said. </P> <P>MAAC chairman Bob Chubala said speculation police are trying to quash cruise night isn't true. </P> <P>Chubala said he was encouraged by the chief's comments. </P> <P>"It shows that they want to work with the car hobby," Chubala said. </P> <P>Chubala said he hopes special interest vehicle owners of all ages get on board. </P> <P>McCaskill also responded to comments by Mayor Sam Katz, who said he told the chief he thinks police should focus less on people whose vehicles pose minor equipment infractions and more on dangerous drivers. </P> <P>McCaskill said police must look at all safety issues, be it inappropriate driving or unsafe equipment. </P> <P>"We'll do a little bit of both," McCaskill said. </P>

--30--

Title: 21-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Good insurance is crucial when travelling
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>I get a lot of questions about travel-related insurance. Most of the time, these questions are about pre-existing conditions, and whether or not an individual qualifies for coverage while they are away. </P> <P>However, lately I have had inquiries that come from a different perspective. And my responses usually reference what is clearly not covered, according to various insurance documents. </P> <P>Given the legalese that is built into the actual policies, sometimes not even another lawyer is willing to give an opinion with absolute certainty. So how are we, as ordinary readers, supposed to come to a conclusion and feel secure enough in how we have defined specific phrases? </P> <P>On the other hand, there are some clear no-no's. </P> <P>QUESTION: I understand there is a new entertainment option in Florida that includes driving a NASCAR car around a regulation oval track several times. I assume they take all kinds of precautions, but should I be hurt in an accident while participating in this activity, would I still have full coverage? </P> <P>ANSWER: Not only would you not have full coverage, it's unlikely you would have any at all. While you might try to launch an argument vis-a-vis the actual wording of the policy, one company puts it succinctly: "Your participation in a motorized race or motorized speed contest, including training or practice for the same, is not covered." </P> <P>You might want to shape a different argument, but I'm betting you'd lose. </P> <P>Likewise will individuals who think rock- or mountain-climbing is a fun and interesting challenge. </P> <P>If you're participating in a professional sport, you'd better be sure your sports body has sufficient coverage because your travel-insurance policy likely excludes such activities as well. </P> <P>A point I found most noteworthy relates to the insurance companies' recommendation that you be transported home for medical attention. </P> <P>If something happens to you on your trip which you at first find serious, but think you'll complete the vacation in spite of the insurance company's request for you to return home at their expense, you are strictly on your own. Should your condition worsen, you can't go back to them and try to reinstate the coverage. Once you refuse to be returned, it's gone. </P> <P>While I have isolated a few areas where travellers would not be covered, for the nth time I repeat: To leave home without travel insurance is sheer folly. There are many stories I could relate where the decision to decline resulted in several thousand dollars of out-of-pocket expenditures. </P> <P>QUESTION: I want to rent a car in Europe for two weeks in September. When I checked with a number of sources, including CAA, my travel agent, and my credit card's help centre, about third-party coverage for damage done to another person's car or liability for injuring a third party, I struck out. </P> <P>They all have varying degrees of coverage available for damage to my rental, but not necessarily third party liability. </P> <P>What is your understanding about this issue? </P> <P>ANSWER: This too is a very complicated issue. I talked with John McClellan, owner of Discount Car and Truck Rental on Gertrude. Most car-rental companies, in your initial contract, supply only the very basic coverage on their cars, often as low as required by the state or country involved. Also, third-party liability in many out-of-province jurisdictions is not included if the company can get away with not providing it. </P> <P>If you are renting your vehicle in other parts of Canada or the United States, he recommends travellers purchase coverage from our own MPI, which launched a program a few years ago which does, in fact, provide fairly substantial third-party liability coverage. </P> <P>We often count on our credit-card coverage to protect us, but most often third-party liability is also limited or not covered. Damages to your car rental will be taken care of, but not necessarily damage to the other car involved in the accident. You need to examine all the details in your credit- card agreement. </P> <P>The concept of 'no fault' does not exist in other destinations, as we are seeing with Canadians caught in the crossfire of Cuban policy and legislation around vehicle accidents. </P> <P>There, you have to prove your innocence, not an easy thing to do with language and cultural barriers in your way. </P> <P>No one likes to pay the extra costs related to automobile rentals when we travel, but the minimal coverage provided by your car-rental company will not likely go far in the event of an accident. Car-rental companies make a good part of their revenues on the supplemental coverage offered. </P> <P>We may not be happy paying but, in the end, the investment is small compared to the risk of not having that protection if we get into an accident. </P> <P>McClellan also added some additional good advice when renting overseas. You should not likely rent from local brands with limited storefront locations, but rather from recognized, worldwide names that have universal criteria for insurance coverage at their franchises. </P> <P>QUESTION: I understand that insurance companies were not providing coverage against trip disruption relating to volcanic ash if going to Europe. Is that correct? </P> <P>ANSWER: That is correct. They were not. Three months after the volcano erupted in Iceland, you still could not get full insurance coverage against a repeat occurrence. For that period of time, most insurance companies refused coverage in the same way they looked upon pre-existing conditions. </P> <P>But two days from today, on August 16, at least one of the insurers will be reinstating that coverage. In a memo sent out just a couple of weeks ago, RBC said clients who purchase travel-insurance coverage with trip cancellation/ interruption benefits and have a departure/return date on or after August 16 will be considered for coverage under their policy, provided no further volcanic eruptions occur before August 16 and all other policy terms and conditions are met. </P> <P>Forward your travel questions to <A href="mailto:askjourneys@journeystravel.com">askjourneys@journeystravel.com</A>. Ron Pradinuk is President of Journeys Travel & Leisure SuperCentre and can be heard Sundays at noon on CJOB. Previous columns and tips can be found on www. journeystravelgear.com or read Ron's travel blog at <A href="http://www.thattravelguy.ca">www.thattravelguy.ca</A> </P>

--30--

Title: 22-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crash bystanders hospitalized
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A downtown restaurant was heavily damaged on Friday by a two-vehicle crash that left three pedestrians hospitalized. </P> <P>The collision between a Toyota Prius -- a Unicity Taxi cab -- and a Honda Civic occurred about 2 p.m. at Hargrave Street and Ellice Avenue, causing the taxi to run head-first into a corner wall of Ken's Restaurant and Lounge. </P> <P>A 32-year-old woman, a 50-year-old man and a young girl were hit by at least one of the cars. </P> <P>"It looked very bad," bystander David Leader said of some of the injuries, after the three pedestrians were taken by ambulances to hospital. </P> <P>The woman was "slammed right into the wall," Leader added. </P> <P>Julie Ezra, who works at a nearby salon, said the girl and two adult pedestrians were bleeding from their heads. </P> <P>The woman was initially in unstable condition and was later upgraded to stable but guarded condition, city police said. The girl and the man were in stable condition. </P> <P>While police cordoned off a stretch of Ellice west of Hargrave and firefighters cleaned up the scene, restaurant owner Ken Zhang showed the Winnipeg Sun the damage to his Asian eatery at the intersection's northwest corner. </P> <P>The demolished taxi's front end remained pressed against the wall, having destroyed a mailbox as well. A section of the wall was severely caved in. </P> <P>'Suddenly, he hit me' </P> <P>Inside the restaurant's lounge, a large television, a stuffed animal dispensing machine and various furnishings had been knocked over or smashed by the impact. </P> <P>"The wall is broken. The TV is gone," Zhang said. "It's all gone." </P> <P>Abid Qayyum, the taxi's driver, said he was struck by the northbound Honda while heading west on Ellice. </P> <P>"Suddenly, he hit me," Qayyum said, adding he and the other male driver were not hurt. </P> <P>A security guard working at a nearby store said he heard a "boom" when the collision happened. </P> <P>Police continue to investigate, and are asking potential witnesses to call them at 986-6288. </P>

--30--

Title: 23-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cruisers all win if focus is on safety
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Mayor Sam Katz was absolutely correct when he urged police to tap the brakes on Sunday cruise night enforcement. </P> <P>For five years now, police have been aggressive in monitoring the Winnipeg pastime -- a natural and justified reaction following the death of Linda Rudnicki, who was killed in 2005 when she unwittingly crossed paths with a vehicle being driven by a street-racing moron. </P> <P>Lately, though, police have upped the ante, pulling over and ticketing Sunday night drivers for relatively minor but technically illegal vehicle modifications by the dozens. </P> <P>Certainly, police are well within their rights to ticket these individuals. That isn't an issue. </P> <P>What is an issue is this targeted enforcement is putting a chill on the summertime ritual and its related charitable events, such as show and shines. Cruisers don't want to risk being ticketed for obscure offences, so they avoid going to high-profile events with their prized set of wheels for fear officers will target them. </P> <P>As a result, police are being perceived as the enemy, using the cover of enforcing public safety to fill their ticket quota at gearheads' considerable expense. </P> <P>Not good. </P> <P>Enter Katz, who revealed on Wednesday he recently encouraged Chief Keith McCaskill to refocus his officers on the people who drive like idiots, not the otherwise law-abiding gearheads whose only crime is some trivial vehicle modification. </P> <P>Some might argue the mayor is merely electioneering, and maybe he is. </P> <P>Regardless, Katz should be congratulated for injecting some common sense into this issue. Ticket the dangerous drivers for every infraction you can find, and show leniency to the motorists who aren't doing anyone any harm. </P> <P>It's a simple compromise that makes too much sense for anyone to ignore -- including McCaskill. </P> <P>On Friday, the chief said police are looking at teaming with the Manitoba Association of Auto Clubs to hold clinics where an owner can have their modified vehicle inspected without fear of being ticketed on site for infractions. That seems like a good start. </P> <P>Here's hoping they follow through and work together to protect a unique Winnipeg tradition from being ticketed into extinction. </P>

--30--

Title: 24-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Two injured in West End crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Three people were transported to hospital in stable condition after two vehicles collided in the city's West End on Saturday morning. </P> <P>The crash happened about 6:45 a.m. at the intersection of McPhillips Street and Notre Dame Avenue. </P> <P>It's not clear whether the injured people were all in one vehicle. </P> <P>Part of the busy intersection was closed to traffic for roughly an hour. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Odd, bloody break-in ; Suspect phoned for a ride after accidental cut: police
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 23-year-old man is facing charges after a bizarre, bloody break-in Saturday night just north of Winnipeg. </P> <P>RCMP say the incident began when the man drove a 1999 Mercury Cougar into a ditch on Highway 59 near McGregor Farm Road in the Rural Municipality of East St. Paul. </P> <P>The man then allegedly abandoned the car and broke into a nearby house. Const. Miles Hiebert, a spokesman for Manitoba RCMP, said there was no one in the home at the time. </P> <P>The suspect allegedly broke a window to get into the home, cutting himself in the process and causing an undisclosed amount of damage, Hiebert said. </P> <P>"I guess there was blood spattered throughout," he said. "He cut himself pretty badly. He was rampaging through the house before he left." </P> <P>Hiebert said he doesn't know why the suspect allegedly broke into the home. It doesn't appear anything was stolen, he said. </P> <P>East St. Paul RCMP were called to the home about 11 p.m. </P> <P>Hiebert said it's his understanding that a passing paramedic crew called police after they spotted the abandoned car in the ditch and heard someone yelling from a nearby home. </P> <P>When officers arrived the bleeding man was trying to flee in another vehicle driven by a family member, RCMP said. </P> <P>PULLING AWAY </P> <P>"I guess he phoned to be picked up. They came and got him and we caught them as they were pulling out of the driveway," Hiebert said, adding officers said the suspect "was covered in blood when they found him." </P> <P>The man, who lives in the Rural Municipality of Springfield, was arrested for break and enter, and later released from custody. </P> <P>He is scheduled to appear in Winnipeg provincial court Oct. 18. Police did not release his name because charges have not been formally laid. </P> <P>RCMP continue to investigate. It's not clear whether alcohol or drugs were factors in the incident, or whether the family member might be facing any charges. </P>

--30--

Title: 26-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Just a sec, say traffic activists  More amber time beats red-light cameras: duo
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Now, the founders of Wise Up Winnipeg are angling for the city to trade the automatic red-light snaps for something they say will do a better job at keeping intersections safe: adding a single second to the length of yellow lights in Winnipeg.</P> <P>Fed up with what they say is indifference from decision-makers on alternative intersection-safety solutions, Wise Up's Larry Stefanuik and Todd Dube are gearing up for a full-throttle media campaign to spread their message that red-light cameras aren't the best way to make intersections safer. The campaign, called Just One Second, will be unveiled on city billboards, large newspaper ads, and a website in mid-September.</P> <P>"One second exposes the entire (red-light camera) scheme for what it is, and that is revenue, period," Dube said. "Yellow lights aren't for the purpose of testing your brakes. They are to orchestrate the safe clearance of traffic through an intersection, and this city has been putting them to work like slot machines."</P> <P>At issue: Dube and Stefanuik, who is a retired Winnipeg Police Service traffic officer, say that their measurements show some city yellow lights are too short for most intersections.</P> <P>Their reference is a commonly used engineering formula that bases light times on factors such as speed limit, the grade of the road, and the length of the intersection. The pair say they have measured lights that timed out too short for the formula.</P> <P>In 2009, the U.S.-based Institute of Transportation Engineers updated its uniform traffic controls, insisting that by 2014 all yellow lights be timed based on that engineering formula, rather than a "rule of thumb."</P> <P>"Safety studies have documented significant reductions in crashes when jurisdictions have revised the durations of the yellow change and red clearance intervals using the accepted engineering practices," the ITE wrote in a notice of the update.</P> <P>The ITE has also reported that while enforcement techniques such as red-light cameras deter drivers who want to run reds, engineering changes -- such as extended yellow-light times or changes to the intersection approach -- better help the majority of red-light runners who do so accidentally.</P> <P>A city spokeswoman said that yellow lights in Winnipeg last a minimum of four seconds, "which is adequate for the speeds and intersection geometries in the city." She noted that the standard is in keeping with engineering guidelines from the ITE and Canadian recommendations for uniform traffic controls.</P> <P>Meanwhile, Dube and Stefanuik are looking south of the border for inspiration.</P> <P>Down south, red-light cameras sat in the hot-seat this summer, the subject of a June 29 United States congressional hearing into the safety and success rates of automated traffic enforcement.</P> <P>One of the loudest voices at the hearing was that of Georgia state congressman Barry Loudermilk, who spearheaded a successful 2008 campaign to cut back on photo enforcement after 2006 reports that accidents at photo-controlled intersections were actually on the rise. The resulting law demanded, in part, that yellow lights at camera-controlled intersections be timed to U.S. federal engineering standards, with one extra second added.</P> <P>In January, the new rules went into effect; within 90 days, red-light running had dropped by 72 per cent at monitored intersections.</P> <P>The campaign was so effective that 12 Georgia cities soon dismantled some or all of their photo-enforcement cameras after they became no longer profitable, Loudermilk reported at the hearing.</P> <P>Dube and Stefanuik keep in close touch with Loudermilk, who spoke in Winnipeg in March. The pair said they invited elected officials from city and provincial government, but none attended.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car hits building, pedestrians
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Three pedestrians were sent to hospital after a vehicle crashed into a building in downtown Winnipeg on Friday.</P> <P>Two vehicles were involved in the crash, one being a taxi that ended up hitting the corner of a restaurant.</P> <P>The drivers of the vehicles were not hurt. The pedestrians — a man, a woman and a young girl — suffered non-life-threatening injuries, according to police.</P> <P>Police are investigating the scene.</P> <P>The intersection of Hargrave Street and Ellice Avenue was still closed to traffic as of 3:30 p.m.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/13/mb-pedestrians-taxi-building-winnipeg.html#ixzz0wm5VIdhb">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/13/mb-pedestrians-taxi-building-winnipeg.html#ixzz0wm5VIdhb</A><BR></P>

Title: 28-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crown execs' pay balancing act; Compensation level for Sask. executives trails private sector
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Saskatchewan's Crown corporation executives are some of the most well-paid individuals in the province. But with even higher compensation levels often seen at the top of Crown corporations and comparable utilities outside Saskatchewan, the question is whether the province can remain competitive when it comes to filling the Crowns' corner offices. </P> <P>Today, three new executives will take the helm of SaskPower, SaskTel and Crown Investments Corp., the umbrella corporation for the major Crowns. </P> <P>But not one is coming from outside the province, or the Saskatchewan government, for that matter. </P> <P>Longtime civil servant and current CIC president Ron Styles becomes SaskTel president, replacing Robert Watson, who takes charge of SaskPower. Richard Carter, chief of staff to the finance minister, becomes CIC president. </P> <P>When the appointments were announced in June, Premier Brad Wall said he was confident the government had hired the "best candidates" but there was an ongoing issue.</P> <P>"The last five or 10 years we have seen the salaries of executives in the private sector and in other Crowns grow exponentially and it is a challenge to the province going forward," he told reporters at the time. </P> <P>"We need to move in that direction so that . . . we've struck this reasonable balance between what is acceptable to the public, to the taxpayers, to the shareholders in terms of compensation for senior executives and also a level that attracts effective senior executives." </P> <P>Compensation figures from outside the province show Crown corporation executives generally trail their counterparts at other Crowns and comparable private companies across Western Canada and Ontario. </P> <P>The issue is not new to Saskatchewan. But the impact of past discrepancies has generally been lessened by the low cost of living in Saskatchewan. </P> <P>The rise of both the cost of living in the province and executive salaries elsewhere in Canada in recent years -- as well as a drop in overtly partisan political appointments to lead Saskatchewan's Crowns -- has made executive compensation a bigger issue, however. </P> <P>In 2006, the previous NDP government introduced a new compensation plan for Crown execs that saw an immediate boost in pay as well as new short- and long-term incentives. </P> <P>Tim McMillan, the Sask. Party's newly minted CIC minister, said the government isn't contemplating further changes at this point, although it isn't ruling them out in the future. </P> <P>Ken Rasmussen, associate director of the Johnson-Shoyama Graduate School of Public Policy, said Crown compensation is "sort of a problem" for the government. </P> <P>Compensation is an issue in recruiting executives, but a potentially bigger problem is the governance issues, where Crown heads have to answer not only to a board but also to the premier and cabinet. </P> <P>"It is a very politicized job, which to many industry people doesn't appear very attractive. It's mostly about keeping cabinet happy than about doing what's best for the corporation or even the province," he said. </P> <P>That means the government favours "responsiveness" in selecting Crown presidents, not necessarily a deep background in their particular industries. </P> <P>"I don't think any of the people are unqualified and are in any way inappropriate. But their qualifications in many cases are their ability to respond to the issues of cabinet in an effective way, in a professional way," Rasmussen said of the new Crown appointments. </P> <P>Maynard Sonntag served twice as Crowns minister in the previous NDP government and oversaw the introduction of the new compensation plan for executives. </P> <P>Recruitment is definitely an issue that Saskatchewan governments struggle with, he said in an interview, but there was seldom a case where the government lost out on a star candidate over compensation issues. </P> <P>"I don't think it's that easy, just because you've been in management in the private sector, to step in and run a utility . . . there is a pretty strong argument for bringing somebody up from within who is familiar with the organization," he said. <BR>Rasmussen said there is one other factor to consider when comparing Crown salaries. </P> <P>"There are lots of arguments, and I'd be the first to put them forward, that executive compensation is rarely connected to organizational performance. There's relatively little evidence that says if somehow you pay somebody a million dollars all of a sudden you're going to get a brilliantly run organization." </P> <P><A href="mailto:jwood@sp.canwest.com">jwood@sp.canwest.com</A> </P> <P>º EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION </P> <P>Total 2009 compensation for senior executives of selected Crown corporations and private utilities. </P> <P>Pat Youzwa SaskPower $337,883 <BR>Ron Styles CIC $332,862 <BR>Robert Watson SaskTel $382,019 <BR>Doug Kelln SaskEnergy $348,251 <BR>Bob Elton BC Hydro $508,874 <BR>Donald Lowry Epcor $2,593,918 <BR>Jon Schubert ICBC $346,263 <BR>Darren Entwistle Telus $6,853,327 <BR>Marilyn McLaren Manitoba Public Insurance $261,542 <BR>Bob Brennan Manitoba Hydro $375,542 <BR>Tom Mitchell Ontario Power Generation $1,591,176 </P> <P>Information compiled from public documents </P> <P><BR> </P>

--30--

Title: 29-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Second thoughts on amber
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Contrary to what some Winnipeg motorists appear to think, when a traffic light turns amber at an intersection, it does not mean "go like hell." </P> <P>Rather it means do not enter the intersection after the light goes yellow and clear it if you are already in it. Any driver who enters the intersection after the light turns yellow or fails to clear it before the light turns red is subject to a ticket if she is caught by a police officer or photographed by one of the city's red-light cameras. </P> <P>As the Driver Licensing Handbook puts it: "An amber light is a warning the light is going to turn red. Slow down and stop -- never accelerate to make the light." </P> <P>A group of Winnipeggers that calls itself Wise Up Winnipeg believes that both problems can be simply solved by lengthening the time that the yellow traffic light is on by just one second, to give drivers more time to clear the intersection. Larry Stefanuik, a former city police service traffic officer, and Todd Dube are planning to take that message to Winnipeggers and their city government in September. It is a pretty straightforward message -- yellow lights that run one second longer reduce the number of accidents and the number of tickets that are issued to drivers; there is less slamming of brakes or rapid acceleration to escape that dreaded amber eye, and only those intent on running the red would be caught. </P> <P>Red-light cameras also would remain useful for catching speeders -- and they will always be with us -- but data from American cities that have added a second to the length of their amber lights indicate that this blink of time renders photo radar marginally useful at best. </P> <P>Photo radar in its conception was sold to us, and to many other cities, as a safety device, a system that could help prevent traffic accidents and make the streets more friendly for pedestrians and motorists. </P> <P>In reality, it has become clear that it is a cash cow for governments. Small adjustments in speed limits or traffic regulations can make significant differences in the amount of revenue generated. As was pointed out on this page last year, school zones and construction zones have been used to beef up photo radar revenue by tens of millions of dollars; conversely, raising the speed limit on Winnipeg's freeways can drastically reduce that revenue. </P> <P>So it is with lengthening the time that amber lights are on. Extending it by as little as one second, it is estimated, would eliminate 80 per cent of the tickets issued for running the amber at city intersections. </P> <P>That would not do anything for revenue -- and it is becoming increasingly clear that photo radar is almost entirely about revenue. It is set up in school zones, although there is no evidence released by the police that this has reduced accidents; it is set up even outside schools that are closed and abandoned and playgrounds that are not used in winter. </P> <P>There are strong indications from other cities that cast doubt on the utility of photo radar except as something that can be used to milk motorists. That is not to say it should be scrapped completely -- there will also be irresponsible drivers who persist in thinking that an amber light means go like hell. But a longer amber light, despite what the city says, may make intersections safer and that is worth trying. Safety, after all, is what it is supposed to be about. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Nov-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: MAN HIT BY BUS TREATED IN HOSPITAL
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A man was taken to hospital after being struck by a Winnipeg Transit bus at a downtown intersection Monday. </P> <P>Police said the injured person was in stable condition. His age wasn't released. </P> <P>The bus-pedestrian collision occurred at Vaughan Street and Graham Avenue about 10:30 a.m. </P> <P>A witness said she was walking when she noticed a commotion near a bus, which was stopped and blocking part of the intersection. </P> <P>An elderly man was lying under the bus, the woman said. </P> <P>"The bottom half of his body was underneath it," she said. </P> <P>Two men were holding the man's hands and speaking to him. </P> <P>"He seemed to be conscious because he responded a few times whenever they spoke to him," the woman said. </P> <P>The southbound bus, on route 33, was turning east onto Graham. </P> <P>Police continue to investigate. <BR></P>

--30--

--30--

Title: 2-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Serving armed forces members eligible for veterans' plates
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Alberta government is expanding eligibility requirements for veterans' licence plates to include currently serving members of the Canadian Armed Forces. </P> <P>"As a retired serviceman, I know this gesture will be appreciated by the men and women in the forces," said His Honour, Col. (Ret'd) the Honourable Donald Ethell, Lieutenant Governor of Alberta. "The plates are instantly recognizable to Albertans. When they see it, they think of the people who put themselves in the service of our country." </P> <P>The Royal Canadian Legion's Alberta-Northwest Territories Command determines eligibility for the plates. Current members of the armed forces with at least three years of service will be able to apply for veterans' plates beginning Aug. 16. They can receive the plate at no extra cost when renewing their vehicle registration. </P> <P>Nearly 18,000 veterans' plates have been issued since the program began in February 2005. Previously, the plates were only available to retired members who had been honourably discharged, as well as members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police or other Canadian police departments who served under NATO or the United Nations.</P>

--30--

Title: 3-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI suing car thieves
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance has filed a lawsuit against two chronic car thieves whose latest escapades involved videotaping and photographing a month- long crime spree. </P> <P>The 16-year-old-girl and her 18-year-old boyfriend have spent the past few years making a mockery of justice by repeatedly ignoring their parents, breaching court orders and taunting police who were trying to stop them. Attempts at rehabilitation have failed, and jail seems to only slow them down. </P> <P>MPI is now hoping a stiff financial penalty that will follow them around like a dark cloud will succeed in sending a stronger message. </P> <P>"These kinds of lawsuits are filed on behalf of our ratepayers, and obviously we are being proactive here. We know we won't be getting this money tomorrow or next week or next month, but that's not to say we won't somewhere down the road," MPI spokesman Brian Smiley said Tuesday. </P> <P>MPI is seeking more than $53,000 from the teens for damage they caused to six different trucks and SUVs stolen in Manitoba last year. The civil judgment will stay with them into adulthood. They will not be able to obtain driver's licences while a balance is owing, and MPI can go after any job earnings or lottery winnings they may obtain in the future. </P> <P>Justice officials told court earlier this summer the pair committed one of the most brazen crime sprees ever uncovered in Manitoba. The case is so unusual they have been unable to find any similar scenarios across Canada. </P> <P>The female accused -- who can't be named under the Youth Criminal Justice Act -- has pleaded guilty to 21 separate crimes stemming from the August- September 2009 rampage. They include thefts, possession of stolen property, mischief and breaches of court orders. </P> <P>The Crown is seeking the maximum youth sentence of two years behind bars for the girl, who has a long history of similar property offences and was on probation at the time. She is a Level 4 auto thief, the highest risk category assigned by police, and has previously been turned in by her frustrated parents who are unable to control her. Her sentencing is set to continue Thursday. </P> <P>Her adult co-accused is expected to deal with his matters later this month. He faces a lengthy prison term. </P> <P>The pair -- dubbed "Bonnie and Clyde" by some justice officials -- was originally sentenced last June for a variety of car thefts and property crimes. She received 18 months probation, while the man got two years of custody less time already served. </P> <P>They were ordered by the courts to stay away from each other. </P> <P>In August, the man was released on a day pass from jail to go shopping with his mother at Walmart. While browsing through the aisles, he suddenly took off, stole his mother's car and picked up his girlfriend. The couple then embarked on 30 days of chaos, which included stops in rural Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, court was told. </P> <P>In the process, they documented most of their crimes by taking pictures and videos that show them taunting police, drinking and driving, boasting to their friends and celebrating their accomplishments by dancing and making out on the top of stolen vehicles. </P> <P>Their crimes included burning a Hummer they stole just outside Winnipeg, nearly mowing down a vehicle owner who tried to interrupt a theft in Saskatchewan and scrawling lyrics to a crude "rap song" over the interior of another car which said "(Expletive) the cops, they'll never catch us." The pair would typically steal one vehicle, drive it for a few hours or days, cause extensive damage and then "trade" it for another one. </P> <P>MPI has filed dozens of lawsuits against auto thieves in recent years with the hopes of one day being able to offset some of their losses. </P> <P>"We've had situations where someone will come to us years later, saying they want to turn their lives around, and a big part of that is obtaining a licence, " said Smiley.</P>

--30--

Title: 4-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Huge MPI fraud scheme suspect surrenders to police, arrested
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>City police have arrested one of the few remaining suspects who was charged in a massive fraud scheme against Manitoba Public Insurance and was still at large. </P> <P>Police said the 41-year-old Winnipeg man was wanted on a warrant and arrested when he turned himself in to police Monday. </P> <P>He was released on a promise to appear in court on charges including participating in a criminal organization and committing an offence for a criminal organization. His name wasn't released. </P> <P>The Crown recently authorized the criminal organization-related charges against five people, who Winnipeg police allege masterminded the scam, which bilked MPI of $800,000. </P> <P><STRONG>Project Rollback</STRONG> </P> <P>More than 35 people have been arrested for allegedly having a role in the fraud, the largest in MPI history. Police allege the group formed an organized crime network. </P> <P>The police and MPI investigation was dubbed Project Rollback. </P> <P>The suspects are accused of buying luxury vehicles outside Manitoba, bringing them to the province, rolling back odometers to increase their value, doctoring sales records, staging collisions or hit-and-runs to make them write-offs, and making false stolen vehicle reports. The suspects allegedly collected Autopac payouts over several years. </P> <P>Last week, police announced the criminal organization charges against the five, including Norman Raymond Beardy, 41, who was wanted on a warrant. </P>

--30--

Title: 5-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Chronic car thieves face lawsuit; Manitoba insurer seeks to deter pair with $53,000 claim
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) has filed a lawsuit against two chronic car thieves whose latest escapades involved videotaping and photographing a month-long crime spree. </P> <P>The 16-year-old-girl and her 18-year-old boyfriend have spent the past few years making a mockery of justice by repeatedly ignoring their parents, breaching court orders and taunting police. Attempts at rehabilitation have failed and jail seems to slow them down only temporarily. </P> <P>MPI is now hoping a stiff financial penalty that will follow them around like a dark cloud will succeed in sending a stronger message. </P> <P>"We know we won't be getting this money tomorrow or next week or next month, but that's not to say we won't somewhere down the road," MPI spokesperson Brian Smiley said Tuesday. </P> <P>MPI is seeking more than $53,000 from the teens for damage they caused to six different trucks and SUVs stolen in Manitoba last year. The civil judgment will stay with them into adulthood. They will not be able to obtain driver's licences while a balance is owing, and MPI can go after any job earnings or lottery winnings they may obtain in their future. </P> <P>Justice officials told court earlier this summer the pair committed one of the most brazen crime sprees ever uncovered in Manitoba. The case is so unusual they have been unable to find any similar scenarios across Canada. </P> <P>The female accused -- who can't be named under the Youth Criminal Justice Act -- has pleaded guilty to 21 separate crimes stemming from the August to September 2009 rampage. They include thefts, possession of stolen property, mischief and breaches of court orders. </P> <P>The Crown is seeking the maximum youth sentence of two years behind bars for the girl, who has a long history of similar property offences and was on probation at the time. She is a Level 4 auto thief, the highest risk category assigned by police, and previously has been turned in by her frustrated parents who are unable to control her. Her sentencing is set to continue on Thursday. </P> <P>Charges against her adult co-accused are expected to be dealt with later this month. He faces a lengthy prison term.</P>

--30--
