Title: 7-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Longer amber safer ; Let's make politicians see the light
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It's probably not an issue city councillors and candidates in the upcoming civic election were expecting to deal with. </P> <P>But the idea of extending amber lights at red-light camera intersections to reduce collisions has gained so much momentum over the past week, candidates -- including Mayor Sam Katz -- will have little choice but to tell voters where they stand on the issue. </P> <P>Several councillors have already been in contact with WiseUp Winnipeg, the pro-traffic safety group that has spearheaded the idea. And come September when the municipal election will be in full swing, the proposal to extend amber lights to reduce collisions and improve traffic safety will be one of the hot topics of debate. </P> <P>Reduces collisions </P> <P>Evidence from U.S. states like Georgia and Arizona have shown giving drivers additional warning to stop for red lights through longer amber times has reduced collisions by as much as 80%. </P> <P>The change worked so well in some U.S. cities that it was no longer profitable for them to continue the red-light camera program. There were far fewer red-light infractions. But revenue from the red-light cameras also dwindled, forcing city officials to cancel the program. </P> <P>There have also been a number of recent studies south of the border that have shown how improving traffic engineering techniques at intersections -- including longer ambers -- is more effective in reducing collisions than deploying red-light cameras. </P> <P>According to a freedom of information request by the Winnipeg Sun last year, all controlled intersections in Winnipeg have amber times of four seconds. </P> <P>It seems odd a longer intersection with an 80 km/h speed limit would have the same amber time as a shorter intersection with a 50 km/h limit. </P> <P>A vehicle obviously requires more time to stop at a red light on Lagimodiere Boulevard at Grassie Boulevard than they do on Moray Street at Lodge Avenue. </P> <P>Despite that, Winnipeg's traffic engineers claim all amber lights are set at four seconds. </P> <P>Obviously this needs to be reviewed, especially in light of the developments in some U.S. states. </P> <P>It seems hard to imagine how adding even one second to amber lights could make such a difference and result in such a dramatic drop in collisions. I was skeptical myself when I first heard the idea. </P> <P>But when you drill down into the evidence of how it has worked in other jurisdictions, it's pretty tough for any reasonable-minded person not to at least ask city traffic engineers to look into the idea. </P> <P>Unless our driving patterns in Winnipeg are so much different than those in Georgia and Arizona, there's no reason we shouldn't expect the same results. </P> <P>Which means voters are going to be asking their municipal candidates in this election where they stand on reducing collisions through longer amber lights. </P> <P>Given the safety implications, it's simply not something any of our elected officials can dismiss out of hand. In fact, it would be grossly irresponsible for them to do so. </P> <P>Phone and e-mail the mayor and your local city councillor and ask them what they plan to do about this. </P> <P>We all want safer streets and fewer collisions. If this can help, the idea of longer amber lights should be top of mind in this fall's municipal election. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Boy accused in vehicle thefts
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A young boy has been charged in connection to a rash of vehicle thefts in Steinbach. </P> <P>The 13-year-old was discovered behind the wheel of a stolen car in the Clearspring Mall parking lot in the early morning hours on Monday. </P> <P>Steinbach RCMP received a call from a security officer of a suspicious vehicle in the lot with several teenagers inside. Once police attended, it was determined the vehicle had been stolen from Steinbach. The investigation resulted with the boy being charged with this offence, along with two other recent vehicle thefts in the Steinbach area. </P> <P>Meanwhile, two other people have been charged in an unrelated theft of a dirt bike that also occurred on Monday. An off-duty RCMP officer was traveling to work when he noticed suspicious activity near Country View School. A 20-year-old male and 17-year-old female were found with a Honda dirt bike that had been stolen from New Bothwell. </P> <P>The pair were also in possession of several other stolen items. </P> <P>Michael John Klassen of Steinbach and the female youth have been charged with possession of property obtained by crime. Additional charges are pending. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cyclist hit by car in stable condition
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A cyclist is in stable condition after being struck by a vehicle during morning rush hour Wednesday. </P> <P>The man was travelling southbound on King Edward Street when he was hit by a southbound vehicle turning west at the intersection of Notre Dame Avenue just before 9 a.m. </P> <P>Winnipeg Police Service Const. Sean Donovan said the cyclist was taken to Seven Oaks General Hospital with relatively minor injuries. </P> <P>"It could have been a lot worse," Donovan said. </P> <P>Ken Garrioch was heading to work when the accident happened. </P> <P>"When we pulled up here, we saw police cars, an ambulance and a guy being taken out on a stretcher," Garrioch said. </P> <P>"The guy looked injured ... I feel sorry for him." </P> <P>Thought he was turning </P> <P>Donovan said it appears the female driver of the small car thought the cyclist was turning right, but then he continued southbound. </P> <P>"It looked like he was going to turn, but then the bike went straight," Donovan said. </P> <P>The crumpled bicycle could be seen near the intersection in the trunk of a police cruiser. </P> <P>Police could not confirm whether the cyclist was wearing a helmet. </P> <P>No charges are anticipated. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Steinbach boy, 13, charged with car theft
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 13-year-old boy in Steinbach, Man., has been charged in connection with three vehicle thefts in the last few weeks.</P> <P>The boy was arrested early Monday morning at the city's Clearspring Mall parking lot when a security guard saw a car with several very young people inside.</P> <P>Police arrived at the scene and determined that the driver of the car was 13 years old and the car was stolen.</P> <P>The boy has been charged with three counts of theft and is scheduled to appear in court in September. </P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/18/mb-car-theft-steinbach.html#ixzz0x3WYgrMX">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/18/mb-car-theft-steinbach.html#ixzz0x3WYgrMX</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI stats for first quarter of 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Fuelled by reduced claims costs, Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) reported net income of $102.9 million for the first quarter of 2010.</P> <P>For the three months ended May 31, 2010, earned revenues increased by $5.2 million over the same period last year, as the number and value of vehicles insured increased. Net income from operations increased from the previous year by $90.7 million due to improved underwriting results of $92.6 million offset by a $1.9 million decrease in investment income.</P> <P>Claims costs for the first three months decreased by $85.2 million to $105.4 million, explained Don Palmer, vice-president of corporate finance and chief financial officer. The significant decrease is largely attributable to a $78.2 million decrease in bodily injury claims. In addition, physical damage claims costs also decreased, attributed to winter ending earlier than normal.</P> <P>“This one-time decrease was due to an unusual release in claims reserves caused by a rise in interest rates,” said Palmer. “This decrease in claims costs is not expected to be sustained throughout the year.</P> <P>“Traditionally, the first two quarters of the corporation’s fiscal year generate a profit, which is then offset by an increase in claims during the winter months,” said Palmer.</P> <P>Proposed rebate<BR>The corporation submitted its 2011/12 Basic insurance rate application to the Public Utilities Board (PUB) in June, requesting an overall Basic insurance rate decrease of four percent and a proposed premium rebate of $92.2 million. If approved by the PUB, policy holders can expect to receive a cheque in the spring of 2011 of about $115 on average.</P> <P>The PUB is expected to rule on the application in late fall.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Auto-thief teen's trail of destruction stuns her mother
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It's a scenario that would make any parent cringe -- a slew of pictures and videos showing your drunken teenage daughter prancing around in skimpy clothes, shouting obscenities, mimicking gang signs, smoking marijuana and making out with her older boyfriend on the hood of cars they just stole. </P> <P>A Winnipeg woman was forced to face that reality in court Thursday at the sentencing hearing for a 16-year-old girl who documented her own brazen month- long crime spree. </P> <P>The single mother, who provincial court Judge Rocky Pollack said "deserves a medal" for trying to rein in her out-of-control child, didn't try to sugar-coat her daughter's conduct. </P> <P>"This is not normal, defiant adolescent behaviour," the mother said. "I have three other children. I've never been in this situation before." </P> <P>The woman, who can't be named to avoid identifying the young offender, told court she was stunned by the extent of her daughter's crimes. She spoke at length about the "groupie culture" that has seen several young girls become attached to prolific Winnipeg car thieves. Many, like her youngest daughter, come from otherwise strong, stable family environments. </P> <P>"There are a lot of us very baffled by what these girls are into, the blatant disrespect these children show," the mother said, describing how young people use Internet websites to network and stay ahead of their technologically challenged parents. </P> <P>"They're way faster than us. It's all about bullying, browbeating, brainwashing," the mother said. </P> <P>The Crown submitted dozens of photos and played a two-minute video in court to chronicle the crimes committed by the girl and her 18-year-old boyfriend across the Prairies last summer, including stealing vehicles, gas and property and leaving a trail of costly damage. In the clip played Thursday, the pair can't contain their glee as they joke about a 2008 Chevy Silverado they stole. </P> <P>"Look at that sexy s ," the girl says, laughing. She begins singing lyrics from a rap song about how the police won't catch her "riding dirty." </P> <P>"That's the tamest of all the videos," said Crown attorney Elizabeth Laite. "In the next one, you see him driving the car while she's pouring him a drink." </P> <P>The Crown is seeking the maximum youth sentence of two years in custody for the girl, who pleaded guilty to 21 separate offences. She has a long history of similar property offences and was on probation at the time she committed the new crimes. </P> <P>Defence lawyer Manny Bhangu wants his client released from custody immediately with a sentence of 230 days already spent in custody. He said any further time behind bars might cause the girl to abandon positive changes she has been trying to make since her arrest. </P> <P>"She is very sincere about wanting to pay back what she owes to the community. She doesn't want to become institutionalized, to feel comfortable at the youth centre. Rehabilitation of someone with this much potential should be our main goal here," Bhangu said. </P> <P>The girl's mother vowed to keep her daughter on a tight leash, as she did last February when she reported the girl breaching her court-ordered curfew and had her locked up. </P> <P>"I think she has learned a great lesson. I'm not going to sit here and condone her behaviour just because I want my sweet little girl to love me," she said. </P> <P>"She knows she has a lot of work to do, a lot of trust to gain back. And if she screws up, she'll be back here." </P> <P>The girl apologized for her actions, reading a written statement to the court. </P> <P>"This was a very poor choice on my behalf," she said. </P> <P>"I now know I was being manipulated. I thought I was in love, but I wasn't; I was selfish. I know I'm capable of doing more with my life." </P> <P>Pollack has reserved his sentencing decision until Aug. 27. He said the facts of the case appear to be "without precedent" in Canada. </P> <P>"(The videos) are a remarkable feature of the lawlessness that was going on at the time," the judge said. </P> <P>The two accused, dubbed "Bonnie and Clyde" by some justice officials, were originally sentenced in June 2009 for a variety of car thefts and property crimes. She got 18 months probation and her boyfriend got two years of custody less time already served. Both were ordered by the courts to stay away from each other. </P> <P>In August, the man was released on a day pass from jail to go shopping with his mother at Wal-Mart. While browsing through the aisles, he suddenly took off, stole his mother's car and picked up his girlfriend. The pair then embarked on 30 days of chaos, including stops in rural Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta. </P> <P>Some of the crimes included burning a Hummer they stole just outside Winnipeg, nearly mowing down a vehicle owner who tried to interrupt a theft in eastern Saskatchewan and scrawling lyrics to a crude rap song over the interior of another car they left behind to be found by police. </P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance filed a $53,000 lawsuit against the pair earlier this week for damage caused during their spree. The male co-accused, who is an adult, is scheduled to be sentenced on Aug. 31.</P>

--30--

She has a long history of similar property offences and was on probation at the time she committed the new crimes. </P> <P>The girl's mother, who can't be named because it would identify her daughter, told court she was stunned by the extent of her daughter's crimes. </P> <P>“This is not normal, defiant adolescent behaviour,” the single mother said. “I have three other children. I've never been in this situation before.'' </P> <P>She talked about the “groupie culture” that has seen several young girls become attached to prolific Winnipeg car thieves. Many, like her youngest daughter, come from strong, stable family environments. </P> <P>“There are a lot of us very baffled by what these girls are into, the blatant disrespect these children show,” the mother said. </P> <P>Defence lawyer Manny Bhangu wants the girl to be released from custody immediately with a sentence of 230 days already spent in custody. </P> <P>He said any further time behind bars might cause the girl to abandon positive changes she has been trying to make since her arrest. </P> <P>“She is very sincere about wanting to pay back what she owes to the community. Title: 15-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Girl 'manipulated' ; Blames ex-boyfriend for role in crime spree
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 17-year-old girl arrested following a month-long car theft spree that spanned three provinces says her criminal days are behind her, as is her relationship with her car-stealing boyfriend. </P> <P>"I thought I was in love but I now know I wasn't," the weepy girl told a judge Thursday, adding she was "manipulated" by her now 19-year-old co-accused. </P> <P>"One of my biggest downfalls is not being able to say no when I have to." </P> <P>The girl, her mother and her lawyer all blamed the girl's former boyfriend for luring her into a criminal lifestyle that resulted in her being labelled a level 4 car thief. </P> <P>"She was absolutely infatuated with him, infatuated with the lifestyle, infatuated with the freedom," said defence lawyer Manny Bhangu. </P> <P>"As long as (the boyfriend) is not there, there is no risk of her relapsing into criminal behaviour," he said. </P> <P>The girl has pleaded guilty to 20 charges in connection with a crime spree that ended with her arrest last September in Lethbridge, Alta. </P> <P>The criminal odyssey included the theft and abandonment of countless vehicles and three high-speed chases in which they escaped capture by police. During one pursuit, the couple drove 160 km/h on the Trans-Canada Highway in the wrong direction. </P> <P>The Crown is seeking the maximum youth sentence of two years custody and community supervision. The defence is urging Judge Rocky Pollack to sentence her to time served. </P> <P>The male accused has pleaded guilty to numerous charges and is expected to receive a lengthy prison sentence later this year. </P> <P><STRONG>Made videos</STRONG> </P> <P>The girl documented their exploits on a stolen video camera. The videos show the girl dancing on cars, smoking marijuana and pouring her drunken boyfriend drinks as he drove. </P> <P>The girl was on probation last August for similar charges involving the same boyfriend when he picked her up in a stolen car. Court heard he was on a day pass from the Agassiz Youth Centre when he stole his mother's car after she stopped to buy something at Wal-Mart. The man stole another car and then picked up the girl as she waited outside her house. </P> <P>Police arrested the girl a month later in Lethbridge, where she and the man had been staying with his father. </P> <P>Pollack said he needed time to consider Crown and defence submissions and adjourned sentencing to Aug. 27. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 16-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Moving on ambers ; Katz pledges study of longer lights
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Mayor Sam Katz says he will bring a motion to his executive policy committee next month to ask the city's traffic engineers to look into the idea of extending amber lights at controlled intersections to reduce collisions and red-light infractions. </P> <P>The move comes a week after the Winnipeg Sun reported how longer yellow lights in a number of southern U.S. cities resulted in a dramatic drop in collisions and red-light running. </P> <P>"When EPC meets again, we'll move a motion to get a report from the department, which is public works, to look into the situation and to do the due diligence," Katz told the Sun Thursday. </P> <P>"My primary concern is safety and if it is safer with extending the length, then it's something we should definitely be looking at." </P> <P>What cities like Mesa, Ariz., and Atlanta, Ga., found was tailoring the length of ambers to the specifics of intersections -- taking into account variables such as speed limit and the size of the intersection -- helped give motorists better warning to stop for red lights. </P> <P>After the state of Georgia mandated all cities had to add one second on top of that where photo enforcement was used, collisions and infractions fell considerably. </P> <P>So much so some municipalities cancelled their photo enforcement programs at intersections because they were no longer profitable. </P> <P>By contrast, the city of Winnipeg sets all of its amber lights at four seconds, regardless of the speed limit and the size of the intersection. </P> <P>Katz said if the evidence and research proves that could work here, he says city council should strongly consider it. </P> <P>"I do believe it's incumbent upon us to definitely look into it, absolutely," said Katz, who will demand a "complete and thorough review" from the department. </P> <P>"I think we need to determine the facts and the only way to get that information is by having the department prepare a report." </P> <P>Katz said if the evidence does show longer ambers could reduce collisions and red-light running, he would not be concerned about a corresponding drop in red-light camera revenue. </P> <P>Photo enforcement, including photo radar, netted the city $4.9 million in profits in 2009. </P> <P>"My concern is the safety of our citizens," said Katz. "The two are not related in my eyes." </P> <P>The next EPC meeting is scheduled for Sept. 8, said Katz, who added he doesn't expect the departmental review will be a lengthy process. </P> <P>The evidence from the U.S., including a number of studies on the issue, shows the vast majority of drivers who received red-light camera tickets entered the intersection less than a second after the traffic lights turned red. </P> <P>By extending the length of the amber one second and giving law-abiding drivers better warning, those infractions dropped dramatically in those cities. </P> <P>Meanwhile, dangerous drivers who "gun it" through reds regardless of the length of the amber still get ticketed. </P> <P>The speculation we've heard from some critics here that drivers would simply adjust to longer yellows and run red lights anyway simply did not occur in the controlled studies performed in the U.S. </P> <P>Hopefully we can get past the unsubstantiated knee-jerk reactions to this idea and proceed based on evidence. </P> <P>Which is what Katz wants to do. </P> <P>All of this is thanks to the group WiseUp Winnipeg, which has been pushing this idea for months and is still planning to launch a campaign on it in September. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Panhandler gets violent ; Driver says man smashed his car with a wooden chair leg
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg man was looking for some new wheels Friday after having his car smashed up Thursday by what appears to have been a violent downtown panhandler. </P> <P>Anthony Morrison, 18, and a friend of his were in Morrison's 1994 Acura Integra, stopped at a red light on Higgins Avenue at Main Street about 1:30 p.m. Thursday, when a shirtless man approached the car. </P> <P>"He seemed to be looking in the window," Morrison said. "He was saying something but we couldn't hear him because the window was up. He shook his head and said something and we looked away." </P> <P>That's when things got weird. </P> <P>"He hit my window with a wooden chair leg," Morrison said. </P> <P>After smashing the driver's window, the man allegedly used the chair leg to smash the windshield as well as the rear driver's side window, the rear windshield and a side mirror. He also made various dents in the car's body, Morrison said. </P> <P>"Then he threw the chair leg into my car and ran away," Morrison said. "It happened so fast we didn't even know what to do. I thought about going after him but he was gone." </P> <P>'Said we hit him' </P> <P>Winnipeg police arrested a suspect close by only a few minutes after the incident. They have charged 29-year-old Duane Evenson with mischief under $5,000 and failing to comply with previous court orders. </P> <P>"He apparently said we hit him with our car," Morrison said, noting there were many witnesses to the incident, whom he said were very helpful. </P> <P>Morrison got shards of glass in his face and back and had to go to the hospital to get them out. His friend got glass in his face and eyes, but Morrison said no permanent damage was done. </P> <P>As for the car, it was at Manitoba Public Insurance's impound lot Friday and Morrison is still unsure what will become of it. </P> <P>In the meantime, he was out looking for a new one Friday just in case. </P> <P>"It sucks that I have to deal with something I didn't cause," Morrison said. </P>

--30--

Title: 18-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hail the size of golf balls ; North 'Peg gets iced
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>For a few minutes on Friday evening, it wasn't easy to tell the golf balls from the hailstones at Shooters Family Golf Centre. </P> <P>The north Winnipeg golf course was right in the path of a brief but intense storm that dumped hail as large as toonies and golf balls from the skies. </P> <P>"We just got hammered," said Guido Cerasani, president of Shooters. "It was quite the experience. Everyone was golfing and then all of a sudden there was an accumulation of ice on the ground." </P> <P>Cerasani said the course's greens were left pock-marked by the hail, as were all the vehicles in the parking lot. </P> <P>"Autopac is going to have some huge claims," he said. </P> <P>The course sustained only minor damage and is open and playable, Cerasani said. </P> <P>Rob Paola, a meteorologist with Environment Canada, said the storm developed on the west side of Winnipeg then moved northeast, dumping golf ball-sized hail around McPhillips Street and the Perimeter Highway, and around Shooters, which is located on Main Street. Other areas received hail the size of quarters and toonies, Paola said. </P> <P>"It only lasted about 15 or 20 minutes but it was fairly intense while it was happening. Even five minutes of hail that size is going to cause some trouble," he said. </P> <P>Although Sunday is predicted to be an unusually hot and humid day, there appears to be little chance of a repeat hailstorm in the near future, Paola said. </P> <P>The forecast for Sunday is for highs between 32 C and 35 C across southern Manitoba, with humidex values creeping closer to 40 C. </P> <P>"It's going to be a hot and sticky one," Paola said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: No jail for woman who killed two people when she accidentally hit the gas pedal
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG - A Winnipeg driver who accidentally hit the gas pedal instead of her brakes has offered a tearful apology to the families of two pedestrians she killed. </P> <P>Lucy Muthoka, 52, was handed a two-year suspended sentence with probation after pleading guilty to dangerous driving causing death. </P> <P>William Halcrow, 57, and James Ross, 58, were killed instantly after being hit by Muthoka's Subaru Forester in June 2008. </P> <P>The two friends were from the Cross Lake reserve in northern Manitoba and were in Winnipeg for medical treatment. </P> <P>Court heard that Muthoka was an infrequent driver who had just completed refresher courses after purchasing a new car. </P> <P>Muthoka told the courtroom she is more sorry than the world will understand. </P> <P>“God being my witness, I never intended to harm. Words fail to express how sorry I am,” a tearful Muthoka told a large courtroom gathering on Friday which included family and friends of the two men. </P> <P>Muthoka wasn't intoxicated or distracted by anything such as a cellular phone or texting, court was told. </P> <P>While exiting the downtown Millennium Library parkade just after 4:30 p.m., Muthoka suddenly accelerated rapidly, striking several vehicles and people at a crowded intersection during rush-hour traffic. </P> <P>Muthoka also went up on the sidewalk and hit a fire hydrant, which caused hundreds of litres of water to quickly flood the area. </P> <P>Outside court, several family members expressed anger at the suspended sentence and questioned the sincerity of Muthoka's apology. </P> <P>Provincial court Judge Brent Stewart said it was an especially difficult case given the tragic circumstances and Muthoka's obvious lack of intent. He said no punishment can undo the damage caused or bring the victims back. </P> <P>“This is not a court of vengeance,” said Stewart. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'Her sense of guilt is enormous'
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An inexperienced Winnipeg driver who accidentally hit the gas pedal instead of her brake offered a tearful apology to the families of two pedestrians she killed in a chaotic downtown crash. </P> <P>Lucy Muthoka, 52, was handed a two-year suspended sentence with probation Friday after pleading guilty to dangerous driving causing death for the June 2008 incident near the intersection of Donald Street and St. Mary Avenue. </P> <P>William Halcrow, 57, and James Ross, 58, were killed instantly after being hit by Muthoka's Subaru Forester. The two friends were from the Cross Lake reserve in northern Manitoba and were in Winnipeg for medical treatment. </P> <P>"God being my witness, I never intended to harm. Words fail to express how sorry I am," a tearful Muthoka told a large courtroom gathering, which included family and friends of the two men. "I am more sorry than the world will understand. I will continue to pray for the healing of everyone affected by this. May God meet the needs of everyone whose lives were changed." </P> <P>Crown attorney Zane Tessler said Muthoka was an "infrequent" driver who had just completed five refresher courses after purchasing a new car. She had placed a "novice driver" warning sign at the back of the vehicle. </P> <P>Her driving instructor later told police she wouldn't have had the skills to pass a driving test following her first lesson, but likely would have following completion of the course. </P> <P>While exiting the Millennium Library parkade just after 4:30 p.m., Muthoka suddenly accelerated rapidly, striking several vehicles and people at the crowded intersection during rush-hour traffic. Muthoka also went up on the sidewalk and hit a fire hydrant, which caused hundreds of litres of water to quickly flood the area. That hampered the police investigation because it was difficult to recreate the scene and figure out the sequence of events. </P> <P>Several witnesses -- who narrowly avoided being hit -- tried frantically to revive the two gravely injured men lying in the rapidly rising waters, as did firefighters and paramedics. A third man was pinned between two cars and suffered serious injuries, as did the drivers of two other vehicles. </P> <P>"The degree of resulting carnage was substantial," Tessler said. </P> <P>Muthoka wasn't intoxicated or distracted by anything such as a cellular phone, court was told. It was a "perfect summer day" with clear skies and dry roads. </P> <P>Muthoka had no criminal record and is a religious single mother who has spent the past decade working for Agriculture Canada. </P> <P>She is originally from Kenya and serves as an elder within the local community. More than 30 people filed letters of support on her behalf. </P> <P>"Her sense of guilt is enormous," defence lawyer Saul Simmonds said. "She goes to sleep at night praying for Mr. Ross and Mr. Halcrow and their families. She wakes up praying for them. This is a decent, honest, hard-working person. It's the nightmare for everyone who gets behind the wheel." </P> <P>The families of both victims made emotional impact statements in court, describing how both men were loved and respected by their community. They were joined by the Cross Lake chief and council members. </P> <P>"The pain of loss is excruciating," said Ross' sister, Betty. "To lose someone in such a sudden, unexpected and inhumane way." </P> <P>Provincial court Judge Brent Stewart said the case was especially difficult given the tragic circumstances, Muthoka's obvious lack of intent and her glowing background. He said no punishment can undo the damage caused or bring the victims back. </P> <P>"This is not a court of vengeance," said Stewart. Outside court, several family members expressed anger at the suspended sentence and questioned the sincerity of Muthoka's apology. </P> <P>As part of her penalty, Stewart ordered Muthoka to perform 240 hours of community service and banned her from driving for a 10-year period. </P> <P>Muthoka also expressed a desire to meet with the families of the victims and make a charitable donation on their behalf, if they wished.</P>

--30--

Title: 21-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Probation in 2 deaths ; Unskilled driving blamed, 10-year ban handed down
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg woman has been sentenced to two years supervised probation for a horrifying car crash that killed two people and seriously injured a third. </P> <P>Lucy Muthoka, 52, was originally charged with criminal negligence causing death. Last March she entered guilty pleas to the reduced charges of dangerous driving causing death. </P> <P>Cross Lake First Nation residents Billy Halcrow, 57, and James Ross, 58, died in the collision at Donald Street and St. Mary Avenue on June 25, 2008. </P> <P>Accelerated </P> <P>"I am more sorry than the world will ever understand," said Muthoka, a Kenyan immigrant and longtime Agriculture Canada employee. </P> <P>Muthoka was behind the wheel of a 2008 Subaru Forester leaving the Millennium Library parkade shortly after 4 p.m. when her vehicle accelerated suddenly on Donald Street, Crown attorney Zane Tessler told court Friday. </P> <P>Muthoka told police she hit the gas pedal believing it was the brake pedal. Court heard Muthoka was an inexperienced driver who had recently taken five "refresher" classes. </P> <P>"As her vehicle suddenly accelerated and she lost control, she continued to step on her gas pedal believing it was the brake pedal," Tessler said. </P> <P>The southbound vehicle swerved across the road as it approached the St. Mary Avenue intersection, where it rear-ended a truck stopped at a red light and tore out a fire hydrant. The truck was pushed into the intersection and struck a male pedestrian, seriously injuring him. Muthoka's vehicle continued through the intersection, striking Halcrow and Ross. Both men were pronounced dead at the scene. </P> <P>As water flooded the intersection, traffic came to a standstill and volunteers rushed in to help, Tessler said. </P> <P>"The degree of chaos that ensued was staggering," he said. </P> <P>Defence lawyer Saul Simmonds said his client insisted on taking responsibility for the collision and rejected advice she explore the possibility of mechanical error. Simmonds said he spoke to several experts and read a number of reports suggesting "numerous situations of improper acceleration by this vehicle." </P> <P>"Her first concern was for the families and what she could do for the families," Simmonds said. </P> <P>Family members of both dead men read out victim impact statements in court. Halcrow's sister said he was instrumental in improving housing in his community. </P> <P>"Billy worked tirelessly for his community and demonstrated leadership abilities," she said. </P> <P>Drugs or alcohol were not factors in the collision. Muthoka was not talking on her cellphone or otherwise distracted prior to the collision. </P> <P>"The aggravating factors that are so often present in cases of dangerous driving are not present here," said Judge Brent Stewart. </P> <P>Court received 30 glowing reference letters that described Muthoka as a churchgoing woman of "deep personal strength and character." </P> <P>Stewart ordered Muthoka to complete 240 hours of community service work and prohibited her from driving for 10 years. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Dangerous driving charge laid
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 20-year-old Brandon man has been charged with dangerous driving after leading police on a chase through the streets of the western Manitoba city Thursday morning. </P> <P>Brandon police said officers tried to pull over a speeding van Thursday morning but the driver refused to stop, leading to a police chase. A 20-year-old man has now been charged with dangerous driving and flight from police. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 23-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: PEDESTRIAN HIT ON PORTAGE
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An adult male pedestrian was transported to hospital in critical condition Saturday night after a collision in St. James. </P> <P>The crash happened about 9:40 p.m. in the area of the Viscount Gort hotel on Portage Avenue. </P> <P>Portage was partially closed to eastbound traffic between Queen and Kintyre streets following the collision, as vehicles were permitted to proceed to the Route 90 exit only. </P> <P>In a media release, the Winnipeg Police Service said traffic collision investigators would be at the scene of the incident, which involved a single vehicle, for several hours. </P> <P>Motorists were advised to avoid the area. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 24-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'No signs of life' ; Pedestrian killed while crossing Portage Avenue
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It's a tragic road incident two Winnipeggers will not soon forget. </P> <P>West End resident Tracy, 30, was driving back to her neighbourhood with her friend Amanda, 29, about 9:40 p.m. Saturday when the two spotted the victim of a fatal motor vehicle collision lying in one of the middle eastbound lanes of Portage Avenue, just moments after the pedestrian was struck. </P> <P><STRONG>TAKEN TO HOSPITAL</STRONG> </P> <P>The two quickly pulled a U-turn and went to check on the 45-year-old man. </P> <P>"There was nobody else around and the (vehicle that struck the man) had stopped," Tracy said. </P> <P>She immediately called 911 and checked on the victim. </P> <P>"I approached him and you could tell his arm was broken," Tracy said. </P> <P>She said the man's neck was turned at an unnatural angle and he was unconscious. </P> <P>"He was pretty messed up," Tracy said. "There were no signs of life or anything. A couple minutes later a nurse was on scene and she couldn't get an airway or a pulse." </P> <P>The collision occurred in front of the Viscount Gort hotel at 1670 Portage Ave. in St. James. The pedestrian was transported to hospital in critical condition but died of his injuries shortly afterward, Winnipeg police said. </P> <P>Police didn't indicate whether any charges might be laid in connection with the collision. </P> <P>Traffic collision investigators were at the scene of the incident, which involved a dark Ford sport utility vehicle, for several hours. A stretch of eastbound Portage Avenue was closed to traffic following the crash and was reopened to traffic early Sunday morning. </P> <P>There is no controlled pedestrian crossing where the victim is believed to have been struck. </P> <P>Tracy said her friend Amanda attended to the middle-aged male driver of the SUV that struck the man. </P> <P>"He was in shock," Tracy said of the driver. </P> <P>She said she barely slept Saturday night because was so shaken up by the sight of the victim. </P> <P>'Feel helpless' </P> <P>"Every time I close my eyes there's that image of when I walked up to him on the road," Tracy said. "You feel helpless." </P> <P>She went back to the scene Sunday to leave flowers in honour of the victim. </P> <P>Tracy said hotel staff told her Saturday night the victim is believed to be a homeless man they often saw in the area. </P> <P>"They think he lived down by the river," she said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Pedestrian killed on Portage Avenue
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 45-year-old pedestrian died after being hit by a car outside the Viscount Gort Hotel on Portage Avenue at around 9:40 p.m. Saturday evening. </P> <P>On Sunday, nothing but a few torn strands of police tape and a small silk flower memorial tied to a bus stop hinted at the car crash that had killed the man the night before. </P> <P>Winnipeg police said he was taken to hospital in critical condition and succumbed to his injuries. They have not released his name. </P> <P>A neighbour who said he knew the deceased man identified him as Ray, a physically disabled man cared for by his brother in a small, unkempt Ashburn Street home with furniture strewn across the backyard. </P> <P>The neighbour said the victim was injured by a tractor in childhood and had difficulty walking. He was surprised the victim was hit because he had never seen Ray be careless when crossing the street. </P> <P>"He wouldn't just walk out in traffic. He wasn't suicidal." </P> <P>A section of Portage Avenue from Queen Street to Kintyre Street was closed for several hours Saturday night while traffic collision investigation team members analyzed the scene. </P> <P>"It looked like most of it happened right in front of the Viscount," said Nancy Zelazny, who returned to her home on nearby Riverbend Crescent late Saturday night. She had to take a detour to reach her home due to the police tape blocking eastbound Portage Avenue traffic. </P> <P>Zelazny said she saw a sport-utility vehicle sitting outside the hotel within the taped-off area. </P> <P>Glenn Patrick, another Riverbend resident, said the area is notorious for people walking across the street in heavy traffic, putting themselves in danger, so some way to help them cross safely is needed. </P> <P>"I'm sure it would help, because from here you have to go all the way to Queen Street (to get to a crosswalk)," he said. "People are just going halfway across (to the boulevard) and waiting for the cars to pass. There's lots of traffic." </P> <P>Just over a week ago, another person was fatally hit near the site of Saturday's incident. </P> <P>Louisa Sala, 20, was struck by a truck while wandering on Portage Avenue near the Empress Overpass in the early hours of Aug. 11. after a night of drinking at the Viscount Gort with her family. </P> <P>Sala's family had been visiting from Nunavut to support her father, who was in the city to address an adjudicator who would determine what compensation he is owed from his time in a residential school. </P> <P>Police would not say whether alcohol was involved in Saturday's incident. Representatives of the Viscount Gort refused to comment. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Loud motorcycles raise hackles  Saskatoon politician pushing crackdown faces threats
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Passions are boiling and pulses are revving across Canada over the issue of loud motorcycles.</P> <P>In one case, a Saskatoon city councillor who suggested a crackdown on noisy bikes has been threatened. And police in Winnipeg and Edmonton have been testing technology to measure the decibels a motorbike puts out, in order to start fining raucous riders.</P> <P>Coun. Bob Pringle isn't alone in his quest to quiet down the roaring exhaust pipes favoured by some riders. The Motorcycle and Moped Industry Council of Canada says municipalities from British Columbia to Nova Scotia are looking for ways to measure that noise and perhaps put a lid on it.</P> <P>Pringle says he started receiving threats a couple of weeks ago after he asked Saskatoon city administrators to examine a possible prohibition on exhaust pipes that amp up a bike's noise — equipment that's usually added after the machines are sold.</P> <P>Pringle, who was social services minister in the government of former premier Roy Romanow in the 1990s, said he hadn't been personally threatened since his days as a cabinet minister.</P> <P>While most motorcycle enthusiasts are peaceful, he's been getting an earful from some who are not, Pringle said.</P> <P>"Bikers are very angry. They feel like I'm targeting them unfairly and they need this extra noise for safety reasons," he said in a recent interview.</P> <P>While some anonymous callers have simply told Pringle to back off, others have been more sinister. "There was also a threat about, 'I would love to meet you in a back lane and you wouldn't come out,"' he said.</P> <P>Pringle acknowledges there have been only a few threatening phone calls. The vast majority of residents complain about ear-splitting noise made by some machines as they blast through city streets.</P> <P>An anonymous caller reached him on his cellphone around 2:30 a.m. last Sunday and promised to call each time he heard a loud noise.</P> <P>Pringle decided the situation was escalating and it was time to step up his response. He spoke to Saskatoon's police chief and a lawyer about whether to start writing down some of the more threatening details.</P> <P>On the other side of the debate is Kelvin Ooms, 44.</P> <P>By day, he's a maintenance supervisor for a food distribution company in Saskatoon. In his off hours, he climbs aboard his Harley Davidson and transforms into a road warrior who isn't ashamed to use his bike's loud exhaust pipes.</P> <P>When he heard that Pringle was pushing the idea of a crackdown on loud bikes, he immediately started a petition and a Facebook site to drum up opposition.</P> <P>Ooms knows people are passionate about the issue, but he also doesn't like the nasty turn this debate has taken. He has removed at least six people from his Loud Pipes Save Lives Facebook page who have been threatening or derogatory.</P> <P>"By no means do I condone any behaviour like this. I don't think we're going to accomplish anything by doing that."</P> <P>Ooms said there are more constructive ways to get out the message that loud exhaust pipes can save riders' lives by making their presence known.</P> <P>The image of loud bikes as souped-up versions of their owners' egos and machismo isn't driving this debate, he insists. Rather, it's about ensuring that drivers, who often admit after a collision that they didn't notice an oncoming motorcycle, both see and hear them.</P> <P>Earlier this year, when a driver started to change lanes without noticing him, Ooms used his loud exhaust pipes to avoid a collision. He honked his horn, locked up his wheels, popped his clutch and hit the gas.</P> <P>"It wasn't until I engaged my clutch and revved my throttle and really snapped my pipes that I finally got the attention of the driver and they moved out of my lane."</P> <P><STRONG>Winnipeg looks to Edmonton laws<BR></STRONG>Some municipalities in Canada are looking at new measures implemented in Edmonton on July 1 as a sort of template on the issue.</P> <P>A city bylaw amendment allows police to use specialized devices to measure the sound levels of noisy bikes. First-time offenders are charged $250.</P> <P>Staff Sgt. Bill Horne, who works in the Edmonton police traffic section, said angry residents had been calling for years to complain about the deafening racket made by motorcycles zooming through the downtown and on the city's popular bar strip, Whyte Avenue.</P> <P>In June, about 40 officers were trained to use meters to measure the sound from idling exhaust pipes. Most bikes aren't allowed to go over 92 decibels while idling. Other bikes can't exceed 96 or 100 decibels, depending on the number of cylinders.</P> <P>Before the amendment came into effect, police tested 1,066 bikes over two days. Almost 430 failed the noise test.</P> <P>Since the new rules took effect, 216 tests have been conducted, with 64 bikes failing.</P> <P>"Without a doubt I've heard feedback from people on Whyte Avenue ... and certainly it has helped control the problem," Horne said.</P> <P>Staff Sgt. Mark Hodgson, commander of the central traffic unit in Winnipeg, says police there are eyeing Edmonton as they examine comprehensive anti-noise measures. They also want a way to deal with loud vehicles and thumping car stereos.</P> <P>Winnipeg has been testing noise-measuring equipment similar to Edmonton's, Hodgson says. Police are working with Crown attorneys and the Manitoba Infrastructure and Transportation Ministry to fashion legislation that can be successfully prosecuted.</P> <P>"We're moving a little more slowly than Edmonton, but we think in a fashion that will allow us to create legislation that is all-encompassing and will also be supportable in court," Hodgson said.</P> <P>Complaints escalate<BR>Bob Ramsay, president of the Motorcycle and Moped Industry Council of Canada, says his organization has helped to develop standards on what constitutes a loud bike. It has been getting calls from interested municipalities and police forces across Canada.</P> <P>The group has spent more than three years developing noise standards for bikes because of an escalating number of complaints.</P> <P>Ramsay says that with an objective standard for noise, it would be easier for municipalities to draft bylaws putting limits on the louder machines.</P> <P>The industry was also worried that all motorcyclists were being painted with the same brush, he said.</P> <P>"It's an approach that we as an industry feel serves motorcycling and motorcyclists best, because we don't want people just thinking of motorcycles and thinking of very loud motorcycles."</P> <P>About 124,000 new motorcycles, scooters and all-terrain vehicles were sold in Canada last year with a value of about $1.5 billion. Motorcycles and scooters made up almost 52 per cent of sales.</P> <P>He says the industry is also closely watching any court cases that arise from Edmonton's bylaw, to learn from Alberta's experience.</P> <P>In Edmonton, Horne — the owner of a BMW touring bike — has heard a long list of riders' reasons for making a big racket, including that a loud bike is a safe bike.</P> <P>"That's a bunch of hogwash," Horne said. "Loud pipes don't save lives. Proper defensive driving saves lives."</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/22/man-sask-motorbikes-noise-cp.html#ixzz0xR0Sq4Xb">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/22/man-sask-motorbikes-noise-cp.html#ixzz0xR0Sq4Xb</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hail to the Autopac ; Storm spurs 1,000 claims
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The owner of a north Main Street used car dealership is very thankful his wife talked him into adding a hail policy to his business insurance. </P> <P>The Car Store on Main and its outdoor inventory of vehicles took a beating Friday night as walnut-sized hail crashed down during a storm. </P> <P>Owner Tony Panidisz said the business located at 2495 Main St. was closed at the time of the storm, so he only learned of the pelting Saturday morning. </P> <P>"There were people in the lot when I got here saying, 'Did you see what happened to your lot?'" said Panidisz, who lives in the Rural Municipality of East St. Paul. </P> <P>He said smaller hail fell at his home during the same storm Friday. </P> <P>"One guy brought hail he had frozen and it was walnut-sized," Panidisz said. "He said you'd get injured if you were walking outside at the time, and said the whole lot was covered in hail." </P> <P>Panidisz said 52 of his lot's vehicles sustained damage, likely a minimum of $3,000 each, mainly in the form of pockmarks on hoods, roofs and trunks. </P> <P>The business owner, who said he has never before sustained hail damage in the 10 years he's owned the lot, took out the hail insurance about six weeks ago at the request of his wife Theresa. </P> <P>"She's been begging me for two years to get it," he said. "With the way the weather's been I decided to do it, and I owe her something good. She's the saviour." </P> <P>Panidisz said he'll fully assess the damage and decide whether to have a hail sale or to fix some of the cars. </P> <P>The north part of the city took the brunt of the damage from the hailstorm Friday and there were reports of motorists and pedestrians scrambling for shelter as the hail, from the size of peas to near golf-ball dimensions, came down. Vehicles on other dealership lots across the area also sustained damage. </P> <P>Brian Smiley, a spokesman for Manitoba Public Insurance, said the automobile insurer has set up a special catastrophic claim centre at its new facility at 1284 Main St. to deal with the high volume of hail-damage reports. </P> <P>"We've had over 1,000 hail-related claims and we certainly expect more," he said. </P> <P>Appointments must still be made in advance, Smiley said. </P> <P>It's nowhere near the worst-ever hail storm in terms of vehicle damage in Winnipeg. Smiley said that in July 1996 more than 24,000 claims were made, resulting in $53 million in damage. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Open liquor, rifle and ammo found in checkstop
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two Manitoba men are facing charges after police found a gun and arrested an impaired driver during a traffic stop in Winnipeg on the weekend. </P> <P>Police allege an impaired driver had a rifle and ammunition -- which belong to a friend who later picked him up -- on the front passenger seat. </P> <P>The vehicle was spot-checked during a checkstop campaign by the Winnipeg Police Service's central traffic unit and Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>Police pulled over the vehicle near Portage Avenue and David Street in the Assiniboia area on Saturday about 7:40 p.m. </P> <P>The driver had visual signs of impairment and at least one officer observed open liquor bottles in the vehicle and a partially concealed firearm and ammunition on the seat, police said. </P> <P>Police seized the gun and arrested the driver, a 23-year-old Portage la Prairie man, who faces charges of impaired driving, driving with a blood-alcohol level over .08, and three firearms charges, including unauthorized possession and transferring without authority. </P> <P>He was released on a promise to appear in court. </P> <P>Things took a twist when his friend, a 22-year-old Winnipeg man, arrived to pick him up. </P> <P>Police learned the friend is the alleged owner of the firearm. </P> <P>He was charged with transferring a firearm, weapon, device or ammunition without authority, and released on a promise to appear in court. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 29-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Hailstorm damage claims surpass 1,000
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>More than 1,000 motorists in Manitoba have filed a claim for hail damage from a violent hailstorm that hit the province on Friday.</P> <P>Rain and hail the size of golf balls was reported in the Elmwood, East Kildonan and Garden City areas of Winnipeg.</P> <P>The intense storm lasted only 20 minutes but rattled the city and areas just north of it.</P> <P>According to Manitoba Public Insurance, 90 percent of the claims filed so far are from Winnipeg.</P> <P>A spokesperson for MPI is suggesting motorists who have not yet filed a claim may want to wait a day or two because there's a long wait to make a report over the telephone.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/23/mb-hail-storm-claims-winnipeg.html#ixzz0xWnMM3LF">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/23/mb-hail-storm-claims-winnipeg.html#ixzz0xWnMM3LF</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Pursuit leads to arrests
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Several people were in custody after Winnipeg police officers pursued a stolen vehicle across the city early Wednesday. </P> <P>None had been charged by late Wednesday afternoon. </P> <P>Police said officers spotted two stolen vehicles near Silver Avenue and Ferry Road in St. James about 4 a.m. </P> <P>Officers pursued one of the vehicles for about five or six kilometres to the area of McPhillips Street and College Avenue, where the suspects were arrested, police said. </P> <P>The vehicle was driven dangerously at a high rate of speed, through stop signs and a construction zone on McPhillips Street, where it knocked over pylons, police said. </P> <P>The stolen auto unit is investigating. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 31-Dec-14
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Have your say: Good rules, bad drivers
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The problem with amber and red lights is not due to their construction or implementation, but due to driver laziness and bad habits. And it is not the only pressing problem on our streets. </P> <P>In addition to traffic-light behaviour, most of Winnipeg's drivers seem to have forgotten what they learned in driver's ed, and need to be reminded, bluntly: Amber does not mean step on the gas. </P> <P>If you've had a collision, if there are no major injuries, and both vehicles are still driveable, you do not stay in the middle of the road or intersection while you wait for the police or exchange your information. </P> <P>Turning on your emergency flashers does not make it legal to park in a restricted parking or no-parking zone. </P> <P>RODNEY PAQUIN <BR>Winnipeg <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Vehicle rollover at Church and Fife
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg Fire and Paramedic service members were the first to arrive on the scene of a vehicle that rolled over near Church and Fife on Wednesday evening.</P> <P>It happened at about 9:55 pm. Three teens were taken to hospital and treated for minor injuries.</P> <P>The driver apparently fled the scene, and the other three have been less than co-operative with police.</P> <P>Police tell CJOB a stop sign was taken out, and a fence damaged in the collision.</P> <P>The cause of the accident is not known at this time.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 2-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Electric scooters catching on in the city
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Nerve damage has forced Mike Paille to live by a few simple rules.</P> <P>“Don’t pollute, unplug and scoot,” says Paille, who is unable to drive a car as a result of diminished eyesight that was caused by his nerve damage.</P> <P>Paille is the owner of Mike’s Bikes, an electric scooter retailer located at 102 King Edwards St. He is one of growing number of Winnipeggers who are choosing to travel the city’s streets via scooters.</P> <P>The Manitoba Electric Vehicle Association says that Winnipeggers have purchased electric scooters in increasing numbers in the past year. There are currently about 500 electric scooters navigating city streets, according to a MEVA spokesperson.</P> <P>Paille is a huge scooter fan. He says they are environmentally friendly and one of the most accessible modes of transportation available.</P> <P>“All you really need is a standard bicycle helmet,” he said.</P> <P>Paille, a Fort Richmond resident, said it takes him about 45 minutes to travel from home to his shop, located on King Edward in St. James.</P> <P>He began driving a scooter about four years ago and said the attitude of motorists towards scooter drivers has changed considerably during that time.</P> <P>“I remember once I was hit with eggs while on the road,” he recalled. “Now they are very courteous and keep an eye out for scooters on the road.”</P> <P>Fellow scooter owner Jason Czmola said he was initially skeptical about driving a supped-up bike around the city.</P> <P>“I used to think there was a stigma with scooters, but now I’m a proud rider,” the St. Vital native said.</P> <P>Scooter drivers must be at least 14 years old but are not required to be licensed by Manitoba Public Insurance. No insurance is required to operate the vehicles, but drivers are required to wear a helmet.</P> <P>Scooters must travel no faster than 32 km/h and cannot produce more than 500 watts of power.</P> <P>MPI spokesperson Brian Smiley said scooter drivers should “know and respect the rules of the road like any other vehicle (operator) and motorists are expected to give them space.”</P> <P>Kobi Hazid, owner of Scooter City at 1156 Main Street, attributes part of the recent increase in the number of scooters on the road to the low cost of operating them. It costs as little as $3 a month to charge a scooter’s battery and a full charge can last for between 60 and 80 km.</P> <P>“The cost of purchasing and running a scooter is quite minimal and people these days are looking for cheap and reliable transportation,” Hazid said.</P> <P>Scooter drivers aren’t the only fans of the increasingly popular mode of transportation.</P> <P>“This gives people another choice and an alternative to fossil fueled powered vehicle,” said Curt Hull, project manager of Climate Change Connection.</P> <P>Manitoba Ozone Protection Industry Association spokesperson Mark Miller said scooters have the potential to reduce some motorists’ reliance on fossil fuels.</P> <P>“Any strides forward away from our dependence on fossil fuels is a positive step forward,” he said.</P> <P>Paille doesn’t expect scooters will completely replace gas-powered vehicles any time soon. Most people use them as an efficient, low-cost alternative for travelling back and forth to to work.</P> <P>“It has been mostly people coming in saying they live five minutes from work and don’t want to drive anymore,” he said.</P> <P>“However, we get a few husbands coming in to pick one up for their wives and they end up buying one too.”<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 3-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Windshield claims online
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance is introducing a new application which will make fixing that crack in the windshield a lot easier. </P> <P>On Thursday, MPI announced eGlassClaim, a program which will allow customers to register claims for auto glass work right at the repair shop, instead of having to report claims through the agency's call centre before taking the vehicle in for repairs. </P> <P>"This new system will make it easier for both the customer and our business partners in the glass repair industry to do business with MPI," said the Crown- owned insurer's president Marilyn McLaren in a statement. </P> <P>The new system will enable repair shops to interface directly with MPI's claim system, file electronic invoices, and receive automatic payments for completed work. </P> <P>"It's a natural progression for us," said McLaren, "as we continue to explore new ways to use technology to increase value for our customers." </P> <P>Adoption of the new system by individual repair shops is not mandatory, said MPI, though all glass repair services are encouraged to participate. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Free inspection clinic won't ticket owners for vehicle infractions
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police are holding a one-day vehicle inspection clinic in response to special- interest vehicle owners' complaints about frequent police checks on Sunday cruise nights. </P> <P>fie free inspections -- held at the Manitoba Public Insurance claim centre at 420 Pembina Hwy. on Sunday between 1 p.m. and 8 p.m. -- are voluntary. No tickets will be issued for on-site infractions, said police spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen. </P> <P>If a vehicle is found to have a serious or dangerous equipment issue, however, it will be considered out of service and the owner will be required to have it towed, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>The idea is to allow people to find out if their vehicles -- modified or not -- meet the rules of the road without being ticketed. </P> <P>"We want to have safe vehicles on the road," Michalyshen said. </P> <P>fie event is being met with skepticism and criticism from people who don't believe the clinic is the solution to mending the fractured relationship between police and a large segment of so-called cruisers. </P> <P>People will be told what to repair for the vehicle to be street legal and to avoid a ticket if pulled over in the future, said Michalyshen. </P> <P>He said the event is being conducted by the police service's vehicle inspection unit and Manitoba Public Insurance mechanics. </P> <P>A vehicle safety inspection report will be filled out but police or MPI won't record driver information, licence plate numbers, vehicle identification numbers (VIN), or issue a re-inspection notice, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>The forms will only list the vehicle's year, make and model, he said. </P> <P>fie purpose is to erase any fears or speculation police will collect driver or vehicle information and use it in the future. But not everyone believes or is satisfied with the assurance. Will Tataryn, a regular on Sunday cruise nights, was one of several special interest vehicle owners who said they won't attend the clinic. </P> <P>No patrol cars are assigned to the event, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>Similar clinics have been held in the past. </P>

--30--

Title: 5-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Drivers wary of inspection event
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police say an upcoming event is meant to help drivers learn if their vehicles are up to snuff for city roadways and avoid pricey traffic tickets. </P> <P>Some drivers who participate in cruise nights, however, are wary about the free vehicle inspection night planned by police and Manitoba Public Insurance, apparently still miffed that police clamped down on them earlier this summer. </P> <P>This Sunday, officers from the Central Traffic Unit and inspectors from the Manitoba Public Insurance will look over vehicles at a Pembina Highway claim centre. </P> <P>Each driver who voluntarily shows up to 420 Pembina from 1 p.m. to 8 p.m. will get an inspection report detailing problems with his vehicle. </P> <P>Police emphasized no tickets will be issued and people with serious equipment issues can arrange to get their vehicles towed to their homes. </P> <P>Andrea Shaffer, a 21-year-old Sunday night cruiser, said she's "sceptical" about the information police might collect after a summer where she said police have regularly put Sunday night cruisers under the microscope. </P> <P>"Right now, a lot of us don't even want to go out," she said. </P> <P>"It's gotten to the point where it's not enjoyable for us to go out anymore. </P> <P>"We feel that it's been taken to a whole other level and it's kind-of ruining the whole Winnipeg cruise night aspect of things...people just don't want to go out for the fear of getting a ticket for the smallest thing." </P> <P>During involuntary inspections -- unlike this Sunday's voluntary inspection - - officers in patrol cars pull over vehicles and send them to an inspection site. </P> <P>Mark Burton, a vocational automotive instructor who heads out on cruise nights, says the free vehicle inspection event is a PR move. </P> <P>He disagrees with some of the vehicle standards set out in the law, and has made entreaties to Manitoba Public Insurance about why certain vehicle modifications are illegal. He says many car enthusiasts are staying off the roads Sunday nights -- the city's traditional cruise night -- because they're afraid of being ticketed by police. </P> <P>"It just sounds like a public relations thing to make it sound OK what they're doing (like) 'Well, we offered you a day where you can come in and take a look and that way we can nail you the next night and you can't complain about it,'" he said. </P> <P>"It's not going to make the people in the car community feel any better about what's happening on Sunday night." </P> <P>However, Central Traffic Unit Sgt. Doug Safioles said the event is in response to Sunday night cruisers from organized car clubs. </P> <P>"Over this last summer, we've ticketed many, many cars for failure to comply with basic conditions, and so at their request, they're saying, 'Can we get our cars checked before we're going to get ticketed?,'" said Safioles. </P> <P>He said the event will likely be a "one time thing" for 2010. He said that will then give the vehicle's owner a chance to seek repairs if they wish. </P> <P>Police have said they will not be recording any vehicle inspection numbers, licence plates, or owner's information on the forms they fill out, and only putting down the vehicle's model and year. Safioles said if the vehicle has "significant" problems owners may have to arrange a tow. </P> <P>"If you come in, and you have no brakes, and it's a danger, you'll have to find a way to get your own vehicle home," he said. </P> <P>"We're not going to seize it or anything, but you can't drive it home." </P> <P>There will be no patrol cars assigned to the event, said police, and inspections will be voluntary. </P> <P>"We're not leaving the building. No one's going out to find anybody," said Safioles. </P> <P>"We don't want to write tickets, we just want everyone's cars to be compliant and safe so if this saves you a ticket and everyone gets compliant, then that's great." </P> <P>He said the event is set on a Sunday so they can use the claim centre and scheduling for police and MPI staff. </P> <P>John Dyck, the Manitoba Association of Auto Clubs vice-chairman, said he supports the event and called it "a step in the right direction" for drivers. </P> <P>He said some youth incorrectly believe police have an agenda to target them. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: eGlassClaim To Make Auto Glass Claims Easier
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance has unveiled a program it says will make auto glass claims easier. The auto insurer has introduced a web application that will enable glass repair facilities to register claims on behalf of customers. It's called eGlassClaim.</P> <P>Under the old system, customers were required to report claims to MPI's Call Centre first.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Prolific car thief busted again
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One of Winnipeg's prolific auto thieves is back in custody after allegedly leading city police officers on a dangerous high-speed pursuit in a stolen vehicle. </P> <P>Two males were in a stolen vehicle in the 300-block of Sackville Street when one got out and stole a second vehicle Wednesday at 3:45 a.m., police said. </P> <P>fie suspects took off in both vehicles. </P> <P>About 15 minutes later, offc-ers spotted and attempted to stop one of the vehicles near Logan Avenue and Quelch Street. </P> <P>The driver took off at a high rate of speed, resulting in a pursuit. </P> <P>Police said the vehicle was ditched near Lansdowne Avenue and Inkster Boulevard. The suspect ran away but was arrested at a home. </P> <P>Police said an 18-year-old man, who is a Level 4 offender in the Winnipeg Auto Theft Suppression Strategy, is charged with theft over $5,000, theft under $5,000, dangerous operation of a motor vehicle, flight from police and driving while disqualified. </P> <P>On fiursday at 3 a.m., offc-ers encountered the second vehicle near McGregor Street and Selkirk Avenue. </P> <P>Police put down a spike belt but the driver fled and abandoned the vehicle on Spence Street south of Sargent Avenue. </P> <P>So far, the male has eluded capture. </P> <P>fie original vehicle was stolen in the 300 block of Templeton Avenue on Monday or Tuesday, police said. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 8-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Golf carts 'automobiles': Manitoba judge
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Manitoba judge has ruled that electric golf carts are "automobiles," and has ordered Manitoba Public Insurance to pay a Winnipeg man compensation for an injury he sustained on the golf course more than seven years ago. </P> <P>Court of Queen's Bench Justice Brenda Keyser's recent ruling is the latest step in Jeff Hruska's legal battle for compensation after he was hurt while riding a battery-powered golf cart at Bridges Golf Club on April 26, 2003. </P> <P>He suffered a broken right leg, muscle tearing and permanent scarring in the incident. Hruska filed a lawsuit against Bridges in 2004. </P> <P>But the case languished in the justice system for years as Bridges denied all responsibility for his injury and claimed that MPI was legally bound to compensate Hruska under Manitoba's public-insurance laws. </P> <P>MPI has long had a "no-fault" insurance policy. This means people injured in vehicle accidents can't sue for damages in the civil court system. </P> <P>In Hruska's case, MPI argued that a golf cart wasn't an "automobile" as defined by provincial legislation and refused to pay his claim. </P> <P>The lawsuit was brought forward as a "special case" to the court earlier this year in order to end the legal stalemate. </P> <P>2 definitions of 'automobile' </P> <P>After hearing all sides on May 28, Keyser ruled last week that there are differing definitions of what constitutes an "automobile" in the Manitoba Public Insurance Act. </P> <P>The section used to calculate no-fault benefits doesn't specifically exclude golf carts, she said in her five-page ruling issued Aug. 19. </P> <P>"It is a device by which a person may be transported on a highway and is not designed to be moved solely by human muscular power, or used on tracks; nor is it a motorized mobility aid," Keyser wrote. </P> <P>"The special case confirms that the golf cart was powered by an electric battery and, thus, was self-propelled," she stated. </P> <P>"On a plain reading of the legislation, the bodily injury to Hruska was caused by an accident involving an automobile as defined [by law] ? he is entitled to no-fault compensatory benefits," she wrote. </P> <P>The amount MPI must pay Hruska was not disclosed. </P> <P>The Crown corporation has 30 days from the date of Keyser's ruling to file an appeal of her decision. </P>

--30--

Title: 9-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Free inspection popular ; Motorists line up for no-ticket, special clinic
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Motorists lined up Sunday for free vehicle inspections. </P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance and the Winnipeg Police Service teamed up to host the free assessment session at the public insurer's Pembina Highway claims centre. </P> <P>The clinic was organized in response to special-interest vehicle owners' complaints about frequent police checks on recent Sunday cruise nights. The special clinic was open to all motorists and police said from the get-go they would not issue tickets for infractions. </P> <P>About a dozen vehicles were lined up before the clinic opened at 1 p.m. and a steady stream came throughout the day. </P> <P>While many who made use of the clinic were drivers of unmodified, newer-model vehicles, numerous classic and modified vehicles turned up as well. </P> <P>Const. Elmer Hanson of the WPS vehicle inspection unit worked at the clinic issuing checklists to vehicle owners outlining any necessary changes. He said he was pleased to see modified vehicles in the queue. </P> <P>"Being a car guy myself, I just want to see them be legal and safe," Hanson said of the classic cars and customized rides. "Here's an opportunity to find out. If you don't take an opportunity like this, you can't say, 'Well, I didn't know.' " </P> <P>Hanson played down the rift between some cruise night drivers and police. </P> <P>"The problem is there are some people who just want to push the envelope," he said. "There is animosity with them, because they think we're just out to get them. We're not. We're out to make the vehicles comply with standards and make them safe for the road." </P> <P>While some in line for the clinic complained about the wait time for the single inspection lane, most seemed happy just to get some free advice and clarifications on what's legal on the road. </P> <P>"I think this is great," said Winnipegger Paul Murray, who brought in his 1929 Chevy coupe. </P> <P>"It has to be legal, and here both police and MPI inspect it," Murray said. </P> <P>He found out his airbrushed yellow wagon with carved wooden interior will need a few upgrades, including a new licence plate light and a slightly raised front-end suspension. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver mocked officers after chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG -- A Manitoba woman is headed to jail after speeding away from a police spot-check in a stolen car -- then later mocking officers for failing to catch her during a dangerous highway chase. </P> <P>"You suck at driving. I smoked you b....," Shontele McKay boasted following her March 2008 arrest. </P> <P>McKay, 30, was sentenced to 16 months behind bars Friday after pleading guilty to numerous charges including dangerous driving, motor vehicle flight from police and impaired driving. </P> <P>Provincial court Judge Lynn Stannard rejected her bid for a conditional sentence which would have allowed her to remain free in the community. </P> <P>"The alternative to custody would not serve the aims of justice. The protection of the public is paramount," Stannard said. </P> <P>McKay was also hit with a two-year driving ban, which will begin once she's released. </P> <P>The incident began with a seemingly innocent afternoon traffic stop at the side of a highway near Eriksdale, about 147 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg. </P> <P>McKay was in the passenger seat, while her boyfriend was driving. As police began to question him outside the car about a theft of gas that happened earlier that day, McKay slipped into the driver's seat, stepped on the pedal and fled the scene. </P> <P>Police quickly realized the car was stolen and called in several officers from nearby detachments for assistance. </P> <P>McKay reached speeds of 160 km/h while passing numerous vehicles. She also managed to avoid a spike belt which was laid across the road by RCMP officers hoping to stop her. </P> <P>Police briefly aborted their pursuit on two different occasions because of potential danger to the public. The chase finally ended when McKay clipped the side of a truck she was trying to pass, which sent her vehicle careening into a ditch. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Boy, 11, killed in ATV rollover
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An 11-year-old Portage la Prairie boy was killed in an all-terrain vehicle incident Friday afternoon. </P> <P>Emergency crews were called to the scene just east of Portage la Prairie about 3:30 p.m. </P> <P>RCMP say two 11-year-old boys were operating a four-wheel, two-seat ATV on a farm when the vehicle overturned, trapping the driver underneath. </P> <P>The injured boy was rushed to Portage and District General Hospital but died of his injuries. The passenger escaped without injury, police said. </P> <P>An RCMP traffic collision analyst attended the scene to assist with the investigation. </P> <P>No other people or vehicles were involved in the accident. Police continue to investigate. </P> <P>It's not known if the boys were wearing helmets or whether adults were supervising them. Under the province's Off-Road Vehicle Act, children are required to wear helmets while operating ATVs and must be supervised by adults. </P> <P>The fatal crash was the second serious motor vehicle incident involving a child in the Portage la Prairie area Friday. A seven-year-old boy from the Rural Municipality of MacDonald remained in critical condition Saturday after a hit-and-run collision Friday morning. </P> <P>Portage la Prairie RCMP were called to the scene just north of the city about 11:30 a.m. Friday. </P> <P>Police said the boy had been walking with some family members on a gravel road when he was hit by a pickup truck, which witnesses said left the scene without stopping. </P> <P>The boy was transported by ambulance to Winnipeg's Health Sciences Centre in critical condition with undetermined injuries. </P> <P>A 58-year-old man from the RM of Portage la Prairie has been arrested and remains in custody. Charges are pending, police said. </P> <P>RCMP said alcohol and speed are considered to have been factors in the collision. Police continue to investigate. </P>

--30--

Title: 12-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Boy, 11, killed in ATV crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Experts say Manitoba needs to impose tougher ATV regulations after an 11-year-old Portage la Prairie boy was killed when an off-road vehicle crashed on Friday. </P> <P>RCMP said two 11-year-old boys were operating a large, two-seater ATV on a farm east of Portage la Prairie around 3:30 p.m. Friday when the vehicle flipped over. The passenger escaped without injury, but the 11-year-old boy who was driving was trapped under the overturned vehicle. </P> <P>RCMP Const. Miles Hiebert said emergency crews arrived within minutes, and the boy was rushed to Portage General Hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries. </P> <P>It appears the boys may have hit a slope in the ground, causing the large, heavy vehicle to flip over, he said. Hiebert could not confirm if the boys were wearing helmets or if speed was a factor.
