Police are continuing their investigation. </P> <P>Hiebert said the tragedy is the latest in a slew of serious ATV crashes involving children, and warned Manitoba adults that off-road vehicles can be extremely dangerous for youth. </P> <P>"There has been a number of (accidents) this summer and the trend has been disturbing to say the least," Hiebert said. </P> <P>"This family has paid a terrible price for the tragic consequences of their actions, but I think adults need to give a lot of thought about who is driving these off-road vehicles." </P> <P>Safety Services Manitoba president Mike Waite said the number of recreational ATV users has ballooned in Manitoba in the past few years, but few people take courses to learn how to properly drive them to avoid injury. </P> <P>In 2005, Safety Services was part of a group that asked the provincial government to establish tougher standards for the licensing and training of drivers of off-road vehicles such as ATVs and snowmobiles, off-road vehicle registration and the enforcement of any new legislation. </P> <P>Waite said nothing happened, and Manitoba still allows children to operate ATVs under adult supervision. </P> <P>"At some point we're going to have to do something," Waite said. </P> <P>"It's unfortunate to have all these people seriously injured or killed. It can be avoided." </P> <P>Waite said he expects more people will continue to be injured in ATV accidents until the province makes it a priority to impose tougher safety standards. He said some Atlantic provinces have enacted mandatory safety training for all ATV riders. </P> <P>A 2007 Canadian Institute of Health Information report found the number of Manitobans admitted to hospital because of all-terrain vehicle accidents has surged by 25 per cent over the last decade. The report found that teenagers and young adults, males in particular, are at the highest risk of sustaining an ATV- related injury. </P> <P>"The unfortunate part is people think, 'It's not going to happen to us,' " Waite said. </P> <P>Hiebert agrees, and said safety information and education about the risks of ATVs exist, but it's difficult for officials to get the message across to the public. </P> <P>Hiebert said it's too early to say whether the boy's parents could face any charges. </P> <P>"I suppose that is a possibility, but it's far too early to consider that," he said. </P> <P><A href="mailto:jen.skerritt@freepress.mb.ca">jen.skerritt@freepress.mb.ca</A> </P> <P>LITANY OF tragedy </P> <P>In Manitoba, there have been several serious ATV crashes over the last two years: </P> <P>April 28, 2010 </P> <P>Four children were taken to hospital after an ATV loaded with children veered off a gravel path in La Broquerie. Injured in the accident were the 13- year-old driver and his passengers, a 10-year-old girl, a two-year-old boy and a one-year-old infant. None of the children was wearing a helmet. </P> <P>April 19, 2010 </P> <P>A 26-year-old man died and two people were taken to hospital in serious condition following a collision of two all-terrain vehicles near Grunthal. The four-wheeler driven by a 26-year-old wearing a helmet rear-ended a second, stationary four-wheeler being ridden by a 30-year-old couple, neither of whom was wearing a helmet. </P> <P>Sept. 12, 2009 </P> <P>An 80-year-old Manitou-area farmer was found dead after being pinned under his ATV while checking his crops. Family found the victim at about 6:30 p.m. after he failed to return home on time. He was not wearing a helmet. </P> <P>April 16, 2009 </P> <P>A 43-year-old man was killed in the RM of Alonsa. His body was found lying on the road and an ATV was in the water-filled ditch. </P> <P>June 2, 2008 </P> <P>A 20-year-old man was killed when his ATV crashed into a police vehicle owned by the Shamattawa First Nation. The driver and his two 13-year-old passengers were thrown from the ATV. None was wearing helmets, RCMP said. </P> <P>June 13, 2008 </P> <P>A 19-year-old man from Carman was killed when the ATV he was driving north on Provincial Road 32 toward Haywood collided with a southbound pickup truck about 9:45 p.m. The occupants of the truck were not injured. </P> <P>Aug. 31, 2008 </P> <P>A 41-year-old man was killed when his ATV rolled in the Interlake north of Gimli. </P> <P>Oct. 19, 2008 </P> <P>Two Saskatchewan men in their 30s died after crashing an all-terrain vehicle near Swan River, 500 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg. Their quad ATV was travelling through a farming area when it drove off a steep embankment and crashed into the ground below. Both riders were wearing helmets at the time of collision. </P>

--30--

Title: 13-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Pedestrian hit by car
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A male pedestrian was transported to hospital in unstable condition after he was hit by a car in the city's North End on Sunday morning. </P> <P>The collision occurred about 7:50 a.m. in the 400-block of Mountain Avenue. The pedestrian has since been upgraded to stable condition. </P> <P>Mountain Avenue was closed to all traffic for a period Sunday morning. </P> <P>Police are investigating. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Winnipeg police say 42 of 60 vehicles checked during a voluntarily inspection clinic Sunday failed for various infractions. </P> <P>Police said the high number of failures is a concern. </P> <P>One "family-style vehicle" was taken off the road and towed for a serious mechanical issue, police said. </P> <P>Police didn't issue any tickets because the inspections, conducted by Manitoba Public Insurance mechanics, were voluntary. </P> <P>The purpose of the seven-hour clinic was to let motorists know if their vehicles -- modified or not -- meet Canada's rules of the road. </P> <P>The inspections were held in response to special-interest vehicle owners' complaints about frequent police checks on Sunday cruise nights. It appears most vehicles associated with cruise night stayed away. </P> <P>Police said 37 "family" vehicles, including sedans, minivans and sport utility vehicles, 20 modified or classic vehicles and three motorcycles were inspected at Manitoba Public Insurance's claim centre on Pembina Highway. </P> <P>Twenty-four family vehicles, 15 modified or classic vehicles and all three motorcycles failed due to "defects," police said. </P> <P>Those vehicle owners were told what to repair to avoid being ticketed if pulled over in the future. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 70-Percent Failure In Weekend Vehicle Inspection
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
Winnipeg Police and inspectors from Manitoba Public Insurance had a busy day Sunday as 60 vehicles passed through a voluntary inspection station on Pembina Highway. 17 of them,  mostly family style vehicles had no problems. The rest failed.  But only was taken off the road. 24 family-style vehicles had problems while 15 modified or classic styled vehicles did not measure up.  3 motorcycles had defects. While the Winnipeg Police Service is pleased with the turnout,  there's concern 70 percent of the vehicles failed.   The service says it will be reviewing the numbers with MPI and other stakeholders to determine where to take the issue next.<BR>

--30--

Title: 16-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI makes glass claims easier
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) has introduce a new Web application that will enable glass repair facilities to register claims on behalf of customers.</P> <P>The new application, called eGlassClaim, will interface with MPI’s claims systems and enable customers to initiate glass claims at the repair shop of their choosing. Under the old system, customers were required to report claims to MPI’s Call Centre first.</P> <P>eGlassClaim will also benefit glass repair shops, as it will allow them to submit invoices to MPI electronically and get paid automatically.</P> <P>“This new system will make it easier for both the customer and our business partners in the glass repair industry to do business with MPI,” said Marilyn McLaren, President and CEO of MPI. “It’s a natural progression for us, as we continue to explore new ways to use technology to increase value for our customers.”</P> <P>The new process will also reduce the number of calls to MPI’s Call Centre for registering routine glass claims, allowing call staff to provide even greater service to other customer’s needs.</P> <P>All glass repairers will be invited to participate in the new program, but participation in the program is optional, explained McLaren.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI Auto glass claims made easier
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One call does it all for Manitobans wanting to open an auto glass claim with Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>Effective last week, Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) will introduce a new web application that will enable glass repair facilities to register claims on behalf of customers.</P> <P>The new application, called eGlassClaim, will interface with MPI’s claims systems and enable customers to initiate glass claims at the repair shop of their choosing. under the old system, customers were required to report claims to MPI’s Call Centre first.</P> <P>eGlassClaim will also benefit glass repair shops, as it will allow them to submit invoices to MPI electronically and get paid automatically.</P> <P>“This new system will make it easier for both the customer and our business partners in the glass repair industry to do business with MPI,” said Marilyn McLaren, President and CEO of Manitoba Public Insurance. “It’s a natural progression for us, as we continue to explore new ways to use technology to increase value for our customers.”</P> <P>The new process will also reduce the number of calls to MPI’s Call Centre for registering routine glass claims, allowing call staff to provide even greater service to other customer’s needs.</P> <P>All glass repairers will be invited to participate in the new program, but participation in the program is optional, explained McLaren.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 18-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Auto Glass Claims Made Even Easier  Manitoba Public Insurance introduces eGlassClaim
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One call does it all for Manitobans wanting to open an auto glass claim with Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>Effective August 26th, Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) introduced a new Web application that will enable glass repair facilities to register claims on behalf of customers.</P> <P>The new application, called eGlassClaim, will interface with MPI’s claims systems and enable customers to initiate glass claims at the repair shop of their choosing. Under the old system, customers were required to report claims to MPI’s Call Centre first.</P> <P>eGlassClaim will also benefit glass repair shops, as it will allow them to submit invoices to MPI electronically and get paid automatically.</P> <P>“This new system will make it easier for both the customer and our business partners in the glass repair industry to do business with MPI,” said Marilyn McLaren, President and CEO of Manitoba Public Insurance. “It’s a natural progression for us, as we continue to explore new ways to use technology to increase value for our customers.”</P> <P>The new process will also reduce the number of calls to MPI’s Call Centre for registering routine glass claims, allowing call staff to provide even greater service to other customer’s needs.</P> <P>All glass repairers will be invited to participate in the new program, but participation in the program is optional, explained McLaren.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MDs toss coin to settle fee row
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The physician, whose south Winnipeg medical clinic has ignited a debate over the ethics of billing patients, settled a three-year legal dispute with a another doctor over $9,000 -- which included fees collected from patients -- by flipping a coin. </P> <P>Court documents reveal former Lakewood Medical Centre physician Dr. Leonard Lockman sued clinic owner Dr. Taras Gwozdecki in May 2005, claiming he had not been paid all of the money he earned between January and May 2005, including his $2,000 share of "cash payments" made by patients for uninsured services. </P> <P>Documents don't specify how much of the $2,000 was collected from patients who missed appointments. </P> <P>Last week, Gwozdecki told the Free Press that money collected from patients for uninsured services, including missed appointments, is not pocketed by clinic staff and is donated to charity. Gwozdecki did not return calls from the Free Press on Tuesday. </P> <P>Court documents show Gwozdecki denied the allegations and filed a counterclaim in the Court of Queen's Bench alleging Lockman accepted payments for uninsured services directly from patients and Manitoba Public Insurance. He alleged the clinic was entitled to a portion of the fees Lockman collected. </P> <P>Documents say the pair "had a falling -out" and "in spite of the small amount of money involved in the claim, counsel indicated that their clients are insistent about proceeding to trial." Gwozdecki conceded that he owed Lockman about $6,000, but pre-trial documents say they could not agree over the remaining $3,000. </P> <P>The disputed funds included a $150 blood pressure cuff Lockman left at the clinic, $700 from a drug company study, and the $2,000 cash payments for uninsured services. </P> <P>They agreed to flip a coin to settle the bill in April 2008. </P> <P>"The parties agreed to settle the matter on a coin toss. The parties agreed that the loser of the coin toss would donate the $3,000 to a charity of his choice (and, of course, keep the benefit of the tax receipt)," documents said. "Dr. Gwozdecki (heads) lost the toss." </P> <P>Legal experts called the case "bizarre," particularly since the cost of disputing the matter would exceed $9,000. </P> <P>Lawyer Dave Hill laughed and said he's never seen a case resolved by the flip of a coin in his 35 years as a civil litigator. </P> <P>"It's very unusual. Maybe I should think about that in the future," he chuckled. </P> <P>Hill said most matters involving a small amount of money can go to small claims court and be resolved in a few months. He estimated it would cost at least $15,000 to take a dispute to the pre-trial stage, if not more. </P> <P>University of Manitoba law professor Cameron Harvey called the dispute "strange," saying the two parties must have been determined not to settle. </P> <P>"That sounds bizarre," he said. "Unless they've got money to burn, it's very odd." </P> <P>Lakewood Medical ignited controversy last week when a local woman claimed clinic staff refused to let her elderly mother see a physician due to an unpaid $120 fee she was charged for canceling a previous appointment when her mother was too ill to attend. </P> <P>The decision outraged the woman's family and others who said patients should not be denied medical care and that clinics should not charge patients who cancel appointments for legitimate reasons. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 20-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Five years for brazen car thief
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Matthew Martens didn't care who was in his way as he tried to flee police, driving a stolen car up to 200 kilometres an hour into oncoming highway traffic while trying to dodge a spike belt. </P> <P>That's why justice officials fear what the future holds for the notorious Winnipeg car thief, who was sentenced Tuesday to the equivalent of five years behind bars. </P> <P>"This is a young man who's going to come back into society. Frankly, that's a scary proposition at this point," Crown attorney Liz Laite told court. </P> <P>Martens, 19, pleaded guilty to 33 separate offences stemming from a brazen, cross-country crime spree that put numerous lives at risk and left a trail of damage in its wake. He admitted spending an entire month wreaking havoc across the Prairies by stealing vehicles, gas and property -- and documenting many of the crimes through photographs and videos taken by his 16-year-old girlfriend. </P> <P>The images show the couple -- whom some justice officials have dubbed "Bonnie and Clyde" -- taunting police, drinking and driving, boasting to their friends and celebrating their accomplishments by dancing and making out on the top of stolen vehicles. </P> <P>"This is not a movie. This is Mr. Martens doing what he does best," said Laite. </P> <P>The August to September 2009 rampage resulted in multiple counts of auto theft and mischief, plus possession of stolen property and dangerous driving stemming from several high-speed chases with police in Manitoba and Saskatchewan that had to be aborted because of the risk to the public. </P> <P>"The danger to everyone on the road is almost incomprehensible," said Laite. "There is nothing redeeming about his criminality." </P> <P>Martens -- who has no prior adult convictions -- was given double-time credit for 12 months of time already spent in custody, plus another three years behind bars, under a joint recommendation from Crown and defence lawyers. Laite said a trial would have been an "enormous" undertaking because of how many different charges and jurisdictions were involved. </P> <P>Provincial court Judge Ted Lismer agreed to the plea bargain and handed down what he conceded was "a very lenient disposition." </P> <P>The female accused -- who can't be named under the Youth Criminal Justice Act -- pleaded guilty to 21 separate crimes and is currently awaiting sentencing. The Crown is seeking the maximum youth sentence of two years behind bars for the girl, who has a long history of similar property offences and was on probation at the time. Her lawyer is asking for her to be released immediately with time in custody. Provincial court Judge Rocky Pollack is expected to give his decision this month. </P> <P>At her sentencing hearing, her lawyer claimed Martens had "manipulated" her into going along for the ride. Some of the "highlights" of their crimes included burning a Hummer they stole just outside Winnipeg, nearly mowing down a vehicle owner who tried to interrupt a theft in eastern Saskatchewan and scrawling lyrics to a crude "rap song" over the interior of another car they left behind to be found by police. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 21-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 'You'll never catch us' ; High-speed car thief gets five years
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>He played high-speed chicken with police and boasted no one could catch him, but like most car thieves, Matthew Martens finally ran out of road. </P> <P>Martens, 19, was sentenced Tuesday to five years in prison after admitting responsibility for a month-long crime spree that spanned the prairies. </P> <P>Martens pleaded guilty to 33 charges, including multiple counts of auto theft and flight from police and arson. </P> <P>Martens was arrested last September following a high speed chase near the Manitoba- Saskatchewan boundary. </P> <P>"This is not a movie, this is Mr. Martens doing what he does best: stealing cars and stealing whatever he wants," said Crown attorney Liz Laite. </P> <P>The sentence was jointly recommended by the Crown and defence. Laite said prosecuting the case at trial would have been tremendously complex, given the number of charges and "enormous" disclosure. </P> <P>" is is a true and genuine plea bargain," Laite said. </P> <P>Martens received double- credit of two years time served. He will be eligible for parole in as little as eight months. </P> <P>"At one point or another, he is going to come back to society and right now that is a scary proposition," Laite said. </P> <P>The most damning evidence against Martens came courtesy of his 17-year-old coaccused and former girlfriend who provided a detailed police statement following her arrest and documented many of their criminal exploits on a stolen video camera. e videos show the couple dancing on top of stolen cars, drinking while driving, partying and smoking marijuana. </P> <P>The crime spree included the theft and abandonment and attempted theft of countless vehicles and three high speed chases in which the couple escaped capture by the police. </P> <P>During one pursuit, the couple drove 160 km/h on the Trans-Canada Highway in the wrong direction toward police. </P> <P>" e danger on the road at that time was almost incomprehensible," Laite said. </P> <P>In one abandoned vehicle, Martens scrawled the message: "F---the cops, you'll never catch us. I'm the boogie man." </P> <P>At a recent sentencing hearing, the 17-year-old coaccused claimed she was "manipulated" by Martens. e girl is set to be sentenced Wednesday. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 22-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cross-province crime spree nets 5-year prison term  Pictures, videos document trail of vehicle destruction
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A young man's brazen, month-long stolen-vehicle crime spree that snaked dangerously through Manitoba and Saskatchewan has netted him a five-year prison term.</P> <P>Matthew Martens, 19, pleaded guilty Tuesday to 33 charges stemming from the theft of several stolen SUVs in both provinces, along with a gas bar robbery, credit-card thefts and the intentional torching of a Hummer.</P> <P>The crimes took place over several weeks in August and September 2009. </P> <P>Police obtained a record of the spree when they seized "hundreds" of pictures and videos taken by Martens's teen girlfriend. The 17-year-old is a co-accused in the case.</P> <P>The images show the two posing with the pilfered SUVs, dancing on their hoods, singing to rap songs and making gang-related hand signs, Crown attorney Liz Laite said during a hearing in Winnipeg on Tuesday.</P> <P>Martens and his teen girlfriend hatched a plan to visit his family in Saskatchewan and they used the stolen vehicles to get there and back, Judge Ted Lismer heard.</P> <P>In one picture, Martens is seen holding a bottle of liquor and driving, Laite said.</P> <P><STRONG>Family visit backdrop to spree</STRONG><BR>Laite told Lismer that Martens's spree began on Aug 16, 2009 when he stole his mother's car and stranded her while she went into a Wal-Mart.</P> <P>A few days later, Martens picked up his teen girlfriend in Winnipeg. The two concocted a plan to visit family in Colville, Sask. On their way there, the two were involved in their first high-speed chase on the Trans-Canada Highway just east of Swift Current.</P> <P>Speeds reached 150 km/h during the chase, which was called off due to safety concerns when Martens intentionally began driving in the wrong lane of traffic, Laite said.</P> <P>After spending about a week in Coleville, Martens stole another SUV that was later found abandoned in Swift Current after yet another high-speed police chase.</P> <P>It was in this car that RCMP officers seized backpacks belonging to Martens and the girl that contained the cameras and cellphones used to take the videos of them showing off, Laite said.</P> <P>Police also found a message scrawled in marker on the cab of the truck that said: "F--k the cops, they'll never catch us. I'm the Bogeyman."</P> <P>In the course of stealing another SUV, Martens nearly ran over a man while speeding out of Swift Current.</P> <P>The two successfully made their way back to Manitoba where RCMP in the south of the province suddenly began to receive "numerous" complaints about "stolen and ransacked" vehicles, Laite said.</P> <P>A few days later, a Hummer with missing rims was found burnt in the Rural Municipality of Reynolds. Martens admitted Tuesday to setting the SUV on fire. The vehicle's rims were sold in Winnipeg, according to the Crown.</P> <P><STRONG>Relative pays for hotel room</STRONG><BR>A member of Martens's family agreed to put him and the girl up for a few nights at a hotel in Winnipeg. Laite said they came and went undisturbed until the money for the room ran out. His family "enabled" his criminal behaviour, she added.</P> <P>Laite said the two made plans to return to Coleville where he would get a job and she would attend school.</P> <P>On Sept. 19, police in the small community located a stolen car in front of Martens's relative's home and learned the two suspects were inside.</P> <P>When they moved in to arrest him and the girl, Martens jumped through a window and escaped. The girl was arrested without incident and gave a full statement to police that implicated Martens, Laite said.</P> <P>Martens managed to make his way back to Manitoba in a stolen sedan, but just before reaching the border, RCMP from Weyburn spot him and begin chasing him at speeds of 160 km/h.</P> <P>Again, Martens deliberately drove in the wrong lane to try and get police to stop, Laite said. A dashboard camera on an RCMP cruiser showed a number of unsuspecting motorists had to drive off the highway to avoid being hit, Laite said.</P> <P>"The danger to everyone on that road and that time is almost incomprehensible," she said.</P> <P>Police used a spike belt to stop Martens at the junction of Highway 2 and 10. He refuses to give police a statement and has been in custody ever since, Laite said.</P> <P>"This is not a movie. This is Mr. Martens doing what he does best: steal cars and basically taking whatever he wants when he wants it," she said.</P> <P><STRONG>'Lenient'<BR></STRONG>Defence lawyer Alan Libman told Lismer that Martens has wanted to take responsibility for his actions since his arrest. Unlike the girl in the case, he has never pointed the finger at anyone else for what he did, Libman said.</P> <P>"He's not blaming others for what occurred," he said. "She put the blame on Mr. Martens."</P> <P>The girl has also pleaded guilty to a number of similar charges and is awaiting sentencing. She can't be identified under the Youth Criminal Justice Act.</P> <P>Martens's five-year prison term came in the form of a joint recommendation between the Crown and defence after problems with police disclosure arose, Laite said.</P> <P>Lismer called the sentence "a very lenient disposition" in his decision to go along with the plea deal.</P> <P>Lismer gave Martens double credit for the year he's already spent in jail. He will have to serve three more years at a federal prison.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/31/man-spree-martens-sask-stolen-suv.html#ixzz0yHZ1l2SB">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/08/31/man-spree-martens-sask-stolen-suv.html#ixzz0yHZ1l2SB</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 23-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Work accident kills man
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 32-year-old Saskatchewan man is dead following a workplace accident at an oil drilling site near Virden. </P> <P>Virden RCMP said the fatality occurred Sunday at 9:30 a.m. </P> <P>Police said the man, a resident of McLean, Sask., was pinned by a load of steel collars, which are large metal pipes. </P> <P>RCMP said the man was freed by co-workers at the site in the Rural Municipality of Pipestone and rushed to hospital in Virden by ambulance. </P> <P>The man's name wasn't released. </P> <P>RCMP and Manitoba </P> <P>Labour's workplace safety and health department continue to investigate. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 24-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: ICBC rates to go down 2.4 per cent
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Insurance Corp. of B.C. will cut basic insurance rates by 2.4 per cent beginning Nov. 1, the company announced Tuesday. </P> <P>ICBC had originally asked the B.C. Utilities Commission -- which is responsible for regulating basic insurance rates in the province -- approval for a 1.9-per-cent cut, but the commission increased it, noting the insurance provider's expenses were, on average, 2.8 per cent lower than forecast over the past few years. </P> <P>It is the first such reduction in more than a decade. </P> <P>"After years of fiscal restraint, and thanks to our customers' safe driving and the hard work of our employees, we are able to further reduce our rates while reinvesting in the business to better serve our customers," ICBC president and CEO Jon Schubert said in a news release issued Tuesday. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Bizarre concrete slab drives MPI to sue city
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An island of raised concrete located in the middle of a dead-end road in a light industrial area of Winnipeg has triggered a lawsuit between Manitoba Public Insurance and the City of Winnipeg.</P> <P>The legal action comes after a Winnipeg man's BMW was damaged to the tune of nearly $11,000 after he hit the concrete slab, which is placed near the entranceway of Belle-Fosh Signs on Park Lane Avenue.</P> <P>MPI wants the city to pay the costs of repairing the car because the approximately 18 centimetre high, mattress-sized piece of concrete in the road "protrudes excessively."</P> <P>The public insurer alleges city maintenance crews failed to ensure that a sign warning motorists about the island was "erect and functioning properly."</P> <P>A man who has worked in the area for about a decade said he's mystified by the presence of the slab.</P> <P>"It's a big piece of cement in the middle of the road. It doesn't make sense actually," said Mario Mancusi.</P> <P>Mancusi said drivers have knocked over a warning sign many times and have even gotten stuck on top of the concrete slab.</P> <P>He added that a new sign placed at the site was only recently installed.</P> <P>"Shouldn't there have been proper barriers there?" asked Brian Smiley, an MPI spokesman.</P> <P>"Should there have been proper markings there? Perhaps lights, some sort of warning system in place," he added.</P> <P>The city didn't return a request from CBC seeking comment. The allegations in the lawsuit have not been proven and no statement of defence has been filed.</P> <P>Smiley said if the courts won't make the city pay for the repairs, then MPI would have to foot the bill.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/01/man-mpi-city-lawsuit-concrete-hump.html#ixzz0yNQpXVPE">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/01/man-mpi-city-lawsuit-concrete-hump.html#ixzz0yNQpXVPE</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: More jail time for wild crime spree
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg teen who videotaped her month-long crime spree across the Prairies has lost her bid to be immediately released from jail. </P> <P>The 16-year-old girl -- who can't be named under the Youth Criminal Justice Act -- had lobbied for a sentence of eight months already spent in pretrial custody. But provincial court Judge Rocky Pollack said Wednesday further punishment is needed for what justice officials say was one of the most brazen cases in recent memory. </P> <P>He ordered the girl to another eight months of jail followed by four months of community supervision. </P> <P>"You have shown little strength when it comes to saying no to criminal behaviour," said Pollack. </P> <P>Her 19-year-old former boyfriend, Matthew Martens, was sentenced to five years in prison on Tuesday for his role in the crimes. The pair pleaded guilty to dozens of offences that put numerous lives at risk and left a trail of damage. They admitted to stealing vehicles, gas and property -- and documenting many of the crimes in photographs and videos taken by the girl. </P> <P>The images show the couple -- whom some justice officials have dubbed "Bonnie and Clyde" -- taunting police, drinking and driving, boasting to their friends and celebrating their accomplishments by dancing and making out on the top of stolen vehicles. </P> <P>Pollack had strong words Wednesday for the girl's seemingly flippant attitude. </P> <P>"The most significant feature of the videos is that you chose to record them at all," he said. "It demonstrates to me how sure you were that it didn't matter who you victimized. Your sentence must ensure you have lost the attitude depicted in those videos." </P> <P>The August to September 2009 rampage resulted in multiple counts of auto theft and mischief, plus possession of stolen property and dangerous driving stemming from several high-speed chases with police in Manitoba and Saskatchewan that police had to abort because of the risk to the public. Some of the "highlights" of their crimes included burning a Hummer they stole just outside Winnipeg, nearly mowing down a vehicle owner who tried to interrupt a theft in eastern Saskatchewan and scrawling lyrics to a crude rap song over the interior of another car they left behind to be found by police. </P> <P>The Crown was seeking the maximum youth sentence of two years behind bars for the girl, who has a long history of similar property offences and was on probation at the time. At her sentencing hearing, her lawyer claimed Martens had "manipulated" her into going along for the ride. </P> <P>The girl's mother has vowed to keep her daughter on a tight leash, as she did last February when she reported the girl breaching her court-ordered curfew and had her locked up. </P> <P>"I think she has learned a great lesson. I'm not going to sit here and condone her behaviour just because I want my sweet little girl to love me," she told court. "She knows she has a lot of work to do, a lot of trust to gain back. And if she screws up, she'll be back here." </P> <P>The single mother, whom Pollack said "deserves a medal" for trying to rein in her out-of-control child, didn't try to sugar-coat her daughter's conduct. </P> <P>"This is not normal, defiant adolescent behaviour," the mother said. </P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance filed a $53,000 lawsuit against the pair earlier this week for damage caused during their spree. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Female level 4 auto thief gets year for crime spree
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 17-year-old girl arrested following a month-long auto-theft spree has been sentenced to one year of custody and community supervision. </P> <P>The sentence by Judge Rocky Pollack is in addition to the one year the girl has already spent in custody. </P> <P>The accused is a rarity in Manitoba -- a female level 4 auto thief, which is the highest level of repeat offender. </P> <P>Earlier this summer she pleaded guilty to 20 charges in connection with a Prairies-wide crime spree that ended with her arrest last September in Lethbridge, Alta. </P> <P>"You have shown little strength when it comes to saying no to criminal behaviour," Pollack said Wednesday. </P> <P>Her former boyfriend and co-accused, 19-year-old Matthew Martens, was sentenced Tuesday to five years in prison. </P> <P>The girl documented the couple's criminal adventures on a stolen video camera. Videos of the couple show them smoking marijuana, drinking while driving, dancing on the tops of stolen vehicles and throwing gang signs to the camera. </P> <P>"The most significant feature of the videos is that you chose to record them at all," Pollack said. "It demonstrates to me how sure you were that it didn't matter who you victimized ... Your sentence must ensure you have lost the attitude depicted in those videos." </P> <P>The girl claimed at an earlier hearing she was "manipulated" by Martens. </P> <P>The crime spree included the theft and abandonment and attempted theft of countless vehicles and three high-speed chases in which the couple escaped capture by the police. </P> <P>During one pursuit, the couple drove 160 km/h on the Trans-Canada Highway in the wrong direction toward police. </P> <P>In one abandoned vehicle, Martens scrawled the message: "F---the cops, you'll never catch us. I'm the boogie man." </P> <P>Police arrested the girl in Lethbridge, where she and Martens had been staying with his father. Martens slipped away from police once more but was arrested a week later following a high-speed chase at the Saskatchewan- Manitoba boundary. </P> <P>Pollack ordered that the girl have no contact with Martens, not be allowed to enter a vehicle without permission of its owner and complete 100 hours of community service work. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 28-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Electric vehicle to be tested in Man.
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The Manitoba government wants to see how well low-speed electric vehicles work in the middle of a Winnipeg winter.</P> <P>The province has entered a partnership with the University of Winnipeg to test one of the utility machines around the school's downtown campus.</P> <P>In a news release issued Wednesday, Energy and Mines Minister Dave Chomiak said the province is interested in seeing how well the electric vehicles operate in the prairie climate.</P> <P>The province also wants to learn how the vehicles, which substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions, could be used by the government, he said.</P> <P>Low-speed electric vehicles that have a maximum speed of 40 km/h don't meet Canadian safety standards, so testing must be done in controlled environments.</P> <P>The vehicle will have limited access to local streets.</P> <P>A tender is being issued for the purchase of the vehicle, the cost of which is being shared by Manitoba Infrastructure and Transportation, Manitoba Innovation, Energy and Mines, Manitoba Conservation and the University of Winnipeg.</P> <P>The Manitoba government is also currently involved in a plug-in hybrid vehicle project, testing five Toyota Priuses.</P> <P>The plug-in hybrid operates primarily on electricity, with a small gas engine as a backup. For example, the vehicle can be plugged in at home, recharged at night and then used to commute to work the next day on electric power.</P> <P>In addition, there are 110 other hybrid vehicles in the fleet of vehicles the province owns and operates, compared to just 11 in 2005. These hybrid vehicles use a gas engine assisted by an electric motor.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/01/mb-electric-vehicle-test-manitoba.html#ixzz0yNRhy460">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/01/mb-electric-vehicle-test-manitoba.html#ixzz0yNRhy460</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 29-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Van smashes through wall into salon
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg couple was shaken and embarrassed but not hurt after their van smashed through the wall and window of a hair salon in the St. James neighbourhood on Wednesday.</P> <P>It happened around 7 a.m. at T.J.'s Hair Salon on the corner of Bruce Avenue and Strathmillan Road.</P> <P>A married couple that owns Silver Heights Video and convenience store, located immediately next to the salon, was pulling into work for the day.</P> <P>The husband who was driving the van, Chen Lin, told CBC News that he got distracted and hit the gas pedal instead of the brake, and ended up smashing into the building.</P> <P>Lin and his wife are fine but embarrassed, he said.</P> <P>Tracey Joseph, who runs the hair salon, said she is just glad no one was hurt.</P> <P>The salon was not open at the time.</P> <P>"The store owners, the people who came through the window, came and told me that they had an accident and they were sorry," said Joseph.</P> <P>"When I came to the shop, I saw the van in the middle of the window."</P> <P>Despite the broken glass and smashed bricks, Joseph said the business would be open as usual.</P> <P>There's no damage estimate at this point.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/01/mb-van-wall-winnipeg.html#ixzz0yNS7ZXGc">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/01/mb-van-wall-winnipeg.html#ixzz0yNS7ZXGc</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 30-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man Arrested After Allegedly Driving Stolen Truck On Airport Runway
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A bizarre incident at Richardson International Airport Tuesday.<BR>Winnipeg Police say just after 5 a.m. a pick-truck was stolen from the parking lot of the Canadian Forces Base 17-Wing.</P> <P>Airport Authority Spokeswoman Christine Alongi tells CJOB a man then drove the stolen truck onto an active runway at the airport.<BR>The truck was quickly brought to a halt by airport security and Winnipeg Police.</P> <P>Police are now trying to figure out how the man got the truck onto the runway in the first place.</P> <P>No flights were disrupted.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 31-Jan-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Ont. auto insurance reforms hurt consumers: critics
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Changes to Ontario's auto insurance that take effect Wednesday will provide less coverage for the same cost, critics say. </P> <P>One of the most notable differences in the new standard auto insurance policy will be a 50 per cent cut in medical and rehabilitation benefits, to $50,000 from $100,000, and a corresponding drop in attendant-care benefits, to $36,000 from $72,000. </P> <P>Premiums, however, will stay the same for most people. Mel Ghangas ? who lives in Woodbridge just north of Toronto and works in the city ? said the changes don't make any sense to him. </P> <P>"But that's not fair," he said. "It's another way of this [insurance] industry making money I guess." </P> <P>Bryan Yetman, president of the Insurance Brokers Association of Ontario, admits consumers will receive fewer medical and rehabilitation benefits for the same price. </P> <P>"Yes, we're going to see reduction in coverage and yes, stability means that the price is going to stay relatively the same," he said Tuesday. "But in reality what the changes are going to do is to really introduce pricing stability to the product in the long term." </P> <P>Yetman said the changes should end the double-digit annual increases Ontario drivers have been hit with over the past few years. </P> <P>The Insurance Bureau of Canada said the average Ontario driver was paying $1,362.11 a year for insurance in September 2009, up 3.6 per cent from $1,314.26 at the same time the previous year. </P> <P>But in November 2003, drivers were paying an average of $1,492.89 a year ? 8.6 per cent more than the September figures, according to the bureau. </P> <P>Rules target abuse </P> <P>The new rules include a $2,000 cap on assessments after costs of exams and assessments skyrocketed 258 per cent over five years. </P> <P>Duncan has said the rules can help cut down on fraud. He contends the number of claims and accidents has remained fairly stable, and blames the jump in costs on abuse of the system. </P> <P>But Progressive Conservative Norm Miller says the changes will hurt Ontario families instead of fraudsters. </P> <P>NDP finance critic Peter Kormos also isn't sold on the changes either. </P> <P>"Benefits are going to be reduced significantly and premiums are going to continue to skyrocket," Kormos told CBC News. </P> <P>"This is yet another round of highway robbery by the for-profit auto insurers of Ontario. They're awfully good at collecting premiums, never any good at paying out benefits and it's going to get even worse for consumers. " </P> <P>But Yetman said even with the reduced benefits, the standard auto coverage will remain the richest in North America. </P> <P>Under the new rules, income replacement coverage will fall to 70 per cent of gross income from 80 per cent, to a maximum of $400 a week. Housekeeping expenses and caregiver benefits currently available to all accident victims will now be restricted to those with catastrophic injuries. </P> <P>However, consumers will be able to purchase additional levels of coverage in the same way they've been able to pay higher premiums to lower deductible levels. </P> <P>"What's happened is that the standard product has been reduced and the nice thing is people who have a need for certain coverage can buy them back," said Yetman, adding that despite the changes, Ontario's standard auto coverage remains the most generous in North America. </P> <P>Duncan has also said that the changes benefit consumers because they give them more choice. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Auto glass claims can now be made at your local body shop
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One call does it all for Manitobans wanting to open an auto glass claim with Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) has introduced a new Web application that will enable glass repair facilities to register claims on behalf of customers.</P> <P>The new application, called eGlassClaim, will interface with MPI’s claims systems and enable customers to initiate glass claims at the repair shop of their choosing. Under the old system, customers were required to report claims to MPI’s Call Centre first.</P> <P>eGlassClaim will also benefit glass repair shops, as it will allow them to submit invoices to MPI electronically and get paid automatically.</P> <P>One less step<BR>“This new system will make it easier for both the customer and our business partners in the glass repair industry to do business with MPI,” said Marilyn McLaren, President and CEO of MPI. “It’s a natural progression for us, as we continue to explore new ways to use technology to increase value for our customers.”</P> <P>The new process will also reduce the number of calls to MPI’s Call Centre for registering routine glass claims, allowing call staff to provide even greater service to other customer’s needs.</P> <P>All glass repairers will be invited to participate, but it is optional, explained McLaren.<BR></P>

--30--

NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba Public Insurance eGlassClaim

Under the old system, customers were required to report claims to MPI’s Call Centre first.</P> <P>eGlassClaim will also benefit glass repair shops, as it will allow them to submit invoices to MPI electronically and get paid automatically. </P> <P>“This new system will make it easier for both the customer and our business partners in the glass repair industry to do business with MPI,” said Marilyn McLaren, President and CEO of Manitoba Public Insurance. “It’s a natural progression for us, as we continue to explore new ways to use technology to increase value for our customers.”</P> <P>The new process will also reduce the number of calls to MPI’s Call Centre for registering routine glass claims, allowing call staff to provide even greater service to other customer’s needs. </P> <P>All glass repairers will be invited to participate in the new program, but participation in the program is optional, explained McLaren.<BR></P>
