Title: 3-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Auto glass claims made even easier
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One call does it all for Manitobans wanting to open an auto glass claim with Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>Effective August 26, Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) introduced a new web application that will enable glass repair facilities to register claims on behalf of customers. </P> <P>The new application, called eGlassClaim, will interface with MPI's claims systems and enable customers to initiate glass claims at the repair shop of their choosing. Under the old system, customers were required to report claims to MPI's Call Centre first. </P> <P>eGlassClaim will also benefit glass repair shops, as it will allow them to submit invoices to MPI electronically and get paid automatically. </P> <P>"This new system will make it easier for both the customer and our business partners in the glass repair industry to do business with MPI," said Marilyn McLaren, President and CEO of Manitoba Public Insurance. "It's a natural progression for us, as we continue to explore new ways to use technology to increase value for our customers." </P> <P>The new process will also reduce the number of calls to MPI's Call Centre for registering routine glass claims, allowing call staff to provide even greater service to other customer's needs. </P> <P>All glass repairers will be invited to participate in the new program but participation in the program is optional, explained McLaren. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Truck, horse trailer crash into ditch
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A blown-out tire caused a pickup truck and an attached horse trailer to roll into a ditch beside the Trans-Canada Highway east of Winnipeg.</P> <P>The incident happened about 7 p.m. Wednesday on the Trans Canada near highway 207, according to the RCMP.</P> <P>The blowout caused the driver to lose control and go into the ditch, where the truck and trailer overturned.</P> <P>The trailer, en route from Alberta to Quebec, had four horses and all survived.</P> <P>One horse escaped the trailer and was found grazing nearby while the three had to be extricated from the trailer by firefighters, police said.</P> <P>The occupants of the truck, a 55-year-old man and a 41-year-old woman, both from Alberta, were transported to hospital for treatment of minor injuries.</P> <P>Speed and alcohol are not considered factors at this time, RCMP said.</P> <P>Police continue to investigate. No other information is available at this time.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/02/mb-horse-trailer-truck-ditch-winnipeg.html#ixzz0yPC7aoeD">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/02/mb-horse-trailer-truck-ditch-winnipeg.html#ixzz0yPC7aoeD</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen military truck driven onto Winnipeg runway
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A military pickup truck was stolen from the Canadian Forces Base in Winnipeg on Wednesday and then driven onto the runway at the James Armstrong Richardson International Airport.</P> <P>The truck was stopped by airport security patrols and city police officers at about 5:15 a.m. A man was taken into custody.</P> <P>The base, 17 Wing, is located in the southwest corner of the airport property.</P> <P>Christine Alongi, spokeswoman for the Winnipeg Airports Authority, said the driver of the truck managed to breach a fence around the airport and was spotted driving towards runway 13/31.</P> <P>"Now, at an airport, anybody who drives on the airfield certainly has to be in contact with the tower and immediately the [people in the] tower noticed that there was a vehicle that had not identified themselves and called the airport duty manager as well as Winnipeg police," she said.</P> <P>There were no inbound or outgoing flights at the time, she added.</P> <P>The military base and airport are reviewing security measures.</P> <P>"There's definitely perimeter fences all around the airfield. We're not sure how this person gained access," Alongi said.</P> <P>"That's certainly something that is under investigation right now."</P> <P>The Winnipeg Police Service's major crimes unit is also investigating.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/02/mb-truck-stolen-airport-runway-winnipeg.html#ixzz0yPCU7vlY">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/02/mb-truck-stolen-airport-runway-winnipeg.html#ixzz0yPCU7vlY</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 6-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man charged in runway drive with stolen truck
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police have charged a 23-year-old Montreal man who allegedly stole a military truck and drove it on to an airport runway in Winnipeg on Wednesday morning.</P> <P>The security breach, which occurred while a small plane was taking off, set off alarm bells across Canada and kickstarted a major security review by several agencies.</P> <P>None of the agencies has revealed how the male suspect was able to breach a fence around the perimeter of 17 Wing Winnipeg and the air field, or how no one noticed him until he was on the runway and near the small plane at 5 a.m.</P> <P>Winnipeg police spokeswoman Const. Natalie Aitken said the motive isn’t known.</P> <P>Aitken said the male entered a restricted area at 17 Wing Winnipeg, which is within the airport’s perimeter, and stole a 2009 Ford F150 pickup truck belonging to the Department of National Defence.</P> <P>The truck was parked on a runway apron. Its keys were within the cab, Aitken said.</P> <P>She said the suspect drove the truck to the main runway when a Beechcraft King Air plane, carrying cargo and three people, was departing.</P> <P>Aitken said the plane took off without incident and the suspect continued to drive on the runway.</P> <P>By that point, the control tower had spotted the truck and dispatched the airport’s duty manager and the Winnipeg police airport unit.</P> <P>Officers arrested the male on the runway.</P> <P>The male wasn’t intoxicated, police said.</P> <P>Aitken said a larger plane, carrying 101 passengers and crew, departed about three minutes before the man drove on to the runway.</P> <P>Police said Michael Doss is in custody and charged with theft over $5,000, damaging or interfering with a navigation facility and mischief endangering life.</P> <P>It’s believed Doss isn’t a Department of National Defence employee, Aitken said.</P> <P>She said police don’t know why Doss is in Winnipeg.</P> <P>He arrived in the city a few weeks ago but it appears he has no family or ties here, she said.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 7-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Joyride in allegedly stolen truck prompts closure of Winnipeg airport runway
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>WINNIPEG _ Winnipeg police have laid a trio of charges against a 22-year-old Montreal man accused of driving a stolen pick-up truck on to a runway at Richardson International Airport early Wednesday morning. </P> <P>Police say the vehicle was driven toward a Beechcraft King Aircraft, which was departing with cargo and three passengers around 5:15 a.m. </P> <P>The plane completed its take-off without incident while the truck followed down the runway behind the airborne plane. </P> <P>Airport security then appeared on the scene and stopped the vehicle, which was registered to the Department of National Defence. </P> <P>Christine Alongi, spokeswoman for the Winnipeg Airports Authority, said an Air Canada plane carrying more than 100 passengers lifted off just minutes previously on its way to Toronto. </P> <P>She said there was no other aircraft movement for nearly three hours afterwards. </P> <P>NAV Canada, which is responsible for the air and ground movement on the airfield, would have redirected aircraft if it detected any danger, she said. </P> <P>"There was never any danger to the passengers on either of those flights,'' she said. </P> <P>The accused faces charges of theft over $5,000, damaging or interfering with a navigation facility and mischief endangering life. </P>

--30--

Title: 8-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Horses survive highway crash ; Trailer flipped on Trans-Canada
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It turns out horses have nine lives, too. </P> <P>Four horses survived when the trailer they were being transported in flipped on a highway east of Winnipeg on Wednesday evening, RCMP say. </P> <P>Police said the rollover occurred on the west side of the Red River Floodway bridge on the Trans-Canada Highway near Provincial Road 207. </P> <P>Tire blew </P> <P>An eastbound 2006 GMC truck, pulling the trailer and horses, went off the highway, resulting in the truck and trailer overturning. The driver told RCMP one of the truck's front tires blew, causing him to lose control of the vehicle, which entered the ditch. </P> <P>Police said the driver was travelling to Quebec. </P> <P>All four horses survived. One escaped the damaged trailer and was found grazing nearby. The other three were trapped. Firefighters used the Jaws of Life to free them. </P> <P>The horses were taken to a nearby ranch. </P> <P>The truck's occupants, a 55-year-old man and 41-year-old woman from Alberta, suffered minor injuries, RCMP said. </P> <P>Speed and alcohol aren't considered factors. The investigation continues. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 9-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Back to school driver’s checklist to help keep kids safe
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>CNW - It’s back to school time and our roads will be busy again with school buses, a higher volume of children walking on the road and parents picking up and dropping off in school zones. Drivers need to be cautious and take extra care on the road. As drivers, we can affect pedestrian safety and reduce child pedestrian injury by how we act and react behind the wheel.</P> <P>In Canada, more children acquire pedestrian-related injuries in the months of September and October and the most frequently reported child pedestrian action that results in injury or death is crossing at an intersection followed by running onto the road 1.</P> <P>Young Drivers of Canada President Peter Christianson explains, “Younger children often lack the cognitive and physical skills to make safe decisions. In Canada, children aged 10 to 14 years have the highest incidence of pedestrian-related injuries, but a larger age range of children (5 to 14 years) are at the greatest risk for pedestrian-related fatalities. As drivers, we can predict and prevent these collisions by driving defensively.”</P> <P>Drivers can use this road safety checklist to help navigate this busy back to school time on the road:<BR>•Be aware of school zone signage.<BR>•Reduce speed in school zones.<BR>•Wait for children to complete their crossing before proceeding - (they often change their minds).<BR>•Stop at least 20 metres behind a school bus when the upper red lights begin to flash and wait until the flashing stops.<BR>•Motorists traveling in both directions must stop for a school bus except if the road is divided by a median.<BR>•Be prepared! School buses stop at all railway crossings and are required to open their door but are not required to use the upper flashing red lights so there is not the usual warning.<BR>•If you are driving children to school, drop them off in a safe area away from traffic - most schools have designated drop off zones.<BR>•Change lanes early for bicycles (they should be treated as another vehicle by giving them ample space). Be vigilant many kids ride skateboards, scooters or roller blades on the road so be prepared for a possible fall by providing extra space.<BR>•Use the ground viewing technique to scan under parked cars for the feet of children approaching traffic.<BR>•Always leave plenty of time to get to your destination - running late can cause aggressive driving behaviours.<BR>•Avoid driver distractions such as cell phones, eating or drinking, and personal grooming which take your focus off the road.<BR>For more information on driving tips visit the Young Drivers of Canada website at <A href="http://www.youngdrivers.com/">http://www.youngdrivers.com/</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driving home the back to school road safety message  RCMP remind motorists and pedestrians about exercising caution to cope with all forms of increased traffic
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A new school year is fast approaching with students returning for the fall term in the Prairie Rose School Division this coming Wednesday, Sept. 8.</P> <P>And along with going to classes and hitting the books it’s also time for motorists and pedestrians to prepare for the increased traffic involving regular vehicles, school buses, students in school zones, crosswalks, on the highways and in neighbourhoods.</P> <P>‘More kids out there’<BR>“It’s that time of year when we’re going to see a lot more kids out there,” said Carman Area RCMP Const. Mike Nakonechny. “People are just encouraged to keep being careful and realize there’s going to be a lot more [vehicle and pedestrian] traffic on the roads.”</P> <P>He added with harvest wrapping up, there may also be additional traffic on the highways as farmers may be moving their farm equipment when necessary from field-to-field or to return home.</P> <P>CAA Manitoba’s Liz Peters agreed, noting it can be an especially dangerous time if drivers and pedestrians don’t pay enough attention to road safety.</P> <P>Stressing caution<BR>“Kids are unpredictable to motorists on the best of days – darting into traffic and often failing to look both ways before crossing the street,” Liz Peters, Public and Government Affairs Manager for CAA Manitoba said in a prepared statement. “Add to that the fact that going back to school, kids are with friends and going to be excited, and drivers definitely will need to have a heightened sense of awareness as they pass through school zones.”</P> <P>CAA Manitoba offers the following basic tips for back to school road safety:<BR>• follow the speed limit. School zone speed limits are purposefully set low. Children are unpredictable and may have difficulty gauging the distance and speed of an approaching vehicle.<BR>• look for school safety patrollers, they’re a sure sign you’re approaching a school zone.<BR>• come to a complete stop at intersections with stop signs. Research shows that more than one third of drivers roll through stop signs in school zones or neighbourhoods.<BR>• always stop for loading or unloading school buses. It may be tempting to drive around stopped school buses, but not only is it dangerous, it’s against the law.<BR>• eliminate driver distraction. Research shows that taking your eyes off the road for two seconds doubles your chances of crashing.<BR>• plan ahead and eave early for your destination and build in extra time for congestion. Modify your route to avoid school zones and traffic.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MY PERSPECTIVE: Do you feel safer?
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It’s been just over a month since the province banned drivers from using handheld electronic devices while driving. Do you feel safer? According to further research if you do, you shouldn’t.</P> <P>On July 15, the cell phone ban came into effect in Manitoba. When the law, which bans talking on hand-held electronic devices and texting while driving, was announced, we were told that the changes would improve road safety.</P> <P>The fine for texting or talking on a hand-held device is just under $200.</P> <P>In the Province’s announcement, RCMP Insp. Mark LeMaistre of the Manitoba Association of Chiefs of Police, said, “There’s a direct connection between use of electronic devices and dangerous driving, study after study has shown that drivers who talk or text on a hand-held electronic devices while operating a motor vehicle significantly increased their crash risk. In an effort to improve road safety and healthy living, the province has legislated two new laws that take effect today.”</P> <P>Everyone knows driving while distracted is dangerous, and few would argue against improving the safety of our roads. The problem is that laws such as this only really offer the appearance of making our roads safer.</P> <P>So, while you can’t talk on your phone when the phone is held to your head, you can still make all the phone calls you want with a hands-free device. While this means you still have two hands on the wheel (assuming the hand that would be holding your phone isn’t now holding a hamburger, coffee, ice cream or tube of lipstick), the research seems to show that the dangerous distraction is the conversation, not holding a phone.</P> <P>A frequently referenced University of Utah academic study from 2006 found talking on a cell phone reduced driver attentiveness in many important ways and that “both hand-held and hands-free cell phone conversations impaired driving. There were no significant differences in the impairments caused by these two modes of cellular communication”.</P> <P>A U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) report observed there is a “general delay in information processing and degradations in driving performance regardless of mobile phone platform-hand-held or hands-free”. This conclusion is shared by the Insurance Bureau of Canada. The science behind the hands free ban was dealt another blow in March when the U.S. National Safety Council said bans on hand-held phones “give the false impression that using a hands-free phone is safe”.</P> <P>But there’s more bad news for those hoping for safer roads, the NHTSA found that since using a hands-free device is more comfortable and less cumbersome than holding a phone to your head, drivers who use hands-free phones tend to talk longer and more frequently.</P> <P>Banning the use of hand-held cell phones has other unforeseen effects on driver safety. First of all, when a cell phone now rings, if the driver has a hands-free set, they must fumble with their ear piece, put it on and then answer the call. How many lanes of traffic have they swerved into with this manoeuvre? If they don’t have a hands-free set, the driver must now look at the phone and decide on the call’s importance. If the call is important, they must then distractedly and hurriedly pull over to the side of the road and answer their phone.</P> <P>How many people have noticed an increase in the number of vehicles pulled over on the side of the road? This is a hazard in its own right as other drivers are paying more attention to the car at the side of the road wondering things like “Is the driver is in distress?”, “Will they open their door into traffic?” or “Do they need assistance?”, instead of paying attention the road.</P> <P>I would argue that banning the use of handheld devices limits the ability of other drivers to proactively ensure their safety. At least before, if you saw the driver had a phone pressed to their head, you knew to give them a little extra room.</P> <P>If the end result of the ban has been only to install a false sense of security for the province’s drivers, I wonder if the real point of the ban was to enrich the government through fines and the electronics industry through the purchase of hands-free devices.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Enough for a passport, but not MPI
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Krista Pace has enough documentation to get a Canadian passport but not enough to get a Manitoba driver's licence. </P> <P>It means Pace, 22, would be able to visit countries around the world and would have no problem crossing the American border, but she won't be able to drive down a Winnipeg street. </P> <P>She has a licence to nil. </P> <P>"It's frustrating," said Pace on Friday after receiving the runaround from Manitoba Public Insurance staff when she tried beginning the process to get her first driver's licence about a year and a half after moving here from Alberta. </P> <P>"I'm 22 and I want to get a driver's licence, but they say you don't have enough identification. I thought all I needed was my Alberta identification card, my birth certificate and my Manitoba Health card, but they said I can't use the identification card." </P> <P>To make matters worse for Pace, an MPI clerk explained she would need a guarantor to sign, vouching for her identity. </P> <P>"She suggested I go to a doctor to sign as my guarantor. I did and they said they haven't known me more than two years," Pace said. </P> <P>"Other people she said I could go to were a judge or politician -- I don't know the mayor or a member of Parliament. I don't hang out with doctors. </P> <P>"The MPI person also said I could fly back to Alberta and go to one of my doctors. I don't have the money to fly back to Alberta to get a piece of paper signed. </P> <P>"Then she said I could get a passport. My Alberta card could allow me to get a passport, but not a driver's licence." </P> <P>Looking at MPI's website, there is a list of acceptable documents to prove each part of your identity -- including birth date, legal name, photograph and Manitoba residency. </P> <P>The list does not include the Alberta card, but does include out-of-province driving permits, marriage certificates, utility bills, mortgage documents and refugee protection claimant documents. And looking at the list of guarantors, MPI will accept forms signed by judges, police officers, mayors, lawyers, doctors, dentists or accountants. </P> <P>It's pretty much the same list the Canadian government used to require people obtain to sign to get a Canadian passport before it was changed to allow anyone with a valid passport to sign a person's passport application. </P> <P>The irony is, looking at the Alberta driver's licence website, if Pace still lived there, she could once again try getting a driver's licence because that province's identification card can be used as proof of who you are. </P> <P>MPI spokesman Jack Marquardson said the rules are clear. </P> <P>"We're trying to ensure the person is the person before they get a driver's licence," he said. </P> <P>Marquardson said if the identification card is not on MPI's list of approved cards, it is unacceptable for getting a driver's licence. </P> <P>"I checked with others in MPI and they say this really hasn't been an issue - - people are able to get what they need and proceed to get their driver's licence." </P> <P>Andrew Swan, minister responsible for MPI, could not be reached for comment. Last month, when it was learned that thousands of people were being left on hold trying to book driver's tests, Swan waded in to get MPI to fix the problem within days. </P> <P>But there may be a headlight in the tunnel for Pace. </P> <P>Marquardson said he wants to hook Pace up on Tuesday with a MPI executive to see if they can figure out what she needs to get a licence.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Smarten up, slow down as kids return to school
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Police are asking parents, kids and drivers to smarten up and slow down because rush hour is about to get a lot heavier and more dangerous as children head back to school this week. </P> <P>"Traffic intensity is going to increase significantly, along with the likelihood of collisions occurring," said Winnipeg Police Service spokesman Const. Jason Michalyshen. </P> <P>"They can be prevented with some simple things," he said Monday. "Like lower your speed. If you lower your speed by 10 kilometres an hour... you've increased your ability to stop in time if someone jumps out in front of you." </P> <P>With more people returning to work from summer vacation and children returning to class, roads and intersections will be more crowded and potentially dangerous, he said. </P> <P>"People need to be reminded about school zones." </P> <P>The police are advising parents and school kids to get into a routine that's safe. If your child walks to school, walk with your child several times to familiarize them with the route and point out traffic hazards and situations to avoid. As the distance from home to school increases, so does the risk of encountering traffic safety hazards, police said. </P> <P>"It's really important that people familiarize young kids, and that adults are talking to their children: This is a good route. This, maybe, isn't." </P> <P>Drivers need to be mindful of children in the area and pay particular attention near schools, since children could dart from between vehicles at any time. Around crosswalks, drivers need to make sure their vehicles remain stopped until pedestrians have safely crossed the intersection. </P> <P>Michalyshen said there are a few trouble spots near schools that come to mind. The crosswalk at Balmoral Street near Sister MacNamara School in the inner city and on Laxdal Road in Charleswood near Royal School are two busy crosswalks that have been a safety concern. </P> <P>"Central and suburban areas -- there are no boundaries where congestion and things can happen." </P> <P>Police are urging parents to teach their kids when and where it is safest to cross, and to follow the instruction of school patrols. </P> <P>"As pedestrians -- children and adults -- whether it's a controlled intersection or just a basic crosswalk, before you step out on the roadway" make sure the traffic is stopping, Michalyshen said. </P> <P>"Make eye contact with the driver of the vehicle coming your way -- extending your arm out. You don't have to make it a dramatic thing, just some indicator you're attempting to cross." </P> <P>Until you've made eye contact, don't assume the driver will stop. "You never know -- you could be obstructed by signs or other vehicles on the roadway." </P> <P>Children should visually scan potentially dangerous areas such as parking lots and driveways for vehicles. </P> <P>Michalyshen said he's seen people running across busy roadways when there's a controlled crosswalk or traffic lights less than six metres away. </P> <P>"Take the extra two or three minutes," he advised. </P>

--30--

Title: 14-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sunflashes Column: Rain a factor in collision
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Rain-slicked pavement is seen by police as a likely factor in a head-on highway crash in the RM of St. Clements Wednesday that seriously injured at least four people. </P> <P>Two of the victims -- a 16-year-old girl and a man in his early 20s -- remained in hospital on Thursday, said RCMP spokesman Const. Miles Hiebert. </P> <P>An RCMP collision analyst is probing the crash, which involved a 2006 Ford pickup truck and a 1996 Ford Escort, driven by a 15-year-old girl from Winnipeg. Hiebert said it's unclear whether she has a graduated driver's licence. </P> <P>Hiebert said it's uncertain whether charges will be laid. Speed might also have played a role in the crash, RCMP said, but alcohol did not. </P>

--30--

Title: 15-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Paraplegic ordered to pay road-rage fine after ramming car
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>SELKIRK -- A Manitoba paraplegic who made international headlines after surviving a violent attack in Australia in March was the guilty party Friday when he was fined $1,100 for a road rage conviction. </P> <P>Heath Proden, 36, was in court on a charge of dangerous operation of a motor vehicle stemming from a November 2009 incident. </P> <P>Proden told court he'd been driving inappropriately when another driver pulled in front of him on a Winnipeg street. </P> <P>He was accused of ramming the small car with his 2008 Chrysler van, before causing it to swerve off the road and threatening the driver. There were no injuries in the incident. </P> <P>"I have no excuse for my actions," Proden said. "I believe I should have slowed down." </P> <P>Proden -- who appeared in court with his Australian fiance, Kristin Sharrock -- must pay the $1,100 fine and $152 in other costs. </P> <P>Proden was visiting Sharrock in Sydney when he was viciously stomped and beaten with metal bars while waiting for a late-night train. Two teenage boys were later charged. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 16-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Driver fined $1,100 for road-rage incident
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>SELKIRK -- He's a Manitoba paraplegic who survived a cowardly attack in Australia this March that made international headlines. </P> <P>In court here Friday, though, Heath Proden was the guilty party in a road rage incident. </P> <P>Proden, 36, was fined $1,100 for the dangerous operation of a motor vehicle in November 2009. </P> <P>He appeared in court with his Australian fiance, Kristin Sharrock. </P> <P>He was visiting her earlier this year in Sydney when he was viciously stomped and beaten with metal bars while waiting for a late-night train. </P> <P>The beating was captured on surveillance video and broadcast around the world. Police arrested and charged two teenage boys. </P> <P>Proden, who appeared to be in good health Friday, told a judge he'd been driving inappropriately when another driver pulled in front of him on a Winnipeg street. </P> <P>He was accused of ramming the small car with his 2008 Chrysler van, before causing it to swerve off the road and then threatening the driver. </P> <P>The other vehicle's driver recorded Proden's licence plate and later called police, who arrested him. </P> <P>"I have no excuse for my actions," said Proden Friday. </P> <P>"I believe I should have slowed down." </P> <P>However, Proden said his driving was due to mechanical problems with his vehicle, which required a recall. </P> <P>He acknowledged he'd hit the other vehicle but shook his head at accusations that he'd struck the small car several times, and told court the other driver could also have caused a serious collision. </P> <P>Defence lawyer Edwin Sloane said his client had suffered from a case of "road rage," and that Proden followed close behind the small car. </P> <P>"He admits he lost it," he said. </P> <P>Crown Deann Sahulka said the driving was "completely inappropriate and reckless." </P> <P>Court heard he has no prior record and there were no injuries resulting from the incident. </P> <P>He said after the court hearing that, health-wise, he is "doing alright" after the attack. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 17-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Safety reminders for back to school
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It’s that time of year again - back to school time. Canada Safety Council would like to continue to remind parents and guardians to teach your children about safe travel to and from school. Take the time to know the rules and educate your children about safe conduct when using and sharing roadways, whether it be by school bus, car, bicycle or by foot.</P> <P>School bus travel<BR>Research conducted by Travel Canada shows that school bus travel is one of the safest methods of transportation. It is 16 times safer than travelling in a family car per passenger/kilometre of travel. Although school buses have an excellent safety record, mishaps can happen. These mishaps can include instances where children are injured while riding on the bus. It is more common, however, for injuries to be sustained once outside the bus, including being hit by their own school bus or other vehicles. On average, bus drivers say that about three cars go through their stop sign each day.</P> <P>Parents and guardians should know that they are responsible for their children until they step on to the bus and immediately after they exit the bus. An adult should always be there to send off young passengers and to greet them, on the same side of the street where children exit the bus.</P> <P>Here are some safety tips to share with children to ensure safe travel:<BR>Getting to and on the bus:<BR>1. Arrive at the bus stop at least five minutes before the scheduled pick up time. Children should never run after the school bus to try to catch it. If you miss the bus, go back home or if you are at school, report to a teacher.<BR>2. Stay on the sidewalk, well away from the roadway and stay back until the bus has come to a full stop and the door opens.<BR>3. If you child needs to cross the street, teach them to look to the left, then to the right and to the left once more before crossing the street.<BR>4. Use the handrail when boarding or exiting the bus.</P> <P>Riding on the school bus:<BR>5. Take a seat as quickly as possible, put belongings under the seat and stay seated.<BR>6. Never stick anything out of the window, including arms or heads.<BR>7. Save food for snack time at school or until you get home.<BR>8. Wait until the school bus comes to a complete stop before getting off.<BR>9. When getting off the bus: take two large steps away from the bus. If you must walk in front of the bus, walk ahead at least three metres (10 giant steps).<BR>10. The driver must be able to see you and will give a signal when it is safe to cross. Cross in a single file.</P> <P>Travel by car<BR>Parents and guardians must respect their child’s school safety measures for dropping off and picking up their children at school. Every effort must be made to avoid collision and injury by refraining to create hazardous situations of traffic congestion and unsafe driving practices within the school zone. Respect posted speed limits, and designated drop-off and pick-up areas.</P> <P>To ensure safe cycling, you cyclists must:<BR>1. Wear a properly-fitted helmet and have clothes that are suited for cycling (e.g. their pants tucked in).<BR>2. Have their bikes fitted properly and in good working order.<BR>3. Know and obey all traffic rules, signs and signals. They must signal turns and stops. Ride in a straight line in the same direction as traffic and stop at every<BR>stop sign.<BR>4. Be predictable to other road users by riding with the traffic usually on the right hand side of the roadway.<BR>5. Never ride in the dark. If an older child must ride in the dark, make sure that reflective clothing and night-accessories (e.g. reflectors and lights) are used.</P> <P>Walking to school<BR>Many children use roadways to make their way to and from school. Parents and guardians must review road safety rules with their children and the importance of not accepting rides or any invitations from strangers. It is best to walk with a buddy and keep focused on getting straight home.</P> <P>To keep safe on roads, pedestrians must:<BR>1. Find a safe and direct route to school with the help of their parents. Hazards should be identified (train tracks, busy intersections, etc.) and a designated route with safety rules should be established.<BR>2. Stay on sidewalks whenever possible. If there is no sidewalk, use the left side of the road facing traffic.<BR>3. Cross streets only at crosswalks and learn to look to the left, the right and then left again before proceeding, even at intersections with pedestrian walk signs.<BR>4. Wait until traffic comes to a stop before crossing. Make sure drivers see you before you cross.</P> <P>Prevention is the key to safety. With education and awareness, all children should be able to get safely to school and home again. Take the time to share these valuable rules and tips with your children.</P>

--30--

Title: 18-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Back to school checklist to help keep kids safe
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>CNW - It’s back to school time and our roads will be busy again with school buses, a higher volume of children walking on the road and parents picking up and dropping off in school zones. Drivers need to be cautious and take extra care on the road. As drivers, we can affect pedestrian safety and reduce child pedestrian injury by how we act and react behind the wheel.</P> <P>In Canada, more children acquire pedestrian-related injuries in the months of September and October and the most frequently reported child pedestrian action that results in injury or death is crossing at an intersection followed by running onto the road 1.</P> <P>Young Drivers of Canada President Peter Christianson explains, “Younger children often lack the cognitive and physical skills to make safe decisions. In Canada, children aged 10 to 14 years have the highest incidence of pedestrian-related injuries, but a larger age range of children (5 to 14 years) are at the greatest risk for pedestrian-related fatalities. As drivers, we can predict and prevent these collisions by driving defensively.”</P> <P>Drivers can use this road safety checklist to help navigate this busy back to school time on the road:<BR>•Reduce speed in school zones.<BR>•Wait for children to complete their crossing before proceeding - (they often change their minds).<BR>•Stop at least 20 metres behind a school bus when the upper red lights begin to flash and wait until the flashing stops.<BR>•Motorists traveling in both directions must stop for a school bus except if the road is divided by a median.<BR>•Be prepared! School buses stop at all railway crossings and are required to open their door but are not required to use the upper flashing red lights so there is not the usual warning.<BR>•If you are driving children to school, drop them off in a safe area away from traffic – most schools have designated drop off zones.<BR>•Be vigilant many kids ride skateboards, scooters or roller blades on the road so be prepared for a possible fall by providing extra space.<BR>•Use the ground viewing technique to scan under parked cars for the feet of children approaching traffic.<BR>•Always leave plenty of time to get to your destination - running late can cause aggressive driving behaviours.</P> <P>For more information on driving tips visit the Young Drivers of Canada website at <A href="http://www.youngdrivers.com">www.youngdrivers.com</A></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Unverified stats of the day: Student pedestrians are at risk
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Oooh, it just burns me up when I see press releases cross my desk that make up fancy claims based on statistics that don't even stand up to the slightest of scrutiny. </P> <P>Just moments ago, I got one of them from Manitoba Public Insurance. "Young Children involved in most school-age car/pedestrian collisions" the headline trumpets. </P> <P>Here's the first two paragraphs: </P> <P>Children aged five to 14 accounted for the majority of school-aged pedestrians injured in Manitoba, according to Manitoba Public Insurance data. </P> <P>The data reported that this age group made up six of every 10 school-age victims of car/pedestrian collisions in the province. In total, there are 48 pedestrians from this age group injured each year in Manitoba, said Clif Eden, Manager of Road Safety, Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>Oh, really? The press release doesn't define "school-age" but you can reasonably assume that it means up the end of grade school, or about 18. </P> <P>Well, of course the number of people between the ages of five and 14 -- a 10-year span -- is greater than those in the three years between the ages of 16 and 18. So obviously you'd expect there to be more of the younger ones injured. Add in the fact that some number of 16-year-olds get cars, and the press release could equally claim the opposite: that it is older students who make up a wildly disproportionate amount of pedestrian injuries. </P> <P>Now, obviously I don't want any students -- or any pedestrians, really -- to get hit by cars. And reminding drivers to be on the lookout for pedestrians is great. </P> <P>But the whole press release reeks of phoniness: </P> <P>“Many of these pedestrians were hit while going to, or returning from school,” said Eden. “Manitoba drivers need to focus on making the roads safer and re-familiarizing themselves with safe driving tips as students head back to school.” </P> <P>The return of students results in a dramatic increase in pedestrian activity in many neighbourhoods. </P> <P>Perhaps "many" of them were hit while going to and from school -- but how many? And I doubt there's any real hard data on this "dramatic increase." In fact, since students are about to spend the next 10 months locked up in a classroom for eight hours a day, instead of wandering about the neighbourhoods and scampering around in yards and parks. it's plausible that the number of young pedestrians will actually go down! </P> <P>More from the press release: </P> <P>Many students also travel to school on their bicycle. One in four cyclists struck by cars in Manitoba are five to 19 years old, according to MPI data. On average, 60 school-aged cyclists are hit each year by a vehicle. </P> <P>Oh my goodness! </P> <P>But ... I wonder how many of those bike accidents happen during peak school months, like November through February, and how many might actually happen during July and August, when back-to-school would have nothing to do with it? </P> <P>Again, don't get me wrong. I applaud MPI for trying to keep pedestrians safe. And there are definitely some young kids out there who might be walking to school for the first time, and not always remembering to look both ways before crossing the street. </P> <P>But the numbers? They just don't add up. And I didn't even take high-school stats</P>

--30--

Title: 20-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Stolen truck leads Dauphin police on high-speed chase
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Dauphin police say a stolen truck that led them on a high-speed chase might be connected to a stolen car that was also found in the area. The driver of the stolen truck, which slid into the ditch during the pursuit, was arrested and faces numerous charges. </P> <P>On Saturday, Sept. 4 at around 6:30 p.m., officers from the Dauphin Municipal RCMP detachment clocked a pickup truck on radar at 135 km/h in an 80 km/h zone, just east of the city limits on Highway 20. The officers attempted to stop the truck but the driver refused to stop. A brief pursuit ensued which led onto some gravel municipal roads. The driver lost control of the truck and slid into a ditch. He and his passenger then fled on foot into the nearby bush. </P> <P>Shortly afterwards the two men ran from the bush and were arrested. Shortly after the pursuit started, it was learned that the truck had been stolen just before from a home on Jessie Street in Dauphin. </P> <P>Around the same time, another officer came across a car which had gone off the road and struck a hydro pole. This car had been stolen from Southport, Manitoba the previous day. The investigation into these thefts continues and police believe the two are related. </P> <P>Wade Andrew Tyler Mousseau, 20, of no fixed address, has been charged with a number of criminal charges including dangerous driving, impaired driving, flight from police and possession of stolen property. He has been remanded in custody to appear in Dauphin court today.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 21-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man accused after chase by cops
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>RCMP in Dauphin have charged a 20-year-old man who allegedly led officers on a high-speed pursuit in a stolen truck Saturday. </P> <P>The suspect was allegedly intoxicated and driving impaired. </P> <P>Mounties said the ordeal began when officers clocked a pickup truck travelling 135 km/h in an 80-km/h zone just east of Dauphin on Highway 20. </P> <P>The driver refused to stop for the officers, resulting in a brief pursuit on to gravel roads. The pursuit ended when the driver lost control of the truck and it slid into a ditch. </P> <P>RCMP said two occupants ran into the bush but soon ran out of it and were arrested. </P> <P>fie truck was stolen from a home on Jessie Street in Dauphin, RCMP said. </P> <P>Around the same time police found a car, reported stolen in Southport near Portage la Prairie, which crashed into a hydro pole. RCMP believe the same suspects are responsible. </P> <P>RCMP said Wade Andrew Tyler Mousseau, 20, of no fixed address is charged with dangerous driving, impaired driving, flight from police, and possession of stolen property, among other things. </P>

--30--

Title: 22-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: 2 killed in northern Manitoba crash
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Two people died in northern Manitoba after their pickup truck crashed and rolled several times, striking a large steel highway sign in the process.</P> <P>According to the RCMP, the truck was northbound on Highway 10 in Cranberry Portage when the driver lost control at about 4 a.m. on Saturday.</P> <P>The vehicle left the road, rolling into the ditch.</P> <P>The two occupants, a 32-year-old woman and a 28-year-old man, were thrown from the vehicle and found by emergency personnel, police said.</P> <P>The woman was pronounced dead at the scene. The man was rushed to hospital in Flin Flon where he died a short time later.</P> <P>Both people were from Flin Flon but their names are being withheld pending notification of next of kin.</P> <P>Neither one was wearing a seatbelt and speed is considered to be a factor in the incident, police said.</P> <P>Police continue to investigate.</P> <P>No further information is available at this time.</P> <P>Cranberry Portage is about 700 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/07/mb-crash-fatal-manitoba.html#ixzz0ywUSxx11">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/07/mb-crash-fatal-manitoba.html#ixzz0ywUSxx11</A></P>

--30--

Title: 23-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Kids, cars, congestion coming to a school zone near you
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>As thousands of Manitoba children get ready to start the 2010-2011 school year, CAA Manitoba reminds motorists to be aware of increased child pedestrian activity and traffic congestion in and around neighborhoods and school zones. With more than half of all students in elementary school, typically age 14 and younger, CAA urges motorists to be especially cautious and alert during the morning and afternoon hours. </P> <P>With the start of the school season, CAA also welcomes to duty a new complement of School Safety Patrollers to watch over their peers on their way to and from school each day, but patrollers can only do so much.</P> <P>“Kids are unpredictable to motorists on the best of days – darting into traffic and often failing to look both ways before crossing the street,” Liz Peters, public and government affairs manager for CAA Manitoba says. “Add to that the fact that going back to school, kids are with friends and going to be excited, and drivers definitely will need to have a heightened sense of awareness as they pass through school zones.”</P> <P>Peters offers the following advice for motorists to help keep kids safe on their way to school:</P> <P>Follow the speed limit. School zone speed limits are purposefully set low. Children are unpredictable and may have difficulty gauging the distance and speed of an approaching car.</P> <P>Look for CAA School Safety Patrollers. With more than 10,000 CAA School Safety Patrollers at more than 275 schools in Manitoba, they’re a sure sign you’re approaching a school zone.</P> <P>Come to a complete stop at intersections with stop signs. Research shows that more than one third of drivers roll through stop signs in school zones or neighborhoods.</P> <P>Always stop for loading or unloading school busses. It may be tempting to drive around stopped school busses, but not only is it dangerous, it’s against the law.</P> <P>Eliminate driver distraction. Research shows that taking your eyes off the road for two seconds doubles your chances of crashing. Putting down your phone makes you a safer driver and sets a good example for young passengers and pedestrians.</P> <P>Plan Ahead. Leave early for your destination and build in extra time for congestion. Modify your route to avoid school zones and traffic.</P> <P>CAA Manitoba is a member based organization, representing more than 190,000 Manitobans. For more than 100 years, CAA Manitoba has offered first-rate Emergency Roadside Services, and in recent years, has expanded to also offer travel options and insurance services. During that time, we have advocated on behalf of Manitobans, addressing the issues that matter most to the people in our province.</P>

--30--

Title: 24-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man killed in crash ; Head-on collision near Anola
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One man is dead and another was in critical condition Wednesday after two vehicles collided head-on just west of Anola. </P> <P>RCMP said a 2004 Chevrolet Cavalier and 2008 Honda Civic collided at 9:45 a.m. about two kilometres outside of Anola on Highway 15. </P> <P>The driver of the Civic, a 35-year-old man from La Broquerie, Man., was pronounced dead at the scene. Mounties believe his vehicle was eastbound at the time of the accident. </P> <P>The 52-year-old driver of the Cavalier, a Winnipeg resident, was taken by ambulance to hospital in Winnipeg in critical condition. </P> <P>Crews from Springfield Fire and Rescue were among the first to arrive on scene. </P> <P>The scene was strewn with debris from the vehicles Wednesday as the cars sat wrecked on either shoulder of the undivided highway awaiting tow trucks. </P> <P>The silver Civic sustained extremely heavy damage and the roof appeared to have been cut away by first responders to extricate its driver. </P> <P>RCMP collision analysts worked at the scene for several hours before the highway, also known as Dugald Road, was reopened in the early afternoon. </P> <P>Oakbank-Beausejour RCMP Sgt. Stu Evans said neither alcohol nor speed appeared to be factors in the crash. </P> <P>"It's still early in the investigation, however it does appears driver fatigue may have been one of the conditions of this accident," Evans said. </P> <P>The crash occur red 50 metres east of a roadside memorial for Nicole Dykun, a 21-year-old who was killed in a head-on collision there in August 2006. </P> <P>Eric St. Pierre, 44, a resident of the Anola area at the time, pleaded guilty last January to dangerous driving causing death in the accident that claimed Dykun's life. He was sentenced to 18 months of house arrest. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 25-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: La Broquerie man dies in head-on crash near Anola
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 35-year-old man from La Broquerie is dead and another driver is in critical condition after a head-on collision Wednesday morning on Highway 15 near Anola. </P> <P>The crash happened at about 9:45 a.m., about two kilometres west of Anola, said RCMP spokesman Const. Miles Hiebert. </P> <P>The man from La Broquerie, driving a 2008 Honda Civic, was pronounced dead at the scene. His name has not been released. The driver of a 2004 Chevrolet Cavalier, a 52-year-old man from Winnipeg, was taken to hospital in critical condition. </P> <P>The cause of the collision is under investigation. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 26-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Manitoba drivers are rude, selfish
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The legend on the province's licence plates reads "Friendly Manitoba. " It's an excellent slogan. It both reflects an attitude and suggests how Manitobans should behave. </P> <P>Like all good slogans, it has a central truth. Manitobans are friendly. In part, this is because of the phenomenon the late Carol Shields portrayed so well in her novels, that much of the province is a "cradle to grave society." </P> <P>Manitoba is a place where the expression "small world" works over and over again. People have known each other since kindergarten. In Manitoba it is easy to find connections between people. You know someone who knows someone and so on. </P> <P>This type of friendliness born of familiarity is reflected in our politics and business. Politicians from differing parties have often known each other for years. There's a civility to our dealings that comes from being a relatively small, isolated community where families have stayed for generations. It is what Manitobans often say they like about living here. </P> <P>The irony of the licence plate slogan is that all friendliness seems to disappear when Manitobans, and particularly Winnipeggers, get in their cars. </P> <P>Driving in Winnipeg is not an exercise in friendliness; on the contrary, it's an exercise in downright selfish rudeness. The Winnipeg driving experience is so different from Manitobans' general civil behaviour to be quite remarkable -- and it's getting worse. </P> <P>I expected the introduction of radar cameras at intersections designed to capture and fine drivers running red lights would result in far fewer people taking the risk. </P> <P>No such luck. </P> <P>What may have happened is that drivers have learned which lights they can run and where they can run lights with impunity. Certainly the red-light cameras have not led to any increase in driver civility. </P> <P>On my morning run, I cross a major intersection with traffic lights that allow for left turns only in either direction. The left turn option doesn't last long. As it ends, the green pedestrian light comes on to allow safe crossing for those on foot. Several times cars have still been making their left turns, travelling at speed, after the pedestrian single has changed to the "don't walk" sign. </P> <P>Why do drivers risk pedestrian lives in this way? Why do they pull out of back lanes and driveways without looking for runners or walkers? Why is it so difficult to change lanes in Winnipeg? </P> <P>I have long pondered these questions. Winnipeg is one of the most difficult cities to drive in that I have ever encountered, and I am including Toronto, Vancouver and Minneapolis as comparisons. </P> <P>The reason, I think, is because Winnipeggers have not adapted to driving in what has become big city traffic. They don't see the big picture. Their intent is to get themselves to where they are going as quickly as possible. If this means moving to block a car trying to get into the lane they are in, so be it. If it means blocking an intersection rather than waiting for the next traffic light change, then, in many Winnipeggers' minds, that will get them to their destination faster than if they make the friendly, civil gesture and wait. </P> <P>As a result, Winnipeg's traffic becomes snarled up far more than it needs to. How often do you see cars blocked behind parked vehicles as drivers in the adjacent lane fail to let them in? How friendly is that? </P> <P>This beggar-my-neighbour attitude is why many Winnipeggers dislike driving in bigger cities. They assume they won't be able to change busy lanes because other drivers will close up just like they do at home. What they don't understand is that such selfish driving doesn't happen in bigger cities because, if it did, traffic would grind to a standstill. </P> <P>Of course, there are always selfish drivers in every city. But in larger centres, generally, there is an understanding that give and take on the roads gets everyone where they are going faster than trying to gain that extra 15 seconds from every traffic light, turn or lane change. </P> <P>Winnipeggers need to understand their driving circumstances have changed. Selfish driving behaviour is becoming so noticeable that it threatens to make a mockery of the slogan that so well describes Manitobans' behaviour outside their vehicles. </P> <P>It is unlikely increased police vigilance or more radar cameras will change attitudes. What needs to change is the driving culture: an understanding that traffic is now so busy that beating a light or rushing an intersection doesn't really save any time. Improved signage and road markings could help, but what's needed is for drivers to think of what is on their licence plates and act accordingly. </P> <P>Nicholas Hirst is CEO of Winnipeg-based television and film producer Original Pictures Inc. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 27-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Auto glass claims made even easier
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>One call does it all for Manitobans wanting to open an auto glass claim with Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>Effective August 26, Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) introduced a new web application that will enable glass repair facilities to register claims on behalf of customers. </P> <P>The new application, called eGlassClaim, will interface with MPI's claims systems and enable customers to initiate glass claims at the repair shop of their choosing. Under the old system, customers were required to report claims to MPI's Call Centre first. </P> <P>eGlassClaim will also benefit glass repair shops, as it will allow them to submit invoices to MPI electronically and get paid automatically. </P> <P>"This new system will make it easier for both the customer and our business partners in the glass repair industry to do business with MPI," said Marilyn McLaren, President and CEO of Manitoba Public Insurance. "It's a natural progression for us, as we continue to explore new ways to use technology to increase value for our customers." </P> <P>The new process will also reduce the number of calls to MPI's Call Centre for registering routine glass claims, allowing call staff to provide even greater service to other customer's needs. </P> <P>All glass repairers will be invited to participate in the new program but participation in the program is optional, explained McLaren. </P>

--30--

Title: 28-Feb-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Pedestrian collisions: Manitoba Public Insurance
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Students returning to school means more pedestrian/cyclist traffic<BR>Children aged five to 14 accounted for the majority of school-aged pedestrians injured in Manitoba, according to Manitoba Public Insurance data.</P> <P>The data reported that this age group made up six of every 10 school-age victims of car/pedestrian collisions in the province. In total, there are 48 pedestrians from this age group injured each year in Manitoba, said Clif Eden, Manager of Road Safety, Manitoba Public Insurance.</P> <P>“Many of these pedestrians were hit while going to, or returning from school,” said Eden. “Manitoba drivers need to focus on making the roads safer and re-familiarizing themselves with safe driving tips as students head back to school.”</P> <P>The return of students results in a dramatic increase in pedestrian activity in many neighbourhoods. Unfortunately, several thousand Canadian children are hit yearly by motor vehicles while playing outdoors or walking to and from school, said Eden.</P> <P>Many students also travel to school on their bicycle. One in four cyclists struck by cars in Manitoba are five to 19 years old, according to MPI data. On average, 60 school-aged cyclists are hit each year by a vehicle.</P> <P>“Many young children don’t comprehend the dangers associated with crossing a street unsafely,” said Eden. “The onus of responsibility lies with motorists to ensure everyone gets to school safely.”</P> <P>Parents can also take role in reducing vehicle-pedestrian collisions by discussing road safety with their children.</P> <P>To assist with school-zone safety, Manitoba Public Insurance offers to loan out speed reader boards through its School Zone SpeedWatch program, a partnership of the public auto insurer, police agencies throughout the province, the City of Winnipeg Public Works Department and the Manitoba School Boards Association.</P> <P>School or parent groups can borrow the equipment to raise drivers’ awareness of their speeds as they pass through school zones.</P> <P>To avoid a collision, drivers and pedestrians are encouraged to observe the following safety tips:<BR>- Look well ahead to spot school buses and school zone signs; reduce speed in school zones, and wait for children to cross completely before proceeding.<BR>- If you are driving your children to school, drop them off in a safe area, away from traffic; use a designated drop-off zone if the school has one.<BR>- Stop at least five metres behind a school bus when the upper red lights begin to flash, and do not proceed until the “stop sign” is closed and the red lights stop flashing. Motorists travelling in both directions must stop for the school bus, except if the road is divided by a median.<BR>- Scan under parked cars for the feet of children approaching traffic, and make lane changes early to allow room for children on bicycles, skateboards or roller blades.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 1-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Safety reminders for back to school
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>It’s that time of year again - back to school time. Canada Safety Council would like to continue to remind parents and guardians to teach your children about safe travel to and from school. Take the time to know the rules and educate your children about safe conduct when using and sharing roadways, whether it be by school bus, car, bicycle or by foot.</P> <P>School bus travel<BR>Research conducted by Travel Canada shows that school bus travel is one of the safest methods of transportation. It is 16 times safer than travelling in a family car per passenger/kilometer of travel. Although school buses have an excellent safety record, mishaps can happen. These mishaps can include instances where children are injured while riding on the bus. It is more common, however, for injuries to be sustained once outside the bus, including being hit by their own school bus or other vehicles. On average, bus drivers say that about three cars go through their stop sign each day.</P> <P>Parents and guardians should know that they are responsible for their children until they step on to the bus and immediately after they exit the bus. An adult should always be there to send off young passengers and to greet them, on the same side of the street where children exit the bus.</P> <P>Here are some safety tips to share with children to ensure safe travel:<BR>Getting to and on the bus:<BR>1. Arrive at the bus stop at least five minutes before the scheduled pick up time. Children should never run after the school bus to try to catch it. If you miss the bus, go back home or if you are at school, report to a teacher.<BR>2. Stay on the sidewalk, well away from the roadway and stay back until the bus has come to a full stop and the door opens.<BR>3. If you child needs to cross the street, teach them to look to the left, then to the right and to the left once more before crossing the street.<BR>4. Use the handrail when boarding or exiting the bus.</P> <P>Riding on the school bus:<BR>5. Take a seat as quickly as possible, put belongings under the seat and stay seated.<BR>6. Never stick anything out of the window, including arms or heads.<BR>7. Save food for snack time at school or until you get home.<BR>8. Wait until the school bus comes to a complete stop before getting of.</P> <P>After riding on the school bus:<BR>9. When getting off the bus: take two large steps away from the bus. If you must walk in front of the bus, walk ahead at least three metres (10 giant steps).<BR>10. The driver must be able to see you and will give a signal when it is safe to cross. Cross in a single file.<BR>11. If a child drops something near or under the school bus, they should never attempt to retrieve it without the driver’s permission.</P> <P>Travel by car<BR>Parents and guardians must respect their child’s school safety measures for dropping off and picking up their children at school. Every effort must be made to avoid collision and injury by refraining to create hazardous situations of traffic congestion and unsafe driving practices within the school zone. Respect posted speed limits, and designated drop-off and pick-up areas.</P> <P>To ensure safe cycling, you cyclists must:<BR>1. Wear a properly-fitted helmet and have clothes that are suited for cycling (e.g. their pants tucked in).<BR>2. Have their bikes fitted properly and in good working order. The bike should have a regular maintenance check-up and should have a bell. It is also a good idea to have a safety flag.<BR>3. Know and obey all traffic rules, signs and signals. They must signal turns and stops. Ride in a straight line in the same direction as traffic and stop at every stop sign.<BR>4. Be predictable to other road users by riding with the traffic usually on the right hand side of the roadway.<BR>5. Never ride in the dark. If an older child must ride in the dark, make sure that reflective clothing and night-accessories (e.g. reflectors and lights) are used.</P> <P>Walking to school<BR>Many children use roadways to make their way to and from school. Parents and guardians must review road safety rules with their children and the importance of not accepting rides or any invitations from strangers. It is best to walk with a buddy and keep focused on getting straight home.</P> <P>To keep safe on roads, children pedestrians must:<BR>1. Find a safe and direct route to school with the help of their parents. Hazards should be identified (train tracks, busy intersections, etc.) and a designated route with safety rules should be established.<BR>2. Stay on sidewalks whenever possible. If there is no sidewalk, use the left side of the road facing traffic.<BR>3. Cross streets only at crosswalks and learn to look to the left, the right and then left again before proceeding, even at intersections with pedestrian walk signs.<BR>4. Wait until traffic comes to a stop before crossing. Make sure drivers see you before you cross.</P> <P>Prevention is the key to safety. With education and awareness, all children should be able to get safely to school and home again. Take the time to share these valuable rules and tips with your children.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 2-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Toughest laws in the land; Penalties for certain driving offences about to go up, up, up
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>On Sept. 20 B.C. drivers will face the toughest driving laws in Canada. </P> <P>RCMP Traffic Services say these new laws not only include more immediate sanctions for those who drink and drive, but will also deal with those who think that excessive speeding is OK. </P> <P>In the past, "If you got caught it would sometimes take a year before you went to court, but after Sept. 20 you will feel the consequences immediately," said Sgt. Reinhold Weissbock. </P> <P>Here's what will happen immediately to those who fail a breathalyzer test on the road: Immediate 90-day roadside driving ban; a $500 fine; $250 drivers licence reinstatement fee; responsible drivers program $800; one year ignition interlock $1,730 for a total of at least $4,060. </P> <P>"That does not include a possible criminal charge, legal fees, court-ordered fines or penalties," said Weissbock. </P> <P>Under the new rules, drivers caught speeding more than 40 km over the limit for the first time will have their vehicle impounded for seven days. The penalty increases to 30 days for a second excessive speeding offence, and 60 days for subsequent offences within two years. </P> <P>The new penalties are in addition to the existing penalties for excessive speeding, which include a fine of $368 to $483, three penalty points on the individual's driver's license, and an ICBC driver-risk premium of $320 per year for three years above the Autoplan insurance premiums. </P> <P>"Excessive speed is often a death sentence for everyone involved -- the driver, their passengers and other innocent road-users," Solicitor General and Minister of Public Safety, Mike de Jong, said in a recent news release. </P> <P>"We want to save lives by going after the kind of driver who drives significantly and dangerously over the posted speed limit, and then get them off the road. By doing so, we hope to make our streets and highways safer for everyone." </P> <P>Police in B.C. issue about 10,000 tickets for excessive speeding each year. </P> <P>Ontario imposed new rules in 2007 that allow police to suspend driver's licenses and impound vehicles for seven days in traffic violation cases involving a speed of 50 km or more over the speed limit. The offending driver could also face fines of up to $10,000. </P> <P>Prince Edward Island introduced legislation last April to toughen speeding penalties in the province. Under their new rules, drivers caught speeding in excess of 60 km could have their vehicles impounded for 24 hours. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 3-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Civics collide, leaving woman in serious condition
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 35-year-old woman is in serious but stable condition in a Winnipeg hospital after a two-car crash at a River Heights intersection late Saturday. </P> <P>City police said two Honda Civics collided at Taylor Avenue and Waverley Street at 10 p.m. </P> <P>An eastbound Civic was attempting to turn north onto Waverley when it was struck by a westbound Civic, said police spokeswoman Const. Natalie Aitken. </P> <P>Police said several people were transported to hospital. </P> <P>All but the woman, who suffered upper and lower body injuries, have been discharged, Aitken said. </P> <P>Both vehicles sustained significant damage. </P> <P>The intersection was closed until the central traffic unit concluded its on-scene investigation at 4:30 a.m. </P> <P>No charges have been laid, Aitken said. </P> <P>Police are seeking witnesses to the collision, including the occupants of a sport utility vehicle. </P> <P>Aitken said the westbound vehicle, believed to be black in colour, was stopped in the intersection and was waiting to turn south onto Waverley. </P> <P>Police are asking the vehicle's occupants or any other witnesses to call investigators at 986-6271.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 4-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Man busted after hammer swung at car
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 26-year-old man allegedly tried to strike a motorist's car with a hammer during a possible road rage incident in Winnipeg on Thursday. </P> <P>Police said Winnipeg Fire Paramedic Service members flagged down a passing police car to report the incident as it was in progress. </P> <P>The altercation occurred in the southbound lanes of Lagimodiere Boulevard near Dugald Road about 4:50 p.m. </P> <P>Traffic was at a stop when the driver of a Pontiac Sunfire exited his vehicle and swung a hammer at the back of a Dodge Neon, police said. </P> <P>The driver of the Neon pulled ahead to avoid any damage to his vehicle, so the suspect returned to his car, pulled up beside the victim's car and missed in his second attempt to strike the Neon, police said. </P> <P>The victim drove away. </P> <P><BR>Teen hit by car in St. James </P> <P>A 15-year-old boy was taken to hospital after he was struck by a vehicle in St. James on Friday morning, Winnipeg police say. </P> <P>The collision occurred at Portage Avenue and Ferry Road shortly after 8 a.m. </P> <P>The boy's condition wasn't known but it's believed his injuries weren't life threatening. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 5-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Elderly scooter driver stable after vehicle collision
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>An elderly gentleman who was struck by a vehicle while riding his scooter in North Kildonan early Sunday evening was taken to hospital in stable condition.</P> <P>At about 6:30 pm, a passenger vehicle was turning left from McLeod Avenue onto Henderson Highway, when it struck the scooter, sending the elderly male driver flying out onto the street.</P> <P>Two lanes of southbound Henderson were blocked to traffic at McLeod Avenue for a period of time.</P> <P>Traffic investigators are looking further into the matter.<BR></P>

Title: 6-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Police looking for witness to last night's major accident
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A woman remains in hospital in serious but stable condition after a major two-car accident last night.</P> <P>It happened around 10 p.m. at the corner of Taylor Avenue and Waverly Street.</P> <P>Several people were taken to hospital where all but one were released.</P> <P>Const. Natalie Aitken tells CJOB that police are now looking for the driver of a black SUV who likely witnessed the accident...</P> <P>Anyone who  witnessed the collision are asked to contact the Central Traffic Unit.<BR></P>

Title: 7-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Changes to accident benefits: What it means for drivers;
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>According to a recent RBC Insurance survey, almost half of Ontario drivers (49%) are not aware of the changes to accident benefit coverage limits that came into effect Sept. 1 with Ontario's auto insurance reform. It's important that drivers understand what the changes mean and how it will impact them. </P> <P>"Ontario's basic medical and rehabilitation benefits will remain among the most generous of any province in Canada," said Tim Bzowey, vice-president, home and auto, RBC Insurance. </P> <P>"All auto insurance policies in Ontario will now include standard levels of accident benefits coverage that can help protect drivers financially if they are injured in a car accident. Drivers will also have the ability to tailor their coverage to </P> <P>Time </P> <P>best meet their specific needs." </P> <P>Accident benefits provide coverage for items such as medical and rehabilitation services, attendant care and home maintenance expenses. And while changes to accident benefits coverage will affect minor personal injuries, benefits for serious injuries will not change. </P> <P>"Some Ontarians may already be covered for some risks through their existing employer or private health plans, resulting in a duplication of coverage. Therefore, the standard coverage could be sufficient," added Bzowey. </P> <P>"Everyone's situation is different, so it's important they speak with an insurance advisor to better understand their existing coverage and whether it's adequate for them." </P>

--30--

On average, 60 school-aged cyclists are hit each year by a vehicle.</P> <P>“Many young children don’t comprehend the dangers associated with crossing a street unsafely,” said Eden. “The onus of responsibility lies with motorists to ensure everyone gets to school safely.”</P> <P>Parents can also take role in reducing vehicle-pedestrian collisions by discussing road safety with their children.</P> <P>To assist with school-zone safety, Manitoba Public Insurance offers to loan out speed reader boards through its School Zone SpeedWatch program, a partnership of the public auto insurer, police agencies throughout the province, the City of Winnipeg Public Works Department and the Manitoba School Boards Association. School or parent groups can borrow the equipment to raise drivers’ awareness of their speeds as they pass through school zones.</P> <P>To avoid a collision, drivers and pedestrians are encouraged to observe the following safety tips:<BR>• Look well ahead to spot school buses and school zone signs; reduce speed in school zones, and wait for children to cross completely before<BR>proceeding.<BR>• If you are driving your children to school, drop them off in a safe area, away from traffic; use a designated drop-off zone if the school has one.<BR>• Stop at least five metres behind a school bus when the upper red lights begin to flash, and do not proceed until the "stop sign" is closed and the red lights stop flashing.<BR>Motorists travelling in both directions must stop for the school bus, except if the road is divided by a median. <BR>• Scan under parked cars for the feet of children approaching traffic, and make lane changes early to allow room for children on bicycles, skateboards or roller blades.<BR></P>
