Title: 9-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Reading, writing and road safety  Parents, drivers reminded to watch out for smaller foot traffic as school starts
NEWS_ITM_SRC_TXT: By Dianne Hamill  The Clipper Weekly, September 13, 2010
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>As students prepare to hit the books, Manitoba Public Insurance is reminding drivers to hit the brakes. </P> <P>According to statistics released this week by MPI, on average 48 children between the ages of five and 14 are injured annually throughout the province in car-pedestrian collisions.</P> <P>That number typically peaks in the fall when children and teens head back to class. Between 2005 and 2009, an average of nine pedestrian-vehicle accidents were reported in September as compared to just two in January.</P> <P>“Many of these pedestrians were hit while going to, or returning from school,” Clif Eden, Manager of Road Safety for MPI said this week. “Manitoba drivers need to focus on making the roads safer and re-familiarizing themselves with safe driving tips as students head back to school.”</P> <P>Drivers are reminded to be on the look out for young children who don’t understand the dangers of crossing the street or who may dart out into traffic from in between parked cars. Older students who often travel in large groups may become distracted while walking to or from school, ignoring the vehicles around them.</P> <P>To avoid a collision, MPI reminds drivers to:<BR>- look well ahead to spot school buses and school zone signs; reduce speed in school zones, and wait for children to cross completely before proceeding<BR>- drop students off in a safe area, away from traffic; use a designated drop-off zone if the school has one<BR>- stop at least five metres behind a school bus when the upper red lights begin to flash, and do not proceed until the “stop sign” is closed and the red lights stop flashing. Motorists traveling in both directions must stop for the school bus, unless the road is divided by a median.<BR>- scan under parked cars for the feet of children approaching traffic<BR>- make lane changes early to allow room for children on bicycles, skateboards or roller blades</P> <P>“The onus of responsibility lies with motorists to ensure everyone gets to school safely,” Eden said.</P> <P>And while traffic volumes in rural areas are typically significantly lower than the city, MPI stresses that road safety is a lesson that everyone should learn.</P> <P>Spokesperson Brian Smiley said parents should take an active role in teaching their kids how to cross the street safely and obey traffic signs and signals – regardless of where they live.</P> <P>“Crossing the street in Beausejour can still get you killed the same as in Winnipeg,” he said.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 10-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: There's safety in the numbers; Police should build innovation and accountability into their operations
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>The policing revolution that made some of America's most dangerous cities safer was built on the idea that police forces should take a lesson from private enterprise, collect data, analyze it and treat citizens as their customers, while measuring and continuously improving their outcomes. Just as successful businesses incorporate new technology and management best practices, so should police build innovation and accountability into their operations. In two Canadian cities, this approach is yielding excellent results. </P> <P>From 2006 until 2008, Winnipeg was the car theft capital of North America. It's a title the city was happy to shed last year, and car thefts are down by more than 80% now from their highest peak. Smart applications of IT and data analysis, combined with an assertive police strategy, are responsible for much of this improvement. From immobilizers in the most commonly stolen models, subsidized by Manitoba Public Insurance, to ankle monitors for known offenders to enforce curfews remotely, technology serves as a force multiplier for the Winnipeg Police Service's fight against car theft, helping them to accomplish more with existing resources. </P> <P>Speeding up communication between various branches of the judicial system is also responsible for better outcomes, explains Inspector Tom Kloczko, a Divisional Commander with the Winnipeg Police Service. "The time between a released offender breaking the conditions of his release and the subsequent rearrest used to take a week," he says, as information travelled slowly from the initial report of a violation to the judge who issued a warrant and the police who carried out the arrest. "Now, we often accomplish this within 12 hours. At the peak of the car theft epidemic, the most active car thieves in Winnipeg stole 50 cars per week." Each stolen car costs about $3,000 to repair, a figure that is dwarfed by the costs to the police and justice system. Stopping a repeat offender at the beginning of a spree means significant savings, as well as safer streets. </P> <P>Better financial outcomes matter, because IT solutions often require a significant investment. Licensing fees, training for staff and ongoing upgrades are all expensive, Inspector Kloczko points out, but the consensus within the WPS is that the benefits outweigh the costs. While veteran officers were sometimes less eager to adopt new technologies than their younger colleagues, it's become an accepted part of policing in the 21st century. </P> <P>Edmonton is another example of smart adoption of new technology. After serving on the force for 35 years, John Warden became in January the Edmonton Police Service's first Manager of the Business Performance Section. </P> <P>"In 2005, the EPS adopted a business intelligence technology platform and a long-term strategy for developing performance analytics. We began by looking at the data around meeting the expectations and demands of our citizens, and aligning our performance to meet our strategic objective of reducing crime and victimization. The first phase was to look at what work we were being asked to do by tracking calls for service and the efficiency and effectiveness of how we deployed our resources to those calls. Then, we asked how well we were meeting these expectations," Mr. Warden explains. Analyzing data on an ongoing basis showed where the Edmonton Police were succeeding, and where -- and sometimes why -- they could do better. </P> <P>Since 2005, the Edmonton Police have consistently reduced crime. Rates for 8 index crimes, used to measure crime in most North American cities, show that, so far, crime in 2010 is down 16.7% from this time last year; their goal was a 4% reduction. Over four years, crime is down 27%. </P> <P>Tracking calls for service, crime incidents and the effectiveness and efficiency of resource deployment in real time helps to identify problems as soon as they emerge. Edmonton's goal is to respond to all top-priority calls anywhere in the city within seven minutes, a goal that is currently met 83% of the time. Recently, one region of the city saw performance fall in this regard, so that only 55% of dispatches arrived by the seven-minute mark. Analysts immediately flagged this trend and determined that bridge and road construction was causing traffic congestion, slowing response times. Extra officers were assigned to the area, and rapid response rates went back up to 80% despite the ongoing construction. </P> <P>There are many potential applications of technology in public safety, including organized crime and drug-related violence, Messrs. Kloczko and Warden agree. East Orange, N.J., is already using real-time reporting of robberies and thefts to predict where the next crime will likely take place, sometimes at the level of a city block, and deploy accordingly. Gunshot sensors and alarms throughout the city, combined with GPS triangulation of all patrol cars and deployment algorithms, mean that police can arrive on the scene within two minutes from the moment a gun was fired or an alarm was triggered. Better policing prevents crime, instead of simply responding to it, and Winnipeg and Edmonton are using analytics, technology and good management to make this happen. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 11-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: CARJACKING AT GUNPOINT IN CITY
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 26-year-old man was robbed of his vehicle at gunpoint while he was using a payphone in downtown Winnipeg on Sunday morning, city police say. </P> <P>Police said the man was on a phone near Colony Street and York Avenue when he was confronted and threatened by a gun-toting male. </P> <P>The male demanded and received the victim's belongings, including the keys to his vehicle. </P> <P>Police said the suspect took off in the man's vehicle, which was recovered in the 500-block of Kylemore Avenue in Fort Rouge on Sunday afternoon. </P> <P>No one has been arrested. </P> <P>Police said the suspect is described as aboriginal, 5-foot-10 and in his early 20s. The major crimes unit is investigating. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 12-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Car stolen at gunpoint in Winnipeg
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 26-year-old man had his car stolen at gunpoint in downtown Winnipeg on Sunday.</P> <P>The man was using a payphone in the area of Memorial Boulevard and York Avenue at about 5 a.m. when he was confronted by a male armed with a gun, police said.</P> <P>The man handed over his car keys to the suspect, who then fled in the vehicle.</P> <P>The investigation is continuing by members of the police service's major crime unit.</P> <P>Read more: <A href="http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/13/mb-car-stolen-gunpoint-winnipeg.html#ixzz0zVZuXiSk">http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2010/09/13/mb-car-stolen-gunpoint-winnipeg.html#ixzz0zVZuXiSk</A><BR></P>

--30--

Title: 13-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Victim 'loved by everyone'
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 16-year-old Winnipeg girl who died of injuries she suffered in a crash earlier this month was looking forward to starting classes at a new high school, friends say. </P> <P>The school year got off to a tragic start without Kirsten Hilderman, seriously injured in a head-on collision north of the city Sept. 1. She died in a Winnipeg hospital on the weekend. </P> <P>Hilderman, a backseat passenger in a car driven by a friend, wasn't wearing a seatbelt. </P> <P>"I think every day what could be different if she had been wearing her seatbelt," said Chris Welter, a backseat passenger who survived. "I think the most important message for people to understand from this incident is that Kirsten was loved by everyone in her life and that your universe can change in an instant." </P> <P>Hilderman, Welter, the 15-year-old female driver and a 22-year-old man, who was in the front passenger seat, were heading to the man's house to go dirtbiking, Welter said. </P> <P>"My memory of the rest of the night was erased when I cracked my skull in the collision," he said. "I still don't know exactly how the crash played out but I know for fact the entire occurrence was all an accident." </P> <P>Friends said Hilderman was well-liked by her peers, interested in local music, and involved in sports such as soccer and softball. </P> <P>"What I'm going to miss most about her is she was just an amazing person and so nice," said friend Haley Bielinski. "She was super outgoing and was friends with everyone. She was just always there to talk to and I'm so glad I had the chance to know her." </P> <P>Hilderman was entering Grade 11 at Garden City Collegiate, Bielinski said. She previously attended Calvin Christian Schools' collegiate campus in Transcona. </P> <P>The crash occurred on a dark and rainy night on Provincial Road 202 in the Rural Municipality of St. Clements, about 10 km north of Winnipeg. </P> <P>Police believe the rain-slicked road was a factor, causing one of the vehicles to cross the centre line on the single-lane highway. </P> <P>Hilderman and her friends were in a 1996 Ford Escort, which collided with an oncoming 2006 Ford F150. </P> <P>Welter said the Escort's teen driver has her learner's licence and the front-seat passenger, acting as a supervising driver, has his full driver's licence. Both are still in hospital. <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 14-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Crash-Insurance
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Manitobans hurt in a motor-vehicle crashes will now get quicker confirmation of coverage and delivery of benefits from Manitoba Public Insurance. </P> <P>Attorney General Andrew Swan says recent changes recognize nurse practitioners, physician assistants and clinical assistants in administering benefits under the Personal Injury Protection Plan. </P> <P>Swan says the changes will benefit Manitobans living in rural and northern regions where these practitioners are the most readily available medical personnel. </P> <P>He also says the changes will likely save Manitobans money in that they won't have to travel to see a physician, but get treatment in their own community. (Wpg F-P) <BR></P>

--30--

Title: 15-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Elderly woman injured in MVA
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A 71 year old woman from Gretna is listed in stable condition at a Winnipeg hospital after a two vehicle collision Tuesday morning at Road 1 - North  (Post Road) and Highway 30.</P> <P>RCMP say a south bound truck collided with an east bound car   and the car came to rest in a ditch..</P> <P>The lone female driver was extricated after firefighters removed the roof of the vehicle.     The 54 year old male driver of the truck  was not injured.  <BR></P> <P>Weather, road conditions or alcohol were not considered to be contributing factors in the accident.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 16-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Sobbing drunk driver admits her guilt ; Victim has had eight surgeries
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>A Winnipeg woman has admitted responsibility for a drunk driving crash that sent a city worker to hospital in critical condition. </P> <P>Joan Ann Henderson, 53, sobbed as she pleaded guilty Wednesday to one count of impaired driving causing bodily harm. </P> <P>Henderson was driving northbound on Main Street shortly before 2 a.m. on April 22, 2008, when she swerved to avoid street cleaners in one lane and hit a city worker, pinning him to his truck. </P> <P>Severe pain </P> <P>Michael Pacheco "said the pain was so severe he put his hands on her hood to relieve the pressure," Crown attorney Kusham Sharma told court. </P> <P>Pacheco, then 27, was taken to hospital in critical condition. </P> <P>"Everybody thought his right leg would have to be amputated," Sharma said. "There was bone sticking out of his right leg and the prognosis was not good." </P> <P>Pacheco, who was present in court Wednesday, has undergone eight surgeries to repair the damages to his legs, with at least one more to come, Sharma said. </P> <P>Henderson had a blood alcohol level of .20, more than double the legal limit for driving. </P> <P>The Crown is seeking an unspecified jail term. </P> <P>Henderson will return to court Jan. 25 for sentencing. </P> <P>She remains free on bail. </P>

--30--

Title: 17-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: MPI boss brings message of stability
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>Marilyn McLaren, the Chief Executive Officer and President of Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) was in The Pas on Tuesday afternoon as part of a visit to northern Manitoba MPI locations. Earlier in the day she had been in Swan River and following her stop in The Pas her agenda was to travel to Flin Flon and then on to Thompson.</P> <P>McLaren was in town as part of a tour of various MPI facilities and to visit with staff all across the province. She said she tries to make the trip at least once a year and that she feels it’s important for staff to hear directly from management and for her to in turn get feedback from staff.</P> <P>McLaren noted some of the changes that have recently taken place with MPI legislation in that three medical practitioner groups-nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and clinical assistants will now be recognized for the purpose of administering benefits under the Personal Injury Protection Plan.</P> <P>This should lead to Manitobans who are injured in a motor vehicle accident receiving quicker confirmation of coverage and delivery of benefits, especially for Manitobans living in rural and northern regions where these practitioners may be the most readily available medical personnel.</P> <P>As Attorney General Andrew Swan recently noted, these new amendments should have no financial impact on the Manitoba government and no overall financial impact on Manitoba Public Insurance. In fact, it is anticipated there will be a net cost savings for Manitobans residing in remote communities since having medical practitioners recognized by MPI in the community will reduce the necessity of some medical travel.</P> <P>McLaren told the Opasquia Times that MPI is currently in the process of an application to the Public Utilities Board which would provide a $92 million rebate to its customers. If approved, this would be the biggest rebate it’s ever given.</P> <P>As well, McLaren said MPI is also applying to the Public Utilities Board and looking for a further four per cent reduction in premiums for its safest drivers. This would come into effect in early December of this year if the application is successful.</P> <P>McLaren added that she while she doesn’t believe Manitobans expect either large increases or decreases with their insurance rates, they do look to MPI for both predictability and stability.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 18-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Impaired driving “shatters” lives in MADD program
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>With stark, realistic footage of a crash, and testimonials from real life victims, MADD Canada’s 2010-2011 School Multi-Media Assembly Program pulls no punches in showing students the risks and tragic outcomes of impaired driving.</P> <P>‘Shattered’ opens with a car racing down the road, recklessly passing traffic. The driver loses control, flipping the car and crashing into a guardrail. Flashing back, the scene shows several high school students on a typical Saturday evening. None of them realize how their actions that night will have life-altering consequences.</P> <P>“We know that young people are significantly over-represented in impaired driving crashes,” said MADD Canada National President Margaret Miller. “With Shattered, we hope to show them that the risks are real. This isn’t just a movie; people are killed and injured in impaired driving crashes every single day because someone makes a dangerous and irresponsible decision.”</P> <P>Delivering that message is critical to reducing the disproportionate toll impaired driving takes on teens and young adults. Motor vehicle crashes are the leading cause of death among 15 to 25 year olds, and alcohol is a factor in 45% of those crashes.</P> <P>The School Multi-Media Assembly Program is part of MADD Canada’s efforts to reduce the number of young people being killed and injured in impaired driving crashes. The program presents students with hard facts about alcohol, drugs and driving, the legal and social ramifications of impaired driving, binge drinking, impairments caused by cannabis (on its own or in combination with alcohol) and the dangers of accepting rides from alcohol or drug impaired drivers.</P> <P>“With our School Multi-Media Assembly Program, we help students understand that impaired driving is entirely preventable and provide them with the knowledge they need to always make safe and sober driving choices, as both drivers and passengers,” Miller said.</P> <P>The program began its cross country tour of high schools Sept. 9 in Toronto. With the support of returning Title Sponsor Allstate Canada, and other sponsors, MADD Canada plans to deliver the program to 1 million students in 2010-2011.</P> <P>“Allstate Canada is proud to continue our long-standing partnership with MADD Canada in an effort we believe helps save lives and improve road safety,” said Chris Kiah, President and Chief Executive Officer of Allstate Canada. “Through impactful programs like Shattered, we hope to encourage youth to develop safe and sober driving habits which will help keep them, and others, safe from the tragic impacts of impaired driving.”</P> <P>Miller thanked Allstate Canada for its continued support, noting that “their generous sponsorship enables us to visit more communities and empower more students with the knowledge and tools they need to prevent impaired driving.”</P> <P>In addition to Allstate Canada, MADD Canada recognizes the following sponsors who have made leading contributions to support the 2010-2011 School High Multi-Media Assembly Program: General Motors of Canada, CN, Alberta Culture and Community Spirit, LCBO, Manitoba Public Insurance, NB Liquor, Newfoundland and Labrador Liquor Corporation, Nova Scotia Liquor Corporation, Saskatchewan Liquor and Gaming Authority, Saskatchewan Government Insurance and Discount Car and Truck Rentals Ltd.</P> <P>Sobering Facts:<BR>• Young people have the highest rates of traffic death and injury per capita among all age groups and the highest death rate per kilometre driven among all drivers under 75 years of age.<BR>• 16 - 19 year olds are more than 15 times more likely to die per kilometre driven than their parents, and 20-24 year olds are at more than 9 times the risk of their parents.<BR>• In 2004, traffic crashes killed 695 young people; it is conservatively estimated the 45% of these deaths were alcohol related.<BR>• 16-25 year olds constituted 13.7% of the Canadian population in 2003 but they accounted for 32.1% of all alcohol-related traffic deaths.<BR>• Young people have high rates of driving after drinking and of being a passenger of a driver who has been drinking or takingdrugs.</P> <P>About MADD Canada<BR>MADD Canada (Mothers Against Drunk Driving) is a national, charitable organization that is committed to stopping impaired driving and supporting the victims of this violent crime. With volunteer-driven groups in more than 100 communities across Canada, MADD Canada aims to offer support services to victims, heighten awareness of the dangers of impaired driving and save lives and prevent injuries on our roads.<BR></P>

--30--

Title: 19-Mar-15
NEWS_ITM_HDLN_TXT: Cutlass above
NEWS_ITM_TXT:
<P>While the early1980s didn't produce much in the way of mid-size, rear- drive performance vehicles, it did produce some very nice coupes that would deliver both ride and handling. High gasoline prices, increased emission regulations and safety mandates had auto manufacturers looking in a different direction to please buyers and even with styling still on the back burner, comfort was something that never went out of style. </P> <P>Today, many of those cars are long gone as people moved on to a new technology that included fuel injection, independent suspension and overdrive transmissions, yet some people managed to hang on and make something unique out of them. </P> <P>Lightweight and sturdily built, the G-body intermediates are a great platform to build everything from a mild street cruiser to a full-out drag car. Body parts and suspension upgrades are available and the engine bay will accommodate nearly every engine and transmission combination in the General Motors parts bin. </P> <P>For Ross Moore of Winnipeg, a 1990 collision had wiped out his Ford Taurus and he needed a replacement vehicle. Down the block from his house, a neighbour was selling a 1983 Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme Brougham coupe. The one-owner car had low mileage and was priced right, so Moore drove it home. Filled with optional equipment and a thrifty 3.8-litre V6 engine it was a great economical driver. Six days after purchasing the car, a hailstorm ripped through the city and after assessing the damage, Manitoba Public Insurance wrote the Cutlass off. Not ready to lose two vehicles in as many weeks, Moore bought the Cutlass back from Autopac and drove it for several years. Later, as a retirement gift to himself, the Olds was destined for a full makeover into a potent street cruiser. </P> <P>After many years on the road, the Cutlass had some rust issues and Moore felt the only way to deal with that was to cut it out and replace the rusted areas with new panels from Rondex Limited. New floor pans, a trunk pan, rear quarter panels and lower door skins were installed. Moore then painted the entire underneath of the body with POR-15 rust-inhibiting paint then followed it up with brush-on undercoating. The Landau vinyl top was stripped off as was the side trim, wheelwell and hood mouldings. Following the bodywork, a new coat of dark green metallic paint was applied. The look clearly says less is more and bears a close resemblance to the trim level of the Buick Grand National cars. </P> <P>The chassis was completely rebuilt with new suspension, steering and braking components. New 15-inch Oldsmobile Rally wheels were installed with B.F. Goodrich T/A radial tires. Inside, Moore kept the original green velour split bench front seat and installed a tinted glass sunroof. To keep an eye on things under the hood, an AutoGage tachometer and gauge package was installed. For a powertrain upgrade, the V6 was definitely out and a V8 would take its place in the engine bay. Moore toyed with the idea of using an older small-block V8 he'd acquired but kept his options open. </P> <P>While scouting out some body-trim parts at River City Auto, Moore's son, Dave, saw a wrecked 1987 Trans Am. Moore says, "The car was wrecked but the L98 engine and transmission were untouched in the crash, so I bought it for the Cutlass." The L98 was an option in the Trans Am and is the same 5.7-litre engine as was used in the Corvette. The L98 is a tuned-port fuel-injected engine that is mated to a 700R4 four-speed overdrive automatic transmission and makes a reliable combination that produces a good deal of power with little tuning required. </P> <P>Before installing it in the car, Moore took the transmission to Mr. Transmission, where it was completely rebuilt and fitted with Corvette servos and a mild shift kit. For the engine, he went to see Glen Miller at Competition Engine, where they performed a full-performance rebuild that included high- compression pistons, a performance camshaft, Helix power tower throttle body spacer and MSD ignition system. </P> <P>Moore slipped the engine into the chassis and installed an aluminum radiator with dual electric fans to keep engine heat down and a set of Headman ceramic- coated exhaust headers leading to a 2.5-inch diameter custom dual-exhaust system with Flowmaster 40-series Delta-Flow mufflers to take care of the spent gases. In back, a new fuel tank with the proper pickup to match the new engine was installed and he also installed a special cross-member to support the transmission. The G-Force racing cross-member is a heavy-duty unit designed to mount the 700R4 automatic into the G-body cars. It also has the two clearance notches required to mount the large-diameter dual exhaust pipes, something lacking in the factory units. </P> <P>The car then went to Wally Dyck at Sturgeon Creek Garage where they installed a new Painless wiring kit, 10-bolt 3.73:1 ratio limited-slip rear differential, custom driveshaft and modified the column shift linkage to operate the new automatic overdrive transmission. </P> <P>Since the car was completed in 2002 Moore, has put on about 8,000 trouble- free kilometres attending local shows and cruise nights. Equipped with power steering, power front disc brakes, tilt wheel, cruise control, power windows, power door locks, an AM/FM cassette stereo, tinted glass and rear window defroster it's still a very pleasant-riding, reliable car with just the right blend of power and street presence. <BR></P>

--30--
